name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the question with a request for an oral reply to the Commission on minimum income schemes in the European Union by Thomas Händel, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000087/2016 - B8-0710/2016) (2016/2676(RSP).

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. One of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of people at risk of poverty and at risk of social exclusion by 20 million. We are miles away from that. At present, more than 120 million Europeans are at risk of poverty and social exclusion, partly due to long-term unemployment, low wages and the erosion of social security systems. I would add that the methods of social dumping, as we decided yesterday, also lead to these results. This particularly affects the people of the countries most affected by the crisis, but not only. Major cities in Central Europe, such as London, also have up to 27% of people at risk of poverty and poor. In his inaugural speech in 2014, Jean-Claude Juncker pointed out that in future a decent income for all Europeans must be ensured. We must remember that. In an interview in May 2014, Juncker said – and this is particularly important in this House: "I firmly believe in the future of the European social model, whose origin and future remains the social market economy." He went on to say: "The core of this model is the primacy of people over the economy, but also the primacy of labour over capital." He continued: "This almost inevitably gives rise to my idea of minimum social bases in Europe. In concrete terms, I am also referring to a statutory minimum wage, the amount of which is, however, determined in the country concerned and not in Brussels. I also mean," says Jean-Claude Juncker, "a basic income, so that no one in Europe has to take to the streets or even starve. Especially when it comes to the social model, we have a model function for the world as well." What is clear is that it is employment – and I would add good work – that contributes significantly to overcoming poverty. But rules on the minimum wage can serve as key tools when it comes to safeguarding social security and increasing equal opportunities. In its resolutions of 20 October 2010 and, most recently, yesterday, the European Parliament stressed that an adequate minimum income should be at least 60% of the average wage of each Member State. This would cover the basic cost of living while maintaining a high level of aggregate demand, economic recovery and social convergence. However, the Commission's strategy on how to achieve this remains completely unclear. Yesterday's speech did not shed much light on this either. The Commission could support this approach in order to ensure that Member States implement an adequate and easily accessible minimum income in line with their national practices. With regard to Article 9 and Article 153(1) (h) and (j) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 34 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs therefore asked the following questions: firstly, how does the Commission define the concept of 'reasonable income' and what is it characterised by? Secondly, when will the Commission examine the rules on minimum income in the EU and promote a comparison of performance and the exchange of best practices, as called for in Parliament's resolution of 14 April 2016? What programmes could help Member States manage? Thirdly, what measures will the Commission take with regard to a minimum income in order to follow up its recommendations? Fourthly, how will the Commission ensure that the financial resources made available for the guaranteed minimum income are not used to replace other social benefits in the countries subject to fiscal adjustment programmes? Fifthly, how will the Commission support the Member States in preventing people from being dependent on minimum incomes in the long term? We are asking you for an answer to these questions today, Commissioner.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Chair of the Employment Committee and the Members of the Employment Committee for this oral question and I will answer in order of the list of the questions that you raised. Firstly, let me tell you that there is growing evidence that high and rising inequality hampers both economic and social progress and fuels public mistrust. Well-designed income support schemes can contribute to fight poverty and increase labour market participation, and adequate income support should be high enough for a decent living and, at the same time, should not create disincentives to work or create dependency. Adequacy of income support is only one aspect of the overall policy design. Coverage, take-up, link to activation and access to services are equally crucial. The draft outline of the European pillar of social rights sets out principles to guarantee that adequate minimum income benefits shall be assured for those who lack sufficient resources for a decent standard of living. For those of working age, these benefits shall include requirements for participation and active support to encourage labour market reintegration. This builds on the 2008 Commission’s recommendation on active inclusion. This recommendation sets out common principles and practical guidelines for a comprehensive strategy based on three integrated pillars: adequate income support, inclusive labour markets and access to quality services. The 2013 Social investment package proposed to develop reference budgets as a way of assessing the adequacy of income support. They define poverty thresholds on the basis of a basket of goods and services that are considered necessary to reach an acceptable standard of living within a given country, region or city. They also show the link with the provision of adequate social services and the redistributive role of these services. As such, they can act as catalysts for policy debates on the adequacy of income support, especially in Member States with challenges in the field. On the assessment of minimum income schemes in the EU and promoting benchmarking, best practices and providing administrative support to Member States and the measures taken regarding minimum income as a follow up to the 2008 recommendation on active inclusion, I can tell you the following. First of all, the Commission monitors and assesses Member States’ progress in implementing the 2008 recommendation, including in the area of minimum income within the European semester. In 2016, six Member States received country-specific recommendations on improving the adequacy and coverage of minimum income or social assistance. These recommendations emerge from the assessment of minimum income schemes in the European Union, through the open method of coordination. As you know, social policies and the designing of the social protection systems are a Member State competence and the open method of coordination provides a forum for mutual learning and exchange of good practices on enhancing the effectiveness of social protection systems across the Union. Peer reviews, mutual learning and exchange of good practices on minimum income schemes took place in the past and will continue. In 2017, the Commission will report on the implementation of the 2008 active inclusion recommendation, and this will contain lessons learned and guidance for the future. The Commission has also been funding the European minimum income network, and is elaborating a methodology for developing cross nationally comparable reference budgets in Member States. This will serve as a means of helping Member States to design efficient and adequate income support. You next question is on ensuring that in countries under financial adjustment programmes, funding for guaranteed minimum income schemes do not substitute other welfare provisions. Contributory-based welfare provisions are, and should remain, the first line of protection. This means that the minimum income should not replace welfare programs, but should enhance existing approaches and complement existing measures in the labour market and social fields. There is currently only one country, as you know, one Member State under the financial adjustment program, and we are working together with the Greek authorities to enhance the effectiveness of the welfare system. The main objectives of the Greek programme are the expansion of employment support schemes, the modernisation of social welfare and the roll-out of a guaranteed minimum income scheme. The funding of the new guaranteed minimum income scheme will not be at the expense of contributory-based social welfare provisions. Lastly, on helping Member States providing opportunities to prevent long-term dependency on minimum income, I can tell you that the Commission has been encouraging Member States to better integrate social safety nets and activation measures, not only to bring the unemployed back into jobs but also to keep people in employment. A recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market was adopted in 2015, you know this. The long-term unemployed should benefit from an individualised approach, simplified access and more transparent support, in particular through job integration agreements and a single point of contact. We are also working to support the Member States in improving work-life balance, including through care facilities, leave and flexible working time arrangements, as well as tax and benefit systems free of disincentives for second earners.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. On behalf of the European People's Party, I strongly support the question put by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, as explained by our Chairman Handel. I would like to begin by saying that, fortunately, the Commission has already been active on this issue, is and should continue to act consistently towards the Member States. That is the implementation of the legitimate demand that each Member State of the European Union must regulate the minimum income. However, it is not sufficient to avoid slipping into poverty and social exclusion. What is also needed are active approaches that make re-entry and entry into work attractive, and a process that makes lifelong learning mandatory in order to prevent inadequate vocational training and thus promote a way out of long-term unemployment. I am convinced that all investments in supporting jobseekers in Europe are well-invested money. The issue of minimum income must be dealt with comprehensively. I would also like to draw attention to the pension situation in Europe. What is striking is that 20% of people in retirement in Europe live in poverty due to the lack of minimum pension regulations. This is particularly true for women. Here, too, the Commission's pressure is absolutely useful, not least because of the recommendations of the European Semester. And I would like to call, in principle, on the Commission and also on you, Commissioner, to use the recommendations of the European Semester not only as a recommendation, but also as a hard instrument.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, thank you very much, Commissioner. Yesterday we all attended the state of the Union debate, and I think, from my point of view, we also expected a more social content. It is true that we have been accumulating for more than eight years of economic crisis, which has caused Europe to bring more than 120 million people at risk of social exclusion to the maples today. In Spain, for example, 720 000 families live without any income, as they have been given all kinds of public aid. And I don't know if it's a systemic failure, I don't know if it's a problem in our economy, or it's a problem that should concern all of us, moreover, morally and socially. We are asking the Commissioner to lead a European initiative to create a minimum income system at Community level; to help Member States find a solution precisely for so many people who expect more from the European Union than fiscal consolidation speeches; who also expect social cohesion speeches and initiatives to help exclude poverty from our continent. The euro area, the European Union, remains, with the United States, the most important economic zone in the world, and we have to ask ourselves whether that is compatible with 120 million people, as I say, at risk of social exclusion, without any public assistance. The European Union must also represent a sense of hope. The European social model must be compatible with a fair exit from the crisis, and for that I ask not only for speeches, not only complaints, not only complacency, but also an initiative that will finally give a little hope to millions of citizens through the European Union as a whole. If you take the initiative, there is no doubt that the Socialist Group will support you in bringing it forward.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Since a considerable majority in this House and under the umbrella of the European Commission seems to agree that we are dealing with the continuing EU scepticism with social coercion from Brussels, without respecting the competence of the nation states, we are once again dealing with the minimum income. Let me be quite frank: I am still convinced that this decision belongs in national hands. I am also convinced that it would be as effective at European level as yesterday's EPP air number of an Interrail ticket for all. If that's not a mistake! But good, we are discussing. That is why My question is this: you are justifying a European minimum income by reducing the number of people at risk of poverty and at risk of social exclusion by 20 million. Why do you not take into account the role of parents, families with children, large families in the debates? You almost always have a parent who works beyond all maximum working hours and beyond any minimum wage for his children and thus for our society. Do you not think that a minimum income, a parental salary, is at least as appropriate here, especially with regard to the prevention of poverty, child poverty?

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President. Good morning, again, Commissioner, and thank you very much for coming to answer this question. Look, the minimum income thing is not an economic measure, it is a social measure — it is not an employment measure either — and it is very important, because it corresponds to the social model and the kind of democracy — for us liberals — that European society wants and on which the Union is based, which wants coherence and convergence and which, above all, , wants there to be no marginalized people in one of the richest areas of the world. One of the instruments to combat this — and the Commission has already talked about this – is minimum income, basic income. There are several models and, above all, it is true that it must adapt to the reality of each country, its economic situation, its culture, its economic, industrial, business fabric, etc. But the fundamental principle and fundamental norms can perfectly come, they must perfectly come from an integrated Europe and from a Europe that believes in a solidarity citizenship and a citizenship that expects from it a social pillar, as well as an economic reality. That is why the Commission needs to start implementing a fundamental issue, which is to study minimum income systems, to see their involvement, to see how each nation needs to be adapted through benchmarking, to see also its effectiveness in combating inequalities. It needs to start producing initiatives and roles and, in the end, also address the conjunctural funding needs of countries with serious financial soundness problems that they cannot meet. We expect the Commission for proactivity to tell European citizens.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the Committee on Employment has promoted this debate on minimum income because, with 120 million poor people, that is, with one in four Europeans who cannot meet their basic needs, we have no more time to waste. Juncker pledged in his investiture to ensure adequate income, but so far the Commission's proposals have failed in this objective. Calls to streamline existing minimum income mechanisms or convert them into instruments of active inclusion transform a fundamental right into mechanisms with which to subsidize low wages and reduce coverage of social benefits, rather than guaranteeing a dignified life. We must choose another path. The European Parliament has repeated time and time again that each country must universally secure an income above the poverty line. It is in your hands to legislate in favour of a Minimum Income Framework Directive, as the trade unions, the European Economic and Social Committee, different NGOs and today also this Parliament, have been calling for and providing the resources for its implementation. How much longer are we going to take to act?

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, tackling the problem of the growing risk of poverty and social exclusion for millions of people in the EU is one of the political priorities of the Green/EFA Group. The position of Parliament itself in this respect has been clearly shown this week when we voted on the report by Vilija Blinkevičiūtė and myself, as well as the report by Guillaume Balas – a call to combat social and economic inequalities, promote measures aiming to put in place adequate minimum income schemes, to avoid excessive wage disparities and to underpin social convergence. The minimum income in my country, Latvia, is five times smaller than in Luxembourg and four times smaller than in Great Britain. At the same time, it is 45% of the national average wage and the Gini co-efficient in Latvia is much higher than the EU—wide one. How can we talk about social cohesion when we have such disparities? How is it possible to stop the outflow of labour to the west in such a situation? The disparity between poor and rich in the Member States, and between poor and rich people within one state, must be eliminated.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Article 1 of the Italian Constitution states that the Italian Republic is based on work. Our founding fathers are also the founding fathers of the European Union, which was a Community when it was born, but today the liberal policies perpetrated for years by this European Union have led to the complete eradication of our welfare state. We have prevented labour rights and we have reduced 120 million European citizens to poverty.  What is needed now is a measure to combat absolute poverty in which millions of European citizens live through a minimum income that is guaranteed at European level, because the Member States cannot receive recommendations for which they must implement a minimum income within their reality if budgetary constraints, the fiscal compact and the duty to repay debt actually prevent this necessary structural measure from being implemented.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, once again we are completely out of step with reality, first of all because social protection is an eminently regal area and it must remain so. Talking about non-work minimum income - we agree that this is not a minimum wage - is a real failure of the socio-economic policies of some States, but especially of Europe. I would remind you that the euro area has unemployment two points higher than the rest of Europe. It is therefore a treatment of the consequences, not the causes. This is dramatic for two reasons, given first of all the level of the current crisis, since we see that it is poverty and exclusion that are weighing on growth and on the future of social protection, which is obviously an absolute problem in terms of the sustainability of social protection systems, but especially at the very moment when we are approaching a new era. , digital technology, robotics and the loss of human jobs. The question at the Commission is simple: when do you finally intend to take up a job? When do you intend to release the energies, those of entrepreneurs and those of all those who want to embark on the adventure?

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When will we finally be guided by the fact that we make a minimum income dependent not on the profit of companies, but solely on human dignity? This is a political demand, a political will, which we must explain very clearly here, namely that it cannot be the case that a person must vegetate for a lifetime on the edge of the poverty line, sometimes have to do two or three jobs in order to feed his family at all, and when he then enters retirement age, he is driven into old-age poverty because the pension is not enough. , and will continue to be dependent on social levies.  Human dignity is inviolable – as is often said in this House. Then please send out a signal and at least make the political demand that in future the focus will no longer be on the profit of companies, but on human dignity in determining income.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Ladies and gentlemen, Mr Voigt, I would like to thank mr Voigt for his work and for the work he has said. It strikes me that you speak very frequently in this Chamber this week, when we have many social issues. I would like to ask why you are not so actively involved in where the work is being done, namely in committee? Why do you not bring in many amendments when you are talking as well as we can do better? Here, where it is broadcast on television, where you can perhaps present it beautifully for your constituents, it is of course understandable, but do the work in committee!

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. That was a very polemical question. because you know that, as a non-attached member, I can only work in one committee. I am already a part of the Migration Committee. And it is a question of making a difference in this committee. You say: why do you not make applications? Because I cannot make any requests. I would also like to make more requests here in Parliament. I do what I can do. I am speaking here for my people, for the working class here in Europe, and that is what I am campaigning for.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The crisis has shown how different the economic performance is in the Member States. The principle of subsidiarity is a logical consequence. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats are at least critical of how we want to introduce a uniform minimum income throughout Europe.  The definition of an adequate minimum income shows the diversity of national practices. In Germany, for example, various regulations must be included – from basic security to unemployment benefits, social assistance, subsistence minimum, basic allowance to the minimum wage. Who is surprised if we are sceptical about the demand that the Commission should adopt an EU-standard isused? Each basic income must be based on a variety of factors. Let us leave the national level and, above all, the social partners, the necessary margins for the benefit of the most needy citizens.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the For information only, for those who do not know, the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides for the European Union to support the activities of the Member States in ensuring social and adequate social protection. In other words, we are very much responsible, and it is good that European initiatives are also driving the Member States to develop further in this area. I am glad that the committee has agreed on this oral question, because minimum income is not social romanticism. The rapporteur has already described the situation in Europe; I do not need to repeat this. It is an answer to urgent social questions. We are constantly discussing how we can eradicate poverty in Europe. Europe has set itself high targets for poverty reduction, and people are desperately awaiting answers. We need to move forward. We need more than recommendations; we need a binding timetable, we need concrete measures. And we really need to define what a decent income is. Minimum income is a key instrument for ensuring social security and greater equality of opportunity in Europe.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – When the European Union expanded to the east a decade ago, it generated great enthusiasm in the peoples of Eastern Europe. We believed that, together with the European Union, the area of freedom and prosperity would also be extended. However, the global economic crisis undermined our belief that new members will also be able to achieve a level of Western prosperity in the near future. But despite this, we made an effort, we cut back, we suffered to meet the high european criteria and keep the budget balanced. In the hope that sooner or later we'll catch up. All you have to do is live through the hard times.  Life reaffirmed that the patience of Eastern Europeans, which we have achieved thanks to difficult historical events, is far from specific to all members of the European family. And today, in order to strengthen our Union in order to counter radicalism in order to minimise the damage caused by Brexit, we need to develop common social standards.  An ambitious European project lacks a social dimension. We need to find a common formula, a common understanding of what an adequate income is, and to set a common standard for minimum income. We need solidarity not only in foreign policy, but also in the fight against terror, in the fight against poverty and the beggars that threaten our Union every day.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the concept of minimum income, in this context of profound economic and social crisis, needs to deepen the reflection on its objectives and its implementation, which integrates the reality of each country. Only in this way will it be possible to define a value that actually ensures minimum conditions of dignity for those who are victims of poverty and long-term unemployment.  Today it is questionable whether 60 % of the median income, thanks to the crushing of workers' wages, meets that goal. This concept will not address very serious social problems, which are not solved with palliatives, but with the reversal of the Economic and Social Policies of the European Union and which will be aggravated if its objective is perverted, but rather serves to accentuate exploitation through the attribution of the provision of work, an explicit way of creating cheap labour. Combating inequalities and poverty will only be possible with economic and social development policies that value wages, work with rights and a balanced distribution of wealth.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, growth will not return and the unemployment curve will not recover any time soon. So what do we do? Should we sit idly by? No! With a basic income, we could finally think of post-growth society rather than expect it as godot expects. The technological revolution will destroy thousands of jobs. Look at the autonomous car, look at the drones, ask the taxi drivers, also Uber, who will scream because their jobs are threatened. So what do we do? Should we sit idly by? No! We have to prepare the world for tomorrow. There are also thousands of people who do not receive their social assistance because they do not know they are entitled to it. With an unconditional basic income, on the one hand we no longer waste public money, on the other hand the people who really need it are really helped. With basic income, this is a way to lift people out of poverty, from stigma. Above all, it is the way for each of us to finally have a dignified life and to choose our lives. By the way, basic income is not a cost, it is an investment in our collective happiness. Let's get to the concrete, let's work so that a basic income is really put on the test bench, especially in several of the European regions in order to get out of it grown and that this Europe grows.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Mr President, this is just another example of how the EU is stealing sovereignty. You are creating an EU army, you have stolen Ireland’s taxation policy and now you are taking control of the wage and welfare policy from nation-states. The EU is now an empire in every respect. You are overruling national sovereignty everywhere. I must now demand that Ms May, the UK Prime Minister, immediately evokes Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty and get us out of this terrible mess before it is too late.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Mr President, reducing the number of people at risk of poverty or exclusion by 20 million is an important challenge for the European Union. Unfortunately, let's face it, we're a long way off. The fight against poverty is not simple. There are many factors that need to be taken into account in order to combat it, and the minimum income is one of them. But in order to define effective and efficient policies, we need to give a clear definition at the community level to this minimum income. Today, this concept in the debate is as much about social security, social protection, universal allowance as well as social assistance. We need to be much clearer in order to have policies that are efficient. If we also want this issue to lead to concrete action, we must take into account the socio-economic realities of each country. Finally, I stress that this issue cannot be dealt with without the involvement, the participation of the social partners. More than ever, we need a strong social dialogue in Europe. The issue of minimum income must be part of this social dialogue.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, the increase in the number of people living in poverty and social exclusion in Europe by 4.8 million demonstrates that a decisive and urgent policy shift is necessary. The Commission should at long last adopt the definition of a minimum income as at least equal to the risk-of-poverty threshold, which is set at 60% of the national median equalised disposable income. Regrettably, the country-specific recommendations continue to be dominated by austerity. In Bulgaria more than 40% of the population is at risk of poverty and social exclusion. So it is hypocritical for the Commission simply to recommend modifications of the existing minimum income scheme, which carries a guaranteed minimum of EUR 35 per month and a differentiated amount of just EUR 60. It is therefore high time that the Commission went beyond recommendations and spelled out a sound and reliable mechanism for setting the minimum income in the EU.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, this last decade of crisis and austerity will go down in history through political and financial negligence, which brought us unsustainable rates of poverty and inequality, which mean that today 120 million Europeans live at risk of social exclusion. A decent, adequate and accessible minimum income scheme in the European Union is a political priority that brings autonomy and freedom, but can also help boost innovation and the development of talent typical of an environment free of uncertainty and free of precariousness. And it would also help to boost and regenerate those economies where most citizens do not even have the capacity to consume; where it is impossible for the economy to revive, regenerate and recover if citizens do not have the capacity to consume. But it's also possible. It's just a matter of priorities. With the losses of the Spanish state , which I give you as an example – in banking aid, a guaranteed income could be paid in duplicate for eight million people. We must sign a new social contract that puts people first in front of banks, in the face of all these priorities that set austerity policies.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In today's debate, we are discussing a number of issues that are worth distinguishing from each other and highlighting their different meanings. This work is a source of funding for the minimum wage, while the minimum guaranteed income is financed by public funds. In practice, the financing of the minimum guaranteed income can only come from the specific work of citizens and not from politicians promising a guaranteed income. In fact, therefore, working citizens who pay taxes pay for everything, the state does not have its own resources. A responsible social policy must not induce the state despite its attractiveness in social perception. Responsible social policy encourages work and activates rather than teaches fidelity and dependency.  In the context of the minimum wage, it is right to fight to ensure that work is not exploited and that working people are far from the poverty line. It is therefore important to promote the highest possible minimum wage so that it fulfils its role of safeguarding against poverty without the risk of an increase in the grey or black economy. It is therefore important in this respect to track the percentage of workers receiving the minimum wage in relation to the total number of employees and to analyse the number of people working in systems not covered by the minimum wage. After all, it is sufficient to sign a different type of contract than an employment contract or to encourage the worker to self-employment in order to circumvent the requirements of a fair, fair and decent minimum wage.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Very wise ly, but at the same time there is a certain confusion of concepts that I think needs to be sorted out. Minimum income is not the same as minimum wages. Minimum income is decided by political assemblies. Minimum wages are negotiated between the social partners.  In the years of crisis, we have done little at European level to strengthen trade union rights. Rather, we have legislation, and perhaps above all judgments, which undermine the ability of trade unions to act. We say a lot, but we act very little. The ILO says the following: Collective bargaining is a key means through which employers and their organizations and trade unions can establish fair wages. In the context of the economic crisis, we have seen how countries in Europe have restricted trade union rights. At the same time, therefore, Eurofound says that the countries that are coping with the crisis best for each individual citizen are the countries that are able to assert trade union rights as well. It is the way to welfare and wages.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, between 2013 and 2014, the number of people at risk of social exclusion fell by 0.1%, a drop in the bucket compared to the five million more poor people that Europe has recorded since 2010. However, the fight against precariousness must be our priority for everyone, whether at national or European level, and I know your mobilization, Commissioner. For me, the way out of poverty is through dignified and remunerative work. The minimum income decided in the Member States according to their specificities is, as such, an indispensable safety net, but it must be a net which does not imprison in dependency and which, on the contrary, allows to rebound, as after a fall, to re-enter the labour market. Yes, we need an in-depth analysis of the European mechanisms to combat poverty.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European In the context of minimum income, new issues arise, in particular in the areas of competitiveness, the motivation of workers and a sustainable budget. Can there be a single minimum income fixed in advance in each Member State, which does not create internal migratory pressures?  In the case of EU States, where this possibility exists, how can the principle of internal free movement be ensured? Has the Commission examined cases where the introduction of a minimum income has reduced the motivating effect of competitiveness and performance? My final question would be that, according to research carried out in the United States, the introduction of basic income in the US alone would simply consume most of the federal budget. In the meantime, we need further tax increases. Have its consequences been investigated at EU level?

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is right that we are discussing this issue here in the European Parliament. However, I am with the many colleagues who say that we are perhaps in the wrong place here in terms of competence, because we must put pressure on the Member States to take care of them, and not just try to regulate that of Brussels.  I have two problems with this issue. The first is that I am firmly convinced that a minimum income, or an income in general, must be based on a company's productivity. There is no point in us setting income from politics and companies not being able to pay those incomes; then they will not hire any employees or even sack them. The second is that if the state cannot do this and has to pay high incomes, then it will take on debt if it does not have the tax revenues – that is the problem.  And the second problem I have is: how do you define that? Many colleagues have already said this. When I look at Germany, how do you define a minimum income? What does this mean? What is the basis? Is this the minimum wage, are these payments such as housing and child benefit, and and?  I could list many more issues; a very difficult subject – but it is good that we are at least discussing it here.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: Mr President, the issue of minimum income cannot be treated lightly.  We are debating people's lives, their dignity, and we can do it in a small or ambitious way. To solve the problems of poverty, I advocate much more than a minimum income.  In my country, Portugal, we have a social income of insertion, but do not delude themselves with altruism of expression, because in Portugal we have only made a change in the definition, because we just give a subsidy to people.  I advocate much more than an income, I advocate a social inclusion programme that, in addition to minimum income, guarantees the poorest that they may have social aspirations. The children of needy families can also be doctors, teachers and lawyers, whatever they want.  True social mobility requires the articulation of an income with parental monitoring, lifelong learning and child education programmes. A minimum income is not enough, we need a mechanism of independence and social accountability.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – I welcome, of course, this question... (the microphone was switched off for a few moments). It is right that we start talking about this very intensively and dealing more with financial topics as well as on social topics. A man's decent life is not possible if someone doesn't have enough income to survive. However, in all this, we must also bear in mind in our discussions that ensuring a minimum income is a burden, it can be a burden on the state or a burden on the company.  However, countries are developed differently, have different economic power, so it is particularly important for them to be treated individually and, of course, to allow this to be our rule of subsidiarity. At the same time, it is also important that the ratio between minimum income and minimum wage is appropriate.  The minimum income, however, can only be a temporary instrument that cannot replace the need for more good jobs with decent pay for work.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Mr President, if I consider the determination of a national minimum income as a social step forward, I have great reservations about a European minimum income which would be based on uniform criteria. In my opinion, imposing a common base or even a common range is only a gentle utopia, totally disconnected from local realities, because when a minimum income is introduced, it must also take into account its perverse effects on the economy and on the labour market, such as the levelling of wages from below that it could induce. These consequences can only be effectively studied and understood at the national level. Not all our respective states have the same inflation, labour law, taxation, housing costs or the same cost of access to education. It would therefore not be coherent to impose a macroeconomic view of income, whereas, at the same time, we were yesterday in this Chamber advocating in this House, in the debate on the guidelines for employment policies, in favour of the establishment of regional policies. The protection of Europeans is paramount. It would be a serious mistake, however, to oppose growth and economic development or, worse, to play sorcerer's apprentices.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, a decent income is a basic prerequisite for a decent life. Employment can be key in finding a way out of poverty, but it is important to have a minimum income sufficient to help people meet basic needs.  The latest figures show that one in five citizens are poor in Croatia, while one in three live at risk of poverty. The net minimum wage level in Croatia is EUR 337, which is not enough for a dignified life. The most vulnerable group are women who are employed in shops, who work for three weeks at a time without interruption and without a single day off a week. Almost 93 000 citizens of the Republic of Croatia receive a pension below EUR 70, with which it is almost art to survive. The poverty threshold in Croatia is 270 EUR, and more than 555 000 pensioners in Croatia have a pension below the poverty threshold and live on the verge of existence. I therefore consider it necessary for the Commission to encourage Member States to introduce a minimum national pension and a minimum income that will protect citizens from poverty.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, from the outset I want to say that I support the rapporteur's question. At the same time, I appreciate your trenchant response. That's right: who couldn't argue that we need a minimum income so that citizens don't live in poverty?  Millions of people, as they say here. At the same time, this income must be created and, of course, it is a matter of subsidiarity, but, Commissioner, you must advocate to create economic growth and to be able to make the Member States, which now have very low incomes, Romania, Bulgaria and other countries, be able to have incomes, create income through jobs, through economic growth, through competitiveness otherwise we will not be able to make a uniformity at European level. This equal minimum income will not be given in all countries. And I think we can't talk about this unless you start from social cohesion policies, investments. As I said yesterday, the Strategic Investment Fund has not achieved its goal and must be directed to poor areas so that those people can emerge from poverty.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy to eradicate poverty within the Union, as well as Mr Juncker's statements on the need to provide an adequate income to the Union, seem to have not been achieved, with the result that many Member States of the Union face very high unemployment rates and social impoverishment. As early as 2010, the European Parliament had stressed the need for a minimum guaranteed income covering the basic cost of living of European citizens, and to contribute to the economic development and economic cohesion of the Member States of the Union. However, in countries such as Greece, which is experiencing the troika's harsh austerity measures, the minimum guaranteed income is applied to a very small part of the population, while every day more and more citizens are driven into poverty and poverty. It is therefore clear that poverty and unemployment rates will not be eliminated as long as austerity policies continue to be imposed on the countries of the European South. At the same time, it is necessary that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy be implemented immediately through the implementation of the minimum guaranteed income for most of the population.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Europe needs a framework of clear minimums and guidelines for programmes such as minimum income, which are key to rescuing people from crisis and marginalization. In the Basque Country we know that combining anti-poverty supports with job reintegration results. Basque insertion guarantee income has already reached twenty-five years, today accounts for 44% of the expenditure spent throughout the Spanish State on such programmes and shows that combating marginalization promotes the reintegration of people into the labour market, because it brings stability and dignity to those who are having the worst time. Today we have the lowest unemployment rate in our state and, in the Basque Country, the proportion of people living in households who cannot address extraordinary expenditure is 22%. Only in Sweden is it minor. In the euro area it is 36%; 38% in the European Union of the Twenty-Seven; 42.7% in Spain. That is why this experience has been studied in this Parliament and is considered a good practice by the EMIN network, which is sponsored by the Commission. That is why I ask you, Commissioner, what value they place on the results of such experiences and whether they believe that some of these lessons can be useful in setting targets and functioning of this minimum framework.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the debate we are having this morning on the minimum income is one of the fundamental aspects of the state of the Union: either Europe becomes a social Europe, or the European project is broken.  As early as 20 October 2010, this Parliament has been addressing the issue of minimum income as a measure to combat poverty, I would add as a redistributive measure, as a countercyclical measure, as a measure to escape the blackmail of precariousness. The minimum income does not conflict with the possible definition of a labour standard and a minimum wage.  I believe that today we need a European directive on a minimum income, and the oral question has rightly raised this issue. We need a directive that is beginning to move in the direction of that concrete utopia of a basic and unconditional income, an income of self-determination that recognises the right of all European citizens to exist and the recognition of work and activities, both productive and reproductive. We must change this Europe and the minimum income is a first step in this direction.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Commissioner, I would like to thank you above all for your answer to our question. We agree that it is the responsibility of the Member States to set a minimum income. We also agree that, from the level of the European Union, we can and should help Member States reduce poverty, increase employment and thus also increase individual incomes and increase income convergence across EU countries.  The differences in minimum income across the EU are huge. From thirty, forty thousand euros per year to four thousand euros per year in some areas, such as Bulgaria, France, Spain, but also the Czech Republic. I think we need to try to reduce these huge differences. I support it so that the minimum income helps those who are in a difficult situation, but that it is not a long-term substitute and a reward for work. The income must remain in conjunction with work.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Poverty reduction is one of the five main pillars of the Europe 2020 Strategy for Sustainable Growth. It is also my personal belief that we must do everything we can to reduce poverty. It must be done out of respect for the citizen, because too great inequality is hindering growth, with all its consequences, and because it is fair. We need to make Europe a place where people know how to protect themselves. But Europe, we are all together. These are the various European political institutions and all political levels. David Casa, Jutta Steinruck and others made it clear yesterday: if we want to develop a policy that people feel the result of, then we must do so together. Only then will people see the development of policies that will benefit them in their daily lives. In the answer to the oral questions at the beginning of this debate, I set out what is going on and how the European Commission is using its powers to promote a minimum income in the Member States. You know better than anyone that the European Union has no direct power to legislate in this area. But we are using the tools available and we are encouraging the Member States to do the right and everything possible. In this context, I would like to reiterate the wide-ranging consultation on the European Social Pillar, in which Parliament is very actively participating, for which thanks. The aim of this wide-ranging debate is to develop a new frame of reference that we can use to review and screen the employment and social policies of the Member States and the European Union. In this way, we want to see whether social policy ensures sustainable systems that are financially sustainable and adequate systems that adequately protect people. As you know, in the new semester approach to social protection, we are emphasizing two points: sustainability and adequacy. I hope that this consultation will help to reach a consensus across Europe on the need for more convergence in the European Union, rather than upwards. At the end of the day, we need to come together with all levels a policy where people know that we are leaving no one behind. In the meantime, we in the Commission continue to row with the belts we have. The powers we have are maxims. We are also working on the development of reference budgets, which help Member States to develop the right policies and help us monitor the policies of the Member States. The exchange of good practice is an important part of this. I can assure you that the European Commission will not let go of this issue. But, as one of the esteemed Members of Parliament has said, if we want upward convergence, if we want everyone to have opportunities, then a minimum income alone is not enough. That will depend on our entire policy. Someone has also explicitly said that jobs must also be created, economic development must be achieved that enables growth and jobs. That is exactly what this Commission's policy is aimed at: jobs, growth, investment and security. You heard that again yesterday at the State of the Union. Mr President, this was an interesting debate and I would like to thank you very much for that.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Thank you, Commissioner, for all your interests. I note your point that convergence policies need to be strengthened upwards, not downwards. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – Yesterday, President Juncker came to this House to repeat to us that Europe must be more social, that it must fight inequalities and regain the illusion of citizens in the European project. But those words were not accompanied by any real and tangible measures to alleviate the unrest of the public. Today, more than 120 million Europeans are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. But the problem is even more serious: it is 4.2 million more than in 2008. The economic and social crisis has left millions of households without any income. We Socialists demand that the Commission keep Mr Juncker's promise in his inauguration speech and submit a proposal for a European Minimum Income Framework. Not just because it's legally possible, but because it's the fairest thing. We can't put 120 million people aside. Fiscal consolidation cannot be the EU's only priority. We must regard this serious social crisis as the greatest systemic risk to the EU and the germ of all the populisms that are ending the European project.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Currently, more than EUR 120 million are available. Europeans face poverty for reasons such as long-term unemployment, low wages and weakening social security systems, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis. It is not normal when working people's income is not enough to ensure the dignified life of their families. Economic growth in itself has not reduced poverty and social exclusion, the crisis only exacerbates poverty, and the minimum income allows the protection of the most vulnerable. Minimum income schemes are an important and effective way of overcoming poverty, supporting social integration and access to the labour market and enabling people to live in decent conditions. I would also like to point out that, even at the time of austerity, minimum income schemes should not be seen as a cost-enhancing factor, but as a key tool to combat the crisis, since early anti-poverty investments bring the greatest benefits in reducing long-term societal costs. Thus, in order to meet the commitment to withdraw at least EUR 20 million under the Europe 2020 strategy, the commission will be able to meet its commitment to withdraw the aid. the threat of human poverty or exclusion in the European Union, the Commission must take concrete action and propose solutions that guarantee a minimum income across Europe in the fight against poverty. I would just like to remind you once again that.C President Juncker mentioned in his inaugural address the need to ensure a 'decent income' for all Europeans, but the EU strategy remains unclear. So how does the Commission define 'decent revenue' and what is specific to them?

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – Yesterday President Juncker came to this House to repeat to us that Europe must be more social, that it must fight inequalities and regain the illusion of citizens in the European project. But those words were not accompanied by any real and tangible measures to alleviate the unrest of the public. Today there are more than 120 million Europeans at risk of poverty and social exclusion. But the problem is even more serious: it is 4.2 million more than in 2008. The problem is that the economic and social crisis has left millions of households without any income. We the Socialists therefore call on the Commission to comply with Mr Juncker's promise in his inauguration speech and to submit a proposal for a European Minimum Income Framework. Not just because it's legally possible, but because it's the fairest thing. We can't put 120 million people aside. Fiscal consolidation cannot be the EU's only priority. We must regard this serious social crisis as the greatest systemic risk to the EU and the germ of all the populisms that are putting the European project at risk.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. – Securing the 'appropriate' income level mentioned by Mr Juncker for the majority of the population will be a huge issue in the near future. The number of jobs is declining and wealth is accumulating mainly for the already wealthy. Securing an appropriate level of income is also important in the 5th Amendment tabled by Mr Händel. the issue of long-term dependency caused by minimum income schemes.  In the near future, the Finnish Government will experiment with a so-called basic income, which aims to encourage citizens to push away from support dependency. Basic income is intended to safeguard a certain standard of living for all, to encourage employment and to reduce the bureaucratic burden of social assistance. It may seek, in whole or in part, to replace other social benefits. In Finland, the experiment will affect 2,000 unemployed people who are paid EUR 560 in basic tax-exempt income. The wage income on top of this income does not affect the basic income, which encourages employment even in the short term. Due to its simplicity, the new basic income model can replace subsistence systems and reduce administrative costs.  Current income models may not correspond to the labour market of the 2010s, which is why experiments such as basic income should also be closely monitored at EU level. In addition to the Finnish experiment, switzerland's basic income experiment can also offer fresh perspectives on the renewal of income models.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. – Yesterday President Juncker came to this House to repeat to us that Europe must be more social, that it must fight inequalities and regain the illusion of citizens in the European project. But those words were not accompanied by any real and tangible measures to alleviate the unrest of the public. Today there are more than 120 million Europeans at risk of poverty and social exclusion. But the problem is even more serious: it is 4.2 million more than in 2008. The problem is that the economic and social crisis has left millions of households without any income. We the Socialists therefore call on the Commission to comply with Mr Juncker's promise in his inauguration speech and to submit a proposal for a European Minimum Income Framework. Not just because it's legally possible, but because it's the fairest thing. We can't put 120 million people aside. Fiscal consolidation cannot be the EU's only priority. We must regard this serious social crisis as the greatest systemic risk to the EU and the germ of all the populisms that are ending the European project.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Renate Weber's report, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, implementing Council Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and work ('The Equality in Employment Directive') (2015/2116(INI)) (A8-0225/2016).

name: Renate WEBER
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the shadow rapporteurs not only for their sound and constructive contribution to this report, but mainly for their genuine commitment and work for the protection of human rights and for combating discrimination. In 2000, I was part of a human rights organisation network that advocated for the adoption of anti-discrimination legislation at the EU level. When the two equality directives were adopted we considered it an historical moment, because discriminating against other human beings is one of the most despicable behaviours one could imagine. Sixteen years later, I have the privilege as a Member of this European Parliament to evaluate how the Employment Equality Directive has been implemented. In 2000, a duty was imposed on our Member States to provide protection against discrimination in the areas of employment and occupational and vocational training. It comes as no surprise that, while some Member States have gone beyond its requirement by extending protection against discrimination to other areas, including access to goods and services, others are still pretty far from implementing it at the minimum level. The report highlights the necessity of collecting equality data both at the level of Member States and the European Union in order to make it easier to prove the existence of discrimination and, particularly, indirect discrimination. There is quite a discrepancy between the levels of discrimination experienced and discrimination reported. Awareness-raising, with the help of equality bodies and the social partners, is of utmost importance at all levels of society considering that the victims themselves still have difficulty in recognising discrimination, let alone fighting it. I cannot stress enough the role of equality bodies in awareness-raising and data election in helping the victims but also the employers to understand how to change their policies in line with equality requirements. The impartiality of such bodies must be ensured and their activity supported, including through adequate funding. I particularly want to emphasise the issue of multiple discrimination, which is often a consequence of the existence of fragmented rules and standards across Member States. If it is difficult for the victims of one type of discrimination to understand the situation and act, we can easily imagine their difficulties when they face multiple discrimination. It is important to note that access to justice is still limited in many discrimination cases, and the report strongly recommends that the Member States ensure that victims can obtain accessible legal advice and assistance at all stages of the legal process, including confidential counselling in person by equality bodies or appropriate intermediaries. Legal redress is not only important for the victims, but it also has an educational impact on society because pursuing court cases and ensuring adequate representation are still problematic in some cases. We asked the Member States to find ways to help victims including, for example, by means of court tax exemptions or reductions or legal aid and assistance from specialised NGOs. In fact, it is important to recognise the legal standing of NGOs with a legitimate interest in the relevant judicial or administrative procedures. Sharing good practices among Member States is a must. Acknowledging the importance of fighting all forms of discrimination, I truly hope that this House will adopt this report with a large majority.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Weber, who prepared this comprehensive assessment of the application of the Employment Equality Directive. Discrimination on whatever grounds has no place in the Union. Therefore, the Commission is strongly committed to ensuring that non-discrimination directives are effectively implemented, so as to foster a fairer and more inclusive society, including labour markets providing opportunities to all. The draft outline of the European Pillar of Social Rights specifies that ‘labour market participation of under-represented groups shall be enhanced, ensuring equal treatment in all areas, including by raising awareness and addressing discrimination’. We cannot deny that recent statistics raised certain concerns. According to the 2015 Eurobarometer Survey on discrimination, there is at least a widespread perception of discrimination in the European Union. 64% of the respondents were concerned about discrimination on the grounds of ethnic origin, 58% for sexual orientation, 50% for disability and the same percentage for religious belief. However, we see positive developments. The survey shows, for example, that citizens are increasingly aware of their rights in this area, which is the first critical step in order to improve their enforcement. Our joint implementation report from 2014 on the Race and Employment Equality Directives concluded that they were correctly transposed by Member States. The report also pointed to the necessity of combining existing legislation with appropriate policy action by improving, specifically, awareness of rights, and indeed access to justice. Your report rightly highlights, among others, all these aspects. The Commission is committed to make full use of the Directive on many fronts. Let me mention just a few examples.  Firstly, we promote analysis and research on the situation across Member States through the yearly comparative report on anti-discrimination in Europe referred to in your report; through the report on sexual orientation-based discrimination; through the report on reasonable accommodation for disabled people in the employment context in the European Union; through the report on intersexual discrimination in EU gender-equality and non-discrimination law; and through the ongoing study on equality data collection. We are fully aware that producing these reports is in itself not a solution, but understanding patterns of discrimination is crucial for informed policy-making and enforcement.  Secondly, the High Level Group on Non-discrimination, Equality and Diversity facilitates the exchange of best practices. To improve awareness of rights and access to justice, we support the strengthening of the national equality bodies. We have run training, seminars and conferences such as the 2015 Colloquium on Fundamental Rights, which focused on tolerance and respect, preventing and combating anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim hatred in Europe, and the seminar focusing on multiple discrimination. Moreover, we collaborate and support various organisations active in the field of anti-discrimination – the Academy of European law, the European Union Fundamental Rights Agency and Equinet, the well-known network of national equality bodies for the promotion of equal treatment.  Thirdly, in the legislative field, the 2008 proposal for an equal treatment directive aims at extending the prohibition of discrimination on the grounds of religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation into areas not yet covered, among others the areas of social protection, social advantages, education, and access to and supply of goods and services. It would thus align the protection to that provided on the grounds of race. Directives prohibiting discrimination on grounds of sex do not cover social protection, social advantages and education, as you know. I trust the proposal will be adopted soon by the Council.  We have also achieved progress in the discussions on the proposed Directive for a European Accessibility Act, both in Council and in Parliament. Accessibility is a catalyst for the full and equal participation of people with disabilities in society. I would like in this context also to mention the intense work in relation to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and the forthcoming review of the European Disability Strategy.  Last but not least, in 2015 we proposed a full list of actions to advance on LGBTI. Let us not forget our European Court of Justice, that also plays an important role in clarifying the scope of European anti-discrimination law. For example, we are currently expecting important rulings on two pending cases relating to dismissals of female workers wearing Islamic headscarves in private firms.  Lastly, I want to stress that inclusive labour markets can only be achieved through a partnership approach involving all stakeholders. Public authorities can help people gain skills to get jobs and contribute to growth. Companies can commit to diversity and, as a result of diversity, benefit from enhanced productivity, innovation and performance. Trade unions, NGOs and academia can contribute valuable insights and help in spreading best practices on diversity and non-discrimination. Thank you for your attention.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: rapporteur for advice from LIBE. – This report shows that 16 years after the adoption of the EU Directive on equal treatment in employment and occupation, there is still a lot of work to be done. Progress has certainly been made, but people with disabilities remain severely under-represented in the labour market. Less than 50 percent have a job, compared to 70 percent for people without disabilities. A broad, comprehensive approach remains necessary in all areas, using the concept of reasonable adjustments. It is necessary to ensure that people with disabilities can also enjoy the free movement of people, which is often not the case now. For example, workers with disabilities often face a variety of obstacles, including administrative obstacles, which workers without disabilities do not face. Unacceptable anyway! Finally, I am pleased that the report refers to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the only general human rights treaty that the European Union has so far ratified.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: rapporteur for the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, let me thank Mrs Weber for her work on the report. Together, we agree that discrimination in employment is a problem that must continue to be actively addressed, and we must strive for improvements in this area. I was the draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and in it we raised the issue of indirect and multiple discrimination against women. We also noted the need to address the issue of women's disadvantaged status, which is linked to their motherhood. We must commend women for the work of housewives and their childcare and allow them to return to work if that is their choice.  I welcome the report as a whole, but I have some reservations about it. Existing legislation needs to be applied consistently rather than new directives. I also consider it a very problematic effort to harmonise ethical issues or to criticise Member States that approach a ban on the wearing of religious symbols in the workplace. On these issues, we should respect subsidiarity and let the Member States deal with these issues within their remit. Promoting equal treatment in employment is therefore a task that continues and which we must continue to support.

name: David CASA
text: f'isem il-grupp PPE. – U jiena nibda billi nirringrazzja lir-Rapporteur għax-xogħol tajjeb li għamlet f'din id-Direttiva, għax l-implimentazzjoni tagħha testendi l-protezzjoni kontra d-diskriminazz ion pprovduta taħt il-liġi tal-Unjoni Ewropea billi telenka qafas ġenerali illi bih tista' tiġi miġġielda d-diskriminazzjoni fuq bażi ta' reliġjon jew twemmin, diżabilità, età, orjentazzjoni sesswali, fejn jidħol impjieg jew okkupazzjoni. Dan sar bil-mira li jiġi in effett fil-pajjiżi membri bil-prinảipju tat-trattament ugwali mingħajr ma jiġi mminat ir-rwol tal-pajjiżi membri f'dan il-proảess.  Irridu niggarantixxu li l-pajjiżi membri li sfortunatament anke dalgħodu mhumiex rappreżentati hawn mill-Kunsill sabiex jaqsmu l-esperjenzi u l-prassi tagħhom, sabiex nibnu fuq l-esperjenza li diġà nġabret mill-istituzzjonijiet, sabiex ikollna dinja aktar tolleranti madwarna u nnaqqsu kemm jista' jkun din id-diskrizzjoni.  (Il-kelliem qabel li jwieġeb għal mistoqsija "karta blu" skont l-Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Proảedura).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. We agree on two things in any case, but I also have one question: one is what you said, that we are really facing a good report, and the other is that, well, the Member States, indeed, the Member States' governments still have plenty of work to do, especially some that have fallen so far behind in this whole process.  My question, however, is whether you feel that the current institutional measures, whether in the Member States or in the European Union, allow children with disabilities to prepare together with their parents for a difficult future when they grow up?

name: David CASA
text: tweġiba card blu. – Naturalment Sur President, jiena fid-diskors tiegħi għidt illi nnaqqsu kemm jista' jkun id-diskriminazzjoni. Naturalment, għadna m'aħniex perfetti, fadal ħafna xi jsir, hemm diversi pajjiżi li għandhom diversi tipi ta' diskriminazzjoni u rridu naraw kif ilkoll flimkien naqsmu l-esperjenzi tagħna, kif għidt, ħalli kemm jista' jkun id-diskriminazzjoni nippruvaw neliminawha darba għal dej minn fuq il-postijiet tax-xogħol tagħna, grazzi.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Thank you, President. First of all, I thank the rapporteur, Renate Weber, for her good report and for our cooperation. Indeed, this directive affects each of us in the European Union, every citizen of the European Union, both young and older, disabled, and a man or woman. It is particularly important to realise that demographic changes in Europe, as well as the increase in the retirement age, make the issue of age discrimination against older people increasingly relevant in the area of employment. Therefore, if we are already making decisions in the Member States to increase the retirement age, then we must ensure that our seniors have every chance of remaining in the labour market as full-fledged workers. I would also like to call on the Member States to ensure the protection of older workers against unfair dismissal in the event of retirement age, because the rights of older workers are often violated in the States. Another thing I want to draw attention to is that we are still failing to protect the most vulnerable members of society, people with disabilities, from discrimination. Some Member States are indeed in breach of this Directive by failing to adapt jobs for persons with disabilities, not providing adequate living and quality working conditions, and not ensuring equal opportunities in education and vocational training. We must therefore again call on the Member States to use the Structural Funds to adapt jobs and provide the necessary assistance to people with disabilities in the workplace. We also need to address the problem of harassment at work, which can arise for various reasons, both on grounds of sex and age, because of religious beliefs, which offends human dignity, which degrades, and ultimately makes it really difficult for an employee to work in such a working environment. I therefore believe that it is very important to disseminate information and to campaign for people on their rights and opportunities at work and in the labour market, as well as on the responsibility of employers towards workers. Many of our citizens do not even know what rights are provided for in this directive. Thanks!

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The ECR supports measures to combat discrimination in the workplace. However, it is also a central concern for us that our economy should not be overdone by regulations that could end up costing jobs. I am therefore particularly pleased that the report relates to the better regulation agreement. As with any legislative paper, we must ensure that the objectives are achieved and that there are no undesirable side effects. Discrimination should not only be combated in the workplace. However, since the Council of Ministers was unable to agree on a compromise, we should revise and streamline the anti-discrimination directive.  Two final comments: the ECR will not support the social clauses in public procurement, nor will the urgent introduction of a directive on maternity protection at EU level. This still belongs in the hands of the nation states.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, this report by my colleague Renate Weber is a comprehensive and well-balanced assessment on the challenges we face in ensuring equal treatment in employment. Some of these challenges were already articulated by Commissioner Thyssen earlier. This report deals with core issues such as disability, age, religion and belief and sexual orientation, but it also looks at the horizontal aspects which underpin them. Some of the issues are more straightforward and can be measured more easily. These include, for example, the provision of reasonable accommodation for people with disabilities, the use of universal design in public places, the inclusion of social clauses in public procurement procedures, the need to conduct a review of upper age limits for certain jobs and act on them, and also the need for Member States to work towards ensuring mutual recognition of partnership status, matrimonial regimes and parenting rights. But, equally, some issues are very difficult and very sensitive. Some have a significant impact at national level sometimes because of culture, history or more recent events. All I would say on that aspect is that, when you justify discrimination in the area of employment on those issues, you open a Pandora’s box.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: gue/NGL Group. Mr President! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for a very good report. After all, the report addresses an important issue that affects all of us. Namely, the issue of creating a diverse labour market aimed at all regardless of gender, sexual orientation, age, ethnicity, social origin, religion or disability. It is to me that action in the field of equality and equal treatment must be seen as a showdown with the discrimination that too many people experience. If we just look at the situation of women in the labour market, we see excessive differences in wages and conditions of employment, despite the fact that they have the same training and duties as their male colleagues. Similarly, our minority groups in society fight against prejudice, and often against ignorance, among possible bosses and future colleagues. It makes their way into the labour market far too difficult and sometimes almost impossible. Our society needs to adapt to today's cultural environments in order to put an end to discrimination that is still too many people experiencing. We must free the Member States from the economic reduction policies, we must allow them to invest in more jobs and in better jobs. We must regard anti-discrimination as an investment in the future of society as a whole. It is not an individual problem, but a collective task.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Renate Weber on this report. The Green/EFA Group fully supports the call addressed to the Council to break the deadlock and speed up the adoption of the EU horizontal anti-discrimination directive. At the present time the extension of the existing anti—discrimination legislation, and the enforcement of its consistent application, should be viewed as an important element in the prevention of radicalisation. Council Directive 2000/78/EC makes it possible to introduce positive action in respect of groups suffering from severe and structural discrimination, a possibility not fully used by Member States. I also want to underline and support the recommendation on the adoption of a European framework for national strategies to combat anti-Semitism and Islamophobia. I would like to add here that Russophobia is a further phenomenon that has appeared recently.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Weber for her work.
