The directive was born 16 years ago and, regardless of what state of implementation has been done in recent years, I believe that the work that has been done is fundamental, because during this period the structural problems of the Member States have created new inequalities.  We have new sections of the population, especially within the labour market, who are suffering from inequalities. These are, for example, people who have been forced to raise the retirement age and who are somewhat discriminated against because they do not have the skills to adapt to the change in the labour market, as well as those people who, as victims of the economic crisis, have lost their jobs at an age when it is very difficult to relocate within the labour market. , so it's important. I believe that it is important to protect people who report discrimination in the workplace, as well as the need for guaranteed care when they do so, as an educational purpose. Above all, I would like to make an invitation: our Constitutions – I believe all of them, and mine in particular do so in Article 3 – remind us that it is the task of the State to remove all obstacles of any kind that generate inequality and prevent freedom. So sometimes you have to take a step back, to what it was, to make progress today.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, who insists in her explanatory statement that pluralism and non-discrimination must prevail in the Union, particularly on the basis of convictions. I hope that this reminder will be heard by some of my colleagues who sometimes practice this kind of exclusion here in the European Parliament.  (Mr. Lavrilleux's off-microphone intervention) How? Examples? Recently, I was singled out in my Committee on Culture and Education, where all groups were forbidden to support my amendments because I was part of this group precisely, and I think that is very serious in our institution, especially since these amendments were quite in line with what everyone is currently asking for.  (Mr. Lavrilleux's off-microphone intervention) Look, it depends on how you do your job. I do it with my heart and I find it particularly discriminatory. There are some very positive elements in this report. First of all, I welcome the part on disability and the reminder of the need to do everything in our favour... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The rules must be respected in all directions, that is what I am doing, as President. There's no discrimination.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: "Sorry?" How? So I'm being questioned, but I don't have the right to answer, I have to be insulted!  (Intervention off microphone) For me, you're calling me a liar right now. (President's intervention) No, but it doesn't matter. So that's exactly what I said at the beginning.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, I think we are all convinced that for the same quality and quantity of work anyone should receive the same remuneration. Have the same general rights, regardless of whether they are male or female, regardless of whether or not they have some form of disability. The important thing, however, is to be able to create the conditions that are needed so that even those who, because of either an accident or a related condition, cannot compete with others on the labour market, must have guaranteed access to jobs that allow them to live with dignity and not be economically dependent on third parties. , where of course this is possible. In any case, however, equality at work cannot be guaranteed unless the work itself has been ensured first. You are well aware of the huge unemployment problem that exists in many European countries, first of all Greece. So when jobs are so limited, capital will always take advantage of workers. We must create those conditions that will allow everyone to have a job, a factor which in itself will also help equality between workers.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday morning President Juncker said that, despite the improvements, while encouraging, the issue of employment remains a priority throughout Europe. But there can be no solid growth in employment unless discrimination in access to employment and in the workplace is also combated.  15 years after the entry into force of the Directive on equal treatment in employment and working conditions, the unemployment rate for persons with disabilities is still almost double that of the general population. Following its adoption by the Union, the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities provides a good basis for defining the very concept of disability as well as for the concepts of universal design of physical spaces and appropriate reasonable solutions. In addition, an important economic return is possible with investments in accessibility as well as a gain in terms of social inclusion.  It is therefore necessary for the Member States to do much more to make these reasonable solutions that already exist attractive.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Union is sometimes referred to as Charles Darwin's society, meaning the elite of the EU authorities supports the interests of strong partners. So if that is the case, can the Union guarantee equality in employment and work if, in this pseudo-equality, it wins stronger at the end? So is the transport directive, which aims to destroy Poland's largest transport fleet of trucks and trucks in Europe by introducing the principle of the so-called minimum wage or the rules on posted workers, a manifestation of the Union's struggle for equal treatment in the area of employment and labour, or simply the covert or blatant protectionism of the strongest ones? Is the employment rate of persons with disabilities below 50% compared to the 70% employment rate of the general population a showcase for the Union and a source of pride, or is it evidence of stronger dominance? Therefore, the problem of equal treatment in employment and work should and must be taken seriously and fairly by the European Union.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Renate Weber for the excellent job she has done. The Employment Equality Directive bans discrimination on the grounds of religion or belief. Can we use this act to justify a ban on wearing headscarves in the workplace or other religious symbols? Many MEPs believe that we can – for security reasons, for instance, or because this is a symbol of oppression. The European Court of Justice found such bans permissible if all religious symbols are prohibited in a particular workplace. In spite of that, I would remind you that even a neutrally expressed requirement might lead to unlawful discrimination, for instance if employers deliberately introduce obstacles to the employment of members of particular religious groups. In this context, Muslim woman are particularly vulnerable. Democratic states should not dictate to us what to wear. European values have nothing to do with fashion. Security considerations are hardly relevant in the context of headscarves. The free will of women, whether it is determined by personal, cultural or religious reasons, should be respected. I will finish my speech by reminding you that tolerance is one of the main European values.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: – The aim of the Directive on equal treatment in employment and occupation, which is also part of the Slovak legal order, is to ensure that people are not discriminated against in access to the labour market or in the exercise of their profession. However, the reality for people with disabilities is often different. They are not only wanted to be employed by private companies, but also by state administration bodies, and our society shares the view that these people belong to sheltered workshops and not to an open labour market. However, there are also individuals and organisations who come up with innovative ideas and prove to us that people with disabilities also have huge potential and can be full-fledged employees with well-set support measures. Such projects include, for example, the 'Every business needs its autism' initiative, in which professionals train and prepare not only the people with autism themselves, but also their future employers; or the Bivio Rehabilitation and Education Centre, which wants to help people with intellectual disabilities to take up the labour market. These organisations lack courage, determination or know-how. All they lack is state support and that needs to change.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Mr President, I would just like to go back to the subject of the wearing of religious symbols in business, particularly in paragraph 21 of the report. On behalf of the members of the French delegation of the European People's Party (EPP), I would like to recall the principle of subsidiarity concerning the rules that govern the wearing of so-called religious symbols, whether in companies or in public spaces.  If the Member States, secular or not, are to guarantee religious freedom, it is up to them to set rules on all or part of their territory, according to their history and culture, or in the name of gender equality or security, in accordance with the European texts. We absolutely respect this principle and I wanted to remind you of that.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I also want to thank the rapporteur, Renate Weber, and the others who worked on the report. Equal treatment in employment and employment, I do not think it should be questioned by anyone in every respect: sex, nationality, religion. Moreover, the constitutions of the Member States clearly provide for equal treatment. Problems arise when we have to apply them in practice. I wanted to take the floor to underline the importance of the report and to raise the alarm about non-compliance with equal treatment in the workplace or at the request for employment, particularly when it comes to people with disabilities or to women in the pay process. There are still cases of workplace harassment or pressure to leave the workplace. I believe in the need for equal treatment by respecting the values and competences of each person, which is why I support this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, it has been 15 years since the adoption of the Employment Equality Directive, the aim of which is to combat discrimination in the field of work within the Member States of the Union. And yet, inequalities in the workplace still exist. In particular, the employment rate of people with disabilities within the Union is well below 50%, while the unemployment rate for people with disabilities is close to 18.3%. In other words, it is almost twice that of the general population in the European Union. At the same time, there is a strong gender pay and pension gap in the workplace. In addition, workplaces are discriminated against in the recruitment process between the sexes, while it is women who are most affected by the economic crisis at the risk of finding themselves in precarious jobs or becoming unemployed. Bearing in mind that the Equality Directive has already been adopted by the European Parliament, all forms of discrimination in employment should be eliminated immediately.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Non-discrimination, tolerance, justice and gender equality are words that we would like to describe our society. Unfortunately, in Europe, despite significant progress in recent years, discrimination is still present, particularly in employment, which, of course, has negative effects on all aspects of life, and has a particular negative impact not only on society as such, but on the individual. I think that, in the face of this problem, it is necessary to strengthen, above all, dialogue between governments, dialogue with civil society and, of course, also with the social partners. At the same time, every way to make the public more aware of this problem must be made. Member States must ensure that legislation is systematically harmonised and that the principle of equal treatment is fully enforced.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European In addition to assessing the application of the relevant Directive on equal treatment, we cannot ignore the unjustified limitation of the scope of the legislation. Discrimination on grounds of belonging to national minorities is not part of the text of the Directive. I therefore welcome the call in the report for the Commission to monitor all types of discrimination.  It is also time for the Council to finally come to terms with the adoption of a horizontal EU anti-discrimination directive that would protect European citizens from discrimination outside the workplace. I also proposed in my LIBE opinion that the prohibition of discrimination on grounds of belonging to a national minority should also be at the forefront of legislation and control. After all, the daily experience of millions of EU citizens is discrimination.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, the foundations of the European Union are undoubtedly respect, human dignity, equality, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. As a result, the Equal Employment Directive was adopted fifteen years ago. It is a directive which aims to combat discrimination and, while there have been improvements in recent years, there is no doubt that there are still challenges with certain vulnerable groups, such as disability, a group in which a large part of my work is centered. There much can be done to make reasonable adjustments to employment, fiscal policies, active policies and universal designs. But there are also other vulnerable groups. The report says this very well: groups discriminated against on the grounds of religion, on the grounds of age and also on the grounds of sexual orientation. It takes more than legislation. Strong political commitment is needed. But it is also needed to create a culture of solidarity and to breathe dignity, to breathe equality. In short, effective measures are needed that can turn this society into a society that fights as a priority for equality.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate demonstrates how important it is to remain vigilant and continue fighting against all forms of discrimination, notably on the labour market. As I said, I hope, and the Commission trusts, that the proposal for a horizontal directive will soon be adopted by the European Council. The European directives have set up a comprehensive Europe-wide legal framework against discrimination that has been transposed in all Member States. In 2014, the Commission reviewed their application and found that often there is a lack of awareness, sometimes a weak implementation and enforcement at national level. The Commission has, therefore, further developed support to Member States in order to facilitate the full implementation of those directives, in particular by ensuring that the investment priorities of the European structural funds such as the European Social Fund properly include the fight against discrimination in employment. As you know, with Věra Jourová we last year launched a new initiative to promote work-life balance, with the main objective to ensure that women are not obliged to choose between a family and a professional career. Ms Weber’s report and its recommendations will help the Commission to further monitor and, where needed, improve the policy framework on equality on the labour market. I thank you for the report and this debate and I thank you for your attention.

name: Renate WEBER
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and all the colleagues for their comments. The report highlights the need for adequate training for all relevant stakeholders: from employees of authorities of all kinds to law—enforcement bodies, judges, prosecutors and lawyers. However, I am now thinking that we, as public representatives, could also benefit from such training because I have a hard time understanding how the implementation of a fundamental right, which is provided for by Article 10 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, could be a matter of subsidiarity. We have well-established European Court of Human Rights jurisprudence on the restriction of the fundamental right to a certain extent, but more than that should not be accepted. Moreover, I am wondering how we could accept the non-observance of court decisions: that contradicts everything I had learned and thought over the past 30 years about the meaning of the rule of law. I want to stress that, for me, adequate training not only refers to knowledge of legislation in court decisions but also includes training on understanding cultural differences and on acknowledging unconscious bias. Since 2007, when I became a Member of this Parliament, together with many colleagues I have been advocating the adoption of a horizontal anti-discrimination directive outlawing discrimination in access to goods and services across the EU. Nine years later, yes, I find it is a disgrace that this directive is still blocked in the Council by a coalition of some Member States. I cannot but welcome the optimism of Commissioner Thyssen that the directive will become a reality soon, so let us stay optimistic and let us hope.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – The report on the application of Directive 2000/78/EC on a general framework for equal treatment in employment and employment contains a number of forward-looking provisions. This report is based on the experience of the last 15 years. It is an important step forward that religion has also become a priority in this area, but I believe that the restrictions imposed on the wearing of religious symbols should remain a national competence. Progress is also being made in the area of disability, e.g. by emphasising the importance of providing tax incentives or taking into account public procurement or the activities of the Committee for the Monitoring of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. In this connection, it is important to strengthen the legal protection of persons with disabilities and to take concrete steps to do so.  In line with the development of robotics and artificial intelligence, further progress can also be expected in the area of age discrimination, in particular by improving workers' digital skills and developing smart services. However, the provisions of the report on sexual orientation include elements which call into question national competences and traditions which are ineligible. In addition, with regard to the survey, I am concerned about the production of statistics on racial and ethnic origin, as well as the harmonisation efforts relating to parental leave, in particular the fact that family-related benefits and allowances Hungary spent significantly above the EU average.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Marian Harkin, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014 (2015/2284(INI)) (A8-0227/2016)

name: Marian HARKIN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all, I want to genuinely thank colleagues for the really good and constructive cooperation in this report, and also all the shadows and all the committees who contributed excellent opinions. I just might mention, in particular, our colleague Jean-Paul Denanot from the Committee on Budgets.  I suppose our role here was to assess the activities, the impact and the added-value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) and, of course, to look to the future, to indicate what our proposals are for a more effective and more efficient EGF. I am grateful to colleagues for the engagement. The EGF is small fund compared to the ESF, for example; it is also a new fund. I think that gives us a sense that we can help to shape it in a positive way. In this report we look to see: how we can help to make it more effective; what partnership models will deliver better outcomes for redundant workers who have lost their jobs due to globalisation; how we can organise the process so that it responds in a more timely way to the needs of workers; how we can ensure better value for money for both the workers and for EU taxpayers; and how we can spend that money in a more efficient way; how can we ensure we have relevant data that allows us to assess the outcomes from the funds without placing undue requirements on Member States; and, of course, crucially, how we can help ensure personalised, well-coordinated measures that are tailored to the individual needs of the redundant workers. In that way we do two things: we express our solidarity with them at a difficult time and, secondly, we assist them in the transition to sustainable employment.  So what makes the EGF different to the ESF? Well, the EGF is meant to deal with emergencies, more short-term in its approach, while the ESF is more structural. Both have their advantages, and indeed it has been very positive to see how Member States use the ESF as a complementary tool to the EGF. We also propose that Member States need to achieve synergies between EGF and ESI funds. We emphasize that ESI funds can act as follow-up measures in EGF areas of support by stimulating investment and overall job creation. So what are the positives? Well, timelines have improved considerably due to efforts by all actors: the Commission, Member States, Parliament, etc. The self-employed are now included. NEETs can benefit from EGF support in numbers equal to the numbers of targeted beneficiaries. The EGF is now part of the shared fund management system, and I commend the Commission on this. Co-funding has been increased to 60%, more Member States are using EGF and spending, under personalised measures, has been lowered to 35%. Indeed, in many recent applications that spending is considerably less. The Court of Auditors tells us that nearly all EGF beneficiaries were able to benefit from personalised and well-coordinated measures. The re-employment rate is around 50%, and as Member States become more used to the fund, their applications are more timely. But there are still negatives: Member States don’t use the EGF often enough and, crucially, do not often use the derogation. Funding has been cut from 500 million to 150 million, budget implementation is only 55% but improving. There is a concentration of applications in the manufacturing, automotive construction and aviation sectors. We need to take a different approach to NEETs and to redundant workers. So it is important to design the EGF in such a way that it can respond to their needs. The Member States need to make publicly available all relevant information in regard to EGF cases, and they need to set quantitive reintegration objectives so that we can measure the success. Finally, the most important point is that the EGF must guarantee EU added-value for redundant workers and taxpayers. Then we can strongly call for its continuation and expansion.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, indeed, as rapporteur on the evaluation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund under the Committee on Budgets, I have met many stakeholders, companies, employees, trade unions, reclassification chaperones, administrations. They all said three things to me. The first is that this fund is very useful so as not to leave employees without a solution following their dismissal. Second, the fund is in fact intervening in hindsight and procedures should be expedited. Third, and I think that is the most important thing, it would probably be better to be in prevention than in repair. That is why I am advocating for an anticipation of the changes brought about by globalization, technological changes and trade changes in the world as well. I believe that the Commission must now take this dimension into account and make proposals so that we at European level can support companies in these changes. I think there are real prospects here, especially for SMEs which, with this support, would avoid going into the wall, as is the case now.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Harkin, and the rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets, Mr Denanot, for the attention they have paid to the EGF since it started in 2007, in Ms Harkin’s case. The report is very useful to us. Indeed, despite several improvements introduced in the regulation for the 2014-2020 period and subsequently reflected in the functioning of the Fund, there is still a margin for additional fine-tuning. The EGF is an emergency instrument with its own role. I share your view that in its current shape and budget, the EGF cannot be an intervention tool for job losses as a possible result of EU trade agreements. Some of the issues highlighted in the conclusions of the Court of Auditors report and the evaluation of the EGF have already been addressed in the current regulation, for example, the use of EGF funding to compensate national workers’ income support schemes with no European added value. The former lengthy EGF approval procedure has been reduced from 41 weeks on average to a maximum now of 28 weeks. I welcome your appreciation for the Commission’s efforts to develop standardised procedures for the EGF applications and management using the functionalities of the electronic data exchange system, SFC. Since 3 August 2016, the reporting module for EGF cases is also available in SFC and I am confident that the expectations regarding reporting improvement will be fulfilled once SFC becomes fully operational for EGF cases.  We expect the first results of the ongoing EGF mid-term evaluation for the 2014-2020 period by the end of this year. They will cover the current derogation giving access to EGF co—funding also to NEETs in certain EGF applications. The average share of beneficiaries aged 55 or more was three times that of beneficiaries aged 15 to 24. The inclusion of NEETs as eligible beneficiaries of Globalisation Fund support in the current EGF regulation by way of derogation helps to counterbalance this tendency and is an expression of solidarity with young unemployed persons in regions with high unemployment levels. The Commission shares your view that the EGF should continue to provide assistance to NEETs who live in regions eligible under the Youth Employment Initiative after December 2017, the date of expiry of the derogation. I am happy to announce that the Commission just yesterday tabled a proposal for the extension of this derogation as part of the mid—term review of the multiannual financial framework.  I take note of your concern that workers made redundant by SMEs have fewer chances to be supported by the EGF than workers made redundant by large enterprises. However, applying for EGF co—funding in support of workers made redundant by large enterprises or SMEs belongs to national preferences. Some Member States apply this almost exclusively using the intervention criteria of Article 4.1(a). Other Member States, for example Spain, apply it mainly using the intervention criteria of Article 4.1(b), that cover cases of at least 500 workers being made redundant, particularly in SMEs all operating in the same sector and located in one or two contiguous regions. I would like to recall that the Commission has promoted regular peer reviews across national exchanges or partnering in order to exchange good practices and implementing experience since the start of the Fund. The meetings of the EGF contact persons that the Commission organises twice a year are an established way for Member States to exchange best practices. We will further support the sharing of information so that mutual learning among Member States here, too, is reinforced.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of INTA. – Just in times of economic stagnation and increased globalisation, it is important that we stand up seriously for people who are on the short end. The benefits of trade always bring about shifts in prosperity. The losers therefore have reason to complain if they do not share the growth that trade brings. The Member States are, of course, primarily responsible for this. But for the reception of shocks and for solidarity between Member States, the EGF is a very important fund. I therefore hope that the Commission will take this report to heart, in particular the recommendations of the INTA Committee, namely that trade agreements should look at job losses in advance and afterwards and that workers should be involved in companies' restructuring plans in good time, so that they are able to seriously negotiate the corresponding social plan. I hope that in this way the EGF can be improved and can be helpful to the losers of globalisation.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the lack of complete data makes it difficult for us to understand whether the Globalisation Adjustment Fund has so far been an effective instrument. For this reason, it is necessary for the Commission in future to guarantee public access to all documents relating to fund intervention cases and to provide complete information to enable us to understand whether the training offered has been adapted to the economic prospects and the needs of the labour market in the regions affected by the redundancies and what has been expected and achieved.  Above all, it is necessary to have the opportunity to understand whether company closures and redundancies are the result of a relocation of production to third countries or other Member States that apply aggressive fiscal policies to attract investment. It is important that it is not the citizens who pay for the profit-making of companies, which is why we are calling on the Commission to consider an instrument that obliges companies moving production out of the EU to contribute to reintegration measures for redundant workers.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European As responsible for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development, I would first like to draw attention to the fact that the exploitation of synergies between the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds is essential for rapid, lasting and effective results. Cohesion policy has made a significant contribution to mitigating the negative economic and social impacts of the crisis and globalisation and has fostered sustainable employment and growth.  In order to find lasting solutions to unemployment, it is necessary to exploit synergies and to use more resources together. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that the average approval period for applications from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was 10 months during the period examined in the report, which is unbeatable. Any measure that shortens the period for the examination of these applications is important and we have pushed for them.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. –The European Globalisation Fund has indeed benefited people who have lost their jobs across Europe and has been very significant, especially in times of economic and financial crisis, when in most Member States different industrial sectors experienced severe difficulties and people lost their jobs en masse. Here in my native Lithuania, four sectors benefited from the support of this fund – construction, textile, electronics and furniture manufacturing sectors. And that has really meant a lot to our small labour market and its recovery. As an opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, I would like to point out in this report that only one third of the beneficiaries of the Fund were women during the period assessed. Of course, this is probably due to the fact that globalisation and the financial and economic crisis have touched more on those sectors where men work mainly, but I would ask the Commission to monitor, however, that women in the allocation of fund support do not suffer, that the balanced package of individual services provided to women who have lost their jobs is truly adapted to their real needs. Calls also on the Member States to collect data by gender so that we can better assess the rates of women's return to the labour market and monitor the sectors in which they are returning. It is particularly important to know whether women find quality safe work and whether their entrepreneurship is equally encouraged.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as we concluded yesterday during the debate on the latest cases of job losses, at Caterpillar and Alstom, there can be no substitute for a long-term vision for the reindustrialisation of Europe. That being said, in our global world there can always be unforeseen forces – such as structural changes in world trade patterns, financial crises or a slowdown of growth in Europe or elsewhere, affecting demand – that can hit our industries and our workers. It is thus essential that we have a reliable EU-level cushion to protect our workers from such a blow. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has already proved its worth in this regard in many unfortunate cases of plant closure in Europe, especially through the support it has provided for thousands of lower-skilled, and thus more vulnerable, workers in regaining employment. This report not only offers a comprehensive evaluation of the fund’s strengths and weaknesses but it also succeeds in identifying many ways to make it more efficient in the future. I would like to thank the rapporteur for this and for our great collaboration. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I more or less agree with what you have said, but I would like to ask you one aspect to ask for your opinion: namely, whether, in the TTIP negotiations that are currently going on, you see that the convention itself provides sufficient protection for social rights, as opposed to the fact that, if it does not, the same fund will have to be activated once.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: blue card answer. –We have the same view on social issues, and we are equally concerned about this.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, I thank Marian Harkin for the work she has done and the co-ministers, and I would also like to thank the Commissioner for the announcement she made yesterday that the NEETs would indeed be extended at the level of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I thank her for her action. The WEF does help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major changes in the global trade structure. It is therefore obvious that, in a context of globalization as we live it today, we must defend this instrument, even strengthen it, because everyone knows that there are winners in globalisation, but there are also more and more losers. I therefore plead for more resources, but also to increase the levels of intervention and to activate the clause of exceptional circumstances in order to be able to modulate aid according to needs on the ground. I am also advocating for more prevention and I am a little concerned about what Mrs Thyssen has just said. She says that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund must not compensate for trade policies. However, Mrs Malmstrom says the opposite. In her general policy, Mrs Malmstrom noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be used to compensate for the negative effects of trade. What is particularly interesting is that, in the context of trade impact studies, Mrs Malmstrom says that there are no negative effects. It is therefore quite pecral to hear diverging speeches at this point.  In yesterday's debate on Africa, there was the same ringing: there are no negative effects on agriculture. We know that there are negative effects. If we deny them, we can't anticipate them. I plead for sincere recognition and that we can effectively anticipate these negative effects to help the industry rather than helping workers who have lost their jobs when there are no more opportunities for them.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, again good morning, the third time you have listened to me in this House. It's a very tough house, I guess. Commissioner, thank you for being here. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their work and, of course, for the excellent work done by the rapporteur, Mrs Harkin. I will go to the principles: all asymmetric shock, every economic evolution, every hasty timely change generates times of transition; it's a dynamic where there are going to be winners and losers. And Mrs Arena is right to say that TTE, a big trade change, may have short-term losers. The good thing about the European social model is that we are responsible for supporting and helping these losers during the transition. In this sense, this Fund is fundamental. It is essential to strengthen it and use it well with a sense of employment, recovery and re-inclusion of disadvantaged areas. And, of course, I would put the "ninis", for example, among the social groups that we must recover. But what problem can this Fund have? This Fund may need to be made a little more horizontal, because the problem is when it allows discrimination between one company or another or between sectors or others. This aspect needs to be improved, but certainly the Commission's work of helping social coherence can never be renounced when economic developments impose losers.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Harkin for her work on the report. To echo what some of colleagues have said, the EGF is a worthwhile and positive fund, and I support it. But this Fund is often used to compensate for the damaging effects of policies that have stemmed from the European Commission.  It has been the policies of deindustrialisation and unfettered free trade which in the main have created the need for the EGF. Not only have these policies caused job losses but their fallout has undermined workers’ rights and caused irreparable social damage. Within the report, I agree with the call for greater government transparency and the reference to a mid-term review at Member State level so that Member States can assess the progress of the EGF in their countries and identify issues early that might need intervention. In many countries, such as my own, Ireland, there has been a severe underspend of EGF funds and it does not become apparent until the end of the term when the monies are handed back. This is unfair to workers as they are the ones that suffer when the funding is not put to the best use. I also welcome the reference to creating stronger working conditions and working relationships with the community and voluntary sector, as they are the ones that are best placed to assess, particularly, the needs of NEETs, and to raise the awareness of EGF opportunities with them. As I said, overall this is a very good report – and would again just like to thank Ms Harkin for her work in reaching consensus – and I will be supporting it.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – Ms Boylan, I firmly agree with the beginning of your analysis of the problems of the EGF. Do you also accept, or not, the principle that the very existence of the EGF allows executives at large corporations, when they are considering to make redundancies, know that they can reduce the redundancy values for people, know that they can sack more people – know that they can get away with all their policies because of the very existence of this EGF – and that if it was not there they would be forced by national states to pay proper funds to those people who are leaving?

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: blue-card answer. – I agree with the vast majority of what you have said, but obviously, as somebody who has been a trade union member for many years, my interests are with the workers. While I think we do need to do more to secure proper redundancy payments and proper collective bargaining for workers, in the absence of that, and without changing the direction of the European Union in relation to trade and to its relationship with multinational corporations who treat workers disgracefully, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the only thing that workers have – and that is why, reluctantly, I accept it because we need anything that we can get, particularly in Ireland, and I am sure in many other Member States, to help those workers get back into employment. However, I agree with you: we need to change the direction of the EU to deal with multinational corporations and their shocking treatment of workers.

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I, too, would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur, Mrs Harkin, for her extremely constructive, good and goal-oriented cooperation. For us Greens, the European Globalisation Fund is an important social and labour market governance instrument when people lose their jobs and threaten to fall into the poverty trap as a result of globalisation or the economic crisis. It is also one of the few instruments by which the EU directly supports its citizens, where it is not the economy that is at the forefront, but the human being – as is worthy of a social union as we Greens aspire to it.  We Greens will therefore vote in favour of this report, and we would also like to make it clear that we are pleased that the report includes the establishment of a gender impact assessment, that is, that women and men benefit equally briefly – and in the long term from the EGF. And, of course, the Fund must not be a solution to a misguided trade policy, nor a solution to the wrong group strategies, nor should it be a substitute for preventive measures, as the previous speaker, Jean-Paul Denanot, quite rightly said.  In any case, the EGF also needs major reform. For example, workers from all Member States should also be able to benefit from the EGF, not just the best informed, not just those in the large corporations. The quality of jobs should also be increasingly brought to the fore, and loopholes for Member States, as has already been mentioned, should in any case be closed again. After all, benefits that must be borne by Member States in labour market and social policy must not be passed on to the EGF under any circumstances.  Moreover, I believe that future appointments to the European Court of Auditors should only be made for women until a reasonable gender balance is achieved.

name: Tim AKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Thank you, Mr. President. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund – well, there is a euphemism if ever I heard one. It seems that the solution to all of the problems in the European Union is more money, more money, more money – not a change of policy, not a change of direction. God forbid you guys actually ditch the single currency which is causing misery to southern Europe and creeping its way upwards. But you do not understand, you are getting this money from taxpayers who are already suffering. You may see increased GDP numbers but, in my country, productivity may be up but people’s wages have been compressed because of the seemlessly unlimited supply of cheap labour coming from complete free movement and open borders.  There is another way that you can change this: you can take back control. There is a democratic revolution taking place, with referendums becoming the issue of the day across every single EU Member State, and they will happen. So go with the tide, take back control over trade policy so that you can determine trade policies that reflect your constituents in your country first and foremost, because we are sent here as public servants. We are not here to do what the European Union wants, we are here to do what our constituents want. 17.4 million people in the United Kingdom – a majority – voted to take back control of trade policy so that we can create trade policies that limit redundancies, to make sure that we do not have to discuss redundancy packages. You can do the same. Follow our lead, take back control, let democracy and let your people win the day.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, the regulation is clear about the purpose of the Globalisation Fund. The fund is designed to get people who have lost their jobs to work as a way to get their jobs back to work. But the evaluation teaches us two things: first, less than half of people receiving benefits from the fund find a job again. You can't possibly call that a success. Secondly, there is no longer a global crisis at all, so that the conditions are not met either. Only in the European Union economic growth remains low and in the euro area countries it is even worse than in the other Member States. My question is very simple: The fund does not meet its own criteria and is not successful, why do we keep putting money into it? The only one who is happy with this fund is the European Union itself. Now that the EU has gradually gained power over economic, financial and social policy, this is a very bad sign.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Yesterday we heard the State of the Union speech, and we complained a lot about The fact that Europe is not getting along with the people. Today we are discussing the form and impact of the European Globalisation Fund – a prime example of what we think is good on the European side, but often bad. The fund is an instrument that arrives directly. It is intended for workers and self-employed people who have lost their jobs in order to help them reintegrate into the labour market in a very concrete way. It is intended for cities, for regions affected by the closure of a large company and, say, in economic shock – so far so good.  But, I quote the news magazine Der Spiegel: "We are also talking about millions that no one wants." My group, therefore, together with me, has been constructively critical of the debates on the fund, and we say that this fund must be improved if it is to make sense. Direct aid only makes sense if it is done quickly, really directly and without red tape. That, ladies and gentlemen, remains the great challenge in the second half of the current fund.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Mr President, the supposed support for the mass redundancies, which will be enriched by the imminent liberalisation of mass redundancies by the Greek Government and the quartet, confirms the report's findings that, firstly, businesses are being shut down either by competition from larger ones, or by moving to another place or sector for greater profits at lower labour costs, taking advantage of the famous freedom to move capital from the Maastricht Treaty. I mean, in other words, capitalism. Secondly, the fear of reactions to redundancies prevents such restructuring. As part of this, the Globalisation Fund undertakes to defuse them by sharing "aspirins". For this reason, the applicants for his help are mainly employers. Training programmes, i.e. subsidising employers with unemployment benefit for the unemployed, if they end up in a job, are much worse than the previous one: the subsidised micro-enterprises are closing down, while funds from the Fund are being deftly stretched. Aspirins do not cure unemployment cancer. Struggle, now, not to pass the release of redundancies. Increased unemployment benefit for all, for its entire duration, with full insurance coverage.

name: David CASA
text: – U nixtieq nirringrazzja jien ukoll lil Marian Harkin għal dan ir-rapport li jittratta fond importanti. Id-diskussjoni illi kellna lbieraħ, pereżempju, fuq is-sitwazzjoni diffi大li illi qiegħda tiffa大大ja l-kumpanija Caterpillar fil-Belġju hi eżempju tajjeb ta' fejn l-EGF jista' jkun effettiv. Naturalment hemm fejn wieħed jimpruvja. Naturalment il-problema li għandna... (Il-President interrompa flower-kelliem minħabba nuqqas he' interpretazzjoni) Naturalment... Kont qed nitkellem dwar id-diskussjoni li kellna lbieraħ fuq il-kumpanija Caterpillar fil-Belġju li hi eżempju tajjeb ta' fejn l-EGF jista' jiġi użat. Naturalment irridu nkunu effettivi iktar, irridu nkunu rapidi iktar għaliex mhux sew ħaddiema jitħallew jistennew biex forsi jistgħu jerġgħu jidħlu fid-dinja tax-xħogol permezz ta' dan il-fond u jkoll jistennew żmien twil. Però, naturalment, saru avvanzi f'dan il-Fond. Illum qegħdin anzi aħna nħeġġu flower-pajjiżi membri biex jużaw kemm jista' jkun dan il-Fond illi jista' jgħin ħafna f'dik is-sitwazzjoni diffiħli li jkun gaddej minnha l-ħaddiem.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is important that we evaluate how the Globalisation Fund can benefit more companies – both small and large. One of the issues that we have unfortunately not been able to agree on is the requirement for the number of employees who have to be affected in order for the fund to be used. I have a concrete example, namely a food industry in southern Sweden, Findus in Bjuv in Skåne. With today's rules, it is uncertain whether we could mobilise the fund to help the employees of Findus. I think we have to do something about it. Even in cases such as this, where so many people are affected, where an entire industry is under pressure, the Fund should be able to play a greater role than it does today. We also need to look at how the EGF can be used to mitigate the circumstances of companies affected by trade disputes. The Commission has previously said that the Fund cannot be mobilised for this. Parliament's interpretation is that it can. What does the Commission say today? We must be able to agree on the application of the Fund. It is clear that we have also listened to the Trade Commissioner, Cecilia Malmström, who has opened up to such an interpretation. There is talk of cuts in the fund at the same time as Malmström thus argues that all negative consequences that come as a result of trade agreements should be able to be addressed by the fund. I look forward to an answer to that question.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the Globalisation Adjustment Fund has worked well if people have retrained or got a new job through it. Lessons must be learned from these good experiences. But we have to admit that there are a lot of shortcomings in the functioning of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, and these need to be corrected.  There are cases where fund resources have been used to compensate for national social benefits. For this purpose, the fund has not been created. It's made to help people. It must also be possible to eliminate overlaps through subsidies from other EU funds. One shortcoming is that, in some cases where aid has been provided, the reemployment rate has been far too low, up to 4%.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur. He has brought in proposals for reform with great dignity and told us about the operation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mrs Harkin's report summarises very well the achievements of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) so far. The report rightly takes place on the important issue of the need to distinguish between this Fund and the European Social Fund (ESF). Of course, these are complementary instruments and often addressed to the same target group. However, while the ESF has a multi-annual programming cycle, the EGF is an instrument that can respond more quickly. For this reason, the greatest possible synergy between these instruments should be sought. The ESF can be considered as a complementary and continuing support measure in the areas of EGF intervention.  It is important to invest in long-term solutions to improve the labour market situation and the level of qualifications of workers. Unfortunately, the proportion of self-employed people receiving EGF support is low, an issue that needs to be worked on.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, I wanted to speak as special rapporteur of the Socialist Group in the Committee on Budgets for such projects related to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have often been rapporteur and, therefore, I can afford to come up with the following suggestions. The Fund must become more accessible by reducing the threshold for redundant employees. Thus, former Employees of SMEs can also benefit from this fund. The Commission must also ensure fair and uniform use at European level. Some states use excess funds, while others use it too little. That is why I believe that the Commission must take over the communication on this subject from the Member States and ensure that they are used effectively. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a useful mechanism, as previous speakers have said, to combat unemployment. But we really need to find a way to get it properly funded. This fund is a rapid response to the unfortunate situations arising from globalisation. But we also need a long-term response, and that is why it is important that it is supported by other European funds as well.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide support to workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes or the global financial crisis. For the period 2007-2013, the annual budget of the Fund was EUR 550 million. However, for this year, this amount will fall to EUR 150 million. In particular, the Globalisation Fund recently gave the green light for the granting of 6.5 million euros in aid to the 557 redundant people of the "Larisa" supermarket in Greece, following a request submitted by the Greek authorities on 26 November 2015. Therefore, given the role of the Globalisation Fund, and as I already asked in my written question on 26 April to the European Commission, the compensation of the dismissed people of the supermarket "Larisa" should be launched immediately and the compensation of those made redundant by "Athens Electronics" in Greece, which declared bankruptcy, leaving more than 500 workers unemployed.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – I have been following the operation of this fund for a very long time and, of course, I am also monitoring how it has changed in that time. Since the initial, more cumbersome rules, which allowed funds to be allocated only to those largest companies or employees who have been made redundant in the largest companies, it is now possible to obtain funding from the fund even for the self-employed. But of course we haven't done enough. There is more need for more adaptation, because I agree with my colleague, who has previously pointed out that small and medium-sized enterprises, which we talk very much about in this House, still do not have equal access to these funds.  Companies, and of course, the states in particular, have benefited from this fund. I am sorry that, so far, only one application has come from my country, from Slovenia.  I hear a lot of problems, so I call on the Commission to make all these procedures a little less bureaucratic so that people can get the funds more easily.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, once again I would like to express my appreciation for the work done by the rapporteur and I would also like to thank Parliament on behalf of the Commission for the valuable suggestions to further improve the functioning of the European Globalisation Fund and to adapt it as well as the legal basis allows to the constantly changing needs of the European labour market.  Today, the European Globalisation Fund cannot be used to anticipate the consequences of global trade; it has been designed to react to concrete situations such as the closure of factories. My personal view is that anticipating is always better than repairing the damage. It is therefore logical that trade policy be well coordinated with social and industrial policy to prepare our economy in good time for the changes triggered by a new trade partnership. Today, as you know, the preparation of trade agreements includes a social impact assessment. A trade agreement must, of course, generate overall a positive outcome for both partners, but within the globally positive deal it is not excluded that certain sectors of our economies could suffer. In that respect, I share the view of Cecilia Malmström that something should be done to address possible negative effects of global trade on specific sectors and, as I said, the EGF in its current design is not fit for that purpose.  I want to reassure Members of Parliament that, as your President said, I will ensure that for all policies appropriate gender indicators are used to monitor the respect of gender equality in particular in the labour market and we will of course further reflect on the ideas in your report when preparing the legal basis for the functioning of the EGF beyond 2020. I thank you for your inspiration.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: rapporteur. –  Mr President, I thank colleagues for a most engaging debate. I will not be able to respond to all of the issues raised, but I will try to address a number of them at least.  Commissioner, you started by agreeing that the EGF cannot be used as an intervention tool in job losses in the case of trade deals, and that was re-echoed by many colleagues, particularly Maria Reina who quite rightly challenged Commissioner Malmström for suggesting at some point previously that a small EUR 150 million per annum fund could deal with the negative fall-out from proposed trade deals. Many colleagues spoke of the need to anticipate and manage change, and I think we need to broaden our thinking to see if earlier action or pre-emptive action could be more effective. Some colleagues suggested that employers are using the EGF as a means of evading their legislative responsibilities. I reject this assertion as in all cases Member States guarantee that the dismissing enterprises have complied with all their legal obligations. We might wish that those legal obligations were more extensive, but that is a separate issue. The core point is that the EGF does not replace the responsibilities of companies; it is a solidarity mechanism from the EU and employers do not benefit.  I was really pleased to hear the Commissioner say that the Commission going to come forward with a proposal to extend the derogation on NEETs. Because this  a new facet to the EGF, we have not had time yet to assess its impact, but we need to ensure that measures targeting NEETs are tailored towards their needs, and in that context I thank my colleague, Lynn Boylan, whose amendment on ensuring community participation will, I believe, improve the participation of NEETs.  Commissioner Thyssen, you spoke of the derogations with regard to 4.1(a) and (b), but we also have 4.2 where, in exceptional circumstances, there can be applications from small labour markets. I just want to ask you if there is any bias against those applications – I would hope not. And I agree with colleagues who say that workers in SMEs have not had the same access as workers in larger companies. Finally, I believe that if the suggestions in this report, which represent a compromise from all across Parliament, are implemented, the EGF will be improved and will serve our workers in a more timely, targeted and efficient way.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – The main objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to act quickly and effectively to counter unforeseen difficulties in the labour market. The instrument has helped mitigate the negative effects of restructuring, supporting the sectors most affected by the crisis. EGF measures are provisional in nature, but in the long term should pursue new professional perspectives, depending on the employment potential existing in the regions affected by the relocation or restriction of the activity of certain industries. There are regions with a negative unemployment rate; therefore, I believe that the EGF measures should also include options such as support for the resettlement of workers affected by unemployment in areas with high employment potential. Last year, the restructuring of the activity of a steel company, Mechel Turda, in the region I represent, meant the dismissal of 1,000 workers, who benefited from EGF support worth EUR 3.6 million, but bureaucratic procedures led to delays and subsequently to the imposition of penalties on the Romanian Government. We should pay particular attention to monitoring the impact of globalisation, providing support to businesses to anticipate sectoral changes and to save time to re-professionalise workers under threat of redundancies.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the Philippines.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, the situation in the Philippines is extremely worrying, especially after the election of President Duterte. He started with all kinds of provocations and insults, and this year became the protagonist of verbal attacks against the UN, China, the President of the United States and the Pope, with hate speeches instigating violence against suspected drug sellers and drug users. As a consequence of these promises and behaviour, according to the official information at our disposal, starting from the day of his election on 30 June 2016 until this month of September, 44 people have been killed every day – 2 927 in total – as a result of extrajudicial execution and lynching, following these hateful speeches. Duterte is an elected president and in the near future he will play a fundamental role in the complex and delicate geopolitical balance of the South China Sea between China, the United States and Russia. With this resolution we ask the authorities to investigate and condemn the action of vigilance groups, and we urge the Commission to use all available instruments to help the government in respecting its international human rights obligations. We have the duty to use all our means in order to block the rise of a new dictator and the consequences on human rights violations in the Philippines.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, the illicit drug trade in the Philippines, and its associated criminal activities, is clearly a menace to its domestic – and the wider, global – population. President Duterte’s pledge to crack down on the trade is therefore naturally welcomed. His methods to date, however, are not. A policy that fails to distinguish between users and distributors is but one problem. The indiscriminate killing of thousands of drug users and dealers without any due process is to be absolutely condemned. The arrest of thousands more suspects on the basis of spurious allegations and hearsay is also of concern. Duterte’s comments that we will not stop until the last drug lord and pusher have surrendered or are put either behind bars or below the ground, if they so wish, is far from the tone that I would expect or wish to see from an elected president. I welcome this House’s resolution and call for an investigation into the extrajudicial killings. But EU Member State governments must also do more to put pressure on the government of the Philippines to re—evaluate its totally unacceptable policies and practices in this area.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: author. – Mr President, we are having this urgency debate on the situation in the Philippines since new evidence about extrajudicial executions and killings taking place in that country in the context of an intensified anti-crime and anti-drug campaign is shocking. Actions taken by the government look unacceptable from the perspective of international conventions on human rights the Philippines have ratified, especially as President Duterte has repeatedly urged law enforcement agencies and the public to kill suspected drug traffickers who do not surrender, as well as drug users. President Duterte has even publicly stated that he would not pursue law enforcement officers and citizens who killed drug dealers who resisted arrest. Thousands of people have already been killed by police and vigilante armed groups. President Duterte should understand that he cannot continue like this in the future. The UN Secretary General and the UN special rapporteur on extrajudicial and arbitrary executions have denounced the series of extrajudicial killings as illegal and a breach of fundamental rights and freedoms. We, the European Parliament, urge the government of the Philippines to put an end to the current wave of extrajudicial executions and killings and bring those responsible to justice. We also urge the European Union to use all available instruments to assist the government of the Philippines in respecting its international obligations.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Author. – Like previous speakers, I would also like to point out that the Philippines is being ravaged by a bloody war on drugs. More than 1,800 drug dealers have been killed since President Duterte came to power. During the same period, police killed 712 people on suspicion of drug trafficking and drug use, often without cause and without trial. And this in the Philippines, a country with which we as the European Union have always maintained good relations. Now the Philippines has become a police state where arbitrariness prevails and where human rights have little value. Admittedly, President Duterte had already mentioned in his campaign that he would call on the people to take matters into their own hands. Because of that call and inflammatory language, drug users have actually become a bird for the cat. The Philippines is indeed plagued by drugs, but let us demand that the President conduct the war on drugs within a legal framework and in a humane way. And also ask for the death penalty not to be reapplyed. This is a permanent battle point for us Europeans. The rule of law must not be sold, even when it comes to the fight against drugs. Ladies and gentlemen, I am under no illusions. Perhaps, as a result of this resolution, President Duterte is now going to scold us, as happened with US President Obama, with Ban Ki-moon and with the Pope. But it's more than worth it. A war on drugs is also bound by rules and respect for human rights. That is essential for us liberals.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the President Duterte has set as his political goal to combat drug crime at all levels and to combat it by all means. We are now seeing the consequences of this campaign. In just a few months, thousands were arrested and executed out of court. According to the Philippine national police, thousands of suspected drug dealers and drug addicts were shot dead by unknown persons in July and August of this year alone, and more than 16,000 people were detained on the basis of vague references to drug crime. This does not lead to the end of the drug trade, which leads to brutalisation and uncontrolled violence in society. The Philippine government must immediately ensure that the police and military comply with international legal standards and stop calling the population to lynch justice, as it were. Not only extrajudicial executions, but also torture and enforced disappearances must be independently investigated and those responsible brought before civilian courts. I also call on the Philippine Government to refrain from reintroducing the death penalty and also to refrain from reducing the age of guilt to nine years, as is currently being discussed in the Philippine Parliament. I am addressing the EU to see whether, in view of the deteriorating human rights situation in the Philippines, it is not also appropriate to see whether this is compatible with gSP+, this trade preference, because it is clearly stated here that granting GSP+ is linked to respect for human rights. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Neena GILL
text: blue-card question. – Mrs Lochbihler, you made a reference that since December 2014 the Philippines has enjoyed enhanced trade preferences with the EU under the GSP+ Scheme, granted to them in exchange for good performance on human rights and labour rights, the environment and good governance, and this has already provided a major boost to the Philippines. Do you think the Commission should now reconsider, in light of this debate and what we are considering in terms of the back—sliding we have got on human rights and the rule of law and the extrajudicial killings by vigilante groups? Do you think the Commission should take this up now?

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: blue card answer. – As I said in my statement, I think it is time for the Commission to communicate publicly, including to the President, that this might be the next step if there is no immediate reaction from the Philippines. I am very aware that, including in recent years, the Philippine Ambassador here struggled very hard to get this GSP-plus, and we had also seen good progress on the human rights record in the Philippines. It is timely that the EU should consider this matter now. I would add that the Philippines takes the leadership in the ASEAN community at the beginning of 2017, so it is all the more important that, in their foreign relations, they have a good human rights record.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this person, who now governs the Philippines, has promised to clean up the illegal drug trade in order to get elected, and I have to say that around a battle that is right in itself, there is in fact a hateful repression. Colleagues have already mentioned the numbers of killings and extrajudicial killings; I would add to these the fact that the massive campaign against drug dealers and consumers has led to more than 15 000 arrests and prompted more than half a million people to turn themselves in in the hope of receiving the appropriate health treatment, as well as immunity.  I believe that it is right that this resolution should call, together with the voice and appeals of the activists, for the concern that this policy of zero tolerance has been accompanied by harsh violations of human rights. I am convinced, like others, that the European Union must reconsider its position towards the Philippines.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the President of the Philippines, Rodrigo Duterte, proclaimed on 5 September an indefinite national state of emergency. Since the beginning of his presidency, he has launched the so-called war on drugs, during which police have killed more than 929 drug suspects and 1,507 people have been killed by private and paramilitary security forces. We are extremely concerned about the Philippine Government's military and punitive populism commitment, which gives special powers to public and private security forces, leading to a context of impunity and systematic violation of human rights. We call on this House to take all measures in its power to end the state of violence and impunity in the Philippines and to call on the European Commission to discontinue the Generalized Preferences Plus System with which the Philippines benefits from trade preferences in the European Union market, as well as the immediate cancellation of trade treaty negotiations with the Philippines. This must be our response to impunity and systematic violation of human rights.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European If a state tries to restore legality by deregarding the existing legal order, it can easily lead to chaos and anarchy. It is very important that those who raise their word about the many unexplained murders in the Philippines do not approve of drug use or distribution. It's a very dangerous disease that can consume society. Hard action is therefore justified and necessary.  But there's a difference between tough action by state agencies and a crackdown on common criminals. Unfortunately, in the Philippines, this difference is becoming less and less noticeable. It is the responsibility of the political leadership to act against drugs in accordance with the law and not to encourage citizens to vigilantism. Otherwise, chaos, constant fear and uncertainty will be enveloping, which is not in the interest of the Filipinos or the country's international partners.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The events in the Philippines are extremely worrying. We are witnessing a state that has been respected in the international community destroying itself. This is directly related to the newly elected President. There is a danger that the successful democratisation efforts that began after the overthrow of the dictator Marcos will be undone. The press and freedom of expression are being restricted, the introduction of the death penalty is being prepared, and the rule of law is being completely taken out of the way in the fight against drug crime.  Drug traffickers and drug addicts are killed by death squads. This is done under the eyes and with the encouragement of the authorities. Often the mere suspicion is enough to be killed. This is worrying, extremely worrying, and it is to be feared that this systematic erosion of human rights and the rule of law will feed into Philippine society and destroy the state.  Our resolution calls on the Philippine Government to look urgently at these dangerous developments, to move away from the introduction of the death penalty, to investigate crimes and to move on to a sensible and adequate fight against drug crime, because drug crime is indeed a problem, but it cannot be combated with such methods.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, once again the Europeanists are showing that their real will is to attack peoples and national sovereignty.  President Rodrigo Duterte was elected President of the Republic of the Philippines. He is the best-elected president in the history of the Philippines, more than six million ahead of his rival. It has a policy of eradicating crime, a very important phenomenon in the Philippines, and it must be believed that today it is a real problem, a threat even to Filipinos. As ferocious as this real anti-crime policy is, it must remain within the rules of the law, and if there is to be a death penalty, it must be on the scale of punishment and nowhere else. But once again, let the Eurocrats not interfere in the internal affairs of States, let people express themselves, whatever the consequences, let the European Union take care of its own turpitudes, especially in Ukraine, and leave peace to the Philippines and elsewhere, and above all leave peace to the nations for their national sovereignty.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, since coming to power in June 2016, President Duterte has been doing everything possible to rid his country of the scourge of drugs. More than 3,000 people have already died without a chance to have a fair trial. Whether they are sellers or consumers, there is no distinction. The president doesn't give them a chance. Indeed, most of them were summarily executed, indiscriminately, without judgment. This fight against drugs is the president's real workhorse and he is doing everything he can to achieve his goals. Respect for human rights and therefore the right to life does not stand in the way of his ambition to see 100,000 criminals eliminated during the first six months of his term. He also left the door open to civilian vigilantes, who can then kill with impunity, if it is as part of this major drug eradication project in the Philippines. President Duterte's landslide election victory and his enormous popularity among the Filipino population must not exempt him from respecting basic human rights and the urgency in the Philippines is such that the European Union cannot leave its relations with that state unchanged.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I had the opportunity to visit the Philippines a couple of years ago and I saw many developments that were cause for optimism. Corruption was still a problem but being addressed, and judicial reforms, human rights and criminal law were all on President Aquino’s reform agenda. Upon return, I advocated granting the Philippines GSP+ status. Unfortunately, today there is less cause for optimism. The extrajudicial killings taking place in President Duterte’s war on drugs are setting the country back years in terms of human rights and rule of law. We have heard today that more than a thousand people have been killed in police operations or by vigilante groups. His tendency towards international isolation is a further cause for concern.  At a time when South—East Asia’s strategic importance is rapidly increasing, I would urge President Duterte to step up positive engagement with international actors, including the EU and UN, rather than threaten a retreat. I call upon the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, and the Commission to extend a hand of friendship but, at the same time, to make it clear to the Duterte regime that the consequences will be dire.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the Philippines has, in recent times, become the focus of interest for many reasons. The fact is that, with the new government of President Duterte, respect for some self-evident human and social rights is not a priority. Corruption, human rights violations, criminal prosecutions of political opponents are on the agenda, in a country where the phenomenon of child labour concerns two million minors. But it is an oxymoron and a sign of hypocrisy for the European Union, on the one hand, to express its concern about developments in the Philippines and, on the other hand, to conclude a new partnership with that country, as happened last June. A partnership that is uniquely driven by the interests of European multinational companies, which are trying to invest there, in an emerging economy where hunger wages apply. But then, in June, the Philippines still hadn't turned pro-China. So that is what is bothering the European establishment and not the real problems facing the people of this country.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said.
