I, too, think it is important that the prosecution of criminals of any kind is based on the principles of law and the rule of law, and that this cannot be done with murders in order to solve a problem. On the other hand, however, we should not forget to mention that drug traffickers are criminals, murderers who kill our children. That too must be expressed. It must not become a tribute that we see drug trafficking as a socially acceptable situation. The fight against drugs must be strictly implemented, drug trafficking must be tackled; we should support all of this – but it must be done within the framework of the rule of law. You have to see both together. That is why I hope that the Philippines will pursue a successful policy. We have concluded agreements with them, also in the sense that the international court rules concerning the Philippines and the South China Sea are given due consideration by the international community, that international law is also enforced on these issues.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, the Republic of the Philippines has made significant progress in recent years. It is no coincidence that at the end of 2014 the European Union granted the country gsp+ status. At the level of human rights legislation, until recently, the country was a model for other countries in the region, ratifying eight of the nine main conventions, but also as one of the first countries in Asia to declare against the death penalty. Unfortunately, since the presidential election, the situation in the Philippines has changed dramatically. State politics has acquired authoritarian dimensions. The unprecedented murders of 1,800 suspected drug dealers without trial or evidence of alleged crimes are an undemocratic act that we must oppose. I call on the Government of the Philippines to put an end to extrajudicial executions and to respect the international acts that the country has ratified. President Rodrigo Duterte needs to ensure a fair and independent judiciary and engage in dialogue with international leaders and organizations to get the country back on the path of democracy.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, what this country is doing is appalling. The war on drugs is not actually a war on drugs, it is a war on people.  They say people take drugs to try and experience another reality. Listening to many people in the debate here, I wonder what drugs you are on, because you talk about a war on drugs and you talk about how cartels should not be promoted in selling these drugs, and that we have got to do something about it. Yet, at the same time, I can walk out of here and I can buy as dangerous a drug as exists called alcohol around here, and you do not seem to have a problem with it. When you are having a debate and a discussion on something and young people tune into it and they see that it does not add up, because 2 + 2 is not 5, they tune out. They will tune out of this debate as well, because I hear people here say they are against drugs and I have seen them drink alcohol. Make up your minds.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by reiterating the solidarity of the European Union with the people and the government of the Philippines following the Abu Sayyaf attack in the City of Davao on 2 September. Since the beginning of the term of President Duterte there has been progress – or at lease continuity – in some important areas. An indefinite ceasefire with the National Democratic Front was concluded, the peace process in Mindanao has been reinvigorated and the ratification of the partnership cooperation agreement (PCA) is ongoing.  These positive steps are overshadowed by the war on drugs declared by the President. The fight against drugs was the number one promise in President Duterte’s election campaign and remains highly popular. He also promised the reinstatement of the death penalty. According to the latest official figures, there have been more than 2 400 people killed either during or outside police operations between 1 July and 4 September.  Against the background of these figures, in various statements we have expressed our significant consensus in several meetings with high-ranking officials. However, necessary responses to the drug problem must be carried out in full compliance with human rights, the rule of law and the right to due process. We have also reiterated our principal position on the death penalty. President Duterte has repeatedly expressed his administration’s commitment to human rights and he has warned the police against any abuse of authority. In the coming weeks and months there will be several high-level meetings with the Philippines to discuss this further and to share our concerns. We will be alert to see how President Duterte’s commitments on human rights are applied. The High Representative, Federika Mogherini, is expected to meet with her counterpart twice over the coming weeks. The GSP+ monitoring mission is scheduled for before the end of the year. We will hear – and this is more or less in answer to a question – and we will underline that during the next monitoring period, 2016 to 2017, we have strong expectations that the Philippines will strengthen its human rights legal framework. Following the entry into force of the PCA, we will engage in a formal human rights dialogue. We are also looking at ways to provide further support to the Philippines in a comprehensive approach to combat drug trafficking in line with our shared values. And, of course, we will continue to work closely with the Filipinos on this and other issues. Of course, I would like to congratulate the authors for their work and for this very productive discussion in this political body.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. We must strongly condemn drug trafficking and abuse in the Philippines, pointing out that illicit drugs pose a threat to young Filipinos, as well as one of the most serious social problems.  While welcoming the government's intention to reduce the high levels of crime and corruption in the country, it is necessary to adopt specific policies and programmes, including prevention and recovery measures, without focusing exclusively on violent repression, while also ensuring respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition, the authorities should launch an immediate, thorough, effective and impartial investigation into the extraordinarily high number of people killed during police operations, in order to identify all those responsible, hand them over to a competent and impartial civil court and apply the criminal sanctions provided for by law, while ensuring adequate protection for human rights defenders, trade unionists and journalists.  The EU must use all available instruments to help the Government of the Philippines comply with its international human rights obligations.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Somalia.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, Somalia’s long-running conflict situation continues to leave civilians dead, wounded and displaced in large numbers. In July the UNHCR reported that forced evictions due to an ongoing military offensive resulted in almost 28 000 new displacements. International human rights and humanitarian organisations continue to report serious abuses against people living in informal displacement camps and in government-controlled areas, including rape and forced evictions. According to international human rights organisations and the UN mission in Somalia, journalists continue to be killed, threatened, arbitrarily detained and denied due process or fair trial guarantees. This is an issue of major concern, particularly given the fact that elections should take place very soon. We think that the European Union should support any effort to protect the population. We should also assist the Government of Somalia in its work to build peace and stability. On the other hand, the EU should better monitor the situation in order ensure accountability for abuses committed, fair and timely elections and legal reforms in order to secure respect for human rights. We hope that this joint resolution can help in this.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, nearly five years on since the expulsion of Al—Shabab from Mogadishu, the security situation in Somalia has clearly improved. As we now head towards democratic elections, those developments are clearly very welcome. However, the picture is still mixed. Whilst yesterday leaders from neighbouring countries attended a summit hosted in Mogadishu for the first time in decades, this cannot allow us to ignore the fact that, only two weeks earlier, at least ten people were killed in a terrorist attack outside the presidential palace. Continued and improved EU support for the African Union Mission to Somalia (AMISOM) is therefore vital, just as it is important to ensure the political support for the hugely anti-piracy and very successful CSDP mission EU NAVFOR Atalanta in the Indian Ocean off the coast of Somalia. This should be strengthened.  I also take this personal opportunity to encourage official talks between the Somaliland authorities in Hargeisa and the Government in Mogadishu. The union was never approved by a referendum and it is only right that the re-recognition of an independent Somaliland can remain open politically through peaceful negotiation. The status quo in place since 1991 is to the detriment of both sides and of course to the long-term stability of the Horn of Africa.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, Somalia’s position is a strategic one. Restoring stability and securing this region from terrorist attacks is especially vital after two decades of civil war and Al—Shabab terrorism. The country is on the right path out of crisis now, but nothing is yet guaranteed. The 30 August and 26 July terrorist attacks in Mogadishu show that Al—Shabab is still active. Therefore, efficient support for the positive political process that was launched four years ago is needed.  It is still a long way to the 2020 elections. Political parties have yet to be started, but first of all the inclusion of all interested actors, freedom of expression and the creation of an independent Human Rights Commission will be vital. The continued presence of African Union peacekeeping forces will be important as the security situation remains precarious in different parts of the country.  As our report says, there cannot be security without development and development without security. To break this cycle there need to be joint efforts by the EU and the international community.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: author. – Mr President, after decades of conflict the people of Somalia are still suffering. It is true that Somalia’s problems are more contained than ten years ago but Somalis still cannot feel safe in their country. The only way to change this is through a democratically elected government, a government that has the power to guarantee the safety and the rights of its citizens and is complemented by stable and legitimate institutions that uphold the rule of law. The upcoming elections, which must be transparent and fair, are the first step towards achieving this. Somalia is going through an important political transformation. The international community must under all cirumstances remain engaged in the country. To pull out now would unravel the progress that has slowly been made. We cannot risk Somalia falling into the hands of terrorists.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, the situation is unsustainable in Somalia. Pressure from terrorist groups such as Al-Shabab, widespread lack of security have led to more than one million internally displaced persons and one million refugees in neighbouring countries. With the excuse of the fight against terrorism, the Government applies extraordinary measures, detains journalists, coerfies freedom of expression and blocks access to the internet. There are also no reliable courts to judge these arrests which, if tried, end up in military courts, without any guarantee. The human drama is immense and the weakest victims are the children, recruited as child soldiers by the different factions. The European Union has been involved through a development and security assistance fund, but from here we ask for more involvement and effective control over the use of these funds. This statement seems necessary and also balanced, because it also denounces abuses committed by forces that should install security, such as those of the African Union Mission in Somalia, especially cases of sexual violence and the use of women as a weapon of war in these conflicts. Finally, we call on Somalia not to be forgotten, to become an important country on our European Foreign Affairs agenda, and to make an effective and clear call to countries that welcome their refugees to act accordingly and be realistic and not to make them return to a country that is now anything but safe. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Sebastia, yes there is a terrible situation in Somalia and I refer to a special subject: the killing of children. More than 2 000 died last year. Do you not think, as we have Commissioner Stylianides with us here today, that the European Union should launch a programme for the benefit of the Somali children – an EU programme for their education and health mainly?

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: blue card answer. – I must agree with you because this is a priority for us. It must be a priority for the European Union to take care of these children who are recruited as soldiers, who are fighting in a war, who are using terrible weapons and who are losing their childhood and the capacity to be normal people in the future. So I think this programme must of course be a priority for the European Union.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the long-running armed conflict in Somalia continues to cause enormous problems. Despite the commitments made by the Somali Government, the continuing situation of political instability prevents the country from starting the necessary reform processes, especially in the field of justice and security. Many journalists have been threatened and arrested through trials carried out in accordance with standards that are not in line with international law.  In January 2016, the Somali President signed a new media and information law that still contains several restrictions on freedom of expression. The need for the Somali people to have free media is particularly important in view of the forthcoming electoral process, and that is why it is right to call for attention, including at international level, to ensure that the Government of Somalia protects and protects journalists and revises the legislation so as to allow effective freedom of the press and information, respecting the right to freedom of expression and, more generally, the protection of human rights, which have been largely neglected and violated for a long time.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, an estimated 4.7 million people in Somalia – which means 38% of the population – live in need of drought, famine or forced migration aid. This is the perfect breeding ground for instability and violence, in which pirates and terrorist groups camp at their own devices. In addition, gender-based violence in Somalia exists at unacceptable levels and must be contained. The African Union Military Mission is not only complicit, but in some cases perpetuates it. The European Union should play a role in promoting these public policies. However, our support for military missions is far from that and simply responds to the promotion of geostrategic and commercial interests. Let us be consistent because, as the Resolution recalls, stability and peace can only be achieved through social cohesion, sustainable development and policies based on democratic principles, in which dignity and human rights are fully respected.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, in the case of Somalia, we are talking about a state that has practically decomposed in recent decades and whose citizens therefore cannot and could not invoke any rights. I think that, above all, we need to help ensure elementary security so that the foundations of society can be restored at all. The European Union should therefore work, together with Somalia's regional partners, such as the UN, to gradually make Somalia a state capable of fulfilling its basic functions and whose own citizens not only need not fear it, but can count on its help, e.g. when their lives are threatened by a private army controlling which territory. We must help build Somalia as a state where respect for human rights will be the agenda of that state, not just that of the international community. The upcoming elections in 2020 are a good opportunity to do so.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, with elections this year, Somalia is in a crucial period of transition. It is in all our interests that it does not miss its date with history, yet no ballot can bring about improvement unless fundamental rights are respected and there is minimal degree of stability. We need to make sure that the African Union's peacekeeping force AMISOM does its job protecting civilians and that accountability is insured for all allegations of abuse, indiscriminate killings and sexual exploitation. As the biggest contributor to AMISOM, the EU can play a key role by monitoring programmes and bolstering investigation and prosecution capacity. I also urge Somalian authorities, federal and regional, to put an immediate stop to harassment of journalists and protect them from terrorist attacks carried out by Al-Shabab. Crucially, if there is any hope for Somalia to have a bright future it starts with its younger generation.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in July and August the Islamic fundamentalist group Al-Shabab was responsible for several deadly attacks in Somalia. One of the most deplorable attacks was directed against an African Union base, resulting in 13 deaths, including, moreover, UN officials.  As we know, the fight against Al-Shabab and other armed groups depends largely on the African Union's peacekeeping mission. That is why it is vital to support this mission, as well as all initiatives for stabilisation and national reconciliation. The European Union is the main funder of the African Union mission, with an allocated value of EUR 286 million by 2020. Such support must be ensured and even possibly strengthened, but greater transparency is needed, on the other hand.  The European Union cannot tolerate peacekeepers, supported and funded by it, often accused of human rights abuses, including indiscriminate killings of civilians and sexual violence. The European Union must firmly demand that these crimes be investigated and that their perpetrators do not remain unpunished.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I want to support my speaker. It is very good that we are currently discussing a resolution on Somalia, because – as has already been said – there will be a reform in the personnel composition of parliament at the turn of September and October and then the election of a new head of state. I believe that the debates that we are having here in general about the need to support this country economically, to support particularly suffering children in Somalia, are very correct, but in my opinion they should be conditional on the democratic process in this country continuing. Let us wait, for example, for how the reform will take place in parliament, how the election of the Head of State will take place and how we will approach 2020, when new elections are due to take place. If democratisation and stabilisation relations continue, then it is right for the European Union to support this country, to support the suffering population and children in the first place.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I support the resolution, which I have signed. In 2016, we are 25 years away from the overthrow of dictator Barre in Somalia, a reversal that, unfortunately, has opened up a new blood cycle that remains open. As a result of these 25 years of interracial violence, Somalia is one of the poorest countries in Africa, with a life expectancy of only 55 years and one-sixth of the population living outside its borders. The upcoming elections, which normally have to be held by the end of the year, do not seem to be able to improve the situation in the country. The major issue for Western states is therefore to keep al Shabaab Islamists out of power. However, with their interventions, foreign powers do not have a constructive effect, as the experience of the last 25 years shows. The best thing for the European Union to do, therefore, is to stay away and not get involved in political games that do not concern it. No participation in the dirty games taking place in the Horn of Africa. Solidarity with Christian victims of Islamic terrorism.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we had very productive and constructive discussions, and I know Somalia because I visited the country and I met the Minister and other officials. Regarding education, let me confirm that I have already put in place emergency projects for education in the country, which we want to sustain and expand. You know that I focus on education – and especially in this area in Somalia – and I think it is important to insist on this project. Somalia often hits the headlines, seldom positively. However, following decades of civil war in the area, over the past few years we have witnessed progress – albeit a bit slow – towards state building and democratisation. The forthcoming electoral process will not take the form of universal suffrage, the electoral form familiar to us. Some 14 000 people will be involved and, while they will represent only a fraction of the population, it is an improvement from 2012 when 135 clan elders selected the members of parliament. This should be a stepping stone to ‘one person, one vote’ elections in 2020. Female participation and representation are paramount. The EU has, throughout, consistently insisted on securing a Somali commitment to 30% female representation in parliament. More than two decades of civil war have had a devastating effect on respect for human rights. Women, children and minorities in general, displaced persons and persons with disabilities have often paid the highest price. Abuse, domestic violence and discrimination against women are flagrant and, although Somalia has ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, children remain victims of all the parties to the armed conflict. The EU delegation started implementation of a new set of measures in 2016 through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR), specifically targeting the nexus between human rights and security. One of the main aims is to develop a better connection between human-rights activists and organisations and the government, including the police, the legal profession and the judiciary, in order to provide high-quality, accountable and rights-based safety and security services for victims of sexual and gender-based violence, and thereby break the culture of impunity for the perpetrators of such crimes. On the death penalty also, it is disturbing that Somalia has ended the de facto moratorium. Capital punishment is a serious violation of human rights and dignity. As Somalia embarks on the electoral process, the UN published last month a timely report on the right to freedom of expression. Freedom of expression is key in building a democratic nation, and even more so in times of political transition, with a view to providing space for public debate. Somali journalists censured for such debate are continually attacked, and harassed and sometimes arrested. Media outlets are being closed and proper investigation and prosecution remain rare – leading to a general sense of impunity. These and other issues confirm that building functioning justice institutions is one of the most important tasks in terms of ensuring the rule of law in Somalia. Communities in areas recovering from the activities of al-Shabaab must benefit from peace dividends, including in the form of justice delivery after decades of being left at the mercy of these militants. The European Union is closely working with Somalia to address these matters and we remain committed to continuing to do so with the new leadership.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – 4 years after the appointment of 275 members of the Parliament, Somalia has consistently taken steps to rebuild state institutions. He is working on a law on political parties and the creation of an independent national Commission on Human Rights, and is preparing for parliamentary and presidential elections this autumn. It is important that the electoral process is transparent and democratic, and that freedom of expression and media pluralism are guaranteed. Unfortunately, the terrorist group As-Shabab is destabilising the country by carrying out frequent attacks in areas it controls, as well as in Mogadishu itself. This is also one of the reasons why elections will not be universal this time around. The 11 millionth nation will be represented by 14,000 electors. I hope that the EU will actively support Somalia in building democracy and ensuring security in the country, and that citizens will be able to take part in the general elections in 2020.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on eight motions for resolutions on Zimbabwe.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for many years the people of Zimbabwe have been suffering under an authoritarian regime led by President Mugabe, who retains power through corruption, violence, rigged elections and through brutal apparatus.  Well, today the situation in Zimbabwe is getting worse and worse, in a climate of impunity for the violation of human rights. Since June, numerous civil society figures have engaged in dozens of public protests across the country. The police responded with violent methods, indiscriminately using batons and tear gas. Hundreds of people have been injured, arrested and charged with public violence.  We cannot forget, in this context, that the Government of Zimbabwe and the European Union have jointly signed the National Indicative Programme and, as part of this strategy for joint cooperation, the European Union has allocated EUR 234 million to Zimbabwe as development assistance. I believe that the European Union must effectively monitor the implementation of these funds in order to ensure that Zimbabwe uses this sum in the areas envisaged, such as support for civil society, human rights and agriculture.  Through this resolution, we call for regular elections to be held as soon as possible, in order to create a pluralist, prosperous and human rights-respecting democracy.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Mr President, apparently the elderly President Mugabe after 36 years in power – bringing to his country patronage, kleptocracy, poverty, violence and massive demonstrations – still wants real action. I therefore call for the immediate release of political prisoners, respect for human rights, impartial provision of humanitarian aid, and a peaceful transfer of power in upcoming elections.

name: David McALLISTER
text: author. –  Mr President, the situation in Zimbabwe, as we have just heard, is deeply worrying. This country, which is suffering under the authoritarian regime of Mr Mugabe for 36 years now, left the path of democracy years ago. The political, social and economic challenges Zimbabwe is currently facing combined with an unprecedented drought have created more poverty and more inequality than ever. In the last few months, massive protests against the regime were brutally crushed by the police. This increase in violence at demonstrations in the country is not acceptable. Just this week, the police announced a fresh one-month ban on demonstrations in Harare. Today, we as the European Parliament once again send out a strong and clear message to the authorities in Zimbabwe. The rule of law must prevail under all circumstances and the freedom of association, assembly and expression must be protected by all means. With this resolution we condemn the ongoing human rights abuses and call for the full respect of civil and political freedom, particularly in view of the next important elections in 2018.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Author. Mr President, Zimbabwe would have everything to succeed economically, socially and politically if there were not a major obstacle. This obstacle is called Mugabe, who acts according to the motto "I'm there, I'm staying there, and when I'm gone, it's going to stay in the family." As the system is locked, there is little chance of being able to right a completely rotten situation in the immediate future. My group supports the measures proposed in this resolution and encourages all efforts to rebuild the country. We support all efforts that are likely to strengthen movements that aspire to restore democracy and justice in Zimbabwe. Therefore, the countries of the Southern African region are called upon to become more involved in solving this problem, which is, above all, an African problem, but we are at their side.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Author. – Three years ago, Mugabe's ZANU-PF won the elections in Zimbabwe and the unity government came to an end. Under that unity government, we saw some economic growth. It's gone now. Millions of people need food aid, salaries are not paid, civil servants are being laid off en masse. In short, the country is bankrupt again and the ZANU government is falling into repression tactics of the past. The protests of the last few months have been hard-hit by the government. Activists disappear behind bars and demonstration bans are being sprinkled. The European Parliament today wants to give a heart to the people of Zimbabwe. One thing remains about our joint resolution: nostalgia for sanctions is not appropriate. Mugabe and his relatives still have travel restrictions and should remain so, but the effect of further sanctions was really worked out two years ago. I have therefore tabled an amendment to our joint resolution to put it into words.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, following a series of anti-government demonstrations in Zimbabwe, President Mugabe, who has been in power for 36 years, has taken a strict repressive line. For fear of losing power, he has already announced his intention to stand in the 2018 presidential election – but it is hard to think how he can complete a new term, which would end at the venerable age of 99. The president has also been accused of voluntarily deciding to stop food aid in rural areas most hostile to his policy and hit by the worst drought in a hundred years.  With this urgent resolution we are calling on Zimbabwe to respect its international obligations and to guarantee the independence of the judiciary and free demonstrations. The European Union can play a key role in this delicate phase by maintaining and, if necessary, strengthening restrictive measures against persons and entities linked to the Mugabe regime, at least until there is a political reversal aimed at protecting the population and respecting democratic principles and the rule of law.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, this is not the first time zimbabwe has been discussed here. Its president, Robert Mugabe, has been in power since 1980, he is 92 years old, and is indeed already a candidate to succeed him. The unprecedented scale of the country's protest today must be highlighted. The Court of Justice's decision to overturn the government's ban on demonstrations is a sign of the crisis in the country. Yes, we must call for the release of all political prisoners, including those who have only demonstrated peacefully. But we also need to address the economic and social causes of popular discontent. 80% of the population lives below the poverty line. 80% of GDP is dedicated to debt repayment in the world record-breaking country. It is also one of the most corrupt countries in the world. At a time when the European Union is re-establishing its development aid, the traceability of this aid is an urgent necessity, as is the cancellation of part of the debt, provided that the efforts of the international community actually benefit the population, and especially women. 68% of them are victims of violence.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this is the second time in this mandate that we have discussed the situation in Zimbabwe. Last year we expressed concern about the harassment of human rights defenders, opponents, journalists and other members of civil society. Today we are obliged to condemn the violent repression of the protests of recent months. That's right, the protests have multiplied. The citizens of Zimbabwe have enough reason to protest. Corruption, mismanagement, drought-amplified poverty, falling mineral prices. After three and a half decades of rule by Robert Mugabe, the only leader Zimbabwe has had since independence, the country is bankrupt, it is completely destroyed. The resolution we are voting on denounces this situation and represents a call for change, a political transition based on free and fair elections, respect for human rights and the rule of law. Here's the only way for Zimbabwe.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if necessary, I would remind the Zimbabwean authorities of the content of Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement and its obligations on respect for human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law. I would also remind you of the restrictive measures to which certain authorities are subject, primarily President Mugabe, who has been in office since 1980.  We can no longer tolerate the violence with which the security forces systematically suppress all voices of dissent in the country. We rebel against violence against women, arbitrary arrests, interference of powers, disappearances and arbitrary killings. The people of Zimbabwe are calling for a peaceful and democratic transition based on free elections, the alternation of powers and respect for human rights. We will stand by you to support you in your political dialogue with the authorities and to denounce any violation of democratic principles.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Repressive regimes expose themselves and this historical fact also applies to President Mugabe's reign of terror in Zimbabwe. While a third of the population now relies on food aid to survive and the majority of Zimbabweans eat only once a day, the buying and pivoting of Mugabe's wife Grace gives her the telling nickname Gucci Grace. Mugabe's reign has no borders even after 36 years, regardless of the free fall in which he has now brought his country through pure mismanagement. The 92-year-old Mugabe has now run again for the 2018 elections, because only God can, by his own admission, extach him from office. That's right, Mr. Chairman. Meanwhile, many in Zimbabwe face a lot of concern for the future after Mugabe. After all, a successor from the ranks of his accomplices to the national ruin is anything but an enticing prospect. Zimbabwe's suffering civilian population must therefore be able to count on the EU at this exciting stage.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the When the current corrupt President Mugabe took power in Zimbabwe in the early 1980s, he was hailed by the left as a great freedom fighter, but he did not create prosperity, democracy and equality, but completely destroyed these values in what was once so rich Zimbabwe-Rhodesia. Racist expropriations, expulsions, massacres of white farmers, and cronyism and corruption made this formerly rich country one of the poorest economies in the world.  And now the European Union is supporting Mugabe and his ZANU party with EUR 234 million in development aid, without claiming anything in return, without respect for human rights, without demanding the return of the expropriated farms, and, above all, without calling for the fight against corruption. And I wonder if we are still right in our minds.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – With this resolution we condemn the brutal regime, the brutal dictatorship imposed by Robert Mugabe, and send a message of support to the people of Zimbabwe. What is happening there is an absolutely brutal, violent and faceted violation of human rights, of freedom of expression, of the right to a fair trial. For example, protesters are beaten by the police, they are arrested, they are political influence on judges. In September this year, police banned all demonstrations hours before 18 parties preparing to make a peaceful demonstration could do so. Now, those protesting against horror and poverty are united by social media, which makes the government respond by trying to control the internet even more strongly. This year, four million people in Zimbabwe need to receive food aid and they must reach them and not be politically manipulated.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, my colleagues have already described the plight in Zimbabwe, I just want to add so much to this that, for me, the main point in this resolution is paragraph 7, which clearly states that the lifting of sanctions against Zimbabwe was premature and that the Commission should reconsider how to impose sanctions on a regime whose horrors have been described in detail here. In short, some of my colleagues have said this, helping the regime of the current President Mugabe by sending around EUR 200 million there is wrong. The money will still not be handed to people who need the money, ending up in the hands of supporters of the regime and the Mugabe family itself. So point 7 is important. I am therefore ready to support this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Republic of Zimbabwe is now facing a very serious economic crisis. , would have decided to stop food aid to the approximately 4 million citizens affected by the drought and no longer able to feed themselves.  For some months now, the country has been in the throes of violent demonstrations about the economic and political situation. The European Union must condemn the blocking of government aid against drought-stricken populations and ensure that the funding granted to Zimbabwe is actually allocated to the sectors concerned. We must work towards a peaceful transition of power in the wake of democracy and respect for human rights.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, colleagues, I definitely personally share your concerns and your views on the situation in Zimbabwe and I strongly believe that this very constructive and productive discussion and of course the coming resolution will be very positive steps for the people of Zimbabwe. The European Union attaches great importance to strengthening the rule of law, human rights and the consolidation of democracy in Zimbabwe, as set out in the government's own constitutional reform agenda. These are essential elements of our relations, which underpin inclusion and sustainable growth and development. Since the creation of the government of national unity in 2009, the EU has taken successive steps towards easing measures applying to Zimbabwe in response to improvements in the human rights situation, such as the adoption of a progressive constitution in 2013, overwhelmingly endorsed by the people of Zimbabwe, and secondly, a peaceful election the same year with a general improvement in the governance and human rights situation. Zimbabwe is now at a critical juncture. The economy shows increasing signs of extortion, which is leading to an increase in social tensions and in violence at public protests. The EU has publicly expressed its concern at this increase in violence in a statement of 13 August. The freedom to demonstrate and present a petition is enshrined in the Zimbabwean constitution along with freedom of expression and it must be respected. The EU has called upon all parties to ensure that these rights are exercised peacefully and fully respected by the authorities. Furthermore, the European Union has fully associated itself with the statement of the Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission on public protests and police conduct and joins its call for the authorities to ensure that the perpetrators of human rights violations are prosecuted. Through the process of re-engagement, the EU has now a broader scope of engagement on human rights and democracy issues through development cooperation, through which it supports the judiciary and Zimbabwe's electoral commission, as well as the implementation of the provisions of the constitution.  The European Union remains fully supportive of the Government of Zimbabwe's ambition to re-engage with the international community and international financial institutions. Economic reforms alone, however, are unlikely to be sufficient in achieving full re-engagement. They will need to be accompanied by a demonstrable commitment to uphold the rule of law and human rights, as set out in Zimbabwe's own constitution.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at 12.00 p.m. (The sitting was suspended at 11.55 a.m. pending voting time and resumed at 12.00 p.m.)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item is voting time.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next vote on The Commissioner-designate Sir Julian King will be conducted by secret ballot. (The vote was taken) (The President announced the result of the vote) Votes cast: 638 votes in favour: 394 votes against: 161 abstentions: 83 I note that Sir Julian King has been elected a Member of the Commission. (Applause) Commissioner, I congratulate you on your election. I do not think it is an exaggeration to say that you accept your office in special circumstances. That is why, on behalf of the European Parliament, we wish you every success in your performance of the office. Since you were an outspoken supporter of the United Kingdom's membership of the European Union, it is also logical that you, as Commissioner, should carry out your work in the interests of the European Union during your time as Commissioner. Congratulations! (Applause) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which If you do not like it in the European Parliament, you are not obliged to stay. (Laughter and applause)

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: Mr President, I have just listened carefully and you have explained to Members who were not happy with this decision to leave the Chamber. I would remind you, Mr President, and this is certainly the subject of a point of order, that we have not been appointed by Mr Schulz, we have been democratically elected by the French people.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, I would like to introduce an oral amendment to Article 6(2) after point (c). It would read as follows: ‘minimum administrative pecuniary sanctions of at least the amount of the profits gained or losses avoided or the losses inflicted on third parties because of the infringement, where those can be determined;’.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to request the postponement of the vote on the draft legislative resolution under Rule 61(2) of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, we would like to change the formulation ‘additional administrative burdens’ to ‘unnecessary administrative burdens;’.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted against the appointment of Julian King, who is a convinced Europeanist, an enemy of national sovereignty.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. If a literal interpretation of the treaty allows the United Kingdom to retain to date the rights of membership of the European Union, including appointing a Commissioner, it also remains bound by its obligations. Under the treaty, London is solemnly committed to fair cooperation with its partners. That is why Article 50 TUE should be activated within a reasonable time to start exit negotiations, and the UK should resist the temptation to negotiate bilateral trade agreements with third countries, as Jean-Claude Juncker has pointed out. In this context, the appointment of a British Commissioner for Security, a policy of which the United Kingdom has never been a full member, was not self-evident. It will be recalled that Commissioner Jonathan Hill resigned in the aftermath of the referendum results, with remarkable dignity, and that the United Kingdom has renounced the rotating presidency of the Council.  That is why, without questioning Julian King's resume, or the very principle of creating a security portfolio, I voted against this appointment.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing a new Member of the European Commission. Jonathan Hill, the EU's Financial Services Commissioner, decided to resign after voting to leave the EU in June after british (UK) citizens voted to leave the EU. The UK Government then proposed to the European Commission diplomat Julian King.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Julian King as Lord Hill as European Commissioner.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted against it because we believe that the creation of this new post as Commissioner, as well as the concept of a Security Union itself, seems to us to be nothing more than a symbolic fact with no real capacity for change.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to point out that I abstained in the vote of British Commissioner Julian King as my group has done. I understand that governed by the Treaties the United Kingdom has to have a Commissioner until he leaves the Union for good but what we do not understand is the portfolio assigned to him by President Juncker taking into account that the United Kingdom in this area, as well as in many others, enjoys the right to opt-out.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ As inseparable as the two appear to be, the appointment of Julian King as Commissioner should be separated from Brexit. The United Kingdom is entitled to a commissioner regardless of the outcome of the referendum, as long as it is not formally separated from the EU. King did the hearing correctly, and that's why I voted in.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today on the appointment of Sir Julian King as Commissioner for Security of the Union because I believe that the Candidate Commissioner has all the necessary conditions to be able to perform the relevant functions in the best possible way.     Sir Julian King has been appointed by the UK government after Jonathan Hill resigned following the Brexit vote last June. As Commissioner for Security of the Union, Julian King will continue the implementation of the European Security Agenda and contribute to the creation of an efficient and concrete Security Union. He will work under the leadership of the Commission's first Vice-President, Frans Timmermans, supporting Commissioner Dimitris Avramopoulos' work on migration, home affairs and citizenship. For the first time, Parliament is deciding on the appropriateness of a Commissioner who will have to work in Brussels during his country's exit from the EU. Sir Julian King, currently ambassador to France, is an expert on international and European relations. From 2009 to 2011, Sir King served as ambassador to Ireland.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 Following an evaluation of sir Julian King's appointment proposal, we are voting in favour of his appointment as a member of the European Commission.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Sir Julian King as UK Commissioner for the Commission. Congratulating him on his appointment, I wish him well in his work.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the appointment of Sir Julian King as Commissioner for the Security Union.  My group and I had no hesitation about the qualifications of the candidate commissioner and the fact that he is qualified to fill the position. However, the hearings in Parliament are not only intended to assess the candidate's personal suitability, but also the political context and thus the candidate's suitability for a particular portfolio. In this regard, we have considered that the allocation of the EU security portfolio to Julian King raises questions given that the UK will soon begin proceedings to leave the EU and has always requested and obtained opt-outs in the context of justice and home affairs measures.  Nevertheless, I welcome Jean-Claude Juncker's creation of this new portfolio within the Commission. As Commissioner for the Security Union, Julian King will be tasked with supporting the establishment of the European Security Agenda and contributing to a union for operational and effective security, which I have been advocating for a long time.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament has given its support to the appointment of Britain's Julian King as Commissioner for Security. In the current context, appointing a British Commissioner is a bad signal. While a literal interpretation of the Treaty allows the United Kingdom to retain to date the rights of membership of the European Union, including appointing a Commissioner, it also remains bound by its obligations. Under the treaty, London is solemnly committed to fair cooperation with its partners. That is why Article 50 TUE should be activated within a reasonable time to start exit negotiations, and the UK should resist the temptation to negotiate bilateral trade agreements with third countries, as Jean-Claude Juncker has pointed out. In this context, the appointment of a British Commissioner for Security, a policy of which the United Kingdom has never been a full member, was not self-evident. It will be recalled that Commissioner Jonathan Hill resigned in the aftermath of the referendum results, with remarkable dignity, and that the United Kingdom has renounced the rotating presidency of the Council.  That is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Sir Julian King is the UK's new Commissioner. Before his election, he had to face questions from MPs this week at the so-called "grilling." Its task will be to create an EU Security Union. His predecessor Jonathan Hill resigned after the Brexit vote. The new Commissioner will now be assigned the portfolio of the Security Union. Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has created the separate security portfolio specifically, responding to a request from the EPP Group. Sir King was previously the UK's ambassador to Paris and is considered a pro-European. I am convinced that Sir King will work for a common EU solution to the current security challenges. Its task will be to establish an EU Security Union. This is particularly important in the fight against terrorism.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against it because we believe that the creation of this new post as Commissioner, as well as the concept of a Security Union itself, seems to us to be nothing more than a symbolic fact with no real capacity for change.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted to support the appointment of Sir Julian King because we are pleased that he has committed to making sure existing EU legislation in the field of security is implemented by national governments, and that he has confirmed he would work closely with the European Parliament to ensure this was achieved. He has also reassured us that further work would be carried out to combat radicalisation, and that fundamental rights would be central to an effective security strategy. It is also important that the Commissioner-designate has committed to carrying out a comprehensive review of all existing EU security measures, which will enable us to assess what measures work well and where legislation is not effectively implemented by Member States.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against the appointment of Julian King to the Commission, because he is a convinced Europeanist who is absolutely not representative of the majority of the British people. Wanting to sit on the Commission to strengthen the EU when its people voted for Brexit, you have to dare to do it!

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted against this inauguration, unlike a huge majority of my colleagues in the European Parliament, because it is incomprehensible today, after the British vote on 23 June, to continue as if nothing had happened! We welcomed the decision of his predecessor, Jonathan HILL, to resign as Commissioner, in view of the results of the vote. However, without having any complaints about the man, an experienced and well-known diplomat, I can only disapprove that we are now rushing to validate the appointment of a new Commissioner with, moreover, a broad portfolio on security - oh so strategic, without conditions or guarantees on the intentions of the British Government, in particular with regard to the triggering of Article 50 , supposed to mark the beginning of official exit negotiations. "Brexit means Brexit," as Theresa MAY has repeated extensively this summer, and I can only deplore the lack of coherence and logic of the political signal sent by Parliament on 15 September.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Sir Julian King is a convinced and smug European. His vision of the European Union is the opposite of ours, namely a Europe of nations and freedoms, respectful of the sovereignty of the Member States. I could only oppose his appointment, so I voted against it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this appointment because I believe that the Security Union, whose leadership the new Commissioner is in charge of, contains many clearings and could lead to a loss of fundamental freedoms, in greater vulnerability to migrants, arbitrary political sanctions and renewed support for authoritarian governments of European defeat in the name of the fight against terrorism.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 The content of my vote in question is not disclosed as it was a secret ballot pursuance to Article 182(2) of the Treaty. 1.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this appointment. Julian King is a convinced Europeanist, the opposite of our vision of a Europe of nations. I also made a reminder to the rules that I invite you to find on my social networks.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. As soon as the Brexit results were announced, British European Commissioner Jonathan Hill resigned. However, until Article 50 is activated, the UK remains a full member of the EU and must be represented in the Commission by a Commissioner. The uk's nominee, Julian King, was Catherine Ashton's chief of staff when she was commissioner herself, which does not bode well. Moreover, the position of Security Commissioner, responsible for the fight against terrorism and crime, seems to me to be too sensitive as the kick noises of the European army demanded by the Commission approach. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. As Julian King was a convinced Europeanist, contrary to our vision of a Europe of nations, I voted against his appointment.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of the new Commissioner appointed by the United Kingdom, because I believe that he presents the necessary conditions to hold the post successfully, at this difficult time for all who is post-Brexit.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I do not think Julian King is fit to become European Commissioner; it is just one eurotechnocrat among many. I'm speaking out against his appointment.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted to support the appointment of Sir Julian King because we are pleased that he has committed to making sure existing EU legislation in the field of security is implemented by national governments, and that he has confirmed he would work closely with the European Parliament to ensure this was achieved. He has also reassured us that further work would be carried out to combat radicalisation, and that fundamental rights would be central to an effective security strategy. It is also important that the Commissioner-designate has committed to carrying out a comprehensive review of all existing EU security measures, which will enable us to assess what measures work well and where legislation is not effectively implemented by Member States.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the appointment of a new a Member of the European Commission.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I can only appreciate Sir King's profile and declare that I would vote in favour of his appointment.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Mr King is a convinced European. He is therefore clearly completely out of step with the majority of his countrymen and I think his appointment as Commissioner is not a good idea. So I'm voting against it.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted against this appointment for the sake of consistency. European citizens have seen that 27 Member States are now meeting at EU summits, as was the case in Bratislava in September. So how can we explain to them that a state whose majority of voters has decided to leave the Union can appoint a new European Commissioner? Traditional rules must adapt to political reality, not the other way around. I do not question Sir Julian King's competence, but I hope that the complete blurring of Brexit will end. Last June, the resignation of Jonathan Hill, who no longer found legitimacy in the performance of his duties as European Commissioner, had begun the political and institutional process. It is urgent that the negotiations, led in particular by former European Commissioner Michel Barnier, begin and that the famous 'Article 50' is activated, so that the political and economic relationship between the Union and the United Kingdom is clarified.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Following Jonathan Hill's resignation following the UK referendum result on BREXIT, the British Prime Minister proposed the name Julian King to replace him in the remainder of his term of office. After the hearing of the Commissioner-designate in the Parliamentary Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on 12 September obtained a positive assessment of his performance by the colleagues present, we voted today by secret ballot to his appointment, which was in my favour - although I regret the fact that this substitution gave rise to this substitution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against it because we believe that the creation of this new post as Commissioner, as well as the concept of a Security Union itself, seems to us to be nothing more than a symbolic fact with no real capacity for change.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Julian King's nomination is a guarantee that Britain wants to participate in European security as it has done so far. After Brexit, we need to build our new relationships on the issues that unite us. The fight against terrorism is one of them.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 Cross-Union cooperation, which the new Commissioner should support, will help to meet the challenges we face in the new geopolitical situation. I fully agree with the creation of a portfolio for the Security Union. Security is vital for all EU Member States. Julian King, who was nominated for the post, should oversee the strengthening of the fight against terrorism, organised crime and cyber crime. At a hearing before the European Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, he gave a professional performance that corresponded to the importance of this agenda. That is why, in voting, I supported julian king's nomination for this post.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the result of the referendum, the UK is still in the EU and is thus entitled to have a commissioner. I am convinced that Sir Julian King is highly competent and has the qualities needed to fulfil the position of commissioner. I am also convinced of his European commitment and I wish him the best in his new duties.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against it because we believe that the creation of this new post as Commissioner, as well as the concept of a Security Union itself, seems to us to be nothing more than a symbolic fact with no real capacity for change.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against it because we believe that the creation of this new post as Commissioner, as well as the concept of a Security Union itself, seems to us to be nothing more than a symbolic fact with no real capacity for change.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported sir Julian King's nomination as Commissioner for the Security Union. Being a British Commissioner in the current situation will certainly not be easy, especially with the agenda of the Security Union. In my opinion, however, Sir Julian King can stand up, not only because of his personal experience in the fight against terrorism from the ground from Northern Ireland or France, but also in the field of professional readiness, which he also demonstrated during the so-called grilling by MEPs.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, there are actually going to be a few aspects of this job that I am going to miss. I will miss the glint of the westering sun on the façade of Strasbourg Cathedral. I am actually going to miss the company of some of my colleagues here. We do not agree very often, but they are good friends and loyal and engaging companions. But I am not going to miss wasting our time on these utterly pointless resolutions about whether they should have the death penalty in the Philippines and whether the Zimbabwean Government is doing enough for women’s rights. Can I tell you, no one in those countries knows or cares what we think. The idea that they are waiting in Manila to see what the European Parliament’s resolution on human rights in the Philippines has decreed is beyond a joke. And the reason we are doing it is not because we think it is going to have any impact on the real world. We are doing it to make ourselves feel better or, more precisely, we are doing it to send a signal to the world about what very nice people we are. It is the ultimate moralistic form of lawmaking and it is this kind of thinking that led to the failures of Schengen and the euro and all the rest of it, because we were projecting our values, rather than looking at the reality. This is not going to be Britain’s problem for very much longer, but of course we have a continuing interest in the prosperity of our friends and allies – and I would urge you, my friends, to focus on the things where we can make a difference, rather than using legislation as a way of sending a message.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I want to justify why I supported the European Parliament's proposal for a Regulation on the European Travel Document. This document could be a positive contribution to the still failing return policy of individual Member States of the European Union. In short, our citizens are very sensitive to the fact that we are not able to return people from third countries who do not qualify for asylum, or it is quite clear that they cannot meet these conditions even in the asylum procedure. In the future, if we want European citizens to respect those who have the right to asylum, we will have to figure out how to get those who do not have that right out of the EU. And the document that we have approved today, the European travel document, can certainly contribute to this, there are a number of good things, such as how to prevent the falsification of such a document, how to arrange its simple publication, etc. So I see this as a positive step and I supported the regulation.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Hannan is right. He said that we should focus on the work, on the things that we can really change, but he could set an example by speaking on the agenda items that are called upon. In my view, he has spoken on a very different report.  I will return to the report on the lack of valid travel documents. I think that this is once again a question of the European Union's ability to work and, if you like, a deficit. The lack of valid travel documents is, of course, a huge deficit if people are to return to their home country. We already had a Council recommendation of 30 November 1994, but it has not been implemented. Today, we are now ready to press for the introduction of a valid European travel document that facilitates repatriation to third countries. I think that is necessary, that is important, and that is why we should be talking about it today and have taken appropriate decisions on it today.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir sa tuarascáil seo agus tuarascáil thábhachtach is ea í. As noted by the rapporteur, one of the exigencies of the current migrant crisis is to establish an effective means of returning those who do not qualify for international protection within the EU to their relevant third countries. A standard European travel document for return will ensure a wider acceptance of returnees by third countries, as well as facilitating understanding of the real recognition rate. The current challenges to readmission decreased the capacity and resources of Member States at a time when a reduction in their administrative burden is essential. It is my belief, therefore, in accordance with this report, that the uniform document, with enhanced technical and security features, would be an effective means of increasing the mutual recognition of asylum decisions across the EU. Dá bhrí sin, cuirim fáilte roimh an tuarascáil seo.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation is designed to create a single model within the Member States that guarantees high technological and security standards with regard to the production of return documents for those residing illegally. Since I believe that the introduction of a single model can increase the return rate of irregular migrants in order to maintain the integrity of the common European asylum system and improve cooperation with third countries, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on this legislative report. Whilst UKIP supports the accelerated return of migrants who are illegally staying in Europe, we do not support the creation of an EU harmonised travel document that progresses EU integration.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. This proposed regulation is essentially a deportation charter. The focus of the proposal is to create a common EU travel document to be issued – with the sole purpose of deportation – only to third-country nationals in the EU ‘illegally’. This EU deportation passport would be uniform and mandatory for Member States to use. It would be printed in only an EU or one third-county language, so most people affected by it would not be able to read it; the document is to specify ‘distinguishing features’; it would contain personal data; and it would be managed by EURODAC and the Schengen Information Service. Recognition of this deportation document would also be a prerequisite for any third-country migration/asylum cooperation with the EU. For the above reasons, I voted against the proposal.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reminds us that returns must be made in a dignified manner, with full respect for the fundamental rights of people.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals. The return of those who do not qualify for international protection within the EU must be a priority for the European Union. Improving the rate of returns for irregular migrants is vital for the integrity of the EU’s asylum system, for cooperation between EU Member States and third countries, and for maintaining the confidence of EU citizens. It is important that, by harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce bureaucracy, variation, costs, and waiting periods, and will hopefully increase recognition of the document by third countries. The EU shall also ensure higher technical and security standards, in particular as regards safeguards against counterfeiting and falsification.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European travel document on the return of illegally stay-at-home third-country nationals. As European Socialists and Democrats we believe that return policy is part of the European Agenda on Migration, but we stress the importance of them being carried out in a humane manner ensuring the safety of returnees and respect for fundamental human rights. In particular, the proposed regulation I voted for aims to create a specific European travel document for the return of third-country nationals in order to speed up procedures and ensure proper and rapid examination of applications and refunds.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. This report deals with the European Commission's proposal to introduce a single travel document for those non-EU citizens who do not have a valid passport or IDENTITY card. The travel document is intended to speed up the repatriation and return of those third-country nationals who are irregularly resident in the EU. In order to prevent counterfeiting, the new travel documents will be provided with strict security features so that the document can be fully recognised by third countries. I voted in favour of the report because I expect the introduction of the new document to reduce the administrative and bureaucratic requirements that currently weigh on both the Member States and third countries. The document is also intended to help counteract the low enforcement rate of return orders. In addition, by introducing the document, I promise myself an important step towards reducing and combating irregular migration.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The proposal aims to introduce a standard European travel document for the return of non-EU nationals in irregular situations within eu Member States who do not have passports or identity cards.  This measure, which should have received the approval of any Front National MP, is in fact a new element towards the establishment of a common asylum and immigration policy, which we reject for obvious reasons of sovereignty. It is up to the Member States, and themselves, to determine the guidelines and modalities of their immigration policy. A country like France must be perfectly capable of determining the format of the document necessary for the return of illegal migrants. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the grounds that this regulation will not impact upon the United Kingdom.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the return of a European travel document to illegally staying third-country nationals in the EU. In view of the complicated current situation due to the migrant crisis and the pressure exerted by Member States and EU agencies, it is necessary to increase the number of return of irregular migrants. This is essential to ensure the integrity of the EU asylum system and cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and to maintain the trust of EU citizens. However, the EU is facing falsification of documents and the reluctance of third countries to recognise documents. I therefore agree that the EU must ensure technical and security standards for EU travel documents and to speed up procedures, transfer travel documents into both EU languages and the relevant language of a third country.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. The return of persons not entitled to international protection (false refugees, economic migrants) should be a priority for the European Union. Improving the return rate of migrants with unsettled status is vital for the completeness of the EU asylum system, cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and the maintenance of trust among EU citizens.  A long-term solution should be provided in order to stabilise the current migration crisis, alleviate pressure on Member States and EU agencies and increase capacity and resources within the EU. The current return rate for rejected asylum seekers is extremely poor. The current standard EU travel document needs to be significantly improved in its format and application in order to be better recognised and effective by third countries. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce bureaucracy, derogations, costs and waiting periods, and hopefully increase the acceptance of the document in third countries. To date, many third countries refuse to accept return documents issued by EU Member States because they are poor quality documents. In view of this, return documents should ensure a higher level of technical and security standards, in particular protection against counterfeiting and falsification. On the basis of the fore over, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this report, which aims to establish the common model and the technical and security specifications of the harmonised European travel document, intended for the return of third country nationals staying irregularly in the EU. The report recalls the essential need to observe the principles recognised by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and, in particular, human dignity, in the event of estrangement, expulsion and extradition.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Halla-aho report on travel documents for the return of third-country nationals whose stay is irregular.  A substantial review of the format and implementation of the EU standard travel document must be carried out quickly, so as to increase its recognition by third countries and ensure its greater effectiveness. Harmonisation can not only lead to a reduction in bureaucracy and costs, but also to allow safe return, respectful of the fundamental rights guaranteed by international treaties and the Nice Charter, while safeguarding the health conditions of migrants.  A translation into multiple languages and new technological standards can be key tools to increase the use of the document and protect it from falsification.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted against this report as a legitimizing text of the regulated removal mechanism for migrants, which is part of the repressive and sectarian logic with which the EU has decided to deal with the humanitarian crisis caused in part by its irresponsible foreign policy. None of our group's amendments, focused on the necessary respect for the rights of migrants and data protection, was included in the final text.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this report, which I have supported, on the European travel document for the return of nationals of stubborn countries in irregular situations. In this case, I have also deferred from my group and voted in favour of Amendment No 35 of the GUE/NGL Group which requires that the European travel document for return be drawn up in the official language(s) of the Member State adopting the return decision, as well as in a language which the returnees understand. I have defended it since the last legislature, when we were talking about the European protection order.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on travel documents for the return of third-country nationals travelling irregularly aims to introduce a standard European travel document to speed up the return of non-EU nationals in irregular situations to EU Member States who do not have passports or identity cards.  Indeed, it is very difficult for many European countries to return these people to their countries of origin by safe and legal means. According to the Commission itself, only 40% of decisions taken within the EU to remove citizens from irregular third countries are implemented each year. The document is valid for a single trip that ends upon the person's arrival in the return third country. We reject this report as it is a new element towards the establishment of a common asylum and immigration policy. Only states must determine the format of a document necessary for the return of illegal migrants. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 A serious and concrete action plan must be found as soon as possible to repatriate the thousands of illegal immigrants who are illegally in Europe.  Although I support the aim of the report, inso far as it calls for better cooperation with third countries in order to facilitate the return of illegal immigrants to their own country, I do not agree with entrusting the EU with the negotiation of return agreements with these countries, as I believe that this prerogative should be maintained by the individual Member States. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The European procedure for returning irregular migrants, on which a return order weighs, is currently not effective. In 2014, less than 40% of the total number of return decisions issued by Member States were implemented. However, about 60% of the time, the facilitation of this return, even in the case of a voluntary and desired return, cannot take effect because the country of origin refuses to accept that person back into its territory due, inter alia, to the lack of documents or the recognition of those documents. This Regulation, which I supported with my vote, establishes a uniform European travel document which facilitates the return of third-country nationals subject to a return decision.
