The document must contain a passport photograph and be issued in an official EU language, with english and French translation and, where possible, the language of the country of return. On a socialist proposal, the report recalls that return, expulsion and extradition must be an element of last resort subject to an effective remedy.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has made Parliament express its position on the European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals in the EU. The return of persons unable to claim international protection in the EU must be a priority for the European Union. Increasing the number of irregular migrants returned is vital to ensure the integrity of the EU asylum system and cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and to maintain the trust of EU citizens. In order to stabilise the current migrant crisis, reduce the pressure on Member States and EU agencies, and increase capacity and resources within the EU, a long-term solution is needed. The EU cannot continue to put up with the current level of return of people who cannot be asylumed. The current standard of the EU travel document needs to be substantially revised, both in terms of format and implementation, in order to be more recognised by third countries and effective. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce bureaucratic burdens, inconsistencies, costs and waiting periods and are expected to encourage third countries to recognise it more.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the adoption of this report to be very important. Improving the return rate of migrants with unsettled status is vital for the completeness of the EU asylum system, cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and the maintenance of trust among EU citizens. A long-term solution should be provided in order to stabilise the current migration crisis, alleviate pressure on Member States and EU agencies and increase capacity and resources within the EU. The current standard EU travel document needs to be significantly improved in its format and application in order to be better recognised and effective by third countries. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce red tape, derogations, costs and waiting periods and hopefully increase the acceptance of the document in third countries. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. In a bid to alleviate the current migrant crisis and alleviate pressures on Member States, MEPs have majority endorsed the amendments to the report on the proposal for a regulation on a European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals.  By harmonising the form of the travel document, Member States will reduce bureaucracy, number of versions, costs and waiting times, and we hope that this will strengthen the recognition of this document in the third countries of the world.  Better protection against counterfeiting and counterfeiting and improved exchange of information between countries regarding their issue are significant improvements to this process, and therefore my support for this document.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report calls for the establishment by Member States of a harmonised travel document to facilitate the return of irregular persons to their countries of origin. Political jurisdiction over asylum and immigration must be the responsibility of the states. So I voted against it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must enforce its agreements with third countries for the return of irregular migrants: it is a question of justice for those who respect the conditions for remaining, security for the overall maintenance of the reception and stability system so as not to further damage the relationship of trust with the institutions. The European Union cannot continue to be satisfied with the rate of return currently registered among the ranks of rejected asylum seekers.  There is a need for a substantial review of the format and implementation of the EU standard travel document in order to increase its recognition by third countries and to ensure their effectiveness. By harmonising the format of the travel document, The Member States will reduce bureaucracy, divergences, costs and waiting times, in the hope that this document will be better recognised by third countries.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report 'Travel document for the return of third-country nationals whose stay is irregular', because I believe that the exceptional wave of migration that has hit Europe puts us in front of ancient problems that, however, given the emergency situation, require urgent, concrete answers but above all in line with EU legislation.  One of these, without a doubt, is the repatriation mechanisms for third-country nationals. This is a sensitive issue, which must be approached with the right amount of rationality, without ever losing sight of strict respect for the rights of these people. An effective and credible return policy goes hand in hand with a more open migration policy.  Hence the need to develop a specific European travel document for the return of third-country nationals subject to a return decision. Increasing the rate of return of irregular migrants certainly makes it possible to free up reception capacity for those who really need protection. This must be the main aim that the European Union must pursue in order to respect the law but above all to welcome and assist all those fleeing war, famine and persecution.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. This proposed regulation is essentially a deportation charter. The focus of the proposal is to create a common EU travel document, to be issued only to third-country nationals who are in the EU ‘illegally’, for the sole purpose of deportation. This EU deportation passport would be uniform and mandatory for Member States to use. It would be printed only in an EU or one third-country language, so most of the people affected by it would not be able to read it. The document would specify ‘distinguishing features’ and would contain personal data, and the system would be managed by EURODAC and the Schengen Information Service. Recognition of this deportation document would also be a prerequisite for any third-country migration/asylum cooperation with the EU. For the above reasons, I voted against the proposal.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is directed at establishing a specific European travel document for the return of third country nationals subject to a return decision, and the increased use of that document for the purpose of readmission. The aim is to create uniformity by harmonising the technical features of this specific European document, thus facilitating its recognition by third countries for the purpose of return and readmission, and cutting down the waiting time in administrative detention for returnees awaiting removal.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation concerns the introduction of a single EU-specific model to be applied to the return of those who do not qualify for international protection. This would facilitate uniform treatment and bureaucracy, thus also facilitating relations with third countries which would be faced with the same type of travel documents. To date, many third countries often refuse to accept return documents issued by Member States because of their poor quality. Finally, this would help protect against the risk of false or counterfeit documents. I voted strongly in favour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, on establishing the common format and the technical security specifications of a common travel document to be used for returns of persons staying illegally in the EU. I believe that this updated format will help to improve the rate of returns for irregular migrants, which is a pillar of the EU’s asylum system and of the cooperation between EU Member States and third countries. It is also a measure much needed for retaining the trust of EU citizens. In my opinion, it must be a priority for the EU to return migrants who do not qualify for international protection within the EU. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce bureaucracy, variation, costs, and waiting periods, and will hopefully increase recognition of the document by third countries.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that improving the rate of returns of irregular migrants is vital for the EU asylum system, for cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and for maintaining the confidence of EU citizens. If we want to stabilise the current migration crisis, mitigate the pressure on EU Member States and agencies and increase capacity and savings within the EU, then we are obliged to find a long-term solution.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote in favour is justified not only by the devastating migration crisis faced by our country mainly with its own resources, but also by the hope that full harmonisation of the Union's migration policies can constitute an effective and resilient system for increasing recognition rates by third countries.   The Council recommendation of 30 November 1994, which has now been repealed, provided for the introduction of a standard travel document. However, it has never been born uniformly in the Union, generating antithetical modus operandi capable of further exacerbating the phenomenon.  In fact, we must be able to tackle common problems together, but in order to do so we need Union instruments characterised by the same format and technical specificities, so as to allow each State to reduce bureaucracy, waiting times for return and related costs.  At the same time, this would simplify relations with non-EU countries through effective recognition and faster readmission of citizens. In the face of increased zeal on the part of the countries involved so that the new European travel document can operate, the Union is committed to establishing a harmonised, clear format that makes the exchange of information easy and secure.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the travel document for the return of illegally staying third country nationals and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of a holistic approach, Parliament has advocated that all factors of the so-called refugee crisis be seen comprehensively. To this end, the Commission has presented a number of legislative initiatives, including this European Travel Document and the aim of which is essentially to make operations for the return of irregular migrants less bureaucratic. Not being a structuring measure, it is about an important problem: just as we have to take in refugees more and better, we must also ensure that those who have no right to enter or reside in our territory are returned to their origin. Only then will we be fair, while - at the same time - ensuring that we allocate more effectively the resources we have at our disposal. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on this legislative report. Whilst UKIP supports the accelerated return of migrants who are illegally staying in Europe, we do not support the creation of an EU harmonised travel document that progresses EU integration.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 They already call it the "Great Wall of Calais". After Austria, London also thought well to equip itself with a 2 km long concrete barrier in the hope of limiting the flow of migrants. But is it really worth taking actions of this kind that are totally opposed to the principle of solidarity? Would it not be better to speed up the implementation of a genuine European immigration strategy, with priority being given to structuring a more coherent return policy? Without a serious development cooperation policy, in which Europe must play a leading role, we will condemn a part of the world to a certain and inevitable destiny of poverty and despair. The European Travel Document will increase the return rate of irregular migrants, harmonise technical specifications to prevent counterfeiting and counterfeiting, and resolve existing differences between States in their acceptance, while ensuring the exchange of information between States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I agree with the rapporteur that the EU cannot continue to be content with its current return rate amongst failed categories of asylum seekers. The existing standard EU travel document requires significant overhaul in its format and its implementation in order to increase its recognition by third countries and be effective. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce bureaucracy, variation, costs, and waiting periods, and hopefully will increase recognition of the document by third countries.  This is essential in facilitating the readmission of a third-country national staying irregularly on the territory of the Union – provided that the private life, liberty and property of the returnee are not endangered and that data protection safeguards as set by our standards are respected.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. U2012 The expulsion of people who have fled the wars, misery and exploitation generated by the West is one of the key elements of the Fortress Europe that we reject. We understand that this is a measure contrary to the rights of migrants, who are expelled violently and against their will and it should be remembered that forced displacement is enshrined in international law as a crime against humanity. That is why we voted against this proposal whose sole objective is to speed up these deportations and reduce the limited guarantees and rights that migrants might have.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the European travel document for the return of third-country nationals whose stay is irregular, within the framework of better cooperation on return and readmission with the main countries of origin and transit. Indeed, the current travel document for the return of third-country nationals, established by the Council recommendation of 30 November 1994, is not accepted by all third countries due to the inadequacy of its security standards, which hinders the execution of returns under the readmission agreements of the EU or its Member States with third countries and, therefore, the proper functioning of European migration policy.  This report remedys the current situation by proposing a uniform system at European level for the travel document allowing return to third countries, in accordance with the technical specifications already laid down in Regulation (EC) No 333/2002.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the EP resolution adopted today is to create an appropriate European travel document ensuring the return of third-country nationals to their home countries and recognised by third-country States. The return rate of migrants with unsettled status needs to be improved, since it is impossible to maintain the EU's asylum system without it. At present, it is a serious problem that third-country states do not recognise return documents issued by EU Member States, citing quality reasons. In order to improve the return rate of migrants with unsettled status, an appropriate EU document is needed to ensure a higher level of technical and security standards, in particular protection against counterfeiting and falsification. The application of the travel document should be regularly and thoroughly reviewed and any improvements that may be necessary should also be examined. In view of the current migration crisis in the EU, this process should be carried out on a regular basis. I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Europe’s migration policy must be inclusive of a number of elements. Relocation and resettlement are part of the strategy. However, return is also a very important element. Migrants whose application for asylum has been refused and others who no longer qualify for such protection must be returned to their country of origin in a humane way. It is only through such a process that we can have a functional EU asylum policy. As things stand today, the EU system to return irregular migrants is not effective.  As a shadow rapporteur, I voted in favour of this report as I believe that this document is another step forward in order to ensure an effective EU asylum policy.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which sets out the criteria for the European travel documents necessary for the return of third-country nationals who are not destined to remain in the European Union. At a time when the explosion of the migration crisis has put a strain on our reception capacity, it is essential to make effective the returns of irregular nationals to their countries of origin on European soil. Travel documents with harmonised provisions in Europe and high security standards are a tool to combat fraud and falsification that allow irregular entry into Europe, techniques all too often used by human traffickers and foreign fighters. Finally, I would argue that the European Union must finally give itself the means to enforce the readmission agreements signed with third countries. This is the necessary condition to ensure that international protection is quickly granted to those who really need it.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed regulation on a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals staying irregularly. Return is an essential part of the overall action to ensure the credibility and proper functioning of the Union's migration policy and to reduce and prevent illegal immigration. Since some third-country nationals who are irregularly resident in the EU do not have valid travel documents, Member States face serious difficulties in ensuring their return to their destination country legally and safely. It is therefore necessary to encourage the acceptance by third countries of a harmonised European pass. However, the current return travel document model is not accepted by all third-country authorities, in particular due to the lack of harmonised and adequate technical features and safety standards. A safer and more harmonised European travel document should therefore be put in place, as the reinforcement of its security and technical elements should facilitate its recognition by third countries.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Hala-aho's report updates the standard EU travel document established in 1994 to speed up the process of returning non-EU nationals who are living in the EU illegally and do not have valid passports or ID cards. Many European countries have extreme difficulties in returning these people to their countries of origin in a secure and legal manner. Nowadays, only 40% of those staying in the EU illegally are returned, as many non-EU countries do not accept documents issued by different EU member states, as many of them differ and do not comply with security and credibility measures.  In order to speed up the return of illegal residents and increase the credibility of travel documents, it was necessary to update the legislation and propose a common format for a European travel document. The new document will use all the security features used for European visas and will include personal information such as name, age, gender, distinguishing marks and will clearly indicate that the document is valid for only one trip until the person arrives in the third country.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is impossible to overlook that on the territory of the Union there are millions of illegally detained migrants and persons whose application for asylum has been rejected. All of them are living or moving illegally within the EU and it is foolish to think that the big problem with their re-promotion is the provision of proper travel documents. To the mockery of Turkey and the other third countries which, while they have signed readmission agreements, do not respect them and even demand more consideration, we must respond forcefully and decisively.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of a standardised European travel document is essential for the management of migration flows, thereby increasing recognition of the document by third countries, ensuring greater acceptance of returnees by those countries and reducing bureaucracy and waiting periods in the Member States. Increasing the return rate of irregular migrants is vital for the integrity of the EU asylum system, cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and maintaining the confidence of EU citizens. A long-term solution is needed to stabilise the current migrant crisis, relieve pressure on EU Member States and agencies, and strengthen the capacity and resources available in the EU.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: this measure is another step towards the establishment of a common asylum and immigration policy, which we reject for obvious reasons of sovereignty.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. –The harmonisation of the format and technical specifications of the European travel document for the return of third-country nationals whose stay is irregular aims to facilitate the recognition of this document by third countries for the purpose of return and readmission.   I fully support the intention to facilitate the success of administrative procedures and the reduction of bureaucracy, divergences, costs and waiting times.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the European Union's biggest challenges today is the effectiveness of europe's common asylum system, which is still too weak and slow to cope with the deep refugee crisis.  I voted in favour of issuing a travel document for the return of those who do not meet the requirements to benefit from international protection within the European Union. This is a very important instrument that will speed up reception and expulsion practices, but above all it will make it possible to avoid uncontrolled and unmanageable immigration with disastrous consequences for our countries, starting with Italy. The European Union must react with all the instruments at its disposal and prevent the collapse of our reception system.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ The provision relating to security features – which is intended to make possible in the future the use of digital and/or biometric data – is also unnecessary, disproportionate and even dangerous (as the document is issued for a person in custody and is valid until her/his return, meaning while this person will remain in police custody). I voted against the proposal.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the European Union must ensure protection for residents living in individual Member States on its territory. Among the many measures that need to be improved after numerous terrorist attacks in recent months is to ensure and increase the return of irregular migrants residing in the European Union and posing a security risk to its people. The existing European Union standard travel document requires an in-depth recast in order to increase its recognition by third countries and to be effective. Ensuring the exchange of information between Member States as regards the issue of travel documents and persons listed as illegally staying third-country nationals who do not have a valid travel document is essential to improve the mutual recognition of asylum decisions in the EU and to prevent the secondary movement of unsuccessful asylum seekers.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on this report because, despite some good ideas, I am not very much in favour of the EU's primacy over the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is impossible to overlook that on the territory of the Union there are millions of illegally detained migrants and persons whose application for asylum has been rejected. All of them are living or moving illegally within the EU and it is foolish to think that the big problem with their re-promotion is the provision of proper travel documents. To the mockery of Turkey and the other third countries, which, while they have signed readmission agreements, do not respect them and even demand more consideration, we must respond forcefully and decisively. For these reasons I am voting against the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European travel document on the return of illegally stay-at-home third-country nationals.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is very important to establish a dedicated European travel document for the return of third-country nationals subject to a return decision and I welcome this regulation, which aims to provide for a uniform format and enhanced technical and security features to ensure a wider acceptance by third countries and the increased use of such document for readmissions. As things stand today the EU system to return irregular migrants is not effective. In 2014, less than 40% of the total number of return decisions issued by Member States have been enforced. However, around 60% of the time, the facilitation of this return – even when voluntary and wanted by the person themselves – cannot occur due to the fact that the country of origin refuses to accept that person back into their country due to a lack of documents or because they do not recognise such documents. Returns should be carried out in a humane manner, ensure the safe return and the safety of the returnees and ensure that such returns are carried out in full respect of fundamental rights.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the return rate of persons not entitled to international protection is vital for maintaining the completeness of the EU's asylum system. The initiative to provide a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals who are in the EU illegally is to be welcomed. Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the root causes are eliminated. To do this, you don't have to bring them here and distribute them, you have to take the help there.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the adoption of this report to be very important and I myself supported it with my vote. Improving the return rate of migrants with unsettled status is vital for the completeness of the EU asylum system, cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and the maintenance of trust among EU citizens. A long-term solution should be provided in order to stabilise the current migration crisis, alleviate pressure on Member States and EU agencies and increase capacity and resources within the EU. The current standard EU travel document needs to be significantly improved in its format and application in order to be better recognised and effective by third countries. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce red tape, derogations, costs and waiting periods and hopefully increase the acceptance of the document in third countries.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very relevant and important proposal that tackles one of the most pressing issues that the EU is currently facing, namely the readmission of illegal immigrants. The document proposed by the Commission would establish a common format with high security and safeguards against falsification. This is something very necessary, which will make the associated administrative work more efficient. The report highlights the fact that, in EU negotiations with third countries, readmission agreements should take precedence over bilateral agreements – something that would guarantee more effective implementation of readmission agreements. This is a very important report and a necessary step to protect the integrity of our Union and the safety of our societies.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals whose stay is irregular because I believe that creating a single format and system for all Member States will make it possible to ensure that return operations are carried out safely , protecting the health and fundamental rights of migrants. In fact, in 2014, more than 60% of the measures for the return of migrants to their country of origin were not implemented, even in the case of voluntary decisions. In fact, the European Agenda for Migration lacks a system that allows real loyal cooperation to be established between EU states and the countries of origin of migrants, who often refuse to accept their fellow citizens by not recognising their documents. The obligation to recognise and accept a European document with a single format, written in the language of the state carrying out the return and translated into French, English and the language of the country of origin, with a photo signage and anti-counterfeiting technology, is therefore the appropriate tool to solve this problem, and makes it possible to improve the protection of the migrant himself.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report 'Travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals'. The plan is to create a special European travel document to repatriat third-country nationals who have been subject to a decision to return. The document should have a uniform format and improved technical specifications and security features to ensure greater acceptance by third countries and increased use of these documents. The use of this new travel document should lead to an increase in the return rate in order to have more capacity to receive migrants who actually need protection. All this makes sense, all of this is long overdue.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The European Union must address the problem of the repatriation of illegal migrants. Those migrants who have come to Europe in recent years and do not have the right to asylum must be returned to their home countries. In 2014, only around 40% of migrants who were recomputed actually left the EU. This process must be speeded up and coordinated throughout Europe. Improving return papers is therefore a measure that I support. Such return documents must be uniform throughout Europe and meet certain safety standards. There is also a need to improve the exchange of information among EU Member States in this area.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The European travel document, intended for the return of third-country nationals in irregular residence, should speed up the return of illegal immigrants who do not have passports or identity cards.  This situation is now widespread as illegal immigrants have understood that the absence of these documents makes it difficult for Member States to identify countries of origin and thus return to those countries. The best solution would therefore be to make real readmission agreements with third countries, in order to be able to deport illegal immigrants despite their very "opportunistic" loss of identity papers. But it is not the European Union that is in fact very favourable to immigration.  I therefore voted against this report, because I am not fooled by its effective application and effectiveness. I note, moreover, that the rapporteur himself points out that in order to be more effective, it would be necessary for the Union to conclude firmer readmission agreements with third countries.  I would add that for these agreements to become a reality, Member States must restore their national borders and regain their immigration sovereignty, in order to conclude these agreements themselves and implement them.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. This is a text that smells like a pure announcement. There is already a harmonization of return documents, but many third countries refuse to accept them because of their poor quality. So that's what it was! This would explain why Member States are struggling to implement the removal or return-to-border measures they are taking... In France, the rate of implementation of such measures is just under 25% for the whole, and 15% for non-EU nationals. I thought the cause was the inability of the public authorities, or the aberration of permissive laws, the water-based regularizations of all those who manage to start a real or fictitious family, or those international conventions systematically favouring the rights of migrants over those of the entrenched man! So was I wrong? So all this would be a matter of papers? And thanks to this initiative of the European Commission, we could therefore safely deport the hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants who enter France every year and the hundreds of thousands that are already there... Do you really believe that? I didn't. Ad effect, I tell you.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report as a legitimizing text of the regulated removal mechanism for migrants, which is part of the repressive and sectarian logic with which the EU has decided to deal with the humanitarian crisis caused in part by its irresponsible foreign policy. None of our group's amendments, focused on the necessary respect for the rights of migrants and data protection, was included in the final text.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals.  The increase in the return rate of irregular migrants is crucial for the integrity of the EU asylum system, for cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and for maintaining the trust of EU citizens. It is necessary to stabilise the current migration crisis, to reduce the pressure on EU Member States and agencies and to expand capacity and resources in the EU.  At present, many third countries do not want to recognise return documents issued by EU Member States because of their poor quality. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce red tape, discrepancies, costs and waiting periods in the hope of more widespread recognition by third countries.  In my opinion, guaranteeing the exchange of information between Member States on the issue of travel documents and persons registered as illegally staying third-country nationals, without valid travel documents, will contribute to increasing the level of mutual recognition of asylum decisions in the EU and avoiding secondary movements of persons who have been refused asylum.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report. EU countries currently face serious difficulties when repatriating migrants back to their home countries due to the fact that the documents used to facilitate the journey are not recognised by the countries of return. Having a single, unified EU document can be viewed as a diplomatic tool which will assist Member States in carrying out safer returns. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the establishment of a common format and technical and security specifications for a harmonised European travel document for the return of third country nationals staying irregularly on the territory of the Union. The content and technical specifications of the European travel documents for return should be harmonised in order to ensure high technical and security standards, in particular as regards safeguards against counterfeiting and falsification. This would combat illegal entry into the EU Member States. It should also be ensured that the fundamental rights and principles recognised by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, in particular human dignity and protection in the event of removal, expulsion or extradition, are observed. The proposal should apply without prejudice to the right to an effective remedy and to a fair trial and to the right to asylum as provided for the Charter.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Unfortunately, the past few years have clearly shown that the EU and its Member States are completely overwhelmed in dealing with the asylum and refugee crisis. This is mainly due to the fact that existing legislation and international treaties such as the Dublin Regulation or the Schengen acquis are not being implemented. An important building block for regaining control of this crisis is to simplify the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers or third-country nationals who are illegally residing in the EU. To this end, a single European travel document will be created to facilitate returns. This is a step towards the restoration of the rule of law in the field of asylum and a step towards regaining citizens' shattered confidence in politics. Only if economic migrants who have entered the EU illegally are consistently deported can the citizens' willingness to help those who are truly persecuted and those threatened with life and limb can be maintained. That is why I voted in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on this legislative report. Whilst UKIP supports the accelerated return of migrants who are illegally staying in Europe, we do not support the creation of an EU harmonised travel document that progresses EU integration.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the text authorising the creation of a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals who are the subject of an administrative or judicial decision on their return. Less than 40% of return decisions are actually implemented in Europe. However, the return policy is an essential part of the fight against irregular immigration.  It is imperative that we reorganize ourselves.  A first step has been taken with the creation of the European Border and Coast Guard Corps, as it will now be possible to plan and implement joint return operations to ensure that irregular migrants do not continue to stay in the Union. However, the diversity of travel documents submitted by Member States with standards, formats and security features varying from country to country was used as a pretext by some third countries to challenge the validity of the document and, therefore, to reject the request for readmission. Therefore, although this instrument is not a quick fix, the creation of a uniform travel document will certainly facilitate and speed up the return of irregular migrants.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposed regulation for the establishment of a dedicated European travel document for third-country nationals subject to return. However, these returns should be closely supervised and should take place with full respect for the fundamental rights of the individuals concerned.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on a European travel document to return illegally staying third-country nationals, as the current migrant crisis needs to be stabilised and the burden on Member States reduced.  In this context, it is necessary to raise the quality of return documents issued in EU Member States, as many third countries still do not recognise them. Therefore, the format of documents must be harmonised, thereby reducing costs, bureaucracy and waiting times. It is also essential to encourage the exchange of information in order to increase the rate of return of irregular migrants, which is a priority for the integrity of the EU asylum system and the Union itself.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text is a further step towards the establishment of a common asylum and immigration policy, which we reject for obvious reasons of sovereignty. It is up to the Member States, and themselves, to determine the guidelines and modalities of their immigration policy. A country like France should be perfectly capable of determining the format of the document necessary for the return of illegal migrants. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – With my UKIP colleagues, I voted to abstain on this legislative report. Whilst UKIP supports the accelerated return of migrants who are illegally staying in Europe, we do not support the creation of an EU harmonised travel document that progresses EU integration.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve and speed up the return of irregular migrants. The European Commission has therefore proposed to create a uniform travel document that complements the instruments to combat irregular immigration. According to Eurostat, the effective rate of implementation of return decisions in 2014 was less than 40%. This low rate may be partly related to the low rate of recognition of travel documents by third countries due to the diversity of documents submitted by Member States. We cannot afford to have such a low rate of enforcement of return decisions in Europe.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report addresses the issue of returns and offers solutions to simplify the return processes of third-country nationals once readmission agreements have been concluded with the countries of origin. The regulation is intended to standardise the format and technical specifications. I agree with this approach and with this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report. EU countries currently face serious difficulties when repatriating migrants back to their home countries due to the fact that the documents used to facilitate the journey are not recognised by the countries of return. Having a single, unified EU document can be viewed as a diplomatic tool which will assist Member States in carrying out safer returns. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: in writing. – The British Conservatives fully support the aims and outcome of this proposal. The need to increase the rate of returns and readmission of failed asylum seekers is essential if Europe is to tackle the migrant crisis effectively. This report is an important step towards reforming the current system of EU returns. However, the UK does not participate in the European Common Asylum System and has not opted in to this measure. Therefore, the UK Conservative delegation will continue its longstanding position of abstaining on reports in relation to policies which the UK has not opted in to.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. Unfortunately, the past few years have clearly shown that the EU and its Member States are completely overwhelmed in dealing with the asylum and refugee crisis. This is mainly due to the fact that existing legislation and international treaties such as the Dublin Regulation or the Schengen acquis are not being implemented. An important building block for regaining control of this crisis is to simplify the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers or third-country nationals who are illegally residing in the EU. To this end, a single European travel document will be created to facilitate returns. This is a step towards the restoration of the rule of law in the field of asylum and a step towards regaining citizens' shattered confidence in politics. Only if economic migrants who have entered the EU illegally are consistently deported can the citizens' willingness to help those who are truly persecuted and those threatened with life and limb can be maintained. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals to be one of the tools necessary to cope with the migration crisis. Improving cooperation on return and readmission with the main countries of origin and transit of illegally staying third-country nationals is essential to increase the still unsuspecting rate of return. An improved European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals is important in this respect. A safer European travel document for the return of third-country nationals should be introduced in order to facilitate the return and readmission of illegally staying third-country nationals. Its enhanced security features should facilitate its recognition by third countries. Such a document should facilitate the return of persons, in particular in the context of readmission agreements or other arrangements with third countries, as well as in the framework of cooperation with third countries in relation to returns of persons not covered by official agreements. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The Commission's report is fundamentally pointing in the right direction, but the libe committee's amendments are considerably more precise. Obviously, it is necessary to find a way of producing modern documents, the rules of edification. It would have been much more expedient and cheaper if the governments of some countries had not sought to destabilise regions outside the EU and lure economic refugees to Europe. But that's a different story, for now, without those responsible.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the European Commission's proposal for a standardised travel document for the accelerated return of third-country nationals illegally residing in the European Union. I believe that this document would facilitate administrative service and data processing.  In view of the refugee situation, such a travel document would contribute to easing information systems as well as a clearer vision of the volumes of illegally staying citizens and border security. The recognition of this document by countries could limit abuses of asylum systems in Europe and strengthen european citizens' confidence in the EU's asylum and immigration policy.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this regulation we do not go into the merits of the return decisions taken by individual Member States. We are merely establishing a safer and more uniform European travel document for the return of third-country nationals whose residence is irregular and whose purpose is to help facilitate the return and readmission of these citizens to their country of origin. We have put in place harmonised reporting models which will use safety standards to prevent counterfeiting and falsification and which will ultimately also help to reduce the administrative and bureaucratic burden on Member States and the authorities of third countries. It is not a question, as some members have already said in this House, of endorsing common return policies, but only of moving towards the recognition of harmonised documents that are valid and recognised by all Member States. It remains clearly written that this document applies only to third-country nationals who are subject to a regular return decision under Directive 2008/115/EC.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. This report addresses the issue of the return of migrants whose stay appears to be irregular, which is our priority. Providing for an increase in the return rate of irregular migrants is essential for the integrity of the EU asylum system, for cooperation between EU Member States and third countries to maintain the confidence of European citizens.  At present, many third countries are not prepared to accept the return documents that EU Member States issue, because of their poor quality, because they must be guaranteed adequate technological and safety standards that can mitigate or eradicate counterfeiting and falsification.  It is therefore necessary to reach a long-term solution to stabilise the current migrant crisis, to ease the pressure on Member States and EU agencies and to increase the EU's capacity and resources. With regard to what the report sets out, I think we should vote in favour of it.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am opposed to the creation of a European passport for migrants, even if the aim is to deport them. I believe that the political competence in the area of asylum and immigration should be a matter of the sovereignty of each State, not the Union.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I supported the adoption of the report by my colleague Jussi Halla-Aho, which is considering the Commission's proposal to create a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals in irregular situations. According to Eurostat, the effective rate of implementation of return decisions in 2014 was less than 40%, due in part to the low recognition of travel documents by third countries due to the diversity of documents submitted by Member States. Such a situation is not tenable; that is why I welcome the creation of a uniform travel document, which will usefully complement the existing instruments to combat irregular immigration.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against this text. It is in fact the creation of a document stamped "EU" whose aim is to facilitate the return of "irregular migrants". It is therefore part of a fiercely Europeanist logic, and sits purely and simply on the prerogatives of the Member States. Yet it is to them, and to them alone, that the political competence over immigration and asylum must come back.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because this Regulation will establish a common model and the technical and safety specifications of a harmonised European travel document for the return of irregularly staying third-country nationals on the territory of the Union. This document shall only operate in cases where there is evidence of the identity and nationality of the returne and never in cases of unknown nationality. The document must contain a passport photograph and be issued in an official EU language, with english and French translation and, where possible, the language of the country of return.   The document will be valid for a single trip ending on arrival in the country of return. The text stresses the importance of respecting human rights and the principles recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, in particular human dignity and access to the right to asylum.  Return, expulsion, and extradition must be a last-minute item subject to an effective resource.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. U2012 The expulsion of people who have fled the wars, misery and exploitation generated by the West is one of the key elements of the Fortress Europe that we reject. We understand that this is a measure contrary to the rights of migrants, who are expelled violently and against their will and it should be remembered that forced displacement is enshrined in international law as a crime against humanity. That is why we voted against this proposal whose sole objective is to speed up these deportations and reduce the limited guarantees and rights that migrants might have.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The EU's return policy has ample room for improvement. Its average efficacy does not reach 40%. In periods such as the current one, when the EU is under very strong and increasing migratory pressures, greater effectiveness of return is one of the key elements of migration policy. I believe that the importance of this report is partly that, in order to improve efficiency in returns, it is key to have a European travel document that meets safety standards and is accepted by third countries. And although this document has been around for years, its use is uneven, partly because of its safety deficiencies. I am voting in favour of the adoption of this report, as it is necessary to promote the use of the aforementioned document, especially with third countries returned to those who are illegally in the EU.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. Unfortunately, the past few years have clearly shown that the EU and its Member States are completely overwhelmed in dealing with the asylum and refugee crisis. This is mainly due to the fact that existing legislation and international treaties such as the Dublin Regulation or the Schengen acquis are not being implemented. An important building block for regaining control of this crisis is to simplify the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers or third-country nationals who are illegally residing in the EU. To this end, a single European travel document will be created to facilitate returns. This is a step towards the restoration of the rule of law in the field of asylum and a step towards regaining citizens' shattered confidence in politics. Only if economic migrants who have entered the EU illegally are consistently deported can the citizens' willingness to help those who are truly persecuted and those threatened with life and limb can be maintained. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of increased harmonisation and technical specification for the European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The European Commission has proposed a model harmonised passport that Member States would give to deported immigrants for the purpose of their return. This thing will certainly not save Europe from illegal migration. Whoever is now being exote by a Member State will either be stamped with an expulsion stamp on his passport or given a replacement document for travel back if he does not have his passport. Rather, I consider the new regulation to be an EU effort to accommodate Turkey, which is chedicing for the readmission of illegal migrants. But I want to give this proposal a chance to see if it will be beneficial.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The return of irregular third-country nationals is one of the problem areas of intra-EU migration management. The system of returning migrants is not yet effective, as evidenced by the fact that in 2014 only 40% of the total number of return decisions taken by Member States was made. The return of irregular migrants frees up scope for the acceptance and protection of people in real need, which is particularly important in the current migrant crisis.  The absence of valid travel documents is one of the main obstacles to the successful return of irregular migrants and should be addressed as such. Higher technical and safety standards are needed to make European travel documents valid and to avoid document forgery. Also, harmonising the format of the travel document and entering it into systems such as Eurodac and the Schengen Information System improves the effectiveness of European migrant management. I supported this report because I believe it addresses the issue of returning irregular migrants and facilitates the management of the current migrant crisis. Improving european travel document standards will contribute to achieving the objectives of the European Agenda on Migration, increase the efficiency of the migrant return system and provide asylum to those in genuine need.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always stressed that the refugee flow to the Member States of the European Union is a mixed flow of asylum seekers and illegal economic immigrants. I am pleased that we have been able to prioritise the return of those who do not qualify for international protection as a priority of the European Union. In the vast majority of cases, these people do not hold valid identity documents. Member States have great difficulties in returning them.  The data shows that less than 40% of return decisions have been actually implemented. The Single European Travel Document on the return of illegally staying third-country nationals is a tool to improve this. It will reduce the administrative burden and deadlines. Efficiency here is key. In order to have a well-managed migration policy, the system must be both fast and fair. In this way, both countries will be facilitated and the refugees themselves will receive the assistance they need.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation under discussion today will make it possible to sort out this issue and finally bring the order in place. Issuing a new document will not solve the problem in itself. Further efforts are needed to force the state concerned to recognise this document. But this is a necessary step in creating an effective system that will quickly and correctly address the problems of deporting illegal immigrants.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ The current lack of travel documents with unsatisfactory security features issued to illegal migrants complicates their smooth return to their home country. Third countries shall not accept these documents. I therefore support the introduction of a special European travel document for the return of third-country nationals, with a uniform format and improved technical and security features. This will simplify administration and facilitate the return policy of illegal migrants to countries that are obliged to accept them under international treaties and agreements.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European travel document on the return of illegally stay-at-home third-country nationals, because this report is well documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This is the creation of an EU document to facilitate the return of 'irregular migrants'. It is therefore part of a Europeanist logic, disregarding the prerogatives of the Member States. It should be remembered that the political competence in the area of asylum and immigration must logically be returned to the Member States. We are thus opposed to this diktat of the Union. France must be able to determine the format of the document necessary for the return of illegal migrants.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – The European Union gladly welcomes third-country nationals as long as they have passports from visa- exempt countries or visas from those which do not qualify for a waiver. I have a concern about foreigners illegally staying in any of the Member States and not under refugee status, for the EU might not be able to guarantee the well-being of those who decide to overstay. Therefore, I voted in favour of the report to express my wish to take action on the matter.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. A long-term solution is needed to stabilise the current migration crisis, alleviate the pressure on Member States and Union agencies and increase the capacity and resources available to us in this area. For this reason, I support the proposal on the Regulation which will regulate the European travel document for the return of irregularly active third-country nationals. We propose that this document should be a requirement of any future agreement concluded by the Union on cooperation and readmission and that the necessary measures be established to ensure the functioning of the system, while protecting human rights these persons.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This report deals with the simplification of the return process of third-country nationals, provided that readmission agreements have been concluded with the countries of origin. However, the current situation is put into perspective. So I am abstaining from voting.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Returning persons unable to claim international protection to the EU must be a priority for the European Union. Increasing the number of irregular migrants returned is vital to ensure the integrity of the EU asylum system and cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and to maintain the trust of EU citizens. In order to stabilise the current migrant crisis, reduce the pressure on Member States and EU agencies, and increase capacity and resources within the EU, a long-term solution is needed. The EU cannot continue to put up with the current level of return of people who cannot be asylumed. The current standard of the EU travel document needs to be substantially revised, both in terms of format and implementation, in order to be more recognised by third countries and effective. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce bureaucratic burdens, inconsistencies, costs and waiting periods and are expected to encourage third countries to recognise it more.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The 'fortress Europe' project is a barrel of the Danaïdes in which the Union is sinking, and it must constantly renew its creativity in an attempt to counter the migrations it has itself caused. The aim here is to standardize the travel documents used for the return and readmission of migrants who have been rejected in their asylum applications or in an irregular situation. And to digitize everything in the various European record systems scaffolded in recent years (Eurodac, VIS II). Including the migrant's "distinctive signs"... The Commission will regularly carry out an 'assessment of the rate of recognition of the travel document by each third country' to find out which foreign country is the worst student and should be penalised in its trade, enlargement or other agreements. It is clear here that Brussels always wants more ways to put out the symptoms of the migration crisis at the expense of migrants' rights, without ever trying to put an end to the causes. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This is the creation of an EU document to facilitate the return of 'irregular migrants'. It is therefore part of a Europeanist logic, disregarding the prerogatives of the Member States. It should be remembered that the political competence in the area of asylum and immigration must logically be returned to the Member States. As a result, I voted against the Commission's proposal and the resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to establish a specific European travel document for the return of third-country nationals subject to a return decision, providing for a standard model and enhanced technical and security characteristics ensuring wider acceptance by third countries and increasing recourse to this document for readmission purposes. Their use should be promoted in bilateral and EU readmission agreements or in other agreements. This proposal follows the announcement of the EU Action Plan on Return to explore ways to improve recognition of EU free transits by third countries. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it is imperative that the Union has an asylum system able to return effectively those applicants who do not qualify for protection. This must be done in a way that respects their rights, while ensuring that the appropriate resources are directed towards those who do qualify for asylum.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this legislation on the creation of a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals who have been irregularly staying and for which I have represented the Liberals in the European Parliament. This European document with enhanced security parameters should be more likely to be recognised by third countries whose irregular situations are expected to be re-adapted. At a time when the Union is facing the refugee crisis and must honour its moral and legal obligations in terms of international protection, it is imperative to strengthen the effectiveness and coherence of our asylum policy. Increasing the implementation of return decisions for return decisions is an essential tool in achieving this goal. Less than 40% of return decisions are applied across the EU. It is time to address these shortcomings, which undermine the credibility of European asylum policy. Recognition of this new return document by third countries should therefore be systematically encouraged when readmission agreements are concluded. The Commission's review of the effectiveness of this new return policy document will be the focus of attention.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The return of persons who do not qualify for international protection within the EU must be a priority for the Union to strengthen the integrity of EU asylum systems, as well as for cooperation between EU Member States by third countries and to maintain citizens' trust. The proposal highlights the need to recast the existing EU travel document in order to improve its recognition and effectiveness by third countries. Many third countries are not yet willing to accept return documents issued by EU Member States because of their poor quality. In addition to harmonising the format of the travel document, which would increase the recognition rate of the document by third countries, as well as reduce bureaucracy, costs and waiting times, the proposal also highlights the need for regular analyses of the functioning of the document, ensuring the exchange of information between Member States as regards the issue of travel documents and persons listed as illegally staying third-country nationals. I support the proposal with my vote.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which aims to establish a dedicated European travel document for the return of third-country nationals subject to a return decision. This regulation aims to provide for a uniform format and enhanced technical and security features to ensure a wider acceptance by third countries and the increase use of such document for readmissions. The returns should be carried out in a humane manner, ensuring the safe return and the safety of the returnees, and such returns must be carried out with full respect for fundamental rights.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Many third countries refuse to accept return documents issued by EU Member States to rejected asylum seekers because they are poor quality documents. The Commission has therefore proposed to Parliament and the Council a regulation on a European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal at first reading with 32 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This text proposes the introduction of a standard European travel document to simplify the return of non-EU nationals in irregular situations to EU Member States who cannot present an identity card or passport. This new standard made it possible to define a common european travel document format, which would contain personal information as well as an official photograph, in order to limit counterfeits and falsifications. We reject this proposal, which is another step towards the establishment of a common asylum and immigration policy. Immigration policy is the responsibility of the Member States, so it is up to them to determine the principles and the modalities.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The return of migrants who are not eligible for international protection in the EU is one of the EU's major challenges. Increasing the return rate of irregular migrants is key to ensuring the integrity of the EU asylum system, for cooperation between EU Member States and third countries and for maintaining the confidence of EU citizens.  I endorse the rapporteur's position on the need to reformulate the format and application of the standard travel document in the EU in order to increase its recognition by third countries and ensure that it is effective.  I also support the guarantee of the exchange of information between Member States regarding the issuing of travel documents and individuals on the list of third-country nationals staying illegally who do not have valid travel documents to increase mutual recognition of asylum decisions in the EU and avoid the secondary movement of applicants who have been refused the right of asylum.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This measure is another step towards the establishment of a common asylum and immigration policy, which I refuse for obvious reasons of sovereignty. It is up to the Member States, and themselves, to determine the guidelines and modalities of their immigration policy. A country like France should be perfectly capable of determining the format of the document necessary for the return of illegal migrants. So I'm voting against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report. EU countries currently face serious difficulties when repatriating migrants back to their home countries due to the fact that the documents used to facilitate the journey are not recognised by the countries of return. Having a single, unified EU document can be viewed as a diplomatic tool which will assist Member States in carrying out safer returns. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the creation of the European travel document for the return of third-country nationals in irregular situations. While the effective rate of implementation of return decisions in 2014 was less than 40%, the European Union must improve and speed up the return of migrants who are not destined to remain on its territory. I am delighted to finally see a text on the European Union's migration policy which does not constitute an air call for illegal immigration.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the travel document for the return of third-country nationals who are staying irregularly. The report focuses on three objectives: harmonizing the format and technical specifications of this document for third-country nationals living irregularly, facilitating the recognition of such a document by third countries and helping to reduce the length of time they are kept in administrative detention.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Returning persons who do not qualify for international protection within the EU is one of the priorities of the European Union. I voted for this report, which should improve the rates of return of irregular migrants, in order to maintain the integrity of the EU asylum system.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of increasing migration to the EU by third-country nationals, this proposal for a regulation could not be more timely. I voted in favour of it, as harmonising the European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals should be a way of gaining control of the current migration crisis, fostering higher return rates while reducing the strain on the EU asylum system. Strengthening the technical and security standards of the travel document would lower the administrative burden of the readmission processes both in the EU and in third countries, and would reduce instances of third countries not accepting the return papers of illegally staying third-country nationals.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's proposal to harmonise the elements of the travel document for the return of illegally staying EU nationals as a concrete contribution to addressing the migration crisis. The EU's return policy is one of the places of migration policy where the EU is most pushing the heel when only about one in two people who are to leave the EU at the decision of the competent authority succeeds. The new adaptation of the EU travel document should improve its recognition by third countries and reduce red tape and waiting times in The Member States when issuing them. In order to ensure the full effectiveness of the approved amendments, the recognition of an EU travel document should become a condition for the conclusion of EU readmission and cooperation agreements.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. This proposed regulation is essentially a deportation charter. The focus of the proposal is to create a common EU travel document, with the sole purpose of deportation, to be issued only to third-country nationals in the EU ‘illegally’. This EU deportation passport would be uniform and mandatory for Member States to use. It would be printed only in an EU or one third-country language, so most people affected by it would not be able to read it. The document is to specify ‘distinguishing features’; would contain personal data; and would be managed by EURODAC and the Schengen Information Service. Recognition of this deportation document would also be a prerequisite for any third-country migration/asylum cooperation with the EU. For the above reasons, I voted against the proposal.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained on the simplification of the return process of third-country nationals, as, where readmission agreements have been concluded with the countries of origin, the current situation is put into perspective.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In a situation where the EU is under a large wave of migrants, the EU cannot afford to have a travel document issued in the EU in the hands of time, not being approved by other countries because of its poor quality or for some other reason. Common standards for return documents in EU Member States are basic and must be implemented immediately. Similarly, it is also high time for EU Member States to exchange information between themselves on issued travel documents and on third-country nationals who do not have a travel document.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on this legislative report. Whilst UKIP supports the accelerated return of migrants who are illegally staying in Europe, we do not support the creation of an EU harmonised travel document that progresses EU integration.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I would welcome the proposed text by increasingly accepting the fears and the need for security of citizens.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The migrant crisis affecting Europe creates problems in the social, regulatory and economic aspects. From a social point of view, adapting migrants within the EU is difficult. Citizens care about their safety and feel fear especially from migrants who are illegally on EU territory.  The regulatory aspect concerns the problem of accepting current travel documents to return to third countries of those residing illegally in the EU, and the system of documents for returning migrants and the system of identifying such migrants needs to be improved, which again requires certain funds that create a problem economically. For all of Europe and EU citizens, it is essential to address the migrant problem and make this problem a priority, as it affects the entire European system.  We need to prove to the citizens of Europe that we are fighting for their safety and ensure higher technical and safety standards. Implementation instruments must not be allowed to schedule and bring even more problems than Europe has now.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The proposal aims to introduce a standard European travel document to speed up the return of non-EU nationals in irregular situations to EU Member States who do not have passports or identity cards. This is a further step towards the establishment of a common asylum and immigration policy, which I refuse for obvious reasons of sovereignty. It is up to the Member States, and themselves, to determine the guidelines and modalities of their immigration policy. A country like France should be perfectly capable of determining the format of the document necessary for the return of illegal migrants. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Current return rates are totally insufficient. Without rapid and certain returns, neither the Schengen area nor the common European asylum system will ever be able to cope with the burden of migratory flows. There is a need for a substantial review of the EU standard travel document in order to increase its recognition by third countries. By harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will reduce bureaucracy, divergences, costs and waiting times.  It is also crucial to ensure the exchange of information between Member States regarding the issue of travel documents and persons who are third-country nationals residing illegally and who do not have any valid travel document, in order to increase the mutual recognition of asylum decisions across the EU and avoid secondary movements by rejected asylum seekers.  I am convinced that the management of irregular migratory flows, in particular the implementation of return orders, is an issue on which the EU plays its credibility both on the international stage and in the eyes of its citizens. That is why I voted in favour of adopting this regulation.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report updates the standard European travel document created in 1994 to speed up the return of third-country nationals illegally residing in EU countries without valid passports or identity documents.  Many EU countries are currently facing serious difficulties in organising their safe and lawful return to their countries. The degree of acceptance by the target countries of replacement documents used by Member States is currently low due to insufficient security details and different formats. The lack of valid travel documents issued by some third countries is also a major obstacle to the success of the return process.  The review of this document creates a common format for the European travel document. The new technical data contained therein would also cover personal data. The application of the same security features set out in 2002 to visas issued by EU countries to residents without valid travel documents should result in greater recognition of documents and a reduction in the administrative burden for both the EU and the authorities of the countries of destination.
