I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I supported the creation of a European document for the return of third-country nationals in irregular situations. According to Eurostat studies, in 2014, only 40% of return decisions were actually carried out. This really low rate may be partly related to the low rate of recognition of travel documents by third countries, in particular due to the diversity of documents submitted by Member States. The aim here is therefore to establish a standardised travel document, as proposed by the European Commission, which would thus complement the various instruments to combat irregular immigration within the European Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 As one of the central actors in the current migration crisis, the European Union cannot be satisfied with the current rate of return of irregular third-country nationals to their States in cases of unapproved asylum applications.  In order to ensure the integrity of the Union's new asylum system and cooperation between Member States, it is essential to resolve the difficulties faced by irregular migrants. One of these difficulties is that some third countries do not accept return documents issued by Member States. This report proposes harmonising the format and technical specificities of this document – it is worth saying, proposes a European tout court document – always on the basis of ensuring the highest safety standards, as well as safeguarding the risk of counterfeiting and counterfeiting. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, by harmonising the format of the travel document, Member States will be able to reduce the bureaucracy, variation, costs and waiting periods associated with the return of irregular migrants to their states, as well as the recognition of this travel document by third countries.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because I believe that this proposal is fundamental to keep alive the sense of solidarity between peoples and respect the rights of the human person. It is essential to be supportive for those who are in an irregular situation and a long-term solution to the current migrant crisis must be found, in a spirit of cooperation between Member States and EU agencies, not limited, but also on the issuance of travel documents and individuals included in the list of third-country nationals who do not have valid travel documents to increase mutual recognition of travel decisions asylum seekers in the EU and avoid the secondary movement of those applicants who have been refused the right of asylum. Due to the high numbers of asylum applications that are not approved, a document is needed to harmonise the travel process, reduce bureaucracy, costs, waiting periods and increase recognition by third countries.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this regulation lays down a common format and the technical and security specifications of the European travel document for the return of illegally located third-country nationals, it must be understood that the return process is only part of a European Agenda on Migration, and that it must be accompanied by the assurance that this process is conducted in strict respect for human rights.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The European procedure for returning irregular migrants, on which a return order weighs, is currently not effective. In 2014, less than 40% of the total number of return decisions issued by Member States were implemented. However, about 60% of the time, the facilitation of this return, even in the case of a voluntary and desired return, cannot be carried out because the country of origin refuses to accept that person back into its territory due, inter alia, to the lack of documents or the recognition of these documents. This Regulation, which I supported with my vote, establishes a uniform European travel document which facilitates the return of third-country nationals subject to a return decision. The document must contain a passport photograph and be issued in an official EU language, with english and French translation and, where possible, the language of the country of return. On a socialist proposal, the report recalls that return, expulsion and extradition must be an element of last resort subject to an effective remedy.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposed regulation on a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals staying irregularly.  This regulation creates a better travel document for the future which will be more widely used by Member States and recognised by third countries. This will make it easier to return.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the unmeasured wave of migration that has beset the EU in recent years and which is currently one of the main priorities of the European agenda, many are migrants who are not covered by the international protection regime in the EU and need to leave The European area.  This report deals with the proposal for a Regulation of Parliament and the Council on a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals who are undocumented in the EU. The aim is not only to try to stabilise the current migration crisis, but also to relieve pressure on Member States and European agencies, whose capacity and resources are, as we know, limited. It is not a question of trying to respond to a purely conjunctural situation, because this is a drama that affects the very structure of European migration policy; rather, the aim is to promote substantive harmonisation and reformulation of the format and application of this European travel document, enhancing its recognition by third countries. Through this Regulation it will be possible for the EU to ensure a greater degree of safety and reliability of technical standards, in particular as regards counterfeiting and falsification of these documents.  I agree overall with the suggestions made by the rapporteur and, to that extent, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out the conditions for the European travel documents necessary for the return of third-country nationals who have failed their asylum applications. This report calls for the establishment of a common model and the technical and safety specifications of the harmonised European travel document.  If the Union is to guarantee rapid international protection to those who really need it, it must give itself the means to enforce readmission agreements with third countries.  With this in mind, I supported this report, which establishes a harmonized document, a useful instrument for return policy.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report as a legitimizing text of the regulated removal mechanism for migrants, which is part of the repressive and sectarian logic with which the EU has decided to deal with the humanitarian crisis caused in part by its irresponsible foreign policy. None of our group's amendments, focused on the necessary respect for the rights of migrants and data protection, was included in the final text.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a European travel document for the return of irregular third-country migrants, as a coordinated, harmonised document speeds up the process of orderly repatriation and resumption in third countries, thus providing relief for the competent European authorities.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. U2012 The expulsion of people who have fled the wars, misery and exploitation generated by the West is one of the key elements of the Fortress Europe that we reject. We understand that this is a measure contrary to the rights of migrants, who are expelled violently and against their will and it should be remembered that forced displacement is enshrined in international law as a crime against humanity. That is why we voted against this proposal whose sole objective is to speed up these deportations and reduce the limited guarantees and rights that migrants might have.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. EU countries currently face serious difficulties when repatriating migrants back to their home countries due to the fact that the documents used to facilitate the journey are not recognised by the countries of return. Having a single, unified EU document can be viewed as a diplomatic tool which will assist Member States in carrying out safer returns. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the draft legislative resolution because I consider the return of third-country nationals who do not or no longer fulfil the conditions for entry into or residence in the Union to be an extremely important part of a comprehensive effort to ensure the credibility and proper and effective functioning of the Union's migration policy. I regret that, although the Council Recommendation of 30 November 1994 established a standard travel document for return throughout the Union, there are many third-country nationals who are illegally present on the territory of the Union and do not have such a valid travel document. This, of course, creates serious problems for Member States in returning them legally and safely to their country of return. I therefore believe that, in order to stabilise the current migration crisis, the measures taken will alleviate the pressure on Member States and EU agencies and strengthen capacities and resources within the EU, which will provide not only short-term but also long-term solutions in this area. As many third countries are not yet willing to accept return documents issued by EU Member States due to their poor quality, I agree that the EU standard travel document should not only be revised, but its recognition should become a constant requirement under any future EU readmission and cooperation agreement.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the report on the proposal for a regulation on a European travel document for the return of illegally staying nationals from the Union to third countries.  From the available data, it can be inferred that the rate of return of irregular migrants to third countries is still very low, while third countries are at the same time refusing to accept low-quality return documents issued by individual Member States. In order to improve this adverse situation and reduce irregular migration, it is therefore necessary to establish a single Union document with high-quality technical and security features that the authorities of third countries can better accept. Thanks to increased acceptance by the authorities of third countries, such a document can not only become another effective tool for combating irregular migration, but will provide a place in Europe for those who really need asylum.  I have minor reservations about only two amendments. I believe that The Member States should not seek to 'obtain a guarantee' of recognition of the document, but directly to recognise it. Also, the return of irregular migrants should concern not only those who do not meet the conditions for entry and presence in the Union, but also those who do not fulfil the conditions for 'residence'.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. Unfortunately, the past few years have clearly shown that the EU and its Member States are completely overwhelmed in dealing with the asylum and refugee crisis. This is mainly due to the fact that existing legislation and international treaties such as the Dublin Regulation or the Schengen acquis are not being implemented. An important building block for regaining control of this crisis is to simplify the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers or third-country nationals who are illegally residing in the EU. To this end, a single European travel document will be created to facilitate returns. This is a step towards the restoration of the rule of law in the field of asylum and a step towards regaining citizens' shattered confidence in politics. Only if economic migrants who have entered the EU illegally are consistently deported can the citizens' willingness to help those who are truly persecuted and those threatened with life and limb can be maintained. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 The introduction of a replacement travel document serving for the rapid and safe readmission of persons to their home countries is a major step forward in the systemic solution to the migration crisis. However, in order for this document to fulfil its purpose, it will be necessary to ensure that it is recognised by as many countries as possible in the world.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support the creation of a new single European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals in the EU in the EP Plenary. The current rate of return of failed categories of asylum seekers is very low across the EU. In 2015, 43% of return decisions were implemented. While the main stumbling block is problematic cooperation with third countries in the readmission of their citizens on a wider range of issues, the European Travel Document for Return is a good and beneficial instrument. The EP and Council Regulations provide for a uniform form of this document, increasing its quality by introducing security features, thus eliminating one of the reasons for the refusal of documents issued by Member States by third countries. This should thus help to increase the level of successful implementation of member states' and EU readmission agreements with countries of transit or origin of persons deported from the territory of the Member States, including failed asylum seekers.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report, as some third-country nationals, who improperly reside within the Union and do not have valid travel documents, need to find a legal, safe and dignified way of returning these persons to the countries from which they originate and ensure readmission.  In particular, this is also an obligation prescribed by international customary law that all states must respect. Given that many third countries do not want to recognise return documents issued in Member States for poor quality, it is essential that the EU establishes a safer and more harmonised European travel document and establishes higher technical standards to protect against falsification and counterfeiting, which would also reduce the administrative and bureaucratic burden on the administrations of Member States and third countries.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I see no added value in handing a special travel document to illegally staying third-country nationals ("illegal immigrants"). Illegal refugees have usually lost their proper passport (but not their iPhone), or they have a fake passport. Why more bureaucracy now? I abstained on this resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union's priority must be to return people who do not qualify for international protection in the EU, as the current rate of return of asylum seekers who do not meet the requirements is insufficient to preserve the integrity of the EU asylum system, the cooperation of EU Member States with third countries and the retention of the trust of EUROPEAN Union citizens.  For this reason, the existing Standard Travel Document of the European Union needs to be substantially amended in terms of format and implementation in order to improve its recognition in third countries and to make it more effective. Among other things, it is important to harmonise the form of Member States' travel documents, protect it from counterfeiting and ensure the exchange of information between Member States regarding the issuance of travel documents.  I support the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Travel Document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals.  The migrant crisis, or the refugee crisis that we have seen recently, and the various security threats that have taken action from us. The return of those who are not eligible for international protection in the European Union and the improvement of the return of irregular migrants is essential for the integrity of the EU asylum system.  I support the need to fundamentally change the format and implementation of the existing EU standard travel document in order to increase its recognition and effectiveness in third countries. This will reduce red tape, the number of variants, the cost and the waiting period.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is impossible to overlook that on the territory of the Union there are millions of illegally detained migrants and persons whose application for asylum has been rejected. All of them are living or moving illegally within the EU and it is foolish to think that the big problem with their re-promotion is the provision of proper travel documents. In the case of Turkey and the other third countries which, while they have signed readmission agreements, do not respect them and even require more consideration, we must respond forcefully and decisively.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal, knowing that the harmonisation of the form and content of EU documents allowing third-country nationals who are or have entered the EU illegally to return home, including, where appropriate, deportation, is an urgent precondition for a more effective and humane common refugee policy. Member States or target states that refuse to accept migrants and refugees for political reasons, out of anti-foreignerism, or target states that are obliged to accept them, have so far been too easy, too often, to refer to the shortcomings of such travel documents.  Of course, we will not be able to completely eliminate this administrative-political tactics in the future, but with new, unified and modern documents, non-cooperative governments, both inside and outside the EU, will have one pretext for rejection and inhumane treatment of migrants. I hope that, in the wake of this decision, together with the introduction of more modern documents, the EU will step up its efforts to reach new reception and toloncents with countries that have so far been reeling from it.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In 2014, EU Member States issued almost half a million return decisions for migrants who do not have the right to enter or reside in the EU. However, only 40% of them have actually returned to a non-EU country. One of the main obstacles preventing return is the lack of valid travel documents for returnees. The effective return of third-country nationals who do not, or no longer fulfil the conditions for entry, residence or residence in the EU, is essential in order to ensure the credibility and proper functioning of THE EU's migration policy and to reduce and discourage irregular migration. The report rightly emphasises the need for EU Member States to ensure the effective use of the European return travel document, which will include information on the departure and arrival of a third-country national. It is also necessary to strengthen cooperation with diplomatic representations on this issue, while respecting existing international and European Union law.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed regulation aims to establish a dedicated European travel document for the return of third-country nationals subject to a return decision. This regulation provides for a uniform format and enhanced technical and security features, with the aim of ensuring wider acceptance of the document by third countries and increasing its use for readmissions. Some 60% of returns cannot be facilitated because the country of origin refuses to accept the person in question back into their country because of a lack of documents or the non-recognition of documents. There should be a guarantee that returns are carried out in a humane manner, ensuring the safe return and the safety of the returnees, and that fundamental rights are fully respected. I therefore support this regulation, which ensures all of the above.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. The return of those who do not qualify for international protection within the Union must be a priority for the European Union. Improving the rate of return of irregular migrants is essential for the integrity of the EU's asylum system, cooperation between EU Member States and third countries, and maintaining the confidence of EU citizens.  A long-term solution must be put in place to stabilise the current migration crisis, relieve pressure on Eu States and EU agencies, and increase capacity and resources within the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation on a European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals, as I believe that this initiative is urgently needed to improve the rate of returns for irregular migrants, and thereby stabilise the current migrant crisis in Europe. By harmonising the content and the technical specifications of the EU travel document we will not only increase its recognition by third countries, and reduce bureaucracy and associated costs for Member States through better cooperation, but also deter attempts at counterfeiting and falsification. A harmonised return policy will also guarantee that these returns are carried out with the full observance of fundamental rights.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals, as I believe that improving the rate of return of irregular migrants is an essential step towards ensuring the integrity of the asylum system, cooperation between Member States and third countries and maintaining citizens' trust in the EU.  By harmonising the form of the travel document, Member States will reduce red tape, the number of versions, costs and waiting times, and it is hoped that this will also increase the recognition of the document in third countries. Ensuring the exchange of information between Member States on the issue of travel documents and individuals listed as illegally staying third-country nationals without a valid travel document is essential as this can increase mutual recognition of asylum decisions throughout the European Union and prevent secondary movements of failed asylum seekers.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report as a legitimizing text of the regulated removal mechanism for migrants, which is part of the repressive and sectarian logic with which the EU has decided to deal with the humanitarian crisis caused in part by its irresponsible foreign policy. None of our group's amendments, focused on the necessary respect for the rights of migrants and data protection, was included in the final text.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. Unfortunately, the past few years have clearly shown that the EU and its Member States are completely overwhelmed in dealing with the asylum and refugee crisis. This is mainly due to the fact that existing legislation and international treaties such as the Dublin Regulation or the Schengen acquis are not being implemented. An important building block for regaining control of this crisis is to simplify the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers or third-country nationals who are illegally residing in the EU. To this end, a single European travel document will be created to facilitate returns. This is a step towards the restoration of the rule of law in the field of asylum and a step towards regaining citizens' shattered confidence in politics. Only if economic migrants who have entered the EU illegally are consistently deported can the citizens' willingness to help those who are truly persecuted and those threatened with life and limb can be maintained. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The proposal aims to introduce a standard European travel document to speed up the return of non-EU nationals in irregular situations to EU Member States who do not have passports or identity cards. It is very difficult for many European countries to return these people to their countries of origin by safe and legal means.  European Commission figures also suggest that only 40% of decisions taken within the EU to remove citizens from irregular third countries are applied each year. The new regulations will determine a common format for the European travel document to improve its recognition in destination countries. Its technical details will include personal information as well as an official photograph, in order to avoid counterfeits and forgeries. The document is valid for a single trip that ends upon the person's arrival in the return third country. This is a new element towards the establishment of a common asylum and immigration policy, which I categorically reject.  I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The European Travel Document is an instrument necessary for the proper management of asylum policy. It is the european Union's duty to protect and ensure the security of the citizens of the Member States, and it is therefore unacceptable not to have control over persons who have not been covered by EU asylum policy. It is necessary to speed up the process of issuing and harmonising documents and to introduce a system of safeguards so that such persons can leave the borders of the European Union without undue delay. I voted in support of the motion for a resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 A long-term solution should be provided in order to stabilise the current migration crisis, alleviate pressure on Member States and EU agencies and increase capacity and resources within the EU. I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against this report as it is a legitimizing text of the mechanism for the regulated expulsion of migrants which is part of the repressive and sectarian logic with which the EU has decided to deal with the humanitarian crisis caused in part by its irresponsible foreign policy. None of our group's amendments, focused on the necessary respect for the rights of migrants and data protection, was included in the final text.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The European refund travel document should help to reduce the administrative and bureaucratic burden on the administrations of Member States and third countries, including consulates, and help to shorten the administrative procedures necessary for the return and readmission of illegally staying third-country nationals in the EU.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals. The return of those who do not qualify for international protection within the EU must be a priority for the European Union. Improving the rate of returns for irregular migrants is vital for the integrity of the EU’s asylum system, for cooperation between EU Member States and third countries, and for maintaining the confidence of EU citizens. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU needs to ensure higher technical and security standards, in particular as regards safeguards against counterfeiting and falsification.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report. EU countries currently face serious difficulties when repatriating migrants back to their home countries due to the fact that the documents used to facilitate the journey are not recognised by the countries of return. Having a single, unified EU document can be viewed as a diplomatic tool which will assist Member States in carrying out safer returns. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. A return policy for illegal migrants is an essential part of the comprehensive approach to the Union's migration policy and serves to reduce and discourage irregular migration. Member States are experiencing difficulties in returning illegal migrants who do not have valid travel documents. The Commission is therefore proposing a regulation which the EP considers should only harmonise the format, safety features and technical specifications of the European travel document for return and not the rules for its issue. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The creation of a standard Ispeus European travel document to facilitate the repatriation of irregular migrants is part of the measures put forward by the Commission to manage migration flows and represents another face of this shameful process that characterises the European response to the migration crisis. A crisis generated by European and US imperialism, which should give rise to widespread EU mobilisation. On the contrary, this crisis has revealed the inesmanity of this EU that declares itself solidarity, but only with large multinational companies and the military industrial complex, which continues to generate billions of profits. Shame on you.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report deals only with the repatriation of third-country nationals and aims to simplify the return process if readmission agreements have been concluded with the countries of origin. The regulation is intended to standardise the format and technical specifications, but this will not change the problem of illegal migration to Europe. The document only adds to the administrative burden, as it would also have to be written into the language of the deportee's country of origin. In addition, it is not used to verify personal data and thus still makes it possible to provide false information. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of Parliament and of the Council on a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals whose stay is irregular.  The report aims to provide this document to non-EU citizens subject to a return decision, thereby ensuring a uniform model for all Member States and preventing countries of origin from rejecting the acceptance of these citizens by not recognising their documentation. In addition, this document will be assigned only to persons whose nationality has been identified, under no circumstances may it be referred to persons whose nationality is unknown. The text also stresses the importance, in return proceedings, of respect for the fundamental rights of the EU Charter, in particular dignity and protection in the event of expulsion, expulsion or extradition.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report. EU countries currently face serious difficulties when repatriating migrants back to their home countries due to the fact that the documents used to facilitate the journey are not recognised by the countries of return. Having a single, unified EU document can be viewed as a diplomatic tool which will assist Member States in carrying out safer returns. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation that we have approved today aims to introduce a single model to be used in all Member States to facilitate the return of those who do not meet the requirements to benefit from international protection within the EU. According to the Commission's intention, a single model would serve to increase the return rate of irregular migrants in order to maintain the integrity of the common European asylum system and improve cooperation with third countries.  To this end, it was necessary to substantially review the format and implementation of the EU standard travel document in order to increase its recognition by third countries. By harmonising the format of the travel document, The Member States will reduce bureaucracy, divergences, costs and waiting times, in the hope that this document will be better recognised by third countries. At the moment, many of these countries are not prepared to accept return documents issued by EU Member States because of their poor quality.  The EU must certainly ensure higher technological and safety standards, in particular as regards protection against the risk of counterfeiting and falsification.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The regulation on the so-called 'European travel document' aims, in the name of the lack of travel documents for migrants and refugees, to facilitate and speed up mass deportations back to the fire of wars, poverty and misery sown by the EU and its allies through their imperialist interventions for the interests of the business groups they represent. This 'deportation document' is a link in a chain of measures (EU-Turkey agreement, list of 'safe countries', European Asylum System, 'European Border Guard – Coast Guard', EU 'Dublin III', Schengen, etc.) review against refugees and migrants. The EU's anti-immigration policy will strengthen the wretched slave trade rings, multiply the hundreds of innocent victims in the Mediterranean and the tragedy of refugees and migrants facing the threat of deportation every day, such as the thousands stranded on the Greek islands (Lesvos, Chios) living in an unacceptable situation with negative consequences for the inhabitants exploited by the Nazis. Peoples' solidarity with refugees and migrants, the fight against imperialist wars and the unpopular policy of the EU and governments can put obstacles in the way of the barbarity of deportations, ensuring under the responsibility of the State human conditions and conditions of reception and hospitality and their safe transfer to their countries of final destination.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The proposal for a Regulation on a European Travel Document is closely linked to the recent creation of a new European Border and Coast Guard, namely the return of persons who do not qualify for international protection in the EU. These return operations were also inefficient because of the outdated and inconsistent travel document, which dates back to 1994, as the countries of origin of these persons did not recognise our travel document, mainly due to the lack of required elements. That is why I welcome the fact that the European travel document has undergone a change, the necessary technical and security features have been added to prevent counterfeiting, and it has been modernised overall to reflect progress on digitisation. And although I do not think that it will solve all the problems relating to the stay of failed asylum seekers on EU territory, I consider it a positive step, which is why I supported it with my vote.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of a travel document for the return of illegally staying third-country nationals. I believe that, in full respect of their fundamental rights, the return of illegally staying third-country nationals is an essential part of the comprehensive efforts to ensure the credibility and proper and effective functioning of the Union's migration policy and to help reduce and deter irregular migration.  The European Return Travel Document should also contribute to reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on the administrations of Member States and third countries and to reducing the administrative procedures necessary to ensure the return and readmission of illegally staying third-country nationals.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Regulation on the information leaflet to be published at the time of issue of securities, as the conditions are homogenized in all Member States, which contributes to strengthening the single market in financial services and capital. The internal market is still one of the key pieces for advancing the federal key in European integration into the economic, political and social dimensions. I am also pleased that the report has included our proposal that no purchaser of emissions can be excluded on the nationality or residence, even if the issues are granted to the quantitative exemption which allows the information leaflet or leaflet not to be published.  At the same time, the report makes it clear that if the issuer publishes the information leaflet and has been granted quantitative exemption, the issue will not have to meet additional requirements in Member States other than where it is produced.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The proposal grants the regulator (ESMA) and the Commission powers to issue delegated acts: UKIP is therefore against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns a ‘prospectus’ – an information and disclosure document – that must be provided to investors in the context of seeking to raise capital on the capital markets. The proposed regulation is part of the Capital Markets Union (CMU). The Commission wants further to harmonise the prospectus regime in the EU so that it will be easier for companies and investors to buy and sell bonds and shares. The proposed measures specifically aim to: reduce the administrative burden of drawing up prospectuses for all issuers, in particular for SMEs and frequent issuers of securities and secondary issuances; make the prospectus a more relevant disclosure tool for potential investors, especially in SMEs; and achieve greater convergence between the EU prospectus and other EU disclosure rules. We are in favour of maximum disclosure on risk to consumers, so we oppose some of the exemptions, but we are also fundamentally opposed to the CMU. Because of the CMU aspects in the report, I voted against it.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I would like to pay tribute to our group of Socialists and Democrats who fought to: - reduce legal costs and red tape; - reducing fragmentation of practices between Member States with a view to further integration of capital markets in the EU; - unlocking liquidity for institutional investors who are currently facing a low-interest environment; - harmonizing investor protection rules in different pieces of legislation; - avoid a race down between the Member States. We are particularly proud to have proposed to other groups a regime that simplifies the lives of SMEs by allowing them to use a standard document - easy to fill out by everyone without the help of banks or lawyers - to sell their securities.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prospectus to be published when offering securities publicly or when importing securities to be traded, because this reduces legal costs and red tape as well as reduces different practices between Member States by moving towards deeper integration of capital markets in the EU.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The revision of the prospectus rules is a key element of the Capital Markets Union and aims to facilitate financing through capital markets, reduce administrative burdens for companies that draw up a prospectus and make the prospectus an essential source of information for potential investors. The report adopted by Parliament and the Council will definitely contribute to achieving these above objectives. In particular, I welcome the new provisions on the EU growth prospectus, which should allow SMEs easier access to financing on the capital markets.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Among other reasons, I voted against this resolution because it grants the Commission authority to issue and adopt regulatory technical standards.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading.  The proposed purpose of the Regulation is to lay down requirements for the preparation, approval and distribution of a prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading on a regulated market established in a Member State. This means that the prospectus must contain the information necessary for investors to make an informed investment decision.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The revision of the "prospectus" directive is an important step in the construction of the Capital Markets Union. The EU's harmonised prospectus is the 'gateway' to European capital markets for issuers seeking financing. The Action Plan for the Establishment of a Capital Markets Union presents a comprehensive and ambitious programme of measures to strengthen the role of financial market financing in the European economy. One of the main objectives of the Capital Markets Union is to facilitate the raising of capital in the capital markets. These markets reach a wide range of funders and provide a way out for private equity funds that invest in companies at an early stage of their development. Prospectuses are documents required by law, which provide information about a company. This information is the basis for investors to decide whether to invest in the various securities issued by the company in question.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ježek report, which I supported today, approves the revision of the European regulation on the prospectus to be published for the offer to the public or admission to securities trading. This regulation is an essential step towards the completion of the Capital Markets Union, as has already been indicated by the Commission, the European Parliament and the Council.  The proposed changes are aimed at fully harmonising the rules on prospectuses and define more precise European standards for investor protection. In particular, small and medium-sized enterprises are considered, with regard to which a clear commitment is made to reduce the administrative burden and legal costs arising from the preparation of the prospectus. Thanks to these measures, SMEs will be able to gain easier access to the capital market and increase their chances of obtaining finance.  Reducing the fragmentation of existing practices in the EU has many positive aspects and is a key step in the real integration of the capital market. At a time when institutional investors are facing the low interest rates that characterise the European economy, this is an inescapable measure.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this regulatory proposal, aimed at establishing the rules that financial companies must comply with when informing the consumer about the financial products they sell. On the one hand, it seems to us that this regulation, as well as all those included in the Capital Market Union Commission project, promotes a financed economy with a high tendency to financial instability and speculation, with an increasingly limited capacity of States to direct funding flows to activities and projects of general interest. On the other hand, it seems to us that the proposed regulation of prospects is excessively lax and does not contain sufficient elements to warn of the risks and responsibilities that the consumer acquires when purchasing these products.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to congratulate my groupmate Petr Jezek on his work in this report on the prospectus to be published in the event of a public offering or admission to securities quotes. The purpose of the same is to define the requirements for the preparation, approval and distribution of this prospectus. It's a good step forward for transparency and clarification.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the prospectus to be issued in the event of an offer to the public of securities or for the admission of securities to the negotiation is part of the Capital Markets Union. The term prospectus is the documentation that issuers of public offering financial products must make available to investors. The Commission wanted to simplify documentation with a new mandatory prospectus of more than 5 million euros per issue over one year and states are free to impose their standards when this format is not mandatory. Overall, from a strictly technical point of view, the redesign of the prospectus directive can be justified. On the text itself and the Capital Markets Union, it is more questionable to want to further financialise the financing of companies, especially SMEs. The winners will actually be primarily market companies and investment banks. So I abstained.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting investors through transparency in the markets seems to be the aim of this report. However, noting that nothing has been done to date to reimburse citizens who have been scammed by banks since the bail-in mechanism came into force, I cannot fully agree with this text. I therefore preferred to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The current Directive 2003/71/EC on the obligation to publish an information leaflet understandable to the average investor has been outdated by market developments, and in general by the uneven application made by the Member States thereof. For this reason, the Commission has chosen to replace it with this regulation which I voted in favour, which simplifies reporting obligations for SMEs and allows national exemptions for emissions of less than EUR 5 million, as well as ensuring uniform application. I also welcome the socialist proposal that the Regulation can be voluntarily fulfilled even if it is below the threshold, which will allow the issuer to benefit from the coverage offered by it, that is to say, to be able to be deployed within the framework of the internal market with the authorisation of a single Member State.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has given Parliament its position on the regulation on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading. This Regulation is one of the most important steps towards completing the 2015 The Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions entitled 'Capital Markets Union Action Plan' describes capital markets union. The aim of the Capital Markets Union is to help businesses benefit from a wider range of sources of capital across the European Union ('the Union') to ensure that markets operate more efficiently and to offer investors and savers additional opportunities to invest their funds to stimulate growth and create jobs.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, together with the European Council and the Commission, has prepared very interesting legislation for Slovenia on how a prospectus should be drawn up when securities are put to the public when securities are admitted to trading.  The disastrous experience of the public sale of NKBM shares and a few years later, with the expropriation of the owners of subordinated bonds, which were apparently purchased by completely unin'oeunced citizens, suggests that, on average, a Slovenian investor is very poorly in -- about the risks involved in their investments.  By harmonising the information on the presentation prospectuses and with clear risk provisions for retail investors in particular, we are likely to prevent many people from investing their hard-to-save assets in significantly riskier investments than I would have liked.  I therefore absolutely support such legislation on the notification of retail investors, which is why I voted in favour of the report in the European Parliament.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this Report on the EUTF for Africa, which aims to help foster stability in regions and contribute to better migration management, namely addressing destabilisation, forced displacement and irregular migration by promoting economic opportunities, equal opportunities, security and development.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Regulation on the information leaflet to be published at the time of issue of securities, as the conditions are homogenized in all Member States, which contributes to strengthening the single market in financial services and capital. The internal market is still one of the key pieces for advancing the federal key in European integration into the economic, political and social dimensions. I am also pleased that the report has included our proposal that no purchaser of emissions can be excluded on the nationality or residence, even if the issues are granted to the quantitative exemption which allows the information leaflet or leaflet not to be published.  At the same time, the report makes it clear that if the issuer publishes the information leaflet and has been granted quantitative exemption, the issue will not have to meet additional requirements in Member States other than where it is produced.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the prospectus to be published for the offer to the public or admission to securities trading. This regulation is a necessary step towards the completion of the Market Union. The aim of the Capital Markets Union is to help companies raise capital from multiple sources of finance. To this end, the functioning of markets must be made more efficient and investors and savers must be offered additional opportunities to help strengthen growth and create jobs. Disclosure about the offer of securities to the public or their trading in a regulated market is essential to protect investors. Disclosure of information is necessary so that investors can make targeted investment decisions, thus ensuring their protection. In addition, information is an effective tool for increasing confidence in securities. The publication of a prospectus may be the right solution for making the information in question available to the public.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report relates to a ‘prospectus’ – an information and disclosure document – that must be provided to investors in the context of seeking to raise capital on the capital markets. The proposed regulation is part of the Capital Markets Union (CMU). The Commission wants further to harmonise the prospectus regime in the EU so that it will be easier for companies and investors to buy and sell bonds and shares. The proposed measures specifically aim to: reduce the administrative burden of drawing up prospectuses for all issuers, in particular for SMEs and frequent issuers of securities and secondary issuances; make the prospectus a more relevant disclosure tool for potential investors, especially in SMEs; and achieve more convergence between the EU prospectus and other EU disclosure rules. We are in favour of maximum disclosure on risk to consumers, so we oppose some of the exemptions but we are also fundamentally opposed to the CMU. Because of the CMU aspects in the report I voted against it.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ In accordance with Rule 61(2) of the Rules of Procedure, the vote on the draft legislative resolution has been postponed and the report has been referred back to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this text. , products and investors involved.  On the contrary, in this Commission proposal, the rules are weakened and a great many unjustified exemptions are introduced. Disclosure requirements for some subjects have been eased and, in addition, entire market shares and entities have been excluded from the scope of the regulation, thereby compromising the completeness and correctness of information on the risks associated with investments. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We call on the committee responsible to review the report again.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report because I firmly believe that investors should be able to know the best possible about the conditions offered by financial intermediaries. All too often, cases of betrayed savers are now rising to the headlines, and this is unacceptable: the protection of savings is a constitutional right and everyone must be able to have free access to what concerns them. The subject of the appeal to the public savings has elements of internationality, thus becoming potentially open to evaluation by a plurality of authorities. This phenomenon raises inevitable doubts of interpretation, as state legislation in this respect is often differentiated.  The aim of this prospectus is therefore to put order in order to achieve the union of capital markets in its own right, allowing effective and secure access for companies to these forms of financing. Only in this way can growth - especially that of our SMEs - be strengthened and jobs created.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision of the European Parliament to refer the report on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading back to the Committee on Economic Affairs.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The proposal grants the regulator (ESMA) and the Commission powers to issue delegated acts, therefore UKIP is against it.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. –  It is important that the regulatory environment at Union level ensures that companies have enough options to raise capital. Therefore, in the spirit of the Capital Markets Union and in order to unlock investment, it would be good to have a regulatory initiative to regulate and harmonise crowdfunding practices across the Union. As legislators we should refrain from imposing at national level other disclosure requirements which could constitute a disproportionate or unnecessary burden in relation to such offers and thus increase fragmentation of the internal market. The varying sizes of financial markets across the Union should be taken in account.  It is appropriate to give Member States the option of exempting offers of securities to the public in case of certain thresholds.  In this sense I agree with the rapporteur that Member States should be free to set out in their national law a threshold, within the established parameters, from which the exemption should apply, taking into account the level of domestic investor protection they deem to be appropriate.   On the other hand, harmonisation of the information contained in the prospectus should provide equivalent investor protection at Union level in order to enable investors to make an informed investment decision.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a step forward in financing the business fabric of the European Union, adopting a model similar to that of the United States to promote speculative financing methods for companies related to the real economy, mainly Small and Medium-sized Enterprises. This proposal, which sets out the information requirements of these companies, is a necessary step within the Capital Market Union, in order to enable financial funds to short-circuit banking requirements and to be able to speculate directly on the financing of SMEs. This will result in the destabilization of the real economy and the externalization of the financial sector's risk to small and medium-sized enterprises. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Capital Markets Union is to help businesses capital sources from anywhere in the European Union, to make markets run efficiently and to provide investors and savers with additional opportunities to use their money, to stimulate economic growth and create jobs. Therefore, in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and to improve the conditions for this functioning, it is appropriate to establish a regulatory framework for prospectuses at Union level. I voted to guarantee investor protection and market efficiency by strengthening the single capital market.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as I believe that prospectuses published when companies want to raise capital either by listing shares or by offering investment opportunities to the general public must contain the necessary information for investors to make an informed investment decision. I believe that a summary of the prospectus would make it easier and less expensive for companies to ensure that retail investors have access to appropriate information so that they can make an informed decision. I agree that this prospectus should be a short document written in a concise manner and easily comparable.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report’s aim of simplifying the rules and procedures for companies to issue a prospectus, allowing investors to make informed decisions, but enhancing SMEs’ access to finance. At the moment, SMEs often face disproportionate and unfair costs when drawing up a prospectus, and this dampens growth and expansion in that sector of the economy.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The revision of the Prospectus Regulation to be published for the offer to the public or admission to trading in securities is one of the key elements in the completion of the Capital Markets Union. With the report adopted today, the European Parliament is relaunching this vital and ambitious project and clarifying its position on what is an essential tool for informing European citizens when they decide to invest in the financial markets: the prospectus.  I voted in favour because the report promotes full harmonisation of the rules on prospectuses and establishes more precise European rules for investor protection. In addition, it undertakes to reduce the administrative burden and legal costs arising from the preparation of the prospectus for issuers, in particular SMEs, so as to make it easier for them to access the capital market and increase their chances of obtaining finance.  The European Union has a duty to provide all the tools and information to help citizens-investors to make informed and fully informed choices, on the basis of the prospectus, without imposing an excessive burden on companies that decide to place financial instruments on the markets.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to revise the prospectus rules to be published in the event of an offer to the public of securities or for the admission of securities to trading, in order to ensure investor protection and market efficiency. By adopting this text, we ensure, among other things, that these leaflets contain the necessary information for a good understanding and that they are written in a way that facilitates easy analysis. There is a need for a climate of trust to contribute to investment in securities.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the prospectus report to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading, as it is key to the proper functioning of the common capital market. The report aims to improve access to finance for companies of all sizes, in particular SMEs, and to reduce barriers while maintaining adequate investor protection.  The report simplifies the rules for drawing up, approving and publishing prospectuses where the securities are offered to the public or traded on a regulated market. This will greatly support SMEs, as they often face excessive costs when drawing up prospectuses in order to access capital.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This regulation essentially marks the resumption of financial market activity, which will therefore probably boost speculation and destabilise economies.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The prospectus shall include the information necessary for investors to make an informed investment decision. The Commission has proposed a revision of the Prospectus Directive with a view to making it easier and less expensive for businesses, including SMEs, to mobilise capital and provide clear information to potential investors, including small investors. I agree that facilitating access to finance for SMEs is beneficial and that consumers would also benefit from increased investment options.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Abstention: on a strictly technical level, the redesign of the "Prospectus" directive can be justified.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ The main reasons for the economic crisis are not addressed in this proposal at all, as the main problem for businesses is not getting access to funding but rather a lack of demand for their products due to ongoing austerity policies.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The review of the prospectus directive in question is included in the Capital Markets Action Plan as one of the early and high priority objectives. Its main objective is to reduce one of the main regulatory obstacles that eminents face when offering their equity and debt securities to retail and wholesale investors. At the same time, the proposal also aims to make the prospectus an important tool for informing potential investors, especially cross-border ones. It is very important that we have succeeded in making progress together for small and medium-sized enterprises, because they will be able to trade without the help of lawyers or banks using a single standard document.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the prospectus to be published when offering securities publicly or when securities are admitted to trading, as this regulation essentially marks the resumption of the activity of financial markets, which will therefore probably boost speculation and destabilise economies.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The review of the Prospectus Directive is one of the Capital Markets Union (CMU) Action Plan’s early and high-priority measures, and I support its main aim: to reduce one of the principal regulatory hurdles that issuers face when offering their equity and debt securities to retail and wholesale investors. I also support the concept of disclosure rules which are tailored to issuers’ specific needs. It is very important to make the prospectus a relevant tool for informing potential investors, especially in a cross-border context. In order to create a real CMU and to deepen EU capital markets, it is more than useful to create the same rules for all companies in all Member States, thus reducing the fragmentation of practices across the Member States and moving towards closer integration of the EU markets – although, regarding the summary of the prospectus, I believe that this should be translated into the official language of the country where the security is issued, in order to foster cross-border investment.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the prospectus to be published when securities are issued to the public or marketed. It is an essential step towards achieving a Capital Markets Union aimed at helping businesses to resort to more diversified funding channels anywhere in the European Union, encouraging markets to operate more efficiently and offering investors and savers additional opportunities to use their money to boost growth and job creation. Disclosure of information when securities are issued to the public or placed on a regulated market is essential for the protection of investors. The harmonisation of this disclosure makes it possible to establish a cross-border licensing mechanism that can facilitate the effective functioning of the internal market in a wide range of securities. Furthermore, it is necessary that the disclosure rules applicable at the time of its introduction be in the form of a regulation in order to ensure that the provisions laying down direct obligations on persons involved in the issue of securities to the public and the introduction into trading on a regulated market are applied in a uniform manner throughout the Union. Cross-border securities issues, multiple subscriptions on regulated markets and EU consumer protection rules should not be obstacles.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Regulation on the information leaflet to be published at the time of issue of securities, as the conditions are homogenized in all Member States, which contributes to strengthening the single market in financial services and capital. The internal market is still one of the key pieces for advancing the federal key in European integration into the economic, political and social dimensions. I am also pleased that the report has included our proposal that no purchaser of emissions can be excluded on the nationality or residence, even if the issues are granted to the quantitative exemption which allows the information leaflet or leaflet not to be published.  At the same time, the report makes it clear that if the issuer publishes the information leaflet and has been granted quantitative exemption, the issue will not have to meet additional requirements in Member States other than where it is produced.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on the Regulation on the information leaflet to be published when issues of securities are made, as conditions are homogenized in all Member States, which contributes to strengthening the single market in financial services and capital. The internal market is still one of the key pieces for advancing the federal key in European integration into the economic, political and social dimensions. I also welcome the fact that the report has included our proposal that no purchasers cannot be excluded from emissions on the nationality or residence, even if the issues are granted to the quantitative exemption which allows the information leaflet or leaflet not to be published. At the same time, the report makes it clear that if the issuer publishes the information leaflet and has been granted quantitative exemption, the issue will not have to meet additional requirements in Member States other than where it is produced.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's position on the proposal for a regulation on the prospectus to be published for the offer to the public or admission to securities trading, as I believe that it represents a further step towards an integrated single market in financial services. I believe that the changes made by the EP improve the Commission's proposal. Indeed, I agree that the prospectus drawn up pursuant to this Regulation should contain the relevant and necessary information in relation to an investment in securities that an investor would reasonably need in order to assess in full knowledge of the facts the financial position, profits and losses and prospects of the issuer and any guarantors, as well as the rights related to the securities. This information should be processed and presented in a form that can be easily analysed.  Similarly, the summary should contain a clear warning highlighting risks, in particular for retail investors, in the case of securities issued by bail-in banks under Directive 2014/59/EU. Finally, I welcome the integration of principles and proportionality criteria, given the different sizes of EU financial markets, and the possibility for Member States to set lower thresholds.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the 'Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prospectus to be published on the public offer of securities or when they are admitted to trading'. The report guarantees greater security for consumers when investing in securities.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The report on prospectuses is a key part of the Capital Markets Union (CMU), and will help improve access to funding for SMEs, of which there are 400 000 in my West Midlands constituency. Among the key features of this report is the fact that prospectuses are to be streamlined, thus reducing legal costs and red tape. In addition, in order to deepen integration of EU capital markets, we need to see less fragmentation of practices across Member States. As well as broadening the range of financing available to SMEs, we are also improving investor protection rules. This report shifts the focus of the prospectus from an exercise in lining the pockets of banks and lawyers to improving funding for SMEs and delivering the jobs and growth that we need.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this proposal for a Regulation, which is intended to lay down the rules to be met by financial companies when informing the consumer about the financial products they sell. On the one hand, it seems to us that this regulation, as well as all those included in the Capital Market Union Commission project, promotes a financed economy with a high tendency to financial instability and speculation, with an increasingly limited capacity of States to direct funding flows to activities and projects of general interest. On the other hand, it seems to us that the proposed regulation of prospects is excessively lax and does not contain sufficient elements to warn of the risks and responsibilities that the consumer acquires when purchasing these products.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I was shadow rapporteur for the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection of the S&D Group for this report and I know how necessary it is, especially for SMEs. At the same time, the Capital Markets Union is a complex issue, which is why I voted to postpone the vote and return to the committee responsible for the substance. The prospectus is an essential element in the process of building the Capital Markets Union, but also a "gateway" to European capital markets for issuers in need of financing. It is important to remove unnecessary barriers to access to public markets and to encourage SMEs to launch public offerings of real estate values by reducing unnecessary red tape and reducing costs in order to facilitate the fulfilment of administrative obligations. At the same time, the prospectus must be a relevant instrument, ensuring rules tailored to the specific needs of all issuers, in particular as regards SMEs, frequent issuers of securities and secondary transactions, as well as potential investors.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Prospectuses published when securities are offered to investors or admitted to trading will become simplified and cheaper, in order to help businesses, especially SMEs, to find diverse sources of capital across the EU. The uniform rules for prospectuses and the information they disclose will protect investors while creating an efficient single market for capital.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Regulation on the information leaflet to be published at the time of issue of securities, as the conditions are homogenized in all Member States, which contributes to strengthening the single market in financial services and capital. The internal market is still one of the key pieces for advancing the federal key in European integration into the economic, political and social dimensions. I am also pleased that the report has included our proposal that no purchaser of emissions can be excluded on the nationality or residence, even if the issues are granted to the quantitative exemption which allows the information leaflet or leaflet not to be published.  At the same time, the report makes it clear that if the issuer publishes the information leaflet and has been granted quantitative exemption, the issue will not have to meet additional requirements in Member States other than where it is produced.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 According to this new regulation, access to corporate finance is one of the important issues that led to the crisis, so harmonising measures are proposed through which companies will reduce their "bureaucratic" costs so that they can more easily target financing. The aim of the regulation is to 'Americanise' the European economy and how banks are financed. Further regulation and harmonisation of financial activities will probably bring more speculation than access to finance, as it is not access to finance that created the crisis but the lack of demand for business products from ongoing austerity measures. This setting fails to fully address this issue. For these reasons, we considered this vote to be an appropriate stance.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation, which constitutes an essential step towards the completion of the Capital Markets Union (CMU). The reform of the current directive will reduce the administrative burden of drawing up prospectuses for all issuers, and in particular for SMEs. It will also make the prospectus a more relevant disclosure tool for potential investors, while unifying EU capital markets to deliver high levels of investor protection, and thus creating growth and jobs. The aim of this regulation is to ensure investor protection and market efficiency, while enhancing the single market for capital through the publication of a prospectus by a company when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading. The provision on the data published in the prospectus ensures that investors will be able to make an informed assessment on investment decisions. The prospectus includes information which, according to the nature of the issuer and of the securities, is necessary to enable investors to make an informed evaluation, as well as rules on the conduct of business and the protection of investors. Such information provides an effective means of increasing confidence in securities and thus of contributing to the proper functioning and development of securities markets.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections to the proposal.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The proposal grants the regulator (ESMA) and the Commission powers to issue delegated acts, therefore UKIP is against it.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The introduction of regulations that simplify the lives of SMEs through the standardisation of documents for selling securities is long overdue.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the Prospectus published when the securities are publicly offered or listed for trading (COM(2015)0583 - C8-0375/2015-2015/0268 (COD)), as this regulation represents an essential step towards completing the Capital Markets Union, and aims to facilitate economic operators' access to diverse sources of capital financing from across the European Union in the same way.  A harmonised framework is needed to ensure the uniqueness of the necessary information for the public offering of securities. This regulates the market, facilitates the process especially for smaller companies and protects investors and reduces the cost of raising capital for businesses. I support activating the non-equity securities market to retail investors.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The proposal grants the regulator (ESMA) and the Commission powers to issue delegated acts, therefore UKIP is against it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ This is the first legislative proposal associated with the Capital Markets Union and I am proud to have been able to steer the regulation through Parliament. We have introduced the concept of a ‘growth prospectus’ in order to ensure that small businesses are not hindered from getting access to capital by over-burdensome requirements and costs associated with producing a prospectus. We need to reduce administration, harmonise the European regime and help our companies grow.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out Parliament's position on the reform of the rules for issuing prospectuses when offering securities. This reform is part of the European Commission's plan to create a single capital market which aims to simplify documentation, particularly for SMEs, to harmonize national and unequal regimes between 'wholesale' and 'retail' and to centralise information with the relevant European authority.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. \u2012 The harmonisation of prospectuses informing investors about investment opportunities and risks is a crucial element in the success of the Capital Markets Union. In many EU Member States, the quality of the information was inadequate or deliberately unclear, thus causing significant market distortions, due to poor monitoring by local regulators. The introduction of common mandatory standards in relation to investment prospectuses effectively introduces a new risk control point resulting from undeveloped governance systems within investment firms in Member States with a very poor tradition, as well as another operational risk control point involved in such cases.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report is a one-way move, provides more and clearer information for the consumer and provides clarity on issuers' liability issues. In principle, the approach is a step forward for harmonisation and, at the same time, creates flexibility in those areas where it is needed. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The Commission's proposal aims to make it easier and cheaper for businesses, in particular SMEs, to raise capital while providing clear information to potential investors, including retail investors. It is unlikely that the resumption of capital market-based financing could be a solution for companies that need more capital to continue and expand their activities, since economic difficulties are essentially a consequence of austerity, neoliberal policies that reduce the demand for SME activities and products. The main and real objective of the Capital Markets Union is to revive the activity of the financial markets.
