This will lead to speculation rather than economic recovery and is likely to destabilise the economy and therefore the report is ineligible.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The current prospectus contains the information necessary for investors in order to make informed investment decisions.  In the field of capital markets, the Commission has proposed a revision of the Prospectus Directive in order to make it easier and cheaper for companies to obtain capital and provide clear information for possible investors. The current Directive 2003/71/EC harmonises the rules for making prospectuses public when companies wish to raise capital by listing or by offering investment opportunities to the general public.  In order to be able to make an informed decision, it is essential for investors to have access to adequate information. For these reasons, I am in favour of and support the decision taken by Parliament.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. On a strictly technical level, the redesign of the "Prospectus" regulation can be justified. On the philosophy of the text and the Union of Capital Markets, it is more questionable to want to further financialise the financing of companies, especially SMEs. The main winners will be primarily market companies and investment banks. We are more in favour of long-term partnerships of companies with banks refocused on their business and on loans to the real economy, not on speculation and market operations. So I opted for abstention.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Regulation on the information leaflet to be published at the time of issue of securities, as the conditions are homogenized in all Member States, which contributes to strengthening the single market in financial services and capital. The internal market is still one of the key pieces for advancing the federal key in European integration into the economic, political and social dimensions. I am also pleased that the report has included our proposal that no purchaser of emissions can be excluded on the nationality or residence, even if the issues are granted to the quantitative exemption which allows the information leaflet or leaflet not to be published.  At the same time, the report makes it clear that if the issuer publishes the information leaflet and has been granted quantitative exemption, the issue will not have to meet additional requirements in Member States other than where it is produced.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a step forward in financing the business fabric of the European Union, adopting a model similar to that of the United States to promote speculative financing methods for companies related to the real economy, mainly Small and Medium-sized Enterprises. This proposal, which sets out the information requirements of these companies, is a necessary step within the Capital Market Union, in order to enable financial funds to short-circuit banking requirements and to be able to speculate directly on the financing of SMEs. This will result in the destabilization of the real economy and the externalization of the financial sector's risk to small and medium-sized enterprises. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. U2012 Disclosure of information in the event of public offerings of securities or admission of securities to trading on a regulated market is vital to protect investors, eliminating information asymmetry between them and issuers. The harmonisation of this disclosure of information allows the establishment of a cross-border passport mechanism to facilitate the effective functioning of the internal market in a wide variety of securities. We cannot forget that differentiation of approaches results in fragmentation of the internal market. I therefore consider that it is necessary that the rules on the disclosure of information in the event of a public offer or admission to securities trading on a regulated market should take the same legal form as set out in a regulation, in order to ensure that provisions involving direct obligations to those involved are made uniformly.  I vote favourably for the adoption of this report because I also believe that this regulation will strengthen confidence in the transparency of markets through the union as a whole, reduce regulatory complexity and search and regulatory compliance costs for businesses.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This proposal is crucial for the process of further integrating the capital markets of the Member States of the European Union. In order to ensure growth and create new jobs, it is necessary to provide businesses with access to more diverse sources of capital and to ensure the efficient operation of the market. Investors and savers should be provided with further options for using their financial resources more efficiently to stimulate economic growth. The prospectus published in the public offering of securities or the listing for trading is an essential element of the improvement of the single capital market, as it enables the protection of investors. Issuing and harmonising the publication of a prospectus removes the asymmetrical availability of data between them and the issuer. Also, the information provided allows investors to make an informed investment decision.  The principles and regulations laid down in Directive 2003/71/EC of the European Parliament and the Council must be amended in view of the news that has emerged on the legislative and market fronts since its adoption. I supported the proposal for a regulation and the proposed reforms because they contain complements that are important for further building a Capital Markets Union and reduce unnecessary administrative barriers.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this proposal is to reform the prospectus rules in order to enhance investor protection and market efficiency while establishing the Capital Markets Union. This information is to be the basis on which investors can decide whether to invest in a variety of securities. I agree that a harmonised EU prospectus is an essential tool for the integration of capital markets throughout the Union.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Prospectuses are legally required documents that provide information about a particular company so that on their basis the investor can decide whether to invest in securities issued by that company. It is important that the proposed directive removes unnecessary administrative burdens when creating a harmonised prospectus. A prospectus approved by the national authorities shall be accepted by all Member States of the Union without further approval in another Member State. At the same time, the conditions for providing more relevant data to potential investors are created, which may ultimately revive the capital market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Referring to my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/9/2016, I note that I voted in favour of postponing the vote in accordance with the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. From a strictly technical point of view, the redesign of the "Prospectus" regulation can be justified. The Commission wanted to simplify documentation by making it both more concise and more readable, which we agree with. On the other hand, on the spirit of the text and the Capital Markets Union, it is more questionable to want to further financialise the financing of companies, especially SMEs. The main winners will be primarily market companies and investment banks. We are more in favour of long-term partnerships between companies and banks refocused on their business and loans to the real economy than to speculation and market operations.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report provides more and clearer information for the consumer. It also provides clarity on liability issues on the part of issuers. I therefore support this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amendments to the Regulation as one of the most important steps towards completing the Capital Markets Union. The aim of the Capital Markets Union is to help businesses benefit from a wider range of sources of capital across the European Union ('the Union') to ensure that markets function more efficiently and to offer investors and savers additional opportunities to invest their funds in order to stimulate growth and create jobs.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. "The prospectuses are documents required by law, which provide information about a company. This information is the basis for investors to decide whether to invest in the various securities issued by the company in question." The report argues that the EU's harmonised prospectus is an essential tool for integrating capital markets across the EU. It specifies how it works. Thus, it is appropriate that these prospectuses "should include a clear warning of risks, particularly for retail investors." For my part, I fear that the publication of such brochures is not enough to fight against finance. Especially in the context of the Union of Capital Markets and the financial arrangements it allows (securitisation, shadow banking, etc.). More red tape and bureaucracy. Benchmarking is an archaic formalist dictatorship. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. On a strictly technical level, the redesign of the "Prospectus" regulation can be justified. On the philosophy of the text and the Union of Capital Markets, it is more questionable to want to further financialise the financing of companies, especially SMEs. The main winners will be primarily market companies and investment banks. We are more in favour of long-term partnerships of companies with banks refocused on their business and loans to the real economy than to speculation and market operations. So I abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation is an essential step towards the realisation of the Capital Markets Union, as set out in the Commission's communication to the European Parliament, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions entitled 'Action Plan for the Creation of a Capital Markets Union' of 30 September 2015. The Capital Markets Union aims to help companies take advantage of sources of capital from anywhere in the European Union ('the Union'), make markets work more effectively and offer investors and earners additional opportunities to apply their money in order to increase growth and create jobs. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution as it furthers the Union’s drive to complete the Capital Markets Union – ensuring proper protection for investors by removing asymmetries of information between them and issuers.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report, which aims to strengthen the rules on prospectuses that a company must publish in order to inform potential investors. These are measures to strengthen the capital markets union. The aim is to set up a prospectus containing the information to properly assess the desired investment in a real estate value. Access to information is essential if we are to create a framework of trust conducive to investment and therefore growth. The European Parliament has taken an ambitious position, calling for genuine European harmonisation of the regime. However, we will now have to go into negotiations with the Council so that this legislation can actually succeed.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The proposal to recast the Prospectus Directive aims to simplify and make it cheaper to raise capital for businesses, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and to provide clear information to potential investors, including retail investors. It is important that retail investors have access to adequate information so that they can make informed choices. The proposal supports the opening-up of the non-equity securities market to retail investors and the reduction of the exemption for bonds with a minimum value above EUR 100 000, while maintaining the differentiation between qualified and unskilled investors in terms of providing information. The investor should be able to read the summary of the prospectus in one of the official languages of his home Member State, the summary being translated as necessary. Improving access to finance for SMEs benefits both SMEs and consumers, who could also benefit from a wider choice of investment options. I support the proposal with my vote.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation, which aims to reduce one of the principal regulatory hurdles that issuers face when offering their equity and debt securities to retail and wholesale investors, and also to provide all types of issuers with disclosure rules tailored to their specific needs. At the same time, the proposal aims to make the prospectus a more relevant tool for informing potential investors, especially in a cross-border context. The regulation also simplifies the lives of SMEs by allowing them to use a standard document – that is easy for anyone to fill in without the help of banks or lawyers – to sell their securities.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council a regulation on prospectuses to be published when securities are issued to the public or marketed. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal at first reading with a consolidated text with a number of substantial amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. On a practical level, the redesign of the "Prospectus" directive can be justified. On the philosophy of the text and the union of capital markets, it is more questionable to want to further financialize the financing of companies, especially SMEs. The main winners will be primarily market companies and investment banks. We are more in favour of long-term partnerships of companies with banks refocused on their business and loans to the real economy than to speculation and market operations. For this reason, and despite better thresholds for SMEs and simplified obligations, we abstain on this text.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. On a strictly technical level, the redesign of the Prospectus Directive can be justified. On the philosophy of the text and the union of capital markets, it is more questionable to want to further financialize the financing of companies, especially SMEs. The main winners will be primarily market companies and investment banks. I am more in favour of long-term partnerships of companies with banks refocused on their business and loans to the real economy than to speculation and market operations. I therefore abstain on this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. This text establishes the European Parliament's position on the reform of the regulation on the rules applicable to the issuance of prospectuses in a securities offering. In particular, I support one of the objectives of this reform, which was to simplify documentation, especially for SMEs that are still under too much administrative constraints. I voted for it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation represents an indispensable step forward towards the completion of the Capital Markets Union. I voted for the report, which will ensure market efficiency and investor protection while enhancing the single market for capital.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is an important step towards the completion of the Capital Markets Union, addressing the issue of the presentation of information in the event of a public offering of securities or the admission of securities to trading on a regulated market.  The harmonisation of these rules provides better protection for investors and ensures the smooth functioning of the internal market, reducing fragmentation. This will reduce situations where the persons involved are subject to different rules in each Member State, reducing the risk that prospectuses approved in one State cannot be used in another Member State.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This report relates to a ‘prospectus’ – an information and disclosure document – that must be provided to investors in the context of seeking to raise capital on the capital markets. The proposed regulation is part of the Capital Markets Union (CMU). The Commission wants further to harmonise the prospectus regime in the EU so that it will be easier for companies and investors to buy and sell bonds and shares. The proposed measures specifically aim to: reduce the administrative burden of drawing up of prospectuses for all issuers and in particular for SMEs and frequent issuers of securities and secondary issuances; make the prospectus a more relevant disclosure tool for potential investors, especially in SMEs; and achieve more convergence between the EU prospectus and other EU disclosure rules. We are in favour of maximum disclosure on risk to consumers, so we are opposed to some of the exemptions, but we are also fundamentally opposed to the CMU. Because of the CMU aspects in the report, I voted against it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim of the regulation is to ensure investor protection and market efficiency, while enhancing the single capital market. The provision of information which, according to the nature of the issuer and the securities, is necessary in order to enable investors to make an informed investment decision, ensures the protection of investors together with the rules of business. In addition, this information is an effective tool for building confidence in securities, which contributes to the proper functioning of securities markets and their development. The appropriate way to make this information available is to publish a prospectus.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The proposal grants the regulator (ESMA) and the Commission powers to issue delegated acts, therefore UKIP is against it.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this legislative resolution because I think that accurate and complete information intended for all stakeholders is the key to trust in the securities market. Securities are offered to the public in the Union only after the prospectus has been published in advance, in accordance with the Regulation. They are traded on a regulated market based in the Union only after the previous publication of the prospectus.  Member States may decide to exempt the obligation to disclose from the public the offer of securities from prospectuses provided that the total consideration of the offer in the Union does not exceed EUR 5 000 000 calculated over a period of 12 months. Public tenders submitted on the basis of an exemption must contain a clear indication that the public tender is not borderline in nature.  The EU Growth Prospectus must be a standardised document covering key information on the issuer, securities and supply. The Commission needs to facilitate access to capital markets for SMEs, so investor confidence should be ensured for investments in such companies by reducing costs and burdens for SMEs. Prospectuses must also include risks arising from the level of subordination of security and the impact on the expected size or payment time of the owners of securities in bankruptcy, or any other similar procedure, including, where relevant, insolvency of the credit institution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The redesign of the Prospectus Directive is part of the Capital Markets Union, launched by Jonathan Hill, whose aim is to boost alternatives to bank financing for businesses. Facilitating the call to financial markets has therefore been one of the Commission's priorities. The term prospectus is the documentation that issuers of public offering financial products must make available to investors. Excessive information requirements can create administrative burden and risk of litigation, especially for SMEs. It is therefore necessary to provide relevant and synthetic information to investors, differentiating whether they are professional or lay, without creating excessive barriers. From a strictly technical point of view, the redesign of the "Prospectus" directive can be justified. On the philosophy of the text and the Union of Capital Markets, it is more questionable to want to further financialise the financing of companies, especially SMEs. The main winners will be primarily market companies and investment banks. I am more in favour of long-term partnerships of companies with banks refocused on their business and loans to the real economy than to speculation and market operations. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a regulation is a key step towards completing the Capital Markets Union. The Capital Markets Union aims to help companies access capital sources more easily, ensure a more efficient market functioning, and offer additional opportunities for investors and savers to use the funds.  The reform of the prospectus should ensure that financial markets are fragmented, funding sources diversified and cross-border capital flows strengthened. A more stable and stronger capital market is an important part of the response to the challenge of strengthening the economy and creating new jobs, so I supported the Ježek MEP's report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the rules applicable to the issuance of the prospectus in a securities offering. In November 2015, the European Commission published a proposal for a European regulation to replace the 2003/71/EC directive on prospectuses. This reform, which is part of the creation of a single capital market, aims to reduce barriers to investment and facilitate capital raising in financial markets. It should be noted that SMEs will be the main beneficiaries of this simplification of documentation, that national regimes will be harmonised and that the centralisation of information at the level of the European Financial Markets Authority (ESMA) will be increased.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The proposal grants the regulator (ESMA) and the Commission powers to issue delegated acts, therefore UKIP is against it.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as this Regulation is an essential step towards the realisation of the Capital Markets Union, as provided for in the European Commission's work plan for this mandate. The Capital Markets Union aims to help companies take advantage of sources of capital from anywhere in the European Union, make markets work more effectively and offer investors and earners additional opportunities to apply their money in order to increase growth and create jobs. The purpose of this Regulation is to ensure investor protection and market efficiency while strengthening the single capital market. The provision of information which, according to the nature of the issuer and securities, is necessary for investors to be able to make an informed investment decision, ensures, together with the rules of conduct, the protection of investors. Furthermore, such information represents an effective means of strengthening confidence in securities, thereby contributing to the smooth functioning and development of securities markets.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Regulation on the information leaflet to be published at the time of issue of securities, as the conditions are homogenized in all Member States, which contributes to strengthening the single market in financial services and capital. The internal market is still one of the key pieces for advancing the federal key in European integration into the economic, political and social dimensions. I am also pleased that the report has included our proposal that no purchaser of emissions can be excluded on the nationality or residence, even if the issues are granted to the quantitative exemption which allows the information leaflet or leaflet not to be published.  At the same time, the report makes it clear that if the issuer publishes the information leaflet and has been granted quantitative exemption, the issue will not have to meet additional requirements in Member States other than where it is produced.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the negotiating position on the Commission's proposed regulation, which amends the rules inherent in the prospectus that a European company must publish when it wishes to raise capital.  This text places particular importance on SMEs by allowing them to produce a reduced version of the prospectus. In addition, Member States are left with the option of exempting issues of securities of less than EUR 5 million.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The report in question concerns a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prospectus to be published in the event of a public offering of securities or their admission to trading.  This proposal for a Regulation comes within the framework of the Capital Markets Union, in which the Commission proposed the revision of the Prospects Directive, with the aim of administrative simplification and, in particular, to make life easier for businesses, freeing them from unnecessary burdens when they wish to mobilise capital or provide clear and accurate information to potential investors.  I support the amendments proposed by the rapporteur, as they provide greater transparency and better access for SMEs to capital markets, as well as to provide greater transparency and security for investors and consumers, meeting their legitimate expectations in terms of investment options.  In view of the above, my vote was in favour of the adoption of this report, which expresses the Position of the European Parliament at first reading.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out Parliament's position on the reform of the rules for issuing prospectuses when offering securities.  The aim of this reform is to simplify documentation, particularly for SMEs, within the framework of the Capital Markets Union. It is also a matter of harmonising national regimes and centralising information with the European Financial Markets Authority.  I supported this report because it is part of the measures needed to create a real single capital market. It is essential that Europe continues its action to remove the obstacles that restrict investment in the Union.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this proposal for a Regulation, which is intended to lay down the rules to be met by financial companies when informing the consumer about the financial products they sell. On the one hand, it seems to us that this regulation, as well as all those included in the Capital Market Union Commission project, promotes a financed economy with a high tendency to financial instability and speculation, with an increasingly limited capacity of States to direct funding flows to activities and projects of general interest. On the other hand, it seems to us that the proposed regulation of prospects is excessively lax and does not contain sufficient elements to warn of the risks and responsibilities that the consumer acquires when purchasing these products.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a step forward in financing the business fabric of the European Union, adopting a model similar to that of the United States to promote speculative financing methods for companies related to the real economy, mainly Small and Medium-sized Enterprises. This proposal, which sets out the information requirements of these companies, is a necessary step within the Capital Market Union, in order to enable financial funds to short-circuit banking requirements and to be able to speculate directly on the financing of SMEs. This will result in the destabilization of the real economy and the externalization of the financial sector's risk to small and medium-sized enterprises. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution because the regulation represents a fundamental step towards the completion of the Capital Markets Union, as set out in the Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions entitled 'An Action Plan to build a Capital Markets Union' of 30 September 2015. The Capital Markets Union aims to help businesses tap into more diverse sources of capital from anywhere in the European Union , streamline the functioning of markets and offer investors and savers additional opportunities to make money, in order to boost growth and create jobs. The objective of this Regulation is to ensure investor protection and market efficiency, while strengthening the single capital market. The provision of information which, by the nature of the issuer and of the securities, is necessary to enable investors to take an informed investment decision shall, together with the rules of conduct on business, ensure investor protection. Moreover, such information is an effective means of increasing confidence in securities and thus contributes to the proper functioning and development of securities markets.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ In the context of building a Capital Markets Union, it is important to harmonise member states' rules so that financial instruments operating within it can be used as optimally as possible.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or when they are admitted to trading. Of course, there is also light and shadow here, for example that a regulation replaces the existing directive. Nevertheless, the content of the regulation is an improvement on the status quo under the Prospectus Directive. The regulation gives the national legislature more leeway than it currently holds under the directive. This is largely due to the good preparatory work of the first rapporteur, who has since left the European Parliament, who has presented a very liberal solution that is very liberal and pro-sovereign, fuelling the competition of the nation states, which goes far beyond the Commission's short-sighted proposal. In the further course, that is to say the trialogue that follows, I will continue to follow the procedure as my group's shadow rapporteur.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Prospectus Directive 2003/71/EC aligns the rules for publishing prospectuses when companies want to raise capital either by emissions of shares or by providing investment opportunities to the general public. Consequently, as part of the Capital Markets Union, the Commission proposed a revision of the Prospectus Directive with a view to simplifying the procedure and reducing costs and providing clear information to investors.  The IMCO Committee is responsible for legislative oversight of consumer interests across a wide range of sectors, including the financial services sector and improving competitiveness in the single market. I support the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the prospectus published in the public offering of securities or the inclusion for trading of the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading.  With this regulation, we will take one step towards establishing a Capital Markets Union to give businesses access to more diverse sources of capital anywhere in the European Union, to make markets more efficient and to offer investors and savers opportunities to invest money more efficiently, to increase growth and create jobs. We will also use the regulation to ensure investor protection and market efficiency and strengthen the single market in capital.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 According to this new regulation, access to company finance is one of the important issues that led to the crisis, and thus harmonising measures are proposed through which companies will reduce their "bureaucratic" costs so that they can more easily target financing. The aim of the regulation is to 'Americanise' the European economy and how banks are financed. However, further regulation and harmonisation of financial activities will probably bring more speculation than access to finance, as it is not access to finance that created the crisis but the lack of demand for business products from ongoing austerity measures. This setting fails to fully address this issue. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This regulation essentially marks the resumption of financial market activity, which will boost speculation and destabilise economies.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on prospectuses to be published when securities are issued to the public or marketed. The main objective of the Capital Markets Union is to facilitate the raising of capital on capital markets, and a harmonised EU prospectus plays a major role in this. In order to ensure greater efficiency, it is important to review the Prospectus Directive, which is also essential for the establishment of a Capital Markets Union. I agree with the report which adopted the Commission's position, in particular with regard to the opening up of the market for non-equity securities to retail investors and the possibility for the investor to read the summary in one of the official languages of his Member State. I therefore welcome the amendments to facilitate smEs' access to capital markets.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report because it aims to simplify the lives of SMEs by allowing them to use a standard document – easy for anyone to fill without the help of banks or lawyers – to sell their securities. Helping cross-border investment and deepening the capital market is at the heart of the proposals. But, in order to create a real Capital Markets Union and to deepen EU capital markets, we have to move away from 28 different national regimes by creating the same rules for all companies in all Member States. With this report, we will be able to achieve or improve several important things for European citizens, such as: reduced legal costs and red tape; reduced fragmentation of practices across Member States and a move towards deeper integration of the capital markets in the EU; unlocked liquidity from institutional investors who are currently facing a low-interest-rate environment and sitting on capital; and harmonised investor protection rules across the different pieces of legislation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I agree with the european Parliament and The Council's proposed regulation on the prospectus to be published in the event of an offer to the public of securities or for the admission of securities to trading. The text fills in the legislative gaps in this regard.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of revising the directive on the prospectus. Prospectuses are legally required documents, presenting information about a company, that inform investors about investment opportunities in the company’s securities. I believe that this is an important tool to reduce the fragmentation of financial markets and to increase investor protection, and thereby enable the European economy to pick up again. In fact, this revision will make it easier and cheaper for companies to raise capital in the EU by reducing the administrative burden, in particular for SMEs. It will also make the prospectus a more relevant disclosure tool for potential investors by further standardising this document.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support this Regulation because it aims to establish requirements for the drafting, approval and distribution of prospectuses published in the public offering of securities or inclusion for trading in a regulation market established in a Member State. I agree that the above-mentioned prospectus should include the information that investors need to make informed investment decisions.  In particular, I support the Commission's proposal to revise the Prospectus Directive in order to simplify procedures and reduce the cost of raising capital for businesses, in particular SMEs. It is essential that small investors have access to the necessary information on the basis of which they can make informed decisions, and that SMEs are given better access to finance.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading, as the prospectus contains relevant and necessary information that the investor would reasonably require in relation to the investment in securities.  On the basis of this information, the investor may assess the assets and liabilities, financial position, profit or loss, prospectus of the issuer and any guarantor, as well as the rights arising from such securities.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this regulatory proposal, aimed at establishing the rules that financial companies must comply with when informing the consumer about the financial products they sell. On the one hand, it seems to us that this regulation, as well as all those included in the Capital Market Union Commission project, promotes a financed economy with a high tendency to financial instability and speculation, with an increasingly limited capacity of States to direct funding flows to activities and projects of general interest. On the other hand, it seems to us that the proposed regulation of prospects is excessively lax and does not contain sufficient elements to warn of the risks and responsibilities that the consumer acquires when purchasing these products.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The redesign of the Prospectus Directive is part of the Capital Markets Union, launched by Jonathan Hill, whose aim is to boost alternatives to bank financing for businesses. Facilitating the call to financial markets has therefore been one of the Commission's priorities. From a strictly technical point of view, the redesign of the prospectus directive can be justified. On the philosophy of the text and the Union of Capital Markets, it is more questionable to want to further financialise the financing of companies, especially SMEs. The main winners will be primarily market companies and investment banks. We are more in favour of long-term partnerships of companies with banks refocused on their business and loans to the real economy than to speculation and market operations. I chose abstention.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Directive 2003/71/EC on prospectuses, which is currently in force, harmonises the rules on the publication of prospectuses to be issued by companies that raise capital by issuing shares for listing or by publicly offering investment opportunities. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against this regulatory proposal, aimed at laying down the rules that financial companies must comply with when informing the consumer about the financial products they sell. On the one hand, it seems to us that this regulation, as well as all those included in the Capital Market Union Commission project, promotes a financed economy with a high tendency to financial instability and speculation, with an increasingly limited capacity of States to direct funding flows to activities and projects of general interest. On the other hand, it seems to us that the proposed regulation of prospects is excessively lax and does not contain sufficient elements to warn of the risks and responsibilities that the consumer acquires when purchasing these products.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I abstained in this report. We got my amendments to protect retail investors to avoid scams like the preferred ones to be accepted, which is very positive. But the text as a whole is unbalanced and deregulatory, benefiting large companies by reducing their obligations to make public the risks of their emissions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading. The aim of this regulation is to ensure investor protection and market efficiency, while enhancing the single market for capital. The provision of information, according to the nature of the issuer and of the securities, is necessary to enable investors to make an informed investment decision, and ensures, together with rules on the conduct of business, the protection of investors. I voted in favour because I believe that such information contributes to the proper functioning and development of securities markets.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Regulation on the information leaflet to be published at the time of issue of securities, as the conditions are homogenized in all Member States, which contributes to strengthening the single market in financial services and capital. The internal market is still one of the key pieces for advancing the federal key in European integration into the economic, political and social dimensions. I am also pleased that the report has included our proposal that no purchaser of emissions can be excluded on the nationality or residence, even if the issues are granted to the quantitative exemption which allows the information leaflet or leaflet not to be published.  At the same time, the report makes it clear that if the issuer publishes the information leaflet and has been granted quantitative exemption, the issue will not have to meet additional requirements in Member States other than where it is produced.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We agree that it is extremely important for investors to have reliable and accurate information and a high degree of transparency.  We refuse to completely distort the genesis of this crisis in the back of this notion of transparency. Transparency helps and is welcome. But it is not believed that it was the lack of transparency that caused the financial crisis. The crisis was provoked by the greed of large institutional investors who had all the information they could, but who still did not want to give up their profits. The problem was the speculative spiral that involved banking and other financial institutions that knew they could risk because they knew and know today that they can always rely on governments and central banks to solve this problem. As much regulation as they may invent, there is nothing to erase today the need for public control of the financial system.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report is a one-off, provides more and, above all, clearer information for the consumer and provides clarity on issuer liability issues. In principle, the approach is a step forward in ensuring consistency, while at the same time creating flexibility where it is necessary. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading. I believe that the regulation represents an important step towards the creation of a Capital Markets Union, that is to say, to ensure that markets operate more efficiently and to offer opportunities to investors and savers to invest money more efficiently in order to increase growth and create jobs.  I also believe that disclosure of information in the event of offers to tender or admission of securities to trading on a regulated market is crucial for the protection of investors, as it eliminates the mismatch of information between investors and issuers.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I did not support this report on quotas and European asylum policy, just as I have never supported quotas here in plenary, i.e. the forced distribution of refugees to individual Member States of the European Union. I believe that this policy cannot work in real life, indeed, practice shows this, and the fact that we have adopted another proposal today without reflecting reality, without how asylum policy works in practice, seems to me to be a bit of a utopia. I am sorry, we should rather perceive reality, think about how to deal with the current situation with pragmatic common sense, and not invent other projects that will not work. I am convinced that this proposal, which passed today, will only end up as a utopia that will not be fulfilled in practice.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I voted in favour of the report because I quite simply believe that it is right that we must find workable solutions. But we can only do this at European level, and we also need European solidarity from all the Member States of the European Union. Of course, this also includes solving the issue of entry, asylum rights, security of documents and the repatriation of unauthorised asylum seekers at European level. Finally, we will have people who need help and who we must take in in the European Union. I think it is the right approach to say on this second or third task too: when it comes to humanitarian aid for people, we are in overall European solidarity and help each other. That in itself is the style of the report, and that is why I was able to vote in favour.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I also did not support this report for a reason that I consider to be quite serious and I want to explain it here.  I believe that the Commission's proposal was relatively correct. It contained a good level of compromise, and I think that it was a solution that, firstly, followed up on the decision adopted six months ago, which was in favour of Italy and Greece, and secondly, it contained a degree of agreement between the Member States.  However, the report that has been presented to us by my colleague Ska Keller is, however, to some extent lowering these barriers, and I want to illustrate this on the case that the quota to be included in the redistribution should not include those refugees who will be arriving under the EU agreement with Turkey, i.e. the 1:1 example. If these refugees are not included in the quota that has already been negotiated, I think that this weakens the agreement with Turkey and for this reason I could not support this report.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States must commit to handing out responsibilities for reollocateing the 160 000 asylum seekers from Greece and Italy.  They must step up their efforts to make the European relocation scheme work as smoothly as possible. The transformation of resettlement posts into resettlement places for refugees from Turkey, a key point of the EU agreement, does not appear to be the best way to properly implement the resettlement scheme. Since I firmly believe that, from the point of view of European solidarity, it is necessary for each Member State to respect the agreements by accepting the number of refugees that are theirs, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs voted against this consultation procedure vote, which is technically non-legislative. UKIP rejects the role of the European Border and Coast Guard in the migration crisis. Moreover, UKIP also opposes the compulsory resettlement of migrants across EU nations.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report and voted in favour. The report is strong on protecting the concept of shared responsibility for the refugee crisis, and it calls for safe and legal access for refugees, is committed to family reunification, acknowledges the dire situation in Greece and Italy and seeks to add Afghan refugees to the relocation category.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. We must show more solidarity with each other and finally create a truly European asylum system.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Council proposal concerning provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece. The objective of the Council proposal is to amend Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 to relocate people in need of international protection from Italy and Greece. In the framework of the existing commitments under EU—Turkey cooperation in the field of migration, the proposal responds to the need for further measures on resettlement to Turkey. The 54 000 relocation places provided for will now be available for the purpose of resettling Syrians from Turkey in the EU through the 1:1 scheme. Pursuant to the proposed amendment, the EU Member States may meet their commitments by admitting Syrians to their territory directly from Turkey. Important points are that the number of resettled Syrians would be deducted from Member States’ relocation quotas, and that each Member State which uses this facility would receive the sum of EUR 6 500 per person.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. In this resolution, Parliament calls for the rejection of a Commission proposal to give up 54,000 places in the refugee resettlement programme from Italy and Greece to the territory of other Member States and to resettle the same number of Syrian refugees from Turkey in the EU (under the EU-Turkey agreement). Parliament called on EU countries to honour their commitments to take in refugees resettled from Greece and Italy. This is the only way to reduce migratory pressure scomite for Member States at the external borders, while at the same time countering illegal immigration by opening up safe and legal routes into the EU. I, too, rejected the Commission's proposal, as I believe that there is an urgent need to carry out emergency relocations from Greece and Italy to other EU Member States in order to combat the emergency situation in Greece and the risk of a deterioration in the situation in Italy. I agree that the resettlement programme is an instrument of solidarity and should not be confused with the resettlement scheme. In addition, I continue to call for a fair redistribution of refugees and I very much regret that there are still countries that have not yet taken in a single refugee.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the relocation plan agreed by EU representatives in September 2015 to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU, in line with the EU-Turkey migration agreement. The resolution proposes that Member States make available at least one third of their relocation places by 31 December 2016. It adds that if the relocation Member State did not approve the relocation within two weeks, approval should be assumed to have been given. The text stresses that so far only a very small number of Syrian refugees have been relocated to the EU. It recalls the European Parliament's resolution of 12 April 2016 in which it called for more safe and lawful routes in the Union for asylum seekers and refugees, including the adoption by the EU of a binding and mandatory resettlement law, the establishment of humanitarian admission programmes by all Member States and the wider use of humanitarian visas. We reject the policy of distributing migrants, which has proved to be a scathing failure. This text only confirms and makes this policy even more restrictive. So I objected.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the European Union should play a role in asylum, a matter which in my view is subject to the sovereignty of Member States.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council Decision amending Regulation (EC) No 1008/2015 of 22 September 2015 Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. This amendment allows Member States to subtract from the number of resettled persons in the European Union allocated to them the number of Syrians in Turkey admitted to their territory during resettlement, humanitarian admission or other forms of lawful admission under national or multilateral programmes, with the exception of the resettlement programme.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 Subject of the proposal: EP resolution on a proposal for a Council Decision amending Council Decision 2015/1601/EU of 22 September 2015 laying down transitional measures in the field of international protection in the interests of Italy and Greece within the framework of a consultation procedure. The essence of the proposal is that it serves to create a legal framework for a compulsory relocation system, ostensibly by reference to helping Greece and Italy, but in fact it means implementing the great migration plan that is intended to disrupt Europe. It would require Member States to facilitate the indrating of millions of people, who are clearly not refugees but economic migrants, who are considered to be economic migrants in the sense of international law, on the basis of the reception quota imposed on them by the Member States.  The proposal goes even further than the Council proposal and is based on the principle of full, unconditional liberal inclusion and strongly denies the principle of identity protection in the Member States. According to the proposal, resettlement should not be at the expense of relocation, both of which are important instruments of solidarity. Relocation is a form of internal solidarity between Member States, while resettlement and other forms of humanitarian admission or reception are forms of external solidarity with third countries hosting the majority of refugees. It is all a game of words, the point is the same: the great project of dismantling nation states, the surrender of Europe's identity and culture. On this basis, of course, I rejected the adoption of the report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this report which states that relocations should apply only to applicants of Syrian, Iraqi, Eritrean or Afghan nationality or to those who hold a nationality for which the share of decisions granting international protection is equal to or greater than 75%. The report also stresses that resettlement should not come at the expense of relocation, which is a form of internal solidarity between Member States. MEPs also drew attention to the low number of refugees relocated to the EU so far.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. In this legislative resolution, Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of the Agreement with the AAE States of the Community for the Development of Southern Africa (Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland). This Agreement seeks to increase cooperation with this region of Africa. It contains provisions to promote trade and development, the promotion of regional integration, and contains clauses for respect for values and follow-up to the implementation of the Agreement. However, this agreement poses a threat to the Spanish agricultural sector, in particular the citrícola, due to the unfair competition it allows and the lack of reciprocity. I share the objectives of promoting interregional cooperation and helping the economic growth of southern Africa, but not without transparency, at the expense of the Spanish agricultural sector and without taking into account its demands and its potential impact, or providing for countervailing measures.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The continuation of the migration crisis makes increasingly evident the effort that countries such as Greece and Italy put in place daily to manage the influx of thousands of migrants landing on the coasts of Europe fleeing poverty and conflict.  The Keller report, which I strongly supported, addresses the problem of asylum and temporary measures for the benefit of Italy and Greece, amending the proposal originally presented by the Commission. Parliament rejected the provision to use the 54 000 places originally earmarked for the relocation of asylum seekers from Greece and Italy to other EU Member States for the resettlement of Syrian refugees from Turkey to the EU. The transfer regime within the Eu ropean Union should not be confused with that of relocation in a non-EU country, as suggested by the Commission.  The two Mediterranean countries are currently facing a complex situation which is in danger of deteriorating; All Member States must take action as soon as possible to deliver on their promise to relocate 160 000 asylum seekers within two years. The European Union must demonstrate that there is a real bond of solidarity between states, and its own future depends on it.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report opposing the EU-Turkey Agreement and the readmission scheme proposed by the Commission in the context of its human rights-infringing migration policy. We share the criticism of the Member States for their petty behaviour in welcoming people in need of international protection on their territory and for the need to act in co-responsibility with Greece and Italy in dealing with sufficient resources and in solidarity with the greatest humanitarian crisis in Europe since World War II.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs of the report for their work and efforts to reach agreement on the provisional measures for Italy and Greece on asylum. I have also supported the amendment concerning the fact that many applicants in need of international protection who are currently in these two countries cannot benefit from the relocation plan by being subject to Regulation (EU) No 604/2013 and I support the idea that Member States should without delay apply the right to family reunification provided for in that Regulation and thus expedite vulnerable cases in order to allow reunification as soon as possible.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the relocation plan agreed by EU representatives in September 2015 to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU, in line with the EU-Turkey migration agreement. The resolution actually wants states to make at least two-thirds of their relocation places available by 31 December 2016. If the Member State does not approve the relocation within 2 weeks, it is considered accepted. The text stresses the very low number of Syrian refugees relocated to the EU, calls for the establishment of a binding mechanism for the resettlement of migrants, the establishment of humanitarian admission programmes by all Member States and the wider use of humanitarian visas. I was opposed to the failed policy of distributing migrants, which leads to more immigration.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 One year after the entry into force of the migrant resettlement and resettlement mechanism in the EU, the numbers showed that we in the League were right. Eu summits also had to admit that it was a complete failure: out of the 160 000 relocations planned by 2017 to alleviate the immigration emergency in Italy and Greece, to date only just over 3 000 have been made.  However, this report insists that the fault for the failure of this mechanism lies with the Member States and not with the EU, which, through its crazy policies, is doing nothing to stop the ongoing invasion of illegal immigrants in Italy. For all these reasons, I did not support the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Decision 2015/1601 indicated that refugees should be relocated from Italy and Greece to the territory of other Member States. So far, Member States have not been able to mobilisation the planned relocation places. There is therefore a need for Member States to assume their obligations and to comply with the resettlement agreement. It is imperative that Member States respond in solidarity to the challenge posed by the refugee crisis as the basis for developing a true European Asylum System.  That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to draw attention to the fact that this way of distributing asylum seekers is still not an instrument for resolving the situation, since it is the sovereign right of each State to determine who it accepts on its territory. Furthermore, mandatory re relationalation increases the pull effect and does not respond to the treatment of secondary migration movements. In addition, the relocation does not work in practice, with only 4,741 people relocated from the mandatory quota of 120,000 and the voluntary resettlement quota of 40,000 since September 2015. In my opinion, Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the causes of their escape are reduced or eliminated. To do this, it is not the migrants that need to be brought here and distributed, but the help that needs to be brought there. In addition to Turkey, assistance to other states hosting large refugee camps is also needed. The European Parliament's report seeks to expand and accelerate the scope of this failed mechanism, rather than confined to the technical form of the EU-Turkey agreement, which will only make the functioning of this already functioning system even more impossible. Against this basis, I voted against the adoption of this report.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, and on the eve of the Bratislava summit, Parliament reiterates once again that Member States must respect their commitments regarding the relocation of refugees arriving in frontline countries such as Italy and Greece.  The rapporteur has rightly pointed out that the relocation scheme is a genuine instrument of solidarity, which must, if possible, be strengthened and not weakened. Given that we are a long way from the figure of 160 000 refugees to be redistributed – some Member States have not taken in a single refugee – and while landings continue in Italy, it would be misleading, as the report points out, to include in this figure 54 000 refugees who would be resettled from Turkey to the EU.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this Interim Action Report for the benefit of Italy and Greece. Italy and Greece are overwhelmed by the influx of refugees and the deployment of some refugees to other member states facilitates their functioning. I believe that we need to show more solidarity between ourselves and create an effective European asylum system.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This text only makes the effects of the European Parliament's resolution of 12 April 2016, which aimed to impose a quota for the resettlement of Syrian migrants, even more restrictive. This policy has already largely failed, so I voted against it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The human tragedy unfolding in the Mediterranean cannot leave us indifferent. More than three thousand people have lost their lives since the beginning of this year trying to reach European shores. European coasts, that is what it is all about, because the phenomenon of migrants affects not only Italy and Greece but all of us. It is a common theme, requiring common answers.  We must increase the number of people to be relocated and support the Italian and Greek authorities who are struggling to manage this great challenge of the twenty-first century: it is not just a question of solidarity, it is also a question of foresight. No wall has ever stopped the great migrations of history, and our indifference cannot in any way stop the wars and poverty that cause these people to flee. The European Union must practise its fundamental principles of solidarity and protection towards those who need it, and of unity and joint action between the Member States. And you have to do it now.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and extensive discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision establishing temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. The situation of migrants is clearly clear to everyone: we are not doing enough for their relocation. The numbers are all against us. I am very concerned that attempts to manage the refugee crisis highlight a utopian objective that is struggling to achieve itself, with an obligation to do more and more quickly, responding to the emergency humanitarian situation in Greece and preventing a deterioration in the situation in Italy. If today is the news that the Italian Navy has coordinated 6 rescue operations on 5 inflatable boats and a boat in difficulty with about 650 rescued migrants, interventions are needed that are more than proportional, given the urgency and seriousness of the situation, and the impact on the fundamental rights of applicants for international protection must be preserved.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report and voted in favour. The report is strong on protecting the concept of shared responsibility for the refugee crisis, calls for safe and legal access for refugees, is committed to family reunification, acknowledges the dire situation in Greece and Italy and seeks to add Afghan refugees to the relocation category.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it seeks to respond to the need for further measures on the resettlement of refugees from Turkey within the framework of existing commitments under EU-Turkey cooperation in the field of migration.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Last year, at the height of the so-called refugee crisis, the Council decided, despite opposition from some states, to relocate 160 000 refugees from Greece and Italy to other Member States.  This proposal calls for one third of the total amount of refugees to be relocated (54 000) to be used for the implementation of the EU-Turkey agreement; The Member States had not been able to agree on an increase in relocations as a result of the agreement. Most Member States are not, however, meeting their commitments and reception centres continue to be – especially in Greece – overcrowded. My colleague's report rightly sets out the posts devoted to relocation and those necessary for the implementation of the agreement with Turkey, and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as it re-introduces, once again, the relocation mechanism with compulsory quotas for migrants. I keep saying that it is not possible to force any Member State to accept an allocated number of immigrants when they do not want to do so. That principle, among others, was also recognised in the State of the Union speech given yesterday by Commission President Juncker. Moreover, to date, only a minimal number of Syrian refugees have been actually resettled within the Union. I believe that, first of all, we have to protect our external border effectively in order to limit the impact of the migration crisis, and that should be the primary duty of the new European Border and Coast Guard Agency.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and recall that, particularly in Greece, the situation remains critical.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the adoption of interim measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece. The difficulties that Greece and Italy have had to face, often without help from other Member States of Europe, are significant. That is why the provision and implementation of concrete measures to support these two states is a positive step and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I can only welcome the Keller report, hoping that it will help our country in the face of the prostrating and exhausting migration crisis. I very much welcome the fact that, under the agreements undertaken by the Eu ropean Union with Turkey, the substantial differences between resettlement and relocation and the conditions for resettlement are specified for the avoidance of all kinds of misunderstandings. Although these are two forms of transfer of asylum seekers, they are quite distinct since the first is carried out with a country outside the Community, while the second takes place between two Member States. My support is given by the clarification of the relocation conditions: in fact, it is confirmed that by 31 December 2016 the Member States must make available at least one third of the places they have agreed for asylum seekers from Italy and Greece, and it is also cautioned how infringement proceedings will be initiated for those who do not comply with their obligations. Suffice it to say that at 5/6/2016 only 793 people were relocated to Italy compared to the 12764 expected. I very much hope to be able to observe more consistent cooperation by the end of the year.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on Asylum: provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. I have said this several times: we have been slow and unsympathetic in the way we manage the so-called refugee crisis. This proposal also makes this clear. The replacement and reinstallation mechanisms have so far worked very poorly. Starting with numbers that are not in line with the size of the influx of people, the support provided by italy and Greece has been reduced, although it has already been approved for more than a year.  If of the 160 000 initially proposed, 54 000 will be used under the resettlement programme with Turkey and we have given the mechanism more effective, then this is a good proposal. However, what really needs to concern us is the lack of solidarity with Italy and Greece and that the ill-fated agreement with Turkey is only being fulfilled by the Turks and the Union continues to steal its commitments.  In a way, we need to be more effective in using the instruments that are available, as is the aim of this proposal and, on the other hand, we need more European solidarity. Today we take a step towards greater effectiveness.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this consultation procedure vote, which is technically non-legislative. UKIP rejects the role of the European Border and Coast Guard in the migration crisis. Moreover, UKIP opposes the compulsory resettlement of migrants across EU nations.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 There is an urgent need for Member States to honour their commitments to prevent the deterioration of refugee conditions in the countries of arrival, working together efficiently to reduce pressure on states such as Italy and Greece and thus rapidly re- relocation and creating more safe and legal access routes. We cannot remain myopic in the face of this humanitarian emergency, above all we cannot act with the slowness we have shown so far. Progress, as the Commission also said last May, is unsatisfactory. To date, Member States have made available only 7% of the number of relocation places and according to the "5th EC Report on Relocation and Settlement", from 14 June to 11 July, at least in Italy, only 66 people have been relocated compared to 186 in the previous period and only 6 minors. In Italy we are also working to create additional hotspots, because the 1,600 are not enough. But we need the cooperation of all the Member States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – This proposal seeks to tackle situations involving a sudden inflow of persons in the Mediterranean countries, a situation which we have witnessed on a number of occasions. Parliament has repeatedly called for the development of a greater number of safer and lawful routes for asylum seekers and refugees into the Union, as well as a binding and mandatory Union legislative approach to resettlement, the establishment of humanitarian admission programmes by all Member States and more extensive use of humanitarian visas – and I continue to support that call through this report.    We should give due consideration to measures concerning family reunification, to be adopted in conformity with the obligation to protect the family and respect family life, which is enshrined in many instruments of international law.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. We are looking at a proposal that does not call into question the root of the current situation of migrants or the main one in the face of the logic of the Fortress Europe. However, the introduction of a whole range of concrete measures is being proposed to improve the situation of these people. The elimination of the shameful EU-Turkey Agreement or the extension of the right to asylum to more nationalities, in line with the Geneva Convention which is not now complied with by the EU, are very positively valued elements. In addition, we share the need to overcome the current quota system which has failed because of the lack of political will of States, in order to impose a system based really on the solidarity and freedom of movement and choice of the asylum seeker himself. That is why, despite not being the model of migration policy we are defending, we voted in favour of the report, understanding that this proposal would bring tangible improvements in the situation of people forced to flee their countries.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 By voting in favour of this resolution, I intend to support the amendments proposed by the European Parliament on the Commission text amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 establishing temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. In particular, I support the deletion of Amendment No 20, which allows for the reduction of the obligations relating to the relocation of asylum seekers for Member States that accept Syrian citizens present in Turkey on the basis of resettlement programmes other than temporary and exceptional relocation programmes from Italy and Greece, decided by the Council on 20 July 2015. I believe, in fact, that this amendment goes against the rationale of asylum measures for the benefit of the countries most affected by the arrival of asylum seekers, creating a risky legal precedent that legitimises the reduction of relocation obligations for the Member States established in the Council in July 2015. Furthermore, I believe that reception on the basis of resettlement cannot replace the relocation mechanism, which expresses internal solidarity between Member States and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to managing the flows of persons seeking international protection.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 EU Heads of State or Government agreed on 7 March 2016 to work on a series of principles to reach an agreement with Turkey, including reallocation, for each Syrian who arrived to the Greek islands who is readmitted by Turkey, another Syrian from Turkey to the Member States. Large-scale resettlement through national and multilateral systems is necessary to reduce the migratory pressure on Member States by providing a legal and safe way to enter the Union. I voted for this new step in addressing this humanitarian crisis facing the European Union and which, by implication, affects every citizen of the Member States.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report because it ignores the European Council resolution in favour of voluntary re-allocation. This way of distributing asylum seekers cannot be seen as a means of resolving the situation, as it is the sovereign right of each EU Member State to determine who it accepts on its territory. Furthermore, it is feared that mandatory re relationalation will increase the tensile effect. The European Parliament's report seeks to expand and accelerate the scope of this mechanism, which will only make it even more impossible for this already functioning system to function. In my opinion, the best solution is to create the right conditions for refugees in reception camps as close as possible to their home countries, so that they can return to their home countries safely as soon as the causes of their escape are reduced or eliminated. It is Europe's job to provide assistance, but the most effective way is to make the EU-Turkey agreement effective and to support other states hosting large refugee camps alongside Turkey.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the need for relocation to alleviate the pressure on frontline Member States. I strongly believe that Member States need to show more solidarity between them and create a truly European functional asylum system. I agree that Member States need to significantly increase their efforts to address the urgent humanitarian situation in Greece and prevent the deterioration of the situation of the frontline Member States.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the Council decided in 2015 to transfer thousands of asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other Member States, so far only a small part has actually been reallocated. I therefore wholeheartedly supported the adoption of this decision, through which Parliament expresses the importance of greater cooperation between EU countries on immigration, stressing above all the need to fully comply with the obligations relating to a fair and supportive distribution of quotas of asylum seekers, in order to alleviate the immense efforts made by countries that are geographically at the forefront of the migration crisis. , just like Italy. Migratory flows are a problem that affects not only europe's southern borders, but Europe as a whole. It is therefore essential that cooperation is swift and substantial in order to prevent the deterioration of the situation on the Mediterranean front.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing.
