I voted against this European Parliament consultation report on amending the Council's decision to relocate people in need of international protection from Italy and Greece in order to implement the migration agreement between the European Council and Turkey. The text as adopted by Parliament goes far too far in its recommendations on the application of relocation and resettlement mechanisms in Europe. In particular, I am opposed to the afghans benefiting from relocation to the Member States of the European Union, when it is established that only Syrians, Iraqis and Eritreans can benefit from this system. Once again, the left-wing groups in the European Parliament have tried to deflect the Commission's proposal to introduce provisions that do not have to be in such a text, such as incentivizing Member States to regroup.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. Although this report offers interesting solutions on the relocation and resettlement of people in need of international assistance, I have not been able to support this text because some paragraphs deal with issues that go beyond the scope of the Commission's proposal. The report proposes, among other things, to put in place a binding and mandatory legislative framework for the resettlement of these persons, or to make wider use of humanitarian visas. It also deals with the issue of family reunification, a subject which for me must be linked to other European policies or to measures of solidarity and emergency.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – Hungary has opposed compulsory relocation on principle since the beginning of the migration crisis. Hungary government has challenged a decision at the Court of Justice of the EUROPEAN Union to take in migrants, which ignores the European Council's resolution in favour of voluntary re-ingation. This way of distributing asylum seekers remains not an instrument for resolving the situation, since it is the sovereign right of each State to determine who it accepts on its territory. Furthermore, mandatory re relationalation increases the pulling effect and does not respond to the treatment of secondary migration movements. However, the relocation does not work in practice, with only 4,741 people relocated from the mandatory 120,000-strong voluntary resettlement quota and the 40,000-strong voluntary resettlement quota since September 2015. In my opinion, Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the causes of their escape are reduced or eliminated. To do this, it is not the migrants that need to be brought here and distributed, but the help that needs to be brought there. In addition to Turkey, assistance to other states hosting large refugee camps is also needed. The European Parliament's report seeks to expand and speed up the scope of this failed mechanism, rather than limiting the technical form of the EU-Turkey agreement, which makes it even more impossible for this already functioning system to function, so I am voting against it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution giving Parliament its opinion on the Council's motion for a decision amending the decision to introduce interim measures on international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece.  The resolution rejects the Commission's proposal to seize the 54,000 places in the plan to relocate refugees from Greece and Italy to other Member States, and to use them to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU, in accordance with the EU-Turkey agreement. Parliament's view is that the relocation plan within the EU should not be confused with the resettlement plan and that 'resettlement should not take place at the expense of relocation'. Member States must keep their promises to Greece and Italy, in order to relieve them of migratory pressure, while discouraging irregular entry by creating safe and legal routes. The text also highlights the small percentage of people who have so far been relocated. As a result, Parliament insists that Member States make available at least one third of the promised relocation places by 31 December 2016.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Hungary has opposed compulsory relocation on principle since the beginning of the migration crisis. Hungary government has challenged a decision at the Court of Justice of the EUROPEAN Union to take in migrants, which ignores the European Council's resolution in favour of voluntary re-ingation. This way of distributing asylum seekers remains not an instrument for resolving the situation, since it is the sovereign right of each State to determine who it accepts on its territory. Furthermore, mandatory re relationalation increases the pull effect and does not respond to the treatment of secondary migration movements. In addition, the relocation does not work in practice, with only 4,741 people relocated from the mandatory quota of 120,000 and the voluntary resettlement quota of 40,000 since September 2015. In my opinion, Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the causes of their escape are reduced or eliminated. To do this, it is not the migrants that need to be brought here and distributed, but the help that needs to be brought there. In addition to Turkey, assistance to other states hosting large refugee camps is also needed. The European Parliament's report seeks to expand and speed up the scope of this failed mechanism, rather than limiting the technical form of the EU-Turkey agreement, which makes it even more impossible for this already functioning system to function, so I am voting against it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the relocation plan agreed by EU representatives in September 2015 to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU, in line with the EU-Turkey migration agreement. The resolution proposes that Member States make available at least one third of their relocation places by 31 December 2016. It adds that so far only a very small number of Syrian refugees have been relocated to the EU. The text recalls the European Parliament's resolution of 12 April 2016 in which it called for more safe and lawful routes in the Union for asylum seekers and refugees, including the adoption by the EU of a binding and mandatory resettlement law, the establishment of humanitarian admission programmes by all Member States and the wider use of humanitarian visas. I was opposed to the policy of distributing migrants, which turned out to be a failure, and I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, as I do not support the measures proposed by the Commission for refugee resettlement, as well as the EU-Turkey agreement on the exchange of refugees and the provision of financial assistance. From the outset, I am against mandatory quotas for refugees who will not work and more and more countries are refusing to accept refugees.  According to Ms Keller's report, the 1-for-1 refugee exchange scheme with Turkey aims for every Syrian returned to assist another Syrian fleeing war and persecution. I am strongly opposed to this measure, which in itself is conflicting and discriminatory – how will some Syrians have the right to asylum and others will not, but also Syrians sent from Turkey are by no means at risk of war and persecution, as they are already in a safe country.  Under international law, a refugee fleeing war must be held in the first safe country and possibly as close to his homeland as possible in order to be able to return easily after the end of the conflict, which is not the case for refugees coming to the EU. Refugees come to the EU to stay.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report seeks to impose the violent integration of different ethnicities and cultures.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungary has opposed mandatory relocation on principle since the beginning of the migration crisis. Hungary government has challenged a decision at the Court of Justice of the EUROPEAN Union to take in migrants, which ignores the European Council's resolution in favour of voluntary re-ingation. This way of distributing asylum seekers remains not an instrument for resolving the situation, since it is the sovereign right of each State to determine who it accepts on its territory. Furthermore, mandatory re relationalation increases the pull effect and does not respond to the treatment of secondary migration movements. However, the relocation does not work in practice, with only 4,741 people relocated from the mandatory 120,000-strong voluntary resettlement quota and the 40,000-strong voluntary resettlement quota since September 2015. In my opinion, Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the causes of their escape are reduced or eliminated. To do this, it is not the migrants that need to be brought here and distributed, but the help that needs to be brought there. In addition to Turkey, assistance to other states hosting large refugee camps is also needed. The European Parliament's report seeks to expand and speed up the scope of this failed mechanism, rather than limiting the technical form of the EU-Turkey agreement, which makes it even more impossible for this already functioning system to function, so I am voting against it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on temporary measures for Italy and Greece with regard to asylum policies, as it is becoming increasingly necessary for all Member States to become aware of the emergency situation that now characterises countries at the forefront of the management of migratory flows. The Member States must honour their commitments and relocate the 160 000 asylum seekers from Greece and Italy in accordance with the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities. No room for negotiations that see a third of the refugees sacrificed for resettlement under the EU-Turkey agreement.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the amendments recommended in the different articles, as they provide additional information to better clarify provisional measures for the benefit of Italy and Greece, countries that are gateways and shelters for many displaced people who deserve decent treatment and consistent with the practices recommended by the European Union.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: we reject the policy of distribution of migrants, which has proved to be a scathing failure. This text only confirms and makes this policy even more restrictive.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. Resettlement must not be at the expense of relocation. Both are important instruments of solidarity. As M5S, we believe that the Member States must honour their commitments regarding the distribution of responsibilities to relocate the 160 000 asylum seekers from Greece and Italy.  To this end, it is necessary to step up efforts and to make the European relocation scheme work, which has revealed the lack of political will on the part of the Member States to respect the principle of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities. I am therefore in favour of my vote.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it specifically stresses that the migrant emergency in Italy will remain high, also noting the need to relocate a certain number of refugees from Italy and Greece to other Member States. I believe, in this regard, that the European Union can only address this huge migration emergency with a long-term approach, based on respect for human rights, combating irregular immigration and welcoming migrants who can be answered by the national employment system.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is a clear political statement of our opposition to the EU-Turkey deal.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the relocation and resettlement plan was a failure.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on a proposal for a Council Decision amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 laying down provisional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece as this report seeks to enforce the violent integration of different ethnicities and cultures.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that we managed to propose a compromise which highlighted the need of the European Parliament to commit and stick to the decisions taken under relocation. We must show more solidarity between ourselves and create a truly European asylum system. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I supported this report because it represents a concrete expression of solidarity with Member States or third countries affected by a mass influx of migrants. This proposal for a Council Decision amending Decision (EU) 2015/1601 allows Member States to subtract from their number of relocated applicants the number of Syrians admitted to their territory from Turkey through resettlement, humanitarian admission or other forms of legal admission.  The European Parliament's report notes that the implementation of the various resettlement, humanitarian admission or other forms of legal admission will reduce migratory pressure on frontline Member States. This will also make it possible to replace the dangerous and illegal migration flows to the EU of Syrian citizens with safe and legal ways of migration. Last but not least, I welcome the swift adoption of this report by the European Parliament. This supports and accelerates the taking of emergency measures, such as the current one, characterised by an increased influx of migrants, in line with the treaties for the functioning of the Union.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungary has opposed mandatory relocation on principle since the beginning of the migration crisis. Hungary government has challenged a decision at the Court of Justice of the EUROPEAN Union to take in migrants, which ignores the European Council's resolution in favour of voluntary re-ingation.  This way of distributing asylum seekers remains not an instrument for resolving the situation, since it is the sovereign right of each State to determine who it accepts on its territory. Furthermore, mandatory re relationalation increases the pull effect and does not respond to the treatment of secondary migration movements. However, relocation is not working in practice, with only 4 741 people relocated from the mandatory quota of 120 000 and the voluntary resettlement quota of 40 000 since September 2015.  In my opinion, Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the causes of their escape are reduced or eliminated. To do this, it is not the migrants that need to be brought here and distributed, but the help that needs to be brought there. In addition to Turkey, it is also necessary to help other states hosting large refugee camps. The European Parliament's report seeks to expand and accelerate the scope of this failed mechanism, rather than confined to the technical form of the EU-Turkey agreement, which makes it even more impossible for this already functioning system to function, and I am voting against it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungary has opposed mandatory relocation on principle since the beginning of the migration crisis. Hungary government has challenged a decision at the Court of Justice of the EUROPEAN Union to take in migrants, which ignores the European Council's resolution in favour of voluntary re-ingation. This way of distributing asylum seekers remains not an instrument for resolving the situation, since it is the sovereign right of each State to determine who it accepts on its territory. Furthermore, mandatory re relationalation increases the pull effect and does not respond to the treatment of secondary migration movements. However, the relocation does not work in practice, with only 4,741 people relocated from the mandatory 120,000-strong voluntary resettlement quota and the 40,000-strong voluntary resettlement quota since September 2015. In my opinion, Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the causes of their escape are reduced or eliminated. To do this, it is not the migrants that need to be brought here and distributed, but the help that needs to be brought there. In addition to Turkey, assistance to other states hosting large refugee camps is also needed. The European Parliament's report seeks to expand and accelerate the scope of this failed mechanism, rather than confined to the technical form of the EU-Turkey agreement, which makes it even more impossible for this already functioning system to function, so I am voting against it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the basis of the necessity of support for Italy and Greece. Italy is under huge pressure from the large migration flows from Libya, and the current systems to help us are not working at all. One hopeful and important aspect of the report is the point made in it that resettlement from third countries should not take place at the expense of relocation within the EU. I also think it is important that the report calls out the limited numbers of committed relocation places. As of 5 June 2016, only 793 persons had been relocated from Italy. I therefore support the report’s call for Member States to make one third of their relocation places available by 31 December 2016, and I hope this will be done automatically if the Member State does not agree.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank Mrs Keller for completing the legislative work on such a sensitive and decisive dossier for the breakthrough that we all want in the EU's migration policies. With our vote, we are reiterating the position that the LIBE Committee and Parliament have already expressed in plenary in recent months: solidarity between the Member States is essential to meet such large migratory flows and to support the efforts made by the countries at the forefront of the emergency, such as Italy and Greece. As we know, many Member States are still seriously behind in meeting their reception obligations, which is a moral obligation, but also a legal obligation, as today's text rightly emphasises once again and which I wanted to support with great conviction.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I abstained today in the vote on the report 'Asylum: provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece'. In principle, I agree that there must be a mechanism in Europe for the distribution of refugees. At the same time, however, the report's demands go too far, so that security issues and the fight against illegal entry or terrorism, for example, are neglected.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. We must not leave the southern European Member States alone with the influx of refugees, but must remember the founding values of the European Union and show solidarity. Therefore, a fair quota distribution of Syrian refugees among EU member states is essential. Everyone must take responsibility in this crisis. Those who do not take responsibility cannot claim full EU funding.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the implementation of the migrant relocation plan across the European Union. This relocation, presented as aid to Italy and Greece, is mainly aimed at forcing Member States and European peoples to take in asylum seekers, even though they are in most cases economic refugees.  The European Commission therefore wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the relocation plan agreed by European heads of state in September 2015. The plan calls for the start of relocation - allocation between Member States from 26 September 2016. Unfortunately, this is not all since the agreement reached on 18 March between the European Union and Turkey provides for the resettlement of a "Syrian" to one of the Member States for every "Syrian" readmitted by Turkey. Patriotic MEPs reject this compulsory distribution of migrants whose reception is catastrophic for Europeans every day. So I voted against this resolution.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. This text is the finding of failure of the policy of distribution of migrants decided by European governments in 2015. It aims to amend the decision to take into account the dupe agreement with Turkey, by allocating 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the "relocation" plan to refugees from Turkey, while noting that the plan has been very little implemented. We do not have to pay collectively for the measures decided by Mrs Merkel in the sole interest of Germany. I have said the interests of Germany, which imagines that it needs low-cost workers to support its growth and the ease of its pensioners. It seems that the Germans were not really consulted. Seeing the electoral slaps that Mrs Merkel has been taking for several weeks and the irresistible rise of the AfD, they decided to make their opinion known. If we are to help Greece and Italy, it is above all to drive the hundreds of thousands of migrants they unwittingly take home out of Europe and to protect themselves from new arrivals by waging war on smugglers, helping Syria and cutting off the aspiring immigration pumps. Of which Mrs Merkel is a member. But that is for the German citizens to do.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report opposing the EU-Turkey Agreement and the readmission scheme proposed by the Commission in the context of its human rights-infringing migration policy. We share the criticism of the Member States for their petty behaviour in welcoming people in need of international protection on their territory and for the need to act in co-responsibility with Greece and Italy in dealing with sufficient resources and in solidarity with the greatest humanitarian crisis in Europe since World War II.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report, which signals another call on Member States to uphold their responsibility and show solidarity by taking part in relocation and resettlement measures. Countries on the periphery, such as Greece and Italy, are still struggling to respond to the thousands of refugees and asylum-seekers that are arriving. We believe that resettlement should not take place at the expense of relocation: both are important instruments of solidarity. Relocation is a form of internal solidarity among Member States, while resettlement and humanitarian admission or other kinds of admission are a form of external solidarity with third countries hosting the majority of refugees.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The EU is still struggling to adopt a comprehensive, long-term, strategic and, let's face it, readable migration policy. Presented in March 2016 in the wake of the EU-Turkey declaration, the Commission's proposal is a perfect example. By barely magnifying the line, it can be said that what the Commission is asking for is to "trade" relocation places for resettlement. Almost no one will dispute the need and urgency to promote safe and legal routes for migrants and to support third countries, such as Turkey, which are hosting the majority of the world's displaced. That said, the EU's solidarity with its external partners can never com dispense states with solidarity with each other. Relocation and resettlement mechanisms are complementary and cannot be competed under any circumstances. Unfortunately, the latest statistics confirm that intra-European transfers of applicants from Italy and Greece are still on the drip. In this matter, Parliament is consulted, but it has spoken with a strong and clear voice: relocation efforts must be accelerated and strengthened. The ball is now in the Council's court so that it does not miss this opportunity.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The Member States had already pledged to receive a share of 160 000 asylum seekers relocated from Greece and Italy. A part of the total allocation (54 000) was kept as a reserve, this was originally intended for Hungary but was unused. The Commission decided to use the 54 000 relocation allocation for the resettlement of Syrians from Turkey, as this meant that the distribution between Member States had already been effected and no new legal instrument had to be created.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it sends a clear political signal to the need to support Greece and Italy by speeding up, inter alia, a fair system for the relocation of refugees. The report also expresses a clear opposition to the EU-Turkey Agreement, which is not in line with international law on refugees and asylum and is a culmination of the EU's policy of cynicism and analgesia towards the victims of a war for which it itself bears many responsibilities.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Given the strain that the migrant crisis has had on the infrastructures of certain Member States, and given the potential for fundamental rights abuses, I believe that an amendment of provisional measures in the area of international protection, for the benefit of Italy and Greece, is necessary. I accept and support the provision that Member States should make available at least one third of their relocation places by 31 December 2016. It should be the duty of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency to keep under constant review the situation regarding massive inflows of third-country nationals into Member States. It is imperative that Syrian refugees, in particular, be resettled to the Union. There should be a greater number of safer and lawful routes for asylum seekers and refugees into the Union, including a binding and mandatory Union legislative approach to resettlement, the establishment of humanitarian admission programmes by all Member States and more extensive use of humanitarian visas.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The Council Decisions of 14 and 22 September 2015 on the relocation of a total of 160,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other countries are now intended to amend an existing and subsequent Council Decision of 26 September 2015, which regulates the implementation of the relocation. The existing EU-Turkey agreement will be taken into account. In principle, such an approach makes sense. However, the report calls for unsustainable changes. In this way, the momentum of solidarity and fair sharing of burdens is emphasised much more strongly than in the original draft. The principle of non-refoulement of refugees is therefore not in place with the existing EU-Turkey agreement. It also calls for better opportunities for migrants to enter the EU safely and for increased family reunification. Resettlement and relocation should be promoted as a sign of solidarity. Asylum seekers are to be accepted mainly from Syria, Iraq, Eritrea and Afghanistan. Monthly status reports of the Member States are to be omitted. I rejected the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this consultation procedure proposal, which is technically non-legislative. UKIP rejects the role of the European Border and Coast Guard in the migration crisis. Moreover, UKIP also opposes the compulsory resettlement of migrants across EU nations.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I voted against the Keller report because I am convinced that migration to Europe cannot decrease if, at the same time, the EU continues to claim that it will take in all the world's migrants and that it will find them a decent place to welcome them, with optimal conditions.    In particular, the recommendation proposes to create a binding and mandatory legislative scheme for large-scale resettlement, considers that family reunification cannot be "subordinated to other EU policies or emergency solidarity measures" and that it should even be "encouraged by the Member States in all cases", and suggests adding a new country to the list of nationalities eligible for refugee status. Afghanistan. In addition, Parliament requires Member States to commit to taking in more migrants than their 2015 commitments. What do national parliaments think? Can we afford it? The right answer lies not in the continuous and sustained reception of migrants while our own reception capacities are outdated but in more active cooperation with third countries, a better knowledge of our geostrategic environment and a better oriented development assistance policy.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to show solidarity towards Greece and Italy, which are facing a tremendous volume of asylum applications. I welcome the creation of a European asylum system.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 on the imposition of interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, as I strongly support legal and safe routes to the European Union for people seeking protection and asylum. This report goes towards allowing syrians to be resettled from Turkey, and I believe that in the context of the humanitarian crisis in which the Union is located, it is necessary to provide concrete and effective measures available as soon as possible. Long-term solutions are needed to approach this problem efficiently and concretely, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text is a pro-immigration plea, which states that so far only a very small number of Syrian refugees have been relocated to the EU. It recalls the European Parliament's resolution of 12 April 2016 in which it called for more safe and lawful routes in the Union for asylum seekers and refugees, including the adoption by the EU of a binding and mandatory resettlement law, the establishment of humanitarian admission programmes by all Member States and the wider use of humanitarian visas. We reject the policy of distributing migrants, which has proved to be a scathing failure. This text only confirms and makes this policy even more restrictive. In accordance with the National Front's struggle for more than 40 years against the migration invasion, I opposed this text of treason.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs voted against this consultation procedure proposal, which is technically non-legislative. UKIP rejects the role of the European Border and Coast Guard in the migration crisis. Moreover, UKIP also opposes the compulsory resettlement of migrants across EU nations.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted against the Keller report on the introduction of interim measures on international protection for Italy and Greece. I am obviously in favour of Member States showing solidarity with each other in the face of the migration crisis, but this report goes far beyond this by proposing, for example, the establishment of a binding and mandatory legislative mechanism for resettlement. It also wants family reunification not to be subordinated to other EU policies or to solidarity or emergency measures.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for Ms Keller’s report as it looks at the issue of asylum. She stresses the multidimensional nature of the problem and she focuses on an issue that is of vital importance for the smooth procedure of refugee integration, namely relocation. It is of utmost importance that the relocation mechanism becomes efficient and that the various Member States accept their obligations. Additionally we need to face the reality that the EU must be prepared for alternative routes and a potential failure of the deal with Turkey. For those reasons I supported the report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report deals with the relocation of thousands of migrants from Greece and Italy to the other Member States, but does not address the general problem of the migration crisis and possible solutions to the fight against the use of refugees. It also proposes new ways of bringing migrants into the Union by simplifying the issue of humanitarian visas. I therefore do not agree with this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report, which signals another call on Member States to uphold their responsibility and show solidarity by taking part in relocation and resettlement measures. Countries on the periphery such as Greece and Italy are still struggling to respond to the thousands of refugees and asylum-seekers that are arriving. We believe that resettlement should not take place at the expense of relocation. Both are important instruments of solidarity. Relocation is a form of internal solidarity among Member States, while resettlement and humanitarian admission or other kinds of admission are a form of external solidarity with third countries hosting the majority of refugees.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The Council Decisions of 14 and 22 September 2015 on the relocation of a total of 160,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other countries are now intended to amend an existing and subsequent Council Decision of 26 September 2015, which regulates the implementation of the relocation. The existing EU-Turkey agreement will be taken into account. In principle, such an approach makes sense. However, the report calls for unsustainable changes. In this way, the momentum of solidarity and fair sharing of burdens is emphasised much more strongly than in the original draft. The principle of non-refoulement of refugees is therefore not in place with the existing EU-Turkey agreement. It also calls for better opportunities for migrants to enter the EU safely and for increased family reunification. Resettlement and relocation should be promoted as a sign of solidarity. Asylum seekers are to be accepted mainly from Syria, Iraq, Eritrea and Afghanistan. Monthly status reports of the Member States are to be omitted. Overall, the report expresses the desire to take in more asylum seekers and migrants in Europe. The rapporteur of the Greens is thus completely ignoring the problems of crime, terrorism and integration associated with the current asylum and migration crisis, as well as the broad will of the citizens in Europe. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 European Parliament legislative resolution of 15 September 2016 amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 laying down temporary international protection measures in favour of Italy and Greece, as once again these were infamous quotas. I recognise the difficult situation of Italy and Greece, but I do not believe quotas are the solution to such a complex situation.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungary has opposed mandatory relocation on principle since the beginning of the migration crisis. Hungary government has challenged a decision at the Court of Justice of the EUROPEAN Union to take in migrants, which ignores the European Council's resolution in favour of voluntary re-ingation. This way of distributing asylum seekers remains not an instrument for resolving the situation, since it is the sovereign right of each State to determine who it accepts on its territory. Furthermore, mandatory re relationalation increases the pull effect and does not respond to the treatment of secondary migration movements. However, the relocation does not work in practice, with only 4,741 people relocated from the mandatory 120,000-strong voluntary resettlement quota and the 40,000-strong voluntary resettlement quota since September 2015. In my opinion, Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the causes of their escape are reduced or eliminated. To do this, it is not the migrants that need to be brought here and distributed, but the help that needs to be brought there. In addition to Turkey, assistance to other states hosting large refugee camps is also needed. The European Parliament's report seeks to expand and accelerate the scope of this failed mechanism, rather than confined to the technical form of the EU-Turkey agreement, which makes it even more impossible for this already functioning system to function, so I am voting against it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ In the EU-Turkey deal, the Commission made the proposal that 54 000 applicants should be resettled to Turkey, instead of Greece and Italy. This report amends the Commission’s proposal in order to improve conditions in Greece and Italy and to stick to the relocation programme. The report also requests safer and legal routes for asylum-seekers, recalls the right of family reunification and highlights the very low numbers of persons relocated, despite Member States’ commitments. I voted in favour of the report for these reasons.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. "Nono, this has happened in history, but it has not ended well, and they have been searching for the place of the ruins of Troy ever since. Perhaps greek and Italian seafarers should not gather and transport economic "refugees" to Europe off the coast of Africa. In the sense of international law, it should not be regarded as a refugee but as an economic immigrant, and the promotion of the flood of millions of people alien to European culture should not be supported on the basis of the reception quota imposed on the Member States. For example, it is frivolous to make admission compulsory for Afghans, who have already crossed halfway around the world while entering the EU, so they clearly come from a safe country of origin, but this is also true of almost all other immigrants.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 Solidarity is the key principle that should undersoe the development of immigration and asylum policies. Solidarity both internally, between the Member States of the Union and externally, with the third countries that host the majority of refugees. With this vote, Parliament reminds the Member States that resettlement policies, the main instrument of external solidarity, should not take place at the expense of relocation. That is why we call on the Member States to honour the commitments made in previous decisions and to ensure the rapid relocation of 54 thousand applicants for international protection. We also call for the treatment of cases of vulnerable people, especially minors, to be speeded up so that they can rejoin their families. We are not only guaranteeing the relocation rights of Syrians, Eritreans and Iraqis, but we are also including Afghans among those entitled to relocation. The efforts made so far are derisory: we cannot accept that to date only 7% of the number of relocation posts have actually been allocated. The situation is becoming more critical for Italy and Greece every day and, given the high number of asylum seekers arriving mainly in Italy, it is expected that the need for places of emergency relocation will remain high.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the September 2015 relocation plan to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU. However, I reject this policy of distributing migrants.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the September 2015 relocation plan to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU. We oppose the policy of the distribution of migrants when this text only confirms and makes this policy even more restrictive. I have therefore rejected the Commission's proposal and the legislative resolution for these reasons.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, so far, Member States have mobilized only 7% of the planned relocation places. As of 5 July, only 793 people from Italy and 2033 from Greece were effectively relocated. The Commission, in its first report on relocation and resettlement of 16 March 2016, notes that Member States must achieve a monthly relocation rate of at least 5,680 person in order to meet their relocation obligations within the planned two-year period. This report stresses the need for Member States to fully assume their relocation obligations so that under the Decisions it took last year, they will help to alleviate the pressure on frontline Member States. Responsible Member States where resettlement should be carried out should rapidly and substantively increase their efforts to respond to the existing humanitarian situation.  It is imperative that Member States respond in solidarity to the challenge posed by the refugee crisis as the basis for developing a true European Asylum System.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. We are looking at a proposal that does not call into question the root of the current situation of migrants or the main one in the face of the logic of the Fortress Europe. However, the introduction of a whole range of concrete measures is being proposed to improve the situation of these people. The elimination of the shameful EU-Turkey Agreement or the extension of the right to asylum to more nationalities, in line with the Geneva Convention which is not now complied with by the EU, are very positively valued elements. In addition, we share the need to overcome the current quota system which has failed because of the lack of political will of States, in order to impose a system based really on the solidarity and freedom of movement and choice of the asylum seeker himself. That is why, despite not being the model of migration policy we are defending, we voted in favour of the report, understanding that this proposal would bring tangible improvements in the situation of people forced to flee their countries.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The Council Decisions of 14 and 22 September 2015 on the relocation of a total of 160,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other countries are now intended to amend an existing and subsequent Council Decision of 26 September 2015, which regulates the implementation of the relocation. The existing EU-Turkey agreement will be taken into account. In principle, such an approach makes sense. However, the report calls for unsustainable changes. In this way, the momentum of solidarity and fair sharing of burdens is emphasised much more strongly than in the original draft. The principle of non-refoulement of refugees is therefore not in place with the existing EU-Turkey agreement. It also calls for better opportunities for migrants to enter the EU safely and for increased family reunification. Resettlement and relocation should be promoted as a sign of solidarity. Asylum seekers are to be accepted mainly from Syria, Iraq, Eritrea and Afghanistan. Monthly status reports of the Member States are to be omitted. Overall, the report expresses the desire to take in more asylum seekers and migrants in Europe. The rapporteur of the Greens is thus completely ignoring the problems of crime, terrorism and integration associated with the current asylum and migration crisis, as well as the broad will of the citizens in Europe. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which acknowledges the need for further action for resettlement, resettling Syrians from Turkey through a 1:1 scheme.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. This is a proposal for a Council decision, the European Parliament has only a consultative role here, so even if the EP votes against it, the Council does not have to take this into account. The essence of the proposal is the adaptation of the infamous decision taken last year on the redistribution of migrants, in which we, as the Czech Republic, were re-voted. The current proposal introduces into EU legislation an EU agreement with Turkey on 7 March this year on migrant exchanges (for every Syrian returned to Turkey, the EU will take another Syrian). I voted against it for two main reasons: firstly, I completely disagree with the principles of the EU-Turkey agreement. Secondly, I consider the Council's decision to circumvent the will of both the European Parliament and the national parliaments. If the agreement took the form of an international treaty and not just a temporary Council decision, it would have to be properly debated in both the European Parliament and national parliaments. The regulation of the temporary decision is a mockery of the principles of the rule of law, in this way we can temporarily adjust it indefinitely. This is an abuse of article of the Treaty of Lisbon, which does not require the consent of the European Parliament and the involvement of national parliaments for temporary measures.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The influx of third-country nationals has increased significantly in certain EU Member States. The pressure of the migratory influx has been felt in other exposed countries, such as Italy. Strengthening internal solidarity and responsibility for assistance to Member States, resettlement and legal or humanitarian admission from Turkey are necessary to relieve pressure on the Member States exposed.  As a result of this pressure, they are incapable of providing adequate protection to asylum seekers. This is confirmed by the European Parliament Resolution of 12 April 2016 on the situation in the Mediterranean, which underlines the need for a holistic EU approach to migration and calls for the development and diversification of migration flows towards the Union. The relocation of migrants from the territory of one Member State to the territory of another Member State is one of the key mechanisms within the emergency assistance framework to exposed Member States such as Greece and Italy, thereby supporting them.  Also important is the role of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, which should be responsible for continuously analysing the situation of mass migrant inflows into Member States. In line with these claims, I supported the Council's proposal for a decision and believe that it will contribute to a more efficient management of migrant flows in the EU.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. – I am sceptical about such a system. It will not work in real world. We need a comprehensive mechanism that would help realistically, not declaratively.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ Following the Council (EU) Decision of September 2015 regulating the introduction of temporary international protection measures in favour of Italy and Greece, 54 000 refugees and/or applicants from greece and Italy should be redistributed to other Member States. However, experience shows that the system of compulsory quotas does not work. In view of their other developments vis-à-vis other European countries and the economic and economic situation of their countries, as well as other problems, several countries are unable to accept the required number of applicants.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601, of 22 September 2015 laying down provisional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/9/2016, and because this report is well documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  The Commission wants to use almost half of the places in the September 2015 relocation plan (54,000 out of 120,000) to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU. We oppose the policy of the distribution of migrants when this text only confirms and makes this policy even more restrictive. Moreover, this measure is necessary for the Member States, which constitutes an attack on sovereignty.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – It should be the European Union’s moral duty to assist asylum seekers reaching Italy and Greece, as these countries have declared a state of emergency. No Member State should take a hands-off approach because failing to assist is against what the EU believes in. EU countries are encouraged to be as cooperative as possible, especially in relation to border control. I want to highlight the importance of travel documents to identify those reaching Greek and Italian coasts, because only by identifying them will we be able to assist more effectively in the relocation of migrants. Italy and Greece, as core members of the EU, should not have to battle alone to cope with the hundreds of asylum seekers arriving every day.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the proposal to establish new provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, in the face of pressure from these countries over the arrival of asylum seekers.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The asylum crisis in Italy and Greece is reported here. As a consequence of the status quo, however, we want to take further measures to promote migratory movements. I reject that.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report opposes the Commission's proposal to move 54,000 asylum seekers from Greece and Italy to Turkey. Because since the EU-Turkey agreement imposed by Germany, in addition to the 3 billion given to the Erdogan government to "keep" migrants, the principle of "sorting" Syrians has been introduced. For every Syrian returned, the Union will be able to choose the one it wants to take back. An agreement based on the labour needs of German capitalism. The report also defends a strict application of the relocation programme, which is internal to the European Union. I am personally not satisfied with this programme, which aims to move handfuls of applicants from here and there in the Union. Of course, Greek and Italian asylum services need to be de-cluttered, but a bureaucratic system far from the realities and needs of asylum seekers cannot work. A fortiori, if we do not extinguish the root causes of parallel migration. I support the opposition to these EU-Turkey provisions, but not this programme as presented. In these circumstances, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the September 2015 relocation plan to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU. We oppose the policy of the distribution of migrants when this text only confirms and makes this policy even more restrictive. I therefore rejected the Commission's proposal and the resolution for these reasons.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the framework of the Common Asylum Policy, Article 78(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) provides a specific legal basis for dealing with emergencies. This amendment is the assessment of member states' efforts to take in the admission of Syrians present in Turkey through resettlement, humanitarian admission or other forms of legal admission in relation to the number of applicants for international protection who must be relocated to their territory under Council Decision 2015/1601. For the 54 000 applicants referred to in Article 4(1)(c) of Council Decision 2015/1601, this amendment allows Member States to subtract from the number of relocated applicants assigned to them the number of Syrians present in Turkey admitted to their territory through resettlement, humanitarian admission or other forms of legal admission under national or multilateral schemes other than the resettlement scheme established under the conclusions of the representatives of the Governments of the Member States, meeting within the Council on 20 July 2015. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution which urges Member States to implement the relocation mechanism properly and show solidarity with Italy and Greece.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's objection to the Commission's proposal to reallocate to the relocation of the places originally planned for relocation. These are two different procedures. The solidarity of The Member States between them and that towards third countries should not be a substitute for each other. All relocation commitments must be honoured. With Greece and Italy still facing a considerable challenge, solidarity between Member States must be strengthened. It is therefore not appropriate to fulfil our resettlement commitments to Turkey at the expense of those made in favour of Italy and Greece. People resettled from Turkey by Member States should not reduce our relocation commitments. On the other hand, our solidarity with the third countries that are on the front line of the refugee crisis must be very real. In this respect, resettlement is a tool that should be favoured and for which the Union must adopt an ambitious policy. The new European resettlement programme will therefore have to live up to our duty of solidarity with these third countries.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – the European Commission has proposed to free up 54 000 places out of a total of 120 000 places under the mechanism for relocating asylum seekers within the EU and to use these places to resettle Syrians from Turkey into the Territory of the Union under the EU-Turkey Migration Agreement. The proposal opposes such a change in the mechanism, as the relocation of asylum seekers within the EU cannot be mixed with the resettlement of refugees from third countries. Resettlement (from Turkey to the EU) should not take place at the expense of relocation (within the EU). According to the proposed text, relocation is a form of internal solidarity between EU Member States, while resettlement is a form of external solidarity with third countries where the majority of refugees are located. I am voting in favour in favour.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on asylum and its provisional measure in favour of Italy and Greece because it is essential to show more solidarity among the Member States and to create a truly European asylum system.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the relocation plan agreed by EU representatives in September 2015 to resettle Syrian migrants who came to the EU from Turkey. The resolution calls on Member States to make at least one third of their relocation places available by 31 December 2016.  Worse, if the relocation Member State does not accept relocation within two weeks, then approval will be considered. It is clear that we strongly reject this text, which imposes on the Member States an additional dose of the crazy European migration policy.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Article 78(3) TFEU provides that, on a proposal from the European Commission, the Council, after consulting the EP, adopts interim measures in favour of the Member State or Those faced with an emergency situation characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals to one or more Member States.  As the situation remains dramatic, I advocate further operational initiatives in eu-Turkey cooperation in the field of migration, with the adoption of necessary measures to transfer some of the commitments made under the current relocation decisions, including all or part of the 54 000 posts currently unaffected, to the so-called one-on-one scheme. Resettlement or other legal means for the admission of persons in clear need of international protection can be considered equivalent to relocation, as they are all concrete expressions of solidarity with other Member States or third countries faced with massive influxes of migrants.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I reject the policy of distributing migrants, which has proved to be a scathing failure. This text only confirms and makes this policy even more restrictive. I'm voting against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which signals another call on Member States to uphold their responsibility and show solidarity by taking part in relocation and resettlement measures. Countries on the periphery, such as Greece and Italy, are still struggling to respond to the thousands of refugees and asylum-seekers who are arriving. We believe that resettlement should not take place at the expense of relocation. Both are important instruments of solidarity. Relocation is a form of internal solidarity among Member States, while resettlement and humanitarian admission or other kinds of admission are forms of external solidarity with third countries hosting the majority of refugees.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this report on interim measures on international protection for Italy and Greece, which aim to change the Council's decision to relocate people in need of international protection from Italy and Greece to implement the agreement with Turkey, which I have always opposed. In particular, it calls for the establishment of a binding and mandatory legislative framework for the resettlement of migrants and for the wider use of humanitarian visas.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 A year has passed since, on September 6, 2015, Pope Francis, to prepare for the Holy Year of Mercy, invited parishes, religious communities, monasteries and shrines from all over Europe to welcome a family of refugees. The European Union has tried to react, through the Commission and Parliament, and at the ins of some Member States, by proposing solutions in support of a solidarity approach to the humanitarian emergency. Nevertheless, there has not yet been a real rethink of the Dublin Regulation and a sharing of responsibility. The partial relocation mechanisms proposed by the Council, which provide for aid to the two most exposed States, Italy and Greece, have only been partially complied with. Meanwhile, the number of landings, although slightly decreased, continues to record very high figures: in 2016 alone, 281,055 people have already landed in Italy and Greece. For this reason, I support the report proposed by the Committee on European Free Affairs, which reiterates the need for a compulsory distribution of migrants among the Member States, according to a quota-sharing mechanism. Only in this way will it be possible to develop a system of sincere solidarity between Member States and to create a genuine European asylum system.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on interim measures for Italy and Greece, which follows a 2015 Council decision to alleviate these two countries in view of the number of people in need of international protection on their territory. The report provides for Member States to take care of people directly from Turkey, without going through Italy and Greece as intermediaries.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the need to increase solidarity between Member States, strengthen integration for border management and help prevent crisis situations at the Union's external borders, I welcome the report on temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. Our group has worked hard to produce a report that will stimulate more debate and that calls for more action from European leaders in the first place. The proposal responds to the need to ensure adequate redistribution of migrants landing on European coasts between all Member States. In fact, although the redistribution plan approved by the European Council on 22 September 2015 provides, in accordance with the principle of solidarity between the members of the Union, for the transfer of 54 000 asylum seekers among the 28 countries. As of July 5, 2015, only 793 people from Italy and 33 from Greece have been transferred; these numbers tell us a reality very far removed from what the Council has decided. It is therefore necessary to work to ensure that the redistribution mechanisms start to work and that, as established, there are 5 680 asylum seekers transferred each month.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to allocate 54,000 allowances initially allocated to relocation from Italy and Greece, for the benefit of the resettlement programme for Syrian refugees from Turkey, as provided for in the EU-Turkey declaration, cannot be shared by those who, like me, believe that a valid reaction to the refugee crisis can only be based on a solidarity approach between all Member States. Although I believe it is necessary for the European Union to comply with the clause in the agreement with Turkey, for which, with each relocation from Greece, must be matched by a resettlement from Turkey to European territory, I do not support the idea that it should be Italy and Greece, already under unprecedented migratory pressure, that should be further penalised. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the Keller report which, thanks to a shared will on the part of several political groups, rejects the proposal to switch 54 000 quotas for relocation from Italy to Greece, in quotas valid for resettlement from Turkey. The text also adequately conveys the urgent need to make the relocation programme a truly functioning instrument, capable of producing a real reduction in the burdens that border states are forced to bear.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The rising number of asylum seekers in Greece and in Italy makes the need for emergency relocation places an important issue to address. I voted for this report, which will provide large-scale resettlement, humanitarian admission and other forms of legal admission for migrants in order to relieve the migratory pressure on Greece and Italy.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report with today's vote because I believe that it makes important additions and amendments to the Council Decision amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. Of course, there are still aspects that could be improved, but I believe that, in the context of the pressure in Italy and Greece, this report clarifies the situation of transfers and relocations of nationals.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the EP report because it completely empties the Commission's proposal and instead focuses it in a completely different direction. I believe that, not only in this case, the EP report should have dealt with the Commission's proposal (including its possible criticism) and not confused it with a political declaration. The Commission has pragmatically proposed counting people resettled in the Member States directly from Turkey into national quotas for the relocation of refugees from Italy and Greece, and I understand this proposal as an effort to contribute to addressing the migration crisis while ensuring the functioning of the EU-Turkey Agreement. The decision to relocate refugees within the EU provides for some flexibility in the light of new circumstances, and it is precisely the conclusion of the EU-Turkey agreement and the resulting commitments that i think justify the activation of this flexibility clause.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I supported the report and voted in favour. The report is strong on protecting the concept of shared responsibility for the refugee crisis, calls for safe and legal access for refugees, is committed to family reunification, acknowledges the dire situation in Greece and Italy and seeks to add Afghan refugees to the relocation category.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I strongly oppose this report, as further measures are to be taken with regard to the asylum crisis in Italy and Greece, which would encourage migration.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The decision gives the EU the opportunity to take action on the relocation of Syrian refugees from Turkey. It is important that people seeking asylum can do so on legal and secure roads.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite EU countries' commitments to relocate a total of 160,000 asylum seekers in two years, only a small proportion of people have so far been transferred from Greece and Italy. I voted in favour of the report, which calls on EU countries to allocate at least a third of the relocation places for which they have already committed themselves, by 31 December 2016. EU Member States must honour their commitments and have an equal redistribution of weight. Also, as highlighted in the report, the Commission's proposal that EU countries can count the number of Syrian refugees they accept directly from Turkey under the EU-Turkey agreement at existing relocation locations from Greece and Italy is not correct. Resettlement should not take place at the expense of relocation and there should be a replacement of reception places from Greece and Italy with refugees directly from Turkey. There is a great need for immediate relocation of refugees from Greece and Italy to other EU Member States taking into account the urgent humanitarian situation in Greece and the risk of deterioration in Italy.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this consultation procedure proposal, which is technically non-legislative. UKIP rejects the role of the European Border and Coast Guard in the migration crisis. Moreover, UKIP also opposes the compulsory resettlement of migrants across EU nations.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 From the South, as an Italian and as a European, I urge you to vote in favour of this text. It is too important at this historic moment for all Member States to show solidarity with each other.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Croatia has accepted the refugee-migrant crisis in a humanitarian aspect and by highlighting the empathy of Croatian citizens towards arriving refugees and migrants. In the second half of September and October 2015, 299,969 refugees and migrants headed to Croatia by 1 November 2015. Between 2004 and 2015, 4857 applications were submitted in Croatia.  With the beginning of the crisis, transit centers such as Opatovac and Slavonski Brod were established, with a capacity of 5000 to 10000 people, which were sufficient for short-term accommodation. Asylum seekers' shelters such as those in Kutina and Zagreb are an indication that Croatia is ready to provide assistance. Croatia has so far shown adequate solidarity in the care of refugees and migrants, organising the necessary care according to opportunities, which citizens have supported but also expect authorities to protect national and state sovereignty as well as other vital national interests, in particular the social security of their own citizens. Italy and Greece need to be supported, but Europe ultimately needs to set out a common asylum and immigration policy aimed at tackling the problem at the start-up, rather than how it has been so far on firefighting.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the relocation plan agreed by EU representatives in September 2015 to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU, in line with the EU-Turkey migration agreement. The resolution proposes that Member States make available at least one third of their relocation places by 31 December 2016. It adds that if the relocation Member State did not approve the relocation within two weeks, approval should be assumed to have been given. The text stresses that so far only a very small number of Syrian refugees have been relocated to the EU. It recalls the European Parliament's resolution of 12 April 2016 in which it called for more safe and lawful routes in the Union for asylum seekers and refugees, including the adoption by the EU of a binding and mandatory resettlement law, the establishment of humanitarian admission programmes by all Member States and the wider use of humanitarian visas. I reject the EU-Turkey agreement and the policy of distributing migrants, which has proved to be a scathing failure. This text only confirms and makes this policy even more restrictive. So I'm voting against it.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The two decisions adopted by the Council in 2015, (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601, established provisional measures on international protection, for the benefit of Italy and Greece, which provided for the relocation of 160 000 asylum seekers to other EU countries. Under these decisions, 54 000 people were to be relocated from Italy and Greece by 26 September 2016 to the territory of other Member States, unless the Commission had submitted a proposal by that date to allocate these posts to other Member States in an emergency situation due to a sudden influx of people. Now, the Commission's proposal is intended to take into account the efforts made by the Member States to take in Syrian refugees relocated from Turkey. The Group of the Party of European Socialists and the European Parliament do not support this proposal. To date, the Member States have made available only 7% of the posts needed for relocation from Italy and Greece. That is why the Committee on European Free Affairs and Citizens' Rights adopted this report by a large majority in order to reaffirm the need for the Member States to fulfil their obligations, relieving the pressure on the Mediterranean countries. The prolonging of this situation of absolute lack of solidarity is unacceptable, and I therefore support the report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. I supported The Keller Report, as the introduction of interim measures for the benefit of Italy and Greece, which would allow refugees to be resettle or take in, and reduce migratory pressure, evidence of joint action to tackle the refugee-migration crisis and to find solidarity in the care of refugees in accordance with international laws and regulations.  Of particular importance is the task of the European Border and Coast Guard, whose duty is to keep under constant control the flow of migrants to Italy and Greece. Also important is the Agreement with Turkey, whose application has significantly loosened the refugee wave and strengthened control of the migration wave.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the European Parliament has spoken out clearly against the European Commission's proposal that Member States should be able to deduct the number of Syrians resettled by Turkey from the number of people the Member State has undertaken to host under the relocation agreements. Thanks also to my decisive contribution, as the PPE's shadow rapporteur, we have adopted a legislative resolution which stresses that resettlement must not take place at the expense of the relocations of asylum seekers currently housed in our country. The closure of the Balkan route has once again shifted irregular migratory flows to the central Mediterranean. In addition, the latest figures published by the European Commission tell us that only 1,064 people have been relocated from Italy, while only 3,712 have been relocated from Greece. In order to resolve the migrant crisis, we must continue along the path of sharing responsibilities and costs between the Member States of the Union. Our job as Members of the European Parliament is to urge the Commission and the Council to ensure that this happens. I believe that we have succeeded in this case, and that is why I naturally voted in favour of this legislative resolution.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 7 March 2016, eu Heads of State or Government agreed on a number of principles underpinning the agreement with Turkey, including resettlement in accordance with the principle that any readmission of a Syrian from the Greek islands to Turkey will be accompanied by the resettlement of another Syrian from Turkey to EU Member States, within the framework of existing commitments.  The proposed amendment is to count the actions taken by Member States in relation to the admission of Syrians residing in Turkey through reassurance, humanitarian or other forms of legal admission of the number of applicants for international protection to be relocated to their territory under Council Decision 2015/1601. In line with this change, and for the 54 000 asylum seekers, Member States may subsoue the number of Syrians residing in Turkey admitted on their territory by resettlement, humanitarian admission or other forms of legal admission under national or multilateral programmes other than the resettlement programme from their assigned number of asylum seekers. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted against this consultation report because it concerns a field of competence and decision within the jurisdiction of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent migration crisis has called on the European Union to take international cooperation measures whose relevance is very significant in the current global geopolitical context. The EU-Turkey Agreement has proved to be a relevant tool – the possible tool – in managing the migration crisis. This report approves the relocation of 54 000 asylum seekers in Italy and Greece in other Member States, respecting the quotas set out in the agreement. My vote is therefore in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this consultation procedure proposal, which is technically non-legislative. UKIP rejects the role of the European Border and Coast Guard in the migration crisis. Moreover, UKIP also opposes the compulsory resettlement of migrants across EU nations.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the need for a more equitable redistribution of migrants by EU members. A large-scale resettlement of humanitarian admission and other forms of legal admission from Turkey under national and multilateral regimes should be made to relieve migratory pressure on Member States by providing safe and legal routes to enter the Union and making irregular entry unnecessary. It is essential, together with the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, to monitor the situation with regard to the massive influx of third-country nationals to member states.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Once and for all, Member States need to fully fulfil their obligations with regard to resettlement under decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601, totaling 120,000 refugees, in order to relieve pressure on Greece and Italy. Compliance with humanitarian decisions deserves the same respect and rigour as compliance with economic and financial decisions.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Decision 2015/1601 indicated that refugees should be relocated from Italy and Greece to the territory of other Member States. So far, Member States have not been able to mobilisation the planned relocation places. There is therefore a need for Member States to assume their obligations and to comply with the resettlement agreement. It is imperative that Member States respond in solidarity to the challenge posed by the refugee crisis as the basis for developing a true European Asylum System. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution establishing interim measures on international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece.  This is a strong signal that reaffirms the need to respect the Commission's relocation plan in view of the thousands of people who are stranded in Greece and Italy or who arrive in these countries every day. It is essential to set up a European relocation system that is fair and hopeful for these thousands of people in distress.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report on the proposal to amend the Council decision, which provides for interim measures in the field of international protection for Italy and Greece, as we are facing two emergency asylum situations.  These are provisional measures of an exceptional nature which seek to respond to a serious situation related to the sudden and sudden influx of third-country nationals into Europe. As the situation continues to be urgent, serious and immediate and effective, this report deals with the need to amend the Commission's proposal with regard to the admission of third-country nationals, their resettlement, humanitarian admission and other legal forms.  Since I agree mostly with the amendments that have been introduced, My vote was in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report opposing the EU-Turkey Agreement and the readmission scheme proposed by the Commission in the context of its human rights-infringing migration policy. We share the criticism of the Member States for their petty behaviour in welcoming people in need of international protection on their territory and for the need to act in co-responsibility with Greece and Italy in dealing with sufficient resources and in solidarity with the greatest humanitarian crisis in Europe since World War II.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the temporary asylum measures in favour of Italy and Greece, as the current refugee crisis must be resolved together. Italy and Greece must not be left alone with their European external borders. As a result, eu-Turkey cooperation means that Syrians in need will be resettled directly from Turkey to EU Member States.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We are looking at a proposal that does not call into question the root of the current situation of migrants or the main one in the face of the logic of the Fortress Europe. However, the introduction of a whole range of concrete measures is being proposed to improve the situation of these people. The elimination of the shameful EU-Turkey Agreement or the extension of the right to asylum to more nationalities, in line with the Geneva Convention which is not now complied with by the EU, are very positively valued elements.
