In addition, we share the need to overcome the current quota system which has failed because of the lack of political will of States, in order to impose a system based really on the solidarity and freedom of movement and choice of the asylum seeker himself. That is why, despite not being the model of migration policy we are defending, we voted in favour of the report, understanding that this proposal would bring tangible improvements in the situation of people forced to flee their countries.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which signals another call on Member States to uphold their responsibility and show solidarity by taking part in relocation and resettlement measures. Countries on the periphery, such as Greece and Italy, are still struggling to respond to the thousands of refugees and asylum-seekers who are arriving. We believe that resettlement should not take place at the expense of relocation. Both are important instruments of solidarity. Relocation is a form of internal solidarity among Member States, while resettlement and humanitarian admission or other kinds of admission are forms of external solidarity with third countries hosting the majority of refugees.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I abstained when voting on the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the introduction of temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. The proposal concerns the redistribution of 160 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other Member States. As has become clear a year after this decision has been taken, this measure is not effective enough and does not address the root causes of the migration crisis. The protection of external borders and sufficient control of individuals crossing the borders must remain a priority for the EU in the current situation. On the other hand, refugees already in EU countries should be provided with protection and humanitarian aid. Other Member States have the opportunity to provide assistance to countries affected by the refugee crisis in precisely these areas.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The Council Decisions of 14 and 22 September 2015 on the relocation of a total of 160,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other countries are now intended to amend an existing and subsequent Council Decision of 26 September 2015, which regulates the implementation of the relocation. The existing EU-Turkey agreement will be taken into account. In principle, such an approach makes sense. However, the report calls for unsustainable changes. In this way, the momentum of solidarity and fair sharing of burdens is emphasised much more strongly than in the original draft. The principle of non-refoulement of refugees is therefore not in place with the existing EU-Turkey agreement. It also calls for better opportunities for migrants to enter the EU safely and for increased family reunification. Resettlement and relocation should be promoted as a sign of solidarity. Asylum seekers are to be accepted mainly from Syria, Iraq, Eritrea and Afghanistan. Monthly status reports of the Member States are to be omitted. Overall, the report expresses the desire to take in more asylum seekers and migrants in Europe. The rapporteur of the Greens is thus completely ignoring the problems of crime, terrorism and integration associated with the current asylum and migration crisis, as well as the broad will of the citizens in Europe. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 Relocation of refugees to other Member States can only take place on a voluntary basis. We will help Italy and Greece the most by creating the best possible conditions for the effective functioning of the European coastguard and border guards.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. The N-VA is in favour of relocation as the culmination of an adequate border policy. This time, however, the N-VA supports the fragmented Commission proposal, as relocation sites – an existing obligation – are being reoriented to comply with the EU-Turkey agreement. The aim of this proposal is to use certain already planned places for 1-to-1 resettlement, and thus to further implement that necessary agreement. Member States can therefore, also in this context, call for a financial contribution per syrian relocated. On the other hand, the N-VA voted against Parliament's resolution on the grounds that it took the opportunity to implement the original Council decision on relocation. Among other things, it calls for afghans to be redistributed among EU Member States and calls for broad application of family reunification.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I accept this report because I believe that the world today is facing one of the biggest refugee and migration waves, and Europe must participate in solving this problem in a humanitarian way. In Greece and Italy, the number of asylum seekers is increasing and the need for urgent relocation will remain a major problem for EU border countries.  Humanitarian admission is needed from Turkey to reduce irregular entry into Turkey and later the European Union. I consider it necessary to extend reception places to the territories of other Member States, as 12 764 asylum applicants are in Italy and as many as 41,236 in Greece. These two countries cannot bear the burden of accepting and caring for refugees and immigrants in the EU on their own.  The relocation process must be completed as soon as possible, unless Italy and Greece prove objective obstacles preventing transfers from being made. At this crucial moment, the European Union must show solidarity not only towards refugees, but also towards its border members, which bear the greatest burden of the migration and refugee wave.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the EU Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 on the introduction of provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece in the field of international protection. This will start the relocation of 54 000 applicants from Italy and Greece. Relocation is defined as the transfer of an applicant from the territory of the Member State responsible for examining his application for international protection to the territory of the Member State of relocation. Resettlement or reception on the territory of a Member State of third-country nationals in need of international protection is not covered by the concept of resettlement. It also deals with the implementation of the EU-Turkey refugee deal of 7 March. According to this, for every Syrian resettled from the Greek islands by Turkey, another Syrian from Turkey will be resettled in the EU Member States. This one-to-one rule should be implemented in order to protect Syrians fleeing war and persecution, while fully respecting the right to seek asylum and the principle of non-refoulement agreed in Union law and the Geneva Convention. Both projects carry the fission fungus deep into the EU and jeopardise peace in Europe.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒As part of the common asylum policy article 78(3) of the EIA, The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU (TFEU) provides for a specific legal basis for dealing with crisis situations. Accordingly, on the basis of a proposal from the European Commission and after consulting the European Parliament, the Council may adopt interim measures for the benefit of one or more Member States facing a crisis situation due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals to one or more Member States. Under Article 78(3) of the TFEU, the Council adopted two decisions on the imposition of interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. I support the Report on the Proposal for a Council Decision amending the Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 on the imposition of interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and the Greek Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision amending the Council Decision of 22 September 2015 imposing temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece.  The amendment provides for the transfer of 54000 applicants from Italy and Greece as transfer of an applicant from the territory of the Member State responsible for examining his application for international protection to the territory of the Member State of relocation. Relocation shall not include the relocation or the transfer of persons from a third country in need of international protection to the territory of a Member State.  It is also proposed to change that regular review of the situation of the mass influx of third-country nationals into the Member States is not a task of the European Commission, but should be the task of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support today's report on asylum and temporary measures in favour of Italy and Greece, as I believe that the European Commission's initial proposal proposing the possibility of voluntary resettlement of migrants, a specific number of which could then be deducted from the quotas already approved by a particular Member State, was a sufficient response to the situation where Hungary waived the possibility of relocating a certain number of migrants from its territory to the territory of the other Member States. The issue of the further development of European resettlement mechanisms and other elements of the current migration crisis should be addressed separately.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it sends a clear political signal to the need to support Greece and Italy by speeding up, inter alia, a fair system for the relocation of refugees. The report also expresses a clear opposition to the EU-Turkey Agreement, which is not in line with international law on refugees and asylum but is a culmination of the EU's policy of cynicism and analgesia towards the victims of a war, for which it itself bears many responsibilities.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report seeks to impose the violent integration of different ethnicities and cultures.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the decision, ingesting the conviction that both European solidarity and the experience of EU cooperation on migration so far justifies the urgent and urgent support of the Member States that have taken on the primary burdens of the refugee crisis, including, where appropriate, the Italian and Greek governments. At the same time, I am aware that this can be seen as symptomatic treatment, that tackling the migration crisis requires more multifaceted measures and measures that assume the full unity of the EU. As a Hungarian MEMBER on this subject, I can only regret that my country, as a potential beneficiary, is missing out on joint burden-sharing, because the EU, as a community and as an institution, still seems powerless to the fact that the governments of some Member States still do not wish to be part of any EU solidarity in asylum, and even seek to undermine it, and the Orban government is at the forefront of this.  Without denying the importance of the decision now adopted as a positive gesture, and looking to the future, I must warn that it will deter much from the strength and effectiveness of our common solidarity with those who bear the main burden if the EU continues to prove powerless against such behaviour by some of its own Member States.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The phenomenon of migration affecting the European Union in recent years has demonstrated the need to develop a unified approach to asylum policy at European level. Since most refugees come from conflict zones in Syria and Iraq, their status as asylum seekers is not in question. However, the main problem is the pressure placed on the southern border countries, such as Greece and Italy, which cannot manage the large number of refugees on their own. In this context, the European Commission reacted and came up with the proposal to divide refugees in the Member States according to quotas set according to the capacity of each country. Some Member States did not agree with these quotas, resulting in the crowding of refugees in the camps in Greece and Italy, which creates problems for those States. That attitude is contrary to the spirit of solidarity that underpins the European Union and jeopardises the very viability of the European project in the coming period. In these circumstances, the European Parliament is the most appropriate forum to draw attention to the fact that the refugee problem must be resolved through cooperation between Member States and that no State can scan these obligations using nationalist-populist third-party types.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague Ska Keller's excellent text on the Council's proposal for a decision amending the Council's decision (EU) 2015/1601, establishing interim measures on international protection for Italy and Greece.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Heads of State and Government agreed on 7 March 2016 a series of principles as the basis for an agreement with Turkey – including to resettle, for every Syrian readmitted by Turkey from Greek islands, another Syrian from Turkey to the EU Member States, within the framework of the existing commitments. While I support the deal with Turkey, I voted against the Keller report. Indeed, this report opposed the Commission proposal according to which, out of 120 000 places for applicants to be relocated from Italy and Greece to other Member States, 54 000 shall now be allocated to the relocation of Syrians in the EU, from Turkey in accordance with the EU-Turkey agreement. The Commission proposal enables Member States to subtract from their allocated number of relocated applicants the number of Syrians present in Turkey admitted to their territory through resettlement.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the Report on the Council's proposal for a decision on the imposition of interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. As I have already pointed out, I believe that we cannot only deal with the redistribution of migrants. This report calls on Member States to take in migrants and to step up efforts to respond to the humanitarian situation in Greece and prevent further deterioration of the situation in Italy.  However, the practice of reception and redistribution has already proved ineffective, so I believe that it is necessary, first of all, to address the problem in the area where it arises and not to impose additional pressure on Member States.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Asylum proposal: I supported the temporary measures in favour of Italy and Greece.  As of 26 September 2016, 54 000 asylum seekers were to be relocated from Italy and Greece to the territories of other Member States in the proportion set out in this Decision (namely 12 764 applicants from Italy and 41 236 applicants from Greece), unless by that date the Commission proposes, in accordance with Article 4(3), to allocate these transfers to other beneficiary Member States faced with an emergency due to the sudden influx of persons.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ The situation regarding massive inflows remains critical. Already in the first months of 2016 thousands of people were entering Greece from Turkey daily. It should be stressed that the refugee crisis is a European problem and therefore requires efforts from all Member States. Solidarity with Member States who experience the highest pressure is necessary. This decision should provide some relief to Greece and Italy.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report opposing the EU-Turkey Agreement and the readmission scheme proposed by the Commission in the context of its human rights-infringing migration policy. We share the criticism of the Member States for their petty behaviour in welcoming people in need of international protection on their territory and for the need to act in co-responsibility with Greece and Italy in dealing with sufficient resources and in solidarity with the greatest humanitarian crisis in Europe since World War II.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The Council Decisions of 14 and 22 September 2015 on the relocation of a total of 160,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other countries are now intended to amend an existing and subsequent Council Decision of 26 September 2015, which regulates the implementation of the relocation. The existing EU-Turkey agreement will be taken into account. In principle, such an approach makes sense. However, the report calls for unsustainable changes. In this way, the momentum of solidarity and fair sharing of burdens is emphasised much more strongly than in the original draft. The principle of non-refoulement of refugees is therefore not in place with the existing EU-Turkey agreement. It also calls for better opportunities for migrants to enter the EU safely and for increased family reunification. Resettlement and relocation should be promoted as a sign of solidarity. Asylum seekers are to be accepted mainly from Syria, Iraq, Eritrea and Afghanistan. Monthly status reports of the Member States are to be omitted. Overall, the report expresses the desire to take in more asylum seekers and migrants in Europe. The rapporteur of the Greens is thus completely ignoring the problems of crime, terrorism and integration associated with the current asylum and migration crisis, as well as the broad will of the citizens in Europe. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to use 54,000 of the 120,000 places in the relocation plan agreed by EU representatives in September 2015 to resettle Syrians from Turkey in the EU, in line with the EU-Turkey migration agreement. According to the resolution, "refugee resettlement should not be at the expense of relocation" because while resettlement is a form of 'internal solidarity', resettlement is a process of 'external solidarity' where third countries are home to the majority of refugees. The text stresses that so far only a very small number of Syrian refugees have been relocated to the EU. It recalls the European Parliament's resolution of 12 April 2016 in which it called for more safe and lawful routes in the Union for asylum seekers and refugees, including the adoption by the EU of a binding and mandatory resettlement law, the establishment of humanitarian admission programmes by all Member States and the wider use of humanitarian visas. I reject the policy of distributing migrants, which has proved to be a scathing failure.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the vote on the resolution, I voted against the document. As a general rule, the provision of humanitarian aid and shelter to those leaving their countries due to the dire situation in Syria should be a clear duty of all Member States, but the solutions proposed in the draft may not produce the expected results. The reallocation programme is underdeveloped, so the obligation for all EU countries to implement it may jeopardise the security of citizens.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 As part of the Common Asylum Policy, the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union allows the Council, on a proposal from the European Commission, to adopt transitional measures in the interest of the Member State or Member States concerned, after consulting the European Parliament, if one or more Member States are faced with an emergency situation characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals. In the final vote on the report, I followed S&D's position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of a report which opposes the EU-Turkey Agreement and the readmission scheme proposed by the Commission in the context of its human rights-infringing migration policy. We share the criticism of the Member States for their petty behaviour in welcoming people in need of international protection on their territory and for the need to act in co-responsibility with Greece and Italy in dealing with sufficient resources and in solidarity with the greatest humanitarian crisis in Europe since World War II.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the EU system (highly costly and scarcely effective) to enforce the return of irregular migrants seems not to be sustainable in the long term. For instance, in 2014 less than 40% of the total number of return decisions issued by Member States have been enforced. However, the establishment of a dedicated EU travel document for irregular migrants for the purpose of removal will not ensure an automatic increase in the effectiveness of returns and no impact assessment was carried out by the European Commission in the context of this proposed regulation to prove otherwise.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – Given the current number of asylum seekers in Greece and the increasing number of asylum seekers arriving in Italy, I believe that there will be a strong need for urgent resettlement places.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. The report states that EU countries must honour their pledges to accept refugees relocated from Greece and Italy to relieve migratory pressure on these two ‘frontline’ countries. Furthermore, it underlines that the need for emergency relocation from Greece and Italy to other EU Member States is expected to remain high, pointing to the urgent humanitarian situation in Greece and the risk of deterioration in Italy. I voted in favour because I believe that these measures would, at the same time, discourage irregular entries by opening up legal and safe routes to the EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The purpose of this proposal is to improve the 2015/1601 European Council Decision to relocate persons in need of international protection from Italy and Greece. Within the framework of existing commitments that are part of EU-Turkey cooperation in the area of migration, the proposal responds to the need for further action for resettlement in Turkey. The 54,000 seats scheduled for the re-stay will be available for the relocation of Syrian citizens from Turkey to the EU through scheme 1-1. Under this amendment, Member States can implement their commitments by admitting Syrian citizens to their territories directly from Turkey. The number of resealed Syrians will be deducted from the resettlement quotas set and each of the countries using this route will receive EUR 6,500. Given the increased efficiency of the process involved in these measures, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'This report contains the EP's amendments to the Commission's proposal for a decision on the refugees/migrants/asylum seekers now being taken in Italy and Greece. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the untenable situation in both countries in terms of reception must be urgently needed.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation remains critical. According to data provided by Frontex, during the first months of 2016, on average, 2000 to 3000 people entered Greece irregularly each day from Turkey. Restrictions on the border between Greece and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have increased pressure on Greece and increased the risk of developing new migration routes through other EU Member States as weather conditions improve. These new migratory routes are likely to affect frontline Member States. It should be remembered that this crisis was generated by European and Us imperialism, which should give rise to widespread EU mobilisation. On the contrary, this crisis has revealed the inesmanity of this EU that declares itself solidarity, but only with large multinational companies and the military industrial complex, which continues to generate billions of profits. Shame on you.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This report is just another step in taking the wrong path on the refugee issue. A redistribution of 40,000 and a further 120,000 people from Greece and Italy to the other Member States does not change the situation at all. It also aims to create further safe and legal routes for entry into the EU and to increase the issuing of humanitarian visas. Everyone should also have a right to family reunification, which would increase the immense numbers in Europe even more. I therefore reject the report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision establishing temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece in relation to the migrant emergency. The text aims to ensure compliance with Council decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601 aimed at alleviating migratory pressure on Italy and Greece by applying a relocation of asylum seekers to other Member States. So far, only 7% of the available posts have been made available by the Member States, and this report aims to encourage them to implement their obligations under the Council, increasing their efforts to respond as quickly as possible to this humanitarian crisis.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report, which signals another call on Member States to uphold their responsibility and show solidarity by taking part in relocation and resettlement measures. Countries on the periphery, such as Greece and Italy, are still struggling to respond to the thousands of refugees and asylum-seekers who continue to arrive in Europe. We believe that resettlement should not take place at the expense of relocation. Both are important instruments of solidarity. Relocation is a form of internal solidarity among Member States, while resettlement and humanitarian admission or other kinds of admission are forms of external solidarity with third countries hosting the majority of refugees.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Last year, at the height of the refugee crisis, the Council decided to relocate 160,000 refugees from Greece and Italy to other Member States. Although the decision was challenged by the Eastern European Member States, a clear majority was in favour of such a relocation. Through this Commission proposal, the Council is planning to set aside one third of the total number of refugees to be relocated (54,000) for the implementation of the EU-Turkey agreement: for every Syrian refugee turkey re-accepts from the Greek islands, another Syrian will be resettled by Turkey in other EU Member States. In negotiating the agreement, member states failed to agree to make additional places available for refugees from Turkey, which is why they now plan to use the 54,000 places originally earmarked for the resettlement of refugees from Greece and Italy to resettle Syrian refugees directly from Turkey. However, the Member States are not meeting their relocation commitments: some have not so far taken in any refugees, others, only a handful of people; there is greater solidarity and respect for the commitments made.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The amendments to the EU Council decision on the relocation of refugees, which bears the falsified title "temporary measures for the benefit of Greece and Italy", will not provide the slightest relief to the problem of stranded refugees in Greece and Italy and the miserable conditions they face. Because it is directly linked to the unacceptable EU-Turkey agreement and the mass deportations of refugees, to the EU's barbaric measures against refugees and migrants (deportation travel document, return of asylum seekers back to "gateways" countries such as Greece and Italy, European Border Guard-Coast Guard). The intensity of the imperialist aggression of the EU and its allies, its brutal repressive policy towards refugees, increases daily the number of thousands trapped in Greece under unacceptable conditions, indicative of the miserable situation with the double entrapment of refugees, e.g. Lesvos, Chios, as well as the dangers of new long-dead tragedies. The inhumanity of the EU and the racism of fascist gangs are aspects of the barbaric capitalist system, which they both serve. This must be targeted in the struggle of workers, together with the demand for humane conditions for the reception and reception of refugees and migrants, the rapid granting of refugee or humanitarian status and their immediate transfer to their final destination countries.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ The proposal for a Council Decision on the introduction of temporary measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece was aimed at amending the 2015 Decision, according to which 54 000 asylum seekers were to be relocated from Greece and Italy under the quota system to other Member States. The amendment was proposed in the context of the Agreement concluded with Turkey in March 2016 and was to take into account member states' efforts to receive persons from Turkish territory under that agreement. Member States could thus deduct refugees admitted directly from Turkey under the 1:1 system from mandatory quotas as a result of this change. However, Mrs Keller's report completely reversed these efforts and rejected the possibility of deducting the number of persons admitted from Turkey from the quotas set by the Member State altogether. As in all the other votes concerning the system of compulsory quotas for Member States, I voted against the report as a whole in this one. My view that Member States should not be forced into a kind of compulsory solidarity remains unchanged and, in my opinion, Member States should rather be encouraged to show solidarity voluntarily and offer assistance in order to deal with the refugee crisis.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé arís ina fhabhar seo le mo ghrúpa sna trí vótaí sa tuarascáil seo agus glacadh leis le móramh mór. So, this report deals with the appraisal of economic and social policies within the European Union and I would hope, as this report highlights, that the role and opinion of Parliament will be better considered by the Council as we move forward. This is a very important point. We find ourselves at a critical stage, where the spirit of cooperation between European institutions should not be called into question, nor should it act as an obstacle to the development of more effective policies at Member State level. Staying in line with the Stability and Growth Pact and remaining responsive to economic change, we may together – and together is the key word – promote the development and accommodation of a more skilled and adaptable workforce, providing for sustainable and inclusive growth across all Member States.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The approach adopted by the Council with regard to Member States' employment policies is not properly appropriate. It has proved to be contrary to the spirit of the Treaties, implying a weakening of interinstitutional cooperation and an increase in the democratic deficit with regard to the citizens of the Union. Since I strongly believe that the Council must take account of Parliament's position, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this consultation procedure proposal, which is technically non-legislative. It is written into the treaties (TFEU Article 148) that the EU should coordinate employment policy between all Member States and this is a procedure that is voted on every year. The proposal creates vague goals without specific actions as to what the Member States should be focusing on. This proposal includes things like ‘increasing labour participation and reducing structural employment’ and ‘develop a skilled workforce’. This all sounds OK, but ultimately it is the EU trying to control Member States and tell them what their employment policies should be. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This report included several good aspects such as calling for public investment, job creation, and support for workers’ rights. However, it calls for all of this within the confines of the European Stability and Growth pact as well as the European Semester. These two things are almost diametrically opposed – you cannot have a decent level of investment etc. while you are in a fiscal straight jacket. Because of the positive aspects around workers’ rights etc. I did not vote against this report, but I could not support it either, given the confines in which it wishes to place investment and job creation, i.e. the Stability and Growth Pact and European Semester. For these reasons I abstained on the overall report.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I very much regret that the Council and the Commission remain deaf to our contributions on the guidelines on employment policies in the Member States. We call on the European Commission to amend its proposal accordingly and the Council to take into account our proposals in order to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market, capable of dealing with the serious consequences of unemployment, promoting a high level of employment and ensuring decent working conditions, including a minimum income and decent social protection.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States. The report express the regrets of the European Parliament with regard to the decision of the Council to ignore the EP legislative resolution of 8 July 2015 and stresses that the European Parliament position must be taken into consideration. At present 120 million Union citizens, namely around a quarter of the total of the Union population, are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. I believe that the European Union is in need of holistic policies and public investments that will fight against unemployment and poverty. The number of people at risk of poverty and exclusion has increased by five million, the employment rate in some countries has not yet recovered the pre-crisis level, while in some Member States the rate of young people who are not in employment, education or training (NEETs) is above 20 per cent and the rate of early school leavers is up to 23 per cent. I support the Guidelines that shall be taken into account by the Member States in their employment policies and reform programmes.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Employment policy guidelines coordinate employment policies of EU Member States.  On the Commission's recommendation, the Council maintains the guidelines as of 2015 for 2016. The Council insists on the use of the European Social Fund for employment policies. The European Parliament approves the joint proposal by the Commission and the Council to maintain the employment guidelines for 2016. The employment guidelines were initiated in 1998. Successive editions all have identical objectives, but to no avail. Youth unemployment is an eloquent example. In 2003 and 2008, the goal was to obtain employment or training four to six months after entering the labour market. The Youth Employment Initiative, launched in 2013, follows the same principle. In 2016, youth unemployment in Europe hovered around 20%, reaching 50% in some Member States. I therefore spoke out against this "powder in the eyes" report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that national employment policies should be coordinated by the European Union, and therefore I voted against this resolution on principle.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States. Article 145 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) provides that the Member States and the Union shall act with a view to developing a coordinated strategy for employment in order to achieve the objectives of the Treaty on European Union. The five main objectives constitute the common objectives on which member states are based and take into account the different starting positions of the Member States and the national circumstances and the positions and circumstances of the Union. I agree with the analysis of the Member States' National Reform Programmes in the Joint Employment Report, which shows that Member States should continue to make every effort in priority areas such as increasing labour market participation, reducing structural unemployment, developing a skilled workforce adapted to labour market needs, promoting good quality of work and lifelong learning, improving the functioning of education and training systems at all levels, and increasing participation in higher education systems , foster social inclusion and combat poverty.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this report, which highlights the conclusions of the Court of Auditors, namely that almost all workers eligible for the EGF were able to benefit from personalised and well-coordinated measures tailored to their individual needs, and that almost 50% of workers who received assistance under the WEF have now found employment. Faced with the social damage caused by deregulated capitalism, the EGF is a necessary tool that has helped thousands of laid-off workers. But, as the scandalous closure of Caterpillar has shown, we must take swift steps upstream to avoid these social and human tragedies. Europe must severely penalise companies that make stock market layoffs. It must take strict measures to end tax avoidance and the role of tax havens. Finally, it must redevelop an industrial policy based on activities rich in innovation and research and development that are not easily relocated. This must, of course, be accompanied by a revival of public investment and therefore demand within the Union.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's legislative resolution on additions to the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. Unfortunately, the Council ignored Parliament in its adoption, ignoring some essential aspects of improving labour market conditions, such as improving training opportunities and comparability of qualifications in accordance with the EQF.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Agea report on guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The outbreak of the economic crisis and the persistence of its negative effects on growth and employment, as amply demonstrated by all the indicators of the 2020 Strategy, strongly requires the development of a genuine inclusive and integrated labour market that is supported by a coordinated and incisive social and employment policy. The Member States, in cooperation with local and regional authorities, must tackle the very serious problem of unemployment in a timely manner, facilitating investment in the creation of sustainable and quality jobs, with a particular focus on the green, white and blue sector and the social economy. Social innovation, the reduction of bureaucratic burdens and a new work-life balance for workers are all fundamental aspects which must be linked to the introduction of common instruments in terms of worker participation, information and consultation. Overcoming the crisis is possible, but only if the Union responds jointly to all the problems it has created.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report because we consider it a matter of priority that the content of the report be taken into account in a binding manner by the Council and not as an appendix without any effect. We consider the content of the report to be extremely positive and most of the recommendations are positive, but we find that special emphasis is placed on promoting entrepreneurship in detail with recommendations on how to alleviate long-term unemployment and ensure quality work. Since we do not oppose a part of the report and cannot vote separately on the committee's amendments, we voted abstention

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This vote relates to the draft report on the Council's proposed decision on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. This annual report is based on country-by-country analyses provided to the Commission by member states and Parliament issues only a simple advisory opinion. Horizon 2020 has five objectives in three themes: sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth. The most recent employment guidelines are: boosting demand for employment (5), improving job supply, skills and skills (6), improving the functioning of the labour market (7) and promoting social inclusion, combating poverty and promoting equal opportunities (8). These 1998 guidelines have always advocated identical objectives without concrete results. Youth unemployment is the most glaring example, with 20% of young Europeans unemployed and even more than 50% in Greece, Spain or the Ultramarine regions of France. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the objectives of the report are acceptable, for example the fight against unemployment and the promotion of entrepreneurship, I am not convinced by the 'Employment Policy Guidelines' which, moving in the failed direction of 'more Europe', do not lead to any concrete results for our citizens, businesses and territories. For these reasons, I preferred to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution in which Parliament denounces the lack of attention paid by the Council in October last year to its proposals, adopting guidelines which completely ignored any of the Recommendations made by Parliament a few times earlier, an approach contrary to the spirit of the Treaties and which weakens cooperation between the institutions of the Union. Parliament expresses its concern about the achievement of the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, in particular with regard to employment and social protection objectives, as well as educational objectives, with particular attention to the growing divergences between different countries. In addition, and thanks to the contributions of the S&D group, the resolution stresses the need to introduce the social dimension, at the same level as the financial and fiscal dimension, into the European Semester process in order to improve the results of macroeconomic policies in the social sphere.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it called on the Commission and the Council to respect the treaties and the principle of good cooperation and to take due account of Parliament's position on guidelines for national employment policies. Unfortunately, today, six years after the launch of the Europe 2020 strategy, we can say that we have not achieved the objectives of the strategy and that the current development is of great concern. Instead of reducing the number of people at risk of poverty and exclusion, instead of falling by 20 million, as we expected, the employment rate has not yet risen to pre-crisis levels in some countries, and in some Member States the proportion of young people who do not work, learn and not receive training (NEETs) is more than 20%, while the proportion of early school leavers is 23%. Not to mention the increased number of children living in poverty, which in the long term paints an equally bleak picture. I therefore call on the Commission to come together with the Council and work together to ensure that people in Europe have quality work and that neither they nor their children will be threatened by poverty.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this Report on Member States' employment policy guidelines and believe that the Commission must change its proposal in line with the Report and take the amended Guidelines into account to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market with opportunities to address the serious impact of unemployment, ensure a high level of employment and ensure decent working conditions, including national minimum basic income and social protection schemes.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report merely repeats previous reports on the subject, all of which have failed, and for good reason, since they do not address the root of the evil of employment in Europe, namely the opening of economic borders to all winds, which puts our companies and employees in competition with those of the poorest countries of the world. I voted against it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Policies to ensure that wages represent an adequate subsistence income remain important for creating jobs and reducing poverty in the Union. Therefore, Member States, in consultation with the social partners, should respect and encourage wage-setting mechanisms that allow real wages to be adjusted to productivity trends and help to correct previous divergences without fuelling deflationary pressures: these mechanisms should ensure sufficient resources to meet basic needs, taking into account poverty indicators specific to each Member State.  In this respect, differences in the skills and conditions of local labour markets should be properly assessed in order to guarantee a decent living throughout the Union. In setting minimum wages in accordance with national legislation and practices, Member States and the social partners should ensure their adequacy and take into account the impact on worker poverty, household income, aggregate demand, job creation and competitiveness. A Europe that is more attentive to the wage situation of its workers is a fairer, more humane, more supportive and safer Europe.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In designing and implementing its policies and activities, the Union must ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market capable of coping with the serious effects of unemployment and guaranteeing a high level of employment. The EU needs holistic policies and public investment to combat unemployment and poverty. The number of people at risk of poverty and exclusion has increased by five million, the employment rate in some countries has not yet reached the level before the crisis, and in some Member States, the percentage of young people who do not work or follow any education or training programme exceeds 20%, while the drop-out rate reaches 23%. The implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy in the field of social and employment must remain a key objective of the employment policy of the Member States. I voted in favour of this report because we need a number of guidelines to provide guidance to Member States on the definition of their national reform programmes and on the implementation of reforms.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the guidelines for Member States' employment policies are crucial to the effective integrated implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. While in some countries the employment rate has not yet returned to pre-crisis levels and the proportion of young people who do not study, do not work and do not follow training courses (so-called NEETs) is more than 20 %. Member States should continue to make every effort to address in practice the priority issues of reducing structural unemployment, developing a competent workforce and promoting the quality of work and lifelong learning. It is also necessary to improve the performance of education and training systems at all levels and, at the same time, to increase participation in tertiary education in order to promote social inclusion and combat poverty.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report included several good aspects such as calling for public investment, job creation, and support for workers’ rights. However, it calls for all of this within the confines of the European Stability and Growth pact as well as the European Semester. These two things are almost diametrically opposed – you cannot have a decent level of investment etc. while you are in a fiscal straight jacket. Because of the positive aspects around workers’ rights etc. I did not vote against this report, but I could not support it either, given the confines in which it wishes to place investment and job creation, i.e. the Stability and Growth Pact and European Semester. For these reasons I abstained on the overall report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the European Parliament’s suggestions provide added value to the Member States’ current employment policies in order to help address the many challenges we are facing in this area. The economic recovery in the Union is still very fragile and employment rates although improving are still low. Substantial disparities exist between regions and Member States. This is still a matter of urgency. Europe has a number of tools at its disposal to achieve this, the Europe 2020 Strategy essentially, and the implementation of the Investment Plan for Europe (EFSI). On both counts we need to look carefully at improving its implementation and monitoring in order to ensure smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. It is encouraging to note that three new employment indicators have been added to the main scoreboard.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Our colleague Laura Agea, who also dealt with the same dossier last year, after seeing that the Council not only totally ignored the position expressed by Parliament in 2015, but also decided to ignore what she will say in the 2016 report, she decided to resubmit last year's guidelines as a whole, but also introduced a paragraph of heavy criticism to the EU Council , whose approach has proved 'contrary to the spirit of the Treaties' by 'weakening cooperation between the Union's institutions and increasing the 'democratic deficit' towards the citizens of the Union'. The European Parliament, with this report, therefore strongly deplores the Council's approach and stresses the need to take account of Parliament's position. I voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of the Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies, which confirms what the Council agreed on 5 October 2015. I believe that the Union's employment policies must ensure the creation of an integrated and inclusive labour market that ensures decent working conditions and adequate wages. In particular, I believe it is essential to stimulate the creation of quality jobs by reducing the administrative burden on small and medium-sized enterprises they wish to employ, and to encourage youth entrepreneurship. I welcome the fact that the draft decision considers the fight against youth unemployment and long-term unemployment to be a priority issue on which to guide future European policies. Further efforts must be made to reduce discrimination in access to the labour market for vulnerable groups such as women, young people, older workers or the disabled. I also believe that the Member States must make a greater effort to combat precarious work and uncieving work. In conclusion, I voted in favour of the decision because it indicates as a guideline for employment policies the need to improve the quality and accessibility of member states' education systems.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and consider that the examination of the Member States' national reform programmes contained in the joint employment report shows that Member States must continue to make every effort in the priority areas: increasing labour market participation and reducing structural unemployment, developing a skilled workforce that meets the needs of the labour market , promoting the quality of jobs and lifelong learning, improving the performance of education and training systems at all levels and increasing participation in higher education, promoting social inclusion and combating poverty.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the guidelines for member states' employment policies. This issue is at the heart of the problems facing Europe at this time, which has been particularly reinforced by the economic and political crisis in recent years. Although the report has some positive elements highlighting issues of concern to workers, it also focuses on conservative approaches, which I find to be contrary. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the guidelines for employment policies in the Member States because I believe it is right to master common guidelines on reducing unemployment rates for years preceded only by creepy more. Employment is one of the objectives of Europe 2020 and, with this in mind, it is essential to coordinate and promote strategies to boost labour demand and strengthen its supply by shaping skilled, qualified and resilient workers. The integrated guidelines, which I support, provide for a system that meets businesses and their needs through a reduction in bureaucracy (in Italy it is an endemic and pachydermal problem, which urgently needs to be brought to an end) and the tax burden, but which must be accompanied by an investment programme compatible with the specific recommendations made by the Council to each State. Indeed, in order to reduce and cancel the 120 million Europeans at risk of poverty and social exclusion, measures are needed to train a workforce adapted to changing market demands and an appropriate social protection policy. The availability of the European Social Fund must therefore be reaffirmed and that of the European Fund for Strategic Investments must be activated.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States and I noted no objections.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this consultation procedure vote, which is technically non-legislative. It is written in to the treaties (TFEU Article 148) that the EU should coordinate employment policy between all Member States and this is a procedure that is voted on every year. The proposal creates vague goals without specific actions as to what the Member States should be focussing on. This proposal includes things like ‘increasing labour participation and reducing structural employment’ and ‘develop a skilled workforce’. This all sounds ok, but ultimately it is the EU trying to control Member States and tell them what their employment policies should be. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report so that the general objectives and priorities for employment, as defined by Parliament last year, are also assessed by the Council. The Council should adopt a position on this issue, confirming by a decision the validity of the guidelines for employment policies as the European Parliament has already adopted. This issue is also of great importance because of its economic and social implications, and I therefore believe that it is necessary for the Council to take a decision on this matter.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I support the development of holistic policies, as well as public investment, to address unemployment and poverty, to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market, and to secure a high level of employment. We need to ensure decent working conditions across the Union, including adequate wages; and to guarantee adequate social protection in accordance with labour regulations and collective bargaining and in line with the principle of subsidiarity, as well as a high level of education and training; and we need to combat discrimination on the basis of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. We should push Member States to take action in key areas to ease the burden on small and medium-sized enterprises. Through better access to the labour market we can facilitate entrepreneurship and sustainable job creation in all sectors, including green employment, as well as the provision of social care. More importance should be given to innovation. We need to invest further in skills and make the best use of people’s skills, so as to foster lifelong development and encourage employee-driven innovation.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. In this case, I have spoken in favour of the amendments made in the Committee on Employment to the EU proposal because, despite its shortcomings, it at least broadens the focus on passive employment policies and macroeconomic policies to combat current mass unemployment.  The Commission's proposal, which has had my no vote, is nothing more than a battering ram to reduce social benefits and pensions and to blame workers for their unemployment; serious enough that he would not vote in favour of the final resolution.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal takes no account of the resolution we adopted in Parliament last 2015. This is an unholy choice, and that is why I strongly support the EMPL Committee's decision to express disappointment and regret by retabling amendments in line with our resolution that reaffirm the need for a strong social dimension in economic and employment policies, in order to give concrete form to the challenges and objectives of Europe 2020 and to contribute to the achievement of an inclusive labour market. , capable of generating sustainable employment and decent working conditions. By ignoring our position, the European Commission is not only breaking with the spirit and the letter of the Treaties, but is falling behind positions which, in today's world of work, are absolutely outdated and equally incapable of building answers, particularly to the many young people who are beginning to no longer believe that stable and dignified work can be aspired to in this Europe. We are calling for better social protection and active employment policies, which obviously require adequate investment: all these things have so far been lacking and which have led to the dramatic socio-economic situation we are experiencing and the consequences that, if we do not change, will soon overwhelm us.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union requires the Member States and the Union to develop a coordinated employment strategy and, in particular, to promote a trained, skilled and adaptable workforce and labour markets capable of reacting rapidly to the evolution of the economy. The Europe 2020 strategy proposed by the Commission allows the European Union to direct its economy towards smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, accompanied by a high level of employment, productivity and social cohesion. Today, almost 120 million citizens of the Union, a quarter of its total population, are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. I voted for the immediate encouragement of the Member States to create new national systems that lead to decent living conditions. Member States, in cooperation with local and regional authorities, should effectively and promptly address the serious problem of unemployment, facilitate and invest in the creation of sustainable and quality jobs.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Employment policies must reflect the current realities and tackle the current challenges by taking into consideration the Europe 2020 targets. We need to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market which is able to address unemployment and induce sustainable employment. I believe that the European Union needs to ensure decent working conditions and social protection. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the European Parliament contribution to the guidelines for employment policies of the Member States is important.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that Member States, in cooperation with local and regional authorities, must find solutions to the serious problem of unemployment, facilitate and invest in the creation of sustainable and quality jobs, address the problem of accessibility for the most vulnerable groups by promoting entrepreneurship among young people by supporting the establishment and development of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, in order to increase the employment rate of women and men.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this report to confirm, for 2016, the guidelines for Member States' employment policies adopted in 2015. It is particularly important that the European institutions encourage Member States to ensure quality education and training systems as a priority in order to promote access to employment throughout life and to promote social inclusion for all.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Employment policy guidelines coordinate employment policies of EU member states. They are part of the 'Europe 2020' strategy of 3 March 2010, which sets out the EU's economic guidelines. The Council relies on the Commission's annual report to update the employment guidelines annually. On the Commission's recommendation, the Council wishes to maintain the guidelines as of 2015 for 2016. However, these employment guidelines were initiated in 1998. Successive editions all advocate the same objectives but with no concrete results. Youth unemployment is an eloquent example. In 2003 and 2008, the goal was to obtain employment or training four to six months after entering the labour market. The Youth Employment Initiative, launched in 2013, follows the same principle. In 2016, youth unemployment in Europe hovered around 20%, reaching 50% in some Member States (Greece, Spain). I also voted against this text, insofar as it does not seek to address the real causes of mass unemployment.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support this report because I believe that the intervention here of the European Parliament is irrelevant. The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides that Member States should consider their economic policies as well as employment policies as issues of common interest and coordinate within the EU.  However, there is a request here to open a guidance chapter in the field of these policies, which has already been approved by the Member States and I cannot agree with that.  It is not parliament that should encourage Member States to take into account new employment policy guidelines, provided there is already consensus in the field.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Our work priorities are quite different, and we believe that jobs must first be secured for those who are already looking for them.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The proposal for the Council Decision aims to promote demand for labour, improve supply and work skills, as well as the functioning of labour markets. It also aims to improve the quality and performance of education and training systems at all levels, as well as to ensure social justice. These guidelines are therefore in line with Europe 2020's main objectives, which are, inter facilities, to raise the employment rate of women and men from 20 to 64 years to 75% by 2020; reduce the dropout rate to less than 10%; increase the proportion of people aged 30 to 34 who complete higher education or equivalent to at least 40%; promote social inclusion, in particular by reducing poverty.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported Mrs Agea's report, which repeats the same recommendations as in last year's report: social protections, employment policies with public investment to restart the economy, assistance, minimum income policies that guarantee support for poor families, minimum wage. Recommendations that have been completely ignored by the Council, completely disregarding the objectives of the 2020 poverty reduction strategy and achieving a significant deterioration in employment and poverty. The European Parliament, with this report, therefore strongly deplores the Council's approach and stresses the need to take account of the position of Parliament, the only body democratically and directly elected by the citizens of Europe.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States, in cooperation with regional and local authorities, should effectively and swiftly address the serious problem of unemployment, facilitate and invest in creating quality and sustainable jobs, address the issue of accessibility for groups exposed to risks, reduce barriers preventing companies from hiring people in the various levels of skills and sectors of the labour market , in particular by reducing bureaucracy, while respecting labour and social standards, promoting young entrepreneurship and, in particular, promoting the creation and growth of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises in order to increase the employment rate of men and women. For all this, I agree with the amendments recommended on this matter.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: the employment guidelines were initiated in 1998. Successive editions all advocate the same objectives but with no concrete results.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against this report because I believe that the employment policy guidelines are mainly reserved for the competence of the Member States. Therefore, I do not think it would be useful to reopen the debate on competence in the field of employment, as an agreement had already been reached between the Member States.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ The report mentions public investments for job-creation, and supports workers ‘rights in many aspects. But it also strongly supports the European stability and growth pact, and suggests, that all employment reforms should be made of the European Semester and the country specific recommendations framework. I abstained.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU stipulates that Member States consider their economic policies and employment promotion to be issues of common interest and coordinate them within the Council. However, this year's EC proposal seeks to maintain the same resolutions adopted by the Council back in 2015, taking no account of the Position of the European Parliament and not taking into account its resolution of 8 July 2015, which focuses on the strong social dimension of economic and employment policies, which should include Member States' policies to take account of the challenges and objectives of EUROPA 2020.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining although the objectives set out in the report are partly acceptable, but I can only criticise the European Semester for its poor functioning.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the guidelines of the Employment Policies of the Member States, because my priorities for work are completely different;

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I find the Council’s and Commission’s ignorance of the EP contribution to the guidelines for employment policies of Member States most regrettable and I support the call on the Commission to alter its proposal accordingly and on the Council to take the amended guidelines into account, in order to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market able to address the severe impact of unemployment, secure a high level of employment, and ensure decent working conditions, including national minimum basic income schemes and social protection. I believe we made a very valuable contribution both last year and this year, so far, ensuring that our objectives in employment and social policies are strongly reflected, and I therefore believe that our position must be taken into account, as the Council’s and Commission’s ignorance is against the spirit of the Treaties and the spirit of good cooperation between the EU institutions.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament reiterates its position in support of stronger action by Member States for a coordinated and incisive employment and social policy. Ordinary measures are no longer enough, employment and social targets must be integrated into macro-economic procedures in a concrete and ambitious way and European action must be consistent in all legal, economic and social sectors. I would particularly like to stress the need to include adequate forms of protection against the phenomena of social dumping, following the recent events in Europe between companies and workers. I also think it is very important for Europe to recognise the positive effects on employment and growth that can come from the introduction of new common instruments for participation, consultation and information for workers.  In the coming weeks, Parliament will be busy examining a number of proposals for corporate law reform, so it will be important to give a boost to quality employment there too.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the 'Report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies', as it attacks the sovereignty of Member States on social issues on far too many points and disregards subsidiarity.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The European labour market must face up to a reduction in red tape at all levels, in particular to relieve SMEs. In creating new jobs, we must not tolerate infiltrating existing labour and social standards.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report because we consider it a matter of priority that the content of the report be taken into account in a binding manner by the Council and not as an appendix without any effect. We consider the content of the report to be extremely positive and most of the recommendations are positive, but we find that special emphasis is placed on promoting entrepreneurship in detail with recommendations on how to alleviate long-term unemployment and ensure quality work. Since we do not oppose a part of the report and cannot vote separately on the committee's amendments, we vote on abstention.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a report which encourages Member States to adopt concrete employment policies aiming at ensuring an inclusive and integrated labour market and at addressing the severe impact of unemployment, to create sustainable employment and to ensure decent working conditions including social protection.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Economic policy guidelines and employment guidelines were introduced by the Lisbon treaty and were first adopted by the Council in 2010. Whilst the broad economic policy guidelines remain valid for any duration of time, the employment guidelines need to be drawn up each year.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. Despite all the good reports on workers' rights, we cannot support changes within the framework of the Stability Pact and the European Semester. As a group we insist on their abolition, because these are the instruments by which unpopular policies of worker poverty are imposed. It is indicative of the EU's insistence on neoliberal policies of austerity and memoranda and the lack of democracy in the union, since neither last year nor this year did the Council take account of Parliament's report on employment guidelines. Deregulation of industrial relations, downward pressure on wages and labour rights, the dissolution of the social state and social dumping are imposed on the peoples in order to profit from multinationals and large capital. We therefore consider it appropriate to abstain in the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ The Employment Guidelines are a soft policy instrument by which the EU outlines common priorities and targets for labour market strategy in the Member States. They are one part of broader economic and employment guidelines and are renewed substantively every 5 years. The Council’s decision to maintain the 2015 employment guidelines for this year was particularly galling given they did not take up any suggestions from the European Parliament in the 2015 procedure. This report reiterates the Parliament’s demands on the four Guidelines put forward by the Commission and adopted by Council last year, namely boosting demand for labour, enhancing labour supply and skills, enhancing the functioning of labour markets and ensuring social justice, combatting poverty and promoting equal opportunities. In particular I was happy to support the report’s calls for entrepreneurship education and measures to improve entrepreneurship, less red tape for SMEs, access to quality education and vocational training and the diversification of skills in order to better adapt to future labour market needs.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this consultation procedure vote, which is technically non-legislative. It is written in to the treaties (TFEU Article 148) that the EU should coordinate employment policy between all Member States and this is a procedure that is voted on every year. The proposal creates vague goals without specific actions as to what the Member States should be focussing on. This proposal includes things like ‘increasing labour participation and reducing structural employment’ and ‘develop a skilled workforce’. This all sounds ok, but ultimately it is the EU trying to control Member States and tell them what their employment policies should be. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ It is paramount for the Commission and Council to take into account the European Parliament Resolution of 8 July 2015! It is disappointing to see that the European Parliament is disregarded on matters that are of great importance. I make a further call for the European institutions to take into account the amendments tabled regarding an integrated labour market that can address the pitfalls of unemployment, securing and maintaining high levels of employment, while offering national minimum basic income schemes and social protection.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Council Decision Proposal Report on member states' employment policy guidelines (COM(2016)0071 - C8-0098/2016 - 20 16/0043(NLE)), given the importance of employment policy and the need for Parliament to be involved in the adoption of this legislative initiative, as members come from all countries and have excellent knowledge of the situation on the ground as well as the problems concerning unemployment. Given the rapid economic changes, it is essential to continue integrating the labour market, promoting better education and flexibility, and aligning needs or demand with education policies.  The Union needs holistic policies against unemployment. The tax burden should be shifted from labour to other sources of taxation. Civil society organisations, regional and local self-government should be involved in designing the necessary reforms and policies. I support the targets to increase the employment rate from 20 to 64 to 75% by 2020 and to reduce the dropout rate to less than 10%.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this consultation procedure vote, which is technically non-legislative. It is written in to the treaties (TFEU Article 148) that the EU should coordinate employment policy between all Member States and this is a procedure that is voted on every year. The proposal creates vague goals without specific actions as to what the Member States should be focussing on. This proposal includes things like ‘increasing labour participation and reducing structural employment’ and ‘develop a skilled workforce’. This all sounds ok, but ultimately it is the EU trying to control Member States and tell them what their employment policies should be. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which insists that the Council has not taken into account Parliament's demands, as expressed in the 2015 resolution of 8 July 2015 on the guidelines. This report has no legal impact but is an important political signal.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report contains many positive points that have long been implemented in Austria, but goes far beyond employment policies. Demands are being made which deeply interfere with the social and social responsibilities of Member States. For these reasons, I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, as the report includes a requirement for a minimum wage in the European Union. I believe that this is a requirement of interference with the tax systems of the Member States. The European Union's tax policy is firmly based on the principle of subsidiarity. The situation varies greatly from country to country.  I believe that the Member States themselves must decide on their own tax policy.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Last year, Parliament presented the same report and it was completely ignored by the Council. Fighting unemployment, especially youth unemployment, remains a major concern across Europe and, although it is the Member States implementing the requisite policies, a constructive dialogue between the institutions must take place to address this issue. The report underlines the need for a holistic approach to tackling unemployment and reducing poverty levels. It calls for the realisation of the objectives set in Europe 2020 and notes with concern that these have not yet been met. In that regard, calling for reductions in the 2017 budget to fight youth employment by cutting the budget line for the Youth Guarantee from EUR 6 billion to EUR 2 billion, as proposed by the Commission, is a grave mistake. I call upon the Council to join with Parliament to reject such cuts.
