Meaningful employment policies accompanied by relevant and up-to-date life-long learning schemes must enable barrier-free access to first employment, ensure a balanced work and family life, offer measures for successful re-employment when needed and reduce poverty in employment.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a report which encourages Member States to adopt concrete employment policies aiming at ensuring an inclusive and integrated labour market and at addressing the severe impact of unemployment, to create sustainable employment and to ensure decent working conditions including social protection.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council Decision on the employment guidelines of the Member States is an important document, as the eight guidelines mentioned here can, when appropriately applied, contribute to improving the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy in the field of employment and the labour market. These guidelines are set out in the original 2015 document and are: firstly, promoting investment, secondly, boosting growth through the implementation of structural reforms, thirdly, removing the fundamental barriers to growth and jobs at EU level, fourthly, improving the sustainability and growth orientation of public finances, fifthly, promoting labour demand, sixthly, improving labour supply and skills, seeding, improving the functioning of labour markets and so on, ensuring fairness, combating poverty and promoting equal opportunities. As the integrated guidelines are confirmed, both the Council and the EP can make a significant contribution to the implementation of the European Employment Strategy. They provide for the creation of training and training programmes for workers as well as infrastructure development through a 'growth orientation of public finances'.  With regard 3, I believe that this objective could be used to simplify the administration of SMEs, which will certainly be met with a favourable response from entrepreneurs across the EU. If the administration of nation states makes appropriate use of this initiative. In view of the above, I support the Commission's proposal, as submitted for a vote.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The Commission takes its usual form of finding solutions at the level of slogans, standing strictly on the ground of repeatedly failed neoliberal economic policies. At least the proposals of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs are well-intentioned, although not feasible, since average wages in the EU alone differ by 5-10 times, with the wage gap in developing countries as distorting competition. It should finally be seen that it is impossible to put the same economic policy on such different countries. The commission strikes a much more critical tone than the original Commission material, and has a much better assessment of the situation, so its proposals for amendments should be supported, as opposed to the original material.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – The guidelines for Member States' employment policies are based on the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and are aimed at supporting reforms for sustainable, knowledge-based and innovation-based growth. The European Union aims for an employment rate of 75% for both men and women, and in order to achieve this, the effort is with the Member States, which must encourage participation in the labour market by young people, older workers, low-skilled workers and legal immigrants. For these reasons, I am in favour of and support the decision taken by Parliament.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it commends the EU for playing a major role as a force for creating jobs, wealth and growth. We think we're dreaming!

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The employment guidelines were initiated in 1998. Successive editions all advocate the same objectives but with no concrete results. These are only very general outlines, with only an indicative value. An eloquent example of this inefficiency that we constantly denounce: youth unemployment. In 2003 and 2008, the goal was to obtain employment or training four to six months after entering the labour market. The Youth Employment Initiative, launched in 2013, follows the same principle. In 2016, youth unemployment in Europe hovered around 20%, reaching 50% in some Member States (Greece, Spain).  As a result, I voted against this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Council adopted last year guidelines for employment policies which completely ignored any of the Recommendations made by Parliament a few months earlier.  In addition, the report expresses Parliament's concern about the achievement of the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, in particular with regard to employment and social protection objectives, as well as educational objectives, with particular attention to the growing divergences between different countries. The report also includes the need to introduce the social dimension, at the same level as the financial and fiscal dimension, into the European Semester process in order to improve the performance of macroeconomic policies in the social sphere. Just as it literally reintroduces the position expressed by Parliament on 8 July, as a way of reiterating the role that Parliament must play in this institutional framework of the Union.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. In this case, I have spoken in favour of the amendments made in the Committee on Employment to the EU proposal because, despite its shortcomings, it at least broadens the focus on passive employment policies and macroeconomic policies to combat current mass unemployment.  The Commission's proposal, which has had my no vote, is nothing more than a battering ram to reduce social benefits and pensions and to blame workers for their unemployment; serious enough that he would not vote in favour of the final resolution.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report aims to close collaboration between national parliaments, as well as with the social partners and civil society representatives on employment.  The Employment Policy Guidelines cover the economic and labour market. Approval of this report is important as these Guidelines boost demand for labour, improve labour supply, skills and the functioning of labour markets, ensure equity, combat poverty and promote equal opportunities.  For the reasons described above, I give my positive vote for approval.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the context of the guidelines on member states' employment policies, I note the need to assess the YOUTH Employment Initiative and to step up efforts to reduce youth unemployment in the EU, which remains above 40%.  It is also important to make effective use of European programmes and funds to finance the modernisation of higher education systems in order to better adapt education systems to the needs of the labour market and to changing social and economic conditions. We also need more support for VET institutions in terms of quality improvement and flexibility of learning.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the EU setting guidelines for member states in their employment policy. It is absurd for countries with higher unemployment than the Czech Republic to determine the Czech Republic's employment policy. I do not agree with the call that Member States should 'invest in quality jobs'. I don't think governments are supposed to invest in jobs, employing people is supposed to be a business matter. Nor do I agree with the requirement that housing benefit be part of social policy.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Europe 2020 Strategy The Union should be able to steer its economy towards smart, sustainable and inclusive growth accompanied by high levels of employment, productivity and social cohesion. In this regard, the developments so far in the employment indicators and social indicators of the Europe 2020 strategy are worrying, as the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion has increased.  This report underlines that achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 employment strategy must continue to be a key policy objective for Member States. In its Resolution of 22 February, the European Parliament called on Member States to carry out due diligence and continue reforms on the basis of employment indicators (activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment). Member States must reduce barriers to employment by cutting red tape, promote youth entrepreneurship and support in particular the establishment and growth of micro and SME enterprises.  It is also necessary to create green jobs and to this end make more efficient use of the European Social Fund and other Union funds to combat poverty, improve quality employment, social inclusion, the education system, public administration and public services. The European Fund for Strategic Investments and its investment platforms should also be mobilised to ensure the creation of quality jobs and the training of workers. Because of all of the above, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ It is very important that the proposal for a decision provides that the guidelines for Member States’ employment policies shall be taken into account by the Member States in their employment policies. Member States should continue to make every effort to address the priority areas of: increasing labour market participation and reducing structural unemployment, improving the performance of education and training systems, promoting social inclusion and combating poverty.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the guidelines for member states' employment policies, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/9/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  The employment guidelines were initiated in 1998 and are part of the 'Europe 2020' strategy. Successive editions all advocate the same objectives but with no concrete results. These are only very general outlines, with only an indicative value.  An eloquent example of this inefficiency is youth unemployment. In 2003 and 2008, the target was to obtain employment or training four to six months after entering the labour market. The Youth Employment Initiative, launched three years ago, is based on the same idea. However, in 2016, youth unemployment in Europe averages 20%, reaching 50% in some Member States (such as Greece and Spain).

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – According to the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States, 120 million EU citizens are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Therefore, I voted in favour of the resolution as I agree that the Union needs to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market that is able to address the repercussions of unemployment, provide adequate working conditions and guarantee social protection, while at the same time pursuing smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support this Parliament's proposals to improve guidelines for Member States' employment policies. This is an important decision at the present time, after years of crisis that have done so much damage to job creation, and it is necessary from the EU to take measures that contribute to measures across Europe that ensure harmonious development and leave no one behind, contemplating the most vulnerable sectors of our society.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This report was supposed to create a framework for higher employment. Instead, the EU is trying to seize more powers and interfering with the regulatory powers of the Member States. I strongly oppose this.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Parliamentary report because I support its provisions encouraging Member States to step up their efforts in the formulation and implementation of employment policies. I believe that, in order to ensure the competitiveness and growth of the economy, it is particularly important to develop a skilled workforce that is able to adapt to the needs of the labour market, to promote job creation, lifelong learning, and to improve the functioning of education and training systems at all levels.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The aim of this proposal is to confirm the validity of the guidelines for Member States' employment policies adopted in 2015. These guidelines seek, in the right neoliberal logic, to "strengthen growth through structural reforms" and to "make public finances more sustainable". Parliament's report focuses on combating 'precarious work, underemployment, unreported work and zero-hours contracts', or aims to reduce 'discrimination in the labour market and in terms of access to the labour market, particularly for categories of discrimination or exclusion, such as women, older workers, young people persons with disabilities and migrants in legal circumstances." However, all this remains within the framework of the 'country commission recommendations'. I cannot validate the budgetary supervision of states by the technocrats in Brussels. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The employment guidelines were initiated in 1998. Successive editions all advocate the same objectives but with no concrete results. These are only very general outlines, with only an indicative value. An eloquent example of this inefficiency that we constantly denounce: youth unemployment. In 2003 and 2008, the goal was to obtain employment or training four to six months after entering the labour market. The Youth Employment Initiative, launched in 2013, follows the same principle. In 2016, youth unemployment in Europe hovered around 20%, reaching 50% in some Member States (Greece, Spain).  Therefore, I voted against the Commission's proposal and the resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The Europe 2020 strategy proposed by the Commission should enable the Union to steer its economy towards smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, accompanied by a high level of employment, productivity and social cohesion. The EU needs holistic policies and public investments to combat unemployment and poverty. In this context, the development so far of the employment and social indicators of the Europe 2020 strategy is of great concern, as the number of people at risk of poverty and exclusion has increased by five million instead of a decrease, the employment rate in some countries has not yet reached pre-crisis levels and, in some Member States, the proportion of young people who do not work , do not study and do not train (NEET) is more than 20 % and the rate of early school leaving is 23 %. The European Employment Strategy has the key role of achieving the objectives of the new strategy on employment, social inclusion and the labour market. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this legislative resolution as it enshrines the need for Member States across the Union to tackle the problem of unemployment by increasing the demand for labour with measures that include support for SMEs and greater involvement of actors from civil society.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The European model is social. The fight against poverty and unemployment is enshrined in all EU policies. Thus, vocational training and job creation are at the heart of the Commission's priorities for inclusive and sustainable growth. Although employment responsibility remains the responsibility of the Member States, nothing prevents the European Parliament, embodying the voice of 508 million citizens, from building a European social project. Society evolves, the family transforms, generating new social needs. However, our national social systems are still too based on outdated models. We have to be ambitious. We must continue our efforts, particularly towards employment for young people and small and medium-sized enterprises. In this sense, we make it a point of honour to be heard in the Council through this report mentioning the guidelines for employment policies of the Member States to which I support.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – Increasing the number and quality of jobs is one of the priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy. The European Employment Strategy, with its employment guidelines and programmes, aims to contribute to growth and jobs, labour mobility and social progress. The report presented is a response to the situation where the Council ignored Parliament's position on the employment guidelines issued last year. The report is merely of a consultative nature, does not produce any legal consequences, but is a political signal that Parliament's position should be taken into account. I am voting in favour of the report in favour.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls on the Commission to alter its proposal accordingly and on the Council to take the amended guidelines into account in order to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market able to address the severe impact of unemployment, secure a high level of employment, and ensure decent working conditions including national minimum basic income schemes and social protection.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to the Council a decision on guidelines for employment policies in the Member States. The Council shall consult Parliament before adopting the proposal. In its report, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs recommends that parliament adopt the Commission's proposal in an amended form, with 7 amendments and 5 new guidelines, and to ask the Commission to submit its proposal to the Council accordingly. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Employment policy guidelines coordinate employment policies of EU Member States.  They are part of the 'Europe 2020' strategy, presented on 3 March 2010, which sets out the EU's economic guidelines, monitored as part of the European Semester. The 'Europe 2020' programme sets five targets, divided into three themes: smart growth, sustainable growth and inclusive growth. On the Commission's recommendation, the Council wants to keep the guidelines as of 2015 for 2016, in particular for the liberalisation of the labour market.  Since 1998, these guidelines are supposed to improve employment in the EU, but we can only see their total inefficiency. Logically, we reject this text of Parliament which approves the decision of the Council and the Commission.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The employment guidelines were initiated in 1998. Successive editions all advocate the same objectives but with no concrete results. Youth unemployment is an eloquent example. In 2003 and 2008, the goal was to obtain employment or training four to six months after entering the labour market. The Youth Employment Initiative, launched in 2013, follows the same principle. In 2016, youth unemployment in Europe hovered around 20%, reaching 50% in some Member States (Greece, Spain). So I'm voting against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ At present, 16.8% of UK citizens are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Today the EPLP voted in favour of a report which encourages Member States to adopt concrete employment policies aiming at ensuring an inclusive and integrated labour market and at addressing the severe impact of unemployment, create sustainable employment and ensure decent working conditions including social protection.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Council's proposed decision on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. In particular, it calls on Member States to guarantee decent working conditions and social protection for employees. While social dumping within the European Union is linked in particular to differences in working conditions, the adoption of such a report was necessary.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Laura Agea's report on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The issue of employment is particularly close to my heart, and this report follows on from the fact that the Council had completely ignored Parliament's position on this subject in the context of an advisory procedure.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for employment policies in the Member States. A year ago, we drafted and adopted a proposal, which unfortunately was ultimately ignored by the Council. The European Parliament is the only democratically elected EU institution that directly represents European citizens, so we can rightly expect the Council to take our recommendations seriously. I believe that the European Parliament has today adopted a report that will be able to stand up to the Europe 2020 strategy. The report sets out key objectives such as increasing the employment rate of people between the age of 20 and 64, creating an appropriate working environment or reducing the number of people living in poverty. In order to achieve this, we will need an effective instrument, which I believe could even be used to ensure quality education.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union’s current growth strategy has five ambitious objectives on employment, education, social inclusion, innovation and climate/energy that should be reached by 2020. Entitled Europe 2020, its initiative regarding the Agenda for new skills and jobs will help the EU reach 75% of the working-age population between 20 and 64 under employment. I have voted for this report that calls for more significant efforts to be made in order to reach the established targets.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because indicators for employment such as employment rates, youth employment rates and long-term unemployment were introduced in the macroeconomic imbalances procedure. These indicators will help to draw up a clearer analysis leading to the construction and implementation of labour market reforms as well as additional social reforms. The report also proposes that Member States reduce red tape in order to reduce excessive obligations on small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This report included several good aspects such as calling for public investment, job creation, and support for workers’ rights. However, it calls for all of this within the confines of the European Stability and Growth pact as well as the European Semester. These two things are almost diametrically opposed – you cannot have a decent level of investment etc. while you are in a fiscal straight jacket. Because of the positive aspects around workers’ rights etc. I did not vote against this report, but I could not support it either, given the confines in which it wishes to place investment and job creation, i.e. the Stability and Growth Pact and European Semester. For these reasons I abstained on the overall report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report initially appears positive in terms of creating a framework for higher employment figures. However, attempts are being made to interfere with the regulatory competences of the Member States. I reject that.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The European Employment Strategy has an important role to play in promoting future economic, social and employment policies. The integrated guidelines provide Member States with a detailed overview and guidance for the implementation of their reform programmes, and will, inter alia, focus on the following priorities: increasing labour market participation rates, promoting lifelong learning and social inclusion and combating poverty.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this consultation procedure vote, which is technically non-legislative. It is written in to the treaties (TFEU Article 148) that the EU should coordinate employment policy between all Member States and this is a procedure that is voted on every year. The proposal creates vague goals without specific actions as to what the Member States should be focussing on. This proposal includes things like ‘increasing labour participation and reducing structural employment’ and ‘develop a skilled workforce’. This all sounds ok, but ultimately it is the EU trying to control Member States and tell them what their employment policies should be. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I would vote in favour of this text and I invite you, especially after Mr Juncker's words on millennials, to do the same. We must all bear in mind that new strategies and guidelines are urgently in place to enable young people more job opportunities in the coming years.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The fact is that economic policies and promoting employment are issues of common interest and are issues concerning all Member States in the EU. So far, it has proven to be a good and effective practice for Member States and the EU to work together to coordinate employment strategies and to promote a skilled, educated and adaptable workforce.  The European Commission has proposed in the Europe 2020 Strategy a focus on smart, sustainable and inclusive growth with high levels of employment, productivity and social cohesion across the EU; in this proposal, I particularly welcome the EU-wide focus on social cohesion, as we still face economic and social inequality within the EU.  Furthermore, this proposal led to Member States receiving precise guidance on identifying national reform programmes and implementing reforms. These programmes are aligned with those of other Member States, leading to the homogenisation of economic policies in the EU. That is why I believe that the already existing Decision, which has been valid so far, needs to be re-endorsed in order to continue to be valid.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The employment guidelines were initiated in 1998. Successive editions all advocate the same objectives but with no concrete results. Youth unemployment is an eloquent example. In 2003 and 2008, the goal was to obtain employment or training four to six months after entering the labour market. The Youth Employment Initiative, launched in 2013, follows the same principle. In 2016, youth unemployment in Europe hovered around 20%, reaching 50% in some Member States (Greece, Spain). It is therefore a particularly ineffective and unnecessary policy of interference. I'm voting against the text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report, the European Parliament wishes to express its disappointment at the decision taken by the Commission and the Council to completely ignore the suggestions of this Assembly, formulated in its resolution of 8 July 2015, regarding the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The attitude of the Commission and the Council is contrary to the spirit of the Treaties and to the principle of good cooperation between the European institutions, and risks re-establishing, in the eyes of the citizens, the impression of a democratic deficit in Europe. With this report, we are today calling on the Commission to amend its proposal and on the Council to take account of the guidelines expressed by Parliament, in order to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market, capable of dealing with the severe impact of unemployment, ensuring a high level of employment, and of guaranteeing decent working and living conditions. Over and above the many announcements, the time has come to work seriously and concretely on the construction of the Social Pillar of the Union. I therefore support this report so that this can actually be done.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU stipulates that employment and economic policy guidelines together constitute guidelines for the implementation of the employment strategy. When identifying and implementing a strategy, the Union must ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market that can respond to high levels of unemployment, ensure working conditions and social protection, a high level of education and training, and combat all types of discrimination.  I supported the Age Report, as it is important for Member States to invest in education and vocational training systems to raise the level of knowledge and skills of the workforce in order to better meet the needs of dynamic labour markets and ensure a high level of employment.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the employment guidelines of the Member States because I consider it necessary for both the Commission and the Council to take into account the position of the European Parliament in respect of employment. As the only institution directly elected by citizens, Parliament has proposed introducing a strong social dimension into the economic and employment policies of all 28 Member States. In the event that Parliament is not heard in this regard, this is therefore a simple deepening of the democratic deficit. The European Union must ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market, ensure a high level of employment and decent working conditions throughout the Union, in the implementation of its policies and activities, in line with the Treaty of Lisbon. Unemployment rates, which still did not reach pre-financial and economic crisis levels in several countries, show that employment policies are currently not set correctly. Likewise, the number of Europeans at risk of exclusion and poverty has not increased. By contrast, it saw an increase of 5 million. In particular, up to 120 million Europeans are currently at risk of poverty and exclusion. Member States must therefore make much greater efforts. This situation can no longer be ignored. Employment guidelines should therefore be taken into account without parole in any Council recommendations. They should be further developed with Parliament as an equivalent institution to help secure more jobs, both quality and sustainable.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this consultation report, which reminds the Council of the European Union of the need to take into account the European Parliament's position on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies, already set out a year ago.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The problem of unemployment is, of course, one of the european Union's main priorities.  This report presents, in this area, a set of guidelines aimed at addressing the importance of integrating gaps – which, it should be recognised, exist – to raise awareness of social factors related to unemployment, as well as to promote a fairer labour market. The rapporteur warns of the importance of facilitating and investing in the creation of quality and sustainable jobs, of promoting young entrepreneurship, as well as of driving and promoting policies that guarantee fair wages for all workers. I voted in favour because I believe that by boosting labour demand, increasing workers' skills, improving the functioning of the labour market and promoting equal opportunities, we will be on the right track for a Europe in which the social market economy contributes to the dignification of the labour market and the eradication of unemployment.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this consultation procedure vote, which is technically non-legislative. It is written in to the treaties (TFEU Article 148) that the EU should coordinate employment policy between all Member States and this is a procedure that is voted on every year. The proposal creates vague goals without specific actions as to what the Member States should be focussing on. This proposal includes things like ‘increasing labour participation and reducing structural employment’ and ‘develop a skilled workforce’. This all sounds ok, but ultimately it is the EU trying to control Member States and tell them what their employment policies should be. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of considering it essential that Member States and the Union commit themselves to developing a coordinated employment strategy and, in particular, promoting a skilled, trained and adaptable workforce, as well as labour markets that react rapidly to economic change. Member States, in cooperation with regional and local authorities, should effectively and swiftly address the serious problem of unemployment, facilitate and invest in the creation of quality and sustainable employment, address accessibility for groups exposed to risks, reduce barriers that prevent companies from hiring people in the various levels of skills and sectors of the labour market , in particular by reducing bureaucracy, while respecting labour and social standards, promoting young entrepreneurship and, in particular, promoting the creation and growth of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises in order to increase the employment rate of men and women. Member States should actively promote, inter alia, jobs in the green, white and blue sectors, as well as the social economy, and foster social innovation.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution in which Parliament denounces the lack of attention paid by the Council in October last year to its proposals, adopting guidelines which completely ignored any of the Recommendations made by Parliament a few times earlier, an approach contrary to the spirit of the Treaties and which weakens cooperation between the institutions of the Union. Parliament expresses its concern about the achievement of the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, in particular with regard to employment and social protection objectives, as well as educational objectives, with particular attention to the growing divergences between different countries. In addition, and thanks to the contributions of the S&D group, the resolution stresses the need to introduce the social dimension, at the same level as the financial and fiscal dimension, into the European Semester process in order to improve the results of macroeconomic policies in the social sphere.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's position on the employment guidelines that determine the scope of Member States' policies to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. I am also pleased to have the addition this year of a priority regarding the reconciliation between family and work life.  With this position, I also regret that the Council very rarely takes into account the amendments proposed by the European Parliament to improve these guidelines. I urge the Council to give particular importance to Parliament's amendments to this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out Parliament's position on the guidelines proposed by the Commission for Member States' employment policies. This report highlights the main objectives of employment policies: to stimulate the demand for jobs by reducing, for example, barriers to hiring, to improve the supply of jobs and skills by facilitating access to education, to improve the functioning of labour markets by combating black-market work and finally to guarantee social justice.  The report points out that 120 million EU citizens are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. This alarming figure is a reminder of the urgent need for action on employment and calls for measures to encourage Member States to combat unemployment and precarious working conditions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report because we consider it a matter of priority that the content of the report be taken into account in a binding manner by the Council and not as an appendix without any effect. We consider the content of the report to be extremely positive and most of the recommendations are positive, but we find that special emphasis is placed on promoting the in-balance entrepreneurship of recommendations on how to alleviate long-term unemployment and ensure quality work. Since we do not oppose a part of the report and cannot vote separately on the committee's amendments, we vote on abstention.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted again in favour of the directives on member states' employment policies. Last year, the European Council 'overlooked' the European Parliament's report, so we now want to send out a political signal by voting again.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. In this case, I have spoken in favour of the amendments made in the Committee on Employment to the EU proposal because, despite its shortcomings, it at least broadens the focus on passive employment policies and macroeconomic policies to combat current mass unemployment.  The Commission's proposal, which has had my no vote, is nothing more than a battering ram to reduce social benefits and pensions and to blame workers for their unemployment; serious enough that he would not vote in favour of the final resolution.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is estimated that up to a quarter of the EU population is currently at risk of varying degrees of poverty and social exclusion. This extremely difficult situation, which is characterised, inter alia, by the persistently high number of people out of work, requires measures to encourage Member States to help the unemployed and the lowest earners. An analysis of Member States' national reform programmes shows that Member States continue to focus too little on increasing labour force activity, reducing unemployment, improving labour skills in response to labour market expectations and needs.  Despite the recent recent improvements, young people in Europe are still in a particularly difficult position on the labour market. This applies in particular to the countries most affected by the crisis in southern Europe, but also to some of the new Member States. The continued persistence of high youth unemployment may result in our black visions of a 'lost generation in Europe' and threaten the future of the continent. In this context, it is particularly important to promote the quality of employment, learning-business links and encourage lifelong learning.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ At present, 16.8% of UK citizens are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Today the EPLP voted in favour of a report which encourages Member States to adopt concrete employment policies aiming at ensuring an inclusive and integrated labour market and at addressing the severe impact of unemployment, create sustainable employment and ensure decent working conditions including social protection.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing – In the case of a resolution hearing changes to the employment guidelines of the Member States, I voted against this proposal. I do not share the idea of improving employment policies in the EU, which is automatically linked to LGBTI law enforcement policy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the employment guidelines of the Member States. Despite some positive employment trends, a large number of unemployed young people and people at risk of poverty and social exclusion still remain. I therefore welcome the EU's adopted of the employment guidelines of the Member States, which allow states' efforts in this area to be coordinated. The recommendations rightly include support for youth entrepreneurship and an accent to ensure quality general and vocational training, which plays an essential role in employment and employment.  Other positives of the report can also be seen in the recommendations on ensuring gender equality in the labour market, including their equal pay. Last but not least, the very well-chosen wording regarding the setting of the minimum income cannot be ignored either. The text recalls that each Member State should determine it itself, taking into account its situation and national procedures.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ The fight against unemployment, especially among young people, is one of the priorities of both the European Commission and the European Parliament. In addition to supporting educational and retraining projects, we should place particular emphasis on improving the business environment and promoting job creation in the private sector.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I accept the report on the Council's proposal for a decision on member states' employment policy guidelines, as I consider the issue of unemployment to be of great importance, in particular youth unemployment. The problem of unemployment needs to be addressed quickly and efficiently.  New jobs need to be invested and created, green, white and blue sectors and the social economy actively promoted. Wages must be high enough to outshoo place an income for life, which would reduce poverty in the Union. It is necessary to effectively reduce red tape and support the establishment of SMEs in order to increase overall employment.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The TFEU provides that Member States and the Union shall work towards the development of a coordinated employment strategy and, in particular, the promotion of the skills, training and adaptability of workers, as well as the ability of labour markets to respond to the needs of economic change. The guidelines to be adopted here fall within this framework. There should be no such guidelines, and the EU's competence to do so in general. This is central-government governance that does not bring added value even at national level, let alone at EU level.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU stipulates that Member States consider their economic policies and promotion of employment as matters of common interest and to align them in the Council. I support the Report on the Council's proposal for a decision on the employment policy guidelines of the Member States of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for member states' employment policies.  I regret that the Council did not take into account the European Parliament's legislative resolution adopted in July 2015. The Council's approach is at odds, weakening cooperation between the Union institutions and increasing the democratic deficit for citizens.  I support the amendment that, when defining and implementing its policies and activities, the Union must ensure an integrated and inclusive labour market that can eliminate the serious effects of unemployment and ensure decent working conditions throughout the Union, including adequate wages, ensure adequate social protection in accordance with labour regulations.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We have observed an abstention attitude in the report. Despite all the good reports on workers' rights, we cannot support changes within the framework of the Stability Pact and the European Semester. As a group we insist on their abolition, because these are the instruments by which unpopular policies of worker poverty are imposed. It is indicative of the EU's insistence on neoliberal policies of austerity and memoranda and the lack of democracy in the union, since neither last year nor this year did the Council take account of Parliament's report on employment guidelines. Deregulation of industrial relations, downward pressure on wages and labour rights, the dissolution of the social state and social dumping are imposed on the peoples in order to profit from multinationals and large capital.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU needs holistic policies and public investment to combat unemployment and poverty. However, these objectives have not been achieved and more significant efforts need to be made to achieve the expected results.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, the points of which are submitted for the second time by the European Parliament to the Commission and the Council. I agree with the regret of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, since the Council and the Commission have not taken into account the EP's previous proposals. The Treaty on European Union clearly sets out the objective of coordinating their economic policies within the Union. It also specifies that the European Union is taking measures (in the form of guidelines, for example) to coordinate member states' employment policies and social policies. I regret to say that these principles are not being met 100%, and that more and more Member States are pursuing separate policies. In particular, some Member States disrefie the spirit of the Treaty(s), which, in my opinion, reinforces the phenomenon of a democratic deficit with the EU. I think that we need to talk not only about creating jobs, but also about creating quality jobs. Do not let a Member State (e.g. Hungary) report to its employment data its nationals working abroad or slave public workers paid EUR 150 per month. With regard to the above, I am pleased that the proposals place a strong social emphasis on the economic and labour policies and challenges of Europe 2020 and the Member States.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 For the second year in a row, it is still our colleague Laura Agea who is working as rapporteur on this dossier, which consists of a non-legislative consultation procedure in which Parliament expresses its guidelines for employment policies in the Member States. Thanks to her experience over the past year, she has been able to see that the Council has ignored Parliament's expressed position in 2015 and that it is already in the process of doing so again this year with the 2016 report. So the rapporteur decided to retable the 2015 amendments as a whole by adding a paragraph criticising the EU Council which proved to run counter to the spirit of the Treaties. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report as major political groups in the European Parliament all want to send a clear message to the Council that its position must be taken into account as their ignorance is against the spirit of the Treaties and the good cooperation between the EU institutions. My colleagues and I in the S&D Group very much regret the Council and Commission ignorance of the EP contribution to the Guidelines for employment policies of Member States and call on the Commission to alter its proposal accordingly. Furthermore, we call on the Council to take the amended Guidelines into account in order to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market able to address the severe impact of unemployment, secure a high level of employment, and ensure decent working conditions including national minimum basic income schemes and social protection.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Laura Agea's proposal for a decision on the Council's decision on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of maintaining the 2015 guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States for 2016, as I believe that it is a useful tool to increase the effectiveness of our internal market, and to fight unemployment, particularly amongst youth. The guidelines include boosting demand for labour, enhancing labour skills and supply and the functioning of labour markets, improving the quality and performance of education and training systems, as well as ensuring social justice. Measures to promote entrepreneurship, access to quality education and vocational training as well as the employability capacity for SMEs should also be included. However, we should refrain from going beyond minimum requirements, in order to leave space for national and regional policy-makers to devise measures that are most tailored to the specificities of their own labour market.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision on guidelines for member states' employment policies, as I believe that the European Union must ensure an integrated and inclusive labour market in defining and implementing its policies and activities that can eliminate the serious effects of unemployment and ensure decent working conditions throughout the Union, including adequate wages and adequate social protection in accordance with labour regulations, collective bargaining and in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.  It is also essential to ensure high-level education and training and to prevent discrimination based on sex, race or nationality, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report because we consider it a matter of priority that the content of the report be taken into account in a binding manner by the Council and not as an appendix without any effect. We consider the content of the report to be extremely positive and most of the recommendations are positive, but we find that special emphasis is placed on promoting entrepreneurship in detail with recommendations on how to alleviate long-term unemployment and ensure quality work. Since we do not oppose a part of the report and cannot vote separately on the committee's amendments, we vote on abstention.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Employment policy guidelines coordinate employment policies of EU Member States. They are part of the 'Europe 2020' strategy, enacted on 3 March 2010, which sets out the EU's economic guidelines. The economic guidelines are monitored in the framework of the European Semester: they are subject to specific thematic monitoring. On the Commission's recommendation, the Council maintains the guidelines as of 2015 for 2016. The Council insists on the use of the European Social Fund for employment policies. The European Parliament approves the joint proposal by the Commission and the Council to maintain the employment guidelines for 2016. The employment guidelines were initiated in 1998. Successive editions all advocate the same objectives but with no concrete results. Youth unemployment is an eloquent example. In 2003 and 2008, the goal was to obtain employment or training four to six months after entering the labour market. The Youth Employment Initiative, launched in 2013, follows the same principle. In 2016, youth unemployment in Europe hovered around 20%, reaching 50% in some Member States (Greece, Spain).  I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A common employment policy framework in the Member States can provide an important reference point in the design of future labour market and employment promotion policy plans. However, the important role of the specificity of the approach to employment policy of all Member States should be taken into account; harmonisation of rules and the going of senior EU bodies beyond the competences conferred by the Treaties may result in too serious market interference and not produce the expected results. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against the motion for a resolution tabled.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States and the Union aim to develop a coordinated strategy for the development of employment, in particular skilled, skilled and adapting workers and labour markets capable of responding to economic change, in order to achieve the objectives set out in the Treaty on European Union. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted abstention in this report because we consider it a matter of priority that the content of the report be taken into account in a binding manner by the Council and not as an appendix without any effect. We consider the content of the report to be extremely positive and most of the recommendations are positive, but we find that special emphasis is placed on promoting entrepreneurship in detail with recommendations on how to alleviate long-term unemployment and ensure quality work. Since we do not oppose a part of the report and cannot vote separately on the committee's amendments, we vote on abstention.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as Member States should listen to the message of their citizens, sent via their elected body, the European Parliament, and give sustainable employment and social inclusion higher priority in their agenda settings / employment guidelines.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – These new integrated guidelines should be in line with the Conclusions of the European Council.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States. The ‘Europe 2020 Strategy’ proposed by the Commission should enable the Union to turn its economy towards smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, accompanied by a high level of employment, productivity and social cohesion. The Union is in need of holistic policies and public investments that will fight against unemployment and poverty. I voted in favour because I strongly believe that the achievement of the Europe 2020 Strategy in the employment and social area must remain a key objective of Member States’ employment policies.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By presenting this report for the second time, Parliament intends to issue a political signal for Parliament's position to be taken into consideration. The text strikes a balance among all political groups that has made it possible to reach common commitments in the treatment, on the one hand, of economic policies; and, on the other hand, social policies. In addition, it remains in line with the Stability and Growth Pact. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ At present, 16.8% of UK citizens are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Today the EPLP voted in favour of a report which encourages Member States to adopt concrete employment policies aiming at ensuring an inclusive and integrated labour market and at addressing the severe impact of unemployment, create sustainable employment and ensure decent working conditions including social protection.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report. The European Parliament and the European Council do not agree on the guidelines that the EU should give its Member States in order to boost employment.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims, for 2016, to confirm the validity of the Member States' employment policy guidelines, which had been launched in October 2015. Unfortunately, many of the concepts used – such as "adaptability" and "flexibility" – involve changes in relationships and working conditions, which lead to the deterioration of workers' rights.  On the other hand, the main solution recommended, entrepreneurship, is encouraged in multiple ways, including as a curricular component in the public educational system. There is also the reference to the "necessary flexibility in education systems and a practical orientation", revealing an essentially professionalizing educational paradigm and the concept of subjugation of educational policies to the needs of companies. This report was still inherent in the Europe 2020 strategy, the European Semester and other policies based on supranational interference and the imposition of austerity. Our vote was against it. This motion for a resolution now contains positive considerations with regard to the defence of workers' rights, gender or sexual orientation, the strengthening of collective bargaining and the fight against poverty. However, it does not depart from what, in the original document, made us vote against.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The amendment criticises the Council's inadequate involvement in legislation. It says the EU needs "holistic policies" to combat unemployment and poverty. Accordingly, the amendments call, among other things, for equality between men and women in the labour market, which, in my opinion, will only lead to the debate on women's quotas again. In addition, there should be increased inclusion in the labour market of discriminated groups, including legal immigrants, although the unemployment of the indigenous population (in note to Austria) is already high enough. The report must therefore be rejected.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The text approved by the EMPL Committee expresses disappointment at the lack of consideration by the Council and the Commission of the guidelines presented by Parliament. The report therefore retables the same amendments as last year, which focus attention on the need to achieve an inclusive market that can respond to the problem of unemployment, create sustainable jobs and ensure decent working conditions.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ At present, 16.8% of UK citizens are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Therefore, I voted together with my EPLP colleagues in favour of a report that encourages Member States to adopt concrete employment policies aimed at ensuring an inclusive and integrated labour market and at addressing the severe impact of unemployment, thereby creating sustainable employment and ensuring decent working conditions including social protection. Since being elected, I have consistently worked to include a gender equality and women’s rights perspective at the heart of policy-making on employment and women’s representation and access to labour markets. EU policies have continuously advanced gender equality for decades, and it is crucial that UK citizens continue to enjoy those benefits in years to come, despite the recent referendum vote which risks further progress in these matters.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report because, although it deals with important issues for EU societies and makes important observations, it violates the question of competence. Employment policy guidelines are mostly a competence of the Member States.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Agea report because I believe that Parliament should state its guidelines for member states' employment policies.  I believe that the EU should, in implementing its employment policies, ensure the creation of an integrated and inclusive labour market that is able to combat the impact of unemployment, ensure a high level of employment, ensure decent working conditions across the Union, including adequate pay and adequate levels of social protection, and combat discrimination on grounds of sex , racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. In addition, the EU needs holistic policies and public investments to combat unemployment and poverty. In this context, the development so far of the employment and social indicators of the Europe 2020 strategy is of great concern, as the number of people at risk of poverty and exclusion has increased by five million instead of falling and the employment rate in some countries has not yet reached pre-crisis levels.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. This is not a legislative report but a consultation report. Parliament is 'consulted' on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. We at the M5S also dealt with the same dossier last year and found that the Council not only totally ignored the position expressed by Parliament in 2015, but also decided to ignore what will be expressed in the 2016 report. Together with my colleagues in the 5Star Movement, we managed to build consensus within Parliament so that we could resubmit last year's guidelines as a whole, but introduced a paragraph of strong criticism of the work of the EU Council. The latter's approach has proved to be contrary to the spirit of the Treaties by having the effect of weakening cooperation between the Institutions of the Union. We can only see this as an increase in the 'democratic deficit' with regard to the citizens of the Union. With this report, the European Parliament denounces the Council's modus operandi and reiterates its position, which must be taken into account. I could only vote in favour of the report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for member states' employment policies. I believe that the Union must ensure an integrated and inclusive labour market that can eliminate the serious effects of unemployment and ensure decent working conditions throughout the Union and for all.  The Union must also enable its economy to focus on smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, accompanied by high levels of employment, productivity and social cohesion.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: – Madam President, today I welcome the steps taken by the EU to become part of the global fight against illegal wildlife trade by becoming a party to CITES. The battle against this heinous crime cannot be fought or won in isolation, and this marks an important step in acknowledging that and responding. It is estimated that this illicit trade and criminal activity has a value of between EUR 8 billion and EUR 20 billion per year, and the profits from it prop up corrupt regimes and criminals across the world. Only by stemming the funds from such crime will we really enable development and trade efforts for certain nations to be fully realised. Europe is not only the destination, but is also a transitional market for these goods and their illicit supply chains, and much can be done to tackle this across a range of policy fields. Therefore, whilst we take this international step forward, we should also look at the domestic market and continue to encourage all Member States to end trade in illicit goods, and specifically in ivory. Overall, this is a positive step in terms of joining the global fight against the trade in illegal wildlife products, and we should be an active party to CITES, driving the agenda forward.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I am happy to support this resolution because I consider it extremely important to combat all forms of the so-called zoo-mafia, that is, organised crime, which makes money from the smuggling of animals. Whether it is wild species, this is the case at this international conference, where I hope that our representatives will go with a strong mandate, or about the smuggling of animals within the European Union from Central and Eastern Europe to the western parts of the EU, which affects dogs and cats, and the so-called multiplicitation plant. I happen to be doing a big conference and a big debate on this subject in Prague tomorrow.  It is an important topic that at first glance looks like a fringe theme, but it has already been said, zoo-mafia, this organized crime, is the second or third (according to various statistics) the most profitable crime in the world besides drug trafficking and other illegal things. So we should not underestimate it and pay close attention to it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international instrument aimed at protecting endangered species of wild fauna and flora by controlling international trade in species of wild fauna and flora. This resolution calls on the European Commission to explain the Union's main strategic objectives at the next CONFERENCE of cites parties, highlighting the following aspects: transparency of decision-making, the need to improve the reporting of wildlife smuggling, corruption and the implementation of CITES. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – With regard to the motion for a resolution on the EU strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016, this vote is not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention, but this vote is about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure, which we are not prepared to support.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. The motion comes ahead of the 17th meeting of the parties to the Convention on International Trade in in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), of which the EU is now a member (as of 2015), and it calls for further action in cracking down on illegal trafficking of wildlife, which is still widespread.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on Member States to show political will and intensify their efforts to combat the illegal wildlife trade that is taking place before our eyes in the EU.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the main objectives of the 17th Conference of the Parties to CITES to be held in Johannesburg, because it is important for Member States to show political will and step up their efforts to combat wildlife trafficking in the EU.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the EU's key objectives as a participant in the 17th Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be held from 24 September to 5 October in Johannesburg. This resolution welcomes the EU's accession to the CITES Convention, by which the EU will now vote on behalf of the 28 Member States, who are already all parties to CITES, on matters under EU competence.  The EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on major issues of international cooperation. So I voted against this resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency and democracy, given that the vote is not subject to a roll-call, I wish to confirm that I abstained on this resolution. Whilst I fully support efforts to protect endangered species, this vote also concerns enhancing the status of the European Commission to the detriment of national authorities. As it appears to be a power grab, I cannot support it overall.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the EU's strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be held in Johannesburg, South Africa, from 24 September to 5 October 2016. CITES is the most important existing world-class wildlife conservation agreement signed by 181 countries, including the EU and its 28 Member States. The EU is participating for the first time in the CITIES Conference as a party to the Convention, and I therefore support the EU's accession to CITIES, and I believe that this accession is a very important step in ensuring that the EU continues to pursue broader regulatory objectives for its environmental policy and international trade in endangered species of wild flora and fauna and to promote the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development Policy.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution details the importance of the European Union's accession as a signatory to the Convention in the eradication of illegal wildlife trade. The EU is one of the main destinations for the trade in these live animals and plants, and the main market for their products is the EU territory.  The motion makes recommendations for amendments to the decision-making mechanism and the funding and implementation required by the Convention and aims at increasing the number of species included in the Appendix. The amendments will help to detect and eradicate corruption and abuses and illegal trade more effectively and will encourage the coordination of more effective exchanges of information and controls between Member States and throughout the EU. On this basis, I have accepted the motion.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have endorsed this report which welcomes the EU's accession to CITES and considers it a fundamental step forward for the Union's continuation of CITES' efforts to protect endangered species of flora and fauna.  Among other initiatives, the report also calls on the EU to adopt legislation that reduces illicit trade by making it illegal to import, export, sell or acquire wild animals or plants caught, possessed, transported or sold in violation of the law of the country of origin or transit.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report containing several guidelines for the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg, South Africa, from 24 September to 5 October. All guidelines are intended to meet environmental objectives as well as the promotion of sustainable development policies. Poaching and the alarming situation faced by elephants and tigers are other highlights. CITES's main objective is to ensure that international trade in wild animals and plants does not jeopardize their existence. From its creation in 1963 to the present day, you can see how species have declined while their trade has increased. In this way, it is even more necessary to emphasize that only from international cooperation between different governments will it be possible to combat illegal trade, mafias, and protect wild animals and plants. We are faced with global trade that does not understand borders, so all the actors involved must have a determined will to end this practice that constantly threatens our environment.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora is the most important agreement on the conservation of wild species, with 181 acceding parties including the European Union and its 28 Member States. Whereas the EU is one of the main transit and destination markets for the illegal trade in wild species, in particular birds, turtles, reptiles and plant species included in the lists annexed to CITES; It is clear that its participation in the Convention is a logical consequence of the choices made in the environmental field. The resolution adopted today by Parliament supports the action plan adopted by the EU against wildlife trafficking, encouraging all parties to strengthen cooperation, coordination and synergies between biodiversity conventions. We need new legislation that makes it illegal to import, export, sell and buy wild plants and animals that are caught and possessed in violation of the law of the country of origin or transit. Attacking illegal trade means combating corruption, organised crime and terrorist organisations that profit from trafficking in endangered species.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the key objectives for the 17th CITES CP meeting in Johannesburg as the Union's accession to CITES is essential; it believes that it is a key step in ensuring that the EU can achieve the broader objectives of its environmental policies and the regulation of international trade in threatened species of wildlife, promoting the sustainable development policies of the UN 2030 Agenda.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this Resolution on the key objectives for the 17th meeting of the CITES Conference of the Parties in Johannesburg. It welcomes the EU's accession to CITES and considers this accession a key step in ensuring that the Union can achieve the broader objectives of its environmental policies and the regularisation of international trade in endangered species of wildlife by promoting the sustainable development policies of the 2030 Agenda of the United Nations.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, known by its acronym CITES or the Washington Convention, is an international agreement between states. Its aim is to ensure that the international trade in wild animal and plant specimens does not threaten the survival of the species to which they belong.  This resolution sets out the EU's objectives as a participant in the 17th CONFERENCE of the parties to CITES. Deeply committed to animal protection, I am in favour of this type of agreement. Nevertheless, here the resolution welcomes the EU's accession to CITES, where the EU will now vote in place of the 28 Member States. I do not want the EU to supplant the states, so I voted against it only for that reason.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it is a largely balanced and acceptable text, passages remain that could open up to future critical issues, so I voted with a vote to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Wildlife trafficking has become the fourth largest black market after drugs, human trafficking and the arms market. The EU is an important transit and destination market for illegal wildlife trade in birds, turtles, reptiles and plant species that are subject to high levels of protection under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). An increasing number of exotic species that have been illegally traded are being taken as pets in the EU. In view of the 17th meeting of the CITES Conference of the Parties, I voted in favour of this resolution calling for, among other issues, more measures to combat corruption and deal with organized crime involved in wildlife trafficking, more effective measures to combat illegal trade, the full use of effective sanctions, and joint international cooperation and granting the highest state of conservation (CITES , Annex I) to elephants in Africa, so that a strong political signal is sent for an indefinite ban on the ivory trade in the future.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it has been advocated by Parliament on the main objectives of the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to CITES. CITES is the most important existing world-class wildlife conservation agreement signed by 181 countries, including the EU and its 28 Member States. The aim of CITES is to ensure that international trade in wild animals and plants does not threaten the survival of species in the wild. According to the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) The Red Paper on Endangered Species shows, more than 23 000 species are threatened with extinction, accounting for about 30% of the 79,837 species assessed by the IUCN. Parliament welcomes the recent ADOPTION of the EU Action Plan against wildlife trafficking, which aims to prevent such trade by addressing its root causes, improving the implementation and compliance of existing rules and combating organised wildlife crime more effectively. Parliament also welcomes the inclusion in the Action Plan of a specific chapter on strengthening the global partnership between countries of origin, consumption and transit in the fight against illegal trade in wild animals and plants. Parliament also urges the EU and its Member States to adopt and implement a stronger action plan, thus demonstrating Europe's strong commitment to combating wildlife trafficking.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report. The aim is to ensure that international wildlife and plant trades are not a threat to the survival of this species in the wild. The EU became a signatory to the Convention in 2015. The wildlife trade has become the fourth largest black market after drugs, human smuggling and weapons. The EU is a major transit and destination market due to the illicit trade in wild animals, birds, turtles, reptiles and plant species subject to a high level of protection under CITES. An increasing number of people are illegally trafficking in exotic species kept as pets in the EU. I believe that Member States must show political will and step up efforts to combat the illegal wildlife trade.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a sensitive topic that engages us closely as consumers. Wildlife trafficking is a serious threat to biodiversity and sustainable development. Species such as elephants, rhinos, great apes, tigers and sharks are particularly affected and threatened with extinction. Poaching of elephants and rhinos has reached an all-time high that is compromising restocking. Wildlife trafficking is the fourth illegal activity in the world after drug, arms and human trafficking, with a turnover of around EUR 17 billion per year.  The resolution on the main objectives of COP 17 in Johannesburg proposes tough action to combat corruption and organised crime involved in wildlife trafficking, which is often a funding tool for many criminal organisations (think of the terrorist group Boko Haram in Nigeria).

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today, which focuses on a number of key points on which EU negotiators should focus their attention at the next CITES Conference. Firstly, the traceability of wild species: all parties need to introduce a system of electronic authorisations, which is also useful in the fight against corruption, which is a key factor in the illegal trafficking of endangered species of flora and fauna. Corruption can be detected at every point in the wild species trade chain and affects countries of origin, transit and destination, damaging the effectiveness, proper implementation and ultimate success of CITES. That is why we must insist on the introduction of robust and effective anti-corruption measures and on greater judicial cooperation between Member States. Finally, CITES must provide for the full and immediate application of sanctions against parties that do not comply with the key elements of the Convention.
