The Union and the Member States must use all available instruments to encourage the parties to comply with CITES and the other international agreements referred to in the Convention aimed at protecting wild fauna and flora and biodiversity.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. The motion comes ahead of the 17th meeting of the parties to the Convention on International Trade in in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), of which the EU is now a member (as of 2015), and it calls for further action in cracking down on illegal trafficking of wildlife, which is still widespread.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is important to ensure that international trade in wild animals and plants is not a threat to the survival of species in the wild. We have a moral responsibility to do our utmost to save threatened species from extinction, especially when the EU is found to be a significant transit route and destination market for illegal wildlife trade in species listed in the CITES Agreement. I believe that the penalties for wildlife trafficking offences are not severe enough.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. CITES is the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora and is an international instrument to protect endangered species by controlling international trade in endangered species. The resolution highlights important aspects such as transparency of decision-making, the need to improve reporting of wildlife smuggling, corruption and the implementation of CITES. I voted in favour of the final text.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union acceded to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in 2015. The seventeenth meeting of the Conference of the Parties, which will take place from 21 September to 5 October, will be a very important moment of discussion to present the main objectives for Europe in this area. Cites puts wild species under a very strict protection regime but, given the scale of trafficking and the high profits for criminal organisations, it is clear that a more structured strategy is needed among the countries that sign the Convention. Among the main objectives to be pursued are: the adoption of new measures to combat illegal online trade and, above all, the implementation of more robust actions to combat corruption and organised crime involved in these illicit trafficking. I voted in favour of this resolution because it highlights important aspects in terms of combating international trade managed by cross-border organised crime. I therefore believe it is necessary to take a more effective path to combat this type of trade, especially since the European Union is one of the main markets for transit and destination of endangered species of wild fauna and flora.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline that wildlife smuggling has evolved into the fourth largest black market, following drug trafficking, human trafficking and arms trafficking.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution on the main objectives of the 17th CITES Conference focuses on issues of transparency in decision-making processes, and protection of fauna. I think it is a good effort and I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the line of objectives proposed by my fellow Members since it is a fundamental moment in the fight for the protection of wild flora and fauna. Indeed, I believe that the Conference of the Parties to CITES in Johannesburg, in which the European Union will participate for the first time as a member, will help to combat the illegal trade in wild species, since the EU is one of the main transit and destination markets. Furthermore, I believe that the call for greater transparency in decision-making can contribute to improving the respectability of the organisation and is in line with the principles of democracy and clarity promoted by the Union. I note with regret the increase in illegal activities, especially with regard to trade in products derived from African elephants and tigers, and I hope that EU accession will result in new funding to combat this growing black market.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion on key objectives for the CITES CoP17 meeting in Johannesburg and noted no objections.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ With regard to the motion for a resolution on the EU strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016, this vote is not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention, but this vote is about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure, which we are not prepared to support.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the 17th CITES meeting, in the hope that the decisions at the conference will be taken on the basis of technical and scientific analyses carried out by the states concerned in cooperation with local realities, that is, with the full involvement of rural populations in order to ensure greater protection of the natural heritage.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution of all parliamentary groups in the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment as it makes several positive recommendations for the forthcoming Conference of the Parties (COP) on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be held in South Africa shortly. Since the text emphasizes the importance of transparency in decision-making and action to combat wildlife trafficking and to combat corruption and trafficking in hunting trophies, with particular emphasis on measures to protect african lion, folidot or white rhino, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The CITES convention is the largest international wildlife conservation agreement in existence and it aims to ensure that global trade does not affect the survival of species. Wildlife trafficking is the fourth largest black market. The resolution includes aims to fight corruption and crime, measures for online illegal trade, effective sanctions and the adoption of new EU legislation on illegal animal/plant trade, increased consumer awareness and traceability. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this oral question.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ As a proud proponent of animal welfare, I am pleased to support this resolution. It makes a number of key recommendations on improving the reporting of wildlife trafficking, tackling corruption and establishing international standards on the trade in hunting trophies.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With the adoption of this resolution, Parliament is issuing its recommendations on the EU's strategic objectives for the 17th session of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held from 24 September to 5 October 2016 in Johannesburg. I supported this text, which focuses on sanctions and legislation against the illegal trade in wildlife, as well as cooperation and exchange of information between the States Parties to the Convention. Illegal wildlife trade is now the fourth largest black market and is used by terrorist groups to finance their activities. The UNION, which is participating for the first time in the Conference of the Parties to CITES, will need to lead the way in adopting clear policies to discourage the consumption of derivatives and to raise consumer awareness.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The next international convention on trade in endangered wildlife species will be held in Johannesburg at the end of September 2016. With this in mind, the European Parliament has adopted a resolution on certain key objectives that will need to be discussed during this Convention. These objectives encourage the European Union to commit to the protection of endangered species and to strengthen its legislation against poaching and illegal trade. The resolution includes several proposals to encourage a ban on the ivory trade in member countries and to combat trophy hunting and the exotic animal market. These practices pose a significant threat to a large number of species. Considering biodiversity to be essential, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. 'I fully support the Cites resolution, which rightly emphasises the importance of enforcing existing rules and combating corruption. In the light of the Johannesburg meeting, I would like to call on the Commission and Member States to support a ban on the trade in ivory, without loopholes: illegal ivory always finds its way to the legal circuit. We have to put an end to this, because illegal trade is deadly to biodiversity. A recent Census shows that between 2007 and 2014, 30% of African savannah elephants were poached. That's a whopping 144,000 elephants. The description of elephants as "living dinosaurs" is therefore particularly striking. But the illegal trade has other disastrous and often deadly consequences: the trade spends billions of euros a year in the hands of criminals, militias and terrorist groups, creating insecurity and instability. Moreover, trade is increasing dramatically: the illegal ivory trade has tripled since 1998. A major fight against these criminal activities is needed to ensure the protection of species and safety. The EU can and must make a difference. After all, we are a party involved. This was proven again a few days ago by a record ivory catch of 1.2 tons in Germany.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. At the end of September, the 17th Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) opens in Johannesburg. For the first time, the Union will be part of this major event in the fight against the decline of global biodiversity. With the increase in poaching activities in recent years, many animal and plant species are in danger of disappearing. Illegal trade is now considered a major network of international organized crime. Its turnover is estimated at $20 billion, the fourth largest black market in the world. The EU has recently adopted an action plan to make the fight against wildlife trafficking a priority. This requires closer collaboration between the countries of origin, destination and transit affected by these illicit trades, as well as a broader definition of illegal trade flows, including import, export, sale, acquisition or purchase of threatened species.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text sets out the EU's key objectives as a participant in the 17th Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, which will take place from 24 September to 5 October 2016 in Johannesburg. There is certainly an urgent need to regulate this trade and protect species by strengthening the licensing system and completing the classification of CITES Schedules I, II and III, which reflect the seriousness of the situation. Unfortunately, this resolution welcomes the EU's accession to the CITES Convention, by which the EU will now vote on behalf of the 28 Member States, who are already all parties to CITES, on matters under EU competence. However, this was not the case before the EU joined CITES in 2015. Since the EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on major issues of international cooperation, I voted against this resolution.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this file as it is important that we do everything we can to protect wild animals and prevent the illegal use of them, including common wildlife products. I was pleased to see that the proposal makes specific recommendations to CITES on issues such as decision-making transparency, improved reporting, wildlife tracking, anti-corruption measures, etc.  The draft text also supports proposals made by the EU and its Member States, in particular the proposed anti-corruption resolutions and the establishment of standards applicable to international trade in hunting trophies. Bulgaria also has a very rich flora and fauna and the preservation of wildlife everywhere is an important element for the preservation of the natural balance and our history. That is why I strongly support recent developments in order to more effectively enforce action against illegal trade and barbaric acts that destroy these beautiful species, affecting not only us, but also depriving all generations coming after us.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The fact that the EP is hereby strongly opposed to opacity and the use of secret ballots as a general practice within CITES is incompatible with its proposal to allocate sufficient appropriations to the CITES Secretariat and to increase funding to CITES.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 17th meeting of the Contracting Parties to the Conference on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) will mark a crucial moment in the efforts we must make to preserve biodiversity globally. I therefore hope that in Johannesburg the EU and its Member States will be able to put in place, with conviction, all the negotiating skills necessary to promote an ever higher level of protection by introducing further restrictions on international trade in endangered species. It will be an opportunity to discuss the conservation status of the species listed in Annexes I and II to the Convention and to amend the conventional text in the light of a reflection on its actual implementation. I would also like to point out that a number of issues relating to cites are the subject of wide-ranging reflection by european public opinion. Indeed, many European citizens, exercising their right to petition, are turning to the European Parliament to call for the introduction of a ban on the import of hunting trophies into the EU. My vote on this resolution can only be in favour, as it focuses, among other things, on the need to improve the instruments for reporting the smuggling of wild fauna and flora and, more generally, the application of CITES.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 CITES, with 181 Parties, including the EU and its 28 Member States, is the largest existing agreement in the world on wildlife conservation and according to the red list of endangered species drawn up by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN), more than 23 000 species representing about 30 % of the 79 837 species assessed by the IUCN , are at risk of extinction. EU Member States have declared the import of almost 117 000 specimens of wild species as game trophies, these species in the CITES Convention annexes for a period of ten years.  I agree with the EU's membership of CITES because it is a key step in ensuring that the EU can achieve the more general objectives of its environmental policies, as well as the regulation of international trade in endangered species of wild flora and fauna.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I am voting against it, as the EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on major issues of international cooperation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The fact that the EP is hereby strongly opposed to opacity and the use of secret ballots as a general practice within CITES is incompatible with its proposal to allocate sufficient appropriations to the CITES Secretariat and to increase funding to it, which is why I am voting against the motion for a resolution.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution focuses on general issues and gives strong backing to the EU proposal calling specifically for robust action to fight corruption and tackle organised crime involved in wildlife trafficking; more effective measures for tackling illegal online trade; full use of effective sanctions; and joint international cooperation on law enforcement. Member States must show political will and step up efforts to combat the illegal wildlife trade taking place within the EU. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the main objectives of the CoP17 meeting in Johannesburg. Eu accession to CITES is an essential step towards meeting the broader objectives of the Union's environmental policy and ensuring regulation of international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora and promoting UN sustainable development policies for the period up to 2030. Its accession to the Convention has made the status of the European Union within CITES more transparent. This is a logical and necessary step to ensure that the European Union can fully meet the objectives of its environmental policy.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Wildlife trafficking is the fourth black market after drugs, human trade, drugs and the illicit arms market. Yet I doubt it is a universally recognised problem. Instead, 181 countries around the world will meet in Johannesburg on 2 September to talk about the protection of wildlife, including the 28 EU countries. And the adoption of this text today will give Europe the opportunity to make its contribution so that we can put a real stop to this crime and corruption. The message that Parliament is sending out today with this vote is clear and unequivocal: the commitment to increased controls and a call for international cooperation against illegal trade, which also runs online, certain rules and sanctions, the extension of traceability measures and the proposal for a maximum conservation status for African elephants, which we hope will result in an absolute ban on the trade in ivory as soon as possible.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the EU's strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be held from 24 September to 5 October 2016 in Johannesburg, because I consider it essential to find a common understanding to regulate international hunting of endangered species and preserve plant biodiversity. I believe it is crucial that the EU plays a leading role in the CITES negotiations, as it is unfortunately one of the main transit and destination markets for the illegal trade in protected animal and plant species, which often end up in our homes as ornamental plants or pets. I therefore agree with the call in the resolution to step up the fight against corruption and poaching, to more effective rules to regulate online trade and to prohibit the import, export, sale or purchase of plants or animals sold in violation of the laws of the country of origin or transit. It is now up to the Member States to implement these agreements and to apply effective and effective sanctions to put an end to irregularities and combat illegal hunting inside and outside the EU.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), in German referred to as the Washington Convention on the Protection of Species of Species (WA), was concluded as early as 1973 in view of the dramatic decline in many species caused by poaching and trade. I support the report, which sets out clear key objectives for the 17th Conference of the Parties to the CITES Convention in Johannesburg, South Africa, and calls for more international species protection.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. CITES is an international convention whose purpose is the protection of wildlife, especially protected species.  France is, of course, a signatory to this convention, like all the other Member States of the Union.  The Objectives of the Union are certainly laudable, but this text takes advantage of good intentions to nibble again on the sovereignty of States by substituting the Union for the Member States in this Convention, which was not the case until then.  Beyond the attack on our sovereignty, this substitution will not make it more effective. On the contrary, flora and fauna are so diverse that the state is precisely the right scale to act. The danger to many species and the inefficiency, even the nuisance of European policies, convinced me to vote against this text.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the key objectives for the 17th CITES CP meeting in Johannesburg as the Union's accession to CITES is essential; it believes that it is a key step in ensuring that the EU can achieve the broader objectives of its environmental policies and the regulation of international trade in threatened species of wildlife, promoting the sustainable development policies of the UN 2030 Agenda.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I wanted to support this text to give Parliament's guidance on the key objectives of the forthcoming Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. The protection of biodiversity is a key issue, and Europe must be more effective in combating trafficking and illegal trade in poaching products (e.g. elephant ivory), of which it is an important hub. In particular, the report insists on revising the existing legislative framework so that the import, export, transport, acquisition and possession of protected species in their countries of origin, and therefore illegally obtained or sold in third countries, is automatically banned in Europe.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. – We voted in favour of the report which contains many positive points, particularly with regard to the regulation on wild animals, which should incentivise rural populations to participate in nature conservation by linking their benefits to the state of biodiversity. In addition, the report highlights the need to increase the funding available for the conservation of wild flora and fauna as well as the financing of capacity-building programmes.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ With regard to the motion for a resolution on the EU strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016, this vote is not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention, but this vote is about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure, which we are not prepared to support.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on the EU's strategic objectives for 17 October 2013. meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Animals and Plants (CITES) to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016, as I consider that the endangered species, which this proposal speaks of, should be preserved from extinction, extermination, smuggling and poaching considered the fourth largest illegal market in the world.  Given that the EU has signed the world's largest wildlife conservation agreement - CITES, wider environmental policy objectives should be ensured and international trade in endangered species of wild flora and fauna should be regulated and sustainable development policies promoted by the 2030 UN Agenda. I believe that joint international cooperation among all actors in the law enforcement chain is of utmost importance in order to strengthen law enforcement capacities at local, regional, national and international level.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The protection of endangered wildlife is a just and necessary cause. Unfortunately, this resolution welcomes the EU's accession to the CITES Convention, by which the EU will now vote on behalf of the 28 Member States, who are already all parties to CITES, on matters under EU competence. This provision did not exist before the EU joined CITES in 2015, and is of no use. It is a vain prerogative for the fight against the trade in wild animals and a detrimental element to the Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – With regard to the motion for a resolution on the EU strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016, this vote is not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention, but this vote is about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure, which we are not prepared to support.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to give Parliament guidance on the key objectives of the next Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora to be held in Johannesburg at the end of September. The text reiterates the importance of protecting species of flora and fauna threatened by poaching and illegal trade, underscoring the role that organized crime plays in these activities. It is important to fight in particular against the customers of this traffic.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution contains perfectly correct approaches to environmental protection, but at the same time establishes an insufficiently substantiated link between trophy hunting and species extinction. That is why I am abstaining on this motion for a resolution.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. – I supported the proposed EU strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). The proposed resolution is an important step towards following, upholding and meeting the EU's objectives relating to environmental policies and the regulation of international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora, as well as the EU's commitments on sustainable development set out in the 2030 Agenda.  I believe that the resolution is of utmost importance given that the EU is a major market for transit and for the illegal wildlife trade. Wildlife trafficking must be seen as an organised transnational crime that negatively affects biodiversity, is de-attacking animal welfare and is affecting the budget of countries and the EU. It is necessary to adopt comprehensive legislation that reduce illegal trade and criminally against flora and fauna committed in contravention of the laws of the country of origin, transit and the EU.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution welcomes the EU's accession to CITES. This is a key step as it seeks to ensure that the EU can be guaranteed to be able to pursue the objectives of its environmental policies and the regulation of international trade in endangered species of flora and fauna, as well as to promote the sustainable development policies of the UN 2030 Agenda. The EU is also called on to adopt immediately all appropriate strategies to reduce illegal trade, making it illegal to import, sell, purchase plants or wild animals that are caught, owned, transported or sold in violation of the law of the country of origin. The proposal aims to promote and support all initiatives aimed at improving the welfare of live animals listed in CITES during marketing, while also seeking to minimise the risk of injury, damage to health or ill-treatment.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it welcomes the EU's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora ("CITES"). However, this accession deprives France of one of its competences, since from now on the EU will vote for it at the CITES conferences.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This resolution welcomes the EU's accession to the CITES Convention, by which the EU will now vote on behalf of the 28 Member States, who are already all parties to CITES. However, this was not the case before the EU joined CITES in 2015. Since the EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on major issues of international cooperation, I voted against this resolution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution of all parliamentary groups in the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment as it makes several positive recommendations for the forthcoming Conference of the Parties (COP) on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be held in South Africa shortly. Since the text emphasizes the importance of transparency in decision-making and action to combat wildlife trafficking and to combat corruption and trafficking in hunting trophies, with particular emphasis on measures to protect african lion, folidot or white rhino, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. While I do not agree with the killing or mutilation of animals for trophies, I also do not agree with the abuse of this topic in the fight against bitcoin. I consider the requirement that the parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species examine whether "emerging financial products and technologies, e.g. bitcoin", accidentally allow "species extinction speculation" as an effort to combat new technologies and bitcoin. Let states prosecute the illegal trade in animals, but don't let alternative currencies be caught up in it.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because it calls on the European Union to apply the precautionary principle in all its decisions and listing proposals. The resolution encourages Member States to promote initiatives designed to improve the welfare, during marketing, of live animals listed in CITES. It must be ensured that each specimen is prepared and shipped in such a way as to minimise the risk of injury, damage to health or cruel treatment, and that the destination is adequately equipped to host it. I express strong support for the listing proposals submitted by the EU to regulate strictly the trade in Barbary Macaques and African Grey parrots, both endangered species. Corruption in the trade in wild species can be found at any point of the trade chain, therefore it is essential to introduce solid and effective anti-corruption measures in the fight against wildlife trafficking.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ CITES is the world's largest wildlife conservation agreement, with 181 parties to the convention, including the EU. CITES aims to ensure that international trade in wildlife and plants does not threaten the survival of these species in the wild. According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) Red List of Endangered Species, more than 23,000 species are at risk of extinction, about 30% of species estimated by the IUCN, and the illegal trade in wild animal and plant species is the fourth largest black market. The EU is a major transit and destination market for the illicit wildlife trade, in particular for the trade in birds, turtles, reptiles and plant species, so the EU's accession to CITES is a key step to ensure the continuation of the European environmental policy objectives and regulate international trade in endangered species. This will also continue to promote the sustainable development policies of the 2030 UN Agenda, so I supported this resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the EU's strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties (CoP 17) to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held from 24 September to 5 October 2016 in Johannesburg (South Africa), for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/9/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The resolution welcomes the EU's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), which has already been joined by 27 Member States. Although we are in favour of the supervision of this trade and the protection of species, we believe that the EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on the major issues of international cooperation, which is why we oppose this text.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 CITES is the most important existing world-class wildlife conservation agreement signed by 181 countries. In the light of the upcoming meeting of these countries this year, the EP has drafted a resolution highlighting the biggest problems in wildlife conservation and setting out political guidelines to ensure that international wildlife trade does not threaten the survival of species.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This resolution provides a number of recommendations to the European Commission and Member States ahead of next month's next international conference on international trade in endangered wildlife species (CITES). Its Convention helps combat wildlife-related crime and illegal trade. Illegal trafficking of these species is the 4th largest black market in the world. The text supports many proposals by States to protect new species increasingly threatened by human activity and global warming or to ban the trade of some others, such as elephants, for example, whose ivory trade feeds many paramilitary groups. It calls on EU Member States and the Commission to go beyond existing international arrangements. It calls for greater transparency and vigilance in CITES' decision-making process, potential conflicts of interest and proven cases of internal corruption. I welcome this resolution to which my friend Younous Omarjee has contributed greatly. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This resolution welcomes the EU's accession to the CITES Convention, by which the EU will now vote on behalf of the 28 Member States, who were already all parties to CITES. Since the EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on major issues of international cooperation, I voted against this resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 CITES, with 181 Parties, including the EU and its 28 Member States, is the world's largest existing agreement on wildlife conservation.  CITES aims to ensure that international trade in wild animals and plants does not pose a threat to the survival of these species in the natural environment.  EU membership of CITES is a key step in ensuring that the EU can achieve the more general objectives of its environmental policies, as well as regulating international trade in endangered species of wild flora and fauna, and promoting the sustainable development policies of the UN 2030 Agenda.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it welcomes the Union’s accession to CITES and stresses the need for the Union to take further measures to curb illegal trade in animals and plants.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The illegal trade in endangered species of animals and plants is the fourth largest organised crime activity after drug, human and arms trafficking. This cross-border crime not only has immense implications for biodiversity; illegal trade is detrimental to local economic development, encourages corruption and is used by militias as a source for the financing of conflicts. The EU is an important destination market for and transit port of endangered species of animals and plants. With its own action plan against wildlife trade, the EU, which has joined CITES, wants to step up its efforts to stop the illegal trade. This resolution calls for initiatives to establish global directives to reduce poaching and illegal trade, to establish better international controls and to ensure effective international prosecution for individuals engaged in criminal activities involving wildlife. In any case, it is encouraging that at the Johannesburg meeting a large number of African countries will send out the signal that they are determined to stop the extinction of the African elephant.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – From 24 September to 5 October 2016, the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) will be held in Johannesburg. The objective of the Convention is to ensure that international trade in these animals and plants does not jeopardise the survival of these species in the wild. The Union, which has been a Party to the Convention since July 2015, considers CITES to be a key international convention for the protection of biodiversity and the fight against trafficking. The Union will focus on the following priorities at the Conference: making full use of CITES instruments to regulate international trade in endangered species of animals and plants subject to unsustainable international trade, in line with scientifically sound practice, strengthening the international community's response to wildlife trade, and emphasis will also be placed on improving transparency and accountability within CITES and ensuring that appropriate procedures are agreed. The Union's objectives and priorities set are in line with the relevant Policies of the Union and its international commitments in this area, so I am voting in favour of the resolution in favour.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for measures to combat the illegal wildlife trade taking place within the EU.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has proposed to adopt a resolution on the EU strategic objectives for the 17th Meeting of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) between 24 September and 5 October 2016 in Johannesburg, South Africa. The draft welcomes the EU's accession to CITES and the fact that, for the first time, the EU is now a party to the conference. The draft specifically mentions the adoption of measures to protect and protect some endangered species of animals and plants, such as african elephants, wide-mouthed rhinos, African lions, cones, tigers and Asian big cats, as well as agarwood and rosewood. I supported the adoption of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the EU's key objectives as a participant in the 17th Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). Of course, there is an urgent need to regulate this trade and to protect species, in particular by strengthening the licensing system. But CITES welcomes the EU's accession to the Convention as the sole representative. None of the 28 Member States will be able to make their voices heard and vote because it is now a matter within the EU's competence. As this situation is an attack on the sovereignty of States, we are voting against this resolution.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Since the EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on major issues of international cooperation, I am voting against this resolution.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which gives Parliament guidance on the key objectives of the next Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora to be held at the end of September 2016 in Johannesburg. This text reminds us that it is essential for biodiversity to protect endangered species, in particular by combating poaching and the illegal trade in these species, of which Europe is a hub.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is a major global player in the world, so I particularly welcomed its accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Flora. Cites' number one objective is to prevent the extinction of wild fauna and flora as a result of international trade. The strategy will normally be discussed by members at a conference in Johannesburg this year, and the European Union, which will join as the 181st member, will also represent its position. I believe that the European Parliament's motion for a resolution adequately reflects our priorities in this area.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild fauna and Flora (CITES) was drafted as a result of a resolution adopted in 1963 following a meeting of members of the International Union for Conservation of Nature. As an international agreement between governments, it aims to ensure that international trade in species of wild animals and plants does not threaten their survival. I voted for this motion for a resolution setting out objectives for the CITES CoP17 Conference.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. The motion comes ahead of the 17th meeting of the parties to the Convention on International Trade in in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), of which the EU is now a member (as of 2015), and it calls for further action in cracking down on illegal trafficking of wildlife, which is still widespread.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Convention on trade in wild fauna and flora is essential to protect the survival of endangered species in the wild. Being a party to the Convention and participating in its activities will help the EU to promote environmental policy and regulation of international trade and to contribute more broadly to the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development Policy.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ With regard to the motion for a resolution on the EU strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016, this vote is not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention, but this vote is about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure, which we are not prepared to support.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In thanking the rapporteur for his work and also following the debate in the ENVI Committee, I would confirm my positive opinion.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's Resolution on the EU's strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Animals and Plants (CITES). CITES Convention is the only successful globally established system for the protection of endangered species and it is necessary that it develops further to protect endangered species as much as possible.  The EU's accession to the Convention was just one of the administrative steps necessary to better implement it. It is up to the Member States to strengthen and fully implement this system. According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) Red List of Endangered Species, more than 23,000 species are at risk of extinction, about 30% of the 79837 species estimated by the IUCN. If we know that illegal trade in species is the most lucrative illegal business after drug, arms and human trafficking, it is clear that criminal groups are finding refuge in this nih.  By monitoring international trade, it is possible to prevent environmental devastation and the extermination of endangered species. Unfortunately, during the 1990s, precisely because of flawed regulations, the devastation of the Adriatic was made possible by excessive finger-toeing. In Croatia in wartime and post-war times, some benefited from the lack of proper supervision, and this situation is still today in most unstable countries of Asia and Africa. It's our obligation to help them.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the EU's key objectives as a participant in the 17th Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be held from 24 September to 5 October in Johannesburg. There is certainly an urgent need to regulate this trade and protect species by strengthening the licensing system and completing the classification of CITES Schedules I, II and III, which reflect the seriousness of the situation. Unfortunately, this resolution welcomes the EU's accession to the CITES Convention, by which the EU will now vote on behalf of the 28 Member States, who are already all parties to CITES, on matters under EU competence. However, this was not the case before the EU joined CITES in 2015. Since the EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on major issues of international cooperation, I am voting against this resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which sets out the European Parliament's position on the key objectives of the 17th Conference of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, to be held in Johannesburg at the end of September. It stresses the importance of protecting these species threatened by illegal trade, poaching, organized crime and which fuel corruption and trafficking in some countries of the world. The European Union cannot remain a hub for these illegal businesses.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ With regard to the motion for a resolution on the EU strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016, this vote is not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention, but this vote is about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure, which we are not prepared to support.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour because it is imperative to ensure that international trade in wild animals and plants does not pose a threat to the survival of these species in the natural environment.  Wildlife trafficking is now an organised transnational crime that has major negative impacts on biodiversity and the livelihoods of local populations, as it denies legal income, creating insecurity and instability. More and more illegally marketed exotic species are treated as domestic animals in Europe and the rest of the world, and the escape of these animals can lead to uncontrolled dissemination, with consequences for the public environment and health and safety.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The European Union joined CITES 11 months ago. An essential step forward, and a work that remains immense!  Whenever the fate of one species improves, such as the giant panda, another species is added to the IUCN Red List of "critically endangered" species. This is the case of the great eastern gorilla, victim of intense poaching in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and now in great danger. The EU has a vital role to play in Johannesburg.  It must dare to shake up certain strategic partners, such as China or Japan, and put the sensitive issue of trade in elephant ivory, rhino horn and tiger bones on the agenda. Europe, on the other hand, as an important transit market, must lead by example. It is unacceptable that participants in these criminal traffickings incur, in some EU countries, only minimum penalties, i.e. fines of up to EUR 15,000 in a majority of Member States, while rhino horn on the black market reaches EUR 51,000 per kilo. Sanctions must be harmonized and exemplary.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Wildlife trafficking has become the fourth largest black market after drugs, human trafficking and the arms market. The EU is an important transit and destination market for illegal wildlife trade in birds, turtles, reptiles and plant species that are subject to high levels of protection under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). An increasing number of exotic species that have been illegally traded are being taken as pets in the EU. In view of the 17th meeting of the CITES Conference of the Parties, I voted in favour of this resolution calling for, among other issues, more measures to combat corruption and deal with organized crime involved in wildlife trafficking, more effective measures to combat illegal trade, the full use of effective sanctions, and joint international cooperation and granting the highest state of conservation (CITES , Annex I) to elephants in Africa, so that a strong political signal is sent for an indefinite ban on the ivory trade in the future.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the EU's strategic objectives for the 17th session of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held from 24 September to 5 October 2016 in Johannesburg, South Africa.  Indeed, wildlife trafficking has evolved into a form of transnational organized crime that is severely detrimental to global biodiversity.  The European Union must play an important role in this fight. In this regard, I welcome the EU's financial contribution to CITES. However, we must continue to be vigilant about the issue of legal and illegal trade, which is tenuous in the marketing of cash and their derivatives.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The european union(EU)'s membership of CITES was a key step in ensuring that the EU and its Member States achieve the more general objectives of their environmental policies by improving the regulation of international trade in endangered species of wild flora and fauna and promoting the sustainable development policies of the UN 2030 Agenda. This is the first time that the EU has presented itself as a party to the Convention, making relevant proposals, in particular on the fight against corruption and regulation of the regime on hunting trophies. I would like to highlight the recent adoption of the EU Action Plan against wildlife trafficking, which aims to combat wildlife-related organised crime more effectively, which should also be implemented by Member States as a means of demonstrating the importance of combating this type of crime. Finally, I would also like to mention the importance of encouraging the EU and the Member States to promote initiatives to increase protection against the impact of international trade in species, for which the EU is an important transit or destination market, by creating legislation aimed at reducing its illegal trade.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which echoes Parliament's guidance on the key objectives of the forthcoming Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). The 17th CONFERENCE of the parties to CITES will be held at the end of September in Johannesburg, South Africa.  As this resolution reminds us, it is crucial to protect species threatened by international trafficking and poaching. It is also undeniable that organized crime plays a leading role in the organization of this illegal trade, a source of corruption. I supported this text because it stresses the need to penalize customers of this trafficking, as well as poachers.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the key objectives for the 17th CITES CP meeting in Johannesburg as the Union's accession to CITES is essential; it believes that it is a key step in ensuring that the EU can achieve the broader objectives of its environmental policies and the regulation of international trade in threatened species of wildlife, promoting the sustainable development policies of the UN 2030 Agenda.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ Evidence that the illegal trade in wildlife has become the fourth biggest black market, after drugs, people smuggling and the illegal arms trade, underlines the fact that the importance of CITES is not only environmental. The EU is a large market for this illegal trade and also plays a role in transiting wildlife to other markets around the world. More dissuasive sanctions and improved enforcement regimes are needed to provide effective deterrents, and this requires more resources for national authorities and better international cooperation. I welcome the proposal in this resolution for new EU legislation on importing and selling illegally caught wildlife, which would probably involve the expansion of traceability measures. This would be an important step.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution of all parliamentary groups in the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment as it makes several positive recommendations for the forthcoming Conference of the Parties (COP) on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be held in South Africa shortly. Since the text emphasizes the importance of transparency in decision-making and action to combat wildlife trafficking and to combat corruption and trafficking in hunting trophies, with particular emphasis on measures to protect african lion, folidot or white rhino, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. This report points to clues to a marked improvement in the CITES Convention. Among many, I would like to like to support the proposal to strengthen control over ivory certifications, to strengthen sanctions for the trafficking of protected species (including elephants, rhinos, tigers, primates and tropical wood varieties) and to challenge the development of additional techniques and methodologies to distinguish species from production facilities in wild species.  I hope that all these suggestions will be taken into account during CITES COP 17 and that this will help to combat corruption and protect biodiversity.  For all these reasons, I voted positively for this report.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution on the EU's strategic objectives for the Conference on Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, as I consider it irresponsible to trade species on the brink of extinction. Cites convention on international trade in endangered species of flora and fauna brings together 181 countries around the world. I therefore welcome the fact that the EU has also finally become a signatory to this agreement in 2015. The Conference of the Parties to the Convention will take place at the turn of September and October, where the EU should take a clear and united stance, as wildlife trade has become the fourth most profitable black market after drug trafficking, human smuggling and arms trafficking. Moreover, the EU is the main transit and destination for the most endangered species under the protection of the Convention, such as wild birds, turtles, reptiles and various plant species. I therefore agree with the resolution calling for tougher sanctions in the fight against corruption and organised crimes of smuggling endangered species. It will also be necessary to take effective measures against online trafficking, as well as to move forward with international law enforcement cooperation. Last but not least, consumer sensitivity to products derived from endangered species will need to be increased. The conference will be a unique opportunity to consolidate international cooperation that is indispensable in the protection of the environment.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ we can only prevent the illegal trade in rare and protected plant and animal species by cooperating governments and relevant institutions at global level. As in many other cases, the European Union is the entity that sets up a high-quality legal framework that serves as a model for other countries.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the European Union's strategic objectives for the 17th session of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in Johannesburg, South Africa (2016/2664(RSP)) from 24 September to 5 October 2016. Member States are already parties to CITES, so there is no reason for the EU to be a member. A resolution to give the Commission a negotiating mandate is also superfluous.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ CITES is the world's largest wildlife conservation agreement, with 181 parties to the convention, including the EU and its 28 Member States. Taking into account the severity of the reduction in global biodiversity, representing the sixth wave of mass extinction of species, as well as the role of forests and tropical forests representing the world's largest terrestrial biodiversity reserve, and cites' very objective of ensuring that international trade in wildlife and plants does not threaten the survival of these species in the wild, will be held the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Animals and Plants (CITES) in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016. I support the proposal for a resolution on the EU's strategic objectives for the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Animals and Plants (CITES) to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution to the oral questions on the EU's strategic objectives for the 17th Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, to be held from 24 September to 5 October 2016 in Johannesburg, South Africa.  With the Accession of the European Union to CITES, the legal status of the EU in this Convention has made it more transparent for third countries parties to the Convention. The European Union is thus fully able to achieve its environmental policy objectives.  The resolution also recalls that, on behalf of the EU, the Commission can, on the basis of accession, represent a coherent EU position on the functioning of the Convention and that it can play an essential role in the negotiations at the Conferences of the Parties.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The fact that the European Parliament is hereby strongly opposed to opacity and the use of secret ballots as a general practice within CITES is incompatible with its proposal to allocate sufficient appropriations to and increase funding to the CITES Secretariat.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora is the world's largest Convention for the Conservation of Global Wildlife, with the participation of 181 Member States. Wildlife trafficking is the fourth largest black market area (after the trafficking of drugs, people and weapons) and this illegal trade also affects the EU. The motion calls for decisive action against corruption and organised crime in relation to wildlife trade; calls for more effective measures against illegal online trade; calls for an effective system of sanctions, for consumer awareness to be raised and for traceability to be strengthened. Against this background, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution and I Hungary actively participate in complying with these commitments. I believe that the political elite in Hungary, which wants to hunt, cannot afford to arbitrarily change the list of protected animals, but rather I suggest that they do their best to act together.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Wildlife and Wildlife (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from the end of this month, will be an important moment for the re-establishment of EU strategic objectives in this area. As CITES is the largest global agreement in place on the conservation of wild life, ratified by 181 states, including the EU and 28 Member States, it can become the most important tool to combat illegal wildlife trafficking, which has become the fourth largest black market, after drug, human and arms trafficking. The EU is a major transit and destination market for the illegal trafficking of birds, turtles, reptiles and wild plants protected within CITES. The Union's position must therefore focus on combating organised crime and corruption linked to wildlife trafficking, combating illegal online trade, the use of effective sanctions, the prohibition of the marketing of protected wildlife species within the EU, transport detection measures and the prohibition of the marketing of ivory. These are perfectly justified objectives and I support the adoption of this resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. With this text, we welcome the EU's accession to CITES. This accession is a fundamental step forward in ensuring that the EU pursues the broader objectives of its environmental policies and the regulation of international trade in endangered wildlife species and species, as well as the promotion of the UN's 2030 sustainable development policies.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution setting out our key priorities for the upcoming World Wildlife Conference in Johannesburg – a conference to discuss measures for tackling the unprecedented level of poaching and the trafficking of illegal wildlife products. I believe that all countries should step up their efforts to enforce the CITES rules, combat related corruption, strengthen border control at crossing points, and toughen the sanctions against criminal traffickers of these products. This summit will also be a unique opportunity for the EU to speak with one voice on the implementation of a European wildlife action plan, and to reaffirm its wider commitment to promoting the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Motions for resolutions - Key objectives for the CITES CoP17 meeting in Johannesburg, because species protected by CITES are at risk of extinction and trafficking is prohibited.  Trophy hunting is not ethical and sustainable, it is a direct cause of the decline of biodiversity and endangered species.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the key objectives for the 17th CITES CP meeting in Johannesburg as the Union's accession to CITES is essential; it believes that it is a key step in ensuring that the EU can achieve the broader objectives of its environmental policies and the regulation of international trade in threatened species of wildlife, promoting the sustainable development policies of the UN 2030 Agenda.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour and I support this report. I believe the EU should do its utmost and play its role in the protection and safeguarding of our natural resources – fauna, flora, nature, wildlife, countryside – and I am committed to this. Preserving biodiversity must also be ensured through binding international and regional environmental protection measures and agreements.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the EU's key objectives as a participant in the 17th Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be held from 24 September to 5 October in Johannesburg.  There is certainly an urgent need to regulate this trade and to protect species by strengthening the licensing system. Unfortunately, this resolution welcomes the EU's accession to the CITES Convention, by which the EU will now vote on behalf of the 28 Member States, who are already all parties to CITES, on matters under EU competence. However, this was not the case before the EU joined CITES in 2015.  Since the EU does not have to supplant the role of sovereign states on major issues of international cooperation, I voted against this resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The question has previously been raised as to the main strategic objectives of the European Union at the forthcoming Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in Johannesburg, South Africa, between 24 September and 5 October 2016. In the final vote of the related document, I said yes.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the key objectives for the 17th MEETING of the CITES CP in Johannesburg as the Union's accession to CITES is essential; it believes that it is a key step in ensuring that the EU can achieve the broader objectives of its environmental policies and the regulation of international trade in threatened species of wildlife, promoting the sustainable development policies of the UN 2030 Agenda.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the key objectives for the CITES CoP17 meeting in Johannesburg. The Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), to be held in Johannesburg (South Africa) from 24 September to 5 October 2016 is the largest global wildlife conservation agreement in existence, with 181 parties, including the EU and its 28 Member States. The aim of CITES is to ensure that international trade in wild animals and plants is not a threat to the survival of the species in the wild. I voted in favour because I believe that the accession to CITES of the European Union has rendered the Union’s legal status in respect of CITES more transparent vis-à-vis third parties to the Convention.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties (COP17) of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in Johannesburg, South Africa, from 24 September to 5 October 2016, and due to the fact that the EU participates for the first time as part of CITES, the coordinators of the ENVI Commission decided to submit an oral question to the Council and the Commission , together with a motion for a resolution. The resolution addresses the main topics of the upcoming COP17 and makes a number of recommendations, including on transparency in decision-making and reporting, on wildlife trafficking and corruption, enforcement and financing. The text supports the proposals put forward by the EU and its Member States, in particular the proposed resolutions on corruption and hunting trophies, the extension of CITES to the protection of a number of species that are imported into the EU, such as pets, and proposals to change the control of trade in personal and domestic goods.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Johannesburg Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES) will take place in Johannesburg from 24 September to 5 October, where the EU will act as a party for the first time. CITIES is an intergovernmental agreement aimed at ensuring that trade in endangered species does not cause their extinction.  I supported this report because it contains concrete recommendations on transparency in decision-making, on improving reporting, funding and application of the law, on anti-trafficking and corruption legislation, and on species-specific proposals.  The project also supports proposals from the EU and its Member States, in particular on combating corruption and establishing standards for trophy hunting, as well as extending the scope of CITES to protect certain species imported into the EU as pets and certain moving objects.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The resolution of the ENVI Parliamentary Committee outlines the views and objectives of the European Parliament in the context of the 17th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Agreement on International Trade in Endangered Species of Fauna and Flora (CITES), which will be held in Johannesburg at the turn of September and October this year. Cites aims to ensure that international trade does not jeopardise the survival of endangered plant and animal species. The conference will discuss 62 proposals to increase or reduce controls in international trade affecting many endangered species. At the same time, there will also be talk of how to introduce as much transparency as possible into decision-making processes and how best to grasp the fight against the smuggling of endangered species or corruption. In addition to the general provisions, the report also deals in more detail with several endangered species of plants and animals.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution stipulating the main objectives of the 17th session of the Conference of the Parties to the CITES Convention, for agreeing with the European Parliament's position on what is the largest existing agreement in the world on wildlife conservation. Unfortunately, the Union is now an important market for the destination and transit of the illegal trade in wild species, in particular birds, turtles, reptiles and species of flora. In this context, I particularly welcome the EU's membership of CITES, especially because the EU participates for the first time as a party, making the EU's legal status in CITES more transparent and confirming the EU's role in multilateralism.  This accession will allow the EU to express a coherent position on CITES issues and participate substantially in the negotiations of the Conferences of the Parties.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The 'Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora' (CITES) is an instrument of protection that provides for the control of international trade in these endangered species. In view of the next meeting of the parties, to be held in South Africa from 24 September to 5 October 2016, the ENVI Committee of the European Parliament has decided to put the following oral question to the European Commission with a resolution: "Can the Commission explain the main strategic objectives for the European Union at the next Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) , to be held in Johannesburg, South Africa, from 24 September to 5 October 2016?" This initiative, which I voted in favour of, is intended to highlight the need for transparency in the decision-making process, the need to improve the reporting of wildlife smuggling, the fight against corruption and the implementation of CITES.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I was happy to support this proposal because, as a member of the IMCO Committee, I consider the digital market to be the main issue on this committee's agenda for this parliamentary term. However, the digital market can only work, e.g. selling goods online, if online goods can be delivered quickly and cheaply across Europe. Therefore, the question of post office, the issue of forwarding and cutting borders between countries is extremely important, it is not just about how packages will be sold more dearly, but if we want a digital economy, we need to be able to transport goods electronically in Europe quickly, so that is a good proposal.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ní raibh aon fhadhb agam vótáil le mo ghrúpa sna cúig vóta a bhain leis an tuarascáil seo. Ó thaobh mhuintir na hÉireann... I would like to say that, faced with the decline of the rural post office network, I would be eager to emphasise the value and the presence of our postal services, which are indeed changing but are nonetheless vital to our communication sector and in terms of employment. The 2008 Third Postal Services Directive encouraged the completion of the internal market in this domain. However, in line with this report, I would call for the Commission to assist Member States in their efforts to implement such policies effectively on a national and regional level. We appreciate the vital role that this sector plays in the spheres of communication and employment whilst also boosting economic and territorial cohesion across the EU and in the single market.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to check the status of postal services in the EU following the revision of the relevant directive in 2008. It stresses the need to ensure fair and non-discriminatory access to vocational training, as well as an essential universal service of quality and accessible conditions, with special guarantees for citizens with disabilities. We are therefore calling for a guaranteed minimum level of service for consumers, with transparency in prices and delivery conditions. Finally, it stresses the need to ensure decent working conditions for all workers, including the necessary level of protection of health and safety at work. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 We will vote in favour of this dossier, which puts a substantial update on the issue of postal services, which more than others suffer from keeping up with the enormous and rapid changes dictated by the digitalisation of services and the exponential growth of e-commerce.  Since 2008, public postal services have suffered from the proliferation of offers from private operators and in some Member States, such as Italy, they are much less competitive than private individuals and not at all economically viable.  The digitisation of services and systems such as parcel or mail traceability itself is often cumbery and difficult to access compared to the same services offered by the private sector. And this, with an increasingly elderly European population, does not facilitate the use of a public service that is fundamental and among the most important.  In fact, there is often a gap between the user and the service managers, and the race for digitization often forgets the many users scattered throughout the territory and in small centers, for whom human contact and being able to physically interface with the service manager is still extremely important.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report because the UK already has an established national regulatory authority (NRA) and has already proven that it is able to monitor the delivery network without the interference of the EU.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which followed a review of the application of the Postal Services Directive across the EU. This Directive has been disastrous for public services, jobs and workers’ rights in Ireland and throughout the EU. The liberalisation of postal services under the directive has resulted in the closure of post offices across Ireland, and the postal service in the North especially has been decimated as a result. The report supported the ongoing implementation of the directive, and for that reason I voted against it.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. The report might seem acceptable insofar as it does not directly call for the revision of the postal directive and does not call into question the very principle of a universal service operator. However, several paragraphs tend to cast a form of suspicion on universal operators, notably by calling for increased and systematic control of universal service operators by the Commission and regulators.  So I abstained.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. The revision of postal services in 2008 achieved key objectives in terms of the liberalisation of European postal services. However, postal services have undergone dramatic changes due to the growth of e-commerce. Postal services are a vital part of communication in the EU internal market, and this sector remains a fundamental contributor to social, economic and territorial cohesion and to the development of the digital single market. Sectors such as e—commerce, publishing, mail order, insurance, banking and advertising depend heavily on the postal infrastructure. One of the Commission’s core tasks is to promote and safeguard effective competition in the postal services sector. Promoting more competition in this sector is also important in reaching the Europe 2020 goals for sustainable growth in a resource-efficient and more competitive economy.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive because it calls for increased transparency controls on public pricing conditions, service performance and prices when they are not controlled by competition or are unduly high.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The 2008 review of postal services has achieved important objectives for the liberalisation of postal services in Europe. However, since the postal sector was fully opened up in 2008, postal services have changed significantly. On the one hand, paper-based communication has declined in many Member States. The number of letters sent is declining across the EU. On the other hand, new technologies have made online purchases more convenient, which is why the number of parcels and parcels transported by postal companies has increased. As a result, revenues from parcels and express shipments now account for more than half of total revenues in the postal sector. One of the Commission's core tasks is to promote and protect effective competition in the postal sector. The EU postal sector continues to make a significant contribution to social, economic and territorial cohesion and the development of the Digital Single Market. Affordable and reliable postal and parcel deliveries remain of paramount importance for the internal market. I agree with Parliament's position, particularly with regard to the intention to maintain universal services in order to take account of the local specificities of rural areas. High-quality access to postal services must continue to be guaranteed to meet the needs of users.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing.
