I voted against this report which, in the name of free and undistorted competition, will subject La Poste française to competition against which it will not be able to cope in view of its public service constraints. This report will in no way combat wage exploitation, the denunciation of which in the text will remain purely theoretical.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The United Kingdom already has a highly competent national regulatory authority in the field of postal services. Many of the problems within the UK postal service, such as post office closures, etc., are directly or indirectly linked to the EU Postal Services Directives. Consequently I voted against this report, which completely misses the point of the problems.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. The 2008 postal review achieved the main objectives of the liberalisation of European postal services. However, since the fully opened up of the postal sector in 2008, there has been a huge change in the postal sector. On the one hand, paper reporting has decreased in many Member States, i.e. the number of letters in all 28 EU Member States decreased by an average of 4.85% between 2012 and 2013. On the other hand, new technologies make it more convenient to shop online, leading to an increase in the number of packages and parcels transported by postal service providers. As a result, more than half of the revenues from parcels and express parcels now accrue from parcels and express parcels. Over the past five years, due to the development of e-commerce, the market segment for parcels and package delivery markets has grown rapidly and competition in these markets, even though the market has been fully opened up across the EU, has developed slowly. I therefore agree that the Commission's main tasks remain to promote and protect effective competition in the postal services sector.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the importance of providing a high quality universal service on affordable terms including at least five days of delivery and five days of collection per week for any citizen. It also stresses the need to improve geographical coverage and accessibility to universal parcel delivery services, particularly for people with disabilities and reduced mobility and people living in remote areas.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Feber report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. The postal market remains an economic sector in which the prospects for growth and increased competition are still strong. Despite the decline in letter-related services, generated by a corresponding increase in electronic mailings, the impact of information and communication technologies has allowed a marked increase in revenues on the parcel and courier side, thanks to the large amount of online purchases. The proposed text, taking these aspects into account, calls on the Commission to facilitate and strengthen cooperation and coordination between national regulatory authorities, in order to achieve greater efficiency and interoperability in cross-border provision. Geographical coverage and accessibility to universal parcel delivery services need to be improved by paying particular attention to the needs of citizens with disabilities and people with reduced mobility.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. This report reviews the implementation of the Postal Services Directive, adopted in 1997 and amended in 2002 and 2008. With previous work in committee, we have managed to include in the text several important points that advocate a public postal service that is universal, accessible, sustainable in the long term and able to maintain quality jobs.  However, part of the rapporteur's initial approach, which advocates increasing competition to the detriment of public enterprises and enhancing high-end services within Universal Service services, remains in the text, forgetting that the liberalization of the sector in all countries of which data are available has only led to the concentration of private competitors in the most lucrative segments of the market and the widespread detriment of working conditions.  Thus, in order to reflect the balance between the positive and negative points of the report, we voted abstention.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on the implementation of the postal service directive, which is always conflicting because of the various systems prevailing in the Member States. It boosts universal service by improving the independence of national regulatory authorities, enabling fair competition with access, quality of services and well-defined user needs. Not forgetting also the cross-border dimension and e-commerce as well as the social dimension with improved employment. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns the application of the Postal Services Directive, which has been fully competitive since 2008. The use of e-mails reduces the sending of letters, but the use of the internet and online purchases increases the number of parcels delivered to the benefit of online sellers and parcel delivery drivers.  The report offers us a series of contradictions and the end of the public postal service. For example, it wants the total separation of the functions of postal operator and postal regulation, or it deplores the fact that international intra-EU trade is no longer developing, and therefore asks the Commission to ensure that domestic prices in states are closer to international prices at the risk of raising the price of domestic shipments to compensate for the decline in international prices. However, the report reaffirms the need to maintain universal service by ignoring the fact that this requirement is at odds with competition as an ideal. The report also hunts for public subsidies and, ultimately, for the disappearance of universal service. Living in rural areas and being even more concerned with these issues, I voted against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some interesting and acceptable ideas, such as the need to ensure that the postal service remains accessible to all citizens, there are still some critical points in the report that have led me not to fully share it and to vote against it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Parliament's response to the Commission's report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive five years after its entry into force. The report is positive and concludes that, despite the crisis and the fall in the courier-by-letter market due to electronic substitution, the directive and the Single Postal Service work relatively well. The main contribution concerns the regulation of the parcel sector which does not cover the Postal Services Directive, an aspect on which the Commission has submitted a proposal for a regulation. The report advocates a balance between free competition, consumer demands, the sustainability of the universal service and its financing and maintenance of jobs. A postal sector is requested to ensure the sustainability of the universal service, with low prices for consumers but at the same time of high quality, with fast track and trace services, open to all operators, transparent commercial services to all other operators and at the same time with workers with good working conditions, trained and that stable employment is guaranteed. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it gave Parliament its own assessment of the application of the Postal Services Directive. The 2008 postal review achieved the main objectives of the liberalisation of European postal services. However, since the fully opened up of the postal sector in 2008, there have been huge changes in the postal sector. On the one hand, paper reporting has decreased in many Member States. Between 2012 and 2013, the number of letters across the EU decreased, with an average of 4.85% in the EU-28. On the other hand, new technologies make it more convenient to shop online, increasing the number of packages and parcels transported by postal service providers. As a result, more than half of the revenues from parcels and express parcels now accrue from parcels and express parcels. Over the past five years, due to the development of e-commerce, the market segment for parcels and package delivery markets has grown rapidly and competition in these markets, even though the market has been fully opened up across the EU, has developed slowly.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the increasing frequency of e-services and online purchases, classic postal services are still essential today. In particular, it is necessary to provide them in more remote regions where there is no adequate internet coverage. Back in 2008, the Third Postal Services Directive paved the way for the creation of an internal market for postal services. By 2013, the market had opened in all Member States. However, in recent times there have been significant changes in the postal services market which require a review of the application of the Directive. Classical paper communication – the delivery of letters and newspapers and periodicals – is declining rapidly, while the volume of parcel delivery is increasing thanks to electronic purchases. In addition to domestic services, it is very important to provide cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices, using the achievements of the present era (e.g. track-and-trace tracking of mail). One of the main priorities is to maintain and promote effective competition in the postal services sector, taking into account the needs of users. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The market for postal services in the EU is very divided. In some Member States, national post office has a privileged market position and hinders the development of competition. All this causes illogicalities in the market, such as the fact that cross-border delivery for a smaller distance is significantly up to five times more expensive than shipping by a greater distance within one Member State.  Although the postal activity related to letters is declining, the parcel market has grown by 70% in a few years. This is the result of the growth of online commerce and it is precisely for the sake of consumer confidence in this form of purchase that illogicalities in the prices of postal services within the EU need to be addressed.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report calls for free competition, an end to public service and a standardisation of the Union's postal services. It is clear that this will lead to more social dumping for employees in the sector and less service for the customer. I therefore voted against it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The review of postal services in 2008 achieved the main objectives of liberalising European postal services.  However, postal services have undergone enormous changes since the full opening up of the postal services sector market in 2008. On the one hand, paper communications have decreased in many Member States. The number of letters decreased across the European Union and, between 2012 and 2013, the average rate of decline across the 28 EU Member States as a whole was 4.85%. On the other hand, new technologies make online shopping more affordable and, therefore, increase the number of packages and parcels transported by postal operators. As a result, revenues from parcels and couriers now account for more than half of the total revenues of the postal sector.  The existence of good postal services is a vital element for communication in the EU internal market. From collection to transport, from sorting to delivery of letters and parcels to homes and offices, postal service providers offer a wide range of services at an affordable price that must be safeguarded.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Postal services have undergone significant changes since the full opening of the market in the postal sector in 2008. On the one hand, paper communications have decreased in several Member States and, on the other hand, due to online shopping, the number of packages and parcels carried by postal operators has increased. Thus, the revenues from parcels and fast couriers account for more than half of the total revenues of the postal sector. These services are an essential component of communication within the EU internal market, as well as a factor that contributes fundamentally to ensuring social, economic and territorial cohesion, but also to the development of the single market. I was in favour of this report because I believe that there is a need to promote and guarantee the existence of real competition in the postal sector.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the existence of efficient and state-of-the-art postal services is an element of undoubted importance for good communication in the EU internal market. The opening up of this sector to competition, launched in 2008, has stimulated, until now, the development of value-added services such as track-and-trace tracking and localization technologies, pick-up/drop-off collection and delivery points and flexible delivery times and referral procedures. A competitive, innovative and fast-growing parcel market must not be hampered by unjustified regulations or elephantine bureaucracy. Postal and parcel deliveries must be reliable and available at affordable prices for European citizens. Postal services, with the full opening up of the market, have been the protagonists of important changes. While paper communications have fallen considerably in many Member States, e-commerce, by facilitating purchases, means that the number of parcels and parcels transported by postal operators is increasing sharply. Revenues from parcels and mailings made by courier represent, in fact, more than half of the total revenues of the postal sector.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which followed a review of the application of the Postal Services Directive across the EU. This Directive has been disastrous for public services, jobs and workers’ rights in Ireland and throughout the EU. The liberalisation of postal services under the directive has resulted in the closure of post offices across Ireland, and the postal service in the North especially has been decimated as a result. The report supported the ongoing implementation of the directive, and for that reason I voted against it.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the European Union should continue with the roadmap for completing the single market for parcel delivery. Postal services have undergone tremendous changes since the full opening-up of the sector to the market in 2008. Due to the growth of e-commerce, the business-to-consumer segment of the parcel and packet markets has grown rapidly whereas competition in the letter market has been slow to develop, despite full opening to the market across the EU. I believe that affordable and reliable postal and parcel deliveries remain essential for the single market. Whilst new technologies make shopping online more convenient, and parcel and express revenues now account for more than half of the postal sector’s total revenue, e—retailers’ use of cross-border e—commerce still remains low.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The implementation report aims to verify the status of postal services in Europe following the revision of the postal directive in 2008. In view of no particular problems, I voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The existence of good postal services is a vital element for the communication and proper functioning of the EU internal market. The postal market is an economic sector in which the prospects for growth and increased competition are still strong and not at all held back by the digital age that through new technologies have favored online purchases and transactions with consequent increase in postal items that has allowed to double the total revenues of the sector. Cross-border coordination and harmonisation of authorisation procedures in order to remove barriers to access to the single market must certainly be strengthened in the future. The implementation of the Postal Services Directive has helped to open up the market and increase its competition, but we need to ensure that Member States and the Commission monitor the provision of services to the public and their reliability. We all expect the opening up of a strategic sector such as this not to create cost increases or disruptions for citizens. Consumer protection must be central to all European policies and must be guaranteed through clear and transparent pricing policies and rules for the provision of services. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that good postal services are a vital part of communications in the EU internal market. From collection to transport, from sorting to distribution of mail and packages in homes and offices, postal service providers offer a wide range of services at affordable prices. The EU postal sector remains a fundamental factor in social, economic and territorial cohesion as well as the development of the single digital market.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive could address particular issues relating to the development and strengthening of European postal services. However, as it focuses entirely on issues of deregulation in this sector while promoting private interests, I do not think it is sufficiently close to the workers' side and that is why I voted against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Ferber's report because I agree with the assessment of the ineffectiveness of the Postal Services Directive. In particular, in some Member States, such as Italy, the liberalisation of postal services has not contributed to the creation of a more dynamic market. On the contrary, the Italian State remains a majority shareholder in Poste Italiane, often acting as a private company in search of profits. In fact, many mountain municipalities served only two days a week. I therefore fully agree with Mr Ferber on the need to guarantee a truly universal postal service and on the obligation to guarantee at least five days of delivery and collection per week for all citizens. Finally, I hope that the call for the Commission to promote affordable cross-border tariffs and to identify anticompetitive and monopolistic practices will finally lead to a single European market.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the liberalization of postal services in 2008, there has been a paradigm shift in the sector, with the reduction of paper communications, the application of new technologies and an exponential increase in packaging and orders thanks to online purchases. I support the Ferber Report, which responds to these new challenges by defining a set of observations to national regulatory authorities, whose main function is to give concrete application to the provisions of the Postal Services Directive.  I agree with the need to strengthen cooperation and coordination between regulatory authorities with a view to greater efficiency and interoperability of cross-border delivery services, as well as improving geographical coverage and accessibility to universal parcel delivery services to citizens with disabilities or reduced mobility or living in remote areas. I believe that market liberalisation should be ensured that it benefits all users, in particular consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises, while promoting the strategy on e-commerce and cross-border parcel delivery. These rights should be accompanied by a simple and effective cross-border complaint management and dispute resolution system.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report because the UK already has an established national regulatory authority (NRA) and has already proven that it is able to monitor the delivery network without the interference of the EU.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The evolution of the internal market, such as the revision of the 2008 Postal Services Directive, has led to a decrease in paper communications to the benefit of electronic communications. Thus new opportunities for innovation and greater expansion of the market, with the consequent increase in suppliers and competition. In order to ensure that the postal service continues to be a sector capable of contributing to social, economic and territorial cohesion, it is necessary to define minimum standards among operators, avoiding unjustified regulation and unnecessary bureaucracy, ensuring a sustainable, but at the same time flexible, provision of the universal service, taking into account local specificities, continuing to provide a service that is always of high quality on accessible terms and increasing the transparency of the tariffs applied to the various products.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I believe that this directive is essential to accelerate the pace of development and enable SMEs to thrive online and take full advantage of the benefits of the single digital market. There are also beneficial spill-overs in relation to ensuring the continuation and future growth of services. The universal service obligation (USO) in the postal sector is applied very differently across Member States, reflecting the fact that Member States have a certain flexibility in terms of providing universal service according to their domestic circumstances, including at local level. Postal services should be monitored closely in terms of providers’ legacy costs, in accordance with the main set of rules for the control of state aid in respect of services of general economic interest. I agree with the report which endeavours to promote cost reduction by improving the interoperability of parcel dispatch and collection processes, and to develop European standards for integrated tracking systems. I acknowledge the progress made by the industry in serving consumers and SMEs across borders by enhancing interoperability, but more work needs to be done.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report is positioned in such a way that the liberalization of postal services appears to be little more or less than inevitable. In this way, although it contains a whole series of recommendations on improving working conditions and protecting the universal service with which it could agree, it is at heart used to legitimize the reforms that have allowed the terrible degradation of labour standards in the postal sector, the ruin of public operators and the loss of quality in end-customer service. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The employment equality directive aims to create a level playing field with regard to equality in the sphere of work and ensures a consolidated Union legal framework for employment. I would remind you that to date there is still very little data available on equality and that although the perception of discrimination has increased, there is no real awareness of one's rights and judicial mechanisms against discriminatory practices. In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that national bodies can and must show greater commitment to the implementation of the Equality Directive, taking concrete action and combating all forms of discrimination relating to recruitment and linked to the labour market.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Postal services have undergone significant changes since the full opening of the market in the postal sector in 2008. The increase in the volume of online shopping has led to the stabilisation and increase of the number of parcels transported by postal operators. Quality postal services are an essential component of communication within the EU internal market. In 2011, the European postal sector recorded an annual turnover of EUR 91 billion, representing 0.72% of the Union's GDP. Approximately 1.2 million people are employed by postal service providers. I voted for better working conditions, guaranteed to all postal workers.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – The Third Postal Services Directive paved the way for the creation of an internal market for postal services in 2008. By 2013, the market had opened in all Member States. However, in recent times there have been significant changes in the postal services market which require a review of the application of the Directive. Traditional paper communication – the delivery of letters and newspapers and periodicals – is declining rapidly, while the volume of parcel delivery is increasing thanks to electronic purchases. Despite the rise of e-services and online purchases, the provision of traditional postal services is still important today, especially in areas without adequate internet access. Access to cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices is also an essential requirement, to which modern technologies contribute (e.g. tracking the route of mail). One of the sector's main priorities is to maintain and promote effective competition, taking into account the needs of users. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it takes into consideration the market changes in different Member States and seeks to foster economic growth and social cohesion. I agree that Member States should ensure good working conditions for all employees in the postal services sector and that we need improved transparency with regard to public pricing conditions and service performance.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the increasing frequency of e-services and online purchases, classic postal services are still essential today. In particular, it is necessary to provide them in more remote regions where there is no adequate internet coverage. Back in 2008, the Third Postal Services Directive paved the way for the creation of an internal market for postal services. By 2013, the market had opened in all Member States. However, in recent times there have been significant changes in the postal services market which require a review of the application of the Directive. Classical paper communication – the delivery of letters and newspapers and periodicals – is declining rapidly, while the volume of parcel delivery is increasing thanks to electronic purchases. In addition to domestic services, it is very important to provide cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices, using the achievements of the present era (e.g. track-and-trace tracking of mail). One of the main priorities is to maintain and promote effective competition in the postal services sector, taking into account the needs of users. I also identify with these goals as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 European postal services have undergone substantial changes in recent years: the number of letters has decreased across the European Union while the number of parcels and parcels carried by postal operators as a result of online purchases has increased. Postal services therefore need a new directive in order to achieve a single, transparent and competitive market and to promote sustainable and efficient economic growth. For these reasons, I have decided to support the motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. The aim of this report was for the European right to call on the Commission to revise the Postal Services Directive in order to speed up the liberalisation of the sector, in particular by strengthening regulatory authorities and the control of universal service operators. The challenge for the group was to defend and guarantee the sustainable delivery of the universal service. At the end of the negotiations, the text remains a measured approach and draws attention to key points in my opinion, such as the guarantee of territorial cohesion with the maintenance of certain access points. However, it casts an unacceptable form of suspicion on universal service which I regret as vice-president of the 'common good/public services' intergroup.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report on postal markets deplores the fact that intra-EU international trade is no longer developing. It therefore calls on the Commission to ensure that domestic prices in states are approached by international prices at the risk of raising the price of domestic shipments to compensate for the decline in international prices. The report multiplies the contradictions. It calls for the complete separation of the functions of postal operator and postal regulation. The most important objective is to ensure competition, not efficiency, accessibility, or public service. It calls on the Commission to combat social dumping and wage exploitation when, at the same time, it wants more competition and it is precisely this competition that is at the root of social dumping, the use of seconded workers and even hidden work. Finally, the hunt for public subsidies is reaffirmed. He explains that the aim is to eventually achieve an integrated postal sector, through interoperability and a European definition of minimum standards to be met. Also, I voted against this standardization from the bottom up.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 We know that in recent years postal services have undergone huge changes. The changes are related to a decrease in some postal services due to the advent of new technologies, but new markets for postal shipments are present due to the same new technologies and purchases on the Internet, which are more and more. I supported the report on my own initiative because it offers a policy for the benefit of every citizen and their right of access to these universal services, but at the same time takes into account the specificities of the different markets and offers flexibility in the organisation of these services. The independence of national regulators is also maintained, which for me and my political family is a very important factor and underlines that each Member State has some flexibility in the implementation of the Directive.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By voting on this text, Parliament makes its recommendations on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive, an important sector in European economies. It was necessary to stress the importance of strengthening consumer confidence in these services, including greater transparency in prices and service arrangements.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Despite the increasing frequency of e-services and online purchases, classic postal services are still essential today. In particular, it is necessary to provide them in more remote regions where there is no adequate internet coverage. Back in 2008, the Third Postal Services Directive paved the way for the creation of an internal market for postal services. By 2013, the market had opened in all Member States. However, in recent times there have been significant changes in the postal services market which require a review of the application of the Directive. Classical paper communication – the delivery of letters and newspapers and periodicals – is declining rapidly, while the volume of parcel delivery is increasing thanks to electronic purchases. In addition to domestic services, it is very important to provide cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices, using the achievements of the present era (e.g. tracking the route of mail – track-and-trace). One of the main priorities is to maintain and promote effective competition in the postal services sector, taking into account the needs of users. I also identify with these goals as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the increasing frequency of e-services and online purchases, classic postal services are still essential today. In particular, it is necessary to provide them in more remote regions where there is no adequate internet coverage. Back in 2008, the Third Postal Services Directive paved the way for the creation of an internal market for postal services. By 2013, the market had opened in all Member States. However, in recent times there have been significant changes in the postal services market which require a review of the application of the Directive. Classical paper communication – the delivery of letters and newspapers and periodicals – is declining rapidly, while the volume of parcel delivery is increasing thanks to electronic purchases. In addition to domestic services, it is very important to provide cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices, using the achievements of the present era (e.g. tracking the route of mail – track-and-trace). One of the main priorities is to maintain and promote effective competition in the postal services sector, taking into account the needs of users. I also identify with these goals as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. Good postal services are a vital part of communication in the EU internal market. The EU postal sector remains a key factor for social, economic and territorial cohesion and for the development of the digital single market. Affordable and reliable postal and parcel shipments remain crucial to the single market. The review of postal services in 2008 achieved the objectives of liberalisation of European postal services. In this regard, in February 2008, the European Parliament and the Council adopted Directive 2008/6/EC, which introduced the legal basis for the completion of the internal market in postal services and provided the last legislative step in the process of gradual market opening. The third Postal Services Directive also strengthens the roles and competences of national authorities

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2009, postal services accounted for an annual turnover of EUR 72 billion, corresponding to 0.62 % of GDP in the EU. As regards universal services, more than 85 billion postal shipments and almost 2 billion parcels were dispatched by universal service providers in the EU in 2013. The European postal sector represented an annual turnover of €91 billion in 2011, equivalent to 0.72% of EU GDP. However, parcel delivery is a competitive, innovative and rapidly growing sector. About 1.2 million people work for universal postal service providers, which join people working for other letter and parcel distribution operators. I agree with the need to promote and safeguard effective competition in the postal services sector.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: the report reaffirms that the aim of the Postal Services Directive is to eventually achieve an integrated postal sector, through interoperability and a European definition of minimum standards to be respected. Clearly, once again, uniformity from the bottom.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the existence of good postal services is a vital element for communication in the EU internal market as well as contributing substantially to social, economic, territorial cohesion and the development of the digital single market. Reliable and affordable postal and parcel deliveries are still essential for the single market. In addition, many other areas such as e-commerce, publishing, mail order, insurance, banking and advertising are heavily dependent on postal infrastructure.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ Even if the final result is better than initially expected, I am still concerned about giving the Commission arguments for reviewing the universal service obligation. Therefore I abstained.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Although the postal directive was revised only relatively recently in 2008 and achieved key objectives in the area of liberalisation of the postal market in the European Union, significant changes have occurred in the fully open market of the postal sector. New technologies simplify online shopping and thus increase the number of parcels and parcels transported by postal operators. Consequently, parcel and express delivery revenues account for more than half of the total revenues of the postal sector. There has been a sharp increase in the parcel and parcel delivery market segment between businesses and consumers over the last five years and as a result of the growth of e-commerce, but competition in the letter market is slow to develop, despite the full opening up of markets throughout the European Union. If the European Union wants to make progress in this area in the future, it must complete the single market for parcel delivery. In this sector, the European Commission must focus on promoting and protecting fair and effective competition, which will undoubtedly benefit the European economy as a whole.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain from the resolution which, despite some positive passages, does not touch on some important issues such as the maintenance of certain services in certain areas.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive as the imposed balancing of state services with private postal services harms the interests of the Member States, since government agencies provide a public service, with all that this entails (ensuring confidentiality especially in emergencies, etc.).

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report which calls on the Commission to improve the definition of universal service in order to guarantee a certain level of service for consumers, takes into account market changes in different Member States, fosters economic growth and social cohesion, and facilitates coordination between National Regulatory Authorities (NRAs) with a view to greater interoperability in cross-border delivery and to monitoring their regulatory activities. Member States are urged to ensure good working conditions for all employees in the sector, to support the role and independence of NRAs, and to harmonise licensing procedures further to reduce unjustified barriers to market entry. Finally, I welcome the fact that we kept the general definition of Universal Service, we insisted on postal service as tool of social cohesion and we stated that Member States have to ensure good working conditions for all employees in the sectors.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the increasing frequency of e-services and online purchases, classic postal services are still essential today. In particular, it is necessary to provide them in more remote regions where there is no adequate internet coverage. Back in 2008, the Third Postal Services Directive paved the way for the creation of an internal market for postal services. By 2013, the market had opened in all Member States. However, in recent times there have been significant changes in the postal services market which require a review of the application of the Directive. Classical paper communication – the delivery of letters and newspapers and periodicals – is declining rapidly, while the volume of parcel delivery is increasing thanks to electronic purchases. In addition to domestic services, it is very important to provide cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices, using the achievements of the present era (e.g. tracking the route of mail – track-and-trace). One of the main priorities is to maintain and promote effective competition in the postal services sector, taking into account the needs of users. I also identify with these goals as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the increasing frequency of e-services and online purchases, classic postal services are still essential today. It is particularly necessary to ensure that they are ensured in more remote regions where there is no adequate internet overlap. Back in 2008, the Third Postal Services Directive paved the way for the creation of an internal market for postal services. By 2013, the market had opened in all Member States. However, in recent times there have been significant changes in the postal services market which require a review of the application of the Directive. Classical paper communication – the delivery of letters and newspapers and periodicals – is declining rapidly, while the volume of parcel delivery is increasing thanks to electronic purchases. In addition to domestic services, it is very important to provide cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices, using the achievements of the present era (e.g. tracking the route of mail – track-and-trace). One of the main priorities is to maintain and promote effective competition in the postal services sector, taking into account the needs of users. I also identify with these goals as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive as it sets out some important development steps for the future. In view of the increased share of Internet purchases, for example, a kind of "roaming lid for packages" is being worked on. This benefits the EU's single market, as does retailers and start-ups in Europe.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. A good and reliable postal service is essential for the EU's internal market. Other sectors of the economy, such as e-commerce, publishing, mail order, insurance, banks and advertising, are highly dependent on a good Pan-European postal service. The current 1.2 million postal workers should not have to fear that increased workloads will worsen their working conditions. I am therefore voting in favour of a European directive on the postal service.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ EU rules on postal services guarantee all citizens the right to affordable and regular postal deliveries, and this review of the EU postal market makes clear that such rights need to be protected. The review also recognises the continued growth in online shopping options and alternative postal services. It is vital that EU rules on post and parcel delivery are fit for purpose, ensuring reliable delivery options for consumers and businesses whilst also protecting those working in the sector through safe and secure employment conditions.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Postal services are subject to competition exacerbated by the development of online shopping, which has revolutionized the market by introducing new players such as parcel delivery companies. The aim of this report is to promote greater competition in this sector, in order to increase growth.  The report thus purports to bring internal prices in Member States closer to international prices, by raising national prices to compensate for the decline in international prices. This proposal is surprising at a time when the fight against greenhouse gas emissions is being presented as a priority by the European institutions. Similarly, the report claims to defend universal service, i.e. the minimum public service, but at the same time by combating the public subsidies necessary to maintain this service. Finally, the report calls on the Commission to combat social dumping and poor wage conditions in postal services, but without questioning the heightened competition that encourages the massive use of precarious contracts, seconded and even clandestine workers. I therefore voted against this report, which does not provide real solutions to the contemporary problems of postal services, particularly in social matters.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Mr Ferber looks at the situation of postal services, which were fully liberalised in 2008. As soon as the Commission wanted to liberalise a public service, it hammered out the following argument: more competition would necessarily lower prices while guaranteeing the quality of service. In 2008, the French bought their stamp 0.55 euros to send a letter to France, as in many neighbouring countries. In 2016, it costs them 0.80 euros for a courier to France and 1 euro to Belgium, for example. That's a 45% and 80 percent increase, respectively. For couriers that arrive less quickly. As for the universality of the service, go ask what the many French people who live in towns and villages where the post offices have disappeared or reduced their opening hours. Nevertheless, the rapporteur believes that the market lacks liberalisation, deplores the predominance of the incumbent operator while competitors focus on the most profitable geographical areas and segments. Market skimming long announced by the National Front. As well as the precariousness of employees among all operators, because of competition, and the slow erosion of the very notion of public service. Stop the massacre.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This report reviews the implementation of the Postal Services Directive, adopted in 1997 and amended in 2002 and 2008. With previous work in committee, we have managed to include in the text several important points that advocate a public postal service that is universal, accessible, sustainable in the long term and able to maintain quality jobs.   However, part of the rapporteur's initial approach, which advocates increasing competition to the detriment of public enterprises and enhancing high-end services within Universal Service services, remains in the text, forgetting that the liberalization of the sector in all countries of which data are available has only led to the concentration of private competitors in the most lucrative segments of the market and the widespread detriment of working conditions.  Thus, in order to reflect the balance between the positive and negative points of the report, we voted abstention.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. The 2008 revision of the postal service rules has achieved key objectives of liberalising European postal services. Since its full opening in 2008, the postal market has undergone huge changes. On the one hand, the amount of paper correspondence has decreased in many Member States. On the other hand, new technologies increase the convenience of online shopping and thus increase the number of parcels provided by postal operators.  Good quality postal services are an important part of communication in the EU internal market and the EU postal sector continues to make a significant contribution to strengthening social, economic and territorial cohesion and the development of the Digital Single Market.  In my opinion, supporting the development of competition in this sector is also important in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives of sustainable growth in a more competitive economy.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I support technological advances and the digitisation of the postal sector as modernisation and diversification of postal services. This has had a strong impact on working conditions and employment in this sector, particularly in remote, rural and mountainareas, with a huge increase in the parcel delivery services sector due to the development of e-commerce. As a member of the TRAN committee, I believe that quality postal services are an essential component of communication within the EU internal market. The European Union postal sector remains a fundamental contributor to ensuring social, economic and territorial cohesion and the development of the digital single market. Reliable delivery of packages and packages at an affordable price is an essential aspect for the single market. Other sectors, such as e-commerce, editing, mail order, insurance, banking and advertising, depend to a large extent on the development of postal infrastructure.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ EU rules on postal services guarantee all citizens the right to affordable and regular postal deliveries, and this review of the EU postal market makes clear that such rights need to be protected. The review also recognises the continued growth in online shopping options and alternative postal services. It is vital that EU rules on post and parcel delivery are fit for purpose, ensuring reliable delivery options for consumers and businesses whilst also protecting those working in the sector through safe and secure employment conditions.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. – We voted against the report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive after promoting the limitation of the ability of Member States to decide how to manage their public postal services.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. Speaking of postal services. In my opinion, we must focus primarily on improving the free provision of services within the European Union and increasing their accessibility and affordability at national and transnational level, while adapting to economic, social and technical changes.  I would like to stress that there is a need to improve the transparency and attractiveness of prices, to introduce a functional mechanism for resolving disputes and complaints, and to provide technological solutions for clear monitoring of consignments. It is also necessary to increase the universality of postal services and their geographical coverage so that citizens living in rural, mountainous or remote regions have access to high-quality services to meet their needs.  The rights of postal workers, whose high mobility requires the guarantee m.in safe working environment and health protection, remain an important issue.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report because the UK already has an established national regulatory authority (NRA) and has already proven that it is able to monitor the delivery network without the interference of the EU.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The volume of letter deliveries has decreased in recent years, and this has led to a decrease in the competitiveness of the market. I voted for the report, which calls for greater transparency regarding pricing conditions and performance in postal services.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Postal Services Directive Application Report, as I believe that the postal market has a strong growth and competitiveness prospect, in particular thanks to the advancement of information and communication technologies that provide opportunities for innovation and enable the spread of the postal services market.  While Member States have seen a large decline in paper communication, on the other hand, parcel and express service revenues now account for more than half of total revenues in the postal services sector. Such a competitive, innovative and rapidly growing sector should certainly promote and preserve the effective competition that this report for which I voted speaks speaks.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report because the UK already has an established national regulatory authority (NRA) and has already proven that it is able to monitor the delivery network without the interference of the EU.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the application of the Postal Services Directive, which aims to promote and preserve effective competition in the postal services sector. The EU postal sector, which accounts for 0.72% of the EU's GDP, remains a fundamental contributor to social, economic and territorial cohesion and the development of the digital single market. The existence of affordable and reliable postal distribution and parcel delivery services is a crucial element for the single market.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. ‒ The Postal Services Directive is an essential part of the unveiling of the digital single market. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on geo-blocking, I see the Postal Services Directive as the completion of a grand strategy. I therefore voted for Markus Ferber’s report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Paper-based communication is declining across Europe. On the other hand, the number of parcels has risen sharply and the turnover from the delivery of parcels and express deliveries accounts on average for more than half of the total revenue of postal service providers. National regulatory authorities are therefore invited to adapt the extension of their tasks under the new regulation in the parcel market. There is nothing to counter this call, since setting minimum standards brings benefits for all operators, and hence for the entire industry. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ EU rules on postal services guarantee all citizens the right to affordable and regular postal deliveries, and this review of the EU postal market makes clear that these rights need to be protected. The review also recognises the continued growth in online shopping options and alternative postal services. It is vital that EU rules on post and parcel delivery are fit for purpose, ensuring reliable delivery options for consumers and businesses whilst also protecting those working in the sector through safe and secure employment conditions.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the increasing frequency of e-services and online purchases, classic postal services are still essential today. It is particularly necessary to ensure that they are ensured in more remote regions where there is no adequate internet overlap. Back in 2008, the Third Postal Services Directive paved the way for the creation of an internal market for postal services. By 2013, the market had opened in all Member States. However, in recent times there have been significant changes in the postal services market which require a review of the application of the Directive. Classical paper communication – the delivery of letters and newspapers and periodicals – is declining rapidly, while the volume of parcel delivery is increasing thanks to electronic purchases. In addition to domestic services, it is very important to provide cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices, using the achievements of the present era (e.g. tracking the route of mail – track-and-trace). One of the main priorities is to maintain and promote effective competition in the postal services sector, taking into account the needs of users. I also identify with these goals as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. There has been a sudden change in the postal services sector in recent years. While paper communications have decreased, parcel shipments have increased thanks to technology and the new way of making online purchases. To date, this mail sector provides more than 50% of the total revenue. Indeed, the Union's postal sector continues to contribute to social, economic and territorial cohesion and to the development of the digital single market, and it is therefore vital for communication that these services are carried out efficiently and at affordable prices. The Commission is therefore asked to promote and safeguard competition in this sector, so as to achieve the Europe 2020 objectives towards sustainable growth and a more competitive economy. For the above reasons, I am voting in favour of Parliament's proposal on the application of the Postal Services Directive.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it aims to liberalise the parcel market in Europe at the expense of consumers and for the benefit of large companies in the sector.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Despite the stated objective of employee protection and universal service, this report aims only to fully liberalise and standardise the parcel market in Europe to increase the profits of courier companies (DHL, Deutsche Post, etc.) and online sellers (Amazon, etc.).  I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it concludes that, despite the crisis and the fall in the courier-by-letter market due to electronic substitution, the directive and the Single Postal Service work relatively well. It also advocates a balance between free competition, consumer demands, the sustainability of the universal service and its financing and maintenance of jobs.  On the other hand, the demands of the resolution call for the establishment of a postal sector that guarantees the sustainability of the universal service, with low prices for consumers but at the same time high quality, with fast, open track and trace services to all operators, transparent commercial services to all other operators and at the same time with workers with good working conditions , trained and ensure stable employment. Quality employment in the sector is also repeatedly called for and the growing precariousness in some forms of employment is criticized.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report is positioned in such a way that the liberalization of postal services appears to be little more or less than inevitable. In this way, although it contains a whole series of recommendations on improving working conditions and protecting the universal service with which it could agree, it is at heart used to legitimize the reforms that have allowed the terrible degradation of labour standards in the postal sector, the ruin of public operators and the loss of quality in end-customer service. That's why I voted against it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The overall objective of this initiative report is to address specific issues related to cross-border parcel services and to present Parliament's view to changing the Postal Services Directive. Parliament reiterates the importance of markets functioning more effectively, increasing the coherence of regulatory supervision of parcel markets and promoting competition. It also underlines the need to increase price transparency in order to reduce unjustified price differences and tariffs paid by individuals and small businesses, especially in remote areas. I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report because I agree with the guidelines defined here. At IMCO's headquarters, as rapporteur for the EPP in the legislative report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cross-border parcel services, I will work to achieve these objectives. We need new legislation to develop the digital single market and increase cross-border e-commerce and digital inclusion. More and better Europe for businesses is to regenerate jobs and growth.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which promotes effective competition in the postal services sector as it faces challenges such as e—substitution on one hand and online shopping on the other.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the proposal that delivery drivers should be monitored 'using digital monitoring devices installed in vehicles', even 'whether they are self-employed, subcontractors, temporary agents or contract agents'. I consider it an effort at Big Brother-style state surveillance. Nor do I agree with the requirement that 'the Commission and the Member States collect more data on the parcel delivery market'.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The 2008 revision of postal services achieved key objectives of liberalising European postal services, which have changed greatly since the full opening of the market. New technologies are responsible for facilitating online shopping and the increased number of shipments and parcels entrusted to postal operators, and therefore revenues from parcels and express services account for more than half of total revenues in the postal services sector. The report highlights how good postal services are an important part of communication in the EU internal market, and the post office sector makes a key contribution to social, economic and territorial cohesion and the development of the Digital Single Market. E-commerce is a driver for market growth, and the parcel delivery market is highly competitive. Consumers and small businesses complain that parcel delivery problems and high prices discourage them from using postal services, especially when selling or buying from other Member States. Promoting more competition in this sector is important for achieving the Sustainable Growth Goals under the Europe 2020 strategy, i.e. an economy based on resource efficiency and greater competitiveness, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The postal market is still an area of the economy with strong prospects for growth and increasing competition. It is important to establish affordable and reliable parcel delivery services as part of the realisation of the digital single market, and to promote the strategy on e—commerce and cross-border parcel delivery.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: writing \ u2012 There are 1.2 million people employed in the European Union in the field of universal postal services. Hundreds of thousands more employees work in downstream services. The Commission and the Member States must create the conditions for innovative solutions in this sector so as to further promote employment growth while modernising activities in these services. In order to protect employees, it is necessary to monitor compliance with labour laws in the performance of this employment and to take measures that improve the working and social conditions of employees.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/9/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  Despite the stated objective of employee protection and universal service, this report aims only to liberalise and standardise the parcel market in Europe. Each proposal is in total contradiction. For example, the report reaffirms the need to maintain universal service by ignoring the fact that this requirement is at odds with competition as an unserable ideal. The aim is to increase the profits of courier companies (DHL, Deutsche Post, etc.) and online sellers (Amazon, etc.).

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. Of all the key points listed, I have to agree with the importance of ensuring that there are no barriers to the accessibility of parcel deliveries, especially to citizens with disabilities or those living in remote areas. Not only do deliveries matter, but I would also stress the serious need to improve quality of service and to protect consumers’ rights in order to restore consumer confidence.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for the report from which Parliament urges the Commission to implement the Postal Services Directive correctly, in order to promote and ensure effective competition in the sector.  This promotion of competition, recalled in the motion for a resolution which we have adopted, is of great importance for the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy on sustainable growth in a resource-efficient and more competitive economy. Having good postal services is one of the pillars of communication within the internal market of the Union. Therefore, the proper functioning of the sector must be ensured.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. Jean-Claude Juncker himself seems to have heard, if not take this into account, that blind liberalisation can no longer be the Union's roadmap. Social Europe, 'Europe that protects', in his words, is the first priority.  For postal services, we still have the option of not repeating the mistakes of the past, with the forced liberalisation of energy or rail transport. The text on the balance sheet and prospects of the Postal Services Directive, carried by the EPP, does not take these errors into account.  The only obsession with this text is openness to the market and competition. We know that when there is a natural monopoly or a state monopoly that provides universal service, it requires artificial support to new entrants, sacrificing the profitability of the large incumbent operators, which are still sometimes public services. In addition, the report proposes to abolish the VAT exemption, which does not favour operators, but individual users of the universal service, who would see their fees increase if the VAT exemption were abolished.  This text is, in my view, an economic, political and social error. I voted against it.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 Undoubtedly, correct and efficient postal services are a vital and crucial part of communications in the EU internal market. The EU postal sector is and remains a fundamental factor in social, economic and territorial cohesion. In a single market there should be affordable and reliable postal services in particular. For an additional reason postal services must function properly and efficiently since sectors such as e-commerce, publishing, insurance, banking and others depend to a large extent on postal infrastructure. For all these reasons I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. It is reported here that competition in the letter market is severely underdeveloped. Increased competition would reduce prices for the final customer, similar to the parcel market. I am in favour of that.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive presented by the EP. One of the main tasks of the Directive is to promote and protect effective competition in the postal services sector. It is still essential for the Single Market that postal and parcel delivery is accessible and reliable. Postal services cover a wide range of services, from sending letters and parcels to the provision of value-added services. Postal infrastructure is highly dependent on other sectors, such as e-commerce, publishing, mail order sales, insurance, banking and advertising.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The 2008 Postal Services Directive has achieved its objectives of liberalising postal services. The report before us is deed to ensure that the conditions of competition are met. Thus, it recalls that 'the VAT exemption for postal services must be applied in a way that reduces distortions of competition between old monopolies and new entrants to the market'. While some findings are realistic, the report does not propose any way to remedy them. Thus, the report merely "noted" the "increase in the number of part-time employees, temporary workers and self-employed in the sector". Or to deplore "attempts to circumvent current minimum wage regulations by increasing the workload to such an extent that it cannot be carried out during paid work hours". Also, the few elements conceded on employment, such as the demand for guarantees of "decent working conditions", cannot make us forget the social disaster that accompanied the liberalisation of this sector (11,700 jobs were cut at the French Post office in 2010). I am voting against this text, which is satisfied with it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Despite the stated objective of employee protection and universal service, this report aims only to fully liberalise and standardise the parcel market in Europe to increase the profits of courier companies (DHL, Deutsche Post, etc.) and online sellers (Amazon, etc.).  I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The postal market is still an area of the economy with strong prospects for growth and increased competition, although between 2012 and 2013 the general mail service had decreased by an average of 4.85 % in the EU, according to the European Commission's database on postal service statistics, which is in line with the decrease in mail volume over the last ten years , largely due to the process of replacing by electronic means.  The Postal Services Directive gives Member States the flexibility to deal with local specificities and ensure the long-term sustainability of universal service delivery, while responding to users' needs and adapting to changes in the technical, economic and social context.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the application of the Postal Services Directive following the opening up of the market, as it stresses the need to assess the impact on those employed in the sector and also to promote competitiveness.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Postal services have undergone impressive changes since the full opening of the postal market in 2008: paper communications have declined while parcels and express mail have increased as a result of online purchases. The 2008 Postal Services Directive must be adapted again to meet the needs and expectations of European consumers. Good postal services are essential for communication in the internal market of the European Union. Our policy at European level aims not only to complete the internal market for postal services, but also to ensure that all citizens and businesses have access to efficient, reliable and high-quality postal services at affordable rates throughout the EU. I therefore support the development and application of a regulatory framework that provides universal quality services with minimal flexibility. It is a question of remaining attentive to the right balance between economic prosperity, social well-being and EU cohesion. This is only possible through the establishment of independent regulatory authorities as envisaged in this new directive.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The 2008 revision of the Postal Services Directive achieved the key objectives of the liberalisation of European postal services. Good postal services are an important part of communication in the EU internal market, although technological progress and digitalisation have led to a significant change in the postal sector. The number of letter items in the EU is declining due to the replacement of paper mail with digital tools, while demand is increasing in the express mail sector. The provision of services is essential for regional development, social inclusion and economic and territorial cohesion of the EU and plays an important role in rural and remote areas. Promoting effective competition in the postal sector and protecting it is a priority. Promoting increased economic cooperation is important for achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for a competitive and resource-efficient economy.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for improved transparency as regards public pricing conditions and service performance (delivery options, final delivery and reliability), especially when it comes to e—commerce.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Transport and Tourism has been reviewing the situation of postal services since their liberalisation in 2008. notes that the decline in paper communication and correspondence has been offset by increasing volume of parcel traffic as online shopping has spread. Looking at the data, it concludes that the postal sector remains an essential element of social, economic and territorial cohesion and the development of the Digital Single Market, and that affordable and reliable postal and parcel services remain crucial for the single market. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Since 2008, the postal sector has been completely liberalised and subject to competition. At the same time, the increasing use of e-mails continues to reduce the number of mailings, while, at the same time, online purchases continue to increase the number of parcels delivered. The aim of this report is therefore to redefine new postal service targets with the Commission. It proposes the total separation of the functions of postal operator and postal regulation, the need to maintain universal service and the hunt for public subsidies as a distortion of competition, and the aim is to eventually obtain an integrated European postal sector. As this directive is an additional stone to the building of the single market, we are voting against this text which promotes it.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report calls for increased competition and it is precisely this competition and the end of public monopolies that enable, facilitate and even encourage the use of social dumping, the use of seconded workers, concealed work, this to be competitive on prices even though delivery services require few qualifications for a large number of jobs. The report reaffirms that the aim of the Postal Services Directive is to eventually achieve an integrated postal sector, through interoperability and a European definition of minimum standards to be met. Clearly, once again, uniformity from the bottom. This is already the case in many western European countries where the quality of postal service continues to decline in order to be able to compete.  I therefore speak out against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ EU rules on postal services guarantee all citizens the right to affordable and regular postal deliveries, and this review of the EU postal market makes clear that such rights need to be protected. The review also recognises the continued growth in online shopping options and alternative postal services. It is vital that EU rules on post and parcel delivery are fit for purpose, ensuring reliable delivery options for consumers and businesses whilst also protecting those working in the sector through safe and secure employment conditions.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. In particular, this text reminds us that postal services have an obligation to provide universal service. Therefore, it remains essential that all users have access to it and that the prices charged are reasonable. In this context, the report reiterates the importance of the role played by national regulators.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I approved my colleague Markus Ferber's report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. The European Union's postal sector remains a fundamental contributor to social, economic and territorial cohesion. It is essential that we have an accessible and reliable postal service within the framework of the single market. Many other areas are directly affected by this sector, such as trade, insurance, advertising, banking, etc.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Key objectives of the liberalisation of European postal services have been achieved following the revision of postal services in 2008. Postal services went through formidable changes after the full market opening of the sector in that year. The growth of e-commerce increased the business-to-consumer segment of the parcel and packets market so that, Europe-wide, postal services account for 0.62% of the EU’s GDP. I voted for this report, which promotes and safeguards effective competition in the postal services sector.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the implementation of the Postal Services Directive, while at the same time making substantive additions. I think it is very important that, in the context of competition in this market, consumer rights are protected. In this respect, the simplification of complaint handling procedures and dispute resolution mechanisms are very important. Furthermore, in view of the cross-border nature of these services, I believe that these procedures must protect consumer rights in all Member States.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 Postal services are important segments of the EU internal market and I therefore consider the report on this subject to be very necessary. This need is also due to the fact that the EU postal market is undergoing a dynamic development characterised by an increase in parcel mail and online delivery. The report rightly mentions the need to strengthen cooperation between national regulatory authorities in order to achieve greater efficiency and interoperability in cross-border delivery, and also pays attention to the issue of universal service. It is also worth noting the link between the implementation of the Digital Single Market and affordable and reliable parcel delivery services. Any new legislation on the parcel delivery market must therefore be proportionate and must not interfere with the development of value-added services such as tracking the movement of consignments, pick-up and drop-off points, the possibility of choosing delivery time and appropriate return procedures.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted against this report, which followed a review of the application of the Postal Services Directive across the EU. This Directive has been disastrous for public services, jobs and workers’ rights in Ireland and throughout the EU. The liberalisation of postal services under the directive has resulted in the closure of post offices across Ireland, and the postal service in the North especially has been decimated as a result. The report supported the ongoing implementation of the directive, and for that reason I voted against it.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
