text: Writing. According to this report, the market for correspondence is severely underdeveloped. Accordingly, increased competition would reduce prices for the final customer. I am in favour of that.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Postal services have changed significantly over the years, paper-based correspondence has declined and postal service providers are presenting wide-based services at lower prices. The Directive will contribute to the completion of the common market for parcel management.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report because the UK already has an established national regulatory authority (NRA) and has already proven that it is able to monitor the delivery network without the interference of the EU.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my full support for this text.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Postal services continue to play a vital role across the European Union, although the nature of that role is changing as new technologies are driving both e-substitution and an increasing volume of online purchases. As a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I work for fair competition in all industries of the EU. Hence I voted in favour, because promoting more competition in this sector is also important in reaching the Europe 2020 goals for sustainable growth in a resource-efficient and more competitive economy.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. Despite the many changes affecting the postal sector, it remains very important for the EU, especially for social, economic and territorial cohesion. The EP had this in mind when it formed this motion for a resolution that I support for many reasons. The EP proposes that the national rules of individual Member States should be harmonised with the Postal Services Directive, which will achieve homogeneity of this sector in all Member States.  Parliament also relies on the Commission on many issues that accompany postal services in general. It calls on it to reaffirm once again that a low level of population density is not a legitimate reason for reducing the frequency of service, as everyone is entitled to an equal offer of service. The EP also calls for cooperation between Member States and the Commission in superseding the provision of postal services for reasons of transparency and fairness.  The resolution repeatedly emphasises transparency, which I welcome, in particular as regards transparency regarding delivery opportunities and quality and performance with a view to building trust with users. What I also consider a good proposal is to ensure decent working conditions for all employees in the postal services sector.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Since 2008, postal markets have been completely competitive. At the same time, the use of e-mail continues to reduce the number of mailings while online purchases continue to increase the number of parcels delivered, generating fabulous profits for online sellers (Amazon, fnac, cdiscount, etc.) and parcel delivery drivers (UPS, DHL, fedex, etc.). The aim of this report is to redefine new postal service targets with the Commission. Despite some stated objectives of employee protection and universal service, it is still a text advocating outrageous liberalisation which will, as always, lead to a reduction in service in the most difficult-to-reach and least profitable areas and to a deterioration in the working conditions of employees in the sector. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I believe that the postal services market, thanks to increased competition, can be an important driver for economic growth, technological innovation and the development of high added value services. As services of general interest, postal services are also an important instrument for promoting social cohesion and the report, thanks to the excellent work carried out in the Committee on Transport by the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), states that The Member States are obliged to ensure good working conditions for all employees in the sector. The commitment of the S&D Parliamentarians has also meant that the final text adopted also contains a number of other very important points: a better definition of public utility services, in order to ensure a good level of service for consumers; simplified coordination between national regulatory authorities with a view to greater cross-border interoperability; an indication to Member States to harmonise authorisation procedures in order to reduce unjustified barriers to the entry of competitors into their markets; and the call for greater transparency regarding pricing and quality of service assessment. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The 2008 Revision of Postal Services achieved the key objectives of liberalising European postal services. However, due to the digitisation of society, postal services have changed and in many Member States this type of communication has declined. The EU postal sector continues to make a vital contribution to the social, economic and territorial cohesion and development of the Digital Single Market.  It is important to promote and preserve effective competition in the postal services sector, which will also lead to the achievement of the Sustainable Growth Goals under the Europe 2020 strategy, i.e. an economy based on resource efficiency and greater competitiveness, which is why I supported MeP Ferber's report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The revision of the postal services rules of 2008 has achieved the key objectives of liberalising European postal services. However, since its full opening in 2008, the postal market has undergone huge changes. On the one hand, the amount of paper correspondence has decreased in many Member States. On the other hand, new technologies increase the convenience of online shopping and thus the number of parcels provided by postal operators. As a result, more than half of the postal sector's total revenue comes from parcel and express delivery. The report stresses the obligation to provide, on affordable terms, high-quality universal services with a range of at least five delivery days and five pick-up days per week for each EU citizen. It was also underlined that, given the constraints that characterise each market, some flexibility should be left to operators in order to organise this universal service. Attention has been paid to the independence of national regulatory authorities and emphasised on interoperability and underlined that each Member State has a certain margin of discretion in the application of the Postal Services Directive. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The postal services sector in Europe is fundamental to the economic and social cohesion of all European territories. I voted in favour of this report on the application of the Postal Services Directive as a reminder of the importance of further liberalisation of the sector to enable healthy competition, thereby providing customers with real choice and an increased quality of service. Affordable, enhanced geographical coverage for access and increased cross-border postal services must continue to be priorities for operators and relevant national authorities.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of Directive 2008/6/EC was crucial in achieving the fundamental objectives of the liberalisation of European postal services. Postal services include a wide range of services, from the delivery of letters and parcels to homes and offices, to the promotion of value-added services (e-commerce, insurance, banking, advertising).  This sector is an important part of the communication in the Internal Market of the European Union and plays a key role in European social, territorial and economic cohesion. It follows, however, that postal services have now changed the way in which their services are demanded, so many of these services have been provided by digital means, which is dwarfed by the increase in purchases and deliveries of online parcels.  This report concludes that promoting competition in this sector is important to achieve the objectives set with the 2020 strategy. Therefore, by identifying the European postal services sector as a vital part of the communication on the internal market and for sharing the consideration that the 2020 strategy is fundamental in this area, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report because the UK already has an established national regulatory authority (NRA) and has already proven that it is able to monitor the delivery network without the interference of the EU.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. The revision of postal services in 2008 achieved fundamental objectives for liberalisation. However, they have undergone huge changes since the total opening of the market. Paper-based communications have fallen considerably and the number of letters has decreased across the EU. On the other hand, new technologies make online shopping more convenient and therefore increase the number of packages and parcels processed by postal operators. Over the past five years, the consumer business segment has grown rapidly in the parcel and packaging markets. Good postal services are an essential part of communication in the EU internal market. However, the main trend is in parcel delivery services due to the development of e-commerce. However, parcel delivery is a competitive, innovative and rapidly growing sector. The European express delivery services sector is estimated to employ 272,000 workers in 2010 and this number is expected to increase to 300,000 by 2020. Finally, one of the Commission's main tasks is to promote and safeguard effective competition in the postal services sector.  In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this directive.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Parliament's response to the Commission's report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive five years after its entry into force. The report is positive and concludes that, despite the crisis and the fall in the courier-by-letter market due to electronic substitution, the directive and the Single Postal Service work relatively well. The main contribution concerns the regulation of the parcel sector which does not cover the Postal Services Directive, an aspect on which the Commission has submitted a proposal for a regulation. The report advocates a balance between free competition, consumer demands, the sustainability of the universal service and its financing and maintenance of jobs. A postal sector is requested to ensure the sustainability of the universal service, with low prices for consumers but at the same time of high quality, with fast track and trace services, open to all operators, transparent commercial services to all other operators and at the same time with workers with good working conditions, trained and that stable employment is guaranteed. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report, which aims to assess the implementation of the Postal Services Directive because it contains important recommendations.  I am totally in favour of maintaining a universal service and I categorically refuse to allow discriminatory policies based on population density as is the case in Italy to multiply. Living in a rural area where the population density is lower than the country average, I will always advocate for services, especially postal services, to be identical to those provided in other regions.  I also support the recommendations to improve cross-border postal services and the fight against the deterioration of working conditions. While it is important to constantly improve the quality of postal services, this cannot be done at the expense of working conditions.  Finally, I will mention the important paragraph which aims to promote the installation of tachographs in transport vehicles of less than 3.5 tonnes. We must protect workers and actively combat social dumping. I also regret that the ECR Group voted against this report following the introduction of this paragraph.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report refers to the implementation of the 2008 Postal Services Directive and analyses the significant changes that postal services have underwent over the past few years, proposing some measures to improve them. I agree globally with the characterization that is made, and it is certain that postal services must adapt to the current reality, promoting greater competition in this sector, paying attention to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy with regard to more sustainable growth and a more competitive and resource-efficient economy. With the proposals contained in the report, I would stress two: the need to strengthen the independence of national regulatory authorities and enable fair competition. A final word to mention the importance of Member States' administrations also adapting to this new reality - of a more technological nature, in order to promote more actively the economic, social and regional cohesion, as well as the need to ensure the homogeneous benefit of liberalising this market to all its users, with a particular focus on end-consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives Parliament's position on the application of the Postal Services Directive.  This report calls for improved geographic coverage and better access to postal services, particularly for people with disabilities and reduced mobility. The text calls on Member States to preserve territorial and social cohesion. Ensuring that customers continue to have access to postal services is crucial, ensuring a minimum number of quality services at the same point of access.  The report calls on the Commission to improve the definition of universal service so as to provide a guaranteed minimum level of service for consumers, as well as to ensure a level playing field between traditional and growing parcel delivery.  I supported this text because it focuses on improving the quality of postal services, their universality and the protection of consumer rights.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. This report reviews the implementation of the Postal Services Directive, adopted in 1997 and amended in 2002 and 2008. With previous work in committee, we have managed to include in the text several important points that advocate a public postal service that is universal, accessible, sustainable in the long term and able to maintain quality jobs.   However, part of the rapporteur's initial approach, which advocates increasing competition to the detriment of public enterprises and enhancing high-end services within Universal Service services, remains in the text, forgetting that the liberalization of the sector in all countries of which data are available has only led to the concentration of private competitors in the most lucrative segments of the market and the widespread detriment of working conditions.  Thus, in order to reflect the balance between the positive and negative points of the report, we voted abstention.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive. This last legislative step towards gradual market opening is the legal basis for the fulfilment of the internal market for postal services.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 As stated in the European Commission's report, postal services have changed significantly in recent years. New technologies and electronic services have led to an increase in online purchases, while the number of letters is decreasing. Despite the rapid changes, it is essential that classic postal services are maintained and accessible to all users. Promoting cross-border parcel delivery and reducing price differences between national and cross-border delivery is therefore essential to create a single European market for postal services. Despite the development of new delivery technologies, postal workers need to be protected from increasing their workload beyond manageable levels. As my colleague Ferber's report points out, excessive burdens on workers and reductions in labour costs should not be regarded as flexibility. That is why I supported his report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report is positioned in such a way that the liberalization of postal services appears to be little more or less than inevitable. In this way, although it contains a whole series of recommendations on improving working conditions and protecting the universal service with which it could agree, it is at heart used to legitimize the reforms that have allowed the terrible degradation of labour standards in the postal sector, the ruin of public operators and the loss of quality in end-customer service. That's why I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ EU rules on postal services guarantee all citizens the right to affordable and regular postal deliveries, and this review of the EU postal market makes clear that such rights need to be protected. The review also recognises the continued growth in online shopping options and alternative postal services. It is vital that EU rules on post and parcel delivery are fit for purpose, ensuring reliable delivery options for consumers and businesses whilst also protecting those working in the sector through safe and secure employment conditions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ significant changes in the postal markets have also affected the universal postal service and changed the traditional nature of the services provided within it. I am glad that, thanks to the implementation of the Postal Services Directive, the legislative framework for postal services in the EU Member States has also been significantly strengthened, modernised and adapted to customer requirements. As the development of e-commerce is likely to be the main trend for parcel delivery services, the EU should continue with the roadmap for completing the single market for parcel delivery. I believe that harmonisation and synergies between postal systems, technological innovation and the creation of standardised conditions for measuring the quality of postal services will further accelerate access to the enlarged EU postal market. I call on the EU and its Member States, in order to communicate between people and guarantee the provision of irreplaceable postal services, to maintain postal services in rural and mountainous areas and to guarantee decent working conditions for all postal workers, including the required level of safety and health at work.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 Postal services are undergoing major transformations with the overall digitisation of the economy and society as a whole, to which both national and European legislation must respond adequately. On the one hand, we must maintain the historic role of universal service, which also operates in areas and cases that are not profitable for commercial providers. On the other hand, there is a need to open up space as much as possible for innovative types of services and alternative operators, thereby increasing competition, improving services and falling prices for the customer.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I accept the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive, as I consider the postal services market to be an area of the economy with a strong growth and competitiveness outlook. Strengthening postal services provides opportunities for innovation and by enabling this market to expand, we will drive the growth of the economy.  The parcel delivery market is a highly competitive, fast-growing sector as well as e-commerce, so this should be taken into account. It must also take into account the unease of postal services and costs throughout the European Union. The primary task of each Member State is to achieve the objectives of this Directive in order to ensure fair and equal competition.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the application of the Postal Services Directive.  It calls on the Commission to facilitate and strengthen cooperation and coordination between national regulatory authorities in order to increase efficiency and interoperability in cross-border delivery, and to monitor the regulatory activities of national regulatory authorities, including the provision of universal services, in order to ensure the uniform application of European law and the harmonisation of the postal market in the EU. I think it is wrong to harmonise the postal market. Deregulation and de-bureaucratisation, and possibly– in accordance with national practice, privatization of state-owned enterprises, mostly for traditional reasons, would be necessary instead.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The postal services market still remains an area of the economy with strong prospects for increasing competitiveness and growth, despite the fact that, according to the European Commission, the use of the service of written consignment service in the European Union has fallen by almost 5% on average in recent years, largely due to the electronic postal communication replacement process.  E-commerce is a driver for market growth, and the parcel delivery market is highly competitive. Consumers and small businesses complain that parcel delivery problems and high prices discourage them from using postal services, especially when selling or buying from other Member States. I support the Report on the Application of the Postal Services Directive, as I believe that the guidelines set out in it are well written and will contribute to the maintenance of universal service and provide fair competition in which to take care of the needs of users, access and quality of service.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive.  The postal services sector in the European Union has undergone a number of changes in recent years as a result of digitalisation. On the one hand, e-mails are reducing the volume of letters and, on the other hand, online shopping is increasing the number of shipments and parcels.  Despite the different conditions in each Member State, we need to promote and improve the quality and reliability of parcel delivery in the EU. In the postal services sector, we need market opening and competition, but this is the only way to remove the many barriers to online trade in the EU that we are seeing: high delivery prices, opacity, long delivery deadlines and unclear liability in the event of loss of shipment.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. The report calls for greater transparency as regards the conditions for pricing and the performance of services, in particular as regards e-commerce. The report draws attention to a number of cases of unfair competition in the postal sector, recalls that unfair competition can contribute to a deterioration in working conditions and calls on the competent authorities to properly penalise any misconduct in this regard. The report also suggests that the benefits offered by new technologies, including drones, such as drones, could simplify the delivery of services, especially in sparsely populated, isolated and remote areas.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The imposed balancing of state services with private postal services harms the interests of the Member States, since the State services provide a public service, with all that this entails (ensuring confidentiality especially in emergency situations, etc.).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to amend the European Postal Services Directive, taking into account the significant changes in this area since the adoption of EU legislation in 2008 to liberalise the area. Of these, traditional postal services and correspondence are particularly affected by the rapid growth of digitalisation, while the overall change and expansion of demand for parcel delivery has been triggered by the spread of e-commerce. The amendment of the legislation will help to ensure competition between European service providers and their better adaptation to new conditions, while paying due attention to the sector's job-creating potential in the European labour market.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Good quality postal services are an important part of communication within the EU internal market. From pick-up to transport, sorting and delivery of letters and parcels to homes and offices, postal service providers offer a wide range of services at affordable prices. Other sectors such as e-commerce, publishing, mail order sales, insurance, banking and advertising depend to a large extent on postal infrastructure. The EU postal sector therefore remains a key factor contributing to social, economic and territorial cohesion as well as the development of the Digital Single Market.  In recent years, the postal market has undergone a profound transformation, resulting in a decrease in the number of letters sent, a rapid increase in the number of parcels delivered, related to the popularity of e-commerce and the emergence of new customer needs. The European Union must therefore adapt its regulations to these changes. First of all, the focus should be on improving the quality and accessibility of universal service provision and making cross-border parcel delivery more accessible. Furthermore, emphasis should be placed on market surveillance in order to identify anti-competitive practices and increase price transparency for retail users and businesses. It is also important to promote value-added services such as tracking and flexible deliveries.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The review of the Postal Services Directive has provided the opportunity to examine the current state of the postal services market, with a view to protect the rights of consumers while adopting the use of new technological developments. Given the fact that postal services are a fundamental right for all EU citizens, but also taking into account the decline in letter volume over the past few years, the report has aimed to provide, first of all, a definition of universal service. An improved postal services system would contribute to the social cohesion and economic growth of the Union, and would facilitate coordination between national regulatory authorities. The report also calls for improved transparency as regards public pricing conditions and asks for transparency checks where prices are not controlled by competition.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The revision of postal services in 2008 achieved the main objectives of the liberalisation of European postal services. However, postal services have undergone enormous changes since the full opening of the postal sector market in 2008. On the one hand, paper communications have declined in many Member States.  The number of letters has declined in the European Union and between 2012 and 2013 the average rate of decline in the EU-28 was 4.85%. On the other hand, new technologies facilitate online shopping and thus increase the number of packages and parcels carried by postal operators. As a result, parcel and express mail revenues now account for more than half of total postal revenues.  One of the Commission's main tasks is to promote and maintain effective competition in the postal services sector. Promoting greater competition in this sector is also important to achieving the Europe 2020 targets for sustainable growth in a resource-efficient and more competitive economy.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Communication has changed considerably over recent years: communications are now immediate and our communication tools have become access doors to services. Those changes have impacted on postal services and, whether we like it or not, we send fewer letters but receive more parcels. Innovation in the sector moves swiftly and we must make sure the legislation keeps track and anticipate challenges. I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive because I share its assessment of the situation and the solutions put forward for the future of postal services regulation. We need a regulatory framework that maintains high-quality universal-service obligations while allowing a certain flexibility: strong and independent national regulatory authorities; increased price transparency and consumer awareness; and, if the competition between historic operators, universal-service providers and newcomers is fair, protectionism. This report is only a first step in the establishment of the next regulatory framework on postal and parcel delivery services, and I will continue monitoring those developments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Postal services continue to play a key role in the European Union, although the nature of this role is changing as the introduction of new technologies encourages the transition to online services and increases the volume of online shopping. The high potential of online commerce means that helping to realise the potential of the Digital Single Market is more important than ever for affordable and reliable parcel delivery services. NRAs continue to play a key role in supporting and overseeing the application of the Postal Services Directive in the Member States. The European Group of Postal Regulators, established in 2010, has improved the consultation, coordination and cooperation of NRAs at European level.  Overall, the two core objectives of the European postal policy, namely ensuring a minimum number of services of a certain quality at affordable prices for all users and opening up markets with fair conditions of competition, have been broadly achieved, although concerns remain about the cross-border parcel delivery market.  However, the postal market continues to develop rapidly and therefore it is necessary to constantly closely monitor and analyse the overall postal market and the effects of the regulatory framework, so I voted positively for the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for the application of the Postal Services Directive, as the implementation of the Postal Services Directive has helped to open up domestic mail markets and competition. The postal services sector is constantly expanding through the use of information and communication technology, providing opportunities for innovation and enabling the market to expand.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This report reviews the implementation of the Postal Services Directive, adopted in 1997 and amended in 2002 and 2008. With previous work in committee, we have managed to include in the text several important points that advocate a public postal service that is universal, accessible, sustainable in the long term and able to maintain quality jobs.   However, part of the rapporteur's initial approach, which advocates increasing competition to the detriment of public enterprises and enhancing high-end services within Universal Service services, remains in the text, forgetting that the liberalization of the sector in all countries of which data are available has only led to the concentration of private competitors in the most lucrative segments of the market and the widespread detriment of working conditions. Thus, in order to reflect the balance between the positive and negative points of the report, we voted abstention.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Since 2008, postal markets have been completely competitive. At the same time, the use of e-mail continues to reduce the number of mailings while online purchases continue to increase the number of parcels delivered, generating fabulous profits for online sellers (Amazon, fnac, cdiscount, etc.) and parcel delivery drivers (UPS, DHL, fedex, etc.). The report aims to redefine new objectives with the Commission: - The report deplores the fact that intra-EU international trade is no longer developing, and therefore calls on the Commission to ensure that domestic prices in states are closer to international prices. - Total separation of postal operator and postal regulation functions. - The need to maintain universal service (very contradictory point). - Relaunching the hunt for public subsidies as a distortion of competition. Universal service itself is seen as likely to distort competition. -Fighting against social dumping and wage exploitation while, at the same time, it calls for an opening to competition at the origin of this social dumping.  -Ultimately, obtain an integrated and harmonized postal sector. So I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Postal services are an important element in the smooth transmission of information, regional development and overcoming territorial barriers. There is a decrease in the turnover of letter shipments, while the volume of parcels delivered is constantly increasing for the benefit of the consumer market. Employment in this type of service is expected to increase in future years. It is important to ensure that this market segment is further liberalised within the Member States of the European Union, which is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2008 review of postal services achieved the main objectives of liberalising European postal services. Over the past five years, and as e-commerce has grown, the retail segment of the parcels market has grown rapidly, while competition in the mail delivery market is slow, despite the complete opening up of the Union market. I supported this proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – This report reviews the implementation of the Postal Services Directive, adopted in 1997 and amended in 2002 and 2008. With previous work in committee, we have managed to include in the text several important points that advocate a public postal service that is universal, accessible, sustainable in the long term and able to maintain quality jobs. However, part of the rapporteur's initial approach, which advocates increasing competition to the detriment of public enterprises and enhancing high-end services within Universal Service services, remains in the text, forgetting that the liberalization of the sector in all countries of which data are available has only led to the concentration of private competitors in the most lucrative segments of the market and the widespread detriment of working conditions. Thus, in order to reflect the balance between the positive and negative points of the report, we voted abstention.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. The report underlines that the postal market is still an area of the economy with strong prospects for growth and increasing competition. It also points out that the universal service must evolve in response to the technical, economic and social environment and to the needs of users. I voted in favour because I believe that the Postal Services Directive provides Member States with the flexibility necessary to address local specificities and to ensure the long-term sustainability of universal service provision.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ EU rules on postal services guarantee all citizens the right to affordable and regular postal deliveries, and this review of the EU postal market makes clear that such rights need to be protected. The review also recognises the continued growth in online shopping options and alternative postal services. It is vital that EU rules on post and parcel delivery are fit for purpose, ensuring reliable delivery options for consumers and businesses whilst also protecting those working in the sector through safe and secure employment conditions.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'The Postal Services Directive provides Member States with the necessary scope to respond to specific local characteristics and to ensure that the long-term supply of universal services remains sustainable. I voted in favour of this report because the focus remains on the needs of users and the changes in the technical, economic and social fields are being addressed.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The implementation of the Postal Services Directive, mainly since its revision in 2008, has achieved its fundamental objectives of liberalisation of European postal services. This liberalization resulted in a reduction in the geographical coverage and frequency of distribution; in raising prices and decommissioning unprofitable services; social and labour dumping, by replacing permanent jobs with temporary, precarious workers, with salaries often below the national minimum wage. This report, in a context recognised as more diverse in terms of communications (considering the increasing digitisation), which has taken scale off the objectives of liberalisation (maximising profits for financial capital), calls for more competition, more value-added services and the reduction (or non-obligation to provide) the provision of compulsory universal services. This whole process deserves our total disapproval. The evolution of this sector has been a regression for populations and users.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report notes that paper-based communications are declining across Europe, but the number of parcels and parcels is growing sharply. On average, revenue from parcel delivery and express deliveries accounts for more than half of the total revenue of postal service providers. On the other hand, competition in the letter market is severely underdeveloped. As the postal sector has suffered a net job loss, the report calls for a balance between free competition and the needs of consumers. I have therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ EU rules on postal services guarantee all citizens the right to affordable and regular postal deliveries, and this review of the EU postal market makes clear that such rights need to be protected. The review also recognises the continued growth in online shopping options and alternative postal services. It is vital that EU rules on post and parcel delivery are fit for purpose, ensuring reliable delivery options for consumers and businesses whilst also protecting those working in the sector through safe and secure employment conditions.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive. I welcome the rapporteur's call on the Commission to facilitate and strengthen cooperation and coordination between national regulatory authorities in order to ensure greater efficiency and interoperability in cross-border deliveries and to oversee the regulatory activities of the NRA - including the provision of universal services - with a view to ensuring a uniform approach to the application of European law and harmonising the postal market within the EU. He recalls that universal service must evolve according to the technical, economic and social context, as well as the needs of users, and that the Postal Services Directive gives Member States the flexibility to take into account local characteristics and ensure the long-term sustainability of the provision of universal services.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The postal market has undergone a significant transformation in recent years.  Due to technological developments, demand for traditional postal services is declining, while demand for parcels is increasing, mainly due to the expansion of online stores. The provision of basic postal services is considered to be one of the obligations of the State, and it is therefore important to discuss the scope of the universal postal service obligation. It is important to have comprehensive knowledge of changes in the postal market in order to obtain a global picture of the market. The cross-border parcel delivery market with significant growth potential should be of particular interest, and I therefore support the EC's efforts to support the development of this market sector. I also support the EC's efforts to launch a platform bringing together all the information on market players. Such actions will be beneficial primarily for the client and the possibility of making the best choice.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Postal services were one of the first areas of implementation of the EU and government policy on 'market liberalisation', i.e. privatisation of public services. Experience in the Member States has shown how false propaganda was for cheaper and better quality services in all the sectors liberalised (postal services, transport, energy, water supply, etc.). Public infrastructure, which is a popular property, was handed over to business groups, while prices skyrocketed for popular households and quality deteriorated sharply. The same applies to those undertakings which remained under majority state control, but operating within the liberalised capitalist market on the sole criterion of profit. Workers' rights were crushed the same regardless of their ownership. That is why the report that is supposed to assess the implementation of the relevant EU Postal Services Directive does not say a word. On the contrary, demonstrating the commitment of the EU and its institutions to ensuring monopolistic profits, it explores ways of pushing business groups into new profitable areas of these services, such as the delivery of packages that are growing sharply due to the corresponding increase in e-commerce and electronic transactions, in conjunction with the 'single digital market' promoted by the EU as a prime gold market for monopolies.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament resolution on the application of the Postal Services Directive dealt mainly with the changes the sector has seen since the full market opening in 2008. The changes concern, in particular, the reduction in the number of letter items and, conversely, the increase in the number of parcels resulting from the increasing popularity of online shopping. In addition to the themes relating to preventing discrimination against new entrants on the market and avoiding distortions of competition, the resolution dealt mainly with guaranteeing a minimum range of services that should be provided in the European Union, but also, for example, the affordability of postal services, not only within individual Member States, but also for shipments abroad. The very availability of postal services is of the utmost importance in sparsely populated areas or, apart from the site, also for the elderly or persons with disabilities. In this respect, it is very important, in addition to the availability of services, to ensure barrier-free access to post offices. As the motion for a resolution reflected all these observations, I voted in favour of it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the application of the Postal Services Directive. I believe that it is important to achieve the common objective of the Postal Services Directive to ensure the sustainable provision of universal service, also by calling on the Member States to have high standards of professionalism, legal protection for employees, to fair and non-discriminatory access to vocational training.  It is also important to provide universal service and to enable fair competition, accessibility, quality of service and user needs.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I was also happy to support this material, because yesterday there was also a debate on the position of SMEs in Europe. Their position for the success of the European economy is extremely important and, as far as I know and know from my country, from the Czech Republic, one of the problems for SMEs is access to capital, access to money. Especially if they want to do business in areas that at first glance do not seem too profitable, but are important because they maintain some traditional crafts or some traditional local regional production.  So I consider this material, which deals with the issues of how to facilitate access to credit and capital for SMEs, to be extremely important, and if part of the money used by the European Union to support and develop individual regions under its cohesion policy were used to support SMEs in the area of lending, that would be the right thing to do.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ar dtús ba mhaith liom moladh mór a thabhairt do mo chara agus mo chomhghleacaí, Othmar Karas, as an obair iontach atá déanta aige, ní amháin sa tuarascáil seo, ach in a lán a bhaineann leis an ábhar seo chomh maith, agus maidir le mo thír féin... I want to emphasise that we have one of the highest rejection rates for SME bank loan applications in Europe, and on that basis I welcome the views outlined by the rapporteur in this report. In particular, I note the approval of the non-banking finance recommendations that will provide alternatives to short-term financing options such as overdrafts, which often hinder sustainable development. Although banks are best positioned to provide tailored long-term financial assistance, the reality of the market necessitates an exploration of different means to meet financial needs. I think this initiative is timely and in the right direction, but I would also like to see further examination of the benefits of crowd-funding.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an own-initiative report aimed at analysing various possibilities for increasing funding for European SMEs, given their crucial importance in the European economy, both through the traditional banking channel and through new alternative methods. Although some parts, such as those on bank financing and financial culture, are acceptable, others pose a major risk to SMEs and small operators in general who would end up dealing with opaque and complex financial instruments. Reference is made, in particular, to the Capital Markets Union, securitisations and unconventional policies initiated by the ECB after the crisis. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in the federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – Different legal systems, cultures, languages, country-specific credit risks and the potential for capital controls (as used in Greece and Cyprus) in the likely event of euro-break-up make Capital Markets Union a distraction from more pressing matters (such as planning for an orderly break-up of the euro). Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The report proposes that the best way to boost SMEs in the EU is by pushing forward with the Capital Markets Union, which will promote the shadow banking sector that played a fundamental role in causing the 2008 financial crash and economic crisis. There are some positive calls in there for increasing SMEs’ access to credit from banks and EU funds, but the overall proposal is for the development of new financial vehicles based on securitisation and risk-sharing instruments, and this will supposedly solve the problem.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I supported this balanced report, which calls for measures to defend public and private investment, alternative financing tools and a particular focus on women-led and minority-led SMEs.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on access to finance for SMEs and increasing the diversity of SMEs’ funding in a Capital Markets Union. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are a substantial part of the EU economy. Access to finance for SMEs has, therefore, been a long-standing theme on the policy agenda. Bank lending constitutes still the most important source of funding for the large majority of SMEs. Therefore, it is important to diversify the funding options for SMEs to allow for a wide range of choices. I welcome the proposals made in the Capital Market Unions (CMU) Action Plan for connecting SMEs more effectively with a wide range of funding options and I support the initiative of the Commission to examine and assess barriers and obstacles for SMEs in tapping capital markets.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-caps are an essential part of the EU economy. That is why SMEs' access to finance has been on the political agenda for a long time. During the crisis, SMEs' access to finance was significantly more restricted than access by larger companies. The high dependence of SMEs on bank loans and the adjustment of the banks' loan portfolio triggered by the crisis have contributed to this. For this reason, diversification of financing opportunities for SMEs is one of the priorities of the Capital Markets Union initiative. SMEs must remain competitive. I am therefore very much in favour of facilitating and favourable access to alternative sources of funding. Currently, many SMEs are dependent on bank loans. The fact that access to such loans has become much more difficult as a result of the financial crisis makes it important that small and medium-sized enterprises have better access to alternative sources of finance. This is the only way to ensure their ability to invest.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The report's findings are consensual: SMEs suffer in their access to finance when they are a key driver of the economy, regulatory constraints weigh on them in particular, it is necessary to include the SME dimension in all texts of economic scope. There are a number of relevant proposals, such as the need for appropriate rules to make public procurement more open to SMEs and micro-enterprises, the development of local banks or the compulsory arrowing of certain ECB funds available to banks to provide credit to SMEs. But, as always, it is a matter of calling on the Commission to do so. We know how close institutions are to the major industrial and banking lobbies, and it is hard to imagine that the trial will be transformed. In the end, on the finding and on a number of objectives, this report merely repeats what we have been calling for for a long time, but there is a casting error as to the authority chosen to carry out such a small business act. I have therefore abstained on this good text which will achieve nothing because of the Commission's guidelines.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs function best when they are subject to the minimum necessary regulation and the minimum necessary taxation. It is absurd to heavily tax and regulate them, then provide state subsidies to those deemed worthy. This completely misunderstands the free market; as a supporter of SMEs I cannot support this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because, like the European Parliament, I have always made SMEs the indispensable basis for job creation in Europe. As a reminder, "SMEs form the backbone of the European Union economy and have enormous potential for job creation, creating 85% of new jobs; 20.7 million SMEs account for more than 67% of private sector employment in the European Union, 30% of which come from micro-enterprises." The Parliament also believes that "SMEs are the main drivers of long-term European economic growth and opportunities for sustainable job creation in the 28 Member States".

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on access to finance for SMEs and the diversification of SME funding in the Capital Markets Union. During the crisis, access to finance for SMEs was more limited than that of larger companies. This has been accompanied by a strong reliance on SMEs on bank lending and a reduction in bank lending volume caused by the crisis. As a result, the Capital Markets Union initiative has made diversification of financing opportunities for SMEs one of its priorities. I agree to facilitate access to the various funding opportunities for SMEs. However, there are still many obstacles for SMEs to access market-based and other more innovative financing instruments. I therefore support the Commission's initiative to examine and assess barriers to access to capital markets for SMEs. The analysis would adequately and timely remove the various restrictive barriers.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report considers it important that SMEs understand the complex forms, benefits and risks of external financing. Therefore, increasing the financial literacy of SMEs is a prerequisite for creating a capital market culture where entrepreneurs are willing to consider using capital market solutions. In my opinion, initiatives such as the Capital Markets Union will exacerbate the problems experienced by European SMEs, access to finance. This is because they increase the financialisation of the economy, thereby reducing macroeconomic stability and growth. Improving the financing of SMEs would also require a strengthening of regulation to curtail the strength of the financial sector and bring it under State control and to establish a clear link between lending activity and actual production. The typical role of SMEs is to meet local needs and to participate actively in the local economy. If an SME wants to enter the international market, it can usually only do so if it is strong on the domestic market. This includes financial security, which deteriorates to the extent that funds move away from the place of work. The financial provision of SMEs can be solved by local banks that lend specifically to small businesses and are familiar with their activities and can judge the risk of lending. As these are not encouraged in the report, I have refused to accept it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I would like to point out in the preamble that SMEs account for 67% of jobs, 71.4% of employment growth and 58% of the value added of the EU non-financial sector in 2014 and that 77% of SME financing outstandings in Europe come from banks. This issue of SMEs' access to finance cannot therefore be ignored, so is the sustainability and development of employment. I voted in favour of this report, because it calls on the Commission to support the development of a wide range of programmes, instruments and initiatives to support SMEs in their start-up and growth phases, taking into account their specificity and their financing needs. MEPs also call on the Commission to guarantee synergies between the various European instruments and programmes for SMEs, to promote a comprehensive approach to the dissemination of information on all EU financing possibilities and to make financing more attractive to SMEs. In this regard, it is also worth stressing the importance of the development of local banks because of their long-term relationships with SMEs.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Although not yet clearly defined by European legislation, small and medium-sized enterprises form the backbone of the continent's economy. They account for 67% of total employment, 71.4% of employment growth and 58% of value added in the EU's non-financial sector in 2014. These are important data which oblige the institutions to pay particular attention to the problems that these engines of the European economy may encounter. One of the most important issues is undoubtedly access to credit. The Karas report, which I supported today, is a balanced text calling for an improvement in the public and private funding possibilities proposed to SMEs. The financial services sector must necessarily be diversified, well regulated and stable and offer a wide range of cost-effective tailor-made financing options.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted against this report on funding access for small and medium-sized enterprises. We consider that the guidance it advocates, based on the consolidation and expansion of the Capital Markets Union, is erroneous and harmful. First, because liberalization of access to the capital market is not demonstrated to in any way lead to lower financing costs for SMEs. Secondly, because we believe that it is important in its diagnosis, since access to finance is not today the main problem of SMEs but rather the low level of demand.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report on SME access to finance and the increase in the diversity of SME financing in a Capital Markets Union. SMEs and mid-caps are an important part of the EU economy and, in this context, access to finance is, and needs to remain, a key item on the political agenda. It is important that such funding is given throughout the life cycle of the SME, where the transfer of activities is an important step for an enterprise and where appropriate measures must be taken to support SMEs in the preparation of the transfer of activities involved in tax incentives.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This initiative report is a reflection on how to improve the lot of SMEs in the EU. It concerns THE access of SMEs to finance and the strengthening of the diversity of financing to SMEs in a capital markets union.  I share the fact that SMEs suffer in their access to finance when they are a key driver of the economy and that regulatory constraints weigh on them in particular. Proposals are interesting (rules adapted to make public procurement more open to SMEs and micro-enterprises, development of local banks or compulsory arrowing of certain ECB funds available to banks to grant loans to SMEs, etc.). I doubt, however, that the Commission will go in this direction given its proximity to the industrial and banking lobbies.  Finally, the solution is to facilitate alternatives to bank credit, i.e. financial markets and crowdfunding.  Good findings, good ideas but no real will in fact, so I abstained.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some interesting points, the Karas report contains several critical points, so I preferred to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report calling for better access for SMEs to finance and increase the diversity of their funding, ensuring that SMEs will benefit from the Capital Markets Union and in particular from the provision of cross-border financial services. I also welcome the proposal that the ECB open lines of credit to banking only for SMEs.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it advocated for access to finance for SMEs and for increasing the diversity of SME financing in the Capital Markets Union. Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and mid-caps play an important role in the European economy in terms of employment and growth, with SMEs employing 67% of all workers in the EU's non-financial business sector in 2014, generating 71.4% of new jobs and 58% added value. At present, Union legislation does not provide a common clear definition of SMEs, with the exception of the categories 'small enterprises' and 'medium-sized enterprises' set out in the Accounting Directive. European SMEs are very diverse and include many micro-enterprises, often operating in traditional sectors, as well as an increasing number of new start-ups and fast-growing innovative enterprises. These business models face different problems and therefore have different financial needs.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this balanced and far-reaching report calling for measures defending public and private investment, with particular attention to small and medium-sized enterprises run by women and minorities. In particular, this report follows the work launched by the Commission in 2015 and asks the Commission to pay particular attention to the specificities of SMEs and to ensure that cross-border retail financial services activities lead to better access to finance for SMEs.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. While this report is full of good intentions for SMEs, it does not put enough emphasis on the role of banks in this area. Directing them to the financial markets is not a bad thing in itself, but getting banks to do their job is more effective. I abstained.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-caps account for a significant part of the EU economy. Access to finance for SMEs has therefore rightly been on the political agenda for a long time. Access to finance was more difficult for SMEs during the crisis than for larger companies. The strong dependence of SMEs on bank loans and the reduction in banks' leverage caused by the crisis have contributed to this. The Capital Markets Union initiative has therefore placed the diversification of the way SMEs are financed at the top of its priorities.  The inhomogeneity of SMEs in the EU is considerable: in the Member States there are different types depending on the business model, size, stage of development, financial structure and legal form. In addition, country-specific factors, including the economic environment, structural factors such as the legal framework and cultural issues have a strong influence on financing needs and the availability of funding options: yet they remain the cornerstone of the EU manufacturing economy, need to be supported and the integration of non-bank financial sources for SMEs is a key step in enabling them to survive.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – Small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as mid-caps, play an important role for the European economy in terms of employment and growth, in 2014 they account for 67% of all jobs, 71.4% of the increase in the employment rate and 58% of the value added in the EU's non-financial enterprises sector. Taking into account the above figures, sME financing should have a broader basis, in order to ensure optimal access to finance for SMEs at every stage of the development of an enterprise. Due to the differences between Member States and regions in terms of financing conditions and the needs of SMEs, they face a number of challenges such as the quantity and cost of funding available, economic volatility, slow economic growth and more. I was in favour of this report because I support the need for a diversified, well-regulated and stable financial services sector that provides a wide range of tailored and cost-effective financing options, thus best serving the financing needs of SMEs.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in the federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), as well as medium-sized enterprises, play a very important role in the EU economy. Compared with larger companies, SMEs, especially in times of crisis, find it very difficult to access finance. There are different types of SMEs in the Member States. They vary according to the business model, size, stage of development, financial structure and legal form. I believe it is important to support access to finance for SMEs throughout their life cycle. Concrete measures must therefore be taken to support SMEs also in the run-up to the transfer of the company; for example, tax incentives could be considered. To date, however, bank loans are the main source of finance for SMEs. In line with the rapporteur, I support the proposals made in the action plan on capital markets union. These proposals are possibilities for better linking SMEs with an important range of financing options.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The report proposes that the best way to boost SMEs in the EU is by pushing forward with the Capital Markets Union, which will promote the shadow banking sector that played a fundamental role in causing the 2008 financial crash and economic crisis. There are some positive calls in there for increasing SMEs’ access to credit from banks and EU funds, but the overall proposal is for the development of new financial vehicles based on securitisation and risk-sharing instruments, and this will supposedly solve the problem.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe in the importance of finding ways to incentivise SMEs and support them, especially by facilitating their access to finance. Access to finance was made worse by the crisis. The Capital Markets Union (CMU) initiative made one of its priorities the diversification of funding options for SMEs in order to offer other options beyond bank lending. The report encourages SMEs to consider the potential of the single market for their financing needs. It also underlines the importance of the implementation of the Small Business Act.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analyses various possibilities for increasing funding for SMEs, but some of them are not sustainable because they risk having just the opposite effect. It supports the importance of the Capital Markets Union which, through greater financialisation of the economy, represents a major risk for SMEs and small operators who will have to deal with opaque and complex financial instruments. A return to securitisation, another risk factor par excellence, is also recommended. These instruments will only exacerbate the problems faced by SMEs today, reducing financial stability and, therefore, growth. It endorses the EFSI plan, despite its complete inefficiency. Finally, the report supports the unconventional monetary policies initiated by the ECB after the crisis which, as the evidence has already shown to a large extent, have proved to be completely inefficient, if not harmful, due to excessive reductions in rates and price levels. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are a key part of the Union's economy, accounting for 99% of all EU businesses. Compared to large companies, access to finance for SMEs was much more difficult during the crisis, especially due to their heavy dependence on bank loans and the reduction in banks' leverage. Micro-enterprises and SMEs in the euro area have suddenly faced an unjustified tightening of demands for guarantees from banks. I believe it is necessary to diversify and improve the public and private financing possibilities proposed to SMEs, not by limiting their choice to the banking sector. Furthermore, I believe that access to credit should not be limited to the start-up phase of the business, but should be extended throughout its life cycle, in order to ensure a long-term strategic approach and support in the subsequent stages of development. I particularly welcome the focus on SMEs run by women and the most vulnerable groups, which face greater obstacles in accessing finance. It is up to the Commission to identify unjustified barriers and all forms of discrimination against SMEs. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-caps are an important part of the EU economy. SMEs' access to finance has therefore long been one of the issues on the political agenda.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the access of small and medium-sized enterprises to finance, and the increase in the diversity in the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises within the framework of a Capital Markets Union. Although the search for the causes of the difficulties in financing small and medium-sized enterprises is a positive effort, this report focuses mainly on strengthening conservative approaches that do not actually safeguard the interests of small businesses or their workers. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that SMEs form a fundamental part of the Italian industrial fabric, since they account for well over 137 000 activities with a turnover of over 800 billion and at least 3.9 million employees, I can only welcome the report presented by Mr Karas. The continuing crisis is sluggish access to credit, so it is essential to establish a regulatory framework adapted to the different financing needs for SMEs, since they are by their very nature uneven. In accordance with the report, regional and local banking will be facilitated, as it is the most adaptable to the specific needs of SMEs. In addition, it is intended to implement the use of non-banking sources through better financial literacy of the companies themselves (for an overall and clear view of profitability and riskiness) and the growth of more innovative systems such as crowdfunding and peer-to-peer loans. On the basis of the above, the Commission will undertake to draw up an annual report outlining the state of implementation initiatives and their impact on access to credit, alongside incisive growth strategies.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on access to finance for SMEs and increasing the diversity of SME funding in a Capital Markets Union and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The Economy of the European Union has a key pillar in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs): they represent an overwhelming share of the total number of enterprises, about two thirds of workers and more than half of the added value. I believe that the EU should seek to overcome the difficulties of heterogeneity of the types of SMEs and the different national circumstances of the economic environment or legal framework. In this regard, considering that bank credit is the main source of financing for SMEs and that its decline, motivated by the crisis, has had a significant impact on the European business fabric, I believe that the Capital Markets Union in perspective should take SMEs as a priority vector of their statement. I follow the concern of a balance between the stability of the banking sector and support for SMEs, and I believe that, under the new rules for the banking sector, their financing needs should be taken into account. I also share the view that financial literacy is needed for entrepreneurs and investors: in the case of the former, in the case of non-bank forms of financing, in the case of capital markets; in the case of the latter, in order to increase confidence in the investment. From the foregoing, I support the report.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ Different legal systems, cultures, languages, country-specific credit risks and the potential for capital controls (as used in Greece and Cyprus) in the likely event of euro-break-up make Capital Markets Union a distraction from more pressing matters (such as planning for an orderly break-up of the euro). Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with Mr Karas in calling on the Commission to improve the rules for access to both public and private funding and to adopt a long-term strategic plan that includes a wide range of projects and initiatives suitable for all types of businesses. There is a need to give greater visibility to EFSI, which, through its window, is an important source of support for entrepreneurship as well as for the SME supporting factor, a programme that facilitates banks in granting loans to SMEs.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – We should ensure proportionality as regards the early repayment of loans across the EU, with measures such as a cap to limit costs for SMEs and more transparency in contracts for SMEs. There are country-specific factors, including structural factors such as the legal framework and cultural issues, which influence financing needs and the availability of funding options, and these have a direct impact on their operability. I agree with the report on the importance of transparent, standardised financing information for banks, investors, supervisors and other stakeholders, so that risk profiles can be understood and informed decisions taken, and to reduce financing costs. The creation of a European database, collecting information on business strategies and the financing needs of SMEs, in which they could voluntarily enter their data and which would keep them up to date, could be a step in the right direction. Furthermore, by simplifying rules on support for start-ups, micro enterprises and SMEs, and by improving the EU business environment, we can further assist the contribution made by SMEs to a Capital Markets Union.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the proposals they put forward did not solve the problem of access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, but will expose them more to the risks of financial speculation. This report points to the problem faced by European SMEs in access to credit, however, instead of proposing a healthy retail banking system to finance such companies that form the backbone of the European economy, it argues that the solution should be the Capital Market Union. This proposal will only raise the risk borne by SMEs dependent on complex speculative financial products. It is because this report does not propose solutions for SMEs but for financial capital that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The challenges faced by micro, small and medium-sized enterprises in the EU, as regards the financing conditions, quantity and cost of available funding, are influenced by specific factors linked both to SMEs but also to the countries and regions in which they are established, including economic instability, slow growth and greater financial fragility. It is therefore necessary to diversify and improve the public and private financing possibilities proposed to SMEs, which must not be limited to the start-up phase, but must continue throughout their life cycle, and a long-term strategic approach is also needed to guarantee credit to enterprises and which takes into account the diversity of enterprises in size, sectors in which they operate. , business volumes. In the European Parliament resolution that I voted in favour, the Commission and the Member States are asked to support SMEs in this process, even in the first years of operation. In addition, the Commission is called upon to verify existing instruments, such as the Structural Funds and other relevant programmes, to assess the adequacy of the financial support provided to SMEs in relation to the objectives set.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises are a substantial part of the EU economy. SMEs' access to finance was a greater constraint during the crisis than that of larger enterprises, although these companies are dependent on bank loans which are the most important source of financing for them. It is important that SMEs have in-depth knowledge of complementary sources of market-based financing. I voted for a diversified, well-regulated and stable financial services sector that offers a wide range of tailored and cost-effective financing options. Given the high rate of youth unemployment, encouraging the development of entrepreneurship for younger generations is a viable solution to this crisis.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights the main measures necessary to improve access to finance for SMEs and also increase the diversity of SME funding. I strongly agree that SMEs need diverse and improved public and private funding which does not stop at start-up phase but also assists them throughout their lifecycle.  I also agree that the Commission needs to assess the review of the Late Payment Directive, with the introduction of specific measures aimed at easing payments for SMEs. This report calls for measures to defend public and private investments, alternative financing tools and also special attention to SMEs run by women and minorities. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs are the lifeblood of our economy, so I welcome this report's support for enhancing their access to different funding sources, and reduction in the overall tax burden and lower taxes for businesses.
