Without continued support for SMEs, growth and financing the wider economy will suffer, leading to a drop in overall exchequer revenues.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on access to credit for SMEs in the Capital Markets Union focuses on promoting a culture of risk and capital markets. The text insists on the necessary financial education of SMEs as a prerequisite for increasing the granting of bank loans and for extending the use and acceptance of the solutions proposed by the capital markets. It is not with risk and with financial engineering products that the situation of Europe's micro, small and medium-sized enterprises will improve. Instead, we should avoid any form of moral hazard and create a secure banking sector in order to guarantee the traditional banking relationship as the main source of credit supply for SMEs, avoiding favouring investment banks through the securitisation instrument. Finally, I make no secret of my misgivings about the Capital Markets Union, which, while proposing to increase the range of access to credit for citizens and businesses by improving and homogenising their financial inclusion, exposes them to a real increase in the risk of the entire credit system and capital, focusing on the financialisation of the economy and damaging, especially in the medium and long term. , savers. For these reasons, I am therefore abstaining.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that adequate training, support, access to finance and increased diversity of corporate funding are essential, requiring special training to prepare young people for the green economy. We must not forget that preventing environmental damage and transitioning to a low-carbon economy is a challenge for society that also offers new business opportunities for businesses that bring green products and services to the market.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Micro-enterprises, SMEs and medium-cap enterprises are the heart of European economies, providing the main sources of jobs and growth. We must strongly defend the implementation of measures to promote access to finance for SMEs and to strengthen the diversity of their financing in a capital markets union. It is essential to boost growth and innovation by encouraging entrepreneurship and risk-taking through access to financing tailored to the company's evolution. In particular, we need to strengthen the banking systems in Europe to enable them to meet the financing needs of these companies.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. If it is necessary to help SMEs, key players in the economy, in their access to finance, and to limit the regulatory constraints that weigh on them, it is not the European institutions, which are largely responsible for the situation, that will come the solution.  Indeed, we know the proximity of institutions to the major industrial and banking lobbies. Better opening of public procurement to SMEs is certainly commendable, as is the development of local banks or the compulsory arrowing of certain ECB funds available to banks to grant loans to SMEs.  However, the solution proposed by the Capital Markets Union, which is to facilitate alternatives to bank credit, i.e. financial markets and crowdfunding, has drawbacks. The result is an increased financialization of the economy, sensitive to cycles and costly, at the expense of stable relations between a bank and its client.  Demand-driven policies, such as higher wages or lower charges, or on national preference, would more certainly have an impact on the fabric of SMEs. I have therefore abstained on this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the own-initiative report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the state of small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe. The report draws attention to the dangers that SMEs have had to deal with, but also highlights the potential benefits to them.  My colleague Karas's report also highlights the need for administrative and tax relief for SMEs. I support his view that such reliefs would contribute to their development. An important part of the process of this development is also raising the awareness of SMEs themselves regarding the available sources of funding.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-caps represent a substantial part of the EU economy. Access to finance for SMEs is therefore a long-term issue on the political agenda. The variety of SMEs in the EU is considerable. The different Member States have different types of SMEs, depending on the business model, size, development phase, financial structure and legal form. It is important to support SMEs' access to finance throughout their life cycle, as well as to increase smes' knowledge of complementary sources of market-based financing.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Abstention: in the end, on the finding and on a number of objectives, this report merely repeats what we have been calling for for a long time, but there is a casting error as to the authority chosen to carry out such a small business act.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to support access to finance for SMEs throughout the life cycle. In fact, access to finance was more difficult for SMEs than for larger companies during the crisis. The heavy dependence on bank loans and the reduction in banks' leverage caused by the crisis have contributed to this. The Capital Markets Union initiative has therefore placed the diversification of the way SMEs are financed at the top of its priorities.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ There is a core neoliberal approach here. I voted against.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on SMEs' access to finance and increasing diversity in SME financing within a Capital Markets Union as such initiatives as the Capital Markets Union will exacerbate the problems faced by European SMEs. SMEs, because of their size, are disproportionately affected by the consequences of economic instability and recession and are already particularly exposed to the strength of the oligopolies that control production and credit.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support this balanced and far-reaching report, due to the proposed measures that defend public and private investments, alternative financing tools and special attention to SMEs run by women and minorities. I agree that we should encourage SMEs to consider the whole EU as their home market and to use the potential of the single market for their financing needs. We need to ensure coordination, consistency and synergies between European instruments and programmes for SMEs such as the European Structural and Investment Funds. It is also essential to promote a holistic approach to the dissemination of information on all EU funding opportunities by encouraging the Member States, the EIB and national promotional banks, in this context, to provide information on financing options and loan guarantee schemes. The report points out very well the financial problems suffered by SMEs and the situation of uncertainty experienced by suppliers generated by late payments by larger companies, public institutions and authorities, and thus I believe that the Commission should, during the review of the Late Payment Directive, assess the introduction of specific measures to simplify the payment procedure.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in the federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – SMEs are a key component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs. At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in a federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs. This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly voted in favour of the EP resolution on access to credit for SMEs and strengthening the diversity of financing for SMEs in the Capital Markets Union, because I believe that micro-enterprises and SMEs and mid-caps are the focus of the European economy, particularly in Italy, in terms of growth and employment. However, there is no single, specific definition of SMEs, and they are a very diverse world based on business models that address different problems, resulting in different financial needs. In the EU, 77 % of SME financing is based on bank credit, a very high proportion, and for micro-enterprises it is still the only possible source of access to credit. In view of this, it is considered essential, when reviewing CRD4, to maintain the support factor for SMEs, introduced to safeguard access to credit. At the same time, I believe it is necessary to diversify and improve the public and private funding possibilities proposed to SMEs throughout their life cycle according to a long-term strategic approach. SMEs should be encouraged to have a European vision and to see the EU as their field of action. Member States must reduce administrative barriers.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on "SMEs' access to finance and diversification of SMEs' sources of finance in a Capital Markets Union". A credit crunch puts a disproportionate burden on and puts a disproportionate brake on small and medium-sized enterprises and family businesses. This must be prevented, including from the European side.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. SMEs are particularly reliant on start-up financing from banks. In the wake of the financial crisis, such financing has largely broken down. This has hit SMEs hard. In this context, the European Union's Start-Up Europe initiative provides a welcome opportunity for SMEs to access start-up financing.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises form a substantial part of the EU economy. In the UK, they account for 99.7% of all enterprises and 53.3% of the number of employees. Four banks account for 85% of lending to small businesses. I voted for this report because it calls for improvement in bank lending to SMEs and for a diversification of credit sources.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report on funding access for small and medium-sized enterprises. We consider that the guidance it advocates, based on the consolidation and expansion of the Capital Markets Union, is erroneous and harmful. First, because liberalization of access to the capital market is not demonstrated to in any way lead to lower financing costs for SMEs. Secondly, because we believe that it is important in its diagnosis, since access to finance is not today the main problem of SMEs but rather the low level of demand.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I am Co-Chair of the SME Intergroup in the European Parliament and former Minister Delegate for SMEs, Business Environment and Tourism in my country, but also because I have worked in the real economy as an SME, which is why I am aware of the difficulties they face. Thus, the Karas report asks the Commission to specifically support SMEs, as they have suffered considerable constraints on financing compared to larger companies. As there is a great diversity between types of European SMEs, diversity is also needed in terms of financing options, and this initiative is a priority for the Capital Markets Union. At the same time, it is essential that SMEs have better knowledge of the costs, benefits and risks associated with financing arrangements in order to create a culture of capital markets. A simple and harmonised financing system is needed, which ensures a level playing field for all businesses and is the best way to ensure the development of SMEs.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises form a substantial part of the EU economy. In the UK, they account for 99.7% of all enterprises and 53.3% of the number of employees. Four banks account for 85% of lending to small businesses. I voted for this report because it calls for improvement in bank lending to SMEs and for a diversification of credit sources.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I supported this report because it makes concrete proposals to improve access to financing for SMEs at all stages of their development. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy but are finding it increasingly difficult to access capital. Often too dependent on bank credit, they must be able to diversify their financial contributions, including by gaining easier access to venture capital.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-caps form a substantial part of the EU economy. Access to finance for SMEs has therefore been a long-standing theme on the policy agenda. Therefore, I welcome the recognition of the importance of bank funding for SMEs in the Commission’s Capital Market Unions (CMU) initiative. Nevertheless, it is important to diversify the funding options for SMEs to allow for a wide range of choices.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in the federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. – We voted against the report on SME access to finance, and increasing diversity in SME financing within a Capital Markets Union since our group's view is that the financial system and especially the work of the Banking Union and CMU creates new barriers for SMEs to gain access to finance for their activities. In addition, the increased economic fragility of SMEs is due to the fall in their sales as a result of austerity policies imposed across Europe. Therefore, access to finance is not at the heart of the problem and the CMU proposal will not solve any of the problems of SMEs. On the contrary, it will transfer the risk of investment from the financial system to small and medium-sized enterprises, allowing speculators investors to take advantage of the tragic situation of European SMEs.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of Europe’s economy. They represent 99% of all businesses in the EU. In the past five years, they have created around 85% of new jobs and provided two-thirds of the total private sector employment in the EU. SMEs and entrepreneurship are key to ensuring economic growth, innovation, job creation and social integration in the EU. Accordingly, finance for SMEs has been a long-standing theme on the policy agenda. I voted in favour of this report, which supports the proposals made in the CMU Action Plan for better connecting SMEs with a wide range of funding options, and asks the Commission to initiate a thorough analysis of obstacles to SMEs’ tapping capital markets and to address these barriers in a timely manner.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The Karas report takes a position on making the most of the potential for job creation for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). SMEs provide about two thirds of jobs in the private sector. In order to further strengthen the potential for job creation, SMEs should focus on shaping EU enterprise policy. The report stresses that reducing administrative and regulatory burdens, as well as improving the quality of legislation and enforcement, should relieve SMEs. In addition, the report emphasises that fair conditions of competition are created for SMEs compared to large enterprises. Small and local businesses are particularly disadvantaged in over-regulated and bureaucratic management systems. Measures are needed to reduce market disadvantages for SMEs in such a way as to significantly increase their employment potential. I consider the report as a whole to be very balanced and I have therefore voted in favour of it. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ Different legal systems, cultures, languages, country-specific credit risks and the potential for capital controls (as used in Greece and Cyprus) in the likely event of euro-break-up make Capital Markets Union a distraction from more pressing matters (such as planning for an orderly break-up of the euro). Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report is part of the European Parliament’s contribution to the Capital Markets Union. It follows the work initiated by the Commission with the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services. The Commission should pay particular attention to the specificities of SMEs and ensure that cross-border activities in the field of retail financial services lead to better access to finance. The report calls for measures defending public and private investments and alternative financing tools.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the SMEs Access to Finance report and increasing the diversity of SMEs' financing in the CAPITAL Markets Union, as they, in particular SMEs playing an extremely important role in the European economy in terms of jobs and growth, were more limited during the crisis than for larger companies.  This report, which I supported to increase SME funding opportunities, also speaks about diversifying funding opportunities for SMEs, and to make this one of the priorities of the capital markets union initiative.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Different legal systems, cultures, languages, country-specific credit risks and the potential for capital controls (as used in Greece and Cyprus) in the likely event of euro-break-up make Capital Markets Union a distraction from more pressing matters (such as planning for an orderly break-up of the euro). Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ In the European Parliament we often refer to SMEs as the backbone of our economy. It is therefore important that we propose concrete ways to improve their access to finance. The regulatory framework should incentivise companies to grow, and access to diversity in funding is important. Financial literacy and education is necessary, especially in regions with underdeveloped capital markets, to help companies to improve their knowledge of funding options and processes. Going forward, I hope that this report can help the Commission to develop legislation which cuts administration for businesses while helping them to grow.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to expose the shortcomings in the SME financing model in Europe by assessing the ratio between bank and non-bank financing and, in the second case, to establish the specific needs of SMEs for access to capital markets.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy, but they suffered the greatest funding constraints during the crisis. These restrictions have been greater in countries whose banking systems have come under more pressure, particularly in the region. The new capital markets union tool exists to reduce financial dependence on banks but will in no way succeed unless it creates dynamic relations and links between SMEs and alternative financing bodies. At the moment there are no obvious links, which must be restored if we do not want to expose the sme production model to greater risks, especially in the member states of the region. This is a point on which the Commissioner responsible should place particular emphasis.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report explored future challenges and financing needs and conditions from the perspective of small and medium-sized enterprises in the respective Member States. The report also highlights the need for a differentiated and tailor-made approach to regulation, measures to be supported (e.B. tax incentives) and financing opportunities. I agree with this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report because it calls for improvements in bank lending to SMEs and for a diversification of credit sources.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – As an economist and on the basis of my international experience, I must say that the minority dissent that emerged during the commission debate on the substance should be considered correct. The problems of European SMEs in accessing finance will be exacerbated by initiatives such as the Capital Markets Union because they enhance the financialisation of the economy, thereby reducing macroeconomic stability and growth, and because microeconomic risks are passed on from large financial actors to SMEs, making them dependent on increasingly complex and opaque financial instruments. A general way out is to take public control of the financial sector by strengthening public banking institutions and regulation and to establish a clear link between lending activity and actual production. The segment of SMEs is to meet local needs and can best be financed by local banks that lend to small businesses and are familiar with their activities, so that they can assess the risk of lending. If an SME wants to enter the international market, it can usually only do so if it is strong on the domestic market.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on access to finance for SMEs and increasing the diversity of funding for SMEs within a Capital Markets Union. Small and medium-sized enterprises are fundamental to the European economy. Access to finance for them remains an important issue.  I support proposals to improve the conditions for granting funds to help businesses. The report notes that bank lending is still the most important source of funding for SMEs (77%) but it also needs to be improved. , the most effective non-bank sources of funding for SMEs need to be found. There is a need to increase the culture of risk-taking and capital market use, the potential of new innovative financial technologies and stimulate innovation through lending platforms.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-caps are an essential part of the Union's economy and have been at the heart of the political agenda for several years. None the less, access to finance for SMEs was problematic during the crisis, and caused companies to depend on bank loans. In addition, there are many differences between EU SMEs. In fact, depending on the State and the economic and cultural context, they change in structure, size, and legal form, in turn requiring different financing options. It is for these reasons that we set ourselves the objective of diversifying the way smEs are financed by developing appropriate strategic measures for each situation. The report therefore calls on the Commission to present an annual report on the state of implementation initiatives with their results on SMEs and their recommendations.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. Certainly, it is trying, at least on the surface, to protect SMEs. But I do not trust the good words of the EU which has always favoured large groups.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. We support the idea of better calibrated legislation for SMEs, but we have reservations about the EU's ability to implement it, even though it has always favoured large groups. I therefore abstained on this resolution.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in the federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in the federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to increase the diversity of SME financing in a Capital Markets Union. While it is inclined to continue to promote the bank credit channel for the financing of SMEs, it supports measures that can be taken to improve their effectiveness.  I believe that it is important to diversify SME financing options in order to enable them to improve their connection to other financing options.  Key elements reflected in the report include improving the public availability of financial information on SMEs, reviving the securitisation market, simplifying the listing, crowdfunding or peer-to-peer lending.  In addition, I believe that we must fight for a fair and simple tax system, which guarantees a level playing field for all companies, as this is the best way to ensure the development of SMEs. Given the importance of SMEs, both as job creators and as a key part of the EU's industrial and economic fabric, I support the adoption of this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to increase access to funding for SMEs.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the Commission's call for 'financing programmes for loan purposes that would allow banks to draw on ECB funds for the sole purpose of lending them to SMEs'. In my think, neither the Commission nor the European Central Bank should take care of commercial loans. Nor do I agree with the Commission setting a coefficient that would favour banks in lending to small and large firms. The Commission is not supposed to talk banks into a risk-spreading strategy.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because SMEs are key players in the EU economy in terms of their share in employment and value added. According to the Directorate-General for Internal Market Industry, SMEs employ close to 90 million persons. Bank loans constitute the main source of external funding for corporations in the majority of Member States. Companies in southern and eastern Europe are most reliant on banks loans. The global financial crisis has left a large private-sector debt overhang, and high levels of non-performing loans (NPLs), in several European countries. SMEs across the EU thus face many difficulties in obtaining bank loans, as the result of differences in terms and conditions for loans or credit in the EU.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ As SMEs make up a significant part of the EU economy, their access to finance is extremely important. During the crisis, access to finance for SMEs was limited and this contributed to their reliance on bank lending. The report highlights the diversification of funding opportunities for SMEs as one of the priorities of the initiative to create a Capital Markets Union.  Member States have different types of SMEs, depending on their business model, size, stage of development, financial structure and legal form, and different economic environment and structural factors in the Member States have a strong impact on financial needs and availability of funding opportunities. It is these multiple factors that are different in individual Member States that need to be taken into account when designing appropriate policy measures aimed at diversifying funding opportunities for SMEs.  It is important to support access to finance for SMEs throughout their lifetime and appropriate action needs to be taken to support them in preparing for business transfers. Tackling and fostering bank lending channels is the most effective way to ensure and improve access to finance for SMEs, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ Micro enterprises small and medium-sized enterprises play an important role in the European economy in terms of employment and growth. Is important to ensure coordination, consistency and synergies between European instruments and programmes for SMEs, such as the European Structural and Investment Funds, to promote a holistic approach to the dissemination of information on all EU funding opportunities, and to make significant progress towards further simplification so as to make funding for SMEs more attractive.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 The financial crisis has affected access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises. Funding problems particularly affect entrepreneurship in the cultural and creative sectors, which play an important role in bridging regional disparities and creating interregional cooperation, but their financing is problematic. If SMEs, as the driving force behind the economy, are to play a major role in the development and increase of employment, the banking and financial sectors must also take a more proactive approach to providing financial assistance. I therefore consider it important that the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, examines all appropriate financing opportunities for investments in SME business, including the granting of Non-Distorting State aid. Facilitating access to finance will help to close the gap between SMEs in individual countries and kick-start employment growth.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on SMEs' access to finance, and the increase in diversity in SME financing within a Capital Markets Union for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/9/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. Although we support the idea of better calibrated legislation on THE financing of SMEs, we nevertheless have reservations about the EU's ability to implement it, even though it has always favoured multinationals.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – Linking this resolution to the one by Guillaume Balas, I find myself once again stressing the importance of equal treatment for women and, therefore, I am pleased to see that the resolution included a prohibition on gender discrimination in access to goods and services. That justified my vote in favour of it. On the other hand, I agree with the rapporteur who underlines that a simple and fair taxation system is the best way to ensure the development of SMEs. On a different note, the use of new and innovative technologies that could provide new funding opportunities for SMEs, if it is proven to be effective, is encouraged.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. In the EU, we need to work harder to ensure SME access to finance and increase the diversity of SME financing in a Capital Markets Union. The crisis reduced the ability of these companies to access bank loans, something that must be fully addressed and also look for other complementary sources of financing, as we propose in the resolution I have supported.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This is about SMEs' access to finance. The report recognises the challenges associated with a differentiated and tailor-made approach to regulation. It also takes account of national differences. I therefore support this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 European SMEs account for more than half of the EU's GDP and employ around 75 million people. workers, and they create a fundamental link between the private economy and local production. I therefore support the ep's report, which provides policy guidelines to improve access to finance for SMEs.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report looks at the problems of access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).  SMEs, heavily dependent on bank loans, have been impacted by the contraction of credit by banks that are no longer doing their job of financing the productive economy. Rather than questioning the central bank's failure to indiscriminately refinance large banks, the aim here is to allow SMEs to access financial markets as their main source of financing.  To do this, the EU is setting up a capital markets union, which brings together initiatives developing non-bank lending (shadow banking) that further weaken the financial system. And the solution favoured by the report is that of "simple, transparent and standardized" securitization, i.e. the transformation of financial assets (debt, loan, unpaid invoice) into a financial security issued on the capital market. It is this procedure that is at the root of the subprime crisis.  I oppose this text which leads the EU towards a new financial crisis and votes against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. We support the idea of better calibrated legislation for SMEs, but we have reservations about the EU's ability to implement it, even though it has always favoured large groups. I therefore abstained on this resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. 'micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as mid-caps, play an important role for the European economy in terms of employment and growth, with SMEs contributing 67% of total employment to 71.4% of employment increase and 58% of value added in the non-financial business sector in the EU in 2014. This is why it is necessary to create incentives that provide better conditions for access to finance, as well as diversification of sme funding sources. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it stresses the importance of SMEs to the Union’s economy and the various opportunities that are open to SMEs through the Capital Markets Union.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – Small and medium-sized enterprises and mid-caps make up a significant part of the EU economy. The issue of their access to finance is therefore an important topic on the political agenda. SMEs' access to finance was more limited during the crisis than for most companies. The strong dependence of SMEs on bank loans and the risk reduction of banks triggered by the crisis have contributed to this situation. The 'Capital Markets Union' initiative was one of the priorities precisely to diversify funding opportunities for SMEs. However, bank loans are, and will remain, the most important source of financing for small and medium-sized enterprises in the future, as they are able to adapt to the specific financing needs of different SMEs, but it is important to offer improvements in this area as well. The report encourages SMEs to exploit the potential of the Single Market for their funding needs and to see the EU as their domestic market. It calls for the removal of barriers to the use of market and other innovative funding modals and stresses the need to convergence of rules and practices across the EU and the implementation of the Small Business Act (EU SME policy framework). I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls for measures to protect public and private investments, for alternative financing tools and for special attention to SMEs run by women and minorities.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Motion for a Resolution of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs considers financing opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises within the framework of the Capital Markets Union. It notes that bank lending is and will in all likelihood remain the most important source of financing for SMEs. However, this is significantly hampered by the significant strengthenation and re-implementation of the prudential and supervisory framework of banks in order to ensure financial stability as a direct consequence of the financial crisis. In order to mitigate the potential negative consequences for SMEs, the so-called SME multiplier was therefore introduced, i.e. the requirement that the capital requirement for SME credit exposure should be multiplied by 0,7619. The draft attaches particular importance to this multiplier. The draft also pays attention to the possibilities of financing SMEs from non-bank sources, such as securitisation, IPO, Crowdfunding and inter-personal lending. Finally, it states that the best way to ensure the development of SMEs is a simple and fair tax system ensuring a level playing field for all businesses, not only in terms of corporate income taxation but also in terms of income taxation. I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The report's observation is consensual: SMEs suffer in their access to finance while they are a key driver of the economy, regulatory constraints weigh on them in particular, it is necessary to include the SME dimension in all texts of economic scope.  There are a number of relevant proposals, such as the need for appropriate rules to make public procurement more open to SMEs and micro-enterprises, the development of local banks or the compulsory arrowing of certain ECB funds available to banks to provide loans to SMEs.  But, as always, it is the Commission that is supposed to remedy this, while its proximity to the major industrial and banking lobbies is a prohibitive obstacle.  More generally, the solution proposed by the Capital Markets Union would result in an increased financialization of the economy, sensitive to cycles and expensive, to the detriment of stable relations between a bank and its client. Demand-based policies, such as higher wages or lower charges, or on national preference, would more certainly have an impact on the fabric of SMEs. Forbearance.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. 'micro, small and medium-sized enterprises as well as mid-caps play an important role for the European economy in terms of employment and growth, with SMEs contributing 67% of total employment to 71.4% of employment increase and 58% of value added in the non-financial business sector in the EU in 2014. I am voting in favour of this report which encourages entities to create new funding routes for SMEs other than those already traditionally existing. I therefore believe that the Capital Markets Union should actively contribute to other financial support for businesses, as can and should be the case with venture capital.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report calls for greater financialization of the economy, it is not acceptable.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises form a substantial part of the EU economy. In the UK, they account for 99.7% of all enterprises and 53.3% of the number of employees. Four banks account for 85% of lending to small businesses. I voted for the report because it calls for improvements in bank lending to SMEs and for a diversification of credit sources.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on SMEs' access to finance and on the diversity of financing for SMEs in a capital markets union. This report points to shortcomings in the European SME financing model, whose main source of financing remains bank lending. While this is still to be encouraged, not least because banks have regional and local knowledge that better adapts to the needs of each SME, it should not be the only source of financing for SMEs (securitisation, crowdfunding, loans between individuals).

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted for Mr Karas' report. SMEs are very important in the EU economy and their access to finance has been a long-standing objective on the EU's political agenda. During the crisis, access to finance was more complicated for SMEs than for large companies. The Capital Markets Union initiative is therefore working to diversify financing options for SMEs.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) represent a substantial part of the EU economy, making access to finance for SMEs an important topic on the policy agenda. I voted for this report, which aims to increase SMEs’ knowledge of complementary market-based funding sources and the use of new technologies in relation to new funding opportunities.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ Access to finance for SMEs is essential to the wellbeing of the European economy and to growth, as SMEs account for 67% of employment in Europe. Bank lending was and remains the most used source of SME finance, however, as the resolution rightly concludes, the financial crisis brought home the realisation that diversifying access to finance for SMEs is important to avoid over-dependence on the bank sector. The resolution suggests ways to diversify channels of funding for SMEs, highlighting conditions that would create a conducive environment for SME financing. Removing structural barriers (i.e. reducing red tape and harmonising national legislation governing the SME sector across the EU), developing a Capital Markets Union in the EU, encouraging a culture of crowd-funding, introducing innovative technology (FinTech), and matching SMEs with investors are just a few of the concrete examples cited. To conclude, the resolution is very promising and I therefore vote in favour of it.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which focuses on access to both banking and non-bank sources of financing for SMEs. In the area of bank loans, I welcome the call on the Commission to consider how to adjust early repayments within the EU in a more proportionate way, for example by setting a maximum cost for SMEs and increasing the transparency of contracts concluded by SMEs. As regards non-bank sources of financing, account would be taken of the creation of a European database to collect information on business strategies and financing needs for SMEs, which could voluntarily enter and update their data. The purpose of such a database would be to collect transparent, standardised and publicly available information on SME funding, enabling them to understand their risk profile and make informed decisions and reduce funding costs.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. The report proposes that the best way to boost SMEs in the EU is by pushing forward with the Capital Markets Union, which will promote the shadow banking sector that played a fundamental role in causing the 2008 financial crash and economic crisis. There are some positive calls in there for increasing SMEs’ access to credit from banks and EU funds, but the overall proposal is for the development of new financial vehicles based on securitisation and risk-sharing instruments, and this will supposedly solve the problem.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. In view of national economic differences, SMEs are to be supported in their funding horizons. I think this is absolutely worthy of support.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. SMEs are an important part of the EU economy, so it is important to make these funding opportunities more efficient. The report addresses the ability of SMEs to obtain bank loans, as it is the most reliable method of financing for SMEs, and the reduction of obstacles to other sources outside the bank.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ Different legal systems, cultures, languages, country-specific credit risks and the potential for capital controls (as used in Greece and Cyprus) in the likely event of euro-break-up make Capital Markets Union a distraction from more pressing matters (such as planning for an orderly break-up of the euro). Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to vote in favour of this report because I have always defended the work of SMEs and their access to credit in my committee. I believe that SMEs are the real engine of our economy and the focus on which two-thirds of European households are based. I therefore welcome all sorts of policy that safeguards and inventively safeguards their work.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-caps form a substantial part of the EU economy. Access to finance for SMEs has been a long-standing objective of the EU policy agenda. As a substitute member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, I am working towards easing access to finance for SMEs, and the Capital Markets Union (CMU) can provide a good opportunity for them. That is why I fully support this report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal to increase the diversity of SMEs' funding in the CAPITAL Markets Union. We often mention that small and medium-sized entrepreneurship is important and that we must pay attention to this activity if we want economic growth and development with more jobs and a solution to social issues, and we forget that we must first provide small and medium-sized entrepreneurship with the conditions in which it will operate and help finance it.  Most small and medium-sized enterprises disappear at the very beginning of their establishment even though they had a good idea, but did not have additional funds available with their own resources, or were hampering profits or lacked funding advice. For this reason, SME's financial education is also essential in order to increase the use and management of funds.  Banking systems of financing entrepreneurship must be more lenient in setting interest rates on loans, because high interest rates on loans prevent development, and in most cases the shutdown of small and medium-sized enterprises, which must in no way be in our interest.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This initiative report is a reflection on how to improve the lot of SMEs in the EU. It is part of the Capital Markets Union approach, which has already led to the redesign of the prospectus directive to facilitate market access for SMEs by reducing the requirements for small issues.  The observation is consensual: SMEs suffer in their access to finance while they are a key driver of the economy, regulatory constraints weigh on them in particular, it is necessary to include the SME dimension in all texts of economic scope.  The solution proposed by the Capital Markets Union is to facilitate alternatives to bank credit, i.e. financial markets and crowdfunding.  Critics of this option denounce an increased financialization of the economy, sensitive to cycles and expensive, at the expense of stable relations between a bank and its client. Demand-based policies, such as higher wages or lower charges, or on national preference, would more certainly have an impact on the fabric of SMEs. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report is part of Parliament's contribution to the construction of the single capital market. In particular, it fits into the work beguned by the Commission with the 2015 Green Paper on Retail Financial Services and calls on the Commission to pay particular attention to the specific needs of SMEs and to ensure that cross-border activities in the sector lead to better access to finance for SMEs. More specifically, the report stresses the need to improve and diversify the possibilities available to SMEs to access both public and private funding, including in the post-start-up phase. It called on the Commission and the Member States to promote information on funding opportunities. It instructs the Commission to consider introducing loan financing programmes specifically aimed at SMEs. It points out that, where it does not distort competition, State aid may be necessary for the development of SMEs. SMEs are the real engine of European economic growth, an important stimulus to innovation and generate the majority of jobs. We must support them in the best possible way, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒SMEs make up a significant part of the EU economy, but their access to finance was limited during the financial crisis. Diversifying funding opportunities for companies like this has become one of the capital markets union's priorities.  I supported MeP Karas' report, as it is important that we provide adequate support to SMEs, which is particularly true for better financing opportunities and tax benefits and ensuring a level playing field for all businesses and their development.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The report focuses on the current situation of small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe, highlighting the potential benefits and risks that European SMEs have faced and face. SMEs and mid-caps make up a significant part of the EU economy. That is why their access to finance is so important.  During the crisis, SMEs had more limited access to finance than larger companies. Factors such as the strong dependence of SMEs on bank lending and the deleveraging of banks caused by the crisis have contributed to this. One of the priorities of the CMU initiative is therefore to diversify the financing opportunities of SMEs and the report considers such opportunities, with an emphasis on innovative financial instruments.  The report also stresses the need for administrative and tax facilitation for SMEs, as a simple and fair tax system is the best way to guarantee the development of SMEs. The role of banks should not be ignored, as bank loans are still the most important source of financing for SMEs. It is also important to increase the knowledge of SMEs themselves on all sources of funding. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report, which clearly outlines the difficulties our SMEs face in accessing finance in Europe, even though they represent the heart of the economy in all Member States. With this text, we remind us how the diversification of sources of financing for businesses must be a priority objective of the Capital Markets Union. The European Commission is the forth as follows to propose new financing schemes specific to the needs of SMEs. This is already a matter of programmes such as the Start-up Europe initiative and the implementation of the Small Business Act.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, it is undoubtedly undoubted that, in recent years, SMEs' access to bank financing has been severely restricted, mainly due to the financial crisis that has hit the European economic area. This is most serious when it is certain and known that bank loans are the biggest source of financing for European SMEs.  Despite this heterogeneity of the genesis of these SMEs and their financing modes, this report identifies the importance of supporting the transmission of enterprises, stimulating financial literacy, creating complementary non-banking sources to simplifying and harmonising member states' tax systems. I am voting in this report because SMEs being a substantial part of the European business fabric, the socio-economic impact of which is tremendous, it is imperative to ensure that these companies receive adequate support and funding, especially in times of greater instability in the European and global economic and financial systems.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Different legal systems, cultures, languages, country-specific credit risks and the potential for capital controls (as used in Greece and Cyprus) in the likely event of Euro-break-up make Capital Markets Union a distraction from more pressing matters (such as planning for an orderly break-up of the euro). Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of, in my view, that it is important to support SMEs financially, understanding that there are different types of SMEs, depending on the business model, size, development phase, financial structure and legal form. Country-specific factors, such as the economic environment, structural factors such as the legal framework and cultural issues, have a strong influence on financing needs and the availability of financing options. All these specific factors for SMEs and countries have an impact on productivity, profitability and the risk profile of SMEs. Given the multiplicity of factors, it is difficult to evaluate the influence of each one. This needs to be taken into account when developing appropriate policy measures to diversify financing options for cost-effective SMEs. The provision to the public of financial information on SMEs is essential for them to successfully access the capital market. Investors, whether they are banks, institutional investors or small investors, should be able to assess the profitability and degree of risk of their investment.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, Parliament focused on the access of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to financing in the European Union. He called for clarifying the conditions for obtaining loans for them, making certain information about banks and investors publicly available, and establishing a transparent and effective tax system to attract investment. SMEs account for 99% of businesses in Europe and they perform well. The wealth they produce has caught up with pre-economic crisis levels, up 2.4% from 2008. They also create most private sector jobs. It is therefore particularly crucial to help these small structures and facilitate their access to financing.  Encouraging SMEs and employment in Europe is at the heart of Parliament's concerns, and this is demonstrated once again by today's unambiguous vote.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) represent a substantial part of the EU economy. Access to finance for SMEs is essential. During the crisis, SMEs had more limited access to finance than larger companies. The strong dependence of SMEs on bank credit and the 'deleveraging' of banks triggered by the crisis have contributed to this situation. This is why an initiative is urgently needed to diversify funding options for SMEs as one of their priorities, with particular attention to those run by women and minorities.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in the federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of two reports that deal with the issue of small and medium-sized enterprises. The first report addresses the issue of SMEs' access to finance and the strengthening of the diversity of financing for SMEs in a capital markets union, while the second focuses on ways to make the most of the job creation potential of SMEs. SMEs are vital to the economic growth of our continent and account for 99% of businesses in Europe. It is important to be able to take into account their specificities in the legislative process but without ever, and I stress this, to question social and environmental standards.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 A very significant part of the European economy is composed of SMEs and mid-caps, with variable geometry in the different Member States, depending on the business model, size, legal form and financial structure, to which the country-specific structural factors are in addition.  This heterogeneity has an impact on productivity, profitability, job creation and the complexity of Financing SMEs itself. That is why each of these specific factors should be taken into account when developing policy measures that are diversified into investment throughout the business life cycle. I therefore support the rapporteur's proposals to support access to finance for SMEs, either through tax incentives or through bank loans, by improving the level of support through existing credit channels or to be created and through complementary non-bank sources of financing, such as those listed in the Capital Markets Union action plan.  In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this own-initiative report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which details the shortcomings of the SME financing model within the Union and calls for the development of a diversified strategy for financing SMEs within the framework of a capital markets union. SMEs play a key role in job creation (SMEs account for 67% of jobs in the EU) and the development of EU Member States' economies. Our SMEs are the drivers of innovation and development. SMEs have different financing needs that should be insured on as broad a basis as possible. Support for the development of a wide range of tailored programmes, instruments and initiatives is needed to support businesses, particularly SMEs, in their launch, growth and transmission phases. I supported this text, which reminds us how crucial the financing of SMEs is for them to grow and develop in order to create jobs and growth.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report on funding access for small and medium-sized enterprises. We consider that the guidance it advocates, based on the consolidation and expansion of the Capital Markets Union, is erroneous and harmful. First, because liberalization of access to the capital market is not demonstrated to in any way lead to lower financing costs for SMEs. Secondly, because we believe that it is in its diagnosis, since access to finance is not today the main problem of SMEs but rather the low level of demand.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ This report makes a significant reference to the fact that European SMEs and micro-enterprises currently rely in very large part on bank lending to finance their ongoing and investment initiatives. Opening access for them to new ways of funding projects is vitally important. However, it has to be kept in mind that such enterprises have limited time, experience and resources to get to know about these options and feel confident in following them. Rightly then, the report also emphasises the role of young entrepreneurs. It is they who will be more amenable to seeking out and trying non-traditional ways of mobilising financial support. Promotional and educational programmes specifically targeting young entrepreneurs, when launching new financial tools for SMEs, should have greater traction than with other sectors. That will have carry-forward effects since, as new generations come on stream, financing decisions will increasingly be tilted away from exclusive reliance on banks and toward other avenues. By preparing the ground for such a strategy, the report provides further impetus to the diversification of financing methods which are available not just to SMEs and micro-enterprises but also more widely. For this reason too I voted in favour.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on access to capital for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the growing diversity of support opportunities for SMEs in a Capital Markets Union. Access to funding for SMEs is an important step towards economic growth and job creation, which make up a significant part of the European economic landscape. During the crisis, this access was limited, but now the potential of SMEs is to be promoted as a priority.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the proposals they put forward did not solve the problem of access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, but will expose them more to the risks of financial speculation. This report points to the problem faced by European SMEs in access to credit, however, instead of proposing a healthy retail banking system to finance such companies that form the backbone of the European economy, it argues that the solution should be the Capital Market Union. This proposal will only raise the risk borne by SMEs dependent on complex speculative financial products. It is because this report does not propose solutions for SMEs but for financial capital that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 A 2015 survey showed that the main challenges facing European SMEs are customer search, the availability of skilled labour, standards, competition, production costs and access to finance. With regard to this last point, I believe that it is important to encourage the creation at regional level of new financial players that offer innovative solutions both to established companies and to start-ups. Considering also that the SME sector is extremely diverse in Europe; It is important that initiatives to improve access to finance include different measures that can affect as many companies as possible, taking into account their particularities. I therefore voted in favour of this own-initiative report, which recognises that diversification of sources of credit would lead to greater stability for the entire financial sector. Finally, I hope that a number of concrete measures will soon be put in place to increase financial support for SMEs and thus improve their growth potential.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises form a substantial part of the EU economy. In the UK, they account for 99.7% of all enterprises and 53.3% of the number of employees. There are 378 000 SMEs in the West Midlands alone. The report addresses the diverse funding needs of a diverse SME sector, bank lending to SMEs and non-bank sources for SME funding. As shadow rapporteur, I made sure that the report addresses issues faced by SMEs in my region and throughout the EU.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the European Commission and the European Central Bank consider access to finance to be the second most serious problem facing SMEs. I regret that we keep saying how much we have done for SMEs, but I, too, personally, often see serious shortcomings in the financial market in terms of lending, especially as regards the financing of new and small businesses. Many SMEs will disappear mainly because, at an early stage of expansion, it is struggling to access external financing. Unfortunately, I also see that investors and banks are often reluctant to finance businesses in their early and early stages. I supported the resolution because I believe that the measures taken will make it easier and easier for micro-enterprises and start-ups to access finance more easily. As access to finance is certainly one of the most important conditions for the creation, survival, performance and growth of SMEs, I support all initiatives allowing multi-source funding and a reduction in the cost of capital. I expect the Commission and the Member States to promote a holistic approach to disseminating information on all EU funding opportunities at European, national, regional and local level, which would represent an important step in their financing for SMEs.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 One of the biggest obstacles to the growth of SMEs is the lack of access to investment capital. The European Union is trying to make their situation easier and tolerate their development by offering new types of financial instruments that will encourage innovation, increased competitiveness and job growth.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on access to finance for SMEs and increasing the diversity of SMEs' financing in the CAPITAL Markets Union, as micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and mid-caps play an important role in the European economy as they account for, according to 2014 data, 67% of all jobs.  The volume of financing for SMEs should be as wide as possible so that it has the best possible access to finance at every stage of its development, as sme funding affected by the crisis is stronger than that of large companies. Bank lending is the most important source of financing for SMEs and therefore tackling and fostering bank lending channels is the most effective way to ensure and improve access to finance for SMEs.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on SMEs' access to finance and diversification of SMEs' sources of finance in a Capital Markets Union. The problem of SMEs having supposedly poor access to sources of finance is not addressed at the root, but only at the root of the symptoms. This is not the problem of the rapporteur, who is supposed to look at a limited section. A holistic approach must come to the conclusion that the problem lies solely in the euro. The euro-zone provides a single interest rate for all SMEs. In view of the different regulatory and cultural frameworkconditions, it is quite clear that credit risks must be very different, for example in Portugal and the Netherlands. Until the introduction of the euro, these different conditions were satisfied by an individual interest rate from the national central bank. The euro has destroyed this mechanism. Now there is a euro that, as an average product, offers the soft-currency countries too harsh an interest rate environment, and provides financing subsidies in the hard currency countries, right down to the point of bubble formation. As long as the euro is in place, it is unlikely that these problems will be resolved, especially by more regulation, as the report has suggested in part.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. In 2014, SMEs (SMEs) accounted for 67% of all jobs and 71.4% of employment gains. This is why micro, small and medium-sized enterprises play an important role in the European economy in terms of jobs and growth. Nevertheless, there is no uniform definition of SMEs in EUROPEAN Union legislation.  SMEs are diverse and include an exceptional number of microentergies active in traditional sectors, but there are also a large number of fast-growing innovative companies facing different problems that have different financing needs. The volume of financing for SMEs should be as wide as possible so that SMEs have the best access to finance at every stage of development. I support the SMEs funding approach report, as I think the guidance in it is well stated and will establish the best possible access to finance for SMEs.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on access to finance for SMEs and increasing the diversity of funding for these companies in the Capital Markets Union.  By providing two thirds of private sector jobs throughout the European Union, SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. Therefore, access to finance for SMEs is a long-standing topic on the political agenda.  The Committee on Budgets also stresses, inter alia, that the Commission and the European Central Bank must recognise that access to finance is the second most serious problem facing SMEs.  For this reason, it is essential that the EU budget, regardless of the legal status of these companies, further facilitates their access to finance and markets.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on access to finance for SMEs and on increasing the diversity of SME financing in the Capital Markets Union. The report rightly states that European SMEs are very diverse, have different business models, face different challenges, and therefore have different financing needs.  As the report emphasises, the crisis has hit the financing of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises harder than that of large companies. This situation still exists today, which is why I endorse the call for diversified and more public and private financing opportunities for SMEs not only during the start-up phase, but throughout their life cycle. Diversification is of the utmost importance because there is no single funding method that suits everyone, and a wide range of tailor-made programmes, instruments and initiatives is needed. Furthermore, in line with the report and the Capital Markets Union Action Plan, I also believe that SMEs need to be better linked to financing opportunities, as there are still many obstacles to SMEs using market-based and other innovative financing methods. Finally, I welcome the part of the report which includes distortions caused by the tax system. In agreement with the rapporteur, I call for a simple and fair tax system that ensures a level playing field for all businesses.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises and mid-caps make up a significant part of the European Union's economy. Increasing access to finance has long been one of the EU's priorities, but due to the crisis in recent years, its capacity to implement it has been significantly reduced. The Capital Markets Union currently being created aims to diversify funding opportunities for SMEs. The European Parliament's report analyses the entire life cycle of small and medium-sized enterprises from a financing point of view and makes a proposal to improve funding conditions at all stages. The report concludes that bank loans are still the most important source of funding for SMEs, but that improvements need to be made in this area. The document also emphasises the need to preserve the SME support factor with regard to capital requirements. With almost 99% of all businesses being small and medium-sized enterprises, it is necessary to take measures to facilitate their access to finance. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of Parliament's report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ I believe this is a balanced and far-reaching report which calls for measures to defend public and private investments, alternative financing tools and special attention to SMEs run by women and minorities. It is imperative for the Commission to pay particular attention to the specificities of SMEs and ensure that cross-border activities in the field of retail financial services lead to better access to finance for SMEs. It is especially important to emphasise that financial education for SMEs is not only key to increasing bank lending. It is also key to expanding the use and acceptance of capital market solutions as well as to encouraging women and young people to start and expand their businesses, allowing for a better assessment of costs, benefits and the associated risks. Encouraging women and young people is a very important aspect and one which has my strong support.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the text. The tax system has a strong influence on the self-financing capacity of SMEs. It should be noted that a simple and fair tax system, which ensures equal conditions for all businesses, is the best way to ensure the development of SMEs. It should be noted that it is not only a question of corporate taxation, but also that income taxation plays an important role.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs vary considerably across the EU in terms of size, business model, development stage, financial structure and legal form, and nationality. This is why SME financing is a highly complex issue and has become even more so with the economic crisis, as SMEs depend on bank lending by 80%. Yet, SMEs constitute the backbone of the European economy, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution to facilitate the access to finance for SMEs and increase the diversity of SME funding in a Capital Markets Union. It will do so not only by improving finance opportunities at every stage of their development and facilitating access to bank lending, but also by encouraging new sources of financing such as FinTech. Financial literacy, skills and knowledge of SMEs should also be promoted.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I am pleased that this report highlights the key role of SMEs as the core of our economy for growth and job creation, as they provide two thirds of private sector jobs and more than half of the added value of businesses in the EU, which is why I supported this report.  In addition to access to the global market, access to finance is one of the most important factors for the creation, sustainability, performance, competitiveness and growth of SMEs, and in the current crisis climate and in a situation characterised by budget cuts, a high degree of bank dependency and declining investor confidence, among other things, hamper the flow of funds into the real economy, and in particular into long-term investments. In this regard, cohesion policy is one of the main sources of support for SMEs and is important for strengthening their economic activity.  Complex rules and administrative burdens for access to ESI Funds have a particularly negative impact on SMEs, including administrative costs disproportionate to the size of businesses. It is therefore essential that these procedures are significantly simplified and that particular attention is paid to the fight against fraud and error.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing.
