I supported the proposal on access to finance for SMEs and diversifying the funding of these companies in the Capital Markets Union because European SMEs are very diverse and often operate in traditional sectors.  An increasing number of new start-ups and fast-growing innovative companies are also observed. However, improving access to finance for SMEs should not lead to a decrease in financial standards and regulations.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report on funding access for small and medium-sized enterprises. We consider that the guidance it advocates, based on the consolidation and expansion of the Capital Markets Union, is erroneous and harmful. First, because liberalization of access to the capital market is not demonstrated to in any way lead to lower financing costs for SMEs. Secondly, because we believe that it is important in its diagnosis, since access to finance is not today the main problem of SMEs but rather the low level of demand.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The access of SMEs to the capital markets is a fundamental step to increase the potential economic growth of Europe and its resilience to global shocks. The EU is still too dependent on banking credit and it must move forward with the Capital Markets Union in order to improve this situation.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This initiative report is a reflection on how to improve the lot of SMEs in the EU. It is part of the Capital Markets Union approach, which has already led to the redesign of the prospectus directive to facilitate market access for SMEs by reducing the requirements for small issues. The observation is consensual: SMEs suffer in their access to finance while they are a key driver of the economy, regulatory constraints weigh on them in particular, it is necessary to include the SME dimension in all texts of economic scope. There are a number of relevant proposals, such as the need for appropriate rules to make public procurement more open to SMEs and micro-enterprises, the development of local banks or the compulsory arrowing of certain ECB funds available to banks to provide credit to SMEs. But, as always, it is a matter of calling on the Commission to do so. We know how close institutions are to the major industrial and banking lobbies, and it is hard to imagine that the trial will be transformed. I choose abstention.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs play an extremely important role for the European economy, accounting for 67% of all jobs and making an important contribution to economic growth in the EU. The report underlines the need for a diversified strategy in terms of legislation and initiatives to support SMEs, and calls on the Commission to create a number of programmes and tools to support businesses in the creation and development phases, taking into account their turnovers and financing needs. Moreover, these programmes should ensure equality between women and male entrepreneurs. Member States are encouraged to reduce administrative obstacles for SMEs and to create one-stop shops that centralise all legislative requirements for entrepreneurs. As regards the financing of these enterprises, bank loans are the main source and, in this respect, the report recommends that Member States work with the financial sector to ensure full and equal access for all SMEs to bank loans. Moreover, supporting the principle of diversified financing, the report proposes the possibility of borrowing between individuals, in order to facilitate access to new funds for entrepreneurs. I therefore voted in favour of the report on access to finance for SMEs.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The SME sector plays an important role in member states' economic development, gdp production and job creation, and it is therefore necessary to open up new sources of funding for these entities. The focus should be on banking (loans, loans) and non-bank (public issuance, securitisation, crowdfunding) capital raising methods to enable companies to diversify their business contributions. I support the solutions presented in the report.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 European SMEs are very diverse, with a large number of micro-enterprises, often operating in traditional sectors, as well as an increasing number of new start-ups and rapidly developing innovative enterprises; as these business models have different problems and therefore their financing needs are different. I supported the proposal under discussion in the final vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against this report on funding access for small and medium-sized enterprises. We consider that the guidance it advocates, based on the consolidation and expansion of the Capital Markets Union, is erroneous and harmful. First, because liberalization of access to the capital market is not demonstrated to in any way lead to lower financing costs for SMEs. Secondly, because we believe that it is important in its diagnosis, since access to finance is not today the main problem of SMEs but rather the low level of demand.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the various initiatives under way aimed at improving access to standardised and transparent credit information for SMEs, which can increase investor confidence.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on access to finance for SMEs and increasing the diversity of SME funding in a Capital Markets Union. The report underlines the fact that micro enterprises, small and medium-sized enterprises and mid-caps play an important role for the European economy in terms of employment and growth. However, it acknowledges the diversity of SMEs, including micro-enterprises and mid-caps, in the Member States. The report recognises the challenges that SMEs face as a result of differences between Member States and regions in terms of SME financing conditions and needs. I voted in favour because I believe that a diversified, well-regulated and stable financial services sector, offering a wide range of cost-efficient tailor-made funding options, best serves the actual funding needs of SMEs and the real economy, enabling long-term sustainable development.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. U2012 SMEs are a fundamental component of the European economy, and a key lever for the effective recovery of it. To make this possible, the Union must support SMEs, supporting their creation and growth, ensuring their access to and internationalisation of capital. That is why I voted in favour of this report which contains a detailed list of measures to boost European SMEs.  At the current juncture, in order to make further progress on the project of European integration in the federal key, and to defeat the resurgent nationalisms that would like to condemn Europe to repeat the nightmares of the past, the Union needs to regain the trust of large sections of society, in particular that of the working class as a whole, including precarious workers, and small self-employed people. It is imperative that the European economy, where SMEs play an essential role, grow sustainably and create quality jobs.  This report can contribute to achieving this objective, together with an extension of the Investment Plan for Europe, which must be equipped with new own resources and the ability to issue European public debt in order to double the available financing.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 During the last plenary session, an own-initiative report was voted on to analyse various possibilities for increasing funding for European SMEs, both through the classic banking channel and through new alternative methods. Given the crucial importance of SMEs in the European economy, ensuring easy access to finance is a necessary condition for the recovery of the European economy. On the one hand, it is necessary to strengthen the banking channel, make it more reliable and adapt it to the specific characteristics of SMEs and, on the other hand, alternative methods must be offered to put an end to excessive dependence on banks. The report explores various possibilities for improving financial culture and increasing funding for SMEs, some of which such as crowdfunding and peer to peer lending have also received our support. However, there are some critical issues in the report. It stresses the importance of the Capital Markets Union which, through greater financialisation of the economy, poses a major risk to SMEs. It recommends a return to securitisation, another risk factor par excellence. It endorses the EFSI plan, despite its complete inefficiency. Finally, it supports the ECB's post-crisis policies. For these reasons, we preferred to abstain both during the vote in the ECON Committee and in plenary.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises form a substantial part of the EU economy. In the UK, they account for 99.7% of all enterprises and 53.3% of the number of employees. Four banks account for 85% of lending to small businesses. I voted for this report because it calls for improvement in bank lending to SMEs and for a diversification of credit sources.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Given the many forms of SMEs, including micro-enterprises, their financing needs are most likely to be met with a multi-sector, well-regulated and stable financial services sector that offers a wide range of cost-efficient and tailored financing options, and enables sustainable long-term development. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses that, in this context, the importance of traditional banking models, including small regional banks, savings cooperatives and public institutions, should be taken into account, and that the same attention should be paid in terms of financing to better access to finance for micro-enterprises and entrepreneurs with sole proprietorships.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The diversification of SME funding sources in the Capital Markets Union represents a siren song.  Emerging as an initiative to address the financing difficulties facing SMEs with banks, its real objective is to relaunch and revitalise the capital market of the Member States. The report masks the true objectives of this initiative and does not condemn the negative impact that austerity and neoliberal policies have had on SMEs. Instead of making an apology to the Banking Union and the Capital Markets Union, it would be preferable to read the real causes of the crisis which should at least give us the need for public and effective control over the financial system.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report addresses the challenges of financing needs and conditions for SMEs from different Member States and regions. It points to the need for a differentiated and tailor-made approach to regulation, the measures to be supported (e.B.g. tax incentives) and the financing possibilities. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises form a substantial part of the EU economy. In the UK, they account for 99.7% of all enterprises and 53.3% of the number of employees. Four banks account for 85% of lending to small businesses. I voted for this report because it calls for improvement in bank lending to SMEs and for a diversification of credit sources.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I strongly support this motion for a resolution on the report on access to finance for SMEs. As the resolution states, mid-caps and SMEs are a very important part of our economy. It recognises the role of the Capital Markets Union in making available new options for SME financing. This is needed as the EU inhibits a great variety of SMEs that all have different financing needs, depending on their size, rate of growth, future plans and stage of development. Currently, there are still many barriers to their making use of such financing sources. This resolution and adjoining report aim to remove or lower the barriers. Traditionally, banks have played an important role in SME financing, and they will continue to do so. We therefore need to ensure that banks have sufficient lending capacity. It is my belief that a stable banking sector and a strong Capital Markets Union will lead to stronger SMEs and, in turn, to economic growth.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The report on access to finance for SMEs and increasing the diversity of SME financing within the Capital Markets Union is a welcome initiative. I voted for the report which comes with interesting solutions for access to European SMEs to sources of funding. One of these proposals concerns the possibility of introducing 'lending funds' programmes, which would make the ECB's money available to banks for the sole purpose of lending to SMEs.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report aims to analyse the different possibilities for increasing financing for Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), both through the traditional banking channel and through new alternative methods. Given the crucial importance of SMEs in the European economy, ensuring easy access to finance is a necessary condition for the recovery of the European economy. While it is necessary to strengthen the banking channel, make it more reliable and adapt it to the specific ities of SMEs, alternative methods must be offered to put an end to excessive dependence on banks. The report analyses a number of possibilities for increasing funding for SMEs, some of which are unsustainable. Firstly, the Capital Markets Union, which, through greater financialisation of the economy, represents a major risk for SMEs and small operators who will have to deal with opaque and complex financial instruments. A return to securitisation, another risk factor par excellence, is also recommended. It endorses the EFSI plan, despite its complete inefficiency. Finally, the report supports the unconventional monetary policies initiated by the ECB, which have proved to be completely inefficient, if not harmful, due to an excessive reduction in rates and price levels.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report essentially advertises the EU's 'Capital Markets Union' as a way of alternative financing SMEs to bank lending, which it nevertheless believes will remain dominant. In practice, it focuses on large enterprises, which according to EU criteria are classified as small and medium-sized enterprises, in order to prepare for their introduction into the stock markets. That is why he is talking about 'cultivating a capital market-friendly climate'. The EU essentially baptizes small and medium-sized enterprises as powerful business groups or equivalent mid-caps that operate by satellite to them. Revealing is the EU definition of SMEs, which includes enterprises with 250 employees and 50 million turnover, while for their funding from the notorious Fund for Strategic Investments (also known as the 'Juncker Fund') the definition of SMEs concerns enterprises with 3000 employees! The really small businesses, the poor self-employed and small professional craftsmen are crushed by the dominance of the monopolistic groups served by the unpopular policy of the EU and governments, the same as the one that crushes the working class and the poor middle class. Their interest lies in their great social alliance with the working class against monopolies and their associations, for radical changes in power and the economy.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 This report focuses mainly on the contribution of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises to the European Union economy and looks for ways to facilitate their access to finance. Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises make a significant contribution to employment growth as well as added value in the non-financial sector. Unfortunately, however, these businesses still face many obstacles and most of them are not involved in foreign business. At the same time, their funding opportunities remain limited and up to 77% of their funding is provided by banks. That is why, in this report, we called on the Commission to carefully assess not only the discrimination, obstacles and challenges faced by these businesses, but also to promote, together with the Member States, the widest possible possibilities for financial resources for these enterprises, including in various innovative ways. As these enterprises have arguably been the driving force of the European economy and make a significant contribution to the creation of stable jobs, I was happy to support the report.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Karas report because I agree with the need for diversification of sources of finance for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the European Union. I would like to point out that, on the one hand, European SMEs are characterised by a great heterogeneity and include a large number of micro-enterprises, start-ups and innovative fast-growing companies, which, because they have different business models, face different problems with different financing needs. I therefore stress the need for SMEs to have improved and more diversified public and private funding options, which are not restricted to the start-up phase but to their entire life cycle. To this end, the Commission and the Member States should support SMEs in this process, not only on funding, but also on regulation and initiatives to be supported.  As there is no single funding model suitable for all, the Commission needs to support the development of a wide range of customised programmes, instruments and initiatives in order to support companies in their start-up and growth phase, taking into account their size, turnover and specific financing needs.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I supported the report on access to finance for SMEs and diversifying the funding of these companies in the Capital Markets Union. I believe that SMEs play an important role in employment and growth in the European economy, with SMEs in the EU representing 67% of all employment, 71.4% of the increase in employment (2014).  The financing of SMEs has suffered more as a result of the crisis than the financing of large companies, and they have struggled in the euro area to some extent by tightening banks' lending insurance requirements.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I was able to vote in favour of the report. SMEs provide 85% of all jobs in the EU. This is the backbone of the European economy and must not be constantly brought up to the limits of stress. On the contrary, SMEs must be relieved of taxes and levies and this terrible excessive bureaucracy. Many of my amendments were adopted in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. I think it is essential, for example, that we protect the Master's Letter, that we do not make corporate social responsibility compulsory, but that we still do so voluntarily. And when it come to the integration of refugees into the labour market, where SMEs are doing great, exemplary things, where we can say 'we want this', vocational training and, of course, language courses must be the focus. There must be no special labour market for refugees, let us not undermine minimum wages. Well-trained refugees counteract the shortage of skilled workers in small and medium-sized enterprises and the craft sector. And it is also a question of applied humanity and solidarity.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The situation of small and medium-sized enterprises requires a differentiated approach. Regional differences between Member States must be taken into account. The shortage of skilled workers is already causing huge problems in central and eastern European states, with only one cause of under-development of vocational training systems and the other a massive exodus. Some states, a significant proportion of their active population, work abroad, typically in EU Member States in Western Europe, reducing structural labour shortages in these countries.  The answer to this phenomenon may not be to close down, to reduce work abroad by all administrative means, but to increase wage levels in the new Member States. As long as there are average wage differences between eight and 10 times in the Member States, do not expect a change in labour migration between Member States. Migration will always be present and labour-issuing countries will face a number of problems in the coming decades, such as demographic imbalances, unsustainability of pension systems and labour shortages.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The EU economy is underpinmed by small and medium-sized enterprises. As many as 99% of companies in the Union are included in this group and account for nearly two thirds of jobs. Moreover, in times of crisis, they have proved to be the most stable element of the European economy, as well as the main creation of new jobs. On the other hand, it should be borne in mind that these jobs are not always of good quality. The sources of this situation should be looked for in the difficult situation of this segment of companies. Member State governments very often give preference only to multinational corporations by offering them special legal status and tax credits, and these privileges are not granted to local, small and medium-sized entrepreneurs. This unequal competition forces them to reduce their labour costs. Therefore, if we want to improve the labour market situation, we should first of all support small and medium-sized enterprises in their unequal fight against global corporations. This will not only create new jobs, but also improve the quality of existing ones. In this context, it also appears that the European Commission must assess the impact of the decision to grant market economy status to China on the quantity and quality of jobs in the small and medium-sized enterprises sector in Europe. There is a high risk that a positive decision on this issue will contribute to the deterioration of the situation of small and medium-sized enterprises and thus to the deterioration of the situation on the European labour market. I therefore voted in favour of this directive.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the rules of the internal market, the regulatory framework applicable to SMEs still has major divergences within member states. The report indicates the necessary policies, both at national and European level, in order to achieve a healthy environment for business development and to boost their job creation potential. Although many of our positions have been incorporated into the report, others have remained outside, such as the disparity in fiscal conditions in the various Member States, which generates social dumping, the impact that European constraints on budgetary policies, austerity, excessive taxation and inadequate public expenditure have on the job creation potential of SMEs and their competitiveness and competitiveness. , finally, the equalization of apprenticeships and traineeships with all other forms of work, including equal treatment in social and social security terms. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. Although the report seeks to tell the Commission and Member States that more needs to be done to help SMEs and reduce the regulatory burden (which in principle UKIP supports), it then goes on to call for wide ranging Commission action and further legislation. The initial report seeks to tell Member States what their taxation policy should be, calls to create an EU framework regulation for pan-EU crowd funding and welcomes an EU proposal on business insolvency among many other things. If it wasn’t due to the cost of EU regulation and overly bureaucratic EU red tape SMEs would have a much better chance at growing. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. While I fully support the concept that SMEs have a lot of potential for job creation, the report placed far too much emphasis on reducing protection, rights, wages and conditions for workers. While it had some positive calls for further education and training of workers and access to support for SMEs, it also included negative calls for the promotion of temporary work by the Commission and Member States, as well as for ‘regulatory burdens’ in health and safety to be reduced. Due to the generally neoliberal, anti-worker approach of the report I voted against.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. As such, it is essential to promote fair competition, access to finance, an adequate regulatory environment and good social dialogue to enable SMEs to create sustainable and quality jobs.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on harnessing job creation potential for SMEs. Unemployment and migration flows are the biggest challenges facing Europe at the moment. Therefore, for EU Member States it is crucial to strengthen the conditions for new job creation. The European economic structure is mainly based on SMEs, which are a heterogeneous group and there is a diversity of small business models. The report underlines that for achieving a sound environment for business development and boosting its job creation potential, national and European policies must as a priority address the issues of skills, regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens. It highlights the necessity of ensuring a level playing field for the SMEs regarding their competitive position compared with large corporations. In this regard, there is a need for specific measures for SMEs in order to curb their market diseconomies, enabling their internationalisation and boosting their job creation potential.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. This is a fundamental task for the EU at the moment, given the current very high number of unemployed and migratory flows, namely to improve the conditions for job creation in all EU Member States, both peripheral and central. The EU's economic structure is based mainly on small and medium-sized enterprises, which create new jobs and are seen as the engine of the Union's economy. Over the last decade, SMEs have created 85% of jobs in the EU. SMEs should therefore be the focus of the design of enterprise policy in the European Union and all necessary steps should be taken to strengthen the potential for job creation in this sector. This can only be done on the basis of an in-depth study of the existing barriers. The report contains such an examination of the problem.  Eastern Belgium is also affected by a general shortage of skilled workers or problems in the training of workers. I therefore support Parliament's report on the further creation of methods to help make the best use of the potential of SMEs in terms of job creation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report puts SMEs at the centre of concerns and calls for the reduction of the administrative and bureaucratic burden on them. Whether it's effect tracking is something else. But this is a good move: so I voted in favour.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The report seeks to encourage the Commission and Member States to take into account the needs of SMEs and try to lift the burden on them. In principle this sounds great, but the report goes on to call for far—reaching Commission action and legislation. It discusses taxation policy, information campaigns, data collection and legislative action.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because, like the European Parliament, I have always made SMEs the indispensable basis for job creation in Europe. As a reminder, "SMEs form the backbone of the European Union economy and have enormous potential for job creation, creating 85% of new jobs; 20.7 million SMEs account for more than 67% of private sector employment in the European Union, 30% of which come from micro-enterprises." The Parliament also believes that "SMEs are the main drivers of long-term European economic growth and opportunities for sustainable job creation in the 28 Member States".

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on how to make the most of the job creation potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The number of unemployed remains the highest in the EU as a whole. In 2015, it had 23 million unemployed people, including 4.5 million men and women under the age of 25 who did not work or learn. The recent arrival of hundreds of thousands of migrants is another huge social challenge, as more and more jobs are needed to properly integrate people in Europe. I believe that SMEs should be the focus of the eu and all necessary steps must be taken to strengthen the job creation potential of this sector. I therefore agree with the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in relation to their competitive position vis-à-vis large enterprises.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to support SMEs in order to develop a sustainable economic fabric, close to the citizens, of human size and creator of non-relocable jobs. It should be remembered that while almost 99% of European companies are SMEs and that they create more jobs than other private sector firms (about two thirds of all private sector jobs in the EU), they often do not enjoy the same advantages as multinational companies, either in terms of taxation economies of scale, or access to technology. As a result, the report calls on Member States to adopt, among other things, the principle of taxation of income where it is generated and other measures aimed at countering the tax optimization practices of multinationals. MEPs also consider it necessary to reduce the administrative burden on SMEs , while of course ensuring that employees have adequate health and safety protection, but also to combat their limited access to financing and new technologies.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. This report provides a huge number of excellent recommendations to better harness the job creation potential of SMEs. That is why I voted for it. I would like to highlight some of the recommendations, such as the growing importance of self-employment and micro-enterprises, which are of fundamental importance in driving innovation and entrepreneurship as well as the disproportionately higher administrative burden on self-employed workers and micro-enterprises. The report also highlights the significant value of cooperatives and social enterprises, which employs more than 14 million people, representing approximately 6.5% of EU workers.  It also proposes favourable tax treatment for SMEs as well as a regulatory framework that encourages investment in SMEs and social enterprises.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Z. Krasnod-bski's own-initiative report on methods for making the most of the potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to create jobs, as it is extremely important for the European labour market and the development of the European economy to promote and support the situation of small and medium-sized enterprises. The report contains a number of proposals worth supporting, such as the evaluation and removal of bureaucratic hurdles in the Member States or the promotion of modern and flexible working time models and forms of work.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. SMEs make an important contribution to the union's socio-economic growth and development, supporting them means actually combating unemployment and, in particular, youth unemployment, which remains at historic levels today. The creation of jobs in small and medium-sized enterprises is, however, influenced by a number of factors, both internal and external, ranging from access to finance to administrative burdens, through skilled labour. The Krasnodębski report, which I supported in my vote, calls on the Commission and the Member States to work towards crucial problems such as skills shortages, regulatory uncertainty, lack of innovation capacity and access to credit. Only through a holistic approach, which develops a good social dialogue and takes into account the skills needed for workers in the twenty-first century, will it be possible to create jobs in SMEs.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. This report seeks to identify problems that make it difficult for SMEs to achieve an effective growth rate and create jobs. The report focuses to a large extent on reducing 'administrative burdens' on SMEs and, although it has been improved in the Employment Committee with some progressive content, its basic premise remains neoliberal: that laws and regulations, including payment to workers and working conditions, health and safety, are administrative burdens and should be reduced in order to promote growth. Although it does not directly call for the elimination or reduction of minimum wage standards, it says that "high labour costs" are one of the most important restrictions on job creation in the SME sector. It implicitly calls for an exemption from regulatory rules for SMEs, and suggests the move from direct imposition to indirect, clearly regressive taxation. It also stresses the importance of temporary employment in the SME sector and "urges the Commission and Member States to support all forms of temporary employment". That is why we voted against it.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. I would like to congratulate my colleague on this report in support of European SMEs, which are key drivers of growth for our economies. A balance must be struck between the dogma of "free and undistorted competition" advocated by the European Commission, which prevents any national aid, and the freedom to undertake that allows support for SMEs that often cannot compete on equal terms with The American or Asian giants. On the other hand, let us not forget that any start-up requires financing and therefore bank loans that are difficult to obtain. Let us encourage banks to support entrepreneurs more effectively throughout the business process: from the design phase to the manufacturing phase of its product. Creativity needs to be encouraged and supported. Young entrepreneurs bring dynamism and jobs for national economies and for Europe as a whole. Let us help them to establish themselves on European territory and do not impose too many administrative or fiscal constraints on them, otherwise they will disappear in favour of our non-European neighbours.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in this report on how best to harness the job creation potential of SMEs. We must identify well what we mean when we talk about false self-employed people, as this growing phenomenon raises concerns. The administrative burden on the self-employed and micro-enterprises must be reduced, as they are often overwhelmed by bureaucracy.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report proposes to support SMEs in developing employment. Indeed, over the past ten years, SMEs have created 85% of new jobs in Europe. In 2015, small businesses contributed up to 71% of employment growth in the non-financial market economy.  The report provides an overview of the challenges faced by SMEs, and the ways to address them. It stresses that national and European policies must address skills issues (shortages, inadequacies, brain drain), regulatory insecurity and administrative burden, as well as the problems of undeclared work and the de facto privileged position of multinational enterprises.  In addition, the report stresses the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in terms of their competitive position with respect to large companies.  Finally, states should give priority to SMEs and ensure that entrepreneurs avoid the closure of their businesses for various problems (complex procedures, late payments, unfair competition, transmission and succession, etc.). So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report being voted on is balanced and broadly acceptable. I believe that the role played by small and medium-sized enterprises in the economic growth of the Member States is fundamental. I strongly reiterate my conviction of the need for a radical renewal of the system for programming and managing the European Structural Funds, making it less complex and eliminating all the current administrative burdens on businesses before, during and after the granting of aid. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises form the backbone of the European economy, with 99% of businesses and 67% of employment. An adequate regulatory framework, access to funding and skills are key to ensuring its momentum and the creation of stable and quality employment. Thanks to the work of the S&D Group, the report emphasizes the need to promote social protection and occupational health and the creation of quality employment, as well as to address the problems of precarious labour, false self-employed people, unfair competition and wage and employment inequalities between men and women. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has advocated better job creation for SMEs. SMEs create more jobs than other private sector companies, employing around two thirds of all people working in the EU's private sector, making an important contribution to the social and economic growth and development of the EU. Support for SMEs helps to combat European unemployment and youth unemployment, which is 8.9% and 19.4% respectively, which is particularly important given the number of unemployed people of around 23 million. people in 2015 – which remains historically high so far. In Parliament's view, in order to ensure better conditions for the creation of quality jobs in the SME sector, Member States and the Commission need to address the following different challenges in different Member States and regions: skills shortages, inadequate assessment of future skills needs, skills mismatches, brain drain, unnecessary regulatory burden and regulatory uncertainty in all areas, lack of dialogue between labour market stakeholders, limited access to finance and public procurement , low innovative capacity and access to new technologies, insufficient support for SMEs in public investment policy, the shadow economy and fraud, as well as the particularly favourable situation of multinational corporations.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 With around 99% of European businesses being SMEs, their ability to create jobs has a major impact on the performance of the European economy. As our two biggest current challenges are reducing unemployment and halting migration flows, small and medium-sized enterprises should be at the heart of entrepreneurship policy development in the EU and all necessary steps must be taken to strengthen job creation in this sector. This is only possible on the basis of an in-depth mapping of existing strings. The SME sector in Europe is diverse and fragmented. Despite internal market rules, there are still significant differences in the regulatory framework for SMEs within the European Union, in particular as regards the stability and security of this framework. It is clear that the largest SMEs in Central and Eastern Europe are small compared to their Western counterparts. While the growth of stable economies is fuelled by effective mutual links between SMEs and large companies, difficult economic conditions have weighed on the proper development of SMEs in many Southern and Eastern European Member States. Therefore, in order to create the environment for business development and to increase the job creation capacity of businesses, national and European policies need to address skills problems. The report addresss these problems and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report, as I think SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. It is therefore important to focus on fair competition, access to finance, an adequate regulatory environment, 21st century skills and good social dialogue, in order to enable SMEs to create sustainable quality jobs.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This text stresses the crucial role of SMEs in creating jobs. Second, it highlights a number of avenues for improvement, such as regulatory competence or stability, or small capitalization, etc. While it does not take into account the essential problem of opening economic borders, it is a step in the right direction. So I voted for it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 At the end of 2014, the EU had an average youth unemployment rate of 21.4%, or more than 7 million young people in employment. However, on the same date, 2 million jobs were vacant in the EU. This figure highlights the need to improve the link between the world of training and the world of work, to develop more flexible and interdisciplinary skills.  Cooperation, participation and partnerships are the means to open a constructive relationship with SMEs and the multifaceted European business reality and to loosen the current administrative and financial constraints relating to the start-up of new business activities, through the simplification of procedures, easy access to credit, risk capital and microfinance, guaranteed high-speed Internet connections, tailor-made multidisciplinary advice and the introduction of , where possible, incentive measures for entrepreneurs hiring unemployed young people.  It is clear how important microfinance and the European Programme for Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI) play in achieving full youth employment. Only by increasing the efficiency of the training course and by creating a network of one-stop shops where all the administrative procedures necessary for the creation and management of a business can we raise the rate of youth entrepreneurship in the short term.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. Unemployment is one of the problems facing the European Union, affecting 23 million people in 2015, including 4.5 million young people, women and men. All this culminates in the arrival of hundreds of refugees on the territory of the Member States, which implies an even greater need for jobs, with a view to ensuring the good integration of these people. In this context, European authorities need to support SMEs as they are a major employer on the EU market, providing two thirds of all private sector jobs at EU level. In order to ensure a sound environment for business development, but also to strengthen their job-creating potential, national and European policies must mainly address issues of competence, regulatory insecurity and administrative burdens. In view of the above, I have been in favour of this report, supporting the importance of a stable environment and the need to reduce the burdens imposed on SMEs.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because SMEs, accounting for almost 99 % of European businesses, are the undisputed key to the EU economy. Over the past decade, SMEs have created as many as 85 % of Europe's jobs. Moreover, as the report rightly points out, last year small business contributed up to 71 % to employment growth in the non-financial commercial economy. I am therefore of the opinion that SMEs should be at the cornerstone of the process of defining enterprise policy in the EU. Effective measures must therefore be put in place to strengthen the job creation potential of this fundamental sector. However, the organisations and networks representing SMEs are still too weak. SMEs have, in some cases, to address the further problem of low capitalisation, which results in a worse market position and hinders fair competition. One of the main challenges is the lowering of the burden on SMEs, on all labour costs. This challenge can only be overcome if there is a stable and quality regulatory framework, where standards are applied uniformly and egalitarianly.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. While I fully support the concept that SMEs have a lot of potential for job creation, the report placed far too much emphasis on reducing protection, rights, wages and conditions for workers. While it had some positive calls for further education and training of workers and access to support for SMEs, it also included negative calls for the promotion of temporary work by the Commission and Member States, as well as for ‘regulatory burdens’ in health and safety to be reduced. Due to the generally neoliberal, anti-worker approach of the report I voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it studies ways on how best to harness the job potential of SMEs both at EU and national level. I consider this to be a very important topic as, in my view, working at making SMEs stronger means guaranteeing present and future jobs in the EU. SMEs are the strength of the European economy. When they can thrive in the free market, they build sustainable jobs, growth and prosperity. It is important to seek new ways to stimulate interest in entrepreneurship and cultivate a more entrepreneurial mind-set, especially among young people. To do this, we must ensure that they have access to funds, and the knowledge of how the EU can help them. We need to recognise the importance of thinking small first.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are very heterogeneous and, despite the rules of the internal market, major divergences persist across the Eu ropean Union in terms of the regulatory framework, in particular as regards their stability and level of certainty. Mr Krasnodębski's report stresses that, in order to achieve a healthy environment for business development and to boost their job creation potential, national and European policies must be primarily concerned with addressing skills issues (shortage, inadequacy, brain drain), regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens, as well as undeclared work and the de facto privileged position of multinationals. Unfortunately, some very important concepts proposed by the M5S in the EMPL Committee have remained out of the report: the disparity in fiscal conditions in the various Member States which generates social dumping, the fact that European constraints on budgetary policies, austerity, excessive taxation and inadequate public expenditure have an effect on the job creation potential of SMEs and their competitiveness and , finally, the demand that apprenticeships and traineeships be brought into line with all other forms of work, benefiting from the same treatment in social and social security terms. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the engine of the European economy and make a fundamental contribution to employment. In fact, in 2014, SMEs employed almost 90 million people or 67% of the total employment in Europe. I believe it is essential to create an economic environment that facilitates the development of SMEs and stimulates their capacity to recruit. In this respect, policy action should improve smes' access to skills by promoting vocational training and education activities. In addition, I think it is important to reduce the burden on SMEs, including labour costs, in order to encourage the creation of lasting and quality jobs. I also hope that the administrative burden on SMEs will be reduced. It has been shown that over-regulated administrative economic systems result in higher fixed costs by indirectly providing a competitive advantage for larger companies. I also voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Commission and the Member States to implement measures that favour the internationalisation processes of SMEs, that can expand their market and consequently also their capacity to use. Finally, it should be stressed that the black and criminal economy is a form of unfair competition which particularly penalises SMEs.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and the rapporteur's position that in order to achieve a healthy environment for business growth and boost job creation, national and European policies must, as a matter of priority, address skills issues (deficiencies, mismatches, brain drain), regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens, as well as the problem of undeclared work and the de facto privileged position of multinational companies.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on how best to exploit the potential of small and medium-sized enterprises for job creation concerns a major problem facing EU Member States, businesses and citizens. Although the search for causes leading to the inability to develop and strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises is positive, the report essentially does not put workers' rights and interests first by proposing conservative solutions. I therefore voted against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Krasnodebski report in order to facilitate the creation of new jobs. It is also true that there is a disparity between SMEs and multinationals in the level of regulatory rules that they are able to absorb. Therefore, in order to give the labour market more dynamism, I fully agree with the need to lighten the regulatory and bureaucratic burden that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have to bear. I believe that SMEs are an important pillar of the European Union and I am therefore in favour of facilitating smes' access to public procurement and funding, as well as research and development, in order to promote quality jobs in the long term.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Unemployment and migration flows are the biggest challenges facing Europe today and have multiple implications for the future.  The number of unemployed in the EU remains at historically high levels and the recent arrival of hundreds of thousands of migrants is another huge social challenge, with more and more jobs needed to integrate people who are settled in Europe. The European economic structure is based on small and medium-sized enterprises as a source of new jobs and engine of the EU economy. I agree with the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in relation to their competitive position compared to large enterprises. I support the need for a stable regulatory environment and better quality of regulation and implementation as a correct way to reduce burdens on SMEs, including wage costs. I would like to point out the need for specific measures for SMEs to reduce market economies, enabling their internationalisation and boosting their job creation potential. I support this report.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the approach of increasing the involvement of SMEs in integration into the labour market. The number of unemployed across the EU is still at an all-time high. And our SMEs can make a decisive contribution here. However, with regard to the regulatory framework, we must bear in mind the need to distinguish between multinational companies and SMEs. We need a stable regulatory environment and better enforcement in order to relieve our SMEs and not be burdened with bureaucracy.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. Although the report seeks to tell the Commission and Member States that more needs to be done to help SMEs and reduce the regulatory burden (which in principle UKIP supports), it then goes on to call for wide ranging Commission action and further legislation. The initial report seeks to tell Member States what their taxation policy should be, calls to create an EU framework regulation for pan-EU crowd funding and welcomes an EU proposal on business insolvency among many other things. If it wasn’t due to the cost of EU regulation and overly bureaucratic EU red tape SMEs would have a much better chance at growing. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because SMEs are at the base of our economy and face major problems with regard to the regulatory framework, the raising of funds but, above all, the delay in payments, especially by public administrations. At present, the administrative burden on the self-employed in micro-enterprises is disproportionate to that for large companies and, I agree with the rapporteur, when he calls on the committee and the Member States to promote networks of cooperation through the establishment of cooperatives, considerably strengthening sustainability and job creation. I can only welcome the change in the thresholds for access to European investment projects, adapting them so that SMEs and startups can benefit from them and activate greater cooperation between the Commission, national and regional authorities, businesses and the social partners.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Member States need to provide appropriate training and ensure an ongoing professional development of teachers to promote up-to-date teaching methods and the development of 21st century skills and competences.  Also, we need to overcome the gender gap in the labour market with regard to employment and pay, amongst other issues, by providing carers’ leave, flexible working hours for carers, and ensuring equal pay for equal work between male and female workers. SMEs play an important role in strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion, while also contributing to smarter, sustainable and inclusive growth.  There are still significant differences across the EU in terms of regulatory frameworks for SMEs, in particular regarding the certainty of future regulatory developments and the legal quality of regulation in general.  The fact remains that the highest labour costs have been identified in over-regulated and bureaucratised systems.  The report cautions against this.   Job creation also entails a better engagement with Member States and local as well as regional authorities, education and training facilities, civil society associations, businesses, trade unions and financial institutions with a view to promoting and making full use of EU funding sources to help overcome the difficulties in accessing information.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because its objective is to reduce the labour protection of workers in SMEs and self-employed people, including dependents and false self-employed persons, under the aim of improving their competitiveness. In this way, SMEs are used to open a gap in the interests of large capital against the working class. I believe, on the contrary, that the problems of SMEs (the lack of demand caused by falling wages and public spending; extreme volatility and financial dependence caused by the growing power of bank oligopoly) should serve to create an alliance with the popular classes to end neoliberal policies.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European economic structure is mainly based on small and medium-sized enterprises as a source of new jobs and the driving force of the European economy. I am therefore firmly convinced that SMEs must be at the heart of the process of defining enterprise policy in the European Union, and it is to be hoped that all necessary steps will be taken to strengthen the job-creating potential of this sector. At present, despite the rules of the internal market, major divergences persist throughout the European Union in terms of the regulatory framework for SMEs, which create unfavourable development conditions. In the light of these challenges, I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is essential to consolidate the conditions for the creation of new jobs in all EU Member States, both peripheral and central, in order to achieve a healthy environment for business development.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the main crises facing Europe is that of unemployment. Because of its high rate, more and more unemployed young people are delaying starting a family, and the very high flow of young people leaving the countries with high unemployment rates and leaving for central Europe is creating social tensions in the host countries. Unemployment affects 23 million people, including 4.5 million young people, women and men, under the age of 25. In the last ten years SMEs have created 85% of jobs in Europe. SMEs must be at the heart of the European Union's business policy and all necessary measures should be taken to strengthen the job creation potential in this sector. I voted to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in terms of their position in relation to large companies. Better information to small entrepreneurs and entrepreneurs on the different possibilities for financing from European funds is needed.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that SMEs are the backbone of the European Economy, which is why I am in favour of fair competition, access to financing and an adequate regulatory environment. This report also urges Member States to develop forms of cooperation that involve all governance levels, businesses, trade union, educational institutions and other stakeholders with a view to adapting their education and training systems to address the disparity between skills and qualifications. I support this measure and believe that more informal training, including on-the-job training, is needed and that Member States should implement the ‘Think Small First’ principle.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome my colleague’s report, and its focus on creating a good environment for SMEs to grow and create jobs, particularly addressing a number of key issues including skills mismatches, regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on access to finance for SMEs, because I believe that SMEs require a favourable business environment in which green ideas can be easily developed, financed and placed on the market.  Remanufacturing, repair, maintenance, recycling and eco-design have huge potential to become engines of growth and job creation, while making significant contributions to addressing climate challenges.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This text, which has no binding legislative value, aims to lead the European Parliament's reflection on how best to capitalize on the job creation potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). I would argue that we must work to create the necessary conditions for an environment conducive to the development of SMEs in order to cope with unemployment in our Member States. For this reason, it is particularly important that our legislation does not involve a bureaucratic and administrative burden that is too heavy for our companies. In addition, a facilitation of access to financing for these companies must be put in place in order to foster a level playing field for all SMEs.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Unemployment in the EU affects 23 million people in 2015, including 4.5 million young people under the age of 25 who are unemployed and not in school. The massive influx of migrants is another significant social challenge, as more and more jobs are needed.  Over the past ten years, SMEs have created 85% of new jobs in Europe. The report stresses that national and European policies must address skills issues (shortages, inadequacies, brain drain), regulatory insecurity and administrative burden, as well as the problems of undeclared work and the de facto privileged position of multinational enterprises.  This text goes in the right direction by calling for the reduction of the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs. It stresses the importance of a stable and quality regulatory environment, improved regulation and enforcement, as local small businesses are particularly disadvantaged by the problem of high fixed costs.  So I voted for this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported Mr Krasnodembski's report as it highlights the important role of SMEs in job creation. Currently, 85% of jobs in the Union are created by SMEs and that is why their activity needs to be stimulated. The rapporteur stresses that, in order to achieve a stable business development environment and increase its job creation potential, national and European policies must address skills issues as a matter of priority (shortages, mismatches, brain drains), regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens, as well as the problem of undeclared work.  The rapporteur also stresses the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in terms of their competitive position compared to large corporations. Small and local businesses are particularly disadvantaged in the current over-regulated and bureaucratic administrative system.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. U2012 Migration flows, as well as the high unemployment rate, pose challenges that must be overcome by strengthening the conditions for the creation of new jobs in all the Central and Peripheral Member States of the Union. The European economic structure is mainly based on small and medium-sized enterprises as a source of new jobs and the engine of the economy; SMEs must therefore be at the heart of shape the Union's business policy, and all necessary measures must be taken to strengthen the job creation potential of this sector on the basis of an in-depth diagnosis of existing constraints. This report provides an analysis of the problem – both in the EU and at national level – to take advantage of the job creation potential of SMEs in the European Union. The commitments proposed by the rapporteur are in line with the promotion of the conditions for the development of SMEs and the reduction of the administrative bodies, as well as the burdens and difficulties they experience.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The number of unemployed in the EU remains at historically high levels, reaching 23 million people in 2015, with 4.5 million young people of both sexes under the age of 25 outside the labour market and education system. In 2015, small businesses contributed up to 71% of employment growth in the non-financial market economy. The report stresses that, in order to achieve a sound environment for business development and boost its potential for job creation, national and European policies should, as a priority, address skills issues (scarcity, mislags, 'brain drains'), regulatory insecurity and administrative burdens, as well as the problem of undeclared work and the de facto privileged position of multinational companies.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: this text goes in our direction, putting SMEs at the centre of concerns and calling for the reduction of the administrative and bureaucratic burden on them.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it stresses the importance of creating a healthy environment for business development and for boosting their job creation potential. In this respect, national and European policies must be primarily concerned with addressing issues relating to competences, regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens, as well as undeclared work.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ The report implicitly calls for an exemption for SMEs from regulatory standards, and calls for a shift away from direct taxation to indirect, regressive taxation. I voted against.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because I am convinced that small and medium-sized enterprises play a central role in the growth of the Member States' economies.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on how to make the best possible use of the potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to create jobs, as the growth of small and medium-sized enterprises, but also of the economy in general, does not come with more "flexibility" and funding from banks. All these 'arrangements' are simply trying to unsuccessfully conceal the attempt to exploit workers even more and to serve banks and multinationals.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. Hence it is important to focus on fair competition, access to financing, an adequate regulatory environment, 21st century working skills and a good social dialogue in order to allow SMEs to create sustainable quality jobs. The focus of the report at hand is on which conditions would need to be met in order to better harness the job creation potential of SMEs. I welcome the introduction of important elements such as social and occupational protection; social enterprises and cooperatives; quality job creation; the problems of precarious employment, letter box companies, bogus self-employment, unfair competition and the gender gap with regard to employment and pay; the fight against tax avoidance and the shadow economy; the impact of trade agreements on workers’ rights, wages and jobs; and the impact of the Digital Single Market. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report as a good example of how the EU can help its citizens. Expansion of employment and innovative business practices should be a core focus of the EU. In addressing key issues such as skills mismatches, regulatory uncertainty, administrative burdens and access to finance, this report showcases how the EU can work for its citizens.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of this report, as our two biggest current challenges are reducing unemployment and halting migration flows. With around 99% of European businesses being SMEs, their ability to create jobs has a major impact on the performance of the European economy. Small and medium-sized enterprises should therefore be at the heart of the development of entrepreneurship policy in the EU and all necessary steps should be taken to strengthen job creation in this sector. This is only possible on the basis of an in-depth mapping of existing strings. The SME sector in Europe is diverse and fragmented. Despite internal market rules, there are still significant differences in the regulatory framework for SMEs within the European Union, in particular as regards the stability and security of this framework. It is clear that the largest SMEs in Central and Eastern Europe are small compared to their Western counterparts. While the growth of stable economies is fuelled by effective mutual links between SMEs and large companies, difficult economic conditions have weighed on the proper development of SMEs in many Southern and Eastern European Member States. Therefore, in order to create the environment for business development and to increase the job creation capacity of businesses, national and European policies need to address skills problems (the lack of skilled workers should alleviate regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens). The report addresss these problems and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report as it outlines good policies concerning how we can make the most out of our European SMEs, especially in creating jobs. In order to achieve the potential of our SMEs we need to make sure that national and EU policies are prioritising issues such as skill gaps, uncertain regulations and administrative burdens. We must make sure that rules for doing business are simple and easy to access in order to create a good regulatory environment and that it is easy to hire and do all the accompanying paperwork. Another major point that the report also agrees with is that there are large regional disparities and imbalances when it comes to SMEs’ access to funding and investments. Ways to achieve a more even playing field include to securitise loans to SMEs, use micro-credit and to push for improvements in the enforcement of the Late Payments Directive.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. Small and medium-sized enterprises are Europe's largest, strongest and most reliable employers. Corresponding potentials must be developed and promoted. That is why I voted today in favour of a report on 'Methods for making the most of the potential of SMEs to create jobs', and I thank my colleague Zdzis-aw Krasnod-bski for the excellent work.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The creation of new jobs by SMEs is a central part of European labour market policy. A mutual exchange of experience between the EU and its Member States, as well as between Member States, is an important success factor.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. While unemployment remains at a historically high level, the European Union is beginning to recognise the contribution of SMEs to job creation. Over the past ten years, SMEs have created 85% of new jobs in Europe.  It is therefore vital to help SMEs by removing obstacles to their development. These obstacles include inadequate or inadequate vocational training, regulatory insecurity, administrative overload and tax pressure. The report also stresses the importance of addressing SME financing problems and ensuring a level playing field with large companies. The report also calls for better tax treatment for SMEs. Indeed, it is the multinationals that are currently receiving preferential treatment, especially in France where they pay less corporate taxes. However, I regret the dubious references to the promotion of worker mobility and, above all, to the integration of migrants into the labour market. Despite these marginal references, this text correctly identifies the problems faced by SMEs and proposes some solutions to remedy them. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This report seeks to identify problems that make it difficult for SMEs to achieve an effective growth rate and create jobs. The report focuses to a large extent on reducing 'administrative burdens' on SMEs and, although it has been improved in the Employment Committee with some progressive content, its basic premise remains neoliberal: that laws and regulations, including payment to workers and working conditions, health and safety, are administrative burdens and should be reduced in order to promote growth. Although it does not directly call for the elimination or reduction of minimum wage standards, it says that "high labour costs" are one of the most important restrictions on job creation in the SME sector. It implicitly calls for an exemption from regulatory rules for SMEs, and suggests the move from direct imposition to indirect, clearly regressive taxation. It also stresses the importance of temporary employment in the SME sector and "urges the Commission and Member States to support all forms of temporary employment". That is why we voted against it.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which proposes means of improving the job creation potential of SMEs while emphasising the need for high standards of protection of workers. The report advocates quality job creation, high standards for workers’ protection and calls for means to overcome the gender pay gap.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Unemployment and migration flows are the biggest challenges facing Europe at the moment, with multiple implications for the future. High unemployment threatens demographic perspectives, as many young people without work delay starting a family. As a longer term consequence, this situation puts pressure on social security systems and pension schemes, threatening also the future of the current generation. The report emphasises the importance of a stable regulatory environment, improved regulation quality and enforcement, as the right way to lower SMEs burdens, including labour costs. This is an essential prerequisite for the permanence of jobs and for the SMEs’ potential to create high quality jobs.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. – We voted against the report since the strategic framework proposed for job creation in SMEs does not ensure the creation of new decent and permanent posts. In addition, there is no mention of workers' collective labour rights.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which looks at the potential of Europe’s SMEs to create employment. SMEs make up almost 99% of European companies and form the backbone of the EU economy, providing two thirds of private-sector employment in the EU. However, SMEs face specific challenges such as skills shortages/mismatches, regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens, as well as the problem of undeclared work, which larger companies often do not.  The report emphasises the importance of a stable regulatory environment and improved regulatory efficiency and enforcement as a way to reduce SME costs and establish a level playing field. I was particularly pleased to support provisions emphasising the need for matching skills and qualifications with market demands and promoting entrepreneurship for young people, specifically development of vocational education training that facilitates work-based learning and apprenticeships, and the encouragement of partnerships between employers and educators to help young people to acquire entrepreneurial skills, as well as to better recognise and validate non-formal education and skills. I also support the call on the Commission to conduct an impact assessment regarding the implications of TTIP, and of granting China market economy status (MES), on the number and quality of jobs in the SME sector in Member States.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections against it.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. Although the report seeks to tell the Commission and Member States that more needs to be done to help SMEs and reduce the regulatory burden (which in principle UKIP supports), it then goes on to call for wide ranging Commission action and further legislation. The initial report seeks to tell Member States what their taxation policy should be, calls to create an EU framework regulation for pan-EU crowd funding and welcomes an EU proposal on business insolvency among many other things. If it wasn’t due to the cost of EU regulation and overly bureaucratic EU red tape SMEs would have a much better chance at growing. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The growth of the SME sector is related to fair competition and access to financing. We need education reform and a good social dialogue in order to allow for SMEs to create sustainable quality jobs.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the best way to exploit the job creation potential of SMEs, as it brings many important regulatory frameworks, regulations and implementations that lead to a good path towards reducing the burden on SMEs, and enable the stability of current and new quality jobs to be created. SMEs have been responsible for creating 85% of jobs in Europe over the past decade, making an important contribution to socio-economic growth and EU development.  The report highlights the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs given their competitiveness with respect to large corporations. In some cases, EU competition policy alone results in benefits for large operators that are more economically efficient than SMEs. In this regard, this report underlines the need for specific measures for SMEs to reduce their market uneconomics, the same way as to enable internationalisation and job creation potential.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. Although the report seeks to tell the Commission and Member States that more needs to be done to help SMEs and reduce the regulatory burden (which in principle UKIP supports), it then goes on to call for wide ranging Commission action and further legislation. The initial report seeks to tell Member States what their taxation policy should be, calls to create an EU framework regulation for pan-EU crowd funding and welcomes an EU proposal on business insolvency among many other things. If it wasn’t due to the cost of EU regulation and overly bureaucratic EU red tape SMEs would have a much better chance at growing. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I obviously voted in favour of this report, because SMEs are the engine of the European economy. They have created 85% of new jobs in Europe in the last ten years. It is therefore essential that all necessary measures are taken to ensure a healthy environment conducive to their development. This report therefore analyses the problems faced by SMEs and proposes a number of solutions to address them. Issues raised include, for example, skills issues, regulatory insecurity, excessive administrative burdens and access to funding.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report is an attempt to improve the environment for SMEs. In particular, it aims to improve job creation across Europe. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which proposes means of improving the job creation potential of SMEs while emphasising the need for high standards of protection of workers. The report advocates quality jobs creation, high standards for workers’ protection and calls for means to overcome the gender pay gap.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The Krasnod-bski report takes a position on making the most of the potential for job creation for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). SMEs provide about two thirds of jobs in the private sector. In order to further strengthen the potential for job creation, SMEs should focus on shaping EU enterprise policy. The report stresses that reducing administrative and regulatory burdens, as well as improving the quality of legislation and enforcement, should relieve SMEs.
