In addition, the report emphasises that fair conditions of competition are created for SMEs compared to large enterprises. Small and local businesses are particularly disadvantaged in over-regulated and bureaucratic management systems. Measures are needed to reduce market disadvantages for SMEs in such a way as to significantly increase their employment potential. I consider the report as a whole to be very balanced and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Since I have been an MEP, I have come across a number of reports highlighting the importance of SMEs in terms of job creation and employment in the EU. The reports underline the need to support small and medium-sized enterprises in every way possible, both by reducing their access to resources and their administrative burden. Despite many years of apparent eu ambition, the situation is still not good, and the report shows that access to finance is still one of the main obstacles to the creation and growth of SMEs. SMEs are at a serious competitive disadvantage compared to multinationals, which transfer their profits to Member States or third countries that act as tax havens. In the case of its virtues, the material is not strong enough, it lacks concrete solutions, but it still has to be supported.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on looking for the best way to harness the job creation potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (VEHICLES). The sector needs a lot of support to continue its successful development. This support will mean combating youth unemployment rates and the unprecedentedly high unemployment rate as a whole. We must clearly name the main challenges that we need to tackle in order to create more prerequisites for job creation. Some of these are skills shortages, insufficient assessment of future skills needs, skills mismatches, brain drain, unnecessary regulatory burden and regulatory uncertainty in all areas, a lack of dialogue between market stakeholders, limited access to finance and public procurement, insufficient capacity to innovate and access new technologies, insufficient support provided to SMEs in the framework of public investment policies, the informal economy and fraud, as well as the favoured situation of MNN. Decisions are rooted in promoting a strong entrepreneurial culture for Member States to develop forms of cooperation, appropriate training and change of laws in the Member States.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. We have recently had the opportunity to highlight the central role that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have played in recent years. Today's report explains how to improve regulatory quality in the context of SMEs and how to reduce their burdens, which are essential conditions for ensuring long-term and quality jobs. The future of our young people is in our hands, and we must ensure that it is made as profitable as possible. I am therefore voting in favour of the report on how best to realise the job creation potential of SMEs.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because, despite clumsiness, it has the merit of caring for SMEs, in particular by calling for the reduction of the administrative and bureaucratic burden on them.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This text, if not perfect, is in line with our vision of business and employment by putting SMEs back at the centre of concerns and calling for the reduction of the administrative and bureaucratic burden on them. As a result, I voted in favour of this issue.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it must ensure fair competition, access to finance, an adequate regulatory framework, S.XXI skills and good social dialogue in order to enable SMEs to create quality and sustainable jobs. The report introduces elements such as social protection and occupational health, social economy and cooperative enterprises, quality job creation, problems of precarious labour, mailbox societies, false self-employed persons, unfair competition and wage and employment inequalities between men and women, the fight against tax evasion and the submerged economy, the impact of trade agreements on workers' rights , wages and jobs, or the impact of the Digital Single Market. The reference to "unjustified burdens" for SMEs is also maintained rather than simply burdens. In addition, the focus on SME potential, 21st century skills, dual education and ongoing training has been supported to overcome skillslessness, access to finance and support for SMEs (including European Funds and Programmes) corporate social responsibility as well as specific support for young entrepreneurs.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the proposals they put forward did not solve the problem of access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, but will expose them more to the risks of financial speculation. This report points to the problem faced by European SMEs in access to credit, however, instead of proposing a healthy retail banking system to finance such companies as the backbone of the European economy, it argues that the solution should be the Capital Market Union. This proposal will only raise the risk borne by SMEs dependent on complex speculative financial products. It is because this report does not propose solutions for SMEs but for financial capital that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The objective of this initiative report is to enhance job creation and labour: through a favourable and stable regulatory framework, facilitating access to finance, with an investment plan for Europe, with public procurement, improving investment capacity and innovation and promoting the digital economy. In this report we highlight the need for a regulatory framework that encourages investment while promoting sustainable economic growth and quality employment. I believe that one of the key points that can influence the competitiveness of SMEs is labour costs, but unemployment should not be tackled at the expense of worker protection, but by increasing the value of training as a necessary element in preparing the working population to fill jobs, as well as by adapting demand and labour supply.  Finally, I would like to stress that we must reduce the administrative burden of regulation, as regulation is disproportionately higher for self-employed workers and micro-enterprises than for larger enterprises. For all of the above, I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The Krasnod-bski report takes a position on making the most of the potential for job creation for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). SMEs provide about two thirds of jobs in the private sector. In order to further strengthen the potential for job creation, SMEs should focus on shaping EU enterprise policy. The report stresses that reducing administrative and regulatory burdens, as well as improving the quality of legislation and enforcement, should relieve SMEs. In addition, the report emphasises that fair conditions of competition are created for SMEs compared to large enterprises. Small and local businesses are particularly disadvantaged in over-regulated and bureaucratic management systems. Measures are needed to reduce market disadvantages for SMEs in such a way as to significantly increase their employment potential. I consider the report as a whole to be very balanced and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which looks into the conditions which would best harness the job creation potential of SMEs in the European Union.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the call for Member States to 'promote the creation and development of cooperative enterprises'. I don't think states are supposed to influence what legal forms people use in business. We have already experienced state preference for cooperatives in previous socialism. I do not agree with the 'urgent call for effective and strong advertising campaigns to promote the Fast Track to Innovation (FTI)'. In my view, we do not need more campaigns for European funds paid for with taxpayers' money.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises provide two thirds of all jobs in the private sector. Their support contributes to combating high unemployment – around 23 million at EU level in 2015. 99% of European businesses are SMEs. Over the past 10 years, SMEs have created 85% of jobs in Europe, once again stressing their importance to the European economy. The free movement of workers is a fundamental principle of the European Union and we should not forget this. I support this report because there are around 2 million jobs that cannot be easily filled because of labour incompatibility in Europe, and the report underlines the importance of solving problems, such as incompatibilities. In order to ensure business development and strengthen their job-creating potential, European and national policies must address skills problems (insufficient, incompatibilities), regulatory insecurity, administrative burdens, undeclared work and others.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Economic Structure is based on small and medium-sized enterprises that are a source of new jobs and a driver of the European economy. SMEs play an important role in strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion, also contributing to smarter and sustainable growth, and this sector is important at regional level, especially in rural regions. Despite internal market rules, significant differences remain across the EU in terms of regulatory frameworks for SMEs, with high labour costs and excessive bureaucracy being one of the main barriers to job creation.  Therefore, the EU budget should contribute to fostering the creation of long-term quality and sustainable jobs. Member States must address skills shortages and mismatches, brain drain, unnecessary regulatory burdens and insufficient dialogue between labour market stakeholders and limited access to finance and public procurement. Vocational education and training, in particular dual systems in cooperation with SMEs, need to receive more public support, as they are an important tool in reducing youth unemployment.  Greater attention must also be paid to developing digital skills, critical thinking, problem solving and teamwork. Improved quality regulation and better enforcement are the right way to reduce the burden on SMEs and a major precondition for stability and job creation, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ We are awaiting from the Commission proposals to facilitate loans to micro-companies and SMEs to increase their available credit, to improve the regulatory framework for social businesses, and to create a differentiated approach to improving the environment for SMEs, taking into account the EU regions’ specific structural differences.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: writing \ u2012 One of the EU's biggest problems is the high unemployment rate. In 2015, 23 million people were unemployed in the EU, including 4.5 million young men and women under the age of 25. The situation is also hampered by the large influx of migrants, whose social integration requires the provision of employment. Small and medium-sized enterprises have created 85% of jobs in the last ten years and therefore have the potential to tackle unemployment and create jobs. However, due to the different conditions of individual Member States, there remain obvious differences between SMEs from some Member States, which is reflected in their size and economic impact. This situation persists, particularly in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe that joined the EU after 2004. It is necessary to create appropriate conditions for improving access to skills, apprenticeships and vocational training, taking into account the needs of the labour market. A fair regulatory framework and a level playing field will make it possible to further stimulate the interest and activity of SMEs.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Referring to my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/9/2016, I abstained in the vote on the report on how best to exploit the potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to create jobs, as this report is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  This text, if not perfect, is in line with our vision of business and employment, putting SMEs at the centre of concerns and calling for the reduction of the administrative and bureaucratic burden on them. The European economic structure is mainly based on these structures, which are a source of new jobs. Over the past ten years, SMEs have created 85% of new jobs in Europe. The text stresses the importance of a stable and quality regulatory environment, which we agree with.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. As an engine of our economy, SMEs play a key role in job creation and from institutions we must do everything we can to facilitate business development and increase their job creation potential. My support for the report on how best to harness the job creation potential of small and medium-sized enterprises, which should serve as a reference for the Commission to establish immediate measures to provide an adequate framework for the growth of these enterprises and their protection to ensure a level playing field for large enterprises.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This report aims to improve the conditions for the creation of new jobs. It is true that this potential needs to be better exploited. I can therefore only support this.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report prepared by the EP, which promotes better use of the job creation potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The report highlights a number of existing problems faced by SMEs and distinguishes between key, priority measures to address these problems. For example, the report stresses the importance of stable and better regulatory quality and enforcement, which is one way of reducing labour costs. The report also particularly welcomes the further development of vocational training to promote work-based learning and apprenticeships. The report stresses, inter alia, the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in relation to their competitive position vis-à-vis large enterprises.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This initiative report is designed to identify problems that prevent small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) from achieving an effective growth rate and creating jobs. According to the author, "high labour costs" are one of the most important restrictions on job creation in the SME sector. On the contrary, I believe that it is the restriction of demand. The report implicitly calls for an exemption for SMEs from regulatory standards, and calls for an abandonment of direct to indirect taxation, regressive taxation. It also stresses the importance of temporary and therefore precarious employment in the SME sector and "calls on the Commission and Member States to support all forms of temporary employment".  I vote against this text of a grotesque liberal dogmatism.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This text, if not perfect, is in line with our vision of business and employment by putting SMEs back at the centre of concerns and calling for the reduction of the administrative and bureaucratic burden on them. As a result, I voted in favour of this issue.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, SMEs contributed to a large extent to employment growth, with up to 71 % in the non-financial market economy. Job creation in SMEs is influenced by a number of internal and external factors and, among them, controllable competition (including from multinational companies and the parallel economy), administrative burdens and controllable overall production costs, as well as access to finance and skilled labour are essential assumptions. We need to create mechanisms to make the best use of the potential of SMEs in job creation and economic development. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it makes numerous proposals to make the most of and also support the Union’s Small and Medium Enterprises. The resolution focuses on tackling the skill-gap in certain sectors and the need for SMEs to be given the same level of tax support and access to public procurement processes as larger companies.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Over the past ten years, SMEs have accounted for 85% of new jobs in Europe. In this way, small and medium-sized enterprises guarantee two thirds of the total employment. Moreover, these companies have shown that they are more resistant to job losses during periods of economic downturn. Because they make such an important contribution to the EU's socio-economic growth and development, these companies deserve priority in EU industrial policy. But small and medium-sized enterprises also face major challenges. It is to the credit of this report that a thorough analysis is made of the problems facing SMEs. In addition to the known problems, such as the risk of over-regulation or high labour costs, the skills shortage, low innovation capacity, limited internationalisation and poor access to finance for SMEs must be remedied. That is why, in my amendments to this report, I have asked the Commission to make efforts to encourage more SMEs to export. I have also emphasised the need to embed a strong corporate culture in education and training and skills to better adapt to labour market demands from an early age.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – Europe is currently facing a number of challenges, the most serious of which are the current migration wave and the issue of unemployment. High unemployment in Europe has a negative impact on many areas, jeopardising demographic prospects, as many young people without work are delaying familying, which in turn puts pressure on social security and pension systems. High unemployment in southern and eastern Europe and the consequent departure of young people from these countries to the central Member States are fuelling social tensions in the host countries. Small and medium-sized enterprises have created up to 85% of jobs in Europe in the last decade, so it is important that they become a central theme in shaping entrepreneurship policy in the EU, and the necessary steps should be taken to strengthen the potential for job creation in this sector. SMEs are a diverse group and there are different small business models in Europe. The proposal stresses the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs as regards their competitive position compared to large companies. SMEs are particularly disadvantaged by overregulation in the administrative system and high fixed costs in the bureaucratic system. It is therefore necessary to implement specific measures for SMEs in order to limit their market disadvantages, enable their internationalisation and increase the potential for job creation. I support the proposal with my vote.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. Hence it is important to focus on fair competition, access to financing, an adequate regulatory environment, 21st century working skills and a good social dialogue in order to allow for SMEs to create sustainable quality jobs.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs starts from the importance of creating new jobs. It notes that SMEs are the source of new jobs and the engine of the European economy: SMEs have created 85% of European jobs over the past decade, and small businesses contributed 71% of employment growth in non-financial enterprises in 2015. The report stresses that, in order to create a healthy environment for business development and to increase the job creation capacity of businesses, national and European policies should address skills problems (skills shortages, non-compliance, brain drain), alleviate regulatory uncertainty and administrative burdens, and combat undeclared work and the de facto privileged situation of multinationals. It also underlines the importance of a stable regulatory environment, regulatory quality and implementation, which is the right way to reduce costs for SMEs, including labour costs; It is also an essential prerequisite for the stability of jobs and for SMEs to be able to create high-quality jobs. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. We are voting for this report, which is in line with our discourse on SMEs. It presents SMEs as a priority for jobs and growth, and calls for them to be at the centre of concerns. Indeed, the European economic structure relies mainly on SMEs which are a source of new jobs and the engine of the European economy. They have created 85% of new jobs in Europe over the last 10 years. And in 2015, they contributed 71% of employment growth in the non-financial market economy. It is therefore essential that the economic regulatory environment be favourable to SMEs by ensuring a level playing field against large companies, by further improving vocational education and training, and by reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on them.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 It should be recalled that almost 99 % of European companies are SMEs and are therefore the backbone of the EU economy and have a strategic importance with regard to job creation. I am voting in favour of this report, understanding that SMEs should actively contribute to sustainable growth and the creation of quality jobs. At the same time, new up-to-date teaching methods and the development of skills and competences should be promoted in order to meet the needs of SMEs, thereby increasing the employability of thousands of European citizens.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text puts SMEs back at the centre of concerns and calls for the reduction of the administrative and bureaucratic burden on them. So I'm voting for it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which proposes means of improving the job creation potential of SMEs while emphasising the need for a high standard of protection of workers. The report advocates quality job creation, high standards for workers’ protection and calls for means to overcome the gender pay gap.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report entitled "How can we make the most of the job creation potential of small and medium-sized enterprises?" This text analyses the problems faced by SMEs (regulatory insecurity, heavy administrative burdens, difficulty in accessing financing). SMEs are the companies that create the most jobs in Europe (85% of new jobs in Europe in the last ten years have been created by SMEs). It is therefore essential to identify the problems they face and to propose solutions.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on how to make the most of the job creation potential of SMEs. The report explores the conditions that would help create jobs in small and medium-sized enterprises both at EU and Member State level.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Welcome to the report. I believe that it is high time we emphasised the important role of small and medium-sized enterprises in today's society. The numbers speak for themselves and their positive impact on the economy can be clearly demonstrated. Nevertheless, I do not perceive that individual Member States are trying to support this sector in some way. I therefore agree with this report that small businesses and local business operators should not be treated with the same attitude, bureaucratic and financial burden as multinationals. I trust that the report will encourage Member States, including Slovakia, to finally establish a more favourable legal framework, first and fore being for newly established small and medium-sized enterprises, thereby supporting entrepreneurship and the creation of new jobs.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Europe’s economic structure is mainly based on small and medium-sized enterprises as sources of new jobs and represents a driving force of Europe’s economy. I have voted for this report that calls on national and European policies to address the issues of skills shortages and mismatches.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I endorse this resolution because it offers an analysis of the constraints to the growth of the SME sector in the EU. Especially SMEs in eastern and southern Member States face harder conditions in terms of accessing finance, as the economy in these regions of the EU is under bigger strain and therefore less stable. These disadvantages should be taken into consideration in EU policy assessments. Moreover, problems of competing with big corporations and suffering under heavy administrative systems remain concerning to the growth potential of SMEs – a sector that is vital for getting especially young Europeans out of unemployment and into work.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. While I fully support the concept that SMEs have a lot of potential for job creation, the report placed far too much emphasis on reducing protection, rights, wages and conditions for workers. While it had some positive calls for further education and training of workers and access to support for SMEs, it also included negative calls for the promotion of temporary work by the Commission and Member States, as well as for ‘regulatory burdens’ in health and safety to be reduced. Due to the generally neoliberal, anti-worker approach of the report I voted against.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The aim of this report is to improve the conditions for job creation by SMEs. I abstained on this report because not all financial measures are efficient.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. SMEs create more jobs in the EU than other companies in the private sector. The report calls on the Member States to avoid over-regulation, which hinders the competitiveness of companies and the opportunities for job creation. It is also pointed out that, in order to achieve a favourable environment for the development of enterprises and to increase the potential for job creation, national and European policies need to focus on skills, their scarcity and non-compliance, or on the outflow of educated and know-how and on the privileged position of multinational enterprises.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. Although the report seeks to tell the Commission and Member States that more needs to be done to help SMEs and reduce the regulatory burden (which in principle UKIP supports), it then goes on to call for wide ranging Commission action and further legislation. The initial report seeks to tell Member States what their taxation policy should be, calls to create an EU framework regulation for pan-EU crowd funding and welcomes an EU proposal on business insolvency among many other things. If it wasn’t due to the cost of EU regulation and overly bureaucratic EU red tape SMEs would have a much better chance at growing. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and I would vote positively for the report amended by the amendments proposed by my group which broaden and enrich the basic text.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – As a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection I work for cutting red-tape for businesses and removing barriers for accessing markets. I voted in favour of this report, which promotes the conditions for SMEs’ development and for decreasing the administrative burdens and difficulties they experience.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for job creation potential for SMEs. We know that unemployment of young people is present in EU countries especially in the east, south and central Europe, while in the western part small and medium-sized enterprises are among the main activities in the EU and we can call them the backbone of the EU economic system.  What makes the difference between Central Europe in the development of SME and other parts of Europe is a system that prevents the development of such a form of activity, which is limited by various administrative and regulatory barriers in other parts of Europe. This approach to small and medium-sized entrepreneurship is not good and encourages the departure of young educated people to western parts of Europe and puts pressure on.  We need to encourage young entrepreneurs and enable them to work and thrive in their country to develop and other parts of Europe, and this would also address a social problem such as starting a family and increasing the birthrate that will sustain the pension system.  A great opportunity can be found in the e-commerce store, and since the internet is in the little finger for young people, it is necessary to take advantage of this possibility. I am committed to vocational orientations in SME and best practices for young people in SME and, I repeat, to reduce the restrictive approach on which the market economy should be based.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This text presents some common-sense measures to alleviate the constraints that SMEs have. However, only a national strategy through assumed economic patriotism, borders and a national priority could provide lasting solutions to the difficulties faced by SMEs, which are being put into competition far too brutally within the European Union. I therefore prefer to abstain on this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. That is why it is important to work to ensure fair competition, access to finance, an adequate regulatory framework, skills that match the challenges posed by the reality of the 21st century and a good social dialogue, in order to enable SMEs to create sustainable and quality jobs. I am voting in favour of this report because it was significantly improved in committee thanks to the efforts of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (Democrats) and European Democrats, which succeeded in including in the text a number of very important elements, both for businesses and for workers such as the inclusion of social and cooperative enterprises, the importance of the digital single market and the fight against tax evasion and undeclared work. Equally important are the call for free trade agreements not to penalise workers' rights and salaries, the need to tackle the problems posed by precarious work, fictitious societies, fake self-employment, unfair competition and unequal treatment between men and women, both in terms of levels of employment and pay.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Economic Structure is mainly based on small and medium-sized enterprises that are a source of new jobs and a driver of the European economy. While growth is created in stable economies on the basis of the effective interaction between SMEs and large enterprises, in many southern and eastern Member States difficult economic opportunities are slowing down the development of SMEs.  I supported Representative Krasnodębski's report because it is important to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in view of their competitiveness with respect to large companies, which will also create the potential for job creation and result in economic growth.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 SmEs have created 85% of jobs in Europe in the last decade. In 2015, small businesses contributed to a 71% increase in employment in non-financial sectors. Despite the rules governing the internal market in the European Union, large disparities remain as regards the regulatory framework for SMEs. The assessment and measurement of the impact of EU policies should take greater account of the strong regional diversity among Member States. Due to the multiple obstacles to job creation, the universal model principle has proved discriminatory for the SME sector. Furthermore, macroeconomic instability and transparent regulation mean that SMEs in many post-2004 eu-joined countries and in euro area countries in crisis have unfavourable development conditions.  The rapporteur stressed that, in order to create a solid environment for the development of entrepreneurship and to increase job creation potential, national and European policies should focus primarily on skills, legal uncertainty and administrative burdens and the problem of undeclared work. The rapporteur also highlighted the need to guarantee a level playing field for SMEs in terms of their competitive position compared to large corporations. Small and local businesses are particularly disadvantaged in over-regulated and bureaucratic administrative systems. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report which analyses the problems faced by European SMEs and outlines some solutions to address them. Among the difficulties, the text includes: lack of skills (training), legal and regulatory uncertainty, access to financing, and, of course, excessive administrative burdens.  It should be noted, however, that 85% of SMEs in Europe have created new jobs over the last ten years, despite the difficulties outlined above, and especially the consequences of the global economic and financial crisis. SMEs are therefore the engine of growth in the EU Member States. The European Parliament's position is clear: priority must be given to strengthening an environment conducive to the development of SMEs in Europe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 High unemployment rates and migration flows have been under increasing pressure in the European labour market. Europe is not the continent with the highest birth rates, it is certain that youth unemployment further threatens the demographic outlook and exposes the risks of social security systems and pension systems. The recent arrival of hundreds of thousands of migrants into Europe today requires us to rethink the Union's social integration model, which is more robust and, at the same time, needs employment solutions that reduce potential social tensions in the host Member States, such as the United Kingdom. This report identifies the importance of SMEs in the current conjecture, stressing the need to address issues such as regulatory insecurity, undeclared work, the privileges of multinationals and other major issues such as the so-called 'brain drain'. For the above, and because I consider it essential to create new and sustainable jobs in all member states of the Union, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. Although the report seeks to tell the Commission and Member States that more needs to be done to help SMEs and reduce the regulatory burden (which in principle UKIP supports), it then goes on to call for wide ranging Commission action and further legislation. The initial report seeks to tell Member States what their taxation policy should be, calls to create an EU framework regulation for pan-EU crowd funding and welcomes an EU proposal on business insolvency among many other things. If it wasn’t due to the cost of EU regulation and overly bureaucratic EU red tape SMEs would have a much better chance at growing. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. The high levels of unemployment threaten the demographic outlook, as many young people without work depose the establishment of a family. The recent arrival of hundreds of thousands of migrants is another huge social challenge, with more and more jobs needed. In the face of these challenges, strengthening the conditions for the creation of new jobs in all EU Member States has become essential. SMEs should be a central point in the definition of business policy and the necessary measures should be taken to strengthen the potential for job creation in this sector. The report stresses that skills-related issues (shortages, training gaps, brain drains), regulatory insecurity and administrative burdens, as well as the problem of undeclared work and the de facto privileged position of multinational companies should be addressed. It highlights the importance of reducing the burden on SMEs, further development of vocational training, the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs and the 'labour market paradox', as many jobs cannot be easily occupied due to labour outage in Europe.  I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. By 528 votes to 77 (and 44 abstentions), Parliament called for a significant easing of the administrative burden on SMEs and called on the Commission to always consider the impact of new EU legislation on the situation of SMEs before validating them. SMEs account for 99% of businesses in Europe, and nine out of ten SMEs have fewer than ten employees. European SMEs are an opportunity. They are performing well and the wealth they create has caught up with pre-economic crisis levels, up 2.4% from 2008. It is therefore particularly crucial to move forward on simplifying administrative and tax procedures for these small structures.  Encouraging small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Europe is at the heart of Parliament's concerns, and this is demonstrated once again by this afternoon's unambiguous vote.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The European economic structure is mainly based on small and medium-sized enterprises as a source of new jobs and an engine of Europe's economy. In the last decade, SMEs have created 85% of European jobs. In 2015, small businesses contributed up to 71% of employment growth in the non-financial market economy. SMEs should therefore be a central point in the definition of business policy in the European Union and all necessary measures should be taken to strengthen the potential for job creation in this sector. National and European policies should, as a priority, address issues related to regulatory insecurity and administrative burdens, as well as the problem of undeclared work and the privileged position of multinational companies. We must not yet forget the aspects related to social protection, social enterprises and cooperatives, the creation of quality jobs, the problem of precarious employment, unfair competition, gender inequalities in employment and income, the fight against tax evasion and the parallel economy, the impact of trade agreements on workers' rights, wages and jobs , and also the impact of the digital single market.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises form the backbone of the European economy, with 99% of businesses and 67% of employment. An adequate regulatory framework, access to funding and skills are key to ensuring its momentum and the creation of stable and quality employment. Thanks to the work of the S&D Group, the report emphasizes the need to promote social protection and occupational health and the creation of quality employment, as well as to address the problems of precarious labour, false self-employed people, unfair competition and wage and employment inequalities between men and women. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of two reports that deal with the issue of small and medium-sized enterprises. The first report addresses the issue of SMEs' access to finance and the strengthening of the diversity of financing for SMEs in a capital markets union, while the second focuses on ways to make the most of the job creation potential of SMEs. SMEs are vital to the economic growth of our continent and account for 99% of businesses in Europe. It is important to be able to take into account their specificities in the legislative process but without ever, and I stress this, to question social and environmental standards.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Unemployment and the proper management of migration flows are two of the biggest challenges facing Europe today. This report focuses on the first of these challenges - the creation of measures to promote employment (particularly youth employment), in particular by Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs). In fact, the number of unemployed in the EU remains at historically high levels, especially youth unemployment - unfortunately for some time now. This poses a huge political, economic and social challenge, with the urgent need to create more jobs for young people and to integrate people who are established in Europe in an appropriate way. The European economic structure is mainly based on SMEs, and they have been responsible for the creation of 85 % of European jobs over the last decade. This report, which I voted in favour of, stresses that, in order to achieve a sound environment for business development and boost its job creation potential, national and European policies must address, as a matter of priority, skills-related issues ('brain drain'), regulatory insecurity, administrative burdens, undeclared work and the de facto privileged position of multinational companies.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which analyses the problems faced by SMEs and proposes solutions to these challenges. This report lists the issues facing SMEs. The lack of adequacy of skills to labour market demands, regulatory insecurity, difficulties in accessing finance and the burden of tax and administrative burdens are the main challenges that SMEs face.  It is crucial that SMEs, which are the engines of the European economy, are the focus of special attention and that answers are given to these difficulties.  I therefore supported this report because it reminds, in particular, that the Union's competition rules must ensure a level playing field for small, medium and large enterprises and thus promote their internationalisation.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. This report seeks to identify problems that make it difficult for SMEs to achieve an effective growth rate and create jobs. The report focuses to a large extent on reducing 'administrative burdens' on SMEs and, although it has been improved in the Employment Committee with some progressive content, its basic premise remains neoliberal: that laws and regulations, including payment to workers and working conditions, health and safety, are administrative burdens and should be reduced in order to promote growth. Although it does not directly call for the elimination or reduction of minimum wage standards, it says that "high labour costs" are one of the most important restrictions on job creation in the SME sector. It implicitly calls for an exemption from regulatory rules for SMEs, and suggests the move from direct imposition to indirect, clearly regressive taxation. It also stresses the importance of temporary employment in the SME sector and "urges the Commission and Member States to support all forms of temporary employment". That is why we voted against it.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the methods used to best exploit the potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to create jobs. Supporting SMEs means doing something about youth unemployment and investing in economic growth. They make up a significant proportion of the European economy.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because its objective is to reduce the labour protection of workers in SMEs and self-employed people, including dependents and false self-employed persons, under the aim of improving their competitiveness. In this way, SMEs are used to open a gap in the interests of large capital against the working class. I believe, on the contrary, that the problems of SMEs (the lack of demand caused by falling wages and public spending; extreme volatility and financial dependence caused by the growing power of bank oligopoly) should serve to create an alliance with the popular classes to end neoliberal policies.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which proposes means of improving the job creation potential of SMEs while emphasising the need for high standard of protection of workers. The report advocates quality jobs creation, high standards for workers’ protection and calls for means to overcome the gender pay gap.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are crucial for growth and employment in European regions. This is evidenced by the fact that SMEs provide two thirds of private sector jobs and more than half of the added value of businesses in the EU. Unfortunately, in many Member States, as a result of budgetary constraints, SMEs are being seduted and supported low. I supported the resolution because I see great potential in SMEs for creating new and sustainable quality jobs. I also consider support for SMEs to be extremely important because, due to their size, SMEs are extremely limited by uncompetitive real exchange rates, limited access to finance, cumbersome and bureaucratic procedures concerning the establishment, operation and development of enterprises, poor infrastructure conditions and a lack of effective institutional structures. I believe that, thanks to the proposed measures, SMEs will be able to cope with these problems and, through increased efforts, will ensure good and quality conditions for the establishment and operation of businesses, but especially those set up by young people and businesses located in rural areas. I expect the Commission and the Member States to ensure a stable and transparent legal environment and coordination, coherence and synergies between the various instruments and programmes for the benefit of SMEs.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'SMEs offer a cooperative model that needs to be promoted, as it has already proven its sustainability and resilience in recent years. In addition to improving the competitiveness of SMEs, as discussed earlier this week, this report focuses on access to finance for SMEs according to the think small first principle, on reducing administrative burdens and on the problems of undeclared work and on the more favourable treatment of multinationals. All this in order to make the most of the potential of SMEs in terms of job creation. The report stresses the need to ensure adequate employment and social protection in order to ensure sustainable employment. Difficulties and uncertainties in the start-up of a business, in particular by young people, are also highlighted. The report also calls for tackling skills shortages, validating informal learning and achieving better cooperation between workers and the education sector. The report is very balanced and all green issues are taken into account: the green economy, social and solidarity economy, youth, employment and social protection. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises create the majority of jobs in the European Union. According to several surveys, the biggest obstacles to their development are high tax and levy burdens, burdensome bureaucracy and a lack of capital. In the European Parliament, by creating a capital markets union, we are trying to make it easier for them to access finance and, by breaking down barriers, to open up opportunities for their expansion and growth.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I accept this report, as I believe that SMEs play an important role in strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion. If jobs were created in SMEs, they would affect a number of internal and external factors. It is also important to note that in 2014 SMEs contributed up to 71% employment growth in the non-financial sector of the economy.  This type of enterprise is more resilient to the economic crisis when it comes to job losses, more specifically, cooperatives in industrial and service industries proved more resilient in the period of the 2008 crisis than other companies. In principle, it is difficult to find information on contractual arrangements and the organisation of the work of small and medium-sized enterprises. Working conditions, according to Eurofound data, are much more acceptable than those in larger companies.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on methods for making the most of the potential for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to create jobs. The report recognises that SMEs are very important. He fails to recognise that the best way to do it is to let them operate politically and regulatoryly in peace. Every new political intervention creates so-called "regime uncertainty", which destroys development potential. A report with 96 demands in book form, which are partly contradictory in view of the large number of objectives aimed at promoting SMEs, is not effective. A short report on SMEs, as follows, would have done the same: the EU is staying out, Member States are cutting taxes and reducing red tape, and no government level is considering 'methods to make the most of the potential of small and medium-sized enterprises' from today.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ In 2014, 22.3 million SMEs were active in the 28 Member States of the European Union. SMEs create around two thirds of private sector jobs and make an important contribution to the socio-economic growth and development of the European Union. SMEs also contribute greatly to job growth.  Eurofound research has shown that SMEs are innovative, operate internationally and are mainly located in cities. SMEs contribute to smarter, sustainable and inclusive growth. Major differences remain across the EU in terms of regulatory frameworks for SMEs. I support the Report on the best way to exploit the job creation potential of SMEs, as I believe that the guidelines set out there are of high quality and will contribute to job creation as well as the creation of a new skilled workforce. I also believe that it will ensure a favourable and stable regulatory environment and a level playing field.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on how to make the best use of the potential for job creation in SMEs.  I support the opinion of the Committee on Budgets that the EU budget should be used to promote long-term quality and skilled employment and the potential of SMEs to create decent and sustainable jobs.  The Committee on Budgets therefore proposes that investment in research, innovation, skilled training and development should be increased in order to promote the quality growth and potential of European SMEs to create new jobs.  We must not forget that, by providing two thirds of private sector jobs throughout the European Union, SMEs are the backbone of the European economy.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the report because we disagree with its general philosophy. The general framework proposed for job creation in SMEs does not ensure the creation of new decent and permanent jobs. Nor is there any mention of collective labour rights, i.e. social security, collective bargaining and collective agreements. We do not overlook the rapporteur's good intentions and the improvements made to the text. The reference to ensuring the protection of workers to any increase in flexibility, and supporting the development of cooperative enterprises, agree with us. However, real social and economic growth requires public investment that supports industrial sectors and contributes to decent jobs.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on better exploitation of the job creation capacity of small and medium-sized enterprises. As small and medium-sized enterprises are the engine of the European economy, it is of the utmost importance, as highlighted in the report, that Member States provide better conditions for creating jobs for SMEs, including by reducing skills shortages, simplifying unnecessary, over-complex regulatory burdens, increasing innovation capacity and improving access to finance and public procurement. I welcome the fact that the report mentions the frequent preferential treatment of multinationals and its negative impact on SMEs. In order to ensure a level playing field and to increase the job creation capacity of SMEs, action should be taken against the profit-transfer practices of multinationals. The report also called for the creation and development of cooperative enterprises, cooperation with trade unions, educational institutions and the promotion of entrepreneurs for people from vulnerable groups. Funding is also key to smEs' ability to create jobs. The report also made valuable findings in this area. At the same time, I note that increasing flexibility in the labour market in many cases leads to restrictions on the protection of workers.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises create more jobs than all others in the private sector, providing around two thirds of employment in the EU. In recent crisis years, they have created the most jobs and are often innovative, internationally active and employ young people. SmEs' capacity is even greater, but action is needed at national and EU level to strengthen their job creation potential. The report rightly emphasises that the most important issue is the reduction of administrative burdens. SMEs, because of their smaller size structure, do not have the same absorption capacity for regulatory standards as large companies. Over-regulation hampers the competitiveness of companies and their job creation potential. Parliament's report rightly emphasises the need to create an environment that encourages investment while promoting sustainable growth and the creation of quality jobs. It is also necessary to enforce rules on equal access to public procurement for SMEs. The report also rightly emphasises the importance of the Erasmus for Entrepreneurs programme, which helps young entrepreneurs acquire the knowledge and skills needed to set up and run a successful business. I believe that this is a very good document, which is why I decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. Hence it is important to focus on fair competition, access to financing, an adequate regulatory environment, 21st century working skills and a good social dialogue in order to allow SMEs to create sustainable quality jobs. The report focuses on a very important question, namely, on which conditions would need to be met in order to better harness the job creation potential of SMEs. There are key challenges that need to be taken into consideration when it comes to increasing the competitiveness of the EU’s productive sector, such as: the reduction of regulatory and administrative burden; tax incentives; and the role of trade unions and social partners. I therefore endorse the report due to its focus on the potential of SMEs, 21st century skills, dual education and ongoing training to overcome skills shortages, access to finance and support for SMEs (including EU funding and programmes), corporate social responsibility as well as specific support for young entrepreneurs.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The report highlights the "labour market paradox": around 2 million jobs are struggling to be filled due to the inadequate labour force in Europe. Other jobs could be saved in SMEs if entrepreneurs could avoid the closure of their businesses, in particular because of the low capitalization, delays in payment of contractors, the complexity of succession and business transfer procedures, unfair competition from the underground economy and certain abusive practices of multinational enterprises.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on ‘How best to harness the job creation potential of small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs)’. As SMEs provide 99% of EU businesses, produced two thirds of the EU private sector employment and created 85% of European workplaces in the last decade, boosting the job creation potential of SMEs is the best way to tackle unemployment and encourage growth in our Union. This can be achieved by combining upfront support to help kick-start projects with long-term strategies to improve the investment environment for SMEs. We must also address the issue of skills shortage and mismatches, regulatory uncertainty and work to reduce administrative burdens, in particular to increase their capacity to compete with large corporations.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) create more jobs than other private sector companies, thus providing around two thirds of all private sector employment in the EU, with entrepreneurs and SMEs making an important contribution to EU socio-economic growth and development. Supporting SMEs contributes to the fight against unemployment in Europe, which stood at 23 million in 2015 and has never been so high.  There is a lack of skilled labour and inequality across the EU, as well as an outflow of skilled workers from euro area countries strongly affected by the crisis to other Member States. As an MP from Croatia, a country for whom the departure of highly educated young people in search of any job is one of the most pressing problems, I am particularly sensitive to this issue. It is by youth unemployment that Croatia, with its rate of 43.1%, is at the very top of Europe. For all of the above, I strongly support this Report on the best way to exploit the job creation potential of SMEs, and call on Member States to avoid excessive regulation that stifles the competitiveness of businesses and their job creation potential and to work to address unnecessary regulatory and administrative burdens.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on how to make the most of the potential for job creation in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) because SMEs are important for strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion and contribute to smarter and more sustainable and inclusive growth.  The SME sector is also important at regional level and in rural areas. More and more jobs are unococsure due to low labour mobility and the inadequacy of certain education and training systems in the light of the labour market situation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This report seeks to identify problems that make it difficult for SMEs to achieve an effective growth rate and create jobs. The report focuses to a large extent on reducing 'administrative burdens' on SMEs and, although it has been improved in the Employment Committee with some progressive content, its basic premise remains neoliberal: that laws and regulations, including payment to workers and working conditions, health and safety, are administrative burdens and should be reduced in order to promote growth. Although it does not directly call for the elimination or reduction of minimum wage standards, it says that "high labour costs" are one of the most important restrictions on job creation in the SME sector. It implicitly calls for an exemption from regulatory rules for SMEs, and suggests the move from direct imposition to indirect, clearly regressive taxation. It also stresses the importance of temporary employment in the SME sector and "urges the Commission and Member States to support all forms of temporary employment". That is why we voted against it.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The Krasnod-bski report takes a position on making the most of the potential for job creation for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). SMEs provide about two thirds of jobs in the private sector. In order to further strengthen the potential for job creation, SMEs should focus on shaping EU enterprise policy. The report stresses that reducing administrative and regulatory burdens, as well as improving the quality of legislation and enforcement, should relieve SMEs. In addition, the report emphasises that fair conditions of competition are created for SMEs compared to large enterprises. Small and local businesses are particularly disadvantaged in over-regulated and bureaucratic management systems. Measures are needed to reduce market disadvantages for SMEs in such a way as to significantly increase their employment potential. I consider the report as a whole to be very balanced and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The aim of the report is to take stock of the challenges facing SMEs and the means to address them. The report stresses the importance of a stable and quality regulatory environment, improving the quality of regulation and its application, believing that this is the appropriate way to reduce the burden on SMEs, including labour costs. This is an essential prerequisite for the sustainability of jobs and the potential for the creation of quality jobs for SMEs. Finally, the report stresses the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in terms of their competitive position with respect to large companies. Small local businesses are particularly disadvantaged by over-regulated and bureaucratic administrative systems, as they result in higher fixed costs for businesses. Other jobs could be saved in SMEs if entrepreneurs could avoid the closure of their businesses, in particular because of the low capitalization, delays in payment of contractors, the complexity of succession and business transfer procedures, unfair competition from the underground economy and certain abusive practices of multinational enterprises. Overall positive report. I voted for it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European labour market is facing a serious problem of unemployment and a proper matching of supply with labour market demand, so it is important to choose to stimulate certain segments of the economy. Support for the small and medium-sized enterprises sector through the launch of apprenticeship schemes, access to capital and unlocking potential through simplification of tax law and issues, reducing the privileged role of large corporations and reducing the share of undeclared work can be of great importance. I agree with the rapporteur's recommendation that Member States implement the 'think small first' principle, which is why I support the motion for this resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the reporter, Europe is currently facing two huge challenges: unemployment and migration flows, which will have many implications for the future. The high unemployment rate threatens the demographic outlook, as many young people prefer not to start a family without a job. The long-term consequence of this situation is the pressure on social security systems and pension systems, which also threatens the future of this generation. In the final vote on the proposal, I supported the S&D position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – This report seeks to identify the problems that make it difficult for SMEs to achieve an effective growth rate and create jobs. The report focuses to a large extent on reducing 'administrative burdens' on SMEs and, although it has been improved in the Employment Committee with some progressive content, its basic premise remains neoliberal: that laws and regulations, including payment to workers and working conditions, health and safety, are administrative burdens and should be reduced in order to promote growth. Although it does not directly call for the elimination or reduction of minimum wage standards, it says that "high labour costs" are one of the most important restrictions on job creation in the SMEs sector. It implicitly calls for an exemption from regulatory rules for SMEs, and suggests the move from direct imposition to indirect, clearly regressive taxation. It also stresses the importance of temporary employment in the SMEs sector and "urges the Commission and Member States to support all forms of temporary employment". That is why we voted against it.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the transition to the use of financial instruments to support SMEs, but I believe that the financing of subsidies should continue to be provided where it is essential and necessary to promote innovation, development and research, which are essential for job creation and for the economic success of Europe in the future.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on how best to harness the job creation potential of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The report emphasises that SMEs play an important role in strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion, while also contributing to smarter, sustainable and inclusive growth. In addition, it stresses the need for a regulatory environment that encourages investment that concurrently fosters sustainable growth and quality jobs. I voted in favour because I believe that self-employment and micro-enterprises are of vital importance for boosting innovation and entrepreneurship.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which proposes means of improving the job creation potential of SMEs while emphasising the need for high standard of protection of workers. The report advocates quality job creation, high standards for workers’ protection and calls for means to overcome the gender pay gap.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report in order to make better use of the potential of our SMEs. At the insistence of the European Parliament, the European Commission is beginning to focus more and more on SMEs as the engine behind prosperity and job creation. I very much welcome that.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. SMEs are the sector of the economy that leverages society, contributing to 71% of employment growth in the non-financial economy in 2015. This report recognises the importance of SMEs and their relationship with the development of societies and the quality of employment. It contains some points that are considered positive, such as reducing burdens, combating false self-employment, the consequences of trade agreements – TTIP and CETA – or the need for funding opportunities to boost organisations. However, it assumes premises that completely contradict the conditions necessary to ensure business development that promotes employment with rights and the overall development of societies. These assumptions are based on wage reduction and labour deregulation to promote competitiveness; in the promotion of dual education systems, "less academista" and with disciplines of entrepreneurship; encouraging teleworking and so-called "smartworking" and deregulated forms of labour organisation, mainly through the defence of temporary work.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report points out that bogus self-employment cannot be taken as a contribution to the growing number of micro-enterprises and points to the new social problems that arise because many sham self-employed people are barely insured. As an attempt is also being made to improve the potential of SMEs in terms of job creation, I supported the report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on how to increase the job creation of SMEs. The text aims to achieve important objectives, such as social and professional protection, the creation of quality jobs, respect for gender equality in employment, a response to precarious work and problems related to unfair competition and tax evasion. The impact of trade agreements on workers' rights, issues relating to wages and salaries and the impact of the digital single market are also taken into account.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which proposes means of improving the job creation potential of SMEs while emphasising the need for high standard of protection of workers. The report advocates quality jobs creation, high standards for workers’ protection and calls for means to overcome the gender pay gap. Any strategy on SMEs must include support for cooperatives and alternative business models that have so much potential for a more ethical way of doing business, and bringing more flexibility and accountability to the private sector. We must also ensure that vulnerable excluded groups have access to entrepreneurship education, particularly women and girls, who face greater obstacles and prejudice. We must make sure that we share best practice on enabling women and girls to become entrepreneurs.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – Because our SMEs are an important part of our economy, this also means that they contribute significantly to job creation. It is therefore important that their growth potential can be optimised. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. I strongly welcome its recognition of the SMEs’ importance, having provided the majority of all workplaces in the EU in the past ten years. In order to support them, specific measures and/or requirements are mentioned, such as a stable regulatory environment, and improved quality of regulation and actual enforcement. Overregulation and administrative burdens have to be removed whenever possible and should be avoided at all times. Doing so will especially benefit the SME’s and level the playing field between them and larger corporations.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on how best to harness the job creation potential of SMEs. I welcome the rapporteur's approach, which stressed that, despite the rules of the internal market, there continue to be considerable differences in the European Union in the regulatory framework for SMEs, in particular on stability and security. It also notes that, due to macroeconomic instability and the absence of transparent and predictable regulation, SMEs in many countries that joined the EU after 2004, as well as in euro area countries in crisis, face unfavourable development conditions. The report also stresses the need to ensure a level playing field for SMEs in terms of their competitive position with large corporations.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As the report points out, although there are rules governing the internal market in the European Union that create a regulatory framework for SMEs, there are still divergences in the level of stability of this framework. The main problems for SMEs are over-regulation and non-compliance, favouring and treating large and large companies in the EU in a privileged way and a lack of adequately educated staff.  In view of these problems, as well as the problems facing modern Europe: unemployment, job mismatch, demographic crisis, immigration, it is appropriate to exploit and support the potential of small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the engine and pillar of the European economy and offer significant job creation potential. The report recognises the need to look at the regulations and the environment in which they exist in order to make the most of their opportunities.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Krasnodębski report deals with the question of how best to exploit the potential of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the driving force behind the European economy and contribute significantly to economic growth as well as employment growth. At the same time, they generate significant added value in the non-financial sector. However, despite the uniform rules on the market, there are still major differences between Member States as regards stability and certainty for these enterprises. That is why much more attention should be paid to these differences in assessing and measuring the results of European policies. Throughout the report, the rapporteur also stressed that, in order to achieve an environment for the development and strengthening of the potential of SMEs to create jobs, national and European policies must primarily address topics such as regulatory uncertainty, the problem of undeclared work or ensuring the competitiveness of SMEs vis-à-vis large companies.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Krasnodebski report, because I agree with the proposals put forward by the European Parliament on harnessing the job creation potential of SMEs, which make up 99 % of European companies, and are therefore the backbone of the EU economy.  I recall that SMEs create more jobs than other private sector companies, accounting for around two-thirds of all employment in the EU private sector, and that entrepreneurs and SMEs make an important contribution to eu socio-economic growth and development. I would also recall that support for SMEs helps to combat European unemployment rates and youth unemployment. I therefore call on the Member States and the Commission to develop policies to address skills shortages and inadequacy, the 'brain drain' phenomenon, limited access to funding and public procurement, poor capacity for innovation and reduced access to new technologies.  In this context, it is also necessary to take into account the insufficient support that is given to SMEs in the context of public investment policies, which contrasts with the privileged position of multinational companies.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on how to make the best use of the potential for job creation in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). I believe that SMEs are important for strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion and contributing to smarter and more sustainable and inclusive growth, both in rural and urban areas. However, job creation in SMEs is influenced by a number of internal and external factors, with the latter being manageable competition, a manageable administrative burden and total production costs, access to finance and the availability of skilled workers.  For us in particular, the Member States that joined the EU after 2004 is a typical brain drain, creating peripheral regions with a shortage of skilled workers.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Fifteen years after the adoption of the Equal Treatment Directive in the area of employment and work, it seems that we have accumulated a certain amount of knowledge and experience that allows us to assess not only the effectiveness of the solutions adopted in it, but also the sustainability of the phenomenon of discrimination itself in this area.  The fundamental problem that we have not found an effective solution to is the lack of awareness of a discriminatory situation, both on the part of victims and of those who discriminate. There is therefore a great difficulty in combating this phenomenon and its permanence. Therefore, specific action is needed on the part of the Union, the Member States and the social partners to promote knowledge of discriminatory behaviour and practices in the field of employment. Raising awareness will eliminate many pathological situations at a relatively low cost.  These actions seem justified for one more reason: in recent months, we have seen a growing wave of hatred within the Union, not only towards Muslims, but also towards citizens of other Member States. Rising nationalism and xenophobia not only lead to discrimination against workers within the single market, but also to violent attacks and beatings, as poles in the UK have recently experienced. It is therefore necessary to take action as soon as possible to stop this wave. The European Parliament's proposals on the application of the Equality Directive are therefore necessary, which is why I voted in favour of Mrs Weber's report.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the Employment Equality Directive is to combat discrimination based on sex, race or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation in the workplace. Among the main points of the report are the removal of natural, social and economic obstacles which prevent the substantial implementation of the principle of equality and which restrict the freedom of European citizens; the promotion of Smart Working that allows disabled people to carry out work at their home; the rules to protect whistleblowers and their confidentiality in the event of discriminatory conduct in the workplace, and the reintegration into the labour market of detainees who have served their sentences. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.  It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. The S&D amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, own-initiative report. This vote wasn’t on the legislation itself, but on how it was being implemented. The report covered a wide range of sensitive issues such as discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, nationality sexual orientation etc., and rightly condemned aspects such as harassment and violence. However the report then went on to call for wide-reaching Commission action and EU legislation such as data collection, information campaigns, adopting the EU framework on racism and called for further harmonisation of laws regarding secularism.
