The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels. While UKIP cannot support more EU action and spending of taxpayer’s money, we do not want to appear to oppose equality or against fighting discrimination.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this positive report examining the application of the Employment Equality Directive across the EU. The report contains strong and positive proposals about achieving workplace and social equality for LGBTI people, women and parents, anti-discrimination elements around race, religion and gender, as well as positive aspects around equality for people with disabilities in the workplace.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Despite the very positive application of the directive in many Member States, it is clear that many problems and challenges remain, such as funding, discrimination awareness, access to information and justice, and data collection. Social partners (unions and employers) and civil society need to be more involved in the effective implementation of this employment equality directive.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the application of the Employment Equality Directive. The Employment Equality Directive, whose ultimate objective is the creation of a level playing field as regards equality in employment and occupation, was adopted 15 years ago. The report underlines that some EU Member States go beyond the requirements of the Employment Equality Directive, not limiting the protection against discrimination based on religion and belief, disability, age and sexual orientation to employment, occupation and vocational training. However, challenges to the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive still exist, since some groups and minorities in the EU have reported experiencing discrimination. This situation has a negative impact on social cohesion, as well as on respect for fundamental rights. I welcome the report as it stresses the importance of raising awareness among public opinion and the need to increase dialogue among governments, civil society and the social partners across all grounds.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Under the Treaty on European Union, the values on which the European Union is founded are respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Combating social exclusion and discrimination is a duty of the European Union.  Fifteen years have passed since the adoption of the Employment Equality Directive; The ultimate aim of the directive is to create a level playing field with regard to equality in employment and occupation. However, there are still challenges with regard to the implementation of the directive on equal treatment in employment and occupation. Europe must ensure, taking into account the principle of subsidiarity, that exclusion and discrimination against people are combated. I therefore welcome the creation of further measures to contribute to the achievement of equal treatment in employment and occupation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. A new text purportedly aimed at combating discrimination denounced by the LGBTI lobby in particular. Poor European heterosexual man who seems to be the only one who receives no attention. I obviously voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights that SMEs can become overburdened with too many rules. We have seen the impact of EU rules in watching British SMEs go out of business. However, as always with this kind of report it goes on to ask the Commission to collect more data from SMEs, organise information campaigns and interfere in many areas of national policy.  The report also ‘considers it necessary that the Commission provides private companies, including SMEs and micro companies with models for equality and diversity frameworks.’

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it identifies a number of remaining challenges in implementing the directive, for example, on the need to better inform citizens about their legal rights and obligations.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the application of the Employment Equality Directive. According to the European Commission, the working age (15-64) population in the EU has started to decline and the proportion of the population aged 65 and over is projected to increase from 87 million to 152 million between 2010 and 2060. In view of this need in the future, I agree with the need to ensure greater participation in the labour market, long-term income, and better measures to reconcile work and family life, including the care of family members. In society and in the labour market, the organisation of long-term care services must play a key role.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is of course a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad. However this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Given the need to increase labour market participation in the future, as well as to ensure long-term income security, it is important to find better solutions to reconcile work and family life, including the care of a family member. Therefore, your rapporteur hopes that the 2013 annual report of the Commission's Social Protection Committee, in which it is stated that the organisation of a long-term care system will play a decisive role in terms of participation in society and the labour market, will soon be translated into practice. Discrimination affects all aspects of people's lives and employment is just one of them. Any evolution involves change and our society must adapt to today's cultural contexts. The work environment must also be adapted; to do this, the Commission and the Member States should not only focus on legislation, but also on creating a work culture and on the well-being of everyone.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Weber report on the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive. In the face of those who insist on banning fundamental human rights by apologies for the principle of subsidiarity, insist on the idea that human rights are universal and indivisible. We need to move forward with European standards that regulate and prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, religion or race.  Prohibitions on certain religious symbols do not always conform to international human rights standards, as they are not limited to well-defined and delimited circumstances or pursue a legitimate objective. States do not always take appropriate measures against these restrictions when they do not conform to international human rights standards. In the face of prohibitions, freedom of expression. Faced with intolerance, education and the promotion of diversity and mutual respect.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Mr Weber's own-initiative report on the application of Council Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 establishing a general framework for the implementation of equal treatment in employment and occupation, as I consider the evaluation and permanent implementation of the Employment Equality Directive to be particularly important for the social integration of Europe. The own-initiative report calls for the removal of social and economic barriers to equal treatment and the termination of discrimination based on religion and belief, age, disability, sexual orientation, gender or ethnic origin.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Weber report on the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive, which I supported today, draws up a balance sheet fifteen years after its adoption and outlines some important recommendations for future developments. Even today, Roma, LGBTI people, disabled people and individuals belonging to religious minorities suffer daily discrimination and are sometimes victims of hate crimes. Despite the positive application of the directive in many Member States, there are still areas where the principles of non-discrimination which are fundamental elements of European integration still need to be affirmed. Many States have set up bodies to provide information on anti-discrimination legislation and to raise awareness of these issues, but these structures often complain of a chronic lack of funds. The problems in terms of awareness, information and access to justice can be largely overcome, but a concrete commitment is needed. The social partners and civil society must be properly involved in order to support and encourage the institutions towards the effective application of equality and equality at work.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as its content is positive in that it identifies the main problems and challenges of the implementation of this Directive, and proposes recommendations to the Commission and the Member States with which we agree to eliminate discrimination on the basis of sex, religion, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation and to ensure equal treatment in employment. Among others, some of the highlights that we find very positive are: that the Commission introduce a Directive on leave for caregivers; improvement and cross-cutting of available equality data, including harmonised and homogeneous statistics; provide ongoing training to stakeholders on employment legislation; strengthen and support civil society organizations working in this area; measures to ensure that the private sector assumes responsibility for creating a discrimination-free environment; the adoption of a European framework for national strategies to combat anti-Semitism and Islamophobia; recognize social clauses in public contracts or the application of effective legislation (GED recast) to ensure the protection of all trans people, among others

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. Reading the title of this report "on equal treatment in employment and work," I thought it would be consensual and not controversial. What was not my surprise that this is not the case. This report succeeds in integrating all the societal issues that are now the subject of debate in our European societies. It also includes issues relating to the principle of secularism, including whether or not religious symbols can be worn in the workplace, discrimination against the disabled or the elderly, euthanasia, abortion, LGBTI and transgender rights issues, and the fight against racism. This report mixes all these elements at will in a sometimes confused but often dogmatic way. Unfortunately, we end up forgetting the initial subject of this report: equal treatment between men and women: a subject that deserves to be examined and studied in its own right.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank rapporteur Renate Weber for her intensive work in this report on the implementation of the Equal Employment Treatment Directive which I have supported. It discusses, inter alia, improving the reconciliation of working and private life through concrete measures including the urgent submission of new legislative proposals on the Maternity Leave Directive. It is essential that we receive this proposal as soon as possible so that we can discuss it and try to agree with the Council. It is a necessary pillar for a more social Europe focused on citizenship.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which is embarking on a race to victimize minorities (women, LGBTI, migrants) without seeking to address the real and structural causes of mass unemployment. Of course, everyone agrees that discrimination in hiring does not have to be. But the rapporteur is misguided by focusing on promoting communitarianism instead of equal treatment. The priority is the fight against unemployment for all, not to have additional expenses for anti-racist organizations that often exclude from their fight communities "not victimized enough for them", as happened recently in Paris for the Chinese community. While I welcome the disability section and the reminder of the need to do everything possible to integrate people with disabilities into the world of work, overall, the only objective of this text is the over-production of standards for businesses, which will not promote employment and will only lead to workers being equal only in poverty.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is partisan and blatantly in favour of the usual good-natured rhetoric towards Roma, migrants and LGBTI groups. Instead of assessing the state of the art in the fight against discrimination at work by European citizens, the text shows all the hypocrisy of the EU, which publicly defends the right of workers to a fair work-life balance, but on the other hand forces Member States to cut more and more services under the blows of austerity policies. Finally, the text ends in a completely outsying criticism of eurosceptic movements, which are 'guilty' of thinking differently. For all these reasons, I voted against.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. The S&D amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because this Equal Opportunities Directive in the field of employment affects everyone's daily lives, both young people and people with disabilities, and the elderly. It is particularly important to realise that demographic changes in Europe, as well as the increase in the retirement age, make the issue of age discrimination against older people increasingly relevant in the area of employment. Therefore, if we are already raising the retirement age, we must ensure that our seniors have every chance of remaining in the labour market as full-fledged workers. I would also like to call on the Member States to ensure the protection of older workers against unfair retirement age, because the rights of older workers are more vulnerable. Secondly, unfortunately, we are still unable to protect the most vulnerable members of society, people with disabilities, from discrimination. Some Member States are in breach of this Directive by failing to adapt jobs for persons with disabilities, not providing adequate living and quality working conditions, and not ensuring equal opportunities in education and vocational training. We must therefore call on the Member States to make use of the Structural Funds and to adapt jobs and provide the necessary assistance to people with disabilities in the workplace.  We cannot be indifferent to the most sensitive groups in our society and to these problems, and I would urge the Commission and the Member States to ensure better implementation of this directive on equal opportunities for all in the Member States, because for the Member States this directive should become a tool for everyday life, protecting and improving the lives of all people.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ According to the latest research, women receive on average about 16 percent less pay than their male counterparts. This means that in relation to them they do 59 days for free. This is precisely where this Directive is relevant. We cannot allow women, who graduate from colleges in greater numbers, not to find employment, which is then reflected in their position in the family, in society, and of course on their pension.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Treaty on European Union, we are founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights. The European Union is fighting social exclusion and discrimination: pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men must prevail in the Member States.  Article 10 TFEI states that the Union shall combat discrimination based on sex, race or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. In addition, Article 21 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights states that any form of discrimination based on sex, race, colour or ethnic or social origin, genetic characteristics, language, religion or belief, political or any other opinion, membership of a national minority, property, birth, disability, , age or sexual orientation.  Today we are still faced with gender discrimination, ethnic, religious discrimination and prejudices of various kinds that undermine the unity and harmony of relations between our fellow citizens: we need to raise awareness, including through education campaigns, of respect for individual value and tolerance.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, the rule of law and respect for human rights. The Equal Treatment Directive has managed to be transposed into the laws of the Member States and implemented, which is a step forward to guarantee the rights of European citizens. In addition to the existing legislative provisions in this Directive, Member States may provide a higher level of protection and, at the same time, take measures of positive discrimination in this area in their national legislation. I have been in favour of this report because I strongly support the need to combat discrimination in an appropriate way, in all areas of life.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.  It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. The S&D amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the state of application of the Directive on equal treatment in employment. 15 years after the adoption of this directive, considerable progress has been made. Some Member States do not restrict protection against discrimination based on belief, disability, age or sexual orientation, but extend it to the areas covered by the Racial Equality Directive. However, the situation must be closely monitored because the economic crisis tends to take away rights, especially from the weakest groups. The report also points out that Directive 2000/78/EC lacks clarity and legal certainty with regard to multiple discrimination. It does not contain any specific provision on multiple discrimination, although it explicitly states that the combination of two or more forms of discrimination may give rise to problems linked to differences in the level of protection afforded for different forms.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this positive report examining the application of the Employment Equality Directive across the EU. The report contains strong and positive proposals about achieving workplace and social equality for LGBTI people, women and parents, anti-discrimination elements around race, religion and gender, as well as positive aspects around equality for people with disabilities in the workplace.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I fully agree with the general elements set out in this report and I therefore voted in favour. The adoption of the Employment Equality Directive (EFD) extended the protection against discrimination provided under EU law by laying down a general framework for combating discrimination on the grounds of religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation with regard to employment and occupation. This was done with a view to putting into effect in the Member States the principle of equal treatment without undermining the role of the Member States in this process. Despite huge steps in the right direction, many are still unaware of their rights. Employers need to create an anti-discriminatory working environment as without their active involvement in this process it will be very hard to achieve.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the Employment Equality Directive, adopted 15 years ago, is to combat discrimination – on any basis – that takes place in the workplace. The report reaffirms all the focal points of the directive and calls for its timely implementation throughout the Union. I certainly voted in favour of it.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Even though I fully agree that the EU should combat social exclusion and discrimination which also means that we should keep removing barriers when it comes to gender equality in employment, I abstained from voting. The reason I did so is that I do not support initiatives included in the report which aim at harmonisation of maternity leaves or reinforcing legislation on compulsory paternity leave as I do not believe that this should be established from the EU level. The same applies for supporting measures such as social clauses in the public procurement.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the report which draws up an assessment of the first fifteen years of application of the Employment Equality Directive. I welcome the fact that almost all Member States have included the general principle of equal treatment in employment in their constitutions. I am pleased that the report calls on the Commission to collect data on discrimination, particularly racial discrimination. I believe that these events have a negative impact on social cohesion and respect for the fundamental rights on which the European Union is based. I regret that, despite positive results on some issues such as the inclusion of people with disabilities, the number of discriminatory incidents against Muslims and LGBT people are increasing. In this respect, It seems to me appropriate to increase the resources allocated to the national bodies responsible for awareness-raising campaigns. I also believe that these organisations should provide information and legal assistance in order to increase the number of complaints by victims of discriminatory incidents. In conclusion, I believe it is essential to increase the participation in the labour market of people between the ages of 55 and 64 in order to ensure that they are guaranteed a long-term income.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline that the need for increased participation in the labour market in the future, as well as for long-term income security, make it necessary to find better arrangements for reconciling work and family life, including providing care to a family member.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the implementation of Council Directive 2000/78/EC on the establishment of a general framework for equal treatment in employment and work, also known as the 'Equality in Employment Directive'. As European society is called upon to eliminate any discrimination in the field of work, I believe that this report is moving in the right direction and, for this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Externally, I welcome mrs Weber's report in order to speed up and deepen the general framework for equal treatment in employment and working conditions. Legislative instruments capable of eliminating discrimination must be implemented, and in the light of this, I have spoken out in favour of recognition among the fundamental rights of freedom of conscience. In this regard, I am alarmed at doctors who suffer discrimination as a result of the use of conscientious objection. While I regard religious freedom as an inalienable right, I broadly support the report's assumption that employers may have legitimate grounds for banning certain religious symbols where they involve security problems or reprimast women's rights. The latter also need innovative proposals on maternity leave and the effective protection of health in the workplace in order to be able to work in optimal conditions and in peace of mind. Since achieving full and effective equality of work has impacts, as you can see, the more transversal, I call on European citizens to remain alive and to keep alive their interest in the measures taken and to point out any shortcomings.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Article 10 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU states that, in defining and implementing its policies and actions, the Union aims to combat discrimination on grounds of sex, race or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age, or sexual orientation. After 15 years since the adoption of the Directive on equal treatment in employment and occupation, this is the guiding thread that we must continue to follow in its implementation, being impervious in values to current feelings or winds of political occasion of the Member States. I support the Weber Report, which strengthens the fight against non-discrimination, warning of the still low level of awareness of the subject and the existence of real phenomena of discrimination in specific groups and the urgency of unlocking the Horizontal Anti-Discrimination Directive. I welcome the abundant case law of the European Court of Human Rights on the subject and I welcome the Commission's initiative to reconcile with private life, which is inseparable from this Directive.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report, although I do not agree with the report on a number of points. Much has been achieved with the Equal Treatment Directive in the last 15 years. The report identifies the areas where we are still a long way from a level playing field with regard to equality in employment and occupation. This applies, for example.B to women who are most affected by unemployment and face negative discrimination in the context of employment. However, the report presented intervenes in a number of areas which are within the competence of the Member States. Issues relating to the recognition of partnership status, property status regimes and rules on educational rights are a matter for the Member States and must be discussed and decided by the national parliaments there.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, own-initiative report. This vote wasn’t on the legislation itself, but on how it was being implemented. The report covered a wide range of sensitive issues such as discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, nationality sexual orientation etc., and rightly condemned aspects such as harassment and violence. However the report then went on to call for wide-reaching Commission action and EU legislation such as data collection, information campaigns, adopting the EU framework on racism and called for further harmonisation of laws regarding secularism. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels. While UKIP cannot support more EU action and spending of taxpayer’s money, we do not want to appear to oppose equality or against fighting discrimination.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the EU institutions to take greater account of the difficulties faced by disabled people on a daily basis and to strengthen both protections against discrimination in the labour market. It is necessary to encourage Member States to implement employment policies that combine positive measures, such as tax concessions, with active policies, such as guidance and training, favour the recruitment of people with disabilities and to follow employers with constant support throughout the employment process.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Measures, such as the Directive on improving the gender balance among non-executive directors of companies listed on stock exchanges and related measures, have already been adopted by Parliament.  They have the potential to help bring about greater equality for women within the field of employment and improve women’s access to management positions.  But legislation should be considered as a crucial tool in reaching gender equality.  As advocated by the report, this should be combined with normative procedures and campaigns in order to implement gender equality, not only in legislation but also in public opinion.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which assesses the implementation of the Equal Employment Directive since it recognises and identifies fundamental problems in the implementation of this directive, such as lack of data on equality, gaps in information and support for victims or sweepers in access to and reparation in the event of breaches thereof.  The report also makes a number of recommendations which I consider positive as the need to adopt a European framework to combat Islamophobia at national level, including the need for Member States to implement legislation to ensure the protection of transgender people, as well as to enable mutual recognition of all types of unions, marriage regimes and parental rights. In supporting these recommendations, my vote has been favourable.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Employment equality is crucially important, we need to ensure that our citizens are equally treated in the job market. I am in favour of this report as it outlines and seeks to address the main issues in this regard – that is equality of data, discrimination reporting, awareness, the role of civil society and the social partners and access to justice, amongst others.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report takes seriously the problems that have recently been imposed as socio-economic conditions in Europe evolve. Unfortunately, there are still many areas in which workers are discriminated against for sexual orientation, skin colour, ethnic or social origin, language, religion, heritage, birth, disability, family difficulties or personal convictions and opinions, including political ones. Not only that: the austerity imposed in recent years has accentuated the cases of forced exit of workers between the ages of 45 and 55, who are unable to re-enter the current employment environment, also due to discrimination linked to their age. The European Union is generally identified with taxation and duties, while a basic text of its own is rarely mentioned which, if applied regularly to the policies of the institutions and the Member States, could help to loosen the gap between citizens and the EU. This is the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which contains a number of fundamental principles, even when applied to the employment context. The hope is therefore that the EU will put these values back at the centre in order to combat social exclusion and affirm solidarity, inclusion and equality. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this report, with no binding legislative value, on the implementation of the directive creating a general framework for equal treatment in employment. It is crucial that Member States do more to combat the recurrent discrimination that takes place in the labour market. However, we must not, by this text, undermine the principle of subsidiarity in Europe. It was important to remember in this text that Member States remain competent to determine the rules governing the wearing of religious symbols in Europe in businesses and public spaces.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. While there is clear evidence of a decline in discrimination and an increasingly comprehensive information on rights for victims of discrimination, this report denounces exactly the opposite. It no longer seems to defend equality in employment but rather communitarianism by promoting judicial terrorism that leads to a break-up of society. On the contrary, this report stigmatizes the European and makes no mention of the massive immigration that member countries have suffered for decades and which the EU has intensified by the arrival and settlement of millions of unsensed migrants.  Beyond cases of immigration discrimination, the unfortunate influence of the LGBTIQ lobby is clearly felt in this report. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to outline the current state of play of the Employment Equality Directive and to encourage Member States to better implement it, which I could agree with. Amendments were made by my group to highlight the EU's role in mediation and coordination in the exchange of best practices. The roll call vote on certain paragraphs requested by my Group of European Conservatives and Reformists shows some of our positions on specific topics, but since the overall spirit of the report is positive, I supported it.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The Employment Equality Directive, which was adopted fifteen years ago, is key legislation to ensure equality and combat discrimination in employment. Since then, the situation has improved greatly despite the fact that it is far from ideal, especially for some groups such as those with disabilities.  The report proposes sound measures to combat discrimination at work for these people. In addition, the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds should play an important role in achieving greater equality and labour inclusion of these individuals, for example by adapting workplaces, implementing universal design, providing the necessary assistance and advice at work, improving education and training and creating programmes for companies that hire people with disabilities.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. I abstained because, although the text was relatively balanced, several uncertainties remained about its application, which concerns the fact that decisions on similar issues should be taken as close as possible to those affected by the policy, which is done much better at national and local level than at EU level.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the fourth Eurobarometer survey, compared to the previous survey, more Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and Europeans are also better informed about their rights in the event of discrimination. According to data from the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), 40% of Roma seeking employment are victims of discrimination, 75% of gay couples do not hold hands in public, 38% of Jews surveyed admit that they do not wear symbolic robes in public, 37% of Muslims surveyed said they were victims of discrimination and 11% who were victims of hate crimes. Overall, the situation has a negative impact on social cohesion as well as respect for fundamental rights. Efforts need to be made to strengthen dialogue between governments, civil society and the social partners in all areas and to raise public awareness.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: it is not intended to defend equality in employment. Rather, it aims to boost communitarianism, resulting in a fragmentation of society.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is essential that the Union is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. The European Union must set itself the objective of reducing social exclusion and discrimination. The principle of non-discrimination must cover all aspects of people's lives, including employment.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ The main points of contention were issues related to LGBTI and the Leave Directives. The outcome of the negotiations was overall positive.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The adoption of the Equal Treatment Directive represented a major step forward for the European Union 15 years ago in terms of creating a level playing field in the labour market and improving conditions of quality of employment and occupation. It should be noted that some Member States go much further in their national rules when implementing the Directive and extend their scope to the areas of racial equality.  However, despite the progress made, there are still very many unresolved challenges for the future. Surveys regularly show a discrepancy between the level of discrimination shown and the reported cases of discrimination. Victims still have trouble recognizing a discriminatory situation. Efforts must be made to intensify dialogue between governments, civil society and the social partners on all grounds of discrimination and to raise public awareness. Most Member States have shifted responsibility for disseminating information relating to anti-discrimination legislation and raising awareness to national specialised bodies without necessarily providing them with adequate means.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report: usual rhetoric in favour only of Roma, migrants, LGBT groups, etc. Europe's citizens are not considered to be in difficulty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive, as I strongly disagree with the Union's approach to this issue, I have different priorities and a very different view on supposedly positive discrimination.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which assesses the application of the Employment Equality Directive 15 years from its adoption and draws recommendations for further improvements. I believe the rapporteur produced a good draft with a balanced focus on the most important aspects such as discrimination based on sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. I welcome the call for work-life balance legislation (maternity, carers, paternity leave), the defending of ‘quality’ employment for people with disabilities, and the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees. Despite very positive application of the directive in many Member States, problems and challenges still exist such as funding, awareness, discrimination reporting, access to information and justice, and data collection. The social partners (trade unions and employers) and civil society, including equality bodies, must be involved in the effective application of equality in employment and occupation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Fidesz-KDNP delegation in the European Parliament voted unanimously and decisively against the EP report on social dumping. The document sees, inter alia, a threat to EU citizens legally employed in another Member State in the context of the free movement of services, in particular workers from Central and Eastern Europe. Instead of defining the concept of 'social dumping', the report sought to define the posting of legally employed workers to another EU country as social dumping. Under existing EU legislation, the report seeks to blur the status of legally posted workers to another Member State, as well as those providing cross-border services, typically hauliers, including undeclared workers and those working in the domestic, nursing and care sectors (in particular home care). As is well known, the proportion of posted workers in the EU is less than 1% of the EU labour market. The question arises as to why the European Commission forced the start of a review of the legislation in relation to posted workers when the deadline for transposition had not yet expired. It is also a well-known fact that western European businesses are much more capital-strong, while in Central and Eastern Europe, lower wage costs are one of the main elements of competitiveness. The difference between the two could be limited, but the legislation on posted workers would be lifted, the review of which would be reasonable and equitable only with sufficient experience.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. Socialist amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws up recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. It also stresses that, although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. Socialist amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another defending the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the application of Council Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and working conditions (Employment Equality Directive) because I support the need to create a level playing field between all EU citizens in order to facilitate their access to the world of work. Although the European Union is based on values such as respect for human dignity, freedom, equality and the protection of human rights, there is a large gap between the Member States in complying with the obligations of the employment directive. While it is true that some more virtuous states go even further than these obligations, extending protections to racial equality, as well as age, sexual orientation and religious convictions, there are still many problems of access to work for the Roma, homosexuals, Muslims or Jews. The need to increase participation in the labour market in the future and the safety of workers are also a fundamental requirement for creating the conditions for a better reconciliation of life and work and for better and widespread social cohesion and the well-being of citizens.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the 'Application of the Employment Equality Directive'. It sets very important accents, although not on all points. For example, I welcome the condemnation of professional bans in individual Member States when people refuse certain activities on religious or conscientious grounds. I also welcome the inclusion of my application for special protection for breastfeeding mothers in the workplace.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The European Union's Equal Treatment Directive is an irrefutable value of the Union. The European directive on combating discrimination must be introduced as soon as possible.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. We consider with respect to the first part of Amendment No 21 that it is precisely the principle of subsidiarity applied to states and social intermediate bodies that generally ensures compliance with international human rights standards, otherwise difficult to apply at least until a supranational justice system is not fully effective.  Without prejudice to the fact that a balance must be fostered between the unity of human rights and the diversity of cultural and political contexts where human rights are applied, we understand that states and employers can in fact retain legitimate grounds for prohibiting symbols that are patently oppressive and cannot be excused in their religious nature. With regard to the second part of the amendment, while it does not clearly specify the criteria by which certain symbols suppress women's rights, which may give rise to some abusive interpretations, we consider that the risk of the text currently being used to justify the repression of legitimately protected symbols in religious freedom is significantly less than the risk of the text abstaining from the need to suppress the public use of oppressive symbols , or that involve manifest security issues.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. It's been a long time since I've seen such an ideological relationship. It is devoted to discrimination in the workplace, supposedly real, massive and systematic against minorities (immigrants, Roma, LGBT, disabled, etc.), a distressing reality that a statistical bias would prevent us from seeing well. One wonders why so many immigrants flock to Europe every year. By masochism, no doubt. Despite her distrust of the numbers, Ms. Weber uses some of them, which she considers reliable because they go in her direction, even if they have only a tenuous relationship with the subject: homosexuals who do not hold hands or Jews who do not wear symbolic clothing in public, without being told whether it is by choice or fear. , and out of fear of who. Minorities who are or say they are discriminated against. All this kneaded in a joyful confusion to promote the only legitimate discrimination, and even recommended: that of the European heterosexual male aged 25 to 50 years. We would like, since we are talking about work and minorities, that Mrs. Weber should look at the explosion of religious practices in business and the instrumentalization of anti-discrimination laws by some to impose these practices on all. But now I can hear his cry of dread: "Padamalgame!"

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as its content is positive in that it identifies the main problems and challenges of the implementation of this Directive, and proposes recommendations to the Commission and the Member States with which we agree to eliminate discrimination on the basis of sex, religion, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation and to ensure equal treatment in employment. Among others, some of the highlights that we find very positive are: that the Commission introduce a Directive on leave for caregivers; improvement and cross-cutting of available equality data, including harmonised and homogeneous statistics; provide ongoing training to stakeholders on employment legislation; strengthen and support civil society organizations working in this area; measures to ensure that the private sector assumes responsibility for creating a discrimination-free environment; the adoption of a European framework for national strategies to combat anti-Semitism and Islamophobia; recognize social clauses in public contracts or the application of effective legislation (GED recast) to ensure the protection of all trans persons, among others.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because, according to a study carried out by the European Commission, it has been shown that there is a possible correlation between countries with a low level of case-law and countries that have transposed the directive by taking only certain formulations of it and introducing them into their national laws. There are certain procedural difficulties affecting access to justice and effective implementation, which also stem from the short deadlines provided for by the legislation, lengthy procedures, high costs and shortcomings in providing legal aid, as well as language barriers, access for persons with disabilities and legal issues relating to the legitimate interest. I believe that further efforts are needed to ensure the credibility and admissibility of evidence based on specific circumstances, as women and persons with disabilities continue to be victims of multiple, direct and indirect discrimination in the labour market, despite the application, in theory, of the principle of equal treatment in the Member States. I strongly encourage and support the protection of persons with disabilities and their non-discrimination in fact because, in theory, all the Constitutions of the Member States provide for non-discrimination.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for a comprehensive approach on combating discrimination in employment and occupation. We urgently need to adapt workplaces and to provide assistance, education and training for people with disabilities.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights many important principles for equality and non-discrimination before employment, but I objected to paragraph 21, which indirectly targeted France by 'concerning that some Member States have put in place general bans on the wearing of religious symbols in public spaces in the name of neutrality and secularism'. This paragraph was contrary to the principle of subsidiarity, and it goes against the French legislation in force, which is quite legitimate to combat communitarianism, which prohibits the wearing of ostentatious religious signs in public institutions. Respect for the values of the Republic forbids us to allow communitarianism to flourish in the enterprise and that is why the wearing of certain religious signs, especially when they violate women's rights, must be prohibited by employers.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.  It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. The S&D amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this report which is a well balanced and comprehensive assessment of the challenges we face in ensuring equal treatment in employment and protection from discrimination on the grounds of sex, race, disability, age, religion and belief or sexual orientation. While great progress has been made since the Directive’s introduction, discrimination is still a problem for our society. According to data from the EU Fundamental Rights Agency, 40% of Roma job seekers experience discrimination, 75% of gay people will not hold hands in public with their partner, 38% of Jewish respondents admitted they do not wear their symbolic garments in public and 37% of Muslim respondents have reported experiencing discrimination. The report highlights the importance of collecting data, in order to help prove the existence of discrimination and in particular indirect discrimination. Awareness raising and access to information, with the help of equality bodies and social partners, is crucial as many victims themselves still have difficulty in recognising discrimination. Access to justice in discrimination cases is also a key area highlighted in the report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, own-initiative report. This vote wasn’t on the legislation itself, but on how it was being implemented. The report covered a wide range of sensitive issues such as discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, nationality sexual orientation etc., and rightly condemned aspects such as harassment and violence. However the report then went on to call for wide-reaching Commission action and EU legislation such as data collection, information campaigns, adopting the EU framework on racism and called for further harmonisation of laws regarding secularism. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels. While UKIP cannot support more EU action and spending of taxpayer’s money, we do not want to appear to oppose equality or against fighting discrimination.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, honourable Members, unfortunately discrimination based on a gender, national, ethnic or religious principle continues to be an obstacle in the daily lives of too many Europeans. I therefore support the conclusions of the report on the implementation of the Employment Equal Treatment Directive.  In order to effectively exercise the principles of equality and fundamental rights and freedoms in the field of employment, Member States should systematically ensure that all existing legal texts comply with the principle of equal treatment. I expect them to encourage the work of national labour inspection bodies and develop policies to raise awareness of victims of discrimination in the field of work, as workers are often unaware of their rights, the competent authorities they can turn to, nor the possibilities of obtaining support and redress.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the recommendations made by the rapporteur regarding the Employment Equality Directive in order to improve the role of civil society and social partners, access to justice, lack of equality data and awareness.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Council Directive 2000/78/EC Application Report from 27 October 2013 to 31 December 2013. I am aware that discrimination is, unfortunately, still part of the everyday life of many Europeans, and I believe in a better world when all Member States will remove natural, social and economic barriers that impede the realisation of the principle of equality and limit the freedom of European citizens.  This Report, which I supported, underlines the need to work on strengthening dialogue between governments, civil society and social partners on all forms of discrimination and raising public awareness. There is also a lot of room for improvement, as most Member States have delegated the responsibility of disseminating information in relation to anti-discrimination legislation and raising awareness with specialised national authorities without necessarily allocating adequate resources to them.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James and her UKIP MEP colleagues abstained on this non-legislative, own-initiative report. This vote wasn’t on the legislation itself, but on how it was being implemented. The report covered a wide range of sensitive issues such as discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, nationality sexual orientation etc., and rightly condemned aspects such as harassment and violence. However the report then went on to call for wide-reaching Commission action and EU legislation such as data collection, information campaigns, adopting the EU framework on racism and called for further harmonisation of laws regarding secularism. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels. While UKIP cannot support more EU action and spending of taxpayer’s money, we do not want to appear to oppose equality or against fighting discrimination.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Weber report on the directive to create a general framework for equal treatment in employment. This directive was adopted 15 years ago and aimed to create a level playing field for access to employment. This report aims to examine the remaining challenges in the implementation of this directive and proposes some practical solutions.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Among the fundamental values on which the EU is based are non-discrimination and respect for human rights. The Union's objective is to combat all discriminatory practices based on sex, age, religion, race, colour and origin. Although many countries have included the prohibition of discrimination in their legal systems, this law is still not fully applicable. The labour market is one of the areas where discrimination occurs. This is illustrated, for example, by the fact that women are more affected by unemployment than men. It is mainly about pregnant women and mothers. This also applies to older people, among whom the unemployment rate is very high, and yet they can enrich companies with their experience and knowledge. In order to deal with this problem, we must seek to eliminate all forms of discrimination, not just those on the labour market. The existing law should be applied consistently and the exercise of rights should be facilitated by ensuring the possibility of free legal aid and simplifying procedures. We should also develop programmes to facilitate adaptation in a changing working environment.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Much has been achieved through the Directive to ensure a more balanced representation of women and men among non-executive directors of listed companies. This report is now trying to push ahead with the horizontal EU anti-discrimination directive, which would, however, violate the principle of subsidiarity and deeply interfere with the competences of the individual Member States. I therefore reject this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for a comprehensive approach on combatting discrimination in employment and occupation. We urgently need to adapt workplaces and to provide assistance, education and training for people with disabilities.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. – I support the report on the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive, adopted 15 years ago and aimed at creating a level playing field for equality in employment. According to data from the fourth Eurobarometer, an increasing number of Europeans are tolerant of groups that are threatened with discrimination and are better informed about their rights in the event of discrimination than the previous survey conducted in 2012.  There are still challenges to the implementation of the Directive. I believe that Member States need to show greater commitment to the implementation of the principle of equality between women and men in employment policies and must develop gender-neutral classifications of professions and evaluation systems as mandatory measures to promote equal treatment. Furthermore, I call on the Member States to encourage employers to recruit young people, but at the same time to ensure and respect equal treatment in terms of pay and social protection.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The directive on equality in employment, adopted 15 years ago, aims to lead towards equality between men and women in the workplace. According to a recent Eurobarometer survey, the European population is now more tolerant, than in 2012, of groups subject to discrimination, as well as being better informed about the rights due in the event of discrimination. None the less, the directive still has a number of problems and weaknesses in its application. For these reasons, the report examines the existing challenges for the implementation of the directive and tries to find solutions to improve it as much as possible. It is our task to promote the fundamental principles of the Union of equality, human dignity, freedom and democracy. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because many of its provisions are contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. The Employment Equality Directive, adopted in 2000, aims to ensure equal treatment in the workplace, regardless of the age, religion, belief, disability or sexual orientation of the individual. I regret that, sixteen years later, some measures have not been able to succeed in a concrete way. I therefore very much welcome this report, which examines the ongoing challenges to employment equality and possible improvements. For example, it encourages the creation of workplaces that take into account the needs of people with disabilities, proposes training programmes, particularly in the development of digital skills, for older workers, or promotes greater awareness of the attention of victims of discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. Therefore, I voted for its adoption in plenary.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. If everyone obviously agrees to denounce discrimination in employment and wages, with equal qualifications, this text broadens the way to distort the fight against discrimination. All that is not man, heterosexual, European and well must, according to this text, benefit from special legislation to combat discrimination. We reject this repository and the very principle of affirmative action, preferring the idea of meritocracy. I therefore opposed this resolution.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.  It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. The S&D amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.  It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. The S&D amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which assesses the implementation of the Equal Employment Directive since it recognises and identifies fundamental problems in the implementation of this directive, such as lack of data on equality, gaps in information and support for victims or sweepers in access to and reparation in the event of breaches thereof.  The report also makes a number of recommendations which I consider positive as the need to adopt a European framework to combat Islamophobia at national level, including the need for Member States to implement legislation to ensure the protection of transgender people, as well as to enable mutual recognition of all types of unions, marriage regimes and parental rights. In supporting these recommendations, my vote has been favourable.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This Directive on the establishment of a general framework for equal treatment in employment and occupation establishes a general framework for ensuring equal treatment in the workplace of persons in the European Union, regardless of religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. I believe that an important point of this initiative is that it will apply to all persons, both those working in the public and private sectors, in relation to conditions of access to employment or self-employment, including selection criteria and conditions of recruitment and promotion; vocational training; conditions of employment and work (including dismissal and remuneration); affiliation and participation in an organization of workers or employers, or in any organization whose members perform a specific profession. For the reasons described above and because we must take, both at national and European level, all possible measures to protect the principle of equality in employment and occupation, I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report that seeks a level playing field and how the EED can be improved.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I opposed the adoption of anti-discrimination directives, and I do not agree with this report either. I do not agree with the call for the government to raise awareness among LGBTI people of their rights through campaigns.  It's up to everyone to figure out for themselves what their rights are. Nor do I agree with the requirement that 'rules to protect whistle-blowers should be adopted in cases of discrimination in the workplace'. In my think, this would lead to the favouritism of whistleblowers in legal disputes relating to alleged discrimination in the workplace.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report’s recommendations to strengthen the role of the national equality bodies, including through the provision of adequate funding, to display greater commitment in implementing the principle of equality between women and men in employment policies, to enhance the reconciliation of work and private life by concrete measures, such as urgently proposing new legislative proposals on the Maternity Leave Directive so as to guarantee the right for women to return to work after pregnancy and maternity leave and parental leave.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ the Union declares in its documents the fight against social exclusion and discrimination. These values touch all spheres of life. Although member states have also transformed these values into their national rules, in practice they are violated and not complied with in various ways and forms. However, proving the existence of discrimination and unequal treatment is difficult in everyday life. It requires a purposeful approach by the authorities involved and the cooperation of the victims, who are usually afraid to talk about their bad experience.  The Commission, the Member States and all bodies and organisations must cooperate in obtaining information on discrimination and unequal practices, exchange practical experience and procedures and propose new solutions from this practice, which must also find reflection and support in the regulation of legislation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Referring to my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 15/9/2016, I abstained in the vote on the report on the implementation of Council Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 on the establishment of a general framework for equal treatment in employment and work ('the Equality in Employment Directive'), as this report is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. While everyone agrees, of course, to denounce discrimination in employment and wages, with equal qualifications, this text broadens the criteria to the point of distorting the fight against discrimination.  Moreover, the use of statistics by the rapporteur, some of which have no direct link to the report, shows his willingness to pervert the substance of the matter. We reject the very principle of affirmative action, preferring the idea of meritocracy.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This report claims to deal with conditions of competition with regard to equality in employment and occupation, but in fact social policy is to be pursued. This must be rejected.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP's report on the application of the Employment Equality Directive. Discrimination affects all areas of people's lives, and employment is only one of them. Although the perception of discrimination has improved, many victims of discrimination still do not know their rights or because of various factors, such as complex and lengthy legal procedures, do not dare to take legal action against discriminatory practices.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Equal Employment Directive came into force in December 2000. It establishes a framework for combating discrimination and ensuring equal treatment in employment.  The report points to shortcomings in the application of this directive. It denounces the low level of awareness, as well as the fact that most Member States have delegated the responsibility to disseminate information on anti-discrimination legislation and to raise public awareness of specialised national bodies, without providing them with the necessary resources.  It also notes that there is a wide gap between the discrimination experienced and their reporting rate, which is regularly reported by surveys. Or the fact that victims still have difficulty recognizing a discriminatory situation.  To remedy this, the report proposes that the Commission adopt a European framework that includes national strategies to combat racism. It also encourages Member States to provide appropriate systems for the reintegration into the labour market of prisoners who have served their sentences.  I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. If everyone obviously agrees to denounce discrimination in employment and equal wages, this text broadens the way to distort the fight against discrimination. All that is not man, heterosexual, European and well must, according to this text, benefit from special legislation to combat discrimination. We reject this repository and the very principle of affirmative action, preferring the idea of meritocracy. I therefore opposed this resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights and must combat social exclusion and discrimination. All Member States need to remove the natural, social and economic obstacles that prevent the principle of equality from finding material expression and limiting the freedom of European citizens. Only in this way will it be possible to achieve the proposed objectives. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it deals with the challenges to the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive. The resolution calls on Member States to commit to the principles of equality and tackle any forms of discrimination whether religious, sexual, gender, race or age; therefore I voted in favour as the Union needs to promote its values on its own soil.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Discrimination occurs in all aspects of life. Work, working conditions and working conditions are examples of cases where unequal treatment of people is still too common. In 2000, the European Directive on Equal Treatment in Employment and Occupation was adopted. The aim was to achieve the same approach in Europe to treatment in employment and occupation and to better weaponise and protect people from all forms of discrimination based on sex, race, origin, sexual orientation, disability, faith or belief and age. Sixteen years later, people are more aware of their rights in the event of discrimination. At the same time, however, we have to note that too few cases of discrimination are actually reported and that some grounds of discrimination receive more attention than others. It is therefore necessary, through data collection, citizens' awareness and legislative and non-legislative initiatives, to recognise, prevent and combat all forms of discrimination and, above all, indirect discrimination.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls on social partners (trade unions and employers) and civil society, including equality bodies to be involved in the effective application of equality in employment and occupation.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on Council Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and work, the ultimate aim of which was to create a level playing field in terms of employment and work. The implementation of the Directive has yielded many results, but there are still serious unresolved problems. The report states that discrimination affects all aspects of people's lives, with employment being just one of them. In any case, there is little data on employment equality, which is also due to the fact that the Employment Equality Directive does not require Member States to collect them. Nevertheless, there is a noticeable discrimination in other areas in this area as well. 40% of Roma jobseekers experience discrimination, 75% of gay people do not walk hand-in-hand with their partner in public places, 38% of Jewish respondents said they do not wear symbolic Jewish garments in public places, 37% of Muslim respondents have experienced discrimination and 11% have experienced hate crimes. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive on equal treatment in employment is founded on one of the basic principles of the Union. Article 10 TFEU provides that the creation and implementation of Union policies and actions is based on non-discrimination on grounds of sex, race or ethnic origin, religion or belief, age or sexual orientation.  However, according to the Commission's report, legislation is not enough to achieve full equality. Awareness of existing protection, the use of EU funds and the strengthening of national equality bodies should therefore be strengthened.  For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The fight against discrimination is a laudable goal if one does not pour into hysteria and paranoia.
