However, this report seems to be doing so, but it does raise good questions about discrimination, particularly against homosexual or transgender people. I therefore abstain on this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which calls for a comprehensive approach on combatting discrimination in employment and occupation. We urgently need to adapt workplaces and to provide assistance, education and training for people with disabilities. In the UK in 2015, only 48% of people with disabilities were in employment.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote on this report. While I agree with his recommendations, particularly with regard to the hiring of disabled workers, I cannot support a text that "is concerned about the prohibitions put in place by some States of the wearing of religious signs in public spaces in the name of neutrality and secularism, which has led the private sector to also attempt to enforce such restrictions" , while religious neutrality in the enterprise is a bulwark against communitarian behaviour that is unacceptable and dangerous.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's report on the application of Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 creating a general framework for equal treatment in employment and work. It reports on the results of the fourth barometer on the subject in Europe, after that of 2012, and finds that Europeans are more tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination than before and that they now know their rights better in the event of discrimination. The report also examines the remaining obstacles to the implementation of the Equal Employment Directive and possible improvements to achieve perfect employment equality.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this own-initiative report which assesses the implementation of the Equal Employment Directive 15 years after its adoption and proposes recommendations for further improvements. We particularly appreciate the decision to focus on the most important aspects such as discrimination based on sex, ethnicity, religion but also on personal beliefs, age, sexual orientation or because of forms of disability. We are pleased to note that, in the 15 years since the entry into force of the directive, some Member States have produced even more advanced legislation, even beyond the requirements of the European standard, and that, from the point of view of civil society, greater attention can be paid to social groups traditionally at risk of discrimination on the part of European citizens. , which today also present better and more extensive information in the field of rights. However, it is undeniable that there are still challenges from the point of view of integration and discrimination on the labour market, even as a result of the onset, or escalation, of phenomena of transformation of our society, such as migratory flows. That is why a proposal for reform by the European Commission is absolutely desirable, as indicated in this report.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ In 2000 the Employment Equality Directive was adopted which extended the protection against discrimination on grounds of sex, race, colour, ethnic or social origin, genetic features, language, religion or belief, political or any other opinion, membership of a national minority, birth, disability, age or sexual orientation that is provided under EU law. I have voted for this report that will address the challenges to the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this initiative because it emphasises that 'discrimination on grounds of disability' means any distinction, exclusion or restriction that prevents the recognition, respect and lawful exercise of human rights and fundamental freedoms. This report also calls on the Member States to strengthen public pension systems in order to ensure a decent replacement of wages after retirement. At the same time, I think it is very important for Member States to review professional insurance systems in order to combat discrimination against persons with disabilities.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained on the report on the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive, as it contains both elements with which I agree and elements with which I disagree. I appreciate that, in a separate vote, a text has passed recognising, for example, the freedom of conscience of every worker or the remission of the adaptation of religious symbols to the sphere of the Member States. I also think that concepts such as paternity leave can bring a number of benefits to society if they are properly grasped. On the other hand, however, there are a number of points in the text of the report that I cannot agree with, such as the point that social inequalities can only be combated through policies that guarantee a better redistribution of wealth and which are based on increases in real wages, measures to promote the regulation of work and working time and the protection of work. Similarly, I do not usually welcome calls for the Commission to prepare new regulations, particularly where the role of states should be essential in subsidiarity.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this positive report examining the application of the Employment Equality Directive across the EU. The report contains strong and positive proposals about achieving workplace and social equality for LGBTI people, women and parents, anti-discrimination elements around race, religion and gender, as well as positive aspects around equality for people with disabilities in the workplace.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Under the guise of improving conditions of competition with regard to equality in employment and occupation, social policy is actually pursued. This must be rejected.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EU values the principles of equal treatment, and it is nevertheless necessary to further pursue the reduction of discrimination in this area. The report calls for greater attention to be paid to people with disabilities, religious beliefs, age and other aspects that are important to a democratic Europe. Work needs to be done to strengthen the dialogue between governments, civil society and social partners on all the causes of discrimination and to raise public awareness.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The principle of equal treatment is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union. Although all 28 Member States have transposed the Directive into their national legislation, legislation alone is not enough to ensure full equality. It must be combined with the necessary action in the field of policy. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive with the ultimate aim of creating a level playing field with regard to equality in the field of employment. The need for increased labour market participation in the future, as well as for long-term income security, make it necessary to find better arrangements for reconciling work and family life. In addition, there is a need to strengthen dialogue between governments, civil society and the social partners on all forms of discrimination, as well as to raise public awareness. The report also highlightes the low number of complaints, reflecting only a low proportion of discrimination incidents actually taking place across the EU. Efforts to raise awareness, disseminate information, improve access to the justice system and complaint mechanisms for discrimination should therefore be intensified.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, own-initiative report. This vote wasn’t on the legislation itself, but on how it was being implemented. The report covered a wide range of sensitive issues such as discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, nationality sexual orientation etc., and rightly condemned aspects such as harassment and violence. However the report then went on to call for wide-reaching Commission action and EU legislation such as data collection, information campaigns, adopting the EU framework on racism and called for further harmonisation of laws regarding secularism. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels. While UKIP cannot support more EU action and spending of taxpayer’s money, we do not want to appear to oppose equality or against fighting discrimination.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I appreciate the work that has been done in trying to produce a text that encompasses all the various positions and better regulates a fundamental pillar of what must be an increasingly integrated and open European labour market. I therefore congratulate the rapporteur and would vote in favour of this text.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – As a convinced European I believe that tolerance and non-discrimination should be at the heart of the EU policies. This is why I voted in favour of this report, which examines the still existing challenges to the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive and looks for possible ways of improvement. Furthermore, according to the forth Eurobarometer, currently more Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are better informed about their rights in case of discrimination as compared to a previous survey conducted in 2012.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for an EP resolution adopts many constructive proposals that jointly aim to prevent discrimination in the employment of persons. Respect for human dignity and human rights, which must be a landmark in these matters, is essential.  The focus of the resolution is on vulnerable groups that should have equal employment rights, namely people with disabilities and older people aged between 55 and 65. It is also good that this resolution critically reflects on the practice of integrating the general principle of equal treatment for all Member States that have not yet adopted this.  However, despite many good aspects of this resolution proposal, I cannot support it because some ideologically impregnated elements are present. I disagree that the social and political climate is increasingly tolerant of the agendas of extremists, racists and xenophobes, and I do not agree that the notion of family is reduced to some communities that are not based on marriage between a man and a woman.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. There is no consensus that discrimination in employment, with equal qualifications, is not appropriate and there is clear evidence of a decline in discrimination and an increasingly comprehensive information on the rights of victims of discrimination. However, the report denounces exactly the opposite. It is no longer intended to defend equality in employment. Rather, it aims to exacerbate communitarianism by encouraging, in particular, systematic judicialization, resulting in a fragmentation of society.  So I prefer to abstain.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report assesses the state of implementation of the Employment Equality Directive 15 years after its adoption and contains recommendations for future improvements. Some Member States have managed to ensure even better conditions than those required by the directive, and more and more European citizens are being tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are more aware of their rights. However, issues still to be resolved remain, such as the lack of denunciation of discrimination and the still limited access to information and justice. The report calls on the social partners (trade unions and employers) and civil society, in particular associations and organisations concerned with equality, to do more to make the principle of non-discrimination effective in the world of work, starting with the search for a better work-life balance. Much remains to be done to ensure that there is full equality in the world of work, but the way is the right one and I therefore support the demands of this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ It has been 15 years since the adoption of the Employment Equality Directive, which aims to create a level playing field in employment and occupation. However, work needs to be done to strengthen dialogue between governments, civil society and social partners on all forms of discrimination and to raise awareness of discrimination in public.  I supported the report, as the creation of advanced legislation, non-discrimination and social inclusion in the workplace are a priority for all Member States.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This implementation report addresses the challenges of implementing the Employment and Labour Equal Treatment Directive adopted 15 years ago, with a particular focus on horizontal aspects, sexual orientation, religion and religion, age and disability. Very little equality data is still available, as the Directive does not require Member States to collect such data. The general nature of this report, which aims only at broadly outlining the current situation and encouraging Member States to implement the provisions of the Directive more fully, is worthy of support. There are several elements that may be worrying, such as references to the proposed Anti-Discrimination Directive, the Maternity Leave Directive and the LGBTI. I therefore abstained.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive, adopted 15 years ago. According to the Eurobarometer studies, discrimination in access to employment is decreasing and victims of discrimination are now better informed about their rights.  Nevertheless, some challenges still need to be addressed. Like equal pay between men and women, equality in employment must be a priority in every Member State at all times.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The transposition and implementation of Directive 2000/78/EC, which establishes a general framework for equal treatment in employment and occupation, by the 28 Member States, has enabled, according to the Eurobarometer, not only an increase in tolerance for groups at risk of discrimination, but also for European citizens to be more informed about their rights in the event of discrimination.  However, challenges remain to the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive. According to the EU, the Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights and must combat social exclusion and discrimination on grounds of sex, race or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. Similarly, pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men must prevail in the Member States. I believe that combating discrimination in the context of employment and professional activity will only be effective if such discrimination is based on this report in a comprehensive manner – an objective achieved in this document, support and vote in favour of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, own-initiative report. This vote wasn’t on the legislation itself, but on how it was being implemented. The report covered a wide range of sensitive issues such as discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, nationality sexual orientation etc., and rightly condemned aspects such as harassment and violence. However the report then went on to call for wide-reaching Commission action and EU legislation such as data collection, information campaigns, adopting the EU framework on racism and called for further harmonisation of laws regarding secularism. The only people that should decide these things are our elected and accountable national governments, not EU bureaucrats in Brussels. While UKIP cannot support more EU action and spending of taxpayer’s money, we do not want to appear to oppose equality or against fighting discrimination.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I think it is essential that the EU should combat social exclusion and discrimination; pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men must prevail. However, according to data from the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, 40% of the Roma population seeking employment are victims of discrimination, 75% of gay couples do not hold hands in public, 38% of Jews surveyed admit that they do not wear symbolic robes in public, 37% of Muslims surveyed said they were victims of discrimination and 11% who were victims of hate crimes. Overall, the situation has a negative impact on social cohesion, as well as respect for fundamental rights and reported cases should be addressed seriously. The available data on equality are still very scarce, mainly due to the fact that the Employment Equality Directive does not require Member States to collect them.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.  It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. The S&D amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report to assess the implementation of the 2000/78/EC Directive on Equal Treatment. This directive, adopted 16 years ago, establishes a general framework to ensure equal treatment between people in the workplace, regardless of religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.  In this resolution, the European Parliament calls for the adoption of European frameworks for the implementation of national strategies to combat anti-Semitism and Islamophobia. This is an important demand in the current context of rising populism.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. The Employment Equality Directive provides a general framework to combat discrimination on the basis of age, sexual orientation, disability, religion or belief.  However, it is not enough to guarantee full equality in employment. Many discriminations remain in the labour market, particularly for women, LGBTI people, the elderly and people with disabilities. This report focuses on combating discrimination on the basis of religion, including the adoption of European frameworks for the implementation of national strategies to combat anti-Semitism and racism. It also urges action to promote the integration of people with disabilities, including the promotion of "smart working" models.  The report also calls for promoting integration into the labour market for all workers, regardless of age, including through vocational training.  Finally, it calls for the prevention of discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, including by re-examining legislation and practices.  To the extent that full equality in employment is an essential imperative, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Treaty on European Union, it is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, and must combat social exclusion and discrimination.  Fifteen years after the adoption of the Employment Equality Directive, the ultimate objective of which was to create a level playing field on equality in employment and occupation, there are still challenges to overcome. Europeans are now more tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights in the event of discrimination. Nevertheless, efforts are still needed to strengthen dialogue between governments, civil society and the social partners, while also raising awareness among the general public.  The need for greater participation in the labour market in the future, as well as the guarantee of long-term income, make it essential to find more effective mechanisms for reconciling work and private life, and I therefore generally agree with this report focusing on the issues described above and voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the implementation of the 2007 directive creating a general framework for equal treatment in employment. While it is true that the vast majority of Member States have enshrined in their constitution the principle of equal treatment on specific grounds of discrimination, in fact there is a persistence in the Union of cases of discrimination and harassment. In this sense, the report stresses the importance of protecting disabled workers from any form of discrimination in the workplace. More generally, age, gender, sexual orientation, origin or religion should not be the source of employment discrimination. For example, it calls for strengthening the role of national equality agencies, improving the implementation of the principle of equality between men and women in employment policies, and improving mechanisms for dealing with complaints at the national level.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as its content is positive in that it identifies the main problems and challenges of the implementation of this Directive and proposes recommendations to the Commission and the Member States with which we agree to eliminate discrimination on the basis of sex, religion, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation and to ensure equal treatment in employment. Among others, some of the highlights that we find very positive are: that the Commission introduce a Directive on leave for caregivers; improvement and cross-cutting of available equality data, including harmonised and homogeneous statistics; provide ongoing training to stakeholders on employment legislation; strengthen and support civil society organizations working in this area; measures to ensure that the private sector assumes responsibility for creating a discrimination-free environment; the adoption of a European framework for national strategies to combat anti-Semitism and Islamophobia; recognize social clauses in public contracts or the application of effective legislation (GED recast) to ensure the protection of all trans persons, among others.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the continued application of the Employment Equality Directive. It dates back to 2000 and aims to achieve greater equal treatment in employment and occupation. After a good 15 years, there have been significant successes; however, there are still challenges in this area. The directive still contains suggestions for improvement and should therefore continue to be applied.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which assesses the implementation of the Equal Employment Directive since it recognises and identifies fundamental problems in the implementation of this directive, such as lack of data on equality, gaps in information and support for victims or sweepers in access to and reparation in the event of breaches thereof. The report also makes a number of recommendations which I consider positive as the need to adopt a European framework to combat Islamophobia among others, or the need for Member States to implement legislation to ensure the protection of transgender people, as well as to enable mutual recognition of all types of unions, marriage regimes and parental rights. In supporting these recommendations, my vote has been favourable.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which calls for a comprehensive approach on combating discrimination in employment and occupation. We urgently need to adapt workplaces and to provide assistance, education and training for people with disabilities. In the UK in 2015, only 48% of people with disabilities were in employment.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing – The report deals with many areas of non-discrimination in employment and occupation and proposes a number of important measures, for example in relation to people with disabilities. At the same time, however, it is putting pressure on the adoption of a highly controversial horizontal anti-discrimination directive, which has been blocked for years and which also places undue emphasis on combating homophobia and transphobia, as well as on the specific protection of groups of transgender and intersex people. The resolution adopted, with its proposals and recommendations, also encroaches on areas which are solely the responsibility of the Member States, which is why I voted against.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Employment Equal Treatment Directive sets minimum requirements, but Member States may provide for a higher level of protection in their national legislation. However, we are still facing problems in the implementation of the Equal Treatment Directive. According to data from the EU Human Rights Agency, it is clear that many Roma job seekers experience discrimination, discrimination in the employment of women, the elderly, the disabled and the remuneration of men and women. Efforts must therefore be made to intensify dialogue between governments, civil society and the social partners on all grounds of discrimination and to raise public awareness. Surveys have clearly shown that there is a large discrepancy between the level of discrimination shown and the reported cases of discrimination. Therefore, involving the general public would help to eliminate this inconsistency, discriminated against individuals should know where and to which institution to turn for help and, above all, so that victims can recognise a discriminatory situation. I supported the motion for a resolution because I consider the application of the Directive on equal treatment in employment to be very important.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'Renate Weber's initiative report deals with the 2000 General Framework for Equal Treatment in Employment and Occupation. That Directive obliges Member States to protect against any form of discrimination on the basis of sex, race or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation in employment and occupation. The changing political climate of fear of unemployment and the refugee crisis is increasing racism and discrimination, including in the labour market. In order to contain this, the European Parliament is asking the Council not to block the adoption of the horizontal anti-discrimination directive. In addition, the consistent application of anti-discrimination legislation is important in preventive strategies around radicalisation. The report also refers to the need to protect disabled workers and promotes the use of socially responsible public procurement. In addition, Member States must do more to protect transgender people and whistleblowers, make use of gender budgeting and organise strong national labour inspections. We also call on the Commission to make new legislative proposals to strengthen the Maternity Directive, the Care Leave Directive and the legislation on paternity leave. For me, this is the obvious thing in this 21st century and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ any discrimination in employment based on sex, age, race, belief or other factors that are subjective personal circumstances is unacceptable. However, it would be a mistake for us to follow the path of quotas in pursuit of equality, which do not address anything and are just another form of discrimination.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I accept the report on the application of Council Directive 2000/78/EC, as I consider it necessary to combat social exclusion and discrimination. The European Union is based on the values of freedom, democracy, equality, respect for human dignity and respect for human rights, and must encourage assistance for people who have encountered any form of discrimination.  Women continue to be victims of multiple direct and indirect discrimination in the labour market and this needs to be changed. Also, any discrimination relating to a person's age, race or ethnicity, language, religion, political or other belief, national or social origin and any other discrimination encountered by people in employment should be combated. Under the Directive, Member States are obliged to combat all types of discrimination when employing people.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I would remind you that the 'Equal Treatment Directive' was originally intended to apply only to people with disabilities in the labour market. In fact, workers should not be placed in a worse position because of a physical disability. However, the existing subject area was then extended to cover all possible grounds for discrimination, including gender and sexual orientation. This is no accident! In this form, we must reject the Equal Treatment Directive and draw the attention of all national governments to the dangers of this draft directive. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is based on the values of freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and combats social exclusion and discrimination. In setting its policies, the EU is focused on combating discrimination based on gender, race and religion. Non-discrimination in employment is only successful if discrimination is combated in all areas of life.  Women, especially pregnant women and mothers, are hardest hit by unemployment and are victims of negative employment discrimination. One in five young people in the European Union is looking for a job, and the total cost of youth unemployment is estimated at €153 billion a year. Also, older workers are still often subjected to discrimination based on age or stereotypes. I support the Report establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and occupation, as I believe that all working age people must have equal employment rights without being victims of any discrimination.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Council Directive on general frameworks for equal treatment in employment and labour (Employment Equality Directive).  We welcome that almost all Member States have included in their Constitution the general principle of equal treatment because of various forms of discrimination. Member States should remove natural, social and political barriers that effectively prevent the implementation of the principle of equality and restrict the freedom of European citizens.  The concept of universality, indivisibility and interconnectedness of human rights must not merely be a legal principle that applies more in theory than in practice, since the different aspects of human identity are addressed separately in the existing legal instruments of the European Union.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the report on the implementation of the Employment Equality Directive, I abstained because, above all, I believe that many of the issues affected by this report are not necessarily addressed at EU level and can be left to the competence of the Member States. Although I fully support equality in employment as well as evaluating the effectiveness of the instruments that help to implement it, I believe that this is an issue that should not serve as a pretext for achieving political objectives, which often have little to do with equality in employment.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses the 15 years of experience of the Employment Equality Directive and makes proposals for further improvements. The reporter produced a balanced material covering aspects of discrimination on grounds of sex, race, religion, political beliefs, disability, age or sexual orientation. Despite the fact that some Member States have over-implemented the Directive, which is why workers are better informed, others are still, unfortunately, behind. Shortcomings include equality data, awareness, the role of civil and social society and lack of access to justice. I think it is important that the report places great emphasis on age and disability discrimination, the importance of data collection and lifelong learning and training. I consider the review on employment equality to be important, I believe that any discrimination should be avoided, so I voted in favour of this report. I am convinced that the Hungarian Government should also introduce more targeted measures in order to put the principle of equality into practice.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Equal treatment in the area of work and employment is a prerequisite for the development of EU economies. There is no doubt that, despite great progress, women, people with disabilities and minorities are still treated worse by employers than men. Moreover, unfortunately, in many areas, they still face problems, barriers and obvious inequality. First of all, this manifests itself in the different amount of remuneration received for equal work by men and women. In addition, the most discriminated against social groups in the area of employment are Jews, Sikhs and Muslims (especially women). Religious beliefs should have no influence on the assessment of the quality of the employee's work or on the perception of him or her as capable or incapable of carrying out his duties. The report raises a number of key issues for achieving equality in the area of employment and work, but the rapporteur has went beyond Community competence in the prepared text. Indeed, the European Commission's call for the urgent presentation of a new proposal for a directive on maternity leave and the strengthening of the rules on paternity leave cannot be achieved, since family-friendly policies are an exclusive competence of the Member States. It should also be emphasised that no proposals should impose a disproportionate burden on employers or service providers, as their weakening will negatively affect the labour market to the detriment of workers in particular.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report because it carefully assesses the application of the Equal Treatment Directive to employment, 15 years after its adoption, and provides recommendations for improving the situation. Key issues addressed in this report include: lack of data on equality, the issue of awareness, the role of civil society and access to justice. The document points out that, despite the very positive application of the Directive in many Member States, there are still problems and challenges such as funding, reporting of discrimination and access to information and justice. I believe that the social partners and civil society, including equality bodies, must be involved in the effective application of equality in the case of employment.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Given the need to increase labour market participation in the future, as well as to ensure long-term income security, it is important to find better solutions to reconcile work and family life, including the care of a family member. Therefore, your rapporteur hopes that the 2013 annual report of the Commission's Social Protection Committee, in which it is stated that the organisation of a long-term care system will play a decisive role in terms of participation in society and the labour market, will soon be translated into practice. Discrimination affects all aspects of people's lives and employment is just one of them. Any evolution involves change and our society must adapt to today's cultural contexts. The work environment must also be adapted; to do this, the Commission and the Member States should not only focus on legislation, but also on creating a work culture and on the well-being of everyone.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Employment Equality Directive was created to protect against discrimination on grounds of religion or belief, age, disability and sexual orientation in the areas of employment, occupation and vocational training. While such measures are vital to ensure equal access to employment, occupation but also for societal cohesion, I believe that discrimination is addressed more effectively at national level, as its roots often lie in specific national historical, cultural and social dynamics. This is why I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The ultimate objective of the Employment Equality Directive is to create a level playing field in terms of equality in employment and occupation. Despite the increase in the perception of discrimination, many victims of discrimination remain unaware of their rights or, due to various factors such as lack of trust in the competent authorities of the Member States or due to complex and lengthy legal proceedings, dare not take legal action against discriminatory practices. I regret that the understanding of human rights as universal, indivisible and interconnected as a legal principle is worth more in theory than in practice, as different aspects of the human being are treated separately in existing EU legal instruments. I hope that all Member States will remove natural, social and economic barriers that impede the achievement of the principle of equality and limit the freedom of European citizens, so I supported this Report on the application of the Employment Equality Directive.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ I supported the motion for a resolution on the application of the Employment Equality Directive, as I believe that there is still discrimination in employment in the EU, which has a negative impact on all aspects of life and also has negative consequences for the individual.  Member States should ensure that legislation is systematically aligned and the principle of equal treatment is implemented.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as its content is positive in that it identifies the main problems and challenges of the implementation of this Directive, and proposes recommendations to the Commission and the Member States with which we agree to eliminate discrimination on the basis of sex, religion, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation and to ensure equal treatment in employment. Among others, some of the highlights that we find very positive are: that the Commission introduce a Directive on leave for caregivers; improvement and cross-cutting of available equality data, including harmonised and homogeneous statistics; provide ongoing training to stakeholders on employment legislation; strengthen and support civil society organizations working in this area; measures to ensure that the private sector assumes responsibility for creating a discrimination-free environment; the adoption of a European framework for national strategies to combat anti-Semitism and Islamophobia; recognize social clauses in public contracts or the application of effective legislation (GED recast) to ensure the protection of all trans persons, among others.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The general principle of this report is the EU's recurrent obsession with combating discrimination and in this case employment.  The European Union's Fundamental Rights Agency reports that 40% of Roma job seekers are discriminated against; 75% of homosexuals do not hold their partner's hand in public; 38% of Jewish respondents admitted not to wear clothing with a symbolic dimension in public; and 37% of Muslims surveyed said they had been discriminated against. The rapporteur's use of these statistics, some of which have no direct link to employment discrimination, demonstrates his willingness to pervert the substance of the matter. While there is clear evidence of a decline in discrimination and an increasingly comprehensive information on the rights of victims of discrimination, the report denounces exactly the opposite. It is no longer intended to defend equality in employment. Rather, it aims to boost communitarianism by installing, in particular, judicial terrorism, resulting in a fragmentation of society. There is, of course, no mention of the mass immigration that member countries have been experiencing for decades. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Seeking appropriate legislative solutions on equal treatment on the labour market is an important objective of the common EU policy. However, the report takes into account world-view issues contrary to the tradition, culture, social and legal order of certain Member States. Aspects of non-discrimination on grounds of age, gender and degree of disability are fully acceptable, but other provisions on the recognition of partner status or parental rights should be approached with a certain amount of reserve so that these actions are not imposed against the wishes of the Member States. For this reason, I have decided to abstain.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the Treaty on European Union, the Union is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Fifteen years have passed since the adoption of the Employment Equality Directive, the ultimate aim of which is to create a level playing field in terms of employment and work. I supported the document we are discussing.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report as its content is positive in that it identifies the main problems and challenges of the implementation of this Directive, and proposes recommendations to the Commission and the Member States with which we agree to eliminate discrimination on the basis of sex, religion, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation and to ensure equal treatment in employment. Among others, some of the highlights that we find very positive are: that the Commission introduce a Directive on leave for caregivers; improvement and cross-cutting of available equality data, including harmonised and homogeneous statistics; provide ongoing training to stakeholders on employment legislation; strengthen and support civil society organizations working in this area; measures to ensure that the private sector assumes responsibility for creating a discrimination-free environment; the adoption of a European framework for national strategies to combat anti-Semitism and Islamophobia; recognize social clauses in public contracts or the application of effective legislation (GED recast) to ensure the protection of all trans persons, among others.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for, as the EU and its MS must step up their efforts to fight discrimination, including by changing the social and political climate that is more and more tolerant towards extremism, racism and xenophobia, fuelling and exploiting fears about unemployment and the refugee crisis. While the Employment Equality Directive has been transposed in all 28 Member States, non-discrimination in the field of occupation and employment is only effective if discrimination is comprehensively combated in all areas of life.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that all Member States provide grants, subsidies or tax incentives, such as employers with decent conditions for persons with disabilities, thus encouraging employers to adapt jobs and open up labour market opportunities for people with disabilities, as well as to ensure that all persons enjoy all human rights and fundamental freedoms on an equal footing with others.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the application of Council Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and occupation (‘Employment Equality Directive’). The report stipulates that in defining and implementing its policies and activities, the Union shall aim to combat discrimination based on sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. Moreover, it points out that, according to the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, all forms of discrimination, including multiple and intersectional discrimination, to a great extent hinder the deployment of human capital and constitute a barrier to career development. I voted in favour because I am of the opinion that non-discrimination in the field of occupation and employment is only effective if discrimination is comprehensively combated in all areas of life.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This Equal Treatment in Employment Directive, adopted 15 years ago, establishes a general framework for ensuring equal treatment in the workplace of EU persons, regardless of religion, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. This report examines the challenges that still exist in the implementation of that directive and looks for possible ways to improve it. In strong support for the implementation of the principle of equality at work, and aware that there are, for example, wage gaps between men and women that will need to be further reduced, I voted in the affirmative.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it assesses the implementation of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive since its adoption and draws out recommendations for future further improvements. It has a balanced approach to the most important aspects such as discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religious or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.  It also stresses that although some Member States have gone further in the implementation of the requirements of the Directive, and that Europeans are tolerant of groups at risk of discrimination and are also better informed about their rights, the challenges for the implementation of the Directive still exist. Socialist amendments strengthened aspects related to age and disability discrimination, reporting, data collection, multiple discrimination, continuing training and learning. A paragraph on work-life balance (maternity, caregivers, paternity leave) and another that defends the "quality" of employment for persons with disabilities, as well as the elimination of discriminatory language against migrants and refugees, was also incorporated.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which calls for a comprehensive approach on combating discrimination in employment and occupation. We urgently need to adapt workplaces and to provide assistance, education and training for people with disabilities. In the UK in 2015, only 48% of people with disabilities were in employment.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'This report concerns the application of the Equal Treatment Directive in employment and profession. I voted in favour of this report because it touches on some important issues such as discrimination, religious freedom, LGBTI issues, people with disabilities, age requirements, etc. It also stresses that the legislative process at all levels should take into account the administrative burden on micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and that planned measures should be subject to a proportionality test.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the general framework for equal treatment in employment and occupation was too lacking in member states' rights in terms of labour and social policy legislation. For these reasons, I did not support the adoption of the report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report takes stock of the directive of 27 November 2000, known as the "equality at work" directive, on the fight against discrimination in the workplace. It is a good tool of the European Union but it remains poorly applied in the States despite its legal transposition. It is and will remain insufficient and even illusory until the cross-cutting directive on combating discrimination is adopted. However, it, proposed by the Commission in 2008 and adopted by Parliament in 2009, is now, like others, blocked by the Council and therefore by the Member States. I broadly agree with this report on the increase in discrimination in the EU, particularly against women, LGBT people and because of religion "used as a substitute for race on the basis of real or presumed membership...." The figures, particularly from the Fundamental Rights Agency, speak for themselves. I therefore voted in favour of this report but again suggest that the EU should have the ad hoc means to enforce fundamental rights and the effective equality of those rights rather than focusing its activity on austerity plans and liberalisations that aggravate their violation.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Equal Treatment at Employment Directive is to create a level playing field for relationships and organisation of work, in particular with regard to gender, racial and ethnic, religious, sexual orientation, disability or age issues. The report assesses the implementation of the Directive and provides a number of recommendations for the future. As we know, the issue of multiple negative discrimination, both in the work context and in society as a whole, is a very relevant factor of social exclusion, with implications and consequences that have an impact on cultural behaviors or social stratification, in order to perpetuate inequalities. It is understood that the report has a good framework and presents effective answers to a problem that has not been behaved and which we see is tended to grow as a result of austerity policies and imperialist aggression.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. According to this report, the equality of all people in the profession is to be established. In reality, however, nothing other than social policy is being pursued. Among other things, employers who restrict religious symbols would in part violate international human rights standards. In principle, any kind of discrimination is to be regretted. On the one hand, however, if an employer who bans religious symbols violates human rights standards, and on the other hand there are many companies that no longer offer pork in canteens out of respect for other religions, this has nothing to do with equality, but is submission to other cultures. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The Employment Equality Directive is a landmark piece of European legislation, which sets out equality at the workplace and prohibits discrimination based on gender, sexual orientation, age, religious belief or disability. This is a prime example of the EU working to create social justice and a level playing field of high employment standards across Europe. This is the kind of progressive legislation which Leave campaigners would like to scrap. Labour MEPs will continue to fight so that UK citizens will retain the rights and protections the EU provides, regardless of the disastrous referendum outcome. As a champion for the rights of people with disabilities and a member of the Disability Rights Intergroup in the European Parliament, I was happy to vote in favour of this report which calls for a comprehensive approach on combating discrimination in employment and occupation. We urgently need to adapt workplaces and to provide assistance, education and training for people with disabilities. In the UK in 2015, only 48% of people with disabilities were in employment.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Despite cultural progress and the efforts made by society and its institutions to reduce discrimination, we still cannot talk about equal treatment, in the case of this report, in the area of employment and work. There are still significant disparities between the pay of women and men and between the pensions of women and men. It is not only gender that is a differentiating factor – the report also deals with inequalities based on religion, disability or age. It is our duty to eliminate all discriminatory practices through institutional action and to identify the desired solutions. However, this important report contains provisions that interfere with the competences of the EU Member States, which is why I abstained.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The aim of the Directive on equal treatment in employment and occupation, which is also part of the Slovak legal order, is to ensure that people are not discriminated against in access to the labour market or in the exercise of their profession. In doing so, the Directive lays down only minimum requirements so as to ensure a certain minimum standard throughout the European Union, and Member States have the possibility to introduce rules more stringently. The general principle of equal treatment has already been included by most states in their constitutions and subsequently in legal orders, but this principle is not strictly respected in employment. The European Parliament's report therefore dealt with precisely the still persistent discrimination in employment that we see, for example, in the employment of women, persons with disabilities, but also against people of older age or different religions. Although the proposal correctly identified many of the shortcomings that are emerging in the Member States, it was contrary to the principle of subsidiarity in some of its provisions, as a result of which I abstained in the final vote.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Weber report, because I share the recommendations presented in the balance sheet implementing the Employment Equality Directive. I would remind you that, despite a globally positive application in many Member States, only in some countries it is systematically guaranteed that all of its legal texts are in accordance with the principle of equal treatment, and are even less so that they apply them systematically. I would remind you that the European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, and must combat social exclusion and discrimination, as is in the context of the Treaty of Lisbon. Since one of the major obstacles is data collection, I would like to point out the call for harmonisation of homogeneous statistics to address the gaps in the collection of data on gender equality, in particular through Eurostat, with the aim of integrating disaggregated data on all grounds of discrimination into the indicators of the European Social Survey , in order to fight in a concrete way against all discrimination related to recruitment and the labour market.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the application of Council Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 on general frameworks for equal treatment in employment and labour (Employment Equality Directive). I believe that it is important for the European Union to work to combat discrimination in defining and implementing its policies and activities.  However, non-discrimination in the field of occupations and employment is only effective if we combat discrimination comprehensively in all areas of life, by removing barriers that restrict freedom and equality and prevent the full development of man and the actual participation of all workers in the political, social and economic structure of individual Member States.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Aim of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not so much to help workers who are victims of this process, but above all to support sustainable employment in areas affected by economic change. The first years of operation of the Fund have made it very clear that flexibility and rapid response to emerging difficulties are required, both on the part of The Member States and the EU institutions. The period assessed was marked by the constant evolution of the rules of operation of this fund and its adaptation to emerging challenges. It therefore seems to be a very convenient instrument at present to support companies experiencing difficulties linked to globalisation and the economic crisis.  However, it would be necessary to make changes to ensure that the Fund in question is coordinated and the actions undertaken under the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund. This would increase the effectiveness of interventions and avoid unnecessary costs. However, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund cannot replace member states' responsible restructuring policies. It is merely intended to provide support in emergency situations and not to be a form of escape from difficult decisions.  So far, out of the hundred and thirty supported companies, we can find both examples of effective and inefficient actions. It can therefore be seen that there are situations where the Fund has not fulfilled its role, which is mainly due to poor preparation of draft actions. It would be good to learn from these failures so as not to make mistakes in the future. This is the reflection of the report, which is why I fully support it in today's vote.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ar dtús vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir agus glacadh leis an tuarascáil gan aon deacracht in aon chor. Ní nach ionadh. Agus freisin ba mhaith liom mo chomhghleacaithe ó ALDE agus feisire ó mó thír féin, Éire, Marian Harkin, a mholadh as an dea-obair a dhéanann sí in a lán slite, go háirithe maidir leis an tuarascáil seo. Agus gan dabht ar bith tá an ciste seo thar a bheith tábhachtach do na daoine a chaill na jabanna. Chonaic mé seo i mo cheantar féin, daoine a chaill jabanna i nDell, a chaill jabanna i Waterford Crystal agus mar sin de. Agus is cuimhin liom go ndúirt oibrí amháin liom nuair a chaill sí a jab agus nuair a chuala sí faoin gciste seo, dúirt sí gur bronntanas ó Dhia é. Dá bhrí sin, taispeánann sé an dea-obair is féidir linn a dhéanamh sa Chomhaontas agus ba chóir dúinn leanúint ar aghaidh leis an gciste seo chomh fada agus is gá.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to thank you very much for allowing and agreeing to full statements that even exceed the time limit that we have. Thank you very much.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a fairly critical own-initiative report on the application of the EGF for the period 2007-2014. In particular, it is stressed that cases of EGF intervention are often linked to the restructuring strategies of large companies and multinationals, without adequate involvement of workers and their representatives.  In view of the improved effectiveness of the EGF, in terms of transparency and efficiency, EGF Member States are encouraged to publish all case data and assessments and to make their final applications and reports public in a timely manner, and the Commission is invited to make public all documents relating to EGF intervention cases, as well as to carry out in-depth ex ante and ex-post impact assessments that also include the social aspect , employment and economic. In this respect, any initiative to consider the EGF as an instrument for action for jobs lost in the EU as a result of trade strategies decided at EU level is strongly condemned, and the Commission is called upon to grant market economy status only to trading partners that meet the five criteria it has set. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is basically EU dole money towards which British taxpayers are forced to pay. Where there has been a large and sudden loss of jobs in a region of a Member State, the government can apply for this EU funding which will be used for retraining and education of workers who have lost their jobs. This report looked at how the EGF performed between 2007 and 2014. The report of course says the EGF was a glowing success and calls for the programme to expand and have more resources to be dedicated to it. UKIP opposes the use of the EGF as British taxpayer’s shouldn’t be asked to pay for poor economic policies in other countries and by the EU.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This was generally a good report and I voted in favour. My Sinn Féin colleague was involved as negotiator at the Committee level where she proposed amendments aiming to increase transparency in the EGF process, increase the focus on reaching out to young people not in education, employment or training, and ensure that the funds do not get returned to the Commission unspent due to slow implementation or incompetence by national authorities. Overall the EGF as a fund helps workers when they are in need of help having been made redundant because they are the victims of deindustrialisation, globalisation, or the financial crisis, therefore we supported it.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. At a time when major industrial accidents are being announced with the Alstom and Caterpillar cases, which are likely to precipitate thousands of unemployed workers, it was essential to recall the usefulness of this 150 million euro system, whose operation can still be improved. The initiation and investigation procedures must be able to be accelerated so that the means can be unlocked early enough to accompany, in real time, employees who are the victims of dismissal.  With a view to a re-establishment of the attribution criteria and the necessary re-industrialisation of Europe, we called on the Commissioner in charge of employment, Marianne Thyssen, to favour a preventive approach to better anticipate technological and commercial changes, to support more upstream companies, especially SMEs, in an ever-changing world.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Global Adjustment Fund (EGF). Initially the EGF was established by Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006 to allow solidarity with workers who lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies because of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, where these redundancies have a significant adverse impact on the regional or local economy. The report underlines that the EGF has undergone numerous reforms since 2006. I welcome the fact that the EGF’s scope has been broadened in order to include self-employed persons and persons not in education, employment or training (NEETs) and that the period of intervention has been extended up to 24 months, thus allowing many beneficiaries to access more extended training or educational programmes.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was originally set up by Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006 to support workers who had lost their jobs as a result of collective redundancies. The scope of the Fund was extended between 2009 and 2011 and for the period from 2013 to workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. Since 2013, the self-employed have also been included in the scope of application. The main objective of this report is to review the activities, impacts and added value of the Fund for the period 2007-2014. It is also the aim to assess the strengths and weaknesses of the reforms introduced during this period. It is important to measure such added value in order to be able to check whether policies at Union level, such as the EGF in this case, are justified or need to be called into question. In my opinion, it is still absolutely necessary to support workers who have lost their jobs as a result of mass redundancies as a result of structural changes in world trade patterns. In the long term, however, it remains essential to create a fair and effective framework in Europe in order to secure jobs and industrial sites in Europe in a sustainable manner.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Globalization Adjustment Fund, which was set up to compensate for the destructive effects of globalization on workers. Yet jobs destroyed are rarely replaced by new jobs, and affected areas are already experiencing a difficult job market. In most cases, young people are forced into mobility and the older ones are unemployed. Moreover, it is recognised that many regions or companies hit hard by globalisation are in fact victims of trade policies decided at EU level: free trade agreements, currently being negotiated or to come, are the main drivers of the massive loss of jobs in Europe.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The EGAF is the equivalent of the UK’s unemployment benefit. Where there has been a sudden loss of jobs in a certain region a Member State can apply for this fund and the money will be used to help retrain the redundant workers. Between 2007 and 2014 there were 131 funding applications for EUR 542 million for 121 380 workers. That is almost EUR 4 500 per worker.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund 2007-2014. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to help and show solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Court presented a report for the period 2007-2014 on the functioning, impact and added value of the EGF Fund. The EGF background has attracted criticism that some Member States have used large sums from the EGF to compensate for national employee income support schemes. In the Court's view, in this case, the use of EU funds has no added value, and it is therefore essential that Member States assess specifically the added value of this type of support. Long egp approval procedures have also been critically assessed. I agree with the Court of Auditors' recommendations that it is necessary for the EU institutions to consider the use of the European Social Fund (ESF) as an alternative to the EGF, as it aims to address long-term structural imbalances, in particular through lifelong learning programmes.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this report, which highlights the conclusions of the Court of Auditors, namely that almost all workers eligible for the EGF were able to benefit from personalised and well-coordinated measures tailored to their individual needs, and that almost 50% of workers who received assistance under the WEF have now found employment. Faced with the social damage caused by deregulated capitalism, the EGF is a necessary tool that has helped thousands of laid-off workers. But, as the scandalous closure of Caterpillar has shown, we must take swift steps upstream to avoid these social and human tragedies. Europe must severely penalise companies that make stock market layoffs. It must take strict measures to end tax avoidance and the role of tax havens. Finally, it must redevelop an industrial policy based on activities rich in innovation and research and development, which are not easily relocated.  This must, of course, be accompanied by a revival of public investment, and therefore demand, within the Union.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I am in favour of this report which analyses the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The EGF was created to help and express solidarity to laid-off workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns.  The report, inter alia, welcomes the extension of the funding period from one to two years, calls for all means to be put in place to speed up the procedures for the application and approval of the Funds and at the same time stresses concerns that the EGF has had a very limited impact on SMEs. I believe that it is a fundamental and very useful instrument and we must continue to improve it and adapt it to the changes taking place in the EU. It is therefore necessary to carry out specific studies of the impact of globalisation by sectors to enable it to develop proposals that encourage companies to anticipate sectoral mutations and to prepare their workers in advance of redundancies and against a real industrial policy at Union level that generates sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Mr Harkin's own-initiative report on the activities, impacts and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014, as it clearly shows where the strengths and weaknesses of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund lie. The fund is intended to use European Union funds to support workers who have become unemployed as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The use of money and its effects must, of course, be carefully evaluated. Therefore, a request to those Member States that have received support from the EGF to make all data and assessments on the cases concerned publicly available and to attach an impact assessment is justified.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument designed to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Created by Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006, it quickly became an important measure of social reintegration, with success rates ranging from 4 % to 98 % depending on the sector. The EGF has included in its sphere of action workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, the self-employed and shares of NEETs in certain predetermined regions.  This is an instrument that is a great added value in strengthening the social dimension of the Union, which is why I have decided to support the Harkin report. Europe must increasingly ensure that its citizens improve their living and working conditions. We must promote an increasingly inclusive European social model that makes the quality of public services, protection and social dialogue its central points.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established in 2006 to help workers who have lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies as a result of globalisation, when such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. The EGF has under modifications such as reducing the number of redundancies in the intervention criteria from 1000 to 500. This means that the EGF is more accessible to regions and smaller Member States. Since 2013, self-employed and "ninis" have been included in eligible regions under the Youth Employment Initiative. The final report voted in committee, although not perfect, incorporates more progressive measures than the initial draft, including greater accessibility for veterans, women, young people and single mothers/parents. She recognizes that women are disproportionately affected by crisis and austerity. It also contains some positive points in increasing the participation of local authorities, social partners and civil society in the access, distribution and implementation of the EGF. We voted for it.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported the report by Meps Marian Harkin whom I would like to congratulate on her great work. The report concerns the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. While supporting the whole report in my case, I have deferred with my group in two votes as in my opinion women have been disproportionately affected by the crisis and austerity policies. I also agree that although the female reintegration rate is higher than that of men, in the case of women it is a mostly provisional and unstable reintegration of work because she must meet family care obligations while looking for a new job or attending professional recycling courses , as well as the lack of affordable and quality childcare and care for the sick.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report covers the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. The WEF was established in 2007 to support the reintegration of workers in disadvantaged regions and sectors by opening up to international competition. The aim is to finance actions aimed at supporting the reintegration of laid-off workers into the labour market in addition to national arrangements, not by substituting them. Several problems: variable re-employment rates, difficulty in assessing efficiency and aid paid mainly to workers in large companies, not smes or self-employed people. The problem is that the European value of the EGF remains low. While the Fund is intended to enhance the effectiveness of national measures, one-third of THE funds allocated under the EGF are used to offset national worker income assistance programmes. Nevertheless, it remains effective in supporting groups or sectors that are not well-recognized at the national level. The WEF compensates for the destructive effects of globalization on workers, a globalization desired by the Free Trade Union. I voted for this text to support workers, but with the awareness of the dual language of the Union.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with what is contained in the Harkin report, which critically analyses the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) between 2007 and 2014. I believe it is essential to make this Fund more accessible to SMEs and young people, who are among the main victims of the EU's insane trade policy. That is why I wanted to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to help laid-off workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns. The EGF was designed to deal with emergencies through rapid intervention and short-term assistance in response to serious and unforeseen labour market difficulties involving large-scale redundancies. This report, which examines the activities, impact and added value of the EGF between 2007 and 2014, sets out a set of recommendations to improve the functioning of the fund. Among other aspects, it calls for more attention to the impact of trade policies and trade agreements on the European labour market and calls on the Commission to anticipate these effects; measures are called for the benefit of SMEs, social economy enterprises and cooperatives, as well as the importance of social dialogue based on mutual trust and shared responsibility, as the best tool for finding consensus solutions and common views in the prediction, prevention and management of restructuring processes.  For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it assessed parliament's activities of the European Globalisation Fund for the period 2007-2014 and provided guidance for further improvements to the fund's activities. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to help and show solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Parliament considers that bienenilding and other reports are not sufficient to fully ensure the transparency and effectiveness of the EGF. Calls on the Member States which have received EGF support to make public all case data and evaluations of support cases and to include gender impact assessments in the case assessment, and strongly encourages all Member States to make public their applications and final reports in a timely manner, as provided for in the current Regulation. The EGF estimates show that the results of the interventions of this Fund are influenced by factors such as the level of education and qualifications of eligible staff, as well as the capacity of the relevant labour markets to absorb support and the GDP of the beneficiary countries. Parliament stresses that such factors are mainly influenced by long-term measures that can be effectively supported by the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to support and express solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of major changes in world trade structures (over 500 persons per enterprise) and the EGF aims to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and promote sustainable employment by preparing and supporting redundant workers for a new job. As opposed to the European Social Fund, the co-financing rate is much lower (60%), with an average duration of 41 weeks (2013 figure) and an average grant of around EUR 4500 per person. Hungary has not taken advantage of this possibility, since mass redundancies took place almost exclusively before 2010, and the existing procedural rules are still not sufficiently flexible for our country. At the same time, the Fund is an important instrument for overcoming the consequences of the economic crisis, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 As an instrument for adapting to the economic prospects and needs of the labour market, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is intended as targeted aid to redundant workers and self-employed workers who are being made redundant as a result of the effects of economic restructuring. An initiative aimed at promoting the development of a Europe capable of creating socio-economic policies tailored to the citizen, accompanying economic transformations and restructurings linked to globalization and changes in trade trends on international markets.  The Adjustment Fund also leads us today to highlight the importance of strengthening the social side of the EU, with harmonised social protection schemes, as recently proposed by the Italian Government.
