Indeed, I believe that it is precisely in the principle of shared responsibility, as the report points out in the vote and well in line with the prerogatives of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), that it is precisely the ability to find flexible solutions to respond promptly to economic changes, cushioning their negative effects.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which supports people who are out of work as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. I believe that we must all fight for a Europe that ensures the improvement of living and working conditions and to promote a European social model consisting of strong social protection, quality public service and social dialogue.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF was created by Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006 to show solidarity with workers who lost their jobs in the event of mass redundancies, as a result of significant structural changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation, where such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. Over time it has become an important tool for social reintegration, with success rates ranging from 4% to 98% depending on the sector, and more than twenty thousand interested parties with positive effects on the territories and training-reorganization chains related to interventions.  For all these reasons, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a useful instrument, to be preserved and strengthened, which represents a concrete response of solidarity and social cohesion to the great changes that the globalised world entails for the 21st century European market and society.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important instrument of support and solidarity for workers made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade. With the launch of this instrument, the EU has expressed its solidarity with particularly vulnerable workers, especially those who, more than others, have suffered most from the negative consequences of globalisation and are still suffering from those of the economic and financial crisis. The cases requiring the intervention of the EGF are increasingly concerned with the restructuring strategies of large companies and multinationals. Strategies which, in most cases, are decided in the absence of the involvement of workers and their representatives. With the launch of the new EU programming cycle, the EGF has been re-proposed as a completely autonomous financial instrument: it operates outside the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was generally a good report and I voted in favour. My Sinn Féin colleague was involved as negotiator at the Committee level where she proposed amendments aiming to increase transparency in the EGF process, increase the focus on reaching out to young people not in education, employment or training, and ensure that the funds do not get returned to the Commission unspent due to slow implementation or incompetence by national authorities. Overall the EGF as a fund helps workers when they are in need of help having been made redundant because they are the victims of deindustrialisation, globalisation, or the financial crisis, therefore we supported it.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that there exist a lot of potential for Member States to make use of this Fund. In order to achieve this, additional information could be stepped up by the Commission informing Member States on the possibilities offered by the EGF. The report underscores amongst others that the EGF cannot act as a substitute to a true industrial policy at EU level to bring sustainable and inclusive growth. It also calls on the Commission to include in its mid-term evaluation a specific assessment of the Fund’s support to young persons not in employment, education or training (NEETs), especially in view of the Youth Guarantee and the synergies between national budgets, the European Social Fund and the Youth Employment Initiative. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Harkin's report is fairly critical of the activities, incidence and added value of the EGF for the period 2007-2014. The European Commission is also criticised for providing disappointing responses to parliamentary resolutions on information and consultation of workers, and it is also pointed out that the Commission's biennial reports do not fully guarantee the transparency and efficiency of the EGF. It is also asked to do everything possible to speed up procedures, because the average duration of an EGF application is currently 41 weeks. I voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union must show solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs as a result of mass redundancies as a result of structural changes in the economic fabric as a result of globalisation. I voted in favour of this report, which gives a positive assessment of the first seven years of application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF).  I welcome the fact that the average rate of reintegration of programme beneficiaries is 49 %, and I am convinced that further promoting personalized and intensive support for redundant workers can become even more positive. Certainly the EGF has contributed in recent years to social cohesion, helping large groups of people in great need of care, producing positive effects for the families of the beneficiaries and the wider community. I am pleased that the report calls on the Commission to present counterfattual impact assessments (VIC) that can provide further information on the European added value that the EGF can offer. I regret that some Member States have used substantial amounts of EGF funding to compensate for national income support schemes for workers and that the EGF approval procedures are still too slow.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that the Fund provides real support and expresses solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in the shape of world trade.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the requests made by my colleague. In line with the report, I believe that the Commission must make it clear that the loss of jobs caused by trade disputes that cause a major change in trade in EU goods or services falls fully within the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF).  I also think that the EGF has provided added value for the EU when it has served to co-finance services for redundant workers or allowances not normally provided for by member states' unemployment benefit systems.  However, I regret that these mechanisms have often replaced, rather than supplemented, member states' obligations towards redundant workers. I would therefore urge the Commission to be more rigid on this point.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014 and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Established by Regulation No 1927/2006, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support and express solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs at large-scale redundancies due to major structural changes in global trade patterns resulting from globalisation, where such redundancies have a considerable negative impact on the regional or local economy. Since 2006, the EGF has undergone numerous reforms: The intervention criterion has been reduced from 1000 to 500 redundant workers, making the EGF more accessible to regions and Member States; The intervention period was extended from 12 to 24 months, enabling many beneficiaries to have access to more developed training or education programmes; Self-employed people can now have access to the EGF, which allows these workers to have the same social protection and safety net as other workers. The reforms of the Regulation have contributed to improving its functioning and have simplified member states' procedures for access ing the EGF. I therefore support Mrs Harkin's report.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is basically EU dole money towards which British taxpayers are forced to pay. Where there has been a large and sudden loss of jobs in a region of a Member State, the government can apply for this EU funding which will be used for retraining and education of workers who have lost their jobs. This report looked at how the EGF performed between 2007 and 2014. The report of course says the EGF was a glowing success and calls for the programme to expand and have more resources to be dedicated to it. UKIP opposes the use of the EGF as British taxpayers shouldn’t be asked to pay for poor economic policies in other countries and by the EU.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014 because, on the assumption that SMEs account for 99 % of all EU companies and employ the majority of workers in the Union, it stresses the need to reorient the EGF more in favour of workers in SMEs , also increasing the eligibility thresholds. It also stresses the importance of stimulating more self-employment through the use of dedicated grants and incentives that do not leave out the theme of lifelong learning, mentoring and peer-to-peer networks. The report also encourages Member States to emphasise the inclusion of women in entrepreneurship programmes.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I see scope for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) contributing to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and the promotion of sustainable employment by preparing redundant workers for a new job and supporting them. It also provides a means of addressing emergencies by providing rapid intervention and short-term assistance in response to acute and unforeseen labour market difficulties involving large-scale redundancies. That makes it different from the European Social Fund (ESF), which also provides support for redundant workers but is intended to address long-term structural imbalances mainly through life-long learning.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this because it is a balanced assessment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. On the basis that this fund cannot replace the economic and industrial policies necessary to maintain the productive fabric, this fund should be used to alleviate the immediate consequences of the closure of companies. The report includes numerous positive references regarding the role of trade unions, the impact that the crisis is having especially on women, the role that local authorities must also play, etc. It also calls on the committee for an ambitious evaluation and review of this fund to address the dramatic situation in the European economy. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument of support and solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade and aims to promote sustainable employment by preparing the unemployed for new jobs and assisting them in doing so. The European Parliament resolution that I voted in favour notes that the European Adjustment Fund has improved its operation thanks to the reforms that have been made, which have also affected the simplification of the procedures for access to the Fund for the Member States.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Major structural changes in global trade practices, generated by globalisation, have a strong negative impact on the regional or local economy. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to enable the Union to support workers made redundant as a result of these structural changes, thereby contributing to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. In recent years, restructuring has become an increasingly widespread phenomenon. I voted to increase the co-financing rate from 50% to 60% in order to come to the aid of the Member States.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to support and express solidarity with workers made redundant at least 500 people per enterprise as a result of major changes in world trade structures. Between 2009 and 2011, and from 2013, the EGF was extended to include workers who lost their jobs as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. It allows solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade trade as a result of globalisation, in cases where such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. In addition, from 2013, the scope of the Fund has been extended to include a number of non-employed young people who are not in employment, education or training in the regions eligible for support under the Youth Employment Initiative. The egf's primary objective is to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and promote sustainable employment by preparing and supporting redundant workers for a new job. I voted in favour of the report approved today, which summarises the EGF's activities, impact and recommendations for the future for 2007-2014.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This fund provides support to those employees who have lost their jobs due to changes in international trade patterns. I am in favour of this report as I believe that Europe needs to keep on fighting for a Europe that ensures improvement of living, social and working conditions.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been consistently shown to be an inefficient and ineffective tool for managing large scale redundancies. It is not good value for money and the case has never been made as to why this investment should be made at an EU rather than a national level.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the principles of gender equality and non-discrimination, which are among the Core Values of the Union and are enshrined in the Europe 2020 Strategy, must be guaranteed and promoted in the framework of the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF).

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported the report on the evaluation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). I note that the WEF has generally provided well-coordinated measures for laid-off workers, is well managed and plays an important role in improving the employment prospects of thousands of citizens at a time of cascading industrial accidents, the latest examples of which are Caterpillar and Alstom. In this context, this tool is essential. One of its benefits is that it provides personalized support to laid-off workers. It should also be noted that the EGF provides for the possibility of intervening on behalf of young people who are out of school, without employment or without training. This helps to ensure that regions with high youth unemployment can benefit from European solidarity. It is of course possible to do better: EU governments must be urged to do more to use the flexibility of the current Fund to help workers laid off from subcontractors, who are mostly SMEs. It is also very important that there be genuine participation of workers or their representatives, social partners and other stakeholders in implementation decisions.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is an emergency fund established in 2006 for workers who have been laid off as a result of a major structural change that has occurred either as a result of globalisation or the ongoing global economic and financial crisis of 2008. In an effort to ensure that workers concerned have quick and personalised solutions to vocational reintegration, the Union has supported through this fund numerous national or regional initiatives over the period 2007-2014. Thanks to this instrument, an average re-employment rate of 49% has been achieved. However, the contours of the WEF still need to be revised to make it more responsive and flexible in its application. And beyond the one-off and specific assistance that the Fund can provide, it is urgent that the European Union put in place a real strategy: it must better anticipate economic changes, preserve SMEs, implement a forward-looking investment policy, and develop genuine trade defence instruments.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The WEF instrument was put in place to compensate for the destructive effects of globalization on workers. Yet jobs destroyed are rarely replaced by new jobs, and affected areas are already experiencing a difficult job market. In most cases, young people are forced into mobility and the older ones are unemployed. Moreover, it is recognised that many regions or companies hit hard by globalisation are in fact victims of trade policies decided at EU level: free trade agreements, currently being negotiated or to come, are the main drivers of the massive loss of jobs in Europe. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 My EQF Group, as well as myself, do not support the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) because we believe that it is not the right measure and employment can and should be stimulated through other instruments, economic growth, skills redirection so that they can be adapted to new labour market conditions, etc.  The EGF is an emergency instrument and is outside the Multiannual Financial Framework. A reserve fund has been set up from which it can make its annual appropriations. I believe that the power of this instrument cannot justify investment, and therefore I do not agree with its existence.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to support and express solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of major changes in world trade structures (over 500 persons per enterprise) and the EGF aims to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and promote sustainable employment by preparing and supporting redundant workers for a new job. As opposed to the European Social Fund, the co-financing rate is much lower (60%), with an average duration of 41 weeks (2013 figure) and an average grant of around EUR 4500 per person. Hungary has not taken advantage of this possibility, since mass redundancies took place almost exclusively before 2010, and the existing procedural rules are still not sufficiently flexible for our country. The shadow rapporteur for the report was Csaba Sógor, a Hungarian MEMBER from across the border, who contributed greatly to make the report more acceptable to the Fidesz-KDNP Group, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. Initially, the FEAG (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) was established by Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006 to support workers who have lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies due to major structural changes in global trade patterns due to globalization, where such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. The main objectives of the report are aimed at reviewing its results in 2007-2014, as well as determining the weaknesses and strengths of EGF reforms that were introduced in this period, and assessing their effectiveness and importance, which could approve the use of the Fund for the current programming period.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. —u2012 Marian Harkin has produced a well-balanced and well-written text that primarily intends to report on the impact of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. The reason I voted against the text was Amendment No 36, which called for additional funding for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which is not appropriate until a full evaluation of this fund has been carried out.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Since its inception, Member States have had the possibility to use the EGF in exceptional circumstances or on small labour markets, when the intervention criterion was not met, if the redundancies in question had a considerable impact on employment and the local economy. The scope of the EGF was extended between 2009 and 2001 and from 2013 to include workers made redundant due to the global financial and economic crisis. In addition, from 2013 on, self-employed workers have been included in the scope, as has been the case in regions eligible under the Youth Employment Initiative, with a neet number equal to the number of beneficiaries targeted. I agree with the conclusions contained in the report.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I do not consider this measure to be a useful tool for the development of policies that promote growth and the creation of new jobs, nor able to give a comprehensive answer with regard to redundant workers.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ The final report voted on in Committee, while not perfect, included more progressive content than the draft, including a focus on how the EGF can work better for older workers, women, young people and single parents. I voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Following the results of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014, we can conclude that this fund has provided individualised and well-coordinated measures to redundant workers. Targeted, individualised and intensive support for redundant workers often leads to positive results. The ability to create measures that complement national measures is also essential, as is the flexibility contained in this instrument. Other positive outcomes for beneficiaries include a positive psychological impact, increased adaptability and flexibility in the labour market. In addition, it is proven that the EGF has contributed to social cohesion by helping large groups of people in urgent need of assistance. This has also had a positive effect on families and the wider community. The participating organisations have achieved positive results in the field of education. This includes capacity building for the effective management of these measures and partnerships in the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund measures. However, in many cases there have been suspicions that funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund have been used by several Member States to compensate and national schemes to promote employment and workers.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report calling for access for SMEs and young people to these resources to be made easier in every way.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. The only way to really eliminate unemployment is to return to production, not retraining and handouts.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund), a fundamental European instrument which provides direct support to workers who have lost their job as a consequence of changes in trade patterns and globalisation. We will keep fighting for a Europe that ensures the improvement of living and working conditions and to promote a European social model consisting of strong social protection, quality public services and social dialogue. I welcome the fact that, through these changes, we will ensure that more attention is paid to the impact of trade policies and trade agreement in the European labour market and we clarify that the loss of jobs as a consequence of trade disputes which result in a serious shift in Union trade in goods or services is fully within the scope of the EGF. Finally, I support the demand to the Commission to present a proposal for a legal act on information and consultation of workers, anticipation and management of restructuring.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to support and express solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of major changes in world trade structures (over 500 persons per enterprise) and the EGF aims to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and promote sustainable employment by preparing and supporting redundant workers for a new job. As opposed to the European Social Fund, the co-financing rate is much lower (60%), with an average duration of 41 weeks (2013 figure) and an average grant of around EUR 4500 per person. Hungary has not taken advantage of this possibility, since mass redundancies took place almost exclusively before 2010, and the existing procedural rules are still not sufficiently flexible for our country. The report is acceptable to the Fidesz-KDNP Group, so I voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to support and express solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of major changes in world trade structures (over 500 persons per enterprise) and the EGF aims to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and promote sustainable employment by preparing and supporting redundant workers for a new job. As opposed to the European Social Fund, the co-financing rate is much lower (60%), with an average duration of 41 weeks (2013 figure) and an average grant of around EUR 4500 per person. Hungary has not taken advantage of this possibility, since mass redundancies took place almost exclusively before 2010, and the existing procedural rules are still not sufficiently flexible for our country. The shadow rapporteur for the report was Csaba Sógor, a Hungarian MEMBER from across the border, who contributed greatly to make the report more acceptable to the Fidesz-KDNP Group, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The text we have approved, which I fully supported, draws up an important political assessment of the use of one of the European Funds of greatest importance to citizens. Indeed, with the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Europe has sought to provide an instrument that can provide support and solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of industrial changes and changes in world trade, a phenomenon that has unfortunately been steadily increasing in recent years. Among the most important political points, I would like to highlight the appeal to the European institutions, as a preventive measure and which anticipates the disbursement of the Fund (first of all company restructuring) to guarantee common instruments for the participation, consultation and information of workers in the main strategies of companies, in line with what was said earlier in the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on Employment.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the European Parliament resolution on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014, because I believe that the EGF is indeed one of the eu's most important programmes. This is the only type of EU assistance to workers who lose their jobs and is one of the most obvious and visible forms of added value and the importance of EU membership. A fund that pursues intelligent policies, that looks at training and retraining, that promotes interinstitutional social dialogue and that takes care of the fate of those who lose their jobs as a result of the crisis, globalisation, trade agreements and mass redundancies. I am convinced that the audience of beneficiaries can still be enlarged and that procedures at national level can be streamlined, perhaps allowing local authorities to directly request the activation of the measure. I hope that the Member States will increase the funds for this programme in the next MFF and that the Commission will also decide to open up this funding to those forms of enterprise, such as social economy enterprises, which are currently excluded, by providing themselves with adequate human resources to streamline the disbursement procedures even further.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Harkin's report 'Activities, impacts and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014' and thank her for the detailed, in-depth and constructive preparation of the text. The fund itself is well-intentioned – but needs to be much better in many respects in order for it to work. That is what we have expressed in this report.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) makes an important contribution to reducing globalisation effects in the EU. The Fund should continue to focus on combating unemployment in the context of globalisation.  I also strongly support the report's call for closer cooperation between the relevant local, regional, national and European authorities in order to make access to the EGF faster and easier.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established in 2006 to help workers who have lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies as a result of globalisation, when such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. The EGF has under modifications such as reducing the number of redundancies in the intervention criteria from 1000 to 500. This means that the EGF is more accessible to regions and smaller Member States. Since 2013, self-employed and "ninis" have been included in eligible regions under the Youth Employment Initiative. The final report voted in committee, although not perfect, incorporates more progressive measures than the initial draft, including greater accessibility for veterans, women, young people and single mothers/parents. She recognizes that women are disproportionately affected by crisis and austerity. It also contains some positive points in increasing the participation of local authorities, social partners and civil society in the access, distribution and implementation of the EGF. We voted for it.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which examines the activities of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), its effects and the trends of the fund. Labour has consistently supported the EGF out of solidarity for workers across Europe and this report outlines the effectiveness of the fund for its beneficiaries.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. On the whole the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has provided personalised and well-coordinated measures for redundant workers. It is very important that there is genuine involvement of the workers or their representatives, the social partners and other relevant stakeholders in drawing up the application. As the fund is a flexibility instrument it allows for innovative action and tailor-made interventions.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this report, for which I was rapporteur, was to assess the activities, implementation and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) from 2007 to 2014 and to make recommendations on how the Fund could be made more effective and efficient based on our observations. The EGF is a small fund compared to the ESF and others but nonetheless has an important role to play in supporting and expressing solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of globalisation, a phenomenon we must grapple with increasingly.  The report examines issues such as what models used will deliver the best outcomes for redundant workers, timely and responsive intervention and implementation, value for money and efficient spending and data collection for qualitative and quantitative assessment. With the revision of the regulation the Fund has seen improvements such as the inclusion of self-employed persons and NEETs as potential beneficiaries, increased efforts to support entrepreneurship and the inclusion of the EGF in the SFC facility resulting in better coordination and data collection. Areas to be improved include the budget implementation rate of 55% and the limited impact on SMEs despite existing flexibility under Art. 4(2) which could be used.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I have no objections.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is basically EU dole money towards which British taxpayers are forced to pay. Where there has been a large and sudden loss of jobs in a region of a Member State, the government can apply for this EU funding which will be used for retraining and education of workers who have lost their jobs. This report looked at how the EGF performed between 2007 and 2014. The report of course says the EGF was a glowing success and calls for the programme to expand and have more resources to be dedicated to it. UKIP opposes the use of the EGF as British taxpayers shouldn’t be asked to pay for poor economic policies in other countries and by the EU.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support a European social model that offers strong social protection and dialogue. Although there are many elements that should be improved, I believe the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014 had great impact on the lives of hard-working citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Activity, Impact and Added Value Report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in 2007-2014, as this Fund is intended to support and express solidarity to workers made redundant by the economic crisis.  The EGF has been shown to have contributed to social cohesion as it has helped large groups of people in dire need of this assistance, which has had a positive impact on beneficiary families and the wider community. The new Regulation lays down new rules that will improve the efficiency of the Fund in the areas of funding, action and stricter timeframes and reporting. Only some of the expanded areas of application of the EGF are, for example, young people who are not in employment, school or training of these self-employed persons. With these new rules, the EGF should be able to respond even more effectively to any new global financial or economic crises.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is basically EU dole money towards which British taxpayers are forced to pay. Where there has been a large and sudden loss of jobs in a region of a Member State, the government can apply for this EU funding which will be used for retraining and education of workers who have lost their jobs. This report looked at how the EGF performed between 2007 and 2014. The report of course says the EGF was a glowing success and calls for the programme to expand and have more resources to be dedicated to it. UKIP opposes the use of the EGF as British taxpayers shouldn’t be asked to pay for poor economic policies in other countries and by the EU.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Harkin report on the activities, impacts and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) between 2007 and 2014. The report stresses that the EGF's interventions should be geared towards investments that contribute to growth and employment, education, skills and geographical mobility of workers, and be coordinated with existing EU programmes. Finally, it is important to remember that the WEF cannot in any way replace a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring; the importance of a genuine industrial policy at the European Union level should be stressed.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report is a very positive one in its approach, as it deals with the core European problem, namely effective job measures. The rapporteur is critical and detailed in her criticism and detail of the use of funds so far. The rapporteur also calls for an increase in the Fund's resources provided by the Member States, while at the same time being used more efficiently and for specific purposes. For these reasons, I agree with this request and the report.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aiming to reduce the negative effects of large-scale redundancies and following job losses can be seen as a valuable tool bringing European added value to ensure re-employment.  Some problems have occurred over the years and need further tackling. I welcome the efforts made to reduce the lengthy bureaucracy in processing the files by the European Commission. I welcome the shortened deadlines and clear timelines presented. The threshold of 500 is a step in the needed direction, but it still leaves smaller Member States where SMEs and bigger companies mostly do not reach this number out of the scope. Despite some possibilities to bypass this threshold, it should be further reviewed. Lastly, the re-employment rate is at 49% and 41% of re-employed individuals claim to be in worse conditions. This is a serious matter that the Member States jointly with the private sector and educational institutions need to find a better solution for. Efficient national measures must compliment the EGF to enable people to swiftly find a new job at a more or less same level.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which examines the activities of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), its effects and the trends of the fund. Labour has consistently supported the EGF out of solidarity for workers across Europe and this report outlines the effectiveness of the fund for its beneficiaries.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to support and express solidarity with workers made redundant as a result of major changes in world trade structures (over 500 persons per enterprise) and the EGF aims to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and promote sustainable employment by preparing and supporting redundant workers for a new job. As opposed to the European Social Fund, the co-financing rate is much lower (60%), with an average duration of 41 weeks (2013 figure) and an average grant of around EUR 4500 per person. Hungary has not taken advantage of this possibility, since mass redundancies took place almost exclusively before 2010, and the existing procedural rules are still not sufficiently flexible for our country. The shadow rapporteur for the report was Csaba Sógor, a Hungarian MEMBER from across the border, who contributed greatly to make the report more acceptable to the Fidesz-KDNP Group, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can be managed with a shamefully low envelope compared to EU GDP. The very intention of enabling solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade in the event of globalisation is correct. At the same time, practice shows that the fund's assets are actually used to mitigate the damage caused by the profit-making activities of large companies in the central countries, which is highly questionable. In my view, it should be used primarily in the less developed Member States, where, in addition to the globalisation effect, there is also the negative economic impact of stronger EU Member States.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The European Adjustment Fund was issued in 2006 to show solidarity with those who lost their jobs during structural changes in the world of trade, mostly due to the process of globalisation.  From 2013 onwards, the Fund was also extended to workers made redundant as a result of the financial and economic crisis. The report now wants to analyse the period from 2007 to 2014, so as to examine its results. Following this analysis, we have positively assessed its operation and recognised the important added value represented during these years of implementation, in terms of aid, support, recovery and training.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I support the action of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, which financially supports the reintegration into work of laid-off workers. Many French workers have benefited from this. I would remind you, however, that the Union is often responsible for the loss of their jobs because of its ultra-liberal policy.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The WEF instrument was put in place to compensate for the destructive effects of globalization on workers. Yet destroyed jobs are rarely replaced and, when they are, it is through jobs requiring other skills, addressing other profiles. Hence the problem of the international division of labour and deindustrialization. In most cases, young people are forced into mobility and the older ones are unemployed. Moreover, it is recognised that many regions or companies hit hard by globalisation are in fact victims of trade policies decided at EU level: free trade agreements, currently being negotiated or to come, are the main drivers of the massive loss of jobs in Europe. However, this fund is a way for French companies to recover a (small) share of the money that the Union takes from them. French agencies frequently benefit from these funds, which is why we support them. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people who lose their jobs as a result of significant structural changes in international trade patterns caused by globalisation. The report calls for more attention to be paid to the impact of trade policies and trade agreements on the European labour market and calls on the Commission to anticipate these effects by also taking into account information on applications to EGF.  It reiterates the request to the Commission to submit a proposal for a legal act on worker information and consultation, and to anticipate and manage corporate restructurings. It also highlights the importance of a social dialogue based on mutual trust and shared responsibility, as the best tool for finding consensus solutions and common views in the prediction, prevention and management of restructuring processes.  Finally, it calls on the Commission to ensure that redundancies are seen as a last resort after all possible alternatives have been considered without reducing the competitiveness of undertakings.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this because it is a balanced assessment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. On the basis that this fund cannot replace the economic and industrial policies necessary to maintain the productive fabric, this fund should be used to alleviate the immediate consequences of the closure of companies. The report includes numerous positive references regarding the role of trade unions, the impact that the crisis is having especially on women, the role that local authorities must also play, etc. It also calls on the committee for an ambitious evaluation and review of this fund to address the dramatic situation in the European economy. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation.  Periodically, evaluation reports have been made of the activities carried out in the following years of validity, with very positive results both in the persons served and in reintegration rates. This initiative report would now seek to make a more comprehensive assessment of the years 2007-2014. My country, Spain, is reasonably satisfied with the functioning of the Fund, because, as in other countries, it has been an important element in responding to the labour consequences of crises. For the reasons described above, I am my positive vote for the approval of this initiative.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The phrase "that an integrated cross-fund planning strategy would reduce the risk of industrial production shifting" is both cut from the socialist central planning brochure. I do not agree with the requirement that Member States 'collect data from a gender perspective' for projects of the European Globalisation Fund. It's just another extra bureaucracy.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is based on the values of freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, and combats social exclusion and discrimination. Women, especially pregnant women and mothers, are hardest hit by unemployment and are victims of negative employment discrimination. This report highlights the important role played by national equality authorities in implementing the Employment Equality Directive by raising awareness and collecting data, working with social partners and tackling non-reporting of discrimination cases. It is of utmost importance to continue to strengthen the role of national equality bodies, their impartiality, the development of activities and the increase in their capacity. I supported this report, because I believe that all working age people must have equal rights in employment and that we must systematically fight discrimination at all levels.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report’s call on the Commission and Member States to use the scope for implementing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund budget more flexibly and effectively, with the focus on outcomes, impact and value added. The application procedure should be made faster, and the Commission must assess the reasons for the low implementation rates and propose measures to address the existing bottlenecks and ensure optimal use of the fund.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to help employees who lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and structural change. The resources of this Fund shall be intended as a matter of priority for the implementation of measures to enable redundant workers to be reintegration into the labour market. Between 2007 and 2014, 20 Member States requested EUR 542.4 million in aid for 131 interventions for 121 380 workers. It takes an average of up to 41 weeks to decide on an application for assistance from the Fund, so it is necessary to adopt mechanisms to reduce this period. Aid from this fund is minimally used by small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up 99% of all EU businesses and employ more than 100 million people. It is therefore right that we ask the Commission and the Member States to focus aid also on SMEs and to take careful care to comply with the rules of this fund when reintegrating employees into the labour market. Timely provision of data will make it possible to better assess the effectiveness of the Fund.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 15/9/2016, and because this report is comprehensive and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. The WEF instrument was created to compensate for the harmful effects of globalization on workers, which we have long denounced. However, jobs destroyed are rarely replaced, and when they are, they are jobs requiring other skills, addressing other profiles, hence the problem of the international division of labour and deindustrialization.  In many cases, young people are forced into mobility and older people are unemployed. Moreover, it is recognised that many regions or companies hit hard by globalisation are in fact victims of trade policies decided at EU level: free trade agreements, currently being negotiated or to come, are the main drivers of massive job losses in Europe.  However, this fund is a way for French companies to recover a (small) share of the money that the Union takes from them. French agencies frequently benefit from these funds, which is why we are voting for this text.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014 because, once again, I am a firm supporter of the principles of gender equality and non-discrimination, which are among the Union’s core values and which need to be safeguarded and promoted. Aside from that, I consider that EU citizens should have access to training and retraining, job-search assistance, mentoring, entrepreneurship promotion, and business start-ups. I also want to highlight the importance of favourable working conditions, including decent working wages.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This report has good approaches to job measures, but there is a need to increase national funding for the Fund. That is why I am abstaining.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report assessing the activities of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The aim of the EGF is to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report takes stock of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund over the period 2007-2014. This fund provides financial assistance to employees who have been made redundant as a result of "major changes in the structure of international trade", whether they are SMEs undergoing austerity European policy or large companies taking advantage of the windfall to relocate to low-wage countries. The report readily acknowledges that this is a dressing on a wooden leg: "the EGF cannot in any way replace a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring." It supports targeted aid primarily to cooperatives, SMEs and subcontractors, older workers and young people, but struggles to get to the bottom of the problem: the Union's trade and industrial policy. In the face of international competition, it calls for "favourable conditions for the relocation of industrial production to the EU". We must go to the end of this thinking and impose ecological and social protectionism at the borders. And get out of austerity to revive activity. Otherwise the Alstom and Caterpillar cases will continue to multiply. Faced with this shyness, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The WEF instrument was put in place to compensate for the destructive effects of globalization on workers. However, jobs destroyed are rarely replaced and, when they are, it is through jobs requiring other skills, addressing other profiles, hence the problem of the international division of labour and deindustrialization. In most cases, young people are forced into mobility and the older ones are unemployed. Moreover, it is recognised that many regions or companies hit hard by globalisation are in fact victims of trade policies decided at EU level: free trade agreements, currently being negotiated or to come, are the main drivers of massive job losses in Europe. However, this fund is a way for French companies to recover a (small) share of the money that the Union takes from them. French agencies frequently benefit from these funds, which is why we support them. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support and express the EU's solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The objective of the EGF is to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and to the promotion of sustainable employment by preparing the unemployed for a new job and providing them with support in this context. We must continue to improve this important mechanism to mitigate the adverse effects of unemployment. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the ways in which the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was used and improved between 2007 and 2014. I fully supported this fund as it is essential that the Union does its utmost to alleviate the situation of workers who have been made redundant due to global market forces, and to get them back into the workforce.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. At a time when the events that are known are hitting Caterpillar, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is making sense. This is a real help for people who have lost their jobs so that they can revert to other growth areas. But the Union's social action must not stop there. The Commission will need to better anticipate and carry out impact assessments by highlighting potential business effects such as Caterpillar's on employment and competitiveness, as well as by shedding light on the consequences for SMEs. The Fund will not replace a real policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring. The European Social Fund and the Juncker Plan must therefore come directly to complement the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to ensure the sustainability of European industrial activity.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up between 2007 and 2014 to provide solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs during large-scale redundancies due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, where these redundancies have a significant adverse impact on the regional and local economies. Since its establishment in 2006, the Fund has undergone several reforms, reducing the criterion of intervention from 1 000 redundancies to 500, making it more accessible to regions and smaller Member States. The scope of the Fund was extended in 2013 to include workers who lost their jobs as a result of the global economic crisis, in addition to the self-employed. The report on the fund's activities, impact and added value revealed a number of shortcomings. One of the reservations about the EGF is that some Member States have used substantial EGF funds to compensate for national schemes to support workers' incomes, and such use of European funds does not bring added value. Another shortcoming is awareness, the Fund suffers from a lack of awareness on the part of some Member States, social partners and businesses; I am speaking in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014 because the EGF is a European instrument providing direct support to workers who have lost their job as a consequence of changes in trade patterns and globalisation. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The WEF instrument was put in place to compensate for the destructive effects of globalization on workers. Yet jobs destroyed are rarely replaced by new ones, and affected areas are already experiencing a difficult job market. In most cases, young people are forced into mobility and older people are unemployed. Moreover, it is recognised that many regions or companies hit hard by globalisation are in fact victims of trade policies decided at EUROPEAN Union level: free trade agreements, currently being negotiated or to come, are the main drivers of massive job losses in Europe. On the text itself, I abstain.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report which examines the activities of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), its effects and the trends of the fund. Labour has consistently supported the EGF out of solidarity for workers across Europe and this report outlines the effectiveness of the fund for its beneficiaries.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the activities, impacts and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. The fund is used to support employees who have been made redundant due to major changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalization, due to the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis, or due to a new global financial and economic crisis.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. This fund was originally created to set in motion solidarity with workers who lost their jobs in large-scale layoffs due to major changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalization, where these layoffs have a negative impact on the regional and local economy, and was expanded in 2013 to include employees dismissed due to global economic and financial crises. The report examined 2007-2014 figures to identify the strengths and weaknesses of the Fund's reforms, with the aim of eventually approving a renewal of the fund for the current programming period.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 To make the most of the great opportunities offered by globalization, you must first know how to mitigate the effects. That is why we welcome the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014.  The Fund has shown itself to be an important instrument of solidarity for workers who are victims of mass redundancies caused by structural changes in world trade, through assistance, retraining and reintegration activities, as well as the promotion of business activity. In addition, the report puts in black and white the need to pay attention to the impacts of trade policies and agreements on the European labour market, as well as to stress the importance of social dialogue and to urge the Commission to ensure that job losses only take place as a last resort.  The response to globalisation cannot and must not be seen as an attitude of mistrust and closure, but must be seen as a great opportunity that needs active adaptation in order to reap the benefits, while maintaining as strong points of reference the achievements of the European social model and the protection of workers.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes in the world trade patterns due to globalisation. I have voted for this report that highlights the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that this report looks objectively at the situation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) and how it was used between 2007 and 2014. At the same time, the report draws attention to the problems that have arisen in the use of the EGF by Member States, such as poor information, the impossibility of pre-financing, and long periods of approval. I believe that the proposals made in this report are beneficial to the future of the EGF and will help to improve its use. In this context, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This was generally a good report and I voted in favour. My Sinn Féin colleague was involved as negotiator at the Committee level where she proposed amendments aiming to increase transparency in the EGF process, increase the focus on reaching out to young people not in education, employment or training, and ensure that the funds do not get returned to the Commission unspent due to slow implementation or incompetence by national authorities. Overall the EGF as a fund helps workers when they are in need of help having been made redundant because they are the victims of deindustrialisation, globalisation, or the financial crisis, therefore we supported it.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained from this report because, although it has good approaches to job measures and job creation, it also calls for an increase in national funding for the Fund.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EGF is important for redundancies who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic downturn. Activities financed by the Fund will help unemployed people to return to the labour market through an individualised and flexible approach.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is basically EU dole money towards which British taxpayers are forced to pay. Where there has been a large and sudden loss of jobs in a region of a Member State, the government can apply for this EU funding which will be used for retraining and education of workers who have lost their jobs. This report looked at how the EGF performed between 2007 and 2014. The report of course says the EGF was a glowing success and calls for the programme to expand and have more resources to be dedicated to it. UKIP opposes the use of the EGF as British taxpayers shouldn’t be asked to pay for poor economic policies in other countries and by the EU.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur and confirm that I would give my positive opinion on the report.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Initially the EGF was established by Regulation EC No 1927/2006 to allow solidarity with workers who lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies because of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, where these redundancies have a significant adverse impact on the regional or local economy. I voted in favour, as the key aims of the report are directed towards examination of the results in the period 2007 – 2014, as well as identifying the weak and strong sides of the reforms of EGF. Such assessment is needed as it could adjust the use of the Fund for the current programming period.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒This resolution first has in mind the consequences of globalisation which has caused major structural changes in world trade flows. This was the original reason why the EGF was founded. Later, the scope of the EGF was also extended for those workers made redundant as a result of the general financial and economic crisis in 2009-2011.  Today, the EGF's main objective is to contribute to smart, inclusive and sustainable economic growth and to foster sustainable employment, which I agree with. In addition, I support the resolution because it adopts many constructive provisions that bear a very strong stamp of social sensitivity, which I particularly welcome. The resolution also places strong emphasis on SMEs.   They account for 85% of all businesses in the EU. As currently the EGF has a very limited impact on SMEs, despite the obvious fact that it can finance SMEs very much, the resolution calls for measures to be taken to make it easier to finance. Parliament calls on Member States to proactively support redundant workers in SMEs.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The WEF instrument was put in place to compensate for the destructive effects of globalization on workers. Yet jobs destroyed are rarely replaced by new jobs, and affected areas are already experiencing a difficult job market. In most cases, young people are forced into mobility and the older ones are unemployed. Moreover, it is recognised that many regions or companies hit hard by globalisation are in fact victims of trade policies decided at EU level: free trade agreements, currently being negotiated or to come, are the main drivers of massive job losses in Europe. Nevertheless, pending the implementation of a smart economic policy, it remains an indispensable relief for businesses and employees. In these circumstances, I therefore vote for the report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that provides direct support to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in international trade relations and due to the process of globalisation. Over time, the criteria for accessing this support have expanded to include workers excluded from the world of production as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. This report analyses the fund's activity, impact and added value between 2007 and 2014.  The S&D Group managed to include a number of priorities and recommendations that greatly improved the text. These include the need to pay more attention to the consequences of trade policies and agreements on the European labour market; the appeal to the Commission to ensure that there is an adequate staff for the management of the Fund, so as to avoid delays in the conduct of the files; the call for greater importance to be attached to social dialogue in the event of corporate restructuring. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to show solidarity with workers who lost their jobs in cases of mass redundancies due to labour surpluses, which had an impact on the regional or local economy. The financing of all eligible actions is conditional on the active participation of beneficiaries in job search or training.  European added value is one of the measures that distinguishES EGF interventions from member states' interventions. The reform of the fund has made it possible to use EGF funds for self-employed people who are neither in school nor in training. The proper use of EGF measures, the balanced and fair allocation of resources to all Member States within an appropriate time limit can help reduce unemployment levels and ensure a stable labour market, so I supported the report.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 Globalisation, on the one hand, makes it much easier for us, citizens and businesses, on the one hand, to operate in an increasingly interconnected world where so-called nothing is too far away. However, there are also downsides to this process and we are seeing it every day. That is why I voted in favour of the report on the functioning of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The Fund provides much-needed support in the form of assistance and training in the search for a new job in the event that workers are made victims of redundancies as part of structural changes and business relocations outside the Union. I am glad that the Fund has been able to cover up to 134 cases in 20 Member States in recent years.  In view of the European Commission's ambitions, I supported greater attention to European trade policy, disputes and their consequences. In this respect, I also supported shortening the deadline for approving applications, which currently averages an incredible 303 days. It is absolutely necessary to reduce this period, otherwise we will not be able to achieve the desired result of maintaining an acceptable standard of living for European workers working in risky industrial production. The European Union and the Member States must ensure that citizens' living conditions do not deteriorate. On the contrary, it must promote a European social model based on the principles of social security, quality public services and social dialogue.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EGF has undergone a number of changes since 2006. These include reducing the intervention criteria from 1000 redundancies to 500 redundancies. This means that the EGF is more accessible to regions and smaller Member States. There were proposals to further reduce the number of redundancies, which was strongly opposed. The intervention period has been extended from 12 to 24 months.  The EGF is an emergency fund and remains outside the multiannual financial framework. A reserve has been created from which annual funds can be collected for the fund. The annual appropriations for the EGF in the EU budget have been reduced from EUR 500 million per year in 2007 to EUR 150 million in the current Regulation. The average amount allocated over 8 years (2007-2014) was EUR 70 million per year. The co-financing rate was initially 50 %, then raised to 65 % between 2009 and 2011, reduced again to 50 % in 2012-2013 and raised to 60 % in the 2013 Regulation for the period 2014-2020.  Eligible actions include personalised training for the acquisition of new qualifications and retraining, job search assistance, mentoring, promotion of entrepreneurship, assistance in self-employment, start-up and take-over of activities by employees, and allowances for transfer costs, subsistence costs or training allowances. I therefore supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to help workers who have been victims of mass layoffs, including social plans initiated in some large companies. On numerous occasions during the year, the European Parliament provides financial assistance under this fund to people who have lost their jobs, for example to accompany them in training or retraining. I voted for this report, which takes stock of the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014, identifying its strengths and weaknesses, in order to strengthen its effectiveness in the current programming period (2014-2020).

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to analyse the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) between 2007 and 2014 and to identify the importance and effectiveness of the reforms implemented in that same period. Created with the aim of enabling solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs at large-scale redundancies due to major structural changes in global trade patterns arising from globalisation, the EGF is an emergency instrument and is not covered by the Multiannual Financial Framework. Between 2007 and 2014, the functioning of the EGF underwent some changes, which would highlight the decrease in the number of workers needed for the possibility of recourse to the fund (today, 500 employees) and the increase in the budget of this mechanism. The use of support through the EGF requires the submission by Member States of a final report on the implementation of the fund, including statistics on the reintegration of assisted workers. I support this report, because I value the increase in capacity and action of the EGF, identifying this solidarity fund as an indispensable tool for the protection of European workers, in a social environment where unemployment is one of the problems that need to be given a European response to Europeans.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, own-initiative report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is basically EU dole money towards which British taxpayers are forced to pay. Where there has been a large and sudden loss of jobs in a region of a Member State, the government can apply for this EU funding which will be used for retraining and education of workers who have lost their jobs. This report looked at how the EGF performed between 2007 and 2014. The report of course says the EGF was a glowing success and calls for the programme to expand and have more resources to be dedicated to it. UKIP opposes the use of the EGF as British taxpayers shouldn’t be asked to pay for poor economic policies in other countries and by the EU.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because I consider the protection of workers that this fund tries to guarantee fundamental. I believe it is imperative to be sympathetic to workers, sometimes even families, who have lost their jobs at large-scale redundancies due to major structural changes in world trade patterns arising from globalisation or crises. The EGF provides personalized, individualised and intensive support to laid-off workers and in many cases gives positive results, including a positive psychological impact, greater adaptability and labour market flexibility. In addition, the data show that the EGF has contributed to social cohesion by helping large groups of people who were in urgent need of assistance. This action had positive repercussions for the families of the beneficiaries and the community at large.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to help laid-off workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns. The EGF was designed to deal with emergencies through rapid intervention and short-term assistance in response to serious and unforeseen labour market difficulties involving large-scale redundancies. This report, which examines the activities, impact and added value of the EGF between 2007 and 2014, sets out a set of recommendations to improve the functioning of the fund. Among other aspects, it calls for more attention to the impact of trade policies and trade agreements on the European labour market and calls on the Commission to anticipate these effects; measures are called for the benefit of SMEs, social economy enterprises and cooperatives, as well as the importance of social dialogue based on mutual trust and shared responsibility, as the best tool for finding consensus solutions and common views in the prediction, prevention and management of restructuring processes.  For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the activities, impacts and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014.  Let us be clear, this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund cannot in any way replace a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring. As such, I am always advocating for a genuine industrial policy at European level. The recent announcement of the intention to close the Caterpillar plant in Gosselies reminds us that the road to re-industrialization is still long and requires real political will, to be translated into legislation now! With regard to the evaluation of this fund, I am concerned that the EGF has had very limited effects on SMEs. The Commission needs to further reorient the EGF for the benefit of SMEs by making greater use of the exemption from the eligibility threshold.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Having initially been set up to enable solidarity with workers made redundant by structural changes in world trade patterns, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was subsequently extended to include workers made redundant in the wake of the financial and global crisis, including self-employed workers.  Also with regard to eligible actions, funding and beneficiaries, there was an extension of the scope in this period 2007-2014, encompassing the most disadvantaged people, the elderly and young unemployed, within a longer period of use of finance - 24 months - and, consequently, increasing the number of beneficiaries reinstated in the labour market.  As evidenced in the report - which I voted in favour of, I also highlight the fact that the intervention criterion for recourse to the fund has been reduced from 1 000 to 500 redundant workers, which has made applications by smaller regions and Member States more accessible, thus contributing to greater economic, social and territorial cohesion. As a negative aspect, just a call for attention to the slowness in the process of approving and allocating the Fund, which should be reviewed in the future, so that the implementation of the measures can be faster and, consequently, more effective.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was launched in 2007 and aims to reconcile the long-term overall benefits of trade liberalization for growth and employment with the potential negative effects of globalisation in the short term, particularly on the employment of the most vulnerable and least skilled workers. Reports show that by the end of the WEF implementation period, 7,656 workers, or 44.9% of the 18,848 workers who received the Fund's assistance, had returned to work or were self-employed. The Union must continue its actions to improve these figures and promote employment and training. I voted in favour of this report, which assesses the functioning of the WEF and calls on the Commission and the Member States to use the more flexible and effective implementation possibilities for the EGF budget. It is important that a distinction be made between the two main types of measures of the WEF, namely active measures in the labour market and income assistance for workers.  The EGF is an important European tool that provides concrete aid for employment and training.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established in 2006 to help workers who have lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies as a result of globalisation, when such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. The EGF has under modifications such as reducing the number of redundancies in the intervention criteria from 1000 to 500. This means that the EGF is more accessible to regions and smaller Member States. Since 2013, self-employed and "ninis" have been included in eligible regions under the Youth Employment Initiative. The final report voted in committee, although not perfect, incorporates more progressive measures than the initial draft, including greater accessibility for veterans, women, young people and single mothers/parents. She recognizes that women are disproportionately affected by crisis and austerity. It also contains some positive points in increasing the participation of local authorities, social partners and civil society in the access, distribution and implementation of the EGF. We voted for it.

name: Sven SCHULZE
