text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the activities, impacts and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It was set up to show solidarity with the workers who have lost their jobs as a result of large-scale production and globalisation processes, or with the regions which have lost their economic strength as a result. The report looks at the results of the 2007-2014 period and analyses the strengths and weaknesses of the Fund in order to highlight its effectiveness and importance.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a clear indication of protectionism. Over the last century, it is hard to find systematic evidence for the benefits of protectionism. I firmly believe that fair competence in a context of free markets is the most suitable way to produce wealth for all. I have exceptionally accepted the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as an emergency measure at time of deep economic crisis. But this time it is meant to be more short-term in its approach, causing a negative impact.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this because it is a balanced assessment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. On the basis that this fund cannot replace the economic and industrial policies necessary to maintain the productive fabric, this fund should be used to alleviate the immediate consequences of the closure of companies. The report includes numerous positive references regarding the role of trade unions, the impact that the crisis is having especially on women, the role that local authorities must also play, etc. It also calls on the committee for an ambitious evaluation and review of this fund to address the dramatic situation in the European economy. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which examines the activities of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), its effects and the trends of the fund. Labour has consistently supported the EGF out of solidarity for workers across Europe and this report outlines the effectiveness of the fund for its beneficiaries

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: In writing ‒ the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support and express solidarity with workers made redundant due to major structural changes in global trade. The EGF aims to promote sustainable employment by preparing redundant workers for new jobs and was set up to deal with emergencies by providing rapid intervention and short-term assistance in response to urgent and unforeseen labour market problems involving large-scale redundancies. The report clearly shows that there is a need to increase the use of the EGF by supporting demand from Member States, which will require an increase in its funding and an increase in the EU co-financing rate. It is detrimental that the Commission's report did not complete the analysis of beneficiaries by region, which would show how the EGF is used in individual regions of the Member States. For this reason, we have asked the Commission to also provide in its next report information on the type and quality of jobs found by people reintegred into the labour market.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. \u2012 Marian Harkin's initiative report looks at the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) between 2007 and 2014. This European Fund was set up to support workers who are made redundant as a result of major unforeseen structural changes in the labour market as a result of world trade. This fund can be relied upon by the Member States for at least 500 redundancies and has a total budget of EUR 150 million per year to co-finance up to 60 % of the costs. Between 2007 and 2014, there were 134 applications from 20 Member States, representing 122 121 workers affected. The report wants the European Commission to anticipate the effects of trade agreements on the labour market and to increase coordination between trade and employment services. This meagre fund should not be seen as a social safety net to push through bad future trade agreements with a negative impact on employment. In addition, Member States should use these funds in their services to laid-off workers in order to promote a resource-efficient and sustainable economy. The Fund may not relieve Member States of their obligations to the workers made redundant. These are all recommendations that put the employee's interest first. That's why I'm voting for it.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of the instruments by which the European economy is coping with a decline in its competitiveness. Its purpose is to provide means for retraining and further application of dismissed employees. It is a pity that Slovakia has not yet made use of this possibility, even in justified cases.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I accept the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in 2007-2014, as the purpose of the European Fund itself is to express solidarity with persons, i.e. workers made redundant by changes in world trade.  I also consider it necessary to have some kind of European legal framework on informing and consulting workers in the event of job loss, which would work in such a way as to succeed and assist them in situations where it is even possible to anticipate and stop job losses.  It is essential to have a well-developed system of industrial relations according to which the rights of workers and their representatives could be accurately regulated, in relation to consultations and information. Tackling the unemployment crisis, protection in jobs should be made the basis of EU policy, as shown by the unemployment rates themselves.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the activities, impacts and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support and show solidarity with workers who have become unemployed as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. It is intended to provide assistance in urgent cases by enabling rapid intervention and short-term assistance in the event of unforeseen difficulties in the labour market, which involve large-scale redundancies. The EGF does not need to be improved or assessed in any way. The EGF must be stamped and abolished. There is probably no EU instrument that seeks to halt economic change in a similar way to the EGF, violating market principles.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 The purpose of establishing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to support and express solidarity with workers made redundant by significant structural changes, and in recent years restructuring has become more frequent.  The reinterment of beneficiaries of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be more successful if it results in quality employment. The minimum labour surplus threshold of 1 000 workers has been reduced to 500, but the EGF may be applied in exceptional circumstances if redundancies affect employment and the local, regional or national economy. The co-financing rate was 60%, while the original was 50%. I support the Activity, Impact and Added Value Report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in 2007-2014, as I believe that the measures outlined there are well developed and will contribute to a better overall functioning of the Fund.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014.  I support the initiative of the Committee on Budgets, which notes that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can support or complement member states' actions in the field of employment and social policy, but cannot replace the basic measures and competences of the national authorities and should therefore not replace national schemes for workers' incomes.  It also recalls that Member States are responsible for co-financing EGF actions in accordance with the provisions of national law and are obliged to implement the EGF budget effectively.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the experience of the operation of the European Globalisation Fund in 2007-14. The Fund was set up 10 years ago as an emergency instrument outside the EU's multiannual financial framework, primarily to support European workers, small and medium-sized enterprises who have lost their jobs as a result of the reorganisation of international economic and trade relations. In my experience, there is still a current need for job creation, retraining and business support, but the knowledge of the instrument, the attitude of some Member States to it and the use of available resources are not yet satisfactory. I trust that the findings and corrective proposals of the adopted report will also contribute to better exploiting the potential of this important EU fund in the future, in particular to create new real Jobs in Europe.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that provides direct support to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and changes in trade. This report carefully analyses the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. In this context, I believe that we should continue measures for a Europe to improve living conditions and promote a European social model, which aims at strong social protection, quality public services and social dialogue.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Initially, financial assistance was intended for "active labour market measures that are part of a coordinated package of personalized services aimed at the reintegration of workers who have lost their jobs." In the 2013 Regulation, this scope was broadened to include "reintegration into the wage or unpaid labour market in particular, of the disadvantaged unemployed, elderly or young".  Eligible actions include tailor-made training and retraining, job search assistance, sponsorship, entrepreneurship promotion, self-employment assistance, business start-ups and takeovers by employees, as well as mobility allowances, living or training allowances.  Funding for all eligible actions is contingent on the active participation of targeted beneficiaries in job-seeking or training activities. In addition, actions that fall within the responsibility of companies under national law or collective agreements, as well as passive social protection measures, cannot be financed.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to support workers who had lost their jobs as a result of the adverse effects of globalisation. It was later broadened to support workers suffering from the global and financial crisis, as well as to self-employed and youth. Since its creation, the Fund has successfully helped put 49% of workers back to work and provided them with tailored support, which is why I voted in favour of extending the funding period from one to two years. It is important that the Fund is carefully coordinated with other EU programmes, that its budget is spent efficiently, and that it focuses more on workers in SMEs, upon which the impact has remained limited until now.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted abstained on the Activity, Impact and Added Value Report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in 2007-2014. While the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and foster sustainable employment, I believe that retraining workers is insufficient to preserve jobs.  I am of the opinion that the current measures provided by this Fund do not contribute to the maintenance of jobs and the competitiveness of the Economy of the European Union. Only long-term measures, such as cutting red tape and high taxes, can help the Economy of the European Union and reducing unemployment.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014.  The Fund was designed to address emergencies through rapid intervention and short-term assistance in response to serious and unforeseen problems in the labour market. The aim is to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth and to promote sustainable employment by supporting redundant workers and preparing them for a new job.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established in 2006 to help workers who have lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies as a result of globalisation, when such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. The EGF has under modifications such as reducing the number of redundancies in the intervention criteria from 1000 to 500. This means that the EGF is more accessible to regions and smaller Member States. Since 2013, self-employed and "ninis" have been included in eligible regions under the Youth Employment Initiative. The final report voted in committee, although not perfect, incorporates more progressive measures than the initial draft, including greater accessibility for veterans, women, young people and single mothers/parents. She recognizes that women are disproportionately affected by crisis and austerity. It also contains some positive points in increasing the participation of local authorities, social partners and civil society in the access, distribution and implementation of the EGF. We voted for it.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The WEF instrument was put in place to compensate for the destructive effects of globalization on workers. Yet jobs destroyed are rarely replaced by new jobs, and affected areas are already experiencing a difficult job market. In most cases, young people are forced into mobility and older people are unemployed. Moreover, it is recognised that many regions or companies hit hard by globalisation are in fact victims of trade policies decided at EU level: free trade agreements being negotiated or to come are the main drivers of the massive loss of jobs in Europe. However, this fund is one way to get our money back. I voted for it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EGF is a key instrument for mitigating the negative effects of mass redundancies, globalisation, labour market and trade developments. Support should continue to be involved in re-employment, re-qualification, adaptation to labour supply. Good reporting should be ensured in order to continuously monitor the progress of Member States receiving assistance from the Fund in order to be able to match funding to the sectors most in need. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The role of the EGF is to enable solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade trade as a result of globalisation, in cases where such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. I supported the report in the final vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established in 2006 to help workers who have lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies as a result of globalisation, when such redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy. The EGF has under modifications such as reducing the number of redundancies in the intervention criteria from 1000 to 500. This means that the EGF is more accessible to regions and smaller Member States. Since 2013, self-employed and "ninis" have been included in eligible regions under the Youth Employment Initiative. The final report voted in committee, although not perfect, incorporates more progressive measures than the initial draft, including greater accessibility for veterans, women, young people and single mothers/parents. She recognizes that women are disproportionately affected by crisis and austerity. It also contains some positive points in increasing the participation of local authorities, social partners and civil society in the access, distribution and implementation of the EGF. We voted for it.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the Globalisation Fund can be an efficient rapid intervention tool in cases of mass redundancies if used for personalised and active labour market measures. It cannot, however, be considered a solution to clean up disastrous trade deals or non-existent restructuring policies.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that many beneficiaries of the EGF have been able, in particular, to obtain personal help in finding work, to update their skills in vocational training programmes and to benefit from mobility benefits; I also welcome the fact that the EGF has given some employees the opportunity to start their own business by providing aid to start-ups or takeovers; I stress, therefore, that the EGF has been found to have had a significant positive impact on self-esteem, a sense of empowerment and motivation; I stress that egf support has increased social cohesion by enabling people to re-enter employment and avoid the negative effects of unemployment.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support for, and express its solidarity with, workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The report emphasises the relevance of strong social dialogue based on mutual trust and shared responsibility as the best instrument with which to seek consensual solutions and common outlooks when predicting, preventing and managing restructuring processes. Furthermore, it highlights that this would help to prevent job losses and therefore EGF cases. I voted in favour because I believe that the current EGF aims not only to support redundant workers but also to demonstrate solidarity towards those workers.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report which examines the activities of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), its effects and the trends of the fund. Labour has consistently supported the EGF out of solidarity for workers across Europe and this report outlines the effectiveness of the fund for its beneficiaries.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This assessment of the "globalisation adjustment" fund denounces the fact that more and more cases dealt with by the eu-fund are linked to the restructuring of large companies. However, for me, it is not permissible for public money to be used to finance return-to-work measures as a result of redundancies whose sole reason is to increase the profits of the companies concerned and the dividends of their shareholders. I remain reserved on the overall logic of this fund, which only reimburses the States a significant part of the financing of restructurings and even often relocations that they did not know or wanted to prevent. One never wonders whether these social plans could have been avoided or whether the unions were actually consulted, nor is it a question of whether the employees concerned have found a job. So I chose to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is a palliative measure, the aim of which is to compensate for the weakest link in neoliberal and austerity policies – workers – pushed into unemployment and precariousness.  We believe that the EGF cannot be used to replace the obligations of companies and Member States in relation to their employees.  It is said, however, that the character of an emergency support fund – in this case social – deserves our approval. Similarly, all the proposed transfers to the European Parliament under these funds have also been approved with our support. Considering that the report takes a realistic view of this period, the vote in favour is proposed.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report is positive in its approach to job measures. The waste of resources is also criticised. However, the Funds of the Fund are to be increased by the States and, in addition, support for persons with a migrant background will be considered. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the activity, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support for people who lose their jobs as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. In addition, the scope of the Fund has been expanded to include workers made redundant due to the global financial and economic crisis of 2009-2011 and, to this end, has been further expanded to include self-employed workers affected by the crisis between 2014 and 2020. It is important for the European Union to do more and more to help workers in difficulty.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report which examines the activities of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), its effects and the trends of the fund. Labour has consistently supported the EGF out of solidarity for workers across Europe and this report outlines the effectiveness of the fund for its beneficiaries. It particularly highlights the view to see the EGF used to its full potential, by calling for it to complement other available instruments and seek consultation of major stakeholders. Social solidarity is a core value of the European Union, and the EGF is an expression of such solidarity. It is an instrument that allows the EU to democratise globalisation, and minimise damage to communities that may be caused by international trade. It is the EU that often steps in when national governments fail to do so.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade, caused by globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis. Periodically, evaluation reports have been made on the activities carried out in successive years of validity, with very positive results both in the persons served and in reintegration rates. The idea is to make a more comprehensive evaluation of the years 2007-2014. I am voting in favour of this report, as Spain is reasonably satisfied with the functioning of this Fund in our country.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Harkin report very realistically summarised the information on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which was originally set up as an expression of solidarity with employees who lost their jobs in collective redundancies as a result of globalisation changes in world trade. The framework of this fund was extended in 2009-2011 and beyond after 2013. Although it is generally the case that people who lose their jobs need to be helped, it is also necessary to monitor whether the money spent is delivering results, whether it has helped redundant workers to re-employ themselves and whether these funds could be used in a different way with greater success. It is also necessary to think about how to help not only large enterprises, but also small and medium-sized enterprises, which are also significantly affected by global change. However, this report notes that there are insufficient data to comprehensively assess the added value of the Fund, that the re-employment assessment is not set up correctly and there are no statistics on what employment and what quality redundant workers have managed to find. That is why I believe that, in order to properly assess the contribution of this fund, we will have to gather even more relevant data and encourage all institutions to cooperate as effectively as possible.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Harkin report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) between 2007 and 2014, as I consider it imperative to support and express the EU's solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade standards.  I believe that there should be greater flexibility in the eligibility thresholds, especially for SMEs, as the EGF has focused on large enterprises, so its impact on SMEs has been very limited. I would remind you that the objective of the EGF is to contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and to the promotion of sustainable employment by preparing the unemployed for a new job and providing them with support in this context.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ I supported the motion for a resolution on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. Restructuring has become an increasingly general phenomenon over the last few years, which has intensified in some sectors and expanded into others. I therefore support the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which provides support to workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade flows, contributes to smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth and promotes sustainable employment by supporting redundant workers and preparing them for new jobs.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Madam President, this morning, during the debates on the Weber report on the application of the Equality in Employment Directive, I was unable to finish my speech because I was cut off by Mr Lavrilleux's false comments. While I welcomed the Union's desire to end discrimination and promote pluralism, I saw fit to point out that the elected representatives of the ENF group, of which I am a member, are themselves regularly the victims of manoeuvres by their EuroLat colleagues in the European Parliament, in the Committee on Culture and Education. Our amendments are constantly censored, even when they correspond to the policy guidelines sought by the majority groups. Jérôme Lavrilleux allowed himself to cut me off, deeming that the elected representatives of the ENF group were not discriminated against. It touched me deeply and as a result, as the regulations say, I was unable to complete my intervention because I had exceeded the legal time, when nothing was said against Mr Lavrilleux who was able to interrupt me without a reminder to order. With my head held high and my hands clean, I have no lessons to learn from a man whose probity can be questioned, especially in France, since at this time we are all waiting for the end of the Bygmalion case which implicates him. I wanted to explain that, thank you for leaving me that opportunity, Madam President.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Auteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I know that the Commissioner is late – not through his fault – but I am sure he will join us in concluding our speeches.  First of all, however, I would like to express, on behalf of the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Common Security and Control, our full opposition to the fact that this debate, in accordance with our initial request, should have taken place at a much better time this week. It had not been possible and we had agreed on the first week of October. It is by no means fair that on Monday, without notifying the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Common Security and Control, nor myself, it was decided by the Presidency to propose another agenda which sees our debate brought forward to Thursday afternoon, not allowing many colleagues in the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Common Security and Control, as they would have liked, to participate. I have a duty to say this, because this must not happen again.  I would also like to say, going into the substance, that we are precisely in The European Week of Sport, the second edition after last year's. I would like to remind you that we inaugurated it with Commissioner Navracsics and the Slovak Presidency on 10 September in Košice, and it has reached an important stage because it is becoming an important event for young people, associations, all European sportsmen and women, but also for those involved not only in sports activities but also in physical and amateur activities. It is also interesting to see how the motto "Be active" suitably chosen, has been activated in many forms in European cities, starting from those involved in the beautiful experience of European capitals and cities of sport.  We agree with the Commissioner's announcement that the date of the European week should be moved forward from next year in order to involve schools more and provide greater organisational capacity, but he will have to take more advantage of the European fact of this initiative, and therefore its transborder character, by accustoming European citizens to do so with national flags, but also with European flags, as Elisa Di Francisca has effectively done. , in Rio, in the Olympics.  In this spirit, we have promoted many initiatives, including one here in Strasbourg, the exhibition 'Run for art', and then in September, on the 27th, there will be a conference promoted with many colleagues, including preparing the report of Mr Takkula's Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Common Security and Reformist Party on the universal language of sport. A language that these days is giving us extraordinary emotions in the Paralympic Games in Rio, with young people asking to be seen as athletes, and not as disabled, and with the victory of gold medals, yesterday, of great athletes, including Alex Zanardi.  Unfortunately, however, there is also the downside, there is a dark side to sport that Parliament has already addressed in the first Fisas report in 2011 and which we now want to address together with the issue of good governance, integrity and also accessibility in the Takkula report. We know that the manipulation of sporting events, linked to illegal betting, which is increasingly taking place online, is manifesting itself in scandals that have mainly affected football – but unfortunately not only, for example tennis and other sports – and constitute a real threat to the integrity, fair competition and credibility of national and European sport.  I would remind you that in December 2012 the Committee on Culture organised a public hearing on this very issue, on combating rigged meetings and on financial fair play, and in March 2013 it also adopted a resolution on the subject. I am delighted that in the same year the Council of Ministers authorised the European Commission – and this is an important turning point in the Treaty of Lisbon – to participate on behalf of the European Union in the negotiations that then went ahead with a process that led to the proposal to ratify the Council of Europe Convention against the Manipulation of Sports Competitions, which was opened in 2014 to the signature of individual Member States.  What are we asking for in our question? We call on the Commission to overcome these last difficulties, which prevent us from reaching all the Member States that sign and ratify this important Convention, and above all that we take those steps on the part of everyone – I very much hope in the Slovak Presidency, but also in the next Maltese Presidency, which is directly concerned – so that we really do not want to achieve harmonisation. , but at least to common rules that allow, in the face of what is now a transborder crime, which goes beyond both the national countries, the nation states and Europe itself, to be able to take joint initiatives, because that is now the dimension and we absolutely must be able to meet this challenge by promoting common education programmes. , prevention, investigation, punishing with harmonised rules criminal affairs – a real black economy – and the crimes that created this completely illegal illicit betting market.  I therefore believe that at this point it is also necessary to harmonise the rules of the gaming industry, which are one of the factors that is contrary to the fact that some countries are party to this Convention. This step must be taken. In conclusion, any action that the Commissioner and the Commission will take in this area, including at the cultural and educational level, will certainly find us willing to help and support these initiatives. I naturally hope that all Member States will be part of them.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At the outset, I would like to support what Mrs Costa said – we are here at this time, but let us move on to the substance. The aim of the Convention is to prevent, detect and combat the setting of the results of sporting competitions and the manipulation of sporting competitions. It calls on governments across Europe to take measures to prevent conflicts of interest between sports betting operators and sports organisers and to encourage sports betting regulators to step up the fight against fraud and illegal betting activities.  We appreciate the European Commission's commitment to the negotiation process and the proposal for the European Union to sign the Convention. Unfortunately, its entry into force has now been delayed. This is a very bad signal, especially as there is broad support from the Member States for the rapid entry into force of this Convention. Some countries are already ready to ratify it, but they cannot do so because of the EU's internal procedural issues and the political opposition of one Member State, which the President has already mentioned, Malta.  For more than 4 years, the European Commission has played a central role in the preparation and negotiation of this agreement. That is why it is now time to take political steps and decisions that will break this deadlock and lead to the entry into force of this Convention. Match-setting is a serious threat, it is a disease that destroys the integrity of the sport, seriously violates the values and trust of fans in their favorite teams or clubs. This problem affects many sports today, although in most cases this negative phenomenon specifically affects sports such as cricket, football or, as mentioned here, tennis.  The European Parliament has repeatedly emphasised its commitment to the fight against match-setting in online gambling resolutions (2009 and 2011), match-setting and corruption in sport (2013) and in resolutions on corruption in an organisation such as FIFA in 2015. In particular, Parliament stressed that the online gambling market 'is not a market like any other because of its risks in protecting consumers and combating organised crime'. That is why we have repeatedly called on sports organisations to take a zero-tolerance policy on corruption and to establish a 'common definition of corruption or sports fraud'. The Council of Europe Convention on combating the manipulation of sports competitions, which Parliament will of course support, is crucial in the fight against these problems.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, rigging matches is a real threat to sport, because it undermines values such as integrity, loyalty and respect for others and risks alienating fans and supporters from organised sporting activities. Rigged matches are often the preserve of organised crime operating on a global scale. This is a problem that has now become a priority for the sports movement and for law enforcement authorities around the world.  I very much welcome the fact that European funds have been allocated to public-private partnerships for the implementation of projects aimed at identifying risk factors for rigged matches and the development of tools for their management. I also very much welcome european regulations on online gambling and the creation of a European discussion platform for national gambling regulators, but that is not enough.  The European Union must play a greater role in the fight against match fixing. We have two organisations in Europe dealing with cross-border cooperation in the detection and prosecution of serious crimes: Europol and Eurojust. The Commission can call on these agencies to cooperate more closely with the sporting movement and pay more attention to match fixing. Member States should implement measures to prevent conflicts of interest between betting operators and sports organisations and to encourage sports betting regulators to step up the fight against fraud and illegal betting.  The European Parliament has on several occasions highlighted its commitment to match fixing, reiterating its full support for the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions, which is, in my view, the best instrument and legal framework for combating illegal sports betting at international level.  I think it is essential that the European Union and its Member States are involved in the establishment of a monitoring system and in the development of operational cooperation within the framework of the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions from the moment of its entry into force. I would remind you that Article 165 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union calls on the Union and the Member States to promote cooperation with international organisations in the field of sport, in particular with the Council of Europe. The European Union's action can make a decisive contribution to addressing the transnational challenges facing sport in Europe, such as match fixing, which require joint efforts and a coordinated approach.  One of the main objectives of the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions is to promote national and international cooperation. Chapter 3 of the Convention lays down a number of provisions to facilitate the exchange of information between all interested parties. The fight against rigged matches requires close cooperation between sports movements, governments, betting operators, law enforcement authorities and international organisations, and such a wide range of stakeholders is in itself a challenge. The European Union can help to create unity and ensure a more coordinated approach. The Member States are at different stages in the development of the fight against match fixing. The transnational nature of rigged matches is likely to involve cooperation between Member States with different levels of experience, creating the need for sharing good practice and developing skills. In this, the European Union plays an important role in capacity building as a catalyst for cooperation and ultimately as a support for the implementation of the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions.  There is broad support from the Member States for the rapid entry into force of the Convention, and some are ready to ratify it but have simply not been able to do so because of procedural issues all within the European Union. I would therefore like to ask the Commission what further steps it intends to take to break this deadlock and to allow Those Member States that have played a key role in the preparation of the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions to sign and ratify it as soon as possible.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Madam President, colleagues, let me begin by thanking the Committee on Culture and Education coordinators for putting together this oral question on illicit match-fixing. I regret that the Commissioner is not here to hear what we have to say this afternoon, and indeed that there are not more Members here. Perhaps a better time could have been found, because match-fixing poses a significant and worrying threat to sport, something that so many of us love.  For fans to follow their sport with a passion that we all want to see, it is necessary that they have the confidence and that any attempts to corrupt sport are cracked down on. They need to know the integrity of sport is there. The ECR are therefore supportive of the Council of Europe Convention and have a strong commitment to tackle match fixing. Match-fixing remains a black mark on sport with around EUR 12 million paid to players, referees, coaches or officials in order to influence matches in 2012 alone. In the last three months, 24 matches were deemed suspicious based on betting patterns across a variety of sports in Europe. Sport must remain inspirational and a showcase for the very best in human endeavours. we should therefore be doing all that we can to encourage Member States to combat match-fixing, but we should also be pushing for stronger cooperation and partnerships between the sports betting industry and sports governing bodies. It is our collective responsibility and one we must do together. But for this very reason the ECR has not been able to support this oral question because it singles out one nation. It dismisses the concerns of a nation that questions the legal clarity and definition of illegal sports betting. We must work together constructively between nations, between our public and private partners and at all levels within sport from the grassroots to the very top to protect the integrity of sport.

name: Yana TOOM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Madam President, I understand I have to speak as slowly as possible to give the Commissioner time to arrive at least by the end of the debate. So I will do my best. On behalf of the ALDE Group I would like to welcome this very important oral question regarding a serious integrity problem in sports. In modern English, match-fixing is normally understood as the act of arranging the outcome of a match even before it has been actually played. It is obvious that match-fixing is widespread internationally, and this problem also concerns illegal gambling and organised crime. Match-fixing is a way of undermining fair sport. It is also a great temptation for sportspersons and a great threat to those of them who have to resist pressure from criminals. Chris Eaton, director of sport integrity at the International Centre for Sport Security has said that football is in a disastrous state, with the fixing of matches for the purposes of criminal gambling and fraud absolutely endemic worldwide. It is a daily occurrence. However, this is a problem not only for football, but also for other sports as well. On the regional level, we would like to highlight the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions. We call all on all Member States to ratify it immediately, if they have not done so already. Furthermore, Member States should establish match-fixing as specific criminal offence and ensure that match-fixing and corruption in sport are subject to judicial proceedings. We would like also to stress the importance of data sharing between sports bodies, public authorities and licensed betting operators. It is essential to detect, investigate and prosecute all forms of match-fixing. Last but not least, we believe that it is hard to overestimate the importance of an awareness-raising campaign, which also may assist us to fight match-fixing. We are looking forward to receiving the Commission’s response to this question and a concrete proposal from the Commission on how match-fixing can be tackled efficiently in the Union.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we address this oral question to the Commission, and Mrs Costa and the colleagues in the Committee on Culture should be thanked for the initiative, without a doubt. It seems timely and necessary. We address it to the Commission, I say, but we could also address it to the Council and address it to each Member State, and surely address it to ourselves. Surely also some Member States more than others, and one in particular: Malta. We should therefore begin by somehow embarrassing ourselves a little collectively because this question still needs to be raised; because this oral question is necessary and relevant; because we are still pending ratification of the Convention. We know everything, we have the information, we have an alleged political agreement, we have the will expressed by everyone, but nothing happens and procedural issues or the known issue of opposition from a state are alleged. Both explanations seem completely unacceptable to stop collective ratification. And we also know that everything remains the same or worse, that the reality is the same as when this Parliament adopted a resolution in 2013 or when the Council of Europe adopted the Convention in 2014. One might wonder, in that regard, whether, for example, FIFA scandals are directly or indirectly related, near or far, to what we are talking about. Illegal sports betting is an increasingly secondary branch of organized crime and pollutes more and more sports, as has just been said. This issue—believe me—is a black hole in our collective responsibility. We have worked in tax evasion, we have worked on the investigation into Luxleaks and now on the roles of Panama, we prepare Directives on money laundering, and we also know that this activity, this business, this organized crime would be impossible without the necessary activity of financial institutions and telecommunication services that must provide the necessary means of payment to make it possible. It is time for us to go into it thoroughly, and I also believe that we should, in order to finish, add a dimension to it, which we have not talked about and which is certainly not part of the question and does not have to be, although perhaps this is an opportunity to consider it, which is the tax aspect associated with the sports betting sector. Do we know what turnover we're talking about? Shouldn't this European Union, this Commission, have an estimate of what this entails and the tax cost to the whole european Union resulting from the lack of regulation of the sector? Could we not include a first effort in the Commission's response, in the active response to estimate that turnover of online betting and the tax performance that each country and the whole of Europe should expect? So we could, perhaps, propose adequate tax treatment, which can only be raised, by the way, in the area, at the very least, of the European Union. I'm done, President. If we do not do all this, I am afraid that even if we were to achieve universal ratification of the Convention, everything would follow or could remain more or less the same. Yesterday we had the opportunity to congratulate Commissioner Vestager on her decision on the Apple case. The volume of tax evasion associated with the online betting industry and the movement of money resulting from it may probably exceed those in that case. We hope that the Commission's response to the question we are asking today will be the first effective step in the right direction.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry to see for the umpteenth time that there is a lack of real will for change and that, as always, everything tends to be delayed, even when it is the most necessary. Delaying the entry into force of the Council of Europe Convention on the manipulation of sporting competitions seems to me to be a missed opportunity to restore citizens' lost confidence in the world of sport, especially at a time when scandals are taking place almost daily in the vast majority of sports. About a year ago in this very Parliament, we in the 5-Star Movement denounced the scandal that has affected the world of football, in which, as you will recall, the leading representatives of the International Football Federation were involved. Even then, we called for a reversal of course, something that would bring the world of sport back to its real and basic vocation, that of aggregating, of uniting, of a return to the culture of sport, which embodied those values of equality, loyalty and social integration that are the basis of civil society. In recent years, the increased commercialisation of sporting events and their media exposure have fostered a substantial increase in economic interests, turning every sporting competition into a mere means of achieving ever greater profits. Criminal organisations, of course, have sniffed the possibility of profit and have begun to act, first at national level, then at transnational level, becoming, in fact, surveillance something extremely complex.  It can be inferred from the recent scandals that the efforts and measures carried out so far have not had the desired effect and the motivation is the lack of cooperation between the various countries. To avoid, like Don Quixote, continuing to fight against windmills, we need teamwork based on information sharing and best practices. I have been informed by the president of the Rugby Intergroup of a remarkable initiative: it is called Keep Rugby Onside and consists of an online information portal to educate and protect players, coaches, race officials from the dangers of betting and rigged matches. I therefore call on the Commission, when it arrives, to do everything in its power to overcome this impasse and to bring about the rapid entry into force of the Convention, which is the first real step towards greater cooperation in the fight against the manipulation of sporting competitions. I would like to point out that the failure to ratify international conventions by opposition of one or more Member States in the Council, in worthy cases such as this, is a real insult to the 500 million citizens we represent. Enormous pressure is being exerted in this House and enormous sacrifices are being demanded in the name of a general interest of the Union, but strangely enough when the interests in question are those of the citizens of Europe, this House is all too often silent. The deafening silence of many in the case of the shameful, for example, failure to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty is just one of many examples that is still being added to and repeated today with the Convention on Sports Manipulation.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, we have asked this question to tackle the fight against the manipulation of the results of sports matches, because we want to stop the abuse of sport for individual and organised illegal enrichment. This endangers sports competitions in which the best are to win.  Sport is not only fun, but it is an activity that is beneficial individually, but also socially. Corruption and manipulation of results harm sport by demotivate athletes, demotivate fans who may lose confidence and also lose their willingness to support the sport.  Manipulation of results is therefore a topical and poignant problem, and this is also linked to illegal betting practices that need to be countered. The need to cleanse sport of these ills, which go against the principle of sports ethics and break down the fundamental values on which sport is exposed, is therefore appropriate at the moment. The Council of Europe Convention on combating the manipulation of sports competitions is an appropriate tool to tackle these problems and to address them effectively. Match fixing is an international problem and it is therefore appropriate that we also address it at the level of the European Parliament. I very much welcome the work of the Commission and the possibility for the European Union to sign this Convention with the Council of Europe. I stress that most Member States have already expressed their support and the close entry of this convention into palatality is therefore ready. However, what is worrying is the situation in Malta's approach, which is preventing the process from ending so far.  I therefore strongly urge that the process of accession to the Convention should not be hampered, that steps be taken so that it is signed by the European Union as soon as possible and can be applied. I would like to say that, although the Commissioner is not here, I know of his personal interest and positive attitude towards sport, because he personally advocates the financing of sport for all and a number of beneficial sporting activities at EU level.  I have here a reminder of the action we had here in June in the European Parliament. It was an exhibition of the Golden Ball by Josef Masopust, who was a phenomenon of Czech football, a gentleman, a personality who always promoted fair play. I would therefore like to remind you today that we have such examples of fair play and these should be an example of how sport is to be carried out for the future.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Dear colleagues, I wanted to say 'honourable Commissioner', but I see that there is no Commissioner on the ground yet. In general, the practice of the Commissioner coming to the chamber in the middle of a discussion does not stand up to any criticism. In fact, this attitude towards the issues to be debated here in Parliament, I do not know... I can only ask a rhetorical question... or the Commissioner to spit simply on what the heart goes for.  On this subject, I can tell my fellow members that the business of making illegal and legal bets is tempted by many athletes and coaches not to engage in sports, but to engage in fraud with the results of a sporting competition and to make money with it. This process is extremely dangerous for many reasons. Firstly, fraud itself is a crime that results in materially suffering the population. Secondly, such action undermines public confidence in public institutions, as they cannot effectively prevent this type of crime. Thirdly, it discredits sport as such. One of the most important functions of sport is the propaganda of a healthy lifestyle, especially among young people, and if fraud reaches large volumes and sports competitions become chemists who invent new forms of doping, or the result of the competition becomes a commodity in itself, sport can be irreversibly discredited in the eyes of young people and its positive potential is greatly reduced.  The characteristic of such crimes is that they are usually of an international nature. That is why the European Union has a duty to engage in the fight against this type of crime. Without coordination or without a common approach, a significant result cannot be achieved. A good instrument has already been developed: the Council of Europe Convention against the Manipulation of Sport Competitions, to which the European Union could join.  The Convention provides for the introduction of certain standards at international level affecting national institutions, sports organisations and gambling operators, as well as the establishment of an international body for effective supervision. This document summarises international practice, based on world experience on how to combat such violations in sport, and also calls for criminal liability in national legal frameworks for more serious crimes. Unfortunately, the entry into force of the Convention has now been postponed. Many Countries of the European Union are prepared to ratify the Convention, but this process is hampered by the internal procedural issues of the European Union and by some differences in national positions.  I would like the European Commission to be more actively involved in this matter. Clearly, not everything depends on the Commission, because the Member States also play an important role in this process. But I would like to call for everything in the Commission's power to be done so that positive changes can still happen. And, dear Commissioner, if you are really holding back sittings in the European Parliament, perhaps it is worth thinking about how to leave this post, to dissuade if this work and this debate are not interesting to you.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, unfortunately the problem of match-fixing is widespread not only on our continent, but far beyond it. Along with doping, it ranks as one of the most serious problems of our time. According to Interpol data, only for the period of one year between June 2012 and May 2013 there was data on settled results in 70 countries, and only in the field of football. The International Football Association has presented evidence that organised crime earns over €13 billion from this type of activity and sees it as a safer alternative to the drug trade, prostitution and trafficking in human beings. According to Interpol, sports betting attracts around one trillion euros a year, with nearly three-quarters of that amount pledged to football. Although football and tennis are the most frequently affected sports, similar practices have unfortunately been observed in recent years in boxing, basketball, handball and volleyball. Settling sporting outcomes undermines confidence in sport and can seriously undermine sporting values.  I believe that the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions has the potential to become one of the important, if not one of the most important documents and instruments in this field. To this end, however, measures must be taken to sign and ratify it by the Member States. I believe that efforts must be made to overcome the existing obstacles to its ratification in order to effectively combat this harmful practice, not just to read declarations.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: "Mr. President, ever since the competition— there's been a result-fixing ever since. And especially the rigging of results since the betting started. But it started back in ancient times. So, match-fixing has been going on since the ancient Olympics. Since then, humanity has failed to solve this problem. And how are we going to solve it today, when there's so much money spinning in that dirty business? I'm not sure we're just going to work it out and maybe it'll take a few hundred or thousand more years.  Namely, today it is evident that we still have a number of scandals present in the sports that we all love. Of course each of us will mention football. I will never forget one game that was in 1982 between then West Germany and Austria when, by fixing the results of those two countries, those two teams, they actually agreed to prevent Algeria from going further in the world competition. A German fan burned the German flag, the Algerians threw money into the pitch and showed how they felt about such match-fixing.  It is already known at the US Open in tennis or the Australian Cup. One good example is known, the example of tennis player Novak Djokovic who, when offered money to set one tennis score, reported it to the tax authorities, reported it to the police and showed that there is also fair play in sports, that there are those who do not want money at all costs and that they are not bribeable and fortunately so in relation to these thieves we are fighting there is also a lot. However, let's not forget that the issue of match-fixing in various sports is from the top, as I said from national teams, from the Bundesliga, from the Premiership, from all the big leagues of world football to the smallest ones, to those little leagues that are played, so to speak, in certain small regions within the European Union or the world. There are score-fixing everywhere. Not to say that there have been horrific situations – it is known when three Lebanese referees were once convicted for asking for sexual favors for their match-fixing in football. There was that, too.  So, what I wanted to emphasize with this speech is that we have before us one great neman that will not be easy to contain and I am convinced that our message to young people and our message to the fans must be the same. We want to reduce this evil as much as possible, and of course the preconditions are the engagement of the European Commission, the engagement of the Member States, the signing of the Council of Europe Convention and the credibility in all this.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Go raibh maith agat a Uachtaráin, fáilte romhat, a Choimisinéir, déarfainn go raibh cuid de na feisirí beagáinín ródhian ort. Is féidir le gach duine a bheith déanach, agus gan dabht tá leithscéal maith agat. Ach, fáilte romhat. Tá a fhios agam go bhfuil fíorshuim agat i gcúrsaí spóirt agus sin é an rud is tábhachtaí. Gan dabht, freisin, bíonn caimiléireacht ag baint le gach gné de ghníomhaíochtaí an chine daonna, agus tá sé ag éirí níos measa de réir dealraimh, i gcúrsaí spóirt agus sin é an fáth go bhfuil an díospóireacht seo againn um thráthnóna agus go bhfuil gá rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi, más féidir linn. Madam President, the Lisbon Treaty has given us certain competences in sport, and we would like to put emphasis on promoting sport. Sports week is a good example of that, and I compliment the Commission and everyone involved in trying to promote it. But there is the downside, which we are discussing now, especially in relation to match-fixing. It came as a surprise to me, and maybe to my colleagues too, when we had the Sport Intergroup meeting here a couple of months back dealing with this issue, when tennis was seen as the game there was most afflicted by this.  In some respects it is not surprising because it is much easier to fix a match involving two people then involving 22, as would be the case in a soccer match. But the same time, there is a good image of tennis, and of course we must look at the reasons, and in some respects of course it is easier to fix it. If I was playing Jim Nicholson in tennis and he was clearly a better player than me, he could allow me to win and take a package. But of course he would not do that. But you can see the point I am making and for that reason, I think there is a need for rules, especially in relation to banning gambling on games you are involved in yourself, on games involving minors and on what I call in-play betting. All those things have to be looked at. There is also need for proper governance, and I think we should ask the forthcoming Maltese Presidency of the Council to try and look at this so that we can get the convention adopted. That would be a good help. We have to have, of course, codes of conduct, and we do not have to look much further than recently, when in the middle of the Olympics, rather strangely, referees were stood down by the boxing authorities. Now that is rather strange, but it just shows you again that there was a lot of controversy prior to that regarding the results. There are all sorts of opportunities, not necessarily to fix matches but certainly to give wrong results, etc. We have a huge task ahead to try and come to grips with it, but at least today we trying to have a debate here in the European Parliament and then we can progress from there under the guidance of the Commissioner, I also look forward to seeing the Maltese Presidency, especially, doing something about it.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, I think as a Member of this Parliament for 27 years that is the first time I have ever been told that I can have so much speaking time. Even though it is on a Thursday afternoon I certainly enjoy it.  We are all rightly proud of the achievements of our athletes from across the different sporting codes and disciplines. I was delighted to join the thousands of others from Northern Ireland recently to watch our national football team play in the European championships with great honour. It was also a great pleasure also to watch the Olympic success of Team GB this summer who were quite astonishing from my point of view.  However, all too often we see the bodies purportedly governing sports and others tarnish the integrity and reputation of their sport through various forms of corruption. I wish the newly-elected President of UEFA well, and I certainly hope his appointment sets football’s governing bodies back on the right direction after recent controversies.  Match-fixing, wherever it may be found, is a blight on our sporting communities, as has already been outlined here this afternoon. In Europe and across the world and at every level, action must be taken to root it out. For the sake of the future of sport, all corruption, including match-fixing, must be tackled in the strongest and most measured way possible. I am therefore supportive of the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions.  The Commission should take a consistent and fair approach to all Member States in relation to this. I also agree with colleagues that any review of this should call the Commission to embed such principles into the funding criteria for any programme related to sport. We should also note the good work that has been done in tackling this by the sporting bodies themselves. I certainly welcome the initiatives of the rugby world such as Keep Rugby Onside and the integrity programmes, which have been widely praised by authorities such as the UK’s Gambling Commission. I did not make the three minutes but I did my best to get there, but anything I have left I am sure Ms Tomašić can use up!

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr President, thank you, but I told my colleague that he can have my minutes because I am only going to speak for about 40 seconds, so we divided this up well!  Mr. President, match-fixing, from the lowest to the top league, especially in football, has been going on for decades. That's what's always been talked about. Someone reports it sometimes, there's an investigation, and in most cases it's all covered up. Why? Because those who make matches have protection in their governments. As far as I know, most GOVERNMENTS of EU Member States spend not too much time or money to promote sport and competitions as something healthy, fair, fair and to set a good example for young people.  If there was political will, match fixing mafia would break quickly, and the sport would return to where it belongs, and that is a healthy, fair, fair competition.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In a situation where we are dealing with the activities of international sports organisations and the organisation of major sporting events, we also come into contact with such events and situations where the sporting organisation, as one of the conditions for the holding of an event in a given country or the award of events to a given country, also presays a certain change in the domestic law of that country so that the law of the country concerned becomes a commodity, one of the goods that is offered. The conditions under which such an organisation can operate in a country are changing, and financial rules are also changing, sometimes granting unjustified financial privileges.  I would therefore like to point out this problem and ask for consideration to be given to whether the European Commission could not monitor such situations so that such unjustified dumping does not occur by, on the one hand, enforcing certain privileges in the host countries of sporting events and, secondly, by offering such dumped conditions.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me remind you about the history of the ratification of the Convention, which was declared open for signature in September 2014. The proposal for the signature by the EU of the Convention has been one of the priorities of the new Commission, and a matter of particular importance to me. On 2 March 2015 the Commission submitted a proposal for the signing of the Convention on behalf of the EU. This proposal took the form of two Council decisions, one with regard to matters related to substantive criminal law and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and one on other matters, such as cooperation between sports organisations, betting operators and state administrations. Under the Latvian and Luxembourg Presidencies in 2015, discussions took place within the Council on these proposals for signature. While the contents of the proposals were agreed at Coreper in November 2015, the proposals were blocked as the Council requested confirmation of a common accord by all Member States before proceeding to a vote. This allows one Member State to continue blocking the process. The Commission disagrees with this approach. The applicable procedure and voting is clear: the Treaty clearly stipulates qualified majority voting for this kind of Council decision. The Court of Justice has also confirmed in a recent judgment that the rules regarding the manner in which the EU institutions arrive at their decisions are laid down by the Treaties and are not at the disposal of the Member States or of the institutions themselves. However, this viewpoint was not shared during the discussions in Coreper in November 2014 when the Presidency refused to proceed to a vote. This is a question which the Council and the Presidency must find a solution to. Despite the efforts of the Dutch Presidency, they were unable to find a compromise which would enable a breakthrough.  The Commission regrets the current stalemate. The Commission is fully aware of the benefits of the Convention, and we would like it to enter into force as soon as possible. For the Convention to come into force, five signatories must ratify it and three of those five have to be Council of Europe Members. To date, there are two such ratifications. If there is no agreement in the Council, the Convention will enter into force without the EU and most EU Member States being on board. That would be a regrettable situation. Given the nature of the Convention, which links matters of national competence with EU competence, including exclusive EU competence, the Commission considers that a coordinated approach to the signature and ratification of the Convention by Member States remains necessary in accordance with the principle of sincere cooperation. The Commission adds its voice to the call by the honourable Member for all parties to continue to seek a solution. The Commission, for its part, will continue its efforts to convince all Member States to support the signature and ratification process. We will use all opportunities to underline the importance of EU participation in this Convention. We fully support the Convention as a valuable tool in the fight against match-fixing. For the states that choose to ratify it, it will be the first legally binding international tool to fight match-fixing – representing a solid basis for ensuring pan-European coordination and cooperation in the fight against match-fixing. The Commission needs your support in trying to find a breakthrough. I would like to thank you for the positive contributions you made during the debate. It is not an easy task to fight complex issues like match-fixing. The Convention is, indeed, an important tool but we must continue to look at match-fixing from all angles. In the Commission, colleagues dealing with sport, betting, organised crime and corruption will continue to work closely in this field. We will continue to finance projects to fight against match-fixing and to raise awareness about the problem. There is also an EU-funded pilot project which supports four major activities, including one preparing Member States for the entry into force of the Convention. We count on your support to help the Council find a way to overcome the current stalemate and enable the Member States and the EU to sign and ratify the Convention as soon as possible.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Tennis, football, basketball, boxing: so many sports are dirty by the mafias who organize match-fixing to get rich. Recently, Europol, the European police agency, revealed the existence of the largest investigation of all time into alleged match-fixing. He suspects a criminal network, based in Asia, with connections in Europe, of having rigged 380 football matches played between 2008 and 2011, across 15 countries.  Initially, most of the world's major criminal organizations have put their noses into sports betting, it is to launder money from drugs, arms sales or prostitution. The crime world knows that to make money clean, you have to agree to lose 30 to 40% of your dirty money. Laundering it through sports betting reduces the risk.  It is necessary for EU Member States to participate in the establishment of the monitoring system and the development of operational cooperation within the framework of the Convention as soon as it comes into force. For these reasons, for the spirit of sport, let us ratify and sign the texts to combat the scourge of rigged betting as soon as possible.
